Pleasure boating advertisers, once a group that could easily fit into a cabin cruiser, now need an ocean liner to accommodate them.

HAMILTON, N. Y., June 8 -Cornelius W. de Kiewiet, president of the University of Rochester, said today it was time to end "the degrading nonsense of describing and treating' our colleges and universities as charitable institutions entitled to casual kindness."

WASHINGTON, June 8 -The Treasury bill rate rose sharply this week, the Treasury disclosed tonight. The average yield on $1,200,000,000 o ninetyone-day bills was 3.283 per cent, compared with 3.149 per cent last week.

NO one can measure beauty like the woman who possesses it. Last week in a New York hotel, a small-boned woman with enormous blue eyes sipped tea and talked about some of the world's most memorable faces.
YONKERS, June 8 -- Four drivers escaped serious injury in a pile-up in the second race at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 8 -- About 40 per cent of all strokes arise from artery blockages in the neck or chest and not in the brain, a Texas research group reported here today.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -- Congress today gave the civilian space agency authority to spend $485,300,000 on space projects during the coming year.
BUENOS AIRES, June 8 -- Argentina ended today the diplomatic activities of the chief of the Bulgarian mission and accused him of sending clandestine radio messages abroad.

Six manufacturers of bedspreads have moved from their traditional location in the downtown Worth Street-Broadway area to the midtown district. Leases aggregating nearly $4,000,000 were signed for showrooms and offices in the streets bounded by Thirtieth to Thirty-fifth and Fifth to Madison Avenues.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The Post Office demonstrated pilotless airmail delivery today.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The Supreme Court upheld in broad terms today the power of Congress and state legislatures to investigate alleged subversion.

A reorganization of the fertilizer operations of the International Minerals and Chemical Corporation was announced yesterday by T. M. Ware, president. The phosphate and potash divisions have been consolidated into the agricultural chemicals division, which will direct sales of all fertilizer materials.
MONTICELLO, N. Y., June 8 (UPI) -- B'nai Zion, the American Fraternal Zionist Organization, elected as its new national president today Hyman J. Fliegel, New York attorney and lay religious leader.

Philippe of the Waldorf, who has organized meals for presidents, kings and thousands of other persons since 1931, is leaving the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel to head the new Zeckendorf Hotel, which is to be built on the Avenue of the Americas.
LONDON, June 9 -- The British advertising industry is paralleling the growth of the nation's economy.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, June 9 (Reuters) -- In spite of rising costs and a poor export market, thousands of hand looms in Turkey today are turning out carpets with better color, quality and design than ever before.
VIENNA, June 9 -- Dr. Leopold Figl, Austrian Foreign Minister, was unanimously elected president of the new National Assembly today.
BONN, Germany, June 9 -- Dr. Ludwig Erhard said tonight that he planned an open fight for the leadership of Dr. Konrad Adenauer's Christian Democratic Union.

DALLAS, June 9 -- A blistering attack on the alleged inefficiencies of building service employes' unions was made here today when the owners of the nation's office buildings were told that control of their operations had shifted to organized labor.
The Transit authority proposed yesterday a number of changes in bus service in Queens, Staten Island and Brooklyn.

Stocks moved uncertainly an uneven session of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday and ended with a net loss in market value of about $1,900,000,000 Since reaching a peak on June 1 market value has contracted about $13,300,000,000.

Directors of the California Bank of Los Angeles voted a 40 per cent stock dividend yesterday. The board also voted the regular quarterly cash dividend of 50 cents a share, which will be payable on the shares to be issued as a stock dividend.
Location -- West course, Winged Foot Golf Club, Mamaroneck, N. Y.
Mayor Wagner gave his approval yesterday to a formula for settling the hospital strike.
A trailer truck carrying $20,000 in merchandise was stolen on a Staten Island ferryboat yesterday at South Ferry. The kidnapped driver was found later handcuffed to a tree in Brooklyn.

The passing of C. C. Burlingham marks the end of an era. All of his contemporaries died many years ago and, at 100 years of age, he was very alone, clinging to the "younger" men who had loved and admired him. I was one of them.
Richard Widmark, who arrived here from Hollywood, Calif., yesterday, has been signed for one of the three leading roles in the forthcoming screen version of Helen MacInnes' novel, "North From Rome."
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- President Eisenhower said today that "compassion, consideration and justice" were the qualities needed to eliminate racial prejudice in this country.
Following is the text of the recommendations contained in a report made to Mayor Wagner yesterday by the special committee studying the strike in voluntary hospitals here:

Montgomery Ward Co., the nation's second largest mail order concern, showed a sharp increase in sales for the five and eighteen weeks ended on June. 3 as compared with the corresponding periods last year.

LONDON, June 9 (Reuters) -- After an eclipse of some 250 years, the seventeenth-century musical version of Shakespeare's "The Tempest" by John Dryden and Sir William Davenant, was successfully revived tonight at London's Old Vic Theatre.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI) -- The chairman of a House subcommittee denied today that a bill to remove the secrecy from Congressional expenses on overseas trips had been pigeonholed.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- An Indiana prosecutor testified today that he might have received hundreds of dollars worth of Christmas gifts from pinball gamblers without knowing from whom the gifts came.
Mayor Wagner commended members of the Building Service Employes International Union yesterday for their promotion of educational opportunities for youth.

Governor Rockefeller declared last night that the resources of local government as well as those of the state must be mobilized if New York was to meet challenges to its economic growth and "keep our state a good place in which to live."
Leaders of the three wings of American Judaism announced the election of Rabbi Max David Davidson yesterday as president of the Synagogue Council of America for a two-year term.
SADDLE RIVER, N. J., June 9 -- The Mayor and council will hold a public hearing Monday night on an amended zoning ordinance governing the establishment of private or parochial schools here.
Steel union leaders prepared yesterday to start hunting for soft spots in the industry's wage front as a means of heading off a national steel strike June 30.
The Health Department removed five suspected polio cases from its records yesterday and announced that no cases of the disease had occurred here this year.
YONKERS, June 9 -- Sara Black, 1 -- 5, won the first race at Yonkers Raceway tonight as all 1-5 favorites should -- as she pleased.
Now that the railroads' freight business is on the right track, Congress, the railroads and shippers are beginning to fear that harvest-time scarecrow, the freight car shortage.
BASKING RIDGE, N. J., June 9 -- A milkman who is also a volunteer fireman was credited this morning with saving the lives of six persons.
GENEVA, June 9 -- The United States workers' delegate urged the International Labor Organization today to "rededicate itself to the cause of freedom and justice everywhere."

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Senate Democratic leadership opened a heavy counterattack today against the Republican campaign to depict the big Democratic majorities in Congress as "do-nothing budget busters."

TIRGU-MURES, Rumania, May 26 -- Tucked away behind the great northward bend of the Carpathian Mountains is a unique area of Rumania, whose inhabitants claim descent from the fifth-century Hunnish warriors of Attila.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The possibility of establishing a joint embassy in Washington for three West European economic organizations was discussed by the heads of the three institutions here today.

COLUMBUS, Ga., June 9 (AP) -- The Rev. Robert B. McNeill, who was removed from his pulpit here, said last night that national publicity over his dismissal had resulted in tentative offers from several other Presbyterian churches. He declined to give details.

AT the stroke of 11 yesterday morning the State Athletic Commission was supposed to supervise the signing of the articles of war by Floyd Patterson and Ingemar Johansson for their heavyweight championship bout at the Yankee Stadium on June 25.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI) -- J. Edgar Hoover said today that crime costs every American $128 a year. The director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation called for a rededication to "love, fair play and fellowship" to cut the expense.

The Apostolic Delegate to the United States yesterday told the graduating class at Manhattan College that a vigorous Catholic education was an "absolute necessity" to sustaining the Catholic church in the United States.

NEW DELHI, India, June 9 (Reuters) -- Representatives of India, Pakistan and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development will meet in London early in August to work out the main points of a treaty dealing with the distribution of the Indus basin waters, it was announced here today.
Street fighting started at Fifth Avenue and 103d Street yesterday after striking hospital workers tried to crash an academic procession of the New York Medical College.

NOW that I have finished the last page of "Tempo di Roma,"* a strange and beautiful novel by Alexis Curvers, I wonder what it is all about. It certainly isn't about real people, their emotions and problems and what happens to them in a particular set of circumstances. It has no general theme, as many novels have, such as the miseries of love, the horrors of war or the tempests of adolescence.

The world heavyweight champion Floyd Patterson, and Sweden's challenger, Ingemar Johansson, signed formal contracts yesterday at the New York State Athletic Commission offices. They are scheduled to fight on June 25 at Yankee Stadium.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 9 -- Three players in the field of eighty-seven tied for the medal after the first round of qualifying play in the forty-third Eastern interscholastic golf championship today.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, has been appointed United states representative on the North Atlantic Studies Committee.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L. I., June 9 -- An Air Force jet pilot was picked up by helicopter from a tiny rubber life raft in the Atlantic Ocean at dawn today, seven hours and forty minutes after ditching his burning plane off Southampton.

The highway smash-up in Arizona that took the lives of sixteen migratory farm workers from Mexico and injured thirty-two others, some critically, seems an unmitigated tragedy. But perhaps it will shock the public into realization of the desperate need of better protection for migrant farmhands, foreign and native, not only in their transportation but in their living and working conditions.

Sam Giammalva of Houston has been added to the list of players who will compete in Jack Kramer's $15,000 tournament of champions. The tournament will be held at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens, June 21 to 28.

GROTON, Conn., June 9 -- The nation's first ballistic-missile submarine -- the George Washington -- was launched here today with the prayerful hope of President Eisenhower that she would "be always ready but never used."
CHICAGO, June 9 -- The United Rubber Workers executive board completed today a policy committee agenda that will provide ammunition for wage negotiations with the industry this summer.

Queens detectives yesterday named Camello Cocchiaro, 24 years old, of 24-38 Eighty-sixth Street, Jackson Heights, as the unknown gunman in a photograph taken by Joseph Sylvester, now in Queens County jail charged with robbery.

NEWARK, N. J., June 9 -Robert Gardner of Essex County and Frank Kaminski of Forsgate were the medal winners today in sectional qualifying for the New Jersey Golf Association's fifty-eighth annual amateur championship.

TOKYO, June 9 (AP) -- Japan closed its 1958 fiscal year on March 31 with a $510,000,000 surplus in its foreign trade. This compared with a $530,000,000 deficit in the preceding year. The Ministry of International Trade and Industry also reported in White Paper today that Japan's foreign exchange reserves had reached a five-year high at $970,000,000 when the fiscal year ended.
LIMA, Peru, June 9 -- An Opposition leader just paroled from prison has called for the resignation of President Manuel Prado y Ugarteche and the establishment of a "transition government."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 9 -- The traveler returning to his own native shore is impressed by the vigor of self-criticism now apparent on the American scene. This questioning of present habits and policies is by no means limited to private individuals or confined to members of a single political faction.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 9 -- President Eisenhower ruled out state-aided medicine today and in return asked the support of the American medical, profession to help him balance the Federal budget.

One of George Washington's first salary payments as President was met through a loan from the Bank of New York. Albert C. Simmonds Jr., chairman, recalled this fact yesterday in marking the 175th anniversary of the city's oldest bank. The bank was founded in 1784.
Grand Central Terminal was busy as a bee hive last night -- with real bees, 10,000 to 15,000 of them.

RYE, N. Y., June 9 -- The casualty list in the twenty-eighth Manursing Island Club Eastern interscholastic tennis championship swelled today. Four more seeded players were upset, bringing the two-day total to five.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Nine European maritime nations have proposed at a conference being held here that the State Department establish a permanent liaison committee through which they could transmit grievances about American merchant marine policies.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The House Democratic leader on the school construction issue offered today to sit down with his Republican opposite number "to work out a compromise and see if the President will sign it."

A Canadian Nobel Peace Prize-winner warned last night that European unity plans might cause "a retreat to continentalism" both in Europe and North America unless extended into a real Atlantic community.
BALTIMORE, June 9 (AP) -- Gene Woodling and Chico Carrasquel slammed two-run homers tonight in leading Baltimore to a 7-3 victory over the Cleveland Indians.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., June 9 -- Air Force leaders are reported fearful that the recent series of five Atlas failures may force postponement of plans to declare the intercontinental ballistic missile ready for combat next month.

Marcus M. Chapman Howard J. Mullin The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday the appointment of Marcus N. Chapman as an administrative vice president-commercial. The appointment of Howard J. Mullin to succeed Mr. Chapman as vice president-sales also was announced.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Senate staged a preliminary skirmish today on the Administration's proposals to raise the national debt limit and to abolish the interest ceilings on Federal bonds.
Community spokesmen yesterday urged the Bureau of Franchises to reroute Fifth Avenue Coach Company buses around Washington Arch when Washington Square Park is closed to all but emergency traffic.

The Claiborne Stable's Dunce qualified at Belmont Park yesterday. In taking a mile-and-a-sixteenth event easily in the role of odds-on favorite, the 3-year-old son of Tom Fool convinced his trainer, Moody Jolley, that he was ready for the Belmont Stakes on Saturday.
Insurgents attacked as "unfair and illegal" yesterday proposed new regulations by the Board of Elections for listing candidates on voting machines in the Sept. 15 primary.
Blood will be given to the New York regional Red Cross blood program today at the Bell iTelephone Laboratories, Inc., 468 West Street, and the New York Telephone Company, 18 Boerum Street, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The House Republican Policy Committee split with the Eisenhower Administration today as it formally endorsed a broad states' rights bill aimed at curbing the power of the Supreme Court.

HATTERAS, N. C., June 9 -- North Carolina and Puerto Rico ran a dead heat in the Great Blue Marlin Politeness Derby, which ended here yesterday and perhaps revolutionized fishing contests in one stroke.
YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N. Y., June 9 -- Voters here tonight approved three propositions to spend a total of $4,547,198 for school expansion.
CHICAGO, June 9 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

The yields to investors on commercial paper sold by dealers in the open market were increased one-eighth of one percentage point yesterday. Commercial paper is the unsecured promissory notes of business concerns.

LENINGRAD, June 7 -- A single figure in black tights postures under the white glare of a spotlight on a naked stage. Not a word is spoken, but every movement of the body projects the unrelieved despair of a lonely man committed to walk the gray and endless corridor of the present era.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI) -- The House brushed aside threats of a Presidential veto today and voted to double Federal outlays for water pollution control.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced yesterday proposed changes in corporate reporting requirements that apparently were designed to deter predatory "take-over" of corporate control or management.

A CRISPLY played and highly polished little entertainment called "The Billy Barnes Revue" arrived at the York Theatre on First Avenue last night. Fresh from California, it is one of those singing revues in which everything is set to music and lyrics, and hardly an ordinary exchange of dialogue takes place.

MOSCOW, June 9 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev and East German leaders were reported today to have reached "complete unanimity of views" on the questions of Germany and West Berlin now before the East-West conference in Geneva.

ST. LOUIS, June 9 (UPI) -The St. Louis Cardinals battered their long-time mound nemesis, Warren Spahn, and four Milwaukee relief pitchers for sixteen hits and scored a 12-3 victory over the Braves tonight.

LONDON, June 9 -- The Atlantic Congress decisively rejected today a proposal by a French delegate to convert the regional defense objectives of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization into a global military strategy.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI) -- The Government rested its case in the ten-week-old Miami television conspiracy trial today. Federal Judge Burnita S. Matthews turned down a defense motion for a directed acquittal.
NEWARK, June 9 -- The interim 20 per cent increase in intrastate commuter fares won last week by the Central Railroad of New Jersey could be a financial boomerang.

Gordon I. Kyle, a real estate appraiser, was elected president of the Real Estate Board of New York last night. He succeeds Robert S. Curtiss, director of real estate of the Port of New York Authority, who has served three one-year terms.
Events today: John Cartwright, organist, St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Chapel, Broadway and Fulton Street, 12:30 P. M.; Chase Manhattan Choral Club, Town Hall, 8:30.

Stockholders of the Standard Coil Porducts Company, Inc., elected John P. Hoffmann to the board of directors at the annual meeting in Chicago yesterday. Mr. Hoffmann is a vice president of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago. He succeeds Glen E. Swanson, retired president of the company, who was not a candidate for reelection.

HAVANA, June 9 -- Cuban landowners were reminded by Premier Fidel Castro today that under his Agrarian Reform Law they must deliver copies of their titles and full information concerning their farms, plantations and ranches within ninety days. Failure to do so will result in confiscation of the lands, he noted.
LOWER BURRELL, Pa., June 9 (AP) -- Three young construction workers drowned today in a chain-reaction rescue attempt at the bottom of a twenty-five-foot deep manhole.
LOS ANGELES, June 9 -- An increase of about 10 per cent in the capital stock of the Security First National Bank will be proposed to shareholders at a meeting on Aug. 6.
LONDON, June 9 (Reuters) -- Parliament will be asked to referee the fight in Britain between the opponents and supporters of boxing.
Yesterday was the hottest, most uncomfortable day of the year so far. If anyone had reason to doubt it, the Weather Bureau was ready with evidence.
Initial plans are being made for the Britannia Ball, which will take place in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on Nov. 4.

OTTAWA, June 9 -- Eight of the United States vessels are to act with eight Canadian naval ships as escort for the Royal yacht Britannia, which will carry Queen Elizabeth II and President Eisenhower at the formal opening of the Seaway on June 26.

The American Civil Liberties Union said yesterday it would continue its efforts to end the House Committee on Un-American Activities. The power of the House panel to investigate subversion was upheld Monday by the Supreme Court.
MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 9 -- The United States Open golf championship will be played outside Claude Harmon's door.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Pan American Sanitary Bureau announced today that fifty specialists from twenty countries would confer on live polio vaccine at Georgetown University here June 22 through 26.

Plans for a twenty-story cooperative apartment building for limited-income families, on York Avenue between Eighty-first and Eighty-second Streets, were submitted yesterday to the City Planning Commission. The city-aided development would cost $4,500,000.

The downtown district office of the Bureau of Old-Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance of the Social Security Administration will hold open house from 2 to 4 P. M. today in its headquarters at 75 Barclay Street.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, said today that he and President Eisenhower had no real differences on labor-reform legislation. However, the distinctions between their positions appeared great.
On 4 hours 10 minutes of steamy effort, the Yankees regained the .500 mark and attained joint tenancy of the American League's first division last night.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- The House today passed a hill to appropriate $1,177;177,000 to finance Federal public works programs during the twelve months beginning July 1.

The four-story building containing thirty apartments at 118-16 Ninety-first Avenue, Richmond Hill, Queens, has been sold by Harry Ihlenburg to a client of Norman Katz of Ossip Associates Inc., broker in the deal. The sale was for cash over a first mortgage of $115,000.

Commencement exercises were held last evening for 152 graduates of the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion. Ten graduates received Master of Arts degrees in Hebrew letters and were ordained as rabbis.

The report of the Mayor's committee on the strike in voluntary, nonprofit hospitals made public in midafternoon yesterday deserves leisurely, careful consideration by the hospital trustees. William H. Davis, the chairman of the committee, is a veteran of long experience in labor relations problems. He had the help of fellow members Aaron Horvitz and Joseph P. McMurray.
A Brooklyn woman was killed yesterday when she was hit by a car that jumped a curb following a collision and pinned her against a wall.
ST. LOUIS, June 9 (AP) -St. Louis Stereotypers Union Local 8 struck The Post-Dispatch at midnight tonight, forcing both the Post-Dispatch and the Globe-Democrat to suspend publication.

The Cuban Agrarian Reform Law has now been promulgated and consequently must be accepted as substantially definitive. It is a drastic law which expropriates much land, some of it American owned, but Cuban landowners will be the greatest sufferers.
A "guest" at the 1957 crime convention in Apalachin, N. Y., told the State Investigation Commission yesterday that he had thought the affair was a buffet luncheon.
An antitrust indictment was returned yesterday by a Federal grand jury here against the Auto Glass Dealers Association, Inc., and three individuals.

Rex Harrison, whose portrait of the fastidious English professor, Henry Higgins, in "My Fair Lady," is still verdant in the minds of theatregoers, is returning to Broadway next season in the part of a quixotic French general.

Northern Illinois Gas Company expects to be able to clean up its backlog of applications for residential home heating in time for next winter, Marvin Chandler, president, told yesterday's annual meeting at Aurora, Ill.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 9 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold established an interdepartment board today to act as a clearing house for United Nations efforts to assist under-developed countries. Mr. Hammarskjold assumed the chairmanship himself to underscore the importance he attaches to the work.

BALTIMORE, June 9 (AP) -- Joanne Goodwin, 23-year-old daughter of a Massachusetts golf pro, took a four-stroke lead in the opening round of the Fifty-third Women's Eastern amateur tournament today with a 74.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 9 -- A Lutheran minister who helped thousands of political refugees leave Communist China complained today that the refugee problem in Asia was not getting the attention it deserved.

BECKENHAM, England, June 9 (AP) -- Alex Olmedo and Barry MacKay, the two top United States contenders for the Wimbledon tennis championships later this month, won easy tune-up matches today in the Kent tournament.
A former city Commissioner of Investigation demanded to know yesterday if city employe organizations were suspected of paying graft to city officials.
Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack strolled across Thirty-sixth and Thirty-seventh Streets yesterday and announced afterward that he was more convinced than ever that they should be widened.
GENEVA, June 9 -- The Soviet Union appeared today to be moving toward acceptance of international staffing of control posts for policing a ban on nuclear weapons tests, according to Western sources.
LIKE beautiful women and the New York skyline, pretty gardens seem even prettier by night.
Complaints by neighbors of Louis Seeley, a retired shiprigger, caused him to give up his hobby of keeping about 50,000 bees in an East Harlem attic.

" SERVE it buffet." This seems to be the catchword for relaxed, enjoyable entertaining on a summer week-end. Several efficient hostesses, queried on how they cope with meals for family and guests, agreed that help-yourself menus were invaluable timesavers. They recommend, too, a repertoire of dishes that can be made in advance.
A request to exempt Port Newark and the Elizabeth pier development from Interstate Commerce Commission trucking rate regulation was made here yesterday by the Port of New York Authority.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, June 9 -- Prime Minister S. W. R. D. Bandaranaike's three - year - old coalition ended today. He tendered his Government's resignation to Governor General Sir Oliver Goonetilleke.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The State Department has advised inquiring Representatives and Senators on Capitol Hill that it is opposed to granting them passports to visit Communist China.

Between 1870 and 1878, Gideon Welles, Secretary of the Navy in President Lincoln's Cabinet, wrote a group of articles to correct "mistaken notions" about the Lincoln Administration. They appeared in The Galaxy and The Atlantic Monthly.

LIMA, Peru, June 9 -- The National Symphony Orchestra of Washington, under the direction of Howard Mitchell, received standing ovations at sold-out concerts in Lima's Municipal Theatre last night and Sunday night.

AKRON, Ohio, June 9 (AP) -- A fifty-five-day strike of the United Rubber Workers against the B. F. Goodrich Company ended today. Maintenance men began preparing the big plants here to resume production.

The Board of Estimate will vote on June 11 on Borough President Hulan Jack's proposal to widen Thirty-sixth and Thirty-seventh Streets between Third and Eleventh Avenues. It is to be hoped that the members of the board will see fit to amend or vote down this proposal.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI) -- Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower will accompany Vice President Richard M. Nixon on his trip to Moscow next month, the White House announced today.
HOUSTON, Tex., June 9 -- The Houston school board voted today in favor of letting the voters decide whether the city's public schools should be integrated.

NAPLES, Italy, June 9 (Reuters) -- More than fifty farmers' wives stormed into a potato-packing plant at Cimitile near her today, wielding pitchforks in an attack on twenty women. It was the second straight day of riots over low potato prices.

GENEVA. June 9 -- A West German official with nothing else to do this afternoon went through the record of the semi-public plenary sessions of the foreign ministers' conference to see who was outtalking whom.
PARIS, June 9 (AP) -- Bernard Buffet, one of France's most successful young painters, has asked a Paris court to keep the owner of a Buffet - decorated refrigerator from selling it in pieces.
The second 1959 All-Star game, on Monday, Aug. 3, in the Coliseum at Los Angeles, will start "in the late afternoon," Ford Frick, baseball's commissioner, said yesterday.

No one can read the current monthly review of the New York Federal Reserve Bank, it seems to us, without coming away with the conclusion that the present recovery has now reached the stage where those who stand for economic expansion without a resurgence of inflation should take their places squarely behind the Administration's objective of a balanced budget in 1960.
ROME, June 9 -- Christian Democratic leaders started consultations today on the chances of "reabsorbing" a successful party rebellion in Sicily.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- The Navy said today that it would go ahead with plans to send a flotilla of twenty-eight ships through the St. Lawrence Seaway despite Canadian fears the warships might cause a traffic jam.
COLOGNE, West Germany, June 9 (Reuters) -- Wholesale and retail organizations from eight European countries have formed an association to facilitate international trade and exchange ideas.
The Columbia Broadcasting System plans to present daily television coverage of next year's Olympic Games in Rome by means of video tape recordings flown here from the Italian capital.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 9 -- A Chamber of Deputies committee is holding weekly hearings in an attempt to find a satisfactory plan for rescuing Brazil's competitive airlines.
OBERLIN, Ohio, June 9 -Seven honorary degrees were conferred at the 126th Oberlin College commencement exercises yesterday.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court reserved decision yesterday on an application by a majority group of stockholders in the H. L. Green Company, Inc., to vacate a restraining order barring a stockholders' meeting which originally was scheduled for last May 27.
Health Department inspectors completed a tour of dry-cleaning establishments yesterday in a campaign to reduce deaths caused by plastic bags.
NEWARK, June 9 -- Two men were in custody today on charges of attempting to extort $3,000 from a former Havana policeman by threatening the lives of his brothers in Cuba.

LAST night, while other New York designers were recovering from the day's grind on Seventh Avenue, Arnold Scaasi presented his wholesale collection for fall in a magnificent mansion uptown. The strictly black-tie affair began at 8 P. M. and was followed by a midnight supper.
Mayor Wagner's $90,000,000-a-year package of five nuisance taxes for 1959-60 was stalled last night at a late session of the City Council.
Twenty-nine firemen and nine other persons suffered injuries and heat exhaustion yesterday when two fires raged in downtown Manhattan and Brooklyn at the height of the year's record temperature.

Three privately held enterprises founded by the late Hans Knoll have been acquired by the Art Metal Construction Company, it was announced yesterday. Andrew Wilson, chairman of Art Metal, said that his company had purchased for an undisclosed amount of cash all the assets of Knoll Associates, Inc.; Knoll International, Ltd., and Knoll Textiles, Inc.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Senate-House conferees agreed today on the complicated life insurance taxation bill, aimed at raising $500,000,000 in revenue for the Government on 1958 income and more in future years.
The Duke Power Company, Charlotte, N. C., raised $25,104,750 in the public market yesterday through the sale of 250,000 shares of $100 par value preferred stock carrying a 5.36 per cent dividend.
Earl Warren, Chief Justice of the United States, will be the principal speaker this morning at New York University's 127th annual commencement.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, June 9 -- President Mario Echandi Jimenez declared today that he would rather step down from office than abandon Costa Rica's neutrality in the Nicaraguan revolt.

The identity of one of a group that is interested in financing New York's entry in the proposed third major league was learned yesterday. She is Mrs. Charles Shipman Payson, sister of John Hay (Jock) Whitney, ambassador to Britain.

The appointment of William G. Rabe as general chairman of this year's fund campaign of the Travelers Aid Society of New York was announced yesterday. He is a director of the organization and a director and chairman of the trust committee of the Manufacturers Trust Company.

Dr. Wernher von Braun, director of development operations for the Army Ballistic Missile Agency, warned yesterday against American complacency in competing with Russian rocketry and missile developments.
PHOENIX, Ariz., June 9 (AP) -- A jury of nine men and three women today found Elliott Roosevelt not guilty on a charge of drunken driving.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Senate debate on the 'nomination of Lewis L. Strauss to be Secretary of Commerce turned bitter and personal today as opponents and proponents charged one another with "harassment'' and "inaccuracies."

LONDON, June 9 -- Industrials again accounted for another long list of losses in the stock market here today. However, the selling slackened in later dealings and many losses were cut as bargain hunters moved in.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 9 (UPI) -- Arkansas' Secretary of State, C. G. Hall, said today it was rather "coincidental" that some one had tried to burn down his home less than twenty-four hours after he had criticized the Ku Klux Klan.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 9 -- Modern American medicine may have something to learn from the centuries-old European spas, it was suggested here today at the American Medical Association's scientific session.
The Waterfront Commission acted yesterday to stifle a type of individual initiative it said it had uncovered on the Hoboken piers.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Puerto Rico's status as a commonwealth raised a constitutional question in Congress today.

CHICAGO, June 9 (AP) -- Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in Chicago and Miami Beach seized six men today on charges that they defrauded some 800 convention visitors in Chicago of at least $240,000 by raising checks.
The city's public high schools have won the top three team and individual events in a nationwide mathematics competition, the Board of Education announced yesterday.
Following is the text of President Eisenhower's speech last night at the American Medical Association's convention in Atlantic City, as recorded by The New York Times:

The near-by July, September, October and July, 1960, world sugar positions fell to new lows for the life of the contracts yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Trading was influenced by lower prices for actuals. The spot quotations declined 2 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) to 2.82 cents.

LONDON, June 9 -- The Times of London has caustically rejected criticism of its report that Prime Minister Harold Macmillan was considering transferring Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd to another post.

The American fashion trend for the fall and winter is now being shaped, as Seventh Avenue designers unveil their collections to the press and to store buyers. The showings now are the American equivalent of the Paris fashion openings in July. The clothes will be in the stores by late summer.
The United Hospital Fund exercised its long-unused voting control power yesterday to assert its right of parentage over the Associated Hospital Service (Blue Cross).

CHICAGO, June 9 -- Brokers have known for a long time that women play a major role in the world of finance, but a survey published today by the Midwest Stock Exchange showed just how tight their hold on the purse strings really was.

In your editorial of June 4 entitled "Treasury Interest Rate" you characterize concern about Government paying more than 4 1/4 per cent in interest on long-term Governments "more sentimental than rational." The whole burden of your editorial is that the interest rate does and should rise and fall in response to free market forces.
DES MOINES, Iowa, June 9 (AP) -- The Rev. Dr. Herbert J. Gezork of Newton Center, Mass., was elected president of the American Baptist Convention today.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI) -- The Air Force assured a House subcommittee today that it had taken "vigorous action" to prevent the conditions associated with $30,000,000 in alleged overpricing on its plane contracts.

PARIS, June 9 -- The expected withdrawal of United States warplanes from France is a symptom of a basic, perplexing difficulty in the relations between Washington and Paris for which no solution is in sight. This is a complex and fundamental conflict of interests and aspirations in the field of nu clear armaments.
The State of Maryland borrowed $10,467,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance school construction, improvements of the Maryland Port Authority and other public improvements.
Fordham University will award 1,427 baccalaureate and graduate degrees today at its 114th commencement exercises on the Rose Hill campus.

Johnny Thomson of Boyertown, Pa., third at Indianapolis and first at Milwaukee in the Lathrop-Glover Special, heads a field of twenty-one big car drivers scheduled to race Sunday on the fast one-mile dirt circle at Langhorne, Pa.
ALBANY, June 9 (AP) -An actress who refuses all jobs except theatrical roles is not eligible for unemployment compensation, the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court held today.
Eleven hundred and seventy-five travelers to the Mediterranean were left to their own devices last night aboard a strike-bound ship here.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Defense Department gave President Eisenhower today a long-waited master air defense plan calling for a combination of Army and Air Force missiles to protect against air attack.

PARIS, June 9 -- The Government was pressed today to establish complete political unity between Algeria and France and to wipe out "defeatists" in France who sought a political settlement with the Algerian rebels.
FRONT ROYAL, Va., June 9 -- Gov. J. Lindsay Almond Jr. tonight urged support of public education wherever possible despite the state's integration problem.

Paperboard production fell to 295,007 tons in the week ended June 6 from a record 326,467 in the preceding week, the National Paperboard Association reported. The sharp decline in production was attributed to the Memorial Day holiday on the previous Saturday, which was the first reporting day for the current week's figures.
General Mills, Inc., has selected Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., to handle six new Betty Crocker dessert mix products, effective immediately.

The 1959 Loeb awards for business and financial reporting were presented yesterday to Nate White of The Christian Science Monitor and to Ernest Havemann of Life magazine. Mr. White, business and financial editor of the Monitor, won $1,000 and a bronze plaque for a series of articles on problems of recession and recovery.

The New York chapters of the Physicians Forum would like to commend the two Mount Sinai social workers who were recently dismissed because they refused to return to work until the current hospital strike was settled.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The State Department's right to prohibit travel by Americans in Communist China was upheld today by the United States Court of Appeals here.

A professor of philosophy warned both humanists and scientists yesterday against "snobbish traditionalism," which he said sometimes made both groups "intolerant of things they don't know very much about."

It might be suggested that ever since Eve consented to the second temptation, and discarded the primal fig leaf in favor of something more chic -- a eucalyptus, perhaps, or whatever they were wearing that season -- her progeny has suffered such molting with whimsical regularity.

First-quarter net earnings of United Artists Corporation increased 12 per cent to $712,000 from $636,000 in the initial three months last year. Robert S. Benjamin, chairman, reported the results to stockholders at the annual meeting held here yesterday in the Astor Theatre.
GENEVA, June 9 -- The Western foreign ministers informed Andrei A. Gromyko today that there was little use in continuing the discussions here unless the Soviet Foreign Minister modified his position.
The bond market moved upward again yesterday.
SAN DIEGO, June 10 -- A proposal to use a Centaur rocket to put in orbit a four-room space trainer was announced today by Convair-Astronautics.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 10 -- In closing sessions of its three-day annual convention today, the Advertising Federation of America elected James S. Fish chairman and heard John J. Ryan, New York State Assemblyman, review governmental attacks on advertising.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., June 10 -- Dr. Wernher von Braun, the rocket expert, said today that it would be "an almost hopeless task" to protect the entire nation against attack by ballistic missiles.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The Liberian Government protested today its exclusion from a ten-nation conference on United States maritime policies.

Two Panamanian loan associations, one of which allegedly attempted to induce potential New York investors to purchase shares in it with the avowed purpose of evading taxes, were ordered yesterday to produce their books and records in Supreme Court next month.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today forecast this year's wheat crop at 1,181,596,000 bushels. This is 19 per cent less than last year's record crop, but 10 per cent above average. A crop of this size would add to a burdensome surplus of the grain, but nothing like the excess produced last year.
Workmen in the New York Coliseum yesterday began uncrating the exhibits for the Soviet scientific, technological and cultural show that will open June 30.
A tenement owned by a Harlem religious leader was ordered evacuated yesterday by the Fire Department because of hazardous conditions.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The House took up today a wheat bill that was as welcome as the surplus its sponsors said it would help eliminate.
The steel industry hinted yesterday that it might reconsider its insistence on a one-year wage freeze in return for specific union contract concessions.

The contrast between two important contempt decisions this week in the Supreme Court and those decided two years ago is bound to leave the layman puzzled. The earlier opinions, upsetting convictions for contempt of the House Un-American Activities Committee and a New Hampshire investigating body, were filled with language about constitutional limitations on investigators' excesses.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 10 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold plans to go to Cairo at the end of June to try to settle a dispute between Israel and the United Arab Republic, which has refused to allow Israeli cargoes to go through the Suez Canal.

ST. LOUIS, June 10 (AP) -- Lindy McDaniel pitched four scoreless innings in relief and the St. Louis Cardinals benefited from three unearned runs as they defeated the Milwaukee Braves tonight, 5 -- 2. The loss whittled the Braves' National League lead to one game over San Francisco.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (UPI) -- Early Wynn turned in his eighth victory of the season with a five-hitter tonight that paced the Chicago White Sox to a 4-1 triumph over the Washington Senators.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- A group of American song writers suggested today they get a share of about 5 cents a day a machine from the $500,000,000-a-year juke-box business.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 10 -- A United Nations working group recommended today a practical approach to legal problems of outer space. It declared that so little was known about outer space that "premature codification might prejudice subsequent efforts to develop the law based on a more complete understanding of the practical problems involved."

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Ralph Bellamy, the actor, told Congress today that television in this country was "at the mercy of advertising agencies, sponsors, and various kinds of ratings with a questionable ant not a proven value."

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 10 -- President Juscelino Kubitschek decided tonight to seek United States financial aid, bypassing the International Monetary Fund. The fund has insisted on greater austerity of his Administration.
MORRISTOWN, N. J., June 10 (AP) -- Robert Conahay 3d, an advertising executive, has purchased the late Clendenin J. Ryan's ranch at Allamuchy for a price "in excess of $200,000."

New York City's public schools, by sweeping the top three team and individual events in a nation-wide mathematics competition, have provided convincing testimony to the quality of their students and of their instruction. In this contest, sponsored by the Mathematical Association of America and the Society of Actuaries, 114,297 students in 4,166 secondary schools in all parts of the nation competed.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The newspaper and television industries had more than a news interest in the Census Bureau sample survey that produced today's report on the job situation in the month of May.

RYE, N. Y., June 10 -- Charles Smith of Taft, who was not seeded, joined three seeded players in the semi-final round of the twenty-eighth Manursing Island Club eastern interscholastic tennis championship today.

RYE, N. Y., June 10 -- The voluntary code of social behavior that teen-agers of this city adopted a year ago was declared generally successful today by parents and children. It will remain in effect despite limited noncompliance.
PARIS, June 10 -- The French Government announced today two measures to soften the austerity program imposed last December to restore the nation's finances and economy.
The Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn held its 104th annual commencement yesterday.
The United States Tobacco Company aims to go into the candy business.

In 1535, Pedro de Cieza de Leon arrived in Cartagena in the New World at the age of 13. For the next seventeen years he traveled through South America, observing the achievements of the Inca civilization "even as it was being destroyed."

California and Connecticut borrowed $162,500,000 in the public bond market yesterday; California to finance loans to war veterans, and Connecticut to complete the permanent financing of the $459,500,000 Connecticut Turnpike.

PURCHASE, N. Y., June 10 -- Arthur P. Hassell, the director of suburban stores of B. Altman Co., won the Simon F. Rothschild Cup at the annual New York City Newspaper-Retail Dry Goods Association golf tournament today.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 10 -- Prescott Seckel of Lawrenceville scored a 72 at Greenwich Country Club today and won the medal in the forty-third Eastern interscholastic golf championship with 149. He also paced his school to the team title.
The controversy over distribution rights to Charlie Chaplin movies has flared into a second legal action.
DALLAS, June 10 -- Construction of Government buildings was described here today as a help to a community by contributing to the stability of rentals and real estate values.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 10 (AP) -- P. Kenneth Peterson was re-elected to a second term as Mayor in yesterday's voting. It was regarded as a conservative victory even though the election was on a nonpartisan basis.

Dominick Mordini, also known as Billy Brown, former matchmaker for the International Boxing Club, was held in $100,000 bail yesterday as a material witness in the case of Frankie Carbo, described as the underworld boxing commissioner.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, June 10 -- Costa Rica's Legislative Assembly continued its attack on the executive branch last night by approving a measure to censure the Organization of American States for intervention in the Nicaraguan revolt.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee ignored White House protests today and approved a five-year authorization of $5,000,000,000 for the Development Loan Fund. The vote was 11 to 4.

The Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University held its first commencement exercises yesterday afternoon on its sixteen-acre campus at Morris Park Avenue and Eastchester Road, the Bronx.
GENEVA, June 10 -- The Soviet Union offered today to extend certain Western rights in Berlin for twelve months if the West would agree to Soviet conditions.

IN world statistics, the average Londoner drinks more beer and ale than anyone. In the United States, Milwaukeeans do. New Yorkers, however, down a fair share of the cool or otherwise brewed product each year, one source putting the figure at 10,000,000 barrels annually.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 10 -- Heat waves danced across the fairways today as the sun blazed down heartlessly on the just and the unjust alike. The Winged Foot Golf Club simmered on the broiler while awaiting the start of the United States Open on the morrow.

The State University of New York Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn conferred 138 degrees of Doctor of Medicine and two of Master of Science at its commencement exercises in Brooklyn College last night.
TRENTON, June 10 -- Municipalities and industries in this state spent a record total of $278,094,000 from 1948 to 1958 to combat pollution of streams and waterways.

The Royal American Corporation, a subsidiary of the Graham-Paige Corporation, has purchased A. E. R. F. Raidle, Inc., one of the largest realty brokerage and land investment companies in Florida. Raidle and associated companies have interests in more than 23,000 acres, mostly in the vicinity of Palm Beach, with an indicated value of more than $10,000,000
Representative Isidore Dollinger was picked yesterday by the Bronx Democratic organization to run for District Attorney this fall.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- The Air Force acknowledged today that there had been leaks of information on two of its big contracts.
The Yankees rolled out of bed yesterday with sufficient momentum to turn back their old pals from Kansas City by a 6-4 margin at the Stadium.
ALBANY, June 10 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller today announced the names of six student winners of a state-win essay contest sponsored by the State Commission on Historic Observances.
The election of Harry E. Wilson as a vice president and member of the executive committee of the F. W. Woolworth Company was announced yesterday.
Following is the text of the citations that accompanied the award of honorary degrees at New York University's commencement exercises yesterday:
YONKERS, June 10 -- Less than a length separated the first four horses at the finish of the featured Class A pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank), lent $11,600,000 yesterday to the Union of South Africa for use in its projected railway expansion.
LONDON, June 10 -- Some opposition is developing here to any attempt to transfer United States fighter-bombers from France to Britain.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (UPI) -- Congress gave final approval today to a compromise bill boosting income taxes on life insurance companies by about 60 per cent.

The rate of delinquency on bank installment loans continues to show a decline, the American Bankers Association reported yesterday. For the month of April, experience improved in every category except property improvement loans financed under the banks' own plans.

NAGS HEAD, N. C., June 10 -- What are the beneficial results of a fishing school conducted for higher purposes by an institution of higher learning without hope of profit? Will it make the world a better place?

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The National Academy of Sciences announced today that Viktor A. Ambartsumyan, a Soviet astronomer, had been made a foreign associate of the academy -- the first Soviet scientist to be so honored in over a decade.

Electric power production rose to 13.023,000,000 kilowatt-hoursI last week, from a revised figure of 12,778,000,000 a week earlier the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. In the same period last year output was 11,681,000,000 kilowatt-hours.

" The Quare Fellow," Brendan Behan's first play, recently introduced the Irish dramatist to theatregoers at Off Broadway's Circle in the Square. His second work, "The Hostage," will reach Broadway in January. That is the objective of Leonard Field and Irvin Shapiro, who are making arrangements to bring the play from London.
Decision was reserved yesterday by five Appellate Division judges on Joseph Papp's legal attempt to compel Park Commissioner Robert Moses to issue a permit for free Shakespeare in Central Park.
TRENTON, June 10 -- The State Public Utility Commission ordered Trenton Transit, operator of Trenton's only bus line, to show cause today why it should not be obliged to continue its services here.

Schenley Industries, Inc., had a net profit of $12,918,000, or $2.30 a common share, for the nine months ended May 31, compared with $10,597,530, or $1.89 a share, a year earlier, Lewis S. Rosenstiel, chairman and president, reported yesterday.

The Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn Heights, divided in recent years by two factions, was taken over yesterday by the group opposing the Rev. William Howard Melish, the ousted supply priest.
MOSCOW, June 10 -- A group of Soviet artists spent several hours today looking at American abstract and impressionist art.

LONDON, June 10 -- The Atlantic Congress called today for greater consultation among the members of the Western alliance, the strengthening of their military forces and a joint program of economic aid to the under-developed countries of the world.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 10 -- The possibility that the motion-picture industry might spread into fields that are not connected with entertainment became stronger today.

Robert Anderson, author of "Tea and Sympathy" and a member-producer of the Playwrights Company, was elected president yesterday of the New Dramatists Committee. Mr. Anderson is an alumnus of the twelve-year-old committee, a nonprofit group designed to encourage and develop new playwriting talent.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Anthony Pinelli, alleged overlord of gambling operations in Lake County, Ind., refused today to tell the Senate rackets committee whether he had ever paid the county s former public prosecutor for protection.

This is the day appointed to launch a New York City gala which is to last three months, thus saluting the navigator Henry Hudson who, 350 years ago, nosed into our unparalleled harbor and found "a very good land to fall with and a pleasant land to see."

Was Betty Co-ed a disturbed teen-ager? A borderline delinquent? Or was she just a little "shook up" and unintelligible to her elders? These questions came to mind recently on reading that the darling of the Nineteen Twenties had been introduced into a discussion of rock 'n' roll by Joseph Carlton, president of a record company.

GREAT NECK, L. I., June 10 -- The Great Neck Aid Fund has made grants of more than $17,000 to twenty-five pupils who will be graduated this year from Great Neck North and South Senior High Schools and St. Mary's High School
LANSING, Mich., June 10 -- The Michigan House of Representatives today defeated for the second time a proposed state income tax.

A ringside radio account of the Floyd Patterson-Ingemar Johansson heavyweight championship fight at Yankee Stadium will be presented over the American Broadcasting Company network beginning at 10:30 P. M. on June 25.
CHICAGO, June 10 (AP) -- Sugar Hart, a Philadelphia welterweight contender, battered Isaac Logart of Cuba relentlessly for a unanimous ten-round decision at Chicago Stadium tonight.

Operating revenues of the Great Northern Railway last month of $22,863,188 were more than 20 per cent above the $18,649,744 of the same month last year, yet net income was only $3,026,968, or $46,748 below the $3,073,716 profit reported in May of 1958.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The Soviet Union may have divided the Geneva foreign ministers' meeting today with its latest proposals on Berlin, but it has united Washington.

The taxpayer occupying a plot 100 by 100 feet at 107 to 113 West 125th Street, between Lenox and Seventh Avenues, has been sold by Harry Horwitz, realty operator. The buyer was B. Hamilton Gordon. Albert Friedlander was the broker.
Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, inferentially called last night for a modification of the Kennedy labor-management bill.
BECKENHAM, England, June 10 (AP) -- It was a poor day for American men and a good one for the Russians in the Kent lawn tennis championships today. However, the American women's contingent did well.
The police arrested forty-five men and four women last night in a raid on a thirty-ninth-floor suite of the New Yorker Hotel.

A good many of the nation's automobiles must have stayed in the garage last week. Figures issued by the American Petroleum Institute yesterday showed that the usual seasonal decline in gasoline inventories failed to materialize.

Massey - Ferguson, Ltd., a major manufacturer of farm machines and light industrial equipment, showed record sales and sharply increased earnings in the six months ended April 30, according to the report issued yesterday.

United States Government securities scored further gains in the dealers' market yesterday. The chief interest centered in the short-term discount bills and in war-issued 2 1/2 per cent bonds quoted at heavy discounts from the principal amount.

The Anderson - Prichard Oil Corporation increased the quarterly dividend yesterday with the declaration of 35 cents a share payable to common stockholders June 30. In previous quarters 30 cents was distributed.
ALBANY, June 10 -- The prospects that Joseph F. Carlino of the powerful Nassau County Republican organization will be elected speaker of the Assembly increased materially today.

Mrs ! Mr. Eugene W. Ong and [ Frederic R. Pratt, co-chairmenI for the Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball to be held Dec. i 21 at the Waldorf-Astoria, will give a luncheon today in the [Pillement Suite of the hotel for Imembers of the debutante coal mittee. I The fete is an annual 'benefit for the maintenance fund io the New York Infirmary.
Earl Warren, Chief Justice of the United States, said yesterday that world peace and domestic tranqillity depended on "mutual respect for the equal rights of others."

A Roman Catholic could be elected President if a "generally favorable political situation" prevailed and if the candidate were "strong," an official of the National Conference of Christians and Jews said yesterday.

Earnings of Adam Consolidated Industries, Inc. this year will "at least triple" the $83,455 or 9 cents a share earned in 1958, Harold N. Leitman, chairman and president, told stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.
THE discomfort index inside the Downtown Theatre was at least 10 points higher than anywhere else in the city last evening.
Yeshiva University received permanent possession of New York City's collegiate blood-donor trophy yesterday at a ceremony at the New York Red Cross Chapter, Thirty-eighth Street and Lexington Avenue.
MONTREAL, June 10 -- The New York Rangers picked up three players at $20,000 apiece in the National Hockey League draft today, but lost a promising goalie to Boston.
ST. LOUIS, June 10 (AP) -- This city's two daily newspapers suspended publication today when forty-four stereotypers went on strike.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, June 10 (UPI) -- Avery Brundage, president of the International Olympic Committee, said today that his organization would find a solution to assure Nationalist Chinese participation in the 1960 Winter Olympics at Squaw Valley, Calif.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (UPI) -- Senator John L. McClellan warned today that the United States would suffer if the House watered down the labor reform bill passed by the Senate.
The heat wilted the city yesterday. Blistering temperatures broke a seventy-year record for the date and surpassed the year's previous high -- established the day before -- by one-tenth of a degree.
PARIS, June 10 -- French exports exceeded imports in May for the first time since December, 1955.

HAVANA, June 10 -- Investment by foreigners in the planned industrialization of Cuba is not desirable, according to Premier Fidel Castro. It would be preferable if foreigners loaned Cubans the money to establish their own industries, the Premier said in a televised interview last night.
A social experiment aimed at the early detection and prevention of juvenile crime is slated to get under way today with the approval by the Board of Estimate of a $50,000 program.

With strong backing from Governor Rockefeller, the chairman of the State Labor Relations Board met yesterday with twelve prosecutors from the city and suburbs to map action against mobster-controlled paper unions.

WALTER CLEMONS seems to be too young to belong to the Beat Generation. This is an awesome thought, isn't it? The Beegees, or Beatniks, or whatever you call them, have now, come to think of it, been around long enough to acquire, along with assorted beards, other mossy signs of antiquity.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Deliberate restraints by the Supreme Court majority on the sweeping latitude of the texts of previous decisions written by its "liberals" were implicit in last Monday's decisions in the Barenblatt and Uphaus civil rights cases.

There was a time, when this country was young, when trees were, in a sense, man's enemies. They had to be cut and burned to open needed farmland. They had to be cut to open routes of trade and travel overland. The forests harbored enemies and impeded progress. But those days are long gone. Trees now are assets, not liabilities.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The Eisenhower Administration got a surprisingly sympathetic hearing in Congress today on its requests for authority to raise interest rates on Government bonds.
CHICAGO, June 10 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

LONDON, June 10 (AP) -- The combined Yale - Harvard track team defeated an Oxford-Cambridge squad for the first time since 1933 today by winning the decisive 440-yard relay. The final score was 8 -- 7. Only first places counted.
A long-missing portrait of Thomas Jefferson, painted from life in 1805 by Gilbert Stuart, has been identified after years of research.

Capt. William V. Bradley, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, has been accused of allowing George A. Brenner to cash forged I. L. A. notes in return for 15 per cent of the face value of the notes.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 4 to 16 points yesterday with new October showing the most weakness. A point is 5 cents a bale.
ABOARD COAST GUARD CUTTER ANDROSCOGGIN, June 9 -- A bombing attack against an eighteen - story-high iceberg in the North Atlantic failed today to split the hazard to navigation.
Sad tidings are in store for many of the city's pupils when the school term ends June 26.
MOSCOW, June 10 -- A 17-year-old ballerina, only five days out of the Bolshoi Ballet School here, has been acclaimed as a new star in the Bolshoi Theatre troupe.
NEW DELHI, India, June 10 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru expressed regret today over the failure of India's efforts to get the International Truce Commission in Laos reconvened.
" STEREOTYPED" art materials, such as coloring books and kits of "paintings-by-the-numbers," were said yesterday to cripple a child's imagination by inducing conformity.
Bally Ache followed the simplest of tactics in winning the $35.550 Juvenile Stakes yesterday.
TOKYO, Thursday, June 11 -- South Korea has suspended trade with Japan because of a Japanese plan to repatriate Koreans here to North Korea, the Seoul Government's Embassy in Tokyo announced today.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Wednesday, June 3:
A grand jury foreman and a General Sessions judge clashed yesterday over a report concerning charges of "fixed" television quiz programs.
BALTIMORE, June 10 (UPI) -- A black bear that may have visited near-by Washington last week was shot to death in metropolitan Baltimore today.
At least to this New Yorker traveling on the Continent, it appears as though wonderful old-new Madrid has found a way to solve the traffic problem still plaguing New York.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The Administration's new master plan for continental air defense will also be a money-saving plan, Pentagon officials said today.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The heads of three European economic communities told President Eisenhower today that their work was meant to lead toward European political unity.
PHOENIX, Ariz., June 10 -- The American Symphony Orchestra League opened its fourteenth national convention here today.

Mayor Wagner expressed confidence yesterday that the City Council, now balking temporarily over the taxicab levy, would approve his $90,000,000 nuisance-tax package. City Council rebellions against administration wishes are rare. This one will probably be brief; the revenues are needed.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., June 10 -- A native of Pennsylvania who moved to Texas more than eighty years ago and later became a pioneer of the oil business lives today in comparative anonymity sixty-five miles northwest of San Antonio.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- A rise of 1,000,000 jobs increased employment to a record of 66,016,000 for May, the Government reported today.

Leading sales finance companies announced yesterday a quarter point increase in the yields of most maturities of their unsecured promisory notes sold directly to investors. It was the first increase in so-called finance paper rates since April 21.
BALTIMORE, June 10 (AP) -- Cleveland's Rocky Colavito tied a major league record of four home runs in a game as the Indians beat the Baltimore Orioles, 11 -- 8, tonight.

Lead and zinc prices moved in narrow ranges yesterday but the volume was heavy on the Commodity Exchange of New York. The lead volume, 175 lots (60,000 pounds to a lot), was the largest since trading was suspended during World War II.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., June 10 -- The trial of four white youths for the alleged rape of a Negro co-ed began today in the crowded courtroom of Leon County Circuit.
PARIS, Thursday, June 11 -- The French National Assembly sanctioned early today the first tentative measures to integrate Algeria with France.
Practically all the statistics and assertions attributed to Leland A. Watson in Arthur Krock's column published June 5 I know to be false.
A strike by the engineers and oilers aboard the tugs of seven New York harbor railroads has been set for 12:01 A. M. Monday, the Transport Workers Union announced yesterday.

The May 25 letter of J. Donald Kingsley, executive director of the Community Council of Greater New York, which strongly criticizes the National Education Association report, "Delinquent Behavior," of which I am coauthor, reflects serious misunderstanding both of specific points in the document and its general implications.
CHICAGO, June 10 (AP) -- Oats became the most bullish grain future on the Board of Trade today. It was the leader in a general but moderate price advance.
Rotary International, meeting here for its fiftieth annual convention, heard a plea yesterday for "a summit meeting of the world's spiritual leaders."

BERLIN, June 10 -- The East German security police arrested two French gendarmes near Magdeburg last night. The gendarmes were pursuing an Algerian who had jumped from a French military train passing through East Germany, the East German press office announced today.
In a general rally yesterday stocks advanced about $4,000,000,000 in market value, erasing about 30 per cent of their losses thus far in June.

Throwing a bombshell into a climactic session of the Geneva conference of foreign ministers the Soviets have now served a new ultimatum with a time limit on the West giving it just one year to sign a German "peace treaty" dictated by Moscow and in any case to get out of Berlin by the end of that year or sooner.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., June 10 -- A white-haired 54-year-old attorney who studied law while working as a city fireman is presiding at the trial of four young white men accused of having raped a Negro co-ed.
Joseph L. Eckhouse will resign Sept. 1 as a top executive of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., and as head of the New York store. He will decide on his plans after that date.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 10 -- The American Medical Association today ended its long-standing opposition to closed-panel medical plans, particularly those sponsored by unions.

What makes Wall Street ridiculous from the viewpoint of the distributors of local government bonds is set forth in song, story and classical and profane art today in the eighteenth annual edition of The Daily Bond Crier.

WASHINGTON June 10 (UPI) -- A House Banking subcommittee, disregarding G.O.P. "budget busting" charges, voted today to expand the Federal program to help local governments build water and sewage plants, hospitals and other public facilities.

DULUTH, Minn., June 10 (UPI) -- The city of Duluth has started a harbor patrol to keep juveniles off foreign ships docking in the twin ports of Superior, Wis., and Duluth since the opening of the St. Lawrence Seaway.
Vice President Richard M. Nixon heads a list of notables who will open New York's ninety-day celebration of Henry Hudson's discovery of the river bearing his name in a ceremony at the Battery today.
Describing the state of the stock market results in odd comparisons by the market letter writers of brokerage houses and banks.

GENEVA, June 10 (Reuters) -- Following are the texts of speeches by Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko and Secretary of State Christian A. Herter at the plenary session of the foreign ministers' conference today:
Hospital and union officials yesterday were weighing the recommendations of Mayor Wagner's fact-finding panel for ending the month-old strike of nonprofessional employes here.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Senator Clair Engle, Democrat of California, declared today that Lewis L. Strauss had "skated the edge of deception and dealt in half-truths" in his relations with Congress and the public.

Henry E. Gilbert, president of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen, charged yesterday that railroads serving New York City were deliberately pursuing at policy to discourage commuter travel. He excepted the Long Island Rail Road.

Scotland, the Faeroe Islands and Iceland will be linked by a submarine telephone cable Scheduled to be operating before the end of 1961. This was disclosed yesterday in an announcement from International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation that its affiliate, Standard Telephones and Cables, Ltd., of London, England, had been awarded the contract to lay the 684-nautical-mile cable.

BONN, Germany, June 10 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and his Minister of the Economy, Dr. Ludwig Erhard, patched up their political quarrel today. Both men agreed to stay where they were. This ended a crisis over West German leadership that was precipitated when Dr. Adenauer reversed his decision to run for the Presidency, which would have opened the way for Dr. Erhard to seek the Chancellorship.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The Circuit Court of Appeals unanimously upheld today an order for a clean-up of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

Walter C. Foster of Westbury, L. I., may find no sermons in stone, but he finds lessons in bronzes. He has been collecting bronze figures of dogs for twenty-five years. As a professional handler he knows a lot about modern dogs.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (UPI) -- Business men, encouraged by rising sales, have increased their planned spending for new factories and machines, the Government reported today.
Visitors who failed to make reservations for hotel rooms here this week are finding that rail, bus and airline waiting rooms and hotel lobbies are less than comfortable during the heat wave.
Of twenty-two purchases of New York Stock Exchange issues reported by insiders -- officers, directors and major stockholders -- during May, thirteen resulted from the exercise of stock options.
GENEVA, June 10 -- The United States and Britain neared agreement with the Soviet Union today on holding a meeting of experts to study the detection of nuclear explosions in outer space.
Mayor Wagner expressed confidence yesterday that his $90,000,000-a-year package of five nuisance taxes would be approved by the City Council next week.
The passenger list of the strike-bound liner Giulio Cesare, immobilized here a second day, began to dwindle yesterday.
Stepped-up selling and marketing efforts were announced yesterday by two major companies.
The measured cadences of Latin oratory rolled over the Fordham University campus yesterday as a Cardinal, two educators, two business men and two public officials were cited for honorary degrees.

The Appellate Division reserved decision yesterday on an application by the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association for the establishment of a departmental grievance procedure for the city's 24,000 member Police Department.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- line reforms aimed at strengthening the structures of United States political parties were suggested today in a study sponsored by the Fund for the Republic, Inc.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The United States and Poland signed a sales and credit agreement today totaling $50,000,000.
LENINGRAD, June 7 -- Leningrad is sparkling again these long June days with much of its ancient imperial grandeur.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 10 -- A field of 150 eligibles was poised and ready tonight to fire away at what appeared to be the withering par of Winged Foot Golf Club's West course. Over this layout the first round of the United States Open golf championship will get under way tomorrow.
If you have not received in the mail a state form for the declaration of estimated personal income tax, and you have to file an estimate, it is up to you to go out and get a copy yourself -- now.
GENEVA, June 10 -- The conference that opened here a month ago to discuss the freedom of Berlin, the unity of Germany and the security of Europe has come down to a less exalted question.
LONDON, June 10 -- The stock market regained its buoyancy today and modest gains predominated among most of the industrial shares.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, May 31 -- Hungarians foresee the day when their country may become a kind of Switzerland of Eastern Europe as far as its industrial output is concerned.
MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 11 -- The Winged Foot Golf Club became a pre-breakfast club today as hordes of combatants and noncombatants arrived early for the opening of the United States Open.
Mrs. Laura Virginia Douglas, retiring after forty-three years as a public school teacher and principal, was given a farewell dinner by her colleagues last night at the Towers Hotel in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- The House Elections subcommittee decided today to hear evidence in an election contest involving Representative Wint Smith, Republican of Kansas.
Simeon II, exiled King of Bulgaria, said yesterday that the West should put more emphasis on freedom and less on peaceful coexistence.

NAGS HEAD, N. C., June 11 -- It is fitting that we should be gathered here, as Federal law requires all Fourth of July orators to say, to witness the historic debate over the relative merits of the East Coast idiot stick and the West Coast idiot stick.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (UPI) -- The Defense Department awarded a $600,000 contract to the Radio Corporation of America today for a study on the feasibility of tracking and intercepting enemy space vehicles.

Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, warned yesterday that the economic "gap, already wide, between the prosperous countries and those less fortunate is steadily becoming wider."

DALLAS, June 11 -- New office buildings designed without some provision for shelter against radioactive fall-out are "inconsistent with the needs of the times," a Federal official in the civil defense program said today.

A 41-year-old former Wall Street broker and veteran of Iwo Jima was ordained a deacon in the Protestant Episcopal Church yesterday. He is Frederick B. Stimson Jr., for ten years a customer's man with Penington Colket Co.

Heavy buying of sugar by Cuban interests firmed prices yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The domestic months closed unchanged to 4 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) higher on 23,950 tons. The world contract was 6 points higher to 6 lower on 22,050 tons.
HOUSTON, Tex., June 11 (AP) -- An internationally known Roman Catholic priest was killed with three members of a Dallas family yesterday when a plane he was flying crashed.

Eddie Arcaro won a trophy at Belmont Park yesterday, and he deserved it. The ace jockey was on the Rockburn Farm's Recite in the feature race, named the Montauk in honor of the venerable Brooklyn club of the same name.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 11 (UPI) -- Bud Abbott, comedian, said today that he and Eddie Foy Jr. were teaming up as a new comedy act.
A threatened strike by railroad harbor tug workers took on port-crippling proportions yesterday.
The first steps toward the construction of a new Municipal Building and auxiliary structures near City Hall were taken yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- The Senate rackets committee was told today that a back-dated pardon granted by John S. Fine as Governor of Pennsylvania thwarted efforts to deport a Pittsburgh hoodlum in 1954. Pierre Salinger, committee investigator, identified the hoodlum as John S. Larocca.
Ten concerts in Moscow and eight in Leningrad will be the highlights of the forthcoming tour of Europe and the Middle East by the New York Philharmonic.

Loans to businesses by the larger New York City banks increased by $94,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with an increase of $21,000,000 in the comparable week a year ago.
