The six-story building on lot 25 by 100 feet at 40 East Seventy-first Street has been purchased by the Tunisian Government for use as a consulate. It was sold by Murray M. Salzberg, who occupied the building as his residence. The all-cash sale was negotiated by the S. J. Landau Corporation, broker.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Governor Rockefeller made his first political sally outside New York State today but smilingly disclaimed that the visit was to promote any higher political ambitions.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Following is the text of a State Department statement today on the Cuban Agrarian Reform Law, incorporating the substance of a note delivered by Ambassador Philip W. Bonsal to Roberto Agramonte, Cuba's Minister of State:
Federal Judge Gregory F. Noonan reserved decision yesterday on a motion by Alexander L. Guterma to have his fraud trial transferred to Buffalo.
The two Geneva conferences were still long on words but short on deeds yesterday.
LITTLE ROCK, June 11 -- The Pulaski County Board of Education named three men today to fill vacancies created on the Little Rock School Board by a recall election May 25.

ALGIERS, June 11 -- A 23-year-old Moslem was shot to death in Setif last night about the time his sister-in-law, one of the first Moslem women Deputies from Algeria, was speaking in the French National Assembly in Paris.

A political crisis in Germany that could have shaken the whole Western world has been averted by the great sense of responsibility displayed by the two principal figures involved -- Chancellor Adenauer and Economic Minister Erhard. In view of the persisting squabbles in the Western camp at a time of impending showdown with the Soviets, this is welcome news indeed.
A gray column of sixteen Navy ships pierced the early morning mists about Ambrose Light and veered gently into New York Harbor yesterday.
Vice President Richard M. Nixon, Governor Rockefeller and other notables yesterday opened New York's celebration of the 350th anniversary of Henry Hudson's arrival.

The Playwrights Company will find itself involved with the arrival of two Broadway productions on consecutive nights. "Five Finger Exercise" is due Dec. 2 at the Music Box; "Silent Night, Lonely Night," Dec. 3 at the Morosco.
Wall Street early yesterday endeavored to resume Wednesday's rally, but after the first hour or so demand for stock faded.

LONDON, June 11 -- A new land and sea vehicle named the Hovercraft and resembling a flying saucer was unveiled today. The craft, scudding about on a cushion of air, intruded among yachts and ocean liners on The Solent, which separates the Isle of Wight from the south coast of England.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- There are men in Washington, members of the inner circle that encloses the secret, ultimate potentials of present and prospective nuclear warfare, who look to the less publicized of the two Geneva conferences to produce the first key to durable world peace.
The Athletics, it seems, get stronger in the field as they become weaker in manpower.

" PROJECT IMMORTALITY," by Loring Mandel, which was last night's attraction on "Playhouse 90" over Channel 2, was a play whose theme had both meaning and pertinency in the present era of scientific wizardry.

FRESH peaches, one of summer's most luscious delights, are just becoming plentiful. There will be more and more of the fruit in stores here in the coming weeks until the supply reaches its peak in August.

A warning to American industry not to be deluded by trade deals into surrendering its advanced processes and equipment to Soviet Russia was voiced yesterday by O. V. Tracy, vice president of Esso Standard Oil Company.

A working model of a railroad train powered by the same engine - and - propeller combination that sends a Lockheed Super Constellation and Douglas DC7 hurtling through the sky is to be shown by the Department of Commerce at a series of international trade fairs.
New traffic rules that permit advertisements on the outside of buses do not extend to other vehicles, Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy warned last night.

The new agency of Cohen, Dowd Aleshire, Inc., has been awarded the Lord Calvert blended whisky account with billings of about $1,000,000 a year. The announcement was the first to be made officially that Cohen Aleshire, Inc., had merged with Dowd, Redfield Johnstone.
ALHUCEMAS, Morocco, June 11 -- King Mohamed V rode as undisputed master today through this historic center of dissidence in the heart of the Rif Mountains.
ALBANY, June 11 -- New York City got a substantial increase in its property-taxing and borrowing powers from the state today.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The United States is prepared to ease Brazil's economic crisis by rescheduling payments due on past loans.
MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 11 -- One hundred First Army soldiers from Fort Jay on Governors Island made a rapid and sad retreat from the Winged Foot Golf Club today.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 11 (AP) -- Five residents of the town of Putnam Valley failed today to win a dismissal of indictments on misdemeanor charges. The charges stemmed from an inquiry by state auditors and the joint legislative watchdog committee.

Dr. Robert A. Moore, president of the State University's Downtown Medical Center in Brooklyn, told graduates of Long Island University yesterday that science and research should be "devoted to peace and not to conquest and domination."
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- Moves in Congress for expanded Federal spending on airports collapsed today.
HAVANA, Friday, June 12 -- Five Cuban Ministers have resigned in disputes with Premier Fidel Castro. The Premier announced the resignations early today.
JERSEY CITY, N. J., June 11 -- The Board of Education here voted tonight to discontinue the Jersey City Junior College and the Department of Recreation for economy reasons.
The city gained a new weapon yesterday in its war on slums.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 11 -- Scientific experts on outer space have proposed that some form of traffic regulations be devised to keep man-made satellites from colliding.

That American fashion designers lead in the field in pre-seating their ideas for any given season is a significant fact. With today's report, this current series on the Seventh Avenue wholesale collections for fall is virtually concluded. Two leading creators will show later -- Norell is scheduled for July 6 and Galanos for July 8 -- at which time their clothes will be reviewed.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (UPI) -- The Senate Democratic leader, Lyndon B. Johnson, said today that Congress still had an obligation to do something about unemployment despite encouraging new employment figures.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- William McChesney Martin Jr., chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that the agency strongly favored the Eisenhower Administration's request to raise interest rates on Government bonds.

PHOENIX, Ariz., June 11 -- The convention of the American Symphony Orchestra League heard a little music this morning. The delegates were also urged by four composers to listen deeply and with tolerance to all kinds of contemporary music, whether it be tonal, atonal, modal, serial, microtonic, electronic or cross-fertilized by Oriental music or jazz.

CHICAGO, June 11 (AP) -- The grain futures market lost ground all along the line on moderate liquidation in late dealings today on the Board of Trade. Most of the declines, however, were held to fractions of a cent.

A grand jury presentment outlining in detail the "fixing" of television quiz shows was sealed and impounded after legal action had been taken by attorneys representing "The $64,000 Question" and "The $64,000 Challenge."
CHICAGO, June 11 (AP) -- The United Rubber Workers will seek a general wage increase later this year, its International Policy Committee announced today.

Arthur E. Littman, former president of Littman-Subow, Inc., merchandising counseling organization, has joined the board of Clothing Research, Inc., and has been named chairman of its new marketing research committee.

The State Investigation Commission yesterday ended its public hearings into the official conduct of George P. Monaghan, the State Harness Racing Commissioner, without having heard Mr. Monaghan himself.
While in Bermuda recently I read the excellent letter printed on your editorial page of May 28 written by Ira Younker criticizing hospital wage scales.

For 500 years Chinese have been leaving the China mainland for South Seas regions. Today the overseas Chinese are considered the most influential group in Southeast Asia. They operate most of the retail business and coastal shipping, and are said to be important factors in the world's rubber and tin production.
BONN, Germany, June 11 -- The quarrel between Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and his Minister of the Economy, Dr. Ludwig Erhard, broke out again tonight despite their formal truce.
Thousands of owners of small pleasure boats have been dismayed to learn that their craft will not be permitted to travel the length of the St. Lawrence Seaway.

A PEEK at the fall knit picture was given to 400 sportswear buyers last night at Woolknit Associates' fifteenth annual fashion show and banquet at the Pierre Hotel. Looking ahead to September, the audience saw fur-like patterns of ponyskin and broadtail, sculptured brocades and brushed effects in solid colors and misty plaids.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The House Veterans Committee approved unanimously today a major reform of the veterans' pension system to relate future pensions to need.

OCEANPORT, N. J., June 11 (AP) -- Monmouth Park opens its fifty-day meeting tomorrow, with the Brookfield Farm's Isendu heading a field of thirteen sprinters entered for the $15,000-added Oceanport Handicap.

There are repeated reports from Geneva of behind-the-scenes talks, chiefly between the Russians and the Britons, about reactivating the Laos Supervisory Commission to check hostilities in the northern provinces of the little Asian kingdom. Indian Prime Minister Nehru has given his blessing to such a move in the hope of stopping bloodshed.
BOSTON, June 11 -- The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad today canceled summer service between New York and Cape Cod.

The budget submitted to Congress by the President on Jan. 19 foresaw expenditures of $77 billion and receipts of $77.1 billion. Since the revised budget estimate for the present year pointed at the time to a deficit of $12.9 billion, the President's estimate for 1960 indicated an over-all improvement of $13 billion.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., June 11 -- Satellite flights of the Project Mercury astronauts may start with three circuits of the globe and be extended later to as many as eighteen.

Prices of all cotton futures except the December on the New York Cotton Exchange declined yesterday. The losses were 3 to 14 points. The December contract was unchanged. (A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.)

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Prof. Walter Hallstein, president of the European common market organization, predicted today that the standard of living in the European Community would reach the level of the United States by 1975.
The City Health Department begins the distribution today of 2,000,000 leaflets warning parents to destroy plastic bags as soon as they have served their purposes and to keep them away from children.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- President Eisenhower advised Congress today that the United States planned to send Greece special equipment and restricted information for training its armed forces in atomic weapons.
July 1 has been designated for the public offering of $195,000,000 of term and serial bonds of Public Utility District 2, Grant County, Wash., according to the managers of the marketing syndicate.

The election of John L. Bricker and Herbert P. Nack as vice presidents of the Colgate-Palmolive Company, manufacturer of soaps, detergents and toilet products, was announced yesterday by Edward H. Little, chairman and president.
NORTHVILLE, L. I., June 11 -- The tanker Esso Lexington today completed the off-shore delivery of 10,126,578 gallons of fuel oil to the Northville Dock Corporation.
A referendum will be held July 1 by members of New York Typographical Union 6 on a proposal for a new contract with ten New York newspapers.
GALVESTON, Tex., June 11 (AP) -- A court-appointed attorney for Gov. Earl K. Long of Louisiana announced today that the Governor would fight any attempt to declare him insane.
A television dramatization of Budd Schulberg's "What Makes Sammy Run?" will be presented over the National Broadcasting Company network in two one-hour installments next fall.
HOBOKEN, N. J., June 11 -- Manhattan put on her most spectacular jewelry tonight to mark the 350th anniversary of Henry Hudson's exploration of the river that bears his name.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 11 if it is unusual for a man to be a dog, how much more so it for one to write for a dog. rling Silliphant is such a man and he does not yet know the answers.

GENEVA, June 11 -- The Western powers told the Soviet Union today that unless it revoked its ultimatum on Berlin, the foreign ministers' conference would soon end in disagreement with no prospect for a summit meeting.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- A Vermont Senator complained today that the debate over Lewis L. Strauss was costing the taxpayers money.
PARIS, June 11 -- Premier Michel Debre threatened today to draft workers on the nationalized French railways to prevent a threatened eight-hour work stoppage Tuesday.
TRENTON, June 11 -- A plan for transforming 187 acres in the heart of this city into an ultramodern shopping, business and residential area was disclosed at a dinner here tonight.

Average member bank borrowings rose $130,000,000 to $979,000,000 in the week ended Wednesdaq, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This was the highest level since the week of Oct. 16, 1957.

This June like countless others is the season of marriages, when happy couples exchange nuptial vows. Various rituals -- some simple, some complex -- have been used over the years, but the chances are that few of the men and women who are principals realize why many customs and traditions in the ceremonies are continued or how they originated.
YONKERS, June 11 -- Trader Horn, taking the overland route, went five-wide around the final turn, yet was strong enough to win in 2:03 before 22,942 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
CARACAS, Venezuela, June 11 -- Dr. Juan Pablo Perez Alfonso, Minister of Mines, said today there was "no reason" to be worried about the future of the oil industry and oil companies in Venezuela.
MOSCOW, June 11 -- Large-scale efforts to teach young Soviet citizens foreign tongues have impressed two prominent United States educators.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- Short-weight in packaged food products is becoming an increasingly serious problem, John L. Harvey, deputy commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, said today.
SEATTLE, June 11 -- The Boeing Airplane Company replied here today to recent Government criticism that it had submitted excessive estimates on the cost of B-52 jet bomber parts.

The Fedders Corporation, Maspeth, Queens, maker of air conditioning equipment, will offer common stockholders today $3,812,300 of 5 1/2 per cent twenty-year subordinated debentures with warrants to purchase 152,492 shares of common stock.
MIAMI, June 11 (AP) -His brother's quick action was credited today by medical authorities with saving the life of Dr. Raymond J. Smith, 45 years old, a dentist.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (UPI) -- The United States Chamber of Commerce urged Congress today to demand that Neil H. McElroy use his authority to wipe out interservice rivarly over missiles.

Twenty-nine men who were arrested in a gambling raid on a suite of the New Yorker Hotel Wednesday night pleaded guilty to charges of disorderly conduct in Manhattan Arrest Court yesterday. Each paid a $5 fine.

LOS ANGELES, June 11 -- Formation of the largest federally chartered savings and loan association in the United States was made known here yesterday with the announcement of the merger, effective July 1, of Standard Federal Savings and Loan Association and California Federal Savings and Loan Association.

ROME, June 11 -- President Celal Bayar of Turkey had a state audience today with Pope John XXIII. It was the first visit ever made to the Vatican by a head of the Turkish nation and was a reunion of two old friends.
Columbia University announced yesterday the appointment of three new members to the advisory board of the American Press Institute for three-year terms, effective July 1.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 11 -- Ben Hogan played one of the greatest rounds of his career today. The 46-year-old Texan skillfully maneuvered over the wind-swept Winged Foot Golf Club's West Course and scored a 69, sharing the opening-round lead in the United States Open golf championship.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 11 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon asserted tonight that persons who were writing off Senator John K. Kennedy of Massachusetts as the 1960 Democratic nominee for President because of his age and his religion, Roman Catholic, might have to "take a re-reading."
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- The House Labor Committee, at a stormy session, blocked a move today to delay floor consideration of a labor reform bill.
Capt. William V. Bradley denied yesterday that he had received a 15 per cent kickback for allowing George A. Brenner to cash forged International Longshoremen's Association notes.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The foreign ministers' conference in Geneva has demonstrated once more the need to devise new ways of negotiating with the Russians.

Phoenix - Rheinrohr A. G., Duesseldorf, West Germany, a producer of steel and pipe, will spend $100,000,000 for modernization and expansion, the company announced yesterday. The program includes the purchase of new machinery, equipment for modernization of mills, two 15,000-ton cargo ships and two of 25,000 tons, a new rolling mill, and the addition of a department for synthetic materials.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (UPI) -- Senator Margaret Chase Smith accused a three-star Air Force general today of trying to "smear" her reputation.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and former Senator Herbert H. Lehman went into Carmine G. De Sapio's own district -- Greenwich Village -- last night to support the drive to dethrone him as leader of Tammany Hall.

The proceedings at Geneva and the debate over another summit conference point up a paradox that has been apparent in Western policy since the Bonn Republic was first established. Today the Soviet Union would alter the status quo in Berlin so as to preserve the German status quo; proposing to alter the German status quo, the West has, from the start, had a profound stake in its preservation.

Directors of Smith-Corona Marchant, Inc., reduced the quarterly dividend yesterday with the declaration of 10 cents a share for payment on June 30. In previous quarters shareholders received 25 cents a share.
MOSCOW, June 11 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev said today the Western rejection of the Soviet Union's latest proposals at Geneva was "unrealistic and bankrupt."
LONDON, June 11 -- The stock market here continued to rally today and gains of around a shilling (14 cents) predominated in the main industrial lists.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (UPI) -- Dick Hyde, the relief pitcher who had been sought by the New York Yankees, was traded to the Boston Red Sox today by the Washington Senators in a four-man deal.

Senator Lyndon Johnson, the Democratic leader, is justified in his annoyance at charges that the present session of Congress is establishing a "won't do" record. As always, the true portrait of the session will be painted in its last two months, and Senator Johnson has listed an impressive array of legislation he counts on passing in that time.

A new stage and seating plan at Madison Square Garden will provide better visibility for the audience and more room for the 200 performers in the Russian Festival of Music and Dance in July. The festival will be presented in conjunction with the Soviet Exposition at the Coliseum.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The increase in teen-age venereal disease has prompted the Public Health Service to join with the Kansas State Board of Health in producing an educational film on syphilis. It will be shown in high schools all over the country.

BECKENHAM, England, June 11 (AP) -- Alex Olmedo of Los Angeles defeated Andrei Potanin of the Soviet Union in the quarter-finals of the Kent tennis championships, while an all-American cast was assured for the semi-finals in the women's singles.
PITTSBURGH, June 11 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates defeated the San Francisco Giants, 12 -- 9, today in a contest marred by twelve errors, seven by the Pirates and five by the Giants.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The House crushed today an Administration-supported wheat bill aimed at cutting the nation's major farm surplus. The vote was 168 to 114, on almost a straight party-line division.
Despite a stepped-up recruitment drive, the city schools lost ground this year in their effort to overcome the teacher shortage.
Criticism against New York commuter railroads by Henry E. Gilbert, president of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen, brought two rejoinders yesterday.

VIENNA, June 11 -- The scientific advisory committee of the International Atomic Energy Agency has recommended to the board of governors that the agency become the world-wide clearing house for information on controlled fusion and plasma physics.
GENEVA, June 11 -- John A. McCone, chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission attended today's meeting of the three-power conference that is negotiating a ban on nuclear weapons tests.
North Dakota's potentials for tremendous industrial development, based on its large deposits of lignite coal, were outlined in impressive terms yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Comittee amended the foreign-aid bill today to require submission of plans for ultimate abolition of grants for defense support and special assistance.
Yeshiva University may apply for sponsorship of the controversial Riverside-Amsterdam Title I project and construct a center with two campuses.
TOKYO, June 11 (AP) -- Japan's Government announced today that it had decided to retain Thomas E. Dewey as an adviser to help expand Japanese exports and protect its interests in the United States.

An agreement was reached yesterday between the Communications Workers of America and the long lines department of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. It covers 22,000 employes in forty-three states for fifteen months.
Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation, said yesterday that raising contributions by the one-fund method would lead eventually to government control of voluntary health organizations.
The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) announced yesterday the start of operations at what it described as the world's largest pipe still for the refining of crude oil.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Nine European nations were assured today that their views on this country's shipping practices would be considered in a study of United States transportation policies being made at the direction of President Eisenhower.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield barred "Lady Chatterley's Lover" from the mails today. His decision set the stage for an important court test of what constitutes obscenity in a literary work.
A proposal to merge the Union Square Savings Bank and the Bank for Savings in the City of New York has been withdrawn from consideration by the State Banking Department.
Negotiations for a new steel wage agreement recessed yesterday, with no certainty that they would resume before the June 30 strike deadline.
ROME, June 11 (Reuters) -- The world's citrus output is expected to be bigger and heavier in the next five years, the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization reported here today.
OTTAWA, June 11 (AP) -- An engineering study on the possibility of duplicating the lock facilities in the crowded Welland Canal to speed traffic was suggested in the House of Commons today.
The bond market was occupied chiefly yesterday with the distribution of $162,500,000 in new tax-exempt-interest obligations of California and Connecticut.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The United States sent a note to Cuba today expressing "serious concern" over the compensation to be paid United States citizens for property to be confiscated under the land-reform program.
ALBANY, June 11 -- A complete investigation of electricity rates charged by the Consolidated Edison Company was ordered today by the Public Service Commission.

We would like to commend The Times on its recent articles on the egg situation. You have properly focused attention on the difficulties egg producers are suffering, particularly in the near-by areas of New Jersey.
The steel industry poured more raw steel last month than in any other month in history -- 11,600,000 net tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- The Government accused virtually the entire rubber industry today of conspiring to fix the prices of tires and tubes.

BRISTOL, England, June 11 (AP) -- Jaroslav Drobny of Egypt advanced to the semi-finals of the men's singles in the West of England tennis championships by defeating Australia's Sam Hicks, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2, today.
More than 800 Europe-bound passengers were stranded here last night as the Italian Line canceled the sailing of the 27,000-ton Giulio Cesare. The ship has been marooned by a strike since Tuesday.

A PETITE, white-haired school teacher with bubbling blue eyes and generous smile, the honored guest last night at a dinner marking her forty-three years of teaching here, is one of those rare persons whose given name alone has instant meaning for millions.
Soloists at this summer's Empire State Music Festival will participate in three operatic works and two Russian cantatas.

The embattled residents of Murray Hill won a delaying action yesterday in their campaign to prevent Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack from widening Thirty-sixth and Thirty-seventh Streets between Third and Eleventh Avenues.
The semi-annual report of the Rath Packing Company showed yesterday slightly larger earnings but a decline in sales for the twenty-six weeks ended April 25.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., June 11 -- A 19-year-old Negro co-ed testified today that she had been spirited into the piney woods near here by four white youths and had been raped repeatedly despite her pleas for mercy.

BUENOS AIRES, June 11 -- A delegate of former President Juan D. Peron made public here today a photostatic text purporting to be a heretofore secret pact between President Arturi Frondizi and the former dictator for last year's election.
BOSTON, June 11 -- An explosion wrecked the North Station elevated railroad stop of the Everett-Forest Hills line today.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 11 -- The honeymoon in antibiotic therapy is over in so far as staphylococcal infections are concerned, it was emphasized here today at a scientific session of the American Medical Association's 108th annual meeting.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower signed legislation today authorizing Congress to hold regular joint talks with the Canadian Parliament on common problems facing the two countries.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- The Tuscarora Indians want the Supreme Court to declare their western New York reservation off limits to the New York Power Authority.
Metropolitan dailies in this country are read by an average of two out of three families in their regions, according to a survey by The Richmond (Va.) Times Dispatch and News Leader.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., June 11 (UPI) -- The nose cone of a Thor-Able rocket rose over the South Atlantic early today and landed on its target. However, the Air Force failed to retrieve the cone after its 5,000-mile flight.
The junior welterweight title will be at stake tonight when Kenny Lane of Muskegon, Mich., meets Carlos Ortiz of New York in a twelve-round bout at Madison Square Garden.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 11 -- The outdoor air-conditioning system was working perfectly today for the first time in a week. A cooling wind chased away the heat wave and radically affected the United States Open, which began this morning at testing Winged Foot.

JOHN WAIN, one of the most accomplished and versatile of the younger English writers, has reached a critical point in his exceptionally promising career. It happens to many authors. The early books that won them a gratifying reputation are clever but slight. More of the same will disappoint personal ambition and critical hopes. Somet hing must be done.

The nation's major chain and mail order companies extended their unbroken line of advance in May to twenty-six consecutive months. Last month, according to a survey made yesterday by The New York Times, sales were better by 9.1 per cent than in May, 1958.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 11 -- Douglas Dillon asserted today that the future of the world would depend on the effectiveness of aid to under-developed countries for the next twenty to fifty years.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (UPI) -- The Treasury joined forces with a private manufacturer today to promote sales of United States savings stamps and the manufacturer's products.
Mayor Wagner yesterday called a meeting of labor and hospital officials for tomorrow to discuss the recommendations of his committee to end the five-week hospital strike.
The classic situation that causes inflation is at work in the cotton textile market. Demand is good, but supplies are short, so prices are high and moving higher.

SHELTER ISLAND, N. Y., June 12 -- Skippers of 170 craft dropped anchor in Dering Harbor today after a successful crossing of Long Island Sound. This completed one phase of the Off Soundings Club's twenty-second annual cruise and race.
MONTREAL, June 12 (Canadian Press) -- A threatened walkout by pilots may put a crimp in ceremonies formally opening the St. Lawrence Seaway June 26.
Buyers by the thousands have been in the city for the last two weeks, seeking merchandise for the fall. They liked what they saw, and they bought heavily.
Stamp and coin dealers do not have to obtain licenses as dealers in second-hand merchandise. This ruling was handed down yesterday by Magistrate Maurice E. Downing, sitting in Vehicle Accident Court.

" THE SCANDALOUS SCAMPS,"* by Harold Mehling, carries as subtitle this contribution to the department of amplification and clarification: "A Gallery of American Rogues." And the book is all of that. But I think Mr. Mehling wrote these sketches more in the spirit of an entertainer than a moralist.

Consolidated Edison's earnings prospects on its plant investment of $1,200,000,000 to provide electricity to this city and Westchester County have deteriorated in less than a year. This change was among the important "demonstrated facts" about the company's need for additional revenue that the Public Service Commission majority considered in approving on Thursday a rate increase without delay.
Ten railroads that operate marine equipment in New York harbor have obtained a Federal Court restraining order to prevent three unions from striking their tugboats at 12:01 A. M. Monday.

The Defense Department's "master plan" for air defense, presented to a Congressional committee yesterday, represents a belated and incomplete acknowledgement that today's offense has an increasing advantage over defense.
NORWALK, Conn., June 12 -- The Norwalk League of Women Voters and three other organizations defended their right today to bring pressure on city officials in a school budget controversy.

STOCKHOLM, June 12 (AP) -- A boxing expert watching Ingemar Johansson prepare for the title bout with the world heavyweight champion, Floyd Patterson, has told Swedish readers that the challenger may not be ready for the June 25 bout at the Yankee Stadium in New York.
TOKYO, June 12 (AP) -- The Japanese Government backtracked today and acknowledged that Thomas E. Dewey had not accepted a $200,000 offer to promote the sale of Japanese products in the United States.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Senator J. W. Fulbright said today that there was "a great deal of sentiment" in the Foreign Relations committee for "a serious cut" in this year's foreign aid program.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- House Democrats are considering possible compromises on President Eisenhower's proposals to raise the national debt limit and abolish ceilings on interest rates of Government bonds.

There is ample reason for Governor Rockefeller to convene a special session of the Legislature to name a Speaker of the Assembly to succeed the late Oswald D. Heck. This new Speaker will, of course, be a Republican, and together with the chief party spokesman in the Senate, Walter J. Mahoney, should be available to the Governor throughout the summer and fall in drafting the majority's legislative program for the 1960 session.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- A tan and white puppy died today wedged so tightly in a crevice between two downtown buildings that rescuers could not get him out.

While the House Education and Labor Committee wrestles with the problem, posed by the Kennedy bill, of how far Congress should regulate the internal affairs of labor unions, the Federal Court of Appeals in Washington has rendered a decision that clears the way for court-directed reforms in union procedures where they are needed most -- the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

Transmission of television pictures between Britain and the United States is scheduled to be inaugurated experimentally on Thursday. The images will be sent over the trans-Atlantic cable normally used for international telephone calls.

Mine production of copper throughout the world rose to the highest level in several years last month. And with both domestic and foreign shipments lower than in April, world stocks of the metal at the end of May were the largest since last September.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 12 -- Ferhat Abbas, Premier of the Algerian rebel government, reiterated today his call for French-rebel talks to end the civil war. This time he specified that the talks should be held in Switzerland or Yugoslavia or on neutral ground elsewhere.
Greenwich Village residents held a public celebration last night to mark one of the pedestrian's rare victories over the automobile -- the closing of Washington Square to all but emergency traffic.
HYANNIS, Mass., June 12 -- A conference at New Haven on Monday will seek some means of resuming New York to Cape Cod train service, a Cape Cod Chamber of Commerce official said today.

The Detroit Tigers, tearing lickety-split through the American League ever since that eventful May 3 when Jimmie Dykes took them in hand and showed them which was north and which was south, made another notable advance at the Stadium last night.
Since the beginning of the hospital strike, 635 strikers have applied for welfare benefits.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, June 12 -- The Chinese Communists fired 430 shells today at Nationalist held Kaoteng Island in the Matsu group off the Fukien coast.
Justice Henry Epstein ruled yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan that the strike against five voluntary hospitals here was a "bona fide labor dispute."

BASEL, Switzerland, June 12 -- The Swiss have invested the equivalent of $100,000,000 in ships and docks to make Basel, at an altitude of 900 feet, into a port on the greatest goods highway in Western Europe, the wide and winding castled Rhine.

The delayed offering of $190,000,000 to $195,000,000 of bonds of the Grant County, Wash., Public Utility District Two now is expected to reach the tax-exempt market by negotiation on June 30, the district announced yesterday in Ephrata, Wash.

Adolph Steinberg, president of M. Steinberg Son, textile exporters of 70-72 Leonard Street, has contracted to buy the five-story building on plot 50 by 100 feet at 75-77 Leonard Street for investment.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Opponents of Lewis L. Strauss held the Senate floor today. Meanwhile, it appeared that a vote on his nomination to be Secretary of Commerce would not take place until the week after next.
NEWARK, June 12 -- Agreement was reached here today on contract terms to end a strike begun on May 5 at plants of E. R. Squibb Sons in New Brunswick and Brooklyn.
CARACAS, Venezuela, June 12 -- Venezuela broke off diplomatic relations with the Dominican Republic today.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The Federal Government approved today a $12,000,000 grant for New York City's Penn Station South slum-clearance project.
Carpet leasing is becoming more widely used in solving floor covering problems.

BONN, Germany, June 12 -- Dr. Ludwig Erhard arose in Parliament today to amplify his version of his quarrel with Chancellor Konrad Adenauer. With the air of a man biding his time, the Minister of the Economy declared that he had had no reason to expect Dr. Adenauer's decision to stay on as Chancellor.
LOS ANGELES, June 12 -- Dr. Raymond B. Allen announced his resignation tonight as Chancellor of the University of California's branch here.
NEWARK, June 12 -- Striking employes of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company were warned today against acts of violence and illegal picketing.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., June 12 (AP) -- Streaming smoke, a Polaris test rocket shot over the Atlantic test range today but failed to achieve all its goals.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday he would seek legislation to restrict dealers who sold used automobiles and other merchandise as new products.
Thick fog rolled into the metropolitan area last night and settled quickly over the city, disrupting airports and slowing ferry service in the harbor.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- The Food and Drug Administration plans an investigation into the possible presence of cancer-causing agents in food-container waxes if Congress votes the necessary funds.
Store owners, merchandise representatives and buyers were subjected to a barrage of advice and counsel in the last few days in addition to long hours spent inspecting new lines of Fall apparel.

YONKERS, June 12 -- A long time of favorites won in the fog Yonkers Raceway tonight. At none triumphed so forcefully or with greater ease than a Speedy Pick in the Tarrytown, a $25,000 free-for-all pace.

Joseph Papp, producer of the Shakespeare Festival Company, which has been banned from giving free performances in Central Park, is in the process of setting up a state-wide touring program of the classics.
The Italian liners Vulcania and Giulio Cesare last night were moved from Pier 84, West Forty-fourth Street. The action came to make room for the incoming Independence of the American Export Lines.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- The Navy has been working for more than two years on a guided torpedo with a range greater than any underwater weapon presently operational.

The Raytheon Company, manufacturer of electronics equipment, yesterday announced plans to buy the assets and business of Sorensen Co., Inc., manufacturer of controlled power supply equipment for laboratories and other scientific applications.
Commodity prices moved irregularly yesterday in dull trading. Evening of positions prior to the week-end accounted for most of the volume.
The launching date of the Navy's first nuclear powered surface warship has been advanced a week to avoid an embarrassing conflict with the launching of the world's first atomic merchantman.
New York University announced yesterday that it was planning to reorganize its social service teaching program to relate it more closely with other schools "such as medicine, education and law."

TWO weeks of highly-packed designer showings reached a climax yesterday with the Fashion Group's showing of significant fall trends in American ready-to-wear. About 2,000 men and women from the fashion world packed the Grand Ball room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel at breakfast and luncheon to see the experts' summing up.

LONDON, June 12 (Reuters) -- Following is a summary, based on a report issued by Tass, the official Soviet press agency, of remarks made at the foreign ministers' conference in Geneva today by Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 12 -- Music directors of radio stations in sixteen countries have agreed to an exchange of new orchestral and choral music through the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.
DETROIT, June 12 (AP) -- Four Ford Division auto assembly plants are working six days this week as the production battle between Ford and Chevrolet continues.

GENEVA, June 12 -- The United States presented to the Soviet Union today its scientific study on underground nuclear explosions in the hope of facilitating discussion on an effective international system for policing a test ban.

MOSCOW, June 12 (AP) -- Dr. Billy Graham arrived today on his first visit to Moscow, accompanied by a financial backer and some aides. The United States evangelist said he planned no revival meetings here but would attend Baptist church services Sunday and meet Russian church leaders.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (UPI) -- The House of Representatives passed an Administration-opposed bill today that would set up a Federal commission charged with seeking cures for the depressed coal industry. bill, approved 251 -- 54, now goes to the Senate.

CLEVELAND, June 12 (UPI) -- The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, and the United Rubber Workers Union signed a new master contract today, ending a fifty-eight-day strike by 18,000 workers in eight plants.
The Appellate Division yesterday upheld a lower court's denial of a motion by an official of a "Chenangoes" union to vacate a subpoena by the Waterfront Commission.

The Ryan Aeronautical Company reported yesterday that its sales and earnings for the six months ended April 30 were above the level of the corresponding period last year. The company makes aircraft frames and engine parts.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 12 -- A United Nations scientific group recommended today that a center be created to promote international cooperation in outer space research and exploration.
CHICAGO, June 12 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Contracts awarded for heavy construction work throughout the country in the first twenty-four weeks of this year amounted to $9,309,800,000. This was an increase of 7 per cent over the volume of $8,715,100,000 in the comparable period of 1958.

MANAGUA, / Nicaragua, June 12 (UPI) -- The Government announced today the capture of three rebel invaders in the Olama area of central Nicaragua. The capture brought the total number of rebel prisoners to forty-nine.

" COULD YOU tell me how to store avocados?" -Mr. J. L., New York. Firm avocados can be held for two or three days. They should be stored in a cool place, but not in the refrigerator. Avocados do not prosper at 40 degrees F. or below, the temperature in any refrigerator that is functioning as it should.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- President Eisenhower said today that he hoped before leaving the White House to send Congress a plan that would give the highest Government officials more time in which to think about their jobs.
Mayor Wagner vented his anger yesterday at two Commissioners for defiance of city policy on advertising on vehicles.

A new book by William Carlos Williams will be published Tuesday by McDowell, Obolensky. In "Yes, Mrs. Williams," the poet-physician gives a record of his mother in a series of anecdotes and conversational fragments gathered during her later years. The book is described as "a study of old age, of life in compression with time removed and events recaptured."
One solid right-hand punch just before the bell ending the second round won the world junior welterweight boxing championship for New York's Carlos Ortiz last night.
The market for fixed-interest securities marked time yesterday.
NEWARK, June 12 -- The New Jersey bus industry made a bid today for legislation to abolish reduced student fare rates.
LONDON, June 12 -- Selling pressure, ascribed partly to yesterday's Wall Street sentiment, today reversed the buoyant trend of the stock market here.
PARIS, June 12 (AP) -- Eleven American week-end golfers, lured by dreams of a national title, advanced today to the second round of the French amateur golf championship.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (UPI) -- Ezra Taft Benson rejected today a Congressional request to bolster egg prices by Government purchases of laying hens and eggs from breeding flocks.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- The American Viscose Corporation and Textile Workers Union of America announced today that workers had ratified a three-year labor contract covering 8,000 employes at six company plants.

AN amiable, lack-luster up-state politician has come up with one of the better plums in the New York State government pie. He is Ralph Alvin Lehr of Buffalo, the Republican chairman of Erie County who has been named by Governor Rockefeller to the Public Service Commis sion at $22,000 a year for eight years.
KARACHI, Pakistan, June 12 -- The Pakistani Government decided today to move the capital from Karachi to a place outside Rawalpindi, the army headquarters town 1,000 miles north of here.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The Administration made public today a study by a White House scientific panel calling for further atomic tests to resolve the present uncertainties over detection and concealment of underground nuclear explosions.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Following is the text of the findings of the Administration's Panel on Seismic Improvement:
More than a fourth of the city's elementary and junior high schools have been listed as difficult by the Board of Education.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 12 -- Two hundred persons in Texas are receiving daily doses of the antimalarial drug chloroquine to determine whether skin cancer caused by sunlight can be reduced.
THIS column is devoted to odds and ends that are designed to help make the summer months as pleasant as possible. Each item listed also would make an appropriate gift.
A long, bitter and costly maritime union jurisdictional fight came to an end yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The Administration made known today its plans to reduce spending for defense against possible surprise attack by bombers.
The Protestant Council of the City of New York will move its headquarters this fall to the new $20,000,000 Interchurch Center now under construction at Riverside Drive and 120th Street.
MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 12 -- No one at the United States Open is busier than Gene Hayden, a sturdily built six-footer of 52. Hayden is the caddie master at the Winged Foot Golf Club.
PARIS, June 12 -- Premier Michel Debre appealed again tonight to the railroad unions to call off a strike they have planned for Tuesday.

BECKENHAM, England, June 12 (UPI) -- Alex Olmedo, Peruvian star for the United States Davis Cup team, and Kurt Nielsen of Denmark reached the men's singles final today in the Kent tennis championships by scoring straight-set victories.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- A chivalrous Connecticut welder has come to the aid of women bingo players, whose frantic efforts to keep up with called numbers he has often watched at church affairs. He obtained a patent this week for a device that drops markers on the numbered squares in jig time.

In upholding the recent action of the International Olympic Committee, which almost unanimously voted to expel Nationalist China (the Chiang Kai-shek Government of Formosa) from that sports body, one of your letter writers cited the fact (issue June 6) that the late John Foster Dulles himself advocated the recognition of Communist China under certain conditions.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Following is the text of extemporaneous remarks by President Eisenhower at the senior officer course graduation exercises today at the Foreign Services Institute:

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -The Senate passed today and sent to the White House an omnibus bill designed to put Alaska on an equal footing with the other states. Among other things it gives Alaska grants of $28,500,000 over a five-year period, primarily for road construction and fish and wildlife administration. The Senate acted by agreeing to House language involving only minor technical differences i in their respective bills.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 2 to 8 points (10 to 40 cents a bale) yesterday, except the new October, which dropped 4 points.
MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 12 -- Walter Kolb, president of the Winged Foot Golf Club, does not believe in fiddling while United States Open fans burn.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The Office of Civil and Defense Mobilization ruled today that imports of heavy electrical equipment were not threatening the national security.
The 27-year-old chaplain to Protestant troops serving under Fidel Castro's revolutionary army in Cuba said yesterday that the "climate" for religious resurgence had never been better in that country.

LONDON, June 12 -- The baronies, knighthoods, orders and medals that are Britain's traditional recognition of service to Queen, country and the British way of life have been awarded to nearly 2,400 persons in the Birthday Honors list to be published tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Average wholesale prices in primary markets eased 0.1 per cent to 119.3 per cent of their 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

PHOENIX, Ariz., June 12 -- Are American symphonic audiences too polite? That question was raised at a lively luncheon of the convention of the American Symphony Orchestra League here today. Douglas Moore, one of the composers here, said they were.
ALBANY, June 12 -- Governor Rockefeller today named Ralph A. Lehr, the Erie County Republican chairman, to a $22,000-a-year vacancy on the Public Service Commission.

BARROW - IN - FURNESS, England, June 12 -- Prince Philip laid the symbolic keel of the first British nuclear-powered submarine today. He praised "astonishing achievements" of the United States that hastened Britain's entry into a new age of underwater sea power.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- President Eisenhower nominated six Air Force major generals today for promotion to lieutenant generals.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- New York's Congressional steering committee wants the Government to ship more grain through the Port of New York.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 12 (AP) -- School officials assigned eleven Negroes to two white public schools for the fall term today. This will bring a court-approved assignment plan into play for the first time.

GALVESTON, Tex., June 12 (UPI) -- Gov. Earl K. Long of Louisiana charged today in a court petition that he had been drugged in Louisiana and brought to a Galveston mental hospital tied hand and foot. He asked a court to order him released.
PITTSBURGH, June 12 (UPI) -- Norm Larker's bases-loaded pinch single scored two runs in the ninth inning tonight and led the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 9-6 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

CHICAGO, June 12 (AP) -- Grain futures made a good general recovery today in the most active session of the week on the Board of Trade. Several contracts in oats, rye and barley finished with gains of a cent or more a bushel.
F. S. Associates, builders and realty investors, have assembled a plot of land on Merritt Avenue, north of East 233d Street, the Bronx, for improvement with a one-story office and warehouse building.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (UPI) -- The Public Health Service reported today that the level of radioactivity in milk samples showed an increase in March in all but two of ten sampling stations.
BABYLON, L. I., June 12 -- Bids are expected to be accepted at Albany soon for the construction of four miles of approach roadway for Sunrise Highway's new six-lane bridge at the Shinnecock Canal.

BOSTON, June 12 -- Often we tend to regard the contest between capitalism and communism in terms of white and black without remembering the mutual effect these rival systems have upon each other. Extreme conservatives here indeed bemoan as "socialistic" the spread of collective bargaining, unemployment insurance, pensions and state intrusion into power and communications.
LONDON, June 12 (AP) -- France and Italy took 2-0 leads today in the European zone quarter-finals of the Davis Cup tennis competition against Rumania and South Africa, respectively.

A survey of the nation's top salaried business men was released today. For last year, a steel man, Arthur B. Homer, president of the Bethlehem Steel Company, topped the list of executives receiving more than $300,000 a year in salary and bonus.
Gunmen stole $10,432 in four hold-ups here yesterday.
The four-year search for oil in the deserts of Libya is beginning to pay off.

TOKYO, June 12 -- Japanese shipping companies have suspended all service to South Korea and the Government has warned fishing craft in Korean waters to be on their guard against seizure by South Korean patrol craft.
THE chair that isn't there will be revealed at Chicago's Merchandise Mart on Monday.
GENEVA, June 12 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of a speech made today by Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd of Britain at the foreign ministers conference here:
VALPARAISO, Ind., June 12 (UPI) -- Tommy Morango, a taciturn witness at a Senate rackets committee hearing, was jailed today on charges of offering bribes to run gambling and prostitution in Indiana.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The House is expected to give overwhelming approval Monday to the major veterans pension bill approved by the Veterans Committee yesterday.
HATTERAS, N. C., June 12 -- The Jones family has been giving a hard time to blue marlin lately in a non-professional, personal way.

Plans are near completion for one of the most ambitious educational film programs ever undertaken by a non-theatrical motion-picture producer. Under a grant from the Ford Foundation's Fund for the Advancement of Education, Encyclopaedia Britannica Films will produce and distribute a series of 140 half-hour color movies as a complete course in the humanities for eleventh-grade classes.

BOSTON, June 12 -- The authorities decided today that black powder caused the explosion that injured thirty-eight persons yesterday at the Metropolitan Transit Authority elevated waiting room in North Station.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 12 (AP) -- Capt. Slade Cutter, Navy's colorful and controversial athletic director for the past two years, will leave the Naval Academy this summer for command duty at sea.

INTEREST in the Nineteen Twenties is beginning to extend beyond the antics of showgirls, stockmarket plungers and gangsters. Art during those years, if not exactly in one of its major creative phases, at least boasted a large number of painters, many of whom have been unfairly overlooked of late.

Some twenty state legislatures have recently made appropriations for state-supported higher education for the ensuing fiscal period. It appears that in general the amounts designated for operating expenses by the states which appropriate for a biennium, or two fiscal years, exceed those for the biennium now coming to a close by about one-fifth.
Almost 1,200 Liberty ships, the logistics backbone of the Allies in World War II, have been written off as weapons in the United States arsenal. According to the Navy they possess scrap value only.
Over the opposition of the Buildings Department, Alexander J. Clarke obtained adjournment of the department's case against the tenement at 120 West 116th Street in Housing Court yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Governor Rockefeller discussed "mutual legislative problems" with President Eisenhower today to wind up a visit to the capital.
New financing in the public capital market will take a sharp drop next week.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (UPI) -- The number claiming unemployment benefits dropped almost to the pre-recession level at the end of May, the Department of Labor reported today.

The Ford Motor Company announced yesterday that it had received tenders of more than 540,000 shares of class A and class B stock of the Ford Motor Company of Canada, Ltd. The United States company last June 3 offered to buy up to a maximum of 775,628 shares of the A and 30,208 shares of the B stock of the Canadian company at $188 a share for both classes.
Your June 11 editorial "Opinions 1957 and 1959" is a perceptive analysis of the impact of the Baren blatt case on the Watkins decision of two years ago.
Stocks made a moderate gain yesterday but the three-day rally fell from a boil to a simmer.
TRIVANDRUM, India, June 12 -- Anti-Communist demonstrations swept Kerala today.
MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 12 -- Big Bill Casper Jr. of Apple Valley, Calif., who likes to play golf in a relaxed manner, took the lead in the United States Open championship today.

HAVANA, June 12 -- Sharp disagreements between Premier Fidel Castro and key figures of his Government, principally over the new agrarian reform law, have resulted in the first major rupture of revolutionary unity since former President Fulgencia Batista fled Cuba last Dec. 31.
The controversy over the impounding of a grand jury presentment dealing with improper manipulation of television quiz shows continued yesterday.
The Cabinet crisis affecting five ministries confronts Fidel Castro with a challenge and an opportunity. A shake-up was due after five months, and fresh minds may well bring new vigor and efficiency.

OCEANPORT, N. J., June 12 -- The Brookfield Farm's entry of Itobe and Isendu ran one, two today in the $17,625 Oceanport Handicap, opening-day feature of Monmouth Park's fifty-day meeting. Sammy Boulmetis rode the winner and Larry Gilligan was on the second horse.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 12 (AP) -- A London banker urged the United States tonight to broaden its foreign banking and trade. He said he believed that the height of American influence in the world had not yet been reached.

The 171-member wage policy committee of the United Steelworkers unanimously empowered the union's officers yesterday to call a strike or take any other action necessary to win a "fair" contract June 30.

Reynolds Co., stock brokers and investment bankers, have leased space in the new building at 2 Broadway, facing Bowling Green. Bertram F. French of Cushman Wakefield, Inc., was the broker. The lessees will move their main office from 120 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (UPI) -- Speaker Sam Rayburn named today a twelve-member House delegation that will hold talks with a delegation of the Canadian Parliament at the St. Lawrence Seaway late this month.

The city's historic past vied with its vigorous present and its military insurance for the future during a parade last night celebrating the 350th anniversary of the ex plorations of Henry Hudson on the Hudson River.
Bette Davis will make one of her rare appearances in a television drama on the new "June Allyson Show" series next season.

VIENNA, June 12 -- Chancellor Julius Raab offered his Socialist rivals today the Ministry of Finance, the most powerful office in the Austrian Cabinet, if they would restore the two-party government coalition.

LINCOLN, Neb., June 12 -- Boston University's John Lawlor distinguished today's deck-clearing trials of the thirty-eighth annual National Collegiate track and field championships by setting a meet record in the hammer throw.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower assured the leaders of three European economic and scientific alliances today that the United States would continue to support the alliances as bulwarks of free world progress.
NEW LONDON, Conn., June 12 -- Harvard's undefeated varsity eight-oared crew is favored to end Yale's string of five victories tomorrow in their four-mile race downstream on the Thames.

GENEVA, June 12 -- The United States, Britain and France told Mayor Willy Brandt of West Berlin today that they would not try to influence the decision on where the West German Presidential election should be held.

For the third month in succession -- the month ended at mid-May -- unemployment declined at a rate exceeding seasonal expectations. The April-May drop in the number of jobless was 238,000 or, according to officials of the Labor Department, roughly "twelve times the customary rate looked for in this period."

Some thoroughbred trainers, aided or even encouraged by the prediction of rain, are not afraid to send their horses against any opposition. They don't even fear Sword Dancer, or Royal Orbit, or Black Hills.
ROME, June 12 -- A proposal to approve the mission of worker priests in France and the church's attitude to politics in Italy are under discussion in the Vatican.

Directors of the Wells Fargo Bank, at their meeting in San Francisco yesterday, voted a two-for-one stock split and declared a 10 per cent stock dividend. The action is contingent on approval by shareholders at a special meeting on July 30 of a change in par value of the stock to $10 from $20 and issuance of additional shares.
MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., June 12 -- Monkeys, mice and sea urchins have been in the news recently for their contributions to medical knowledge. Now it's fireflies.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Democrats, aided by twelve Midwestern Republicans, pushed through the House of Representatives today a wheat bill opposed by the Administration.

The Wrangling Season Students of American history will agree that the season for political wrangling never closes. Paradoxically, however, political abuse in a free country is not a sign of decadence but of vitality. If we were living under a dictatorship, no matter how camouflaged, there would be no open quarrels, no open criticism of the head man and his sanctioned spokesmen.
MOSCOW, June 12 -Christian Dior showed its spring and summer fashion collection to Moscow today. Whether the House of Dior or Moscow will ever be quite the same again is an open question.

Puerto Rico's first rice mill, a $2,000,000 venture, will be established by the Rice Growers Association of California, Sacramento, it was announced here yesterday by the Commonwealth's Economic Development Administration.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., June 12 -- An 18-year-old high school senior testified tonight that he and three other youths took a Negro co-ed away from her date's car after flashing a shotgun and a switch-blade knife.

The postponed annual meeting of H. L. Green Company, variety chain, will be held at the Commodore Hotel next Wednesday at 11 A. M. This was announced yesterday by Joseph H. Unger, president of H. L. Green, following a decision by the Appellate Division that vacated an injunction issued by Supreme Court Justice Samuel M. Gold against holding the meeting, as had been planned, on May 27.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 13 -- It was a strange sight. Spectators crowded behind the restraining ropes from the first tee all the way down the fairway as far as the eye could see. The sun blazed from a cloudless sky. The setting seemed ideal for the final day of the United States Open.
BETHANY, Conn., June 13 -- An old argument is going on here, after a few rounds of skeet shooting: Can a good game shooter be a poor skeet shooter and vice versa.
A West Side citizens committee is seeking the support of war veteran organizations to have the Soldiers and Sailors monument at Riverside Drive and Eighty-ninth Street replaced instead of restored.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 13 -- You have to scratch around to find an Alabama steel worker who wants to strike this year.

TRANSFER bids have been perhaps the most controversial of the new bidding conventions in contract bridge. The purpose of a transfer bid is to transfer the contract -- that is, the right to be declarer -- from one partner to the other.
Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold's decision to go to Cairo at the end of June is another sign of the increasing tension between Israel and the United Arab Republic.

ALGIERS. THE Algerian rebellion goes on -- four and a half years after it began and more than a year after the political crisis it caused brought General de Gaulle to power amid a surge of hope for a way out. Two aspects of the cruel struggle -- in the countryside and in the great city of Algiers -- are shown in the photographs on these and the following pages.

WE are building "Fantasyland" in Gettysburg. Yes, there is construction ahead, the construction of a beautiful, clean, storybook "Land of Make Believe." It will be fabulous and a credit to this community.

President Eisenhower's proposals for raising the Federal debt limit and removing the ceiling on interest rates of Treasury bonds are viewed in the financial district as necessary moves for putting the Government's financial affairs in an up-to-date framework.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (UPI) -- Former President Harry S. Truman will be the main speaker at a fund-raising dinner in Boston on Sept. 19 for Matthew J. Connelly, his former appointments secretary.

HAVANA, June 13 (UPI) -- Two young Americans who arrived here on a yacht were arrested on charges of illegal possession of firearms and released "conditionally" after questioning a United States Embassy spokesman said today.
A study to prevent discrimination against students in offcampus housing accommodations will be made by the State Commission Against Discrimination.
ROME, June 13 -- Jim McGregor is a 37-year-old American whose passions are coaching basketball and seeing the world. What makes McGregor unusual is that he is able to do both simultaneously.

MOSCOW, June 13 -- Dr. Billy Graham, American evangelist, stood in the heart of the Kremlin today and looked up at the great golden crosses topping the bulbous turrets of the ancient churches there.

UP to now Van Cliburn has been primarily associated with two piano concertos -- the Tchaikovsky B flat minor and the Rachmaninoff No. 3 in D minor. His recording of the former has been out for some time now, and at last account it had sold enough copies to come near paying off the national debt.
I refer to Arthur Daley's column in the June 5 Times, in which he deplores the recent decision to play two All-Star baseball games.

BONN, Germany, June 13 -- In all the fury over Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's bald determination to hang on to his dominating leadership, no one has bothered to recall how he got to the head of the table in the first place.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Sunday, June 14 -- Four white youths were convicted early today of raping a 19-year-old Negro co-ed. The jury recommended mercy, thus sparing their lives. The jury had deliberated nearly three hours.
A rush is on to bring to market the shares of savings and loan holding companies.

PARIS, June 13 -- The Government published a decree today "requisitioning" the services of 150,000 to 175,000 employes of the nationalized French railways who have threatened to halt all trains between 4 A. M. and noon Tuesday.

Progress in clinical medicine was reported by 450 physicians in scientific papers, in symposia and in panel discussions at the annual meeting of the American Medical Association last week.

FOR any garden hobbyist with a reasonably protected site, growing some of the exotic rhododendrons can be a rewarding experience. These somewhat tender rhododendrons have a color range rarely seen in hardy types -- rich scarlet, clear yellow, apricot, glowing orange.

There will be no official team champion in the Eastern States interscholastic track and field championships until Friday. That was determined when a driving rain curtailed the program with two events to be completed yesterday at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.
ELLSWORTH, Wis., June 13 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota began a three-day cross-state campaign today to collect funds and build support for his Presidential aspirations.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 13 -- Thirteen young women were presented to society at the annual Greenwich Debutante Ball tonight at the Greenwich Country Club. The debutantes were also honored by their parents at private dinner parties before the ball.
BUFFALO, June 13 -- Although steel workers are ready to strike if necessary, they have serious reservations. Unemployment is still a serious problem on the Niagara Frontier.

Two record javelin throws were made yesterday during qualifying rounds of the third annual National Wheelchair Games at Bulova Park, Jackson Heights, Queens. Two other meet records were broken before rains brought the preliminaries to a halt.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, June 12 -- However the present revolutionary situation in Nicaragua resolves itself, the Somoza famly has never been closer to expulsion from political power since the family succession was founded in 1936.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., June 13 -- Two debutantes were presented to society tonight in the first parties of the "little season" on Long Island. There will be dinners and dances almost every night on the North Shore at clubs or at country homes.

MIAMI -- Dade County, in which the Greater Miami area is situated, has launched a long-range highway program to improve traffic conditions hereabouts. TEHERAN, Iran, June 13 (Reuters) -- The Iranian Foreign Minister and he Ministers of the Interior and Commerce have been replaced in a Cabinet shake-up announced on the return of Mohammed Shah Riza Pahlevi from a month's tour of Europe.
The Yankees managed to bring down Jimmie Dykes' rampant Tigers at the Stadium yesterday for their 1,000th victory under Casey Stengel. They did it with three homers and an assist from the weather.

PAINT should never be applied in an excessively thick film -- particularly when outside paint is being used. Too thick a coat will prevent proper drying and will almost certainly result in wrinkling of the finish as it dries. To avoid this, brush the paint out sufficiently, and apply a second coat if the first one fails to cover adequately.

To simplify sharpening of lawnmowers and other cutting tools here is a compound which permits tools to actually sharpen themselves. WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Whether it is the news from Geneva or just the first hot breath of summer is hard to say. But certainly the mood in Washington has become more stubborn.
