A SIMPLIFIED but adequate technique, plus a neatness in the organization of his material, combine to give this replay of the battle of Gettysburg by first-novelist Don Robertson the qualities of crisp excitement, clarity about convulsive events, unfaltering momentum.

THE appended list of murder novels for summer reading offers a high proportion of women writers: eight of them to five men -- a happy accidental example of the Golden Mean. And I think this illustrates an important current trend in mystery writing.
NORWALK, Conn., June 13 -An apology from the British general who burned this town to the ground has at last been received here.
A majority of the city's voluntary nonprofit hospitals are ready to accept, with reservations, the recommendations of Mayor Wagner's mediation board for settlement of the hospital strike.

JUNE is the month of roses, weddings, garden parties and graduations. But to suburban dwellers it is also the time when long twilight evenings are illuminated by the flashing lights of countless fireflies.

GENEVA, Jun 13 -- No international meeting is really considered genuine until it has lived through a crisis. The conference of foreign ministers here proved it was a real, blown-in-the-bottle article this week when a crisis of formidable proportions threatened the meeting with anything from breakdown to enforced recess.

NORTH HACKENSACK, N.J., June 13 -- Seventy-five men, women and children, members of the Bergen County Historical Society, became amateur archeologists today at the site of the 1739 von Steuben house, on Old Bridge Road. They uncovered the solid brick floor of what they believe was the old smokehouse.
WASHINGTON, June l3 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower has told a Virginia Congressman that an official version of The Star-Spangled Banner would be a "desirable" thing for the nation.

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo Republic, June 13 (Reuters) -- This internally self-governing state within the French Community will vote tomorrow in a general election that is expected to give the Government a large majority.

HOBOKEN, N. J., June 13 -- Nothing short of all-out nuclear war can turn man aside from extraordinary accomplishments in the next fifty years, Dr. Walker Lee Cisler, president of the Detroit Edison Company said today.

The fast-rolling truck piloted by James R. Hoffa ran into a steel wall last week, The unanimous decision of the United States Court of Appeals, upholding the right of court-appointed monitors to force a cleanup of the giant International Brotherhood of Teamsters, represents the most severe setback the cocky union chief has suffered since he swaggered out of a Detroit grocery warehouse twenty-five years ago.
Transforming B. J. Chute's best-selling novel, "Greenwillow," into a Broadway musical will no longer be a one-man job.
" Walk.- Don't Walk" signals will soon blink their green and red safety messages at 100 additional intersections, it was announced yesterday.

TRIVANDRUM, India, June 14 -- One hundred thirty-seven persons were arrested in a school demonstration today on the eve of possible intensification of the struggle between Communist and non-Communist forces in the state of Kerala.
Adequate vacant land should be set aside for recreation on Staten Island, New York's "last frontier," while the land is still available, the City Planning Commission said yesterday.

ADELAIDE, Australia, June 14 -- A young American arrived here after an all-night drive from the opal field at Andamooka, 400 miles north of this city, with an opal matrix that he hoped might be valued at 1,500,000 Australian [$3,320,000] when cut.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 14 -- Performing with little more concern for the outcome, it seemed, than a man playing a casual round of golf with the duffer next door, Bill Casper won a dramatic but wind-blown United States Open championship at Winged Foot today. Some of his golf was of about the same pattern as a neighborly round, too.
For the third consecutive month customs receipts in the Port of New York rose by a third over the comparable 1958 figures.

After twenty-five years as presiding justice of the Domestic Relations Court, John Warren Hill has decided that the decline in the spanking of children has caused much of today's juvenile delinquency.

BOSTON, June 14 (UPI) -- Ted Williams was benched for weak hitting for the first time in his long major league career today before the Boston Red Sox defeated the Kansas City Athletics, 6 -- 1, behind the five-hit pitching of a rookie right-hander, Jerry Casale.

Matters of the Heart It is very important, we are told, to encourage the affectionate impulses of a little girl who has reached the independent age of 6. This is the time when she is discovering the strange and fond ways of her own heart.
The possibility that the city might drop its proposed "meter maid" program appeared yesterday.

Christopher Dawson, Professor of Roman Catholic Studies at Harvard University, told the graduating class at St. John's University yesterday that the work of Roman Catholic colleges was of vital importance to American culture.
The offices of the charitable health agencies abound with piteous and appealing pictures of children and adults in the grip of disease or on the road to recovery.
Many New Yorkers, after experiencing a sweltering week in the city, shivered at the shore yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Two national teen-age trends, a rise in the number of unmarried mothers and increased incidence of venereal disease, are being urged as discussion topics for the 1960 White House Conference on Children and Youth.
Maurice Evans will star in "The Tempest" on the "Hallmark Hall of Fame" series next season.

BALTIMORE, June 14 (UPI) -- Al Smith's two out single in the tenth inning enabled the Chicago White Sox to gain a 3-2 victory over Baltimore today. Early Wynn won his ninth game by beating the Orioles in the opener, 9 -- 6.
VALLETTA, Malta, June 14 -- Dom Mintoff, former Prime Minister of Malta, intends to appeal to the United States for "aid without strings" to make this fortress island independent.
HONG KONG, June 14 -- Indications that Communist China might fail this year in achieving certain announced production goals appeared recently in an official party publication.
LONDON, June 10 -- "Thou shalt not call upon, write to or telephone a client of a fellow member to solicit his account."

FOR nearly half a century, mothers and children have made their way to Best's Liliputian Barber Shop for the first of a lifetime of haircuts. To commemorate this epic event, the store provides a small pink or blue edged card with the child's name on it and a lock of baby hair attached with a pretty ribbon bow.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 14 -- The New United States Open champion is a relaxed golfer. Bill Casper Jr. of Apple Valley, Calif., proved it by winning today under unusual conditions at the Winged Foot Golf Club.

PITTSBURGH, June 14 -- Steel shipments are scheduled at record levels for this week, and there is little chance that they will be off from those levels next week. The pressure for delivery covers all types of steel. But in recent weeks the demand for structurals, bars and heavy plates has been up somewhat.
Chicago Helicopter Airways has signed an agreement to buy three Sikorsky S-61 helicopters -- single-rotored craft that will carry twenty-five passengers at speeds up to 150 miles an hour.
The average size of New York City families has been dropping steadily since the end of the last century, the City Planning Commission reported yesterday.

Business activity in New York State continued to rise in April, Keith S. McHugh, State Commerce Commissioner, announced yesterday. He said that durable goods manufacturing industries, in particular, showed strength.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The Organization of American States sent a fact-finding commission to Central America today to check on Nicaragua's charges that she was a victim of external aggression.
TWO soft-spoken Englishmen are teaching judo to rough and tumble youngsters on the Lower East Side.
Cotton futures prices last week were mostly easier.

The approach of Borough President Jack to traffic policy shows a curious lack of consistency. On the one hand he has said that he will support the program of engineers who favor widening narrow side streets in midtown. On the other hand the reports of engineers apparently do not impress him when it comes to extending one-way avenues that the experts consider even more essential to widespread traffic relief and pedestrian safety.
SALIDA, Colo., June 14 (AP) -- Laurence Campton of Salida shot rapids and dodged boulders in the Arkansas River as he won the 25.7-mile downriver white water race before 30,000 spectators today.

Moscow has seldom spilled more arrogant nonsense than it did on Friday, when Tass revealed that "in the opinion of the Soviet Government there is no foundation for any link between the results of the Geneva conference and the convening of a summit meeting."
Three teen-age boys were shot yesterday, one fatally, in apparently unrelated incidents. Two were believed to involve gang warfare.

Colombia is no longer dependent on imports for its supply of textiles and in fact is building up a small reserve. This was reported last week by Carlos J. Echavarria, president of Compania Colombiana de Tejidos, S. A., Colombia.
Two who have spent a long time at sea will raise their glasses on Wednesday in a silent champagne toast to "home."

The United States is experiencing a "strange paradox of moral decline and religious revival," the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell said yesterday in a sermon at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.

LONDON, June 14 -- The stock market here was dull and indecisive last week. Doubts arising from irregular and featureless trading in Wall Street were reflected here in erratic price movements with an over-all downward trend and in reduced activity.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 14 -- Bill Casper Jr., a former caddie and the new United States Open golf champion, likes baseball, chocolate tapioca pudding topped with ice cream and an occasional beer or Scotch. He doesn't smoke.
PARIS, June 14 (AP) -- Henri de Lamaze, the defending champion in the French amateur Golf tournament, today gained the final along with Paul Coste, an American school teacher at an Air Force base.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The founder of the American Liberty League is backing Vice President Richard M. Nixon's campaign for President in the hope he will curb labor unions.
" Progress is the result of pain and pain is the result of sin," Bishop William J. Walls said yesterday. "Men do not move forward until they feel the pain of sin and move to relieve it."
The May Department Stores Company raised sales and earnings in the quarter ended April 30 from the level of the 1958 period, Morton D. May, president, reported in a statement released today.
Johns-Manville Corporation has not yet made a decision as to what agency will handle its more than $2,000,000-a-year billings in the future.

The current steel dispute is being argued in terms of a family quarrel. The union claims, and management does not deny, that the steel industry operates at a very high rate of profit. The issue turns entirely on the distribution of the profit margin between labor and capital.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, June 14 -- The Government will probably have to cut its spending almost in half to finish the fiscal year in September in a solvent condition.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., June 14 -- Two years ago a state prosecutor stood before a jury made up mostly of farmers in an ancient courtroom and asked it to convict a Negro boy for having raped a white housewife.

LANGHORNE, Pa., June 14 -- Van Johnson of Bally, Pa., drove a Jacob Vargo Special to victory today in the 100-mile championship car race on the one-mile dirt track here. He averaged 99.005 miles an hour.
The population of the twenty-one-ccunty tri-state New York region increased 14 per cent between 1950 and 1958, the Metropolitan Regional Council reported yesterday.

ZURICH, June 14 -- Depressing news from Geneva had no visible effect on the Stock Exchange last week. All loan issues were oversubscribed, including the 4 1/2 per cent 45,000,000 - franc Swedish Ericsson Telephone Company loan offered at par and selling on Friday at a small premium.
The United Steelworkers of America put on television yesterday its version of how its members feel about the deadlocked negotiations for a new steel-wage agreement.

Casey Stengel, whose Yankees had presented him with his 1,000th victory as their manager on Saturday, was still waiting for his first triumph in the second thousand as the shadows lengthened at the Stadium yesterday. He waited in vain despite two chances.

President Ayub Khan has announced some new political plans for Pakistan. The original Constitution was abrogated when the military forces took over the Government last October. Now, the first steps will be taken that will lead to a new Constitution along somewhat different lines.
WITH June come the summer variety replacement shows that put the accent on song relieved by an occasional production number of modest pretensions.

MANHATTAN is a pillar of impermanence. It sometimes seems there never has been a city more dedicated to change and markedly determined to replace its patina with glitter and glass. From the Battery to the Bronx, the tempo of the city is the staccato beat of a riveting machine.

PHILADELPHIA, June 14 -- First place beckoned, but the Giants paid no heed today at Connie Mack Stadium. The San Franciscans participated in a great giveaway program, giving both ends of a double-header to the Phillies, who made the most of four unearned runs in each contest and won, 7 -- 5 and 6 -- 3.

Two five-story apartment buildings for forty families at 1052-56 Sheridan Avenue, the Bronx, were sold by Irving Solomon to a client of Alvin Heller for cash over mortgages amounting to $62,000. The houses occupy a plot 80 by 100 feet. The Philip Fogel Company was the broker.
Luxembourg, one of those places invariably described as "tiny," is thinking in some rather big terms these days.

BONN, Germany, June 14 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer appealed to the United States today to stand fast by Europe. Without American help, he said the free part of Europe will be drawn into the Russian current.

LINCOLN, Neb., June 14 -- The minor portion of its total available talent on display in yesterday's National Collegiate championships showed the United States to be strongly fortified for next month's track and field duel with the Soviet Union and the Pan-American games later in the summer.
OMAHA, June 14 (AP) -- Toby Bensinger"s perfect relief job helped Oklahoma State beat Penn State, 8 -- 6, tonight in a battle of the undefeated in the National Collegiate baseball tournament.
Seven films are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
Baltic leaders urged free nations last night to demand immediate withdrawal of Soviet troops from "captive countries" and to help restore their independence.

An exciting exchange of goals in the last forty seconds provided the big moments yesterday as the Dundee Blues of Scotland struggled to a 3-all tie with Legia of Poland in a soccer game at Ebbets Field.
NEW DELHI, India, June 14 (AP) -- The Prime Ministers of India and Nepal declared today that "no country should be dominated by another" -- and indicated this applied to Tibet.
The bible of the investment companies will make its annual bow today.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI) -- The Government published plans today for a series of atom bomb shelters. They range from a $150 economy model to a $1,500 job and including three do-it-yourself styles.
The appointment of Fred M. Hechinger as education editor of The New York Times, effective July 1, was announced yesterday by Turner Catledge, managing editor.
Five hundred persons are to attend a dinner dance aboard the French liner Liberte tonight as the vessel cruises the harbor.

WHEN foreigners write about the Irish, as T. H. White did in his recently published "The Godstone and the Blackymore," they generally do so in a state of affectionate bafflement. They brood about inconsistencies and paradoxes in what they consider the Irish national character and they beam fondly on picturesque customs, ecoentrio individuals, superstitions and all kinds of oddities.
STRATFORD, Conn., June 14 -- Please, more fire! The script is "Romeo and Juliet" with which the American Shakespeare Festival opened its fifth season Friday evening.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, June 14 -- The two-week-old revolution to oust the Government of President Luis A. Somoza Debayle apparently ended today with the arrival of sixty-one rebel prisoners and a triumphant military parade through the capital.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The Democratic Advisory Council attacked the Republicans today and also the Democratic leadership in Congress.

The Eastern Life Insurance Company of New York has leased a floor in the new building at 355 Lexington Avenue, at the corner of Fortieth Street, for its main office. The office is now at 386 Fourth Avenue.

We would like to correct the false impression created by the background material appended to the report of your Moscow correspondent Osgood Caruthers "Year in Moscow Rewarding" (May 11), which had the effect of demeaning our heroic feats in raising higher the banner of American basketball.

A sparse audience dotted Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon to hear a jazz concert offered as a memorial to Sidney Bechet. It was announced during the concert that proceeds would go toward the establishment of a Sidney Bechet Cancer Fund. Mr. Bechet died of cancer in Paris May 15.

Among the general policy objectives contained in the Employment Act of 1946 was the objective of "economic growth." How such an objective was to be achieved was not spelled out. It couldn't very well have been spelled out, since we had no precedent to which to turn for guidance.

KENOSHA, Wis., June 14 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey announced today a major step in his campaign to gain support for his Presidential aspirations -- the formation of the first Humphrey-for-President organization.
American Protestantism paid tribute yesterday to the late John Foster Dulles at a memorial service in the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Ninety-first Street.
GUATEMALA, June 14 (AP) -- Legal proceedings seeking expropriation of lands owned by the United Fruit Company at Izabal in northern Guatemala were ordered today by President Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., June 14 -- The conviction early today of four white youths who had raped a Negro college girl drew mixed reaction as to its implications for the equality of Southern justice.

LONDON, June 14 -- "Magnificent," "splendid," "fascinating,'' "valuable" and "most welcome" were among the adjectives used by British headmasters to describe the study kits on United States Government sent to them by the Hansard Society for Parliamentary Government.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- A Democratic poll on the nomination of Lewis L. Strauss to be Secretary of Commerce showed today that Mr. Strauss will probably be confirmed by a narrow margin.

THE trans-Atlantic transmission of television newsreel film over an international telephone cable, now scheduled for Thursday morning, may easily prove to be one of this decade's most significant advances in the art of communications.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 14 -- The value of the Indonesian rupiah has dropped to a new low on the black market here.

This year's winner of the Stanley Playwriting Award is Patrolman Gene Radano, a warrant officer attached to the Lower Manhattan Magistrates Courts. He will receive a prize of $500 for his full-length drama, "The Apple Doesn't Fall."

Tippetts - Abbett - McCarthy - Stratton, engineers, have been authorized to make a preliminary study of a l00-acre tract of land in the Flatlands section of Brooklyn that is being considered as the site for an industrial park.
The employment of a firm of engineering specialists to prepare plans for an industrial park in the Flatlands section of Brooklyn was announced by the city's Urban Renewal Board yesterday.

BURLINGTON, Vt., June 14 -- The University of Vermont awarded degrees to 520 undergraduates and forty-six graduate students today. Forty medical degrees also were presented at the commencement exercise.
ALBANY, June 14 -- Governor Rockefeller announced today the reactivation of the State Defense Council.

Because of the succession of tragedies attributable to plastic film wrapping bags, use of the good offices of The New York Times is being made to contribute to the public and the cleaning trades a simple and inexpensive method of eliminating the suffocation hazards inherent in this kind of packaging.

CHICAGO, June 14 -- "To most women, storage space is more important than style; to most men, comfort is more important than design," a speaker said today at the first press meeting at the International Home Furnishings Market.

LIMA, Peru, June 14 -- The rebellion against the policies of the International Monetary Fund begun last week by Brazil may have far-reaching effects on all the organization's relationships in Latin America.
GENEVA, June 14 -- The foreign ministers of the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union will reassemble tomorrow for a critical phase of their conference.

HANOVER, N. H., June 14 -- Dr. Charles Malik of Lebanon, President of the United Nations General Assembly, urged college graduates today to take the moral responsibility for turning back the tide of communism.
Major domestic airlines have reported substantial increases in business in the first months of 1959.
The incidence of murder, assault and rape has been cut 49 per cent since 1957 in five city areas of lawlessness by new and more brilliant street lighting.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Ceilings on the national debt and on Government bond interest rates are out of date, and worse, according to a study to be published this week by the Brookings Institution.

GALVESTON, Tex., June 14 (UPI) -- Gov. Earl K. Long of Louisiana, confined in a mental ward here, charged in an interview today that his wife and his political associates had conspired to spirit him out of Louisiana.
An exchange of bitter statements threatened yesterday to prolong the hospital strike. The dispute came on the eve of acceptance by the hospitals of a peace plan sponsored by Mayor Wagner.
MOSCOW, June 14 -- The Rev. Dr. Billy Graham joined Moscow Baptists in their Sunday devotions today and called their faith in God "a light burning for which we all should be thankful."
A new study shows that the movement of Negroes to the suburbs has been more rapid than that of the general population.

NEW HAVEN, June 14 -- The Yale University Alumni Fund has passed the $2,000,000 mark for 1958-59, A. Whitney Griswold, university president, reported at the alumni reunion luncheon today. He said this was a record.
PRINCETON, N. J., June 14 -- A total of $10,191,000 has been received in gifts and commitments in the Fifty-three Million Dollars for Princeton University campaign.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., June 14 -- Union College graduated 224 upperclassmen today. Frederick R. Kappel, president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, was installed as honorary chancellor of Union College and University for 1959-60.
IN June, the traditional month for weddings, many questions arise concerning proper attire for the bride and bride-groom.

The productivity of the United States economy has been increasing at an even greater rate in recent years than in the period before the second World War, the National Bureau of Economic Research reported yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 14 -- The most nonchalant rebel in the movie world celebrated his debut the other day as an author by sneering jauntily at Hollywood's two most important rules for autobiographies.

MASTIC BEACH, L. I., June 14 -- Suffolk County's $2,500,000 Smith Point Bridge, the first to be built from the mainland to the resort barrier beach of Fire Island, will be opened to the public on July 4.

YALTA. On the steps of Livadia Palace, once the summer home of Russia's last Czar and in 1945 President Roosevelt's residence during the Yalta Conference, a group of Pioneers, the Soviet boy and girl scouts, were assembled to greet me when I drove up.
DUBLIN, June 14 -- The largest demonstration in Ireland today had nothing whatever to do with the Presidential election to be held Wednesday.
The steamship charter market resumed its downward trend last week after a fortnight of holding steady at slightly higher levels.
ATLANTA, June 14 -- Law and order have deteriorated in the South since the United States Supreme Court's outlawing of school segregation, a report by three agencies said today.
LONDON, June 14 (AP) -- Spain joined England, Italy and France in the semi-final round of the European zone Davis Cup tennis competition today by eliminating Brazil at Barcelona.
A British scientist has calculated that if men had wings they could fly.
The Navy's crack team of aerobatic pilots, the Blue Angels, staged a demonstration off the Boardwalk at Coney Island yesterday that made the Cyclone roller coaster seem dull by comparison.

The recently released study of the problems of the metropolitan area conducted by Harvard University for the Regional Plan Association points out that we are creating slums faster than we are replacing them, that mass transit within the city and commuting facilities to and from the suburbs are becoming less and less adequate, and that we have not even begun to cope with automotive traffic.
AMHERST, Mass., June 14 -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff of Connecticut declared that the world suffers from a "woeful lack of contemplation."

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Representative Peter Frelinghuysen Jr., Republican of New Jersey, seems to be giving his constituents the equivalent of that old French political advice: "Plus ca change, plus c'est la meme chose."

CHICAGO, June 14 (AP) -- The Government's June wheat crop report last week was described by most traders in grain futures as a "dud" in so far as a market influence was concerned, but that grain and almost all others scored good gains on the Board of Trade.
It "won't be long" before Eddie Arcaro, long one of the nation's leading riders, returns to action.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- J. Graham Parsons, former Ambassador to Laos, was accused by a House committee today of having "abetted" the "railroading" of a Government auditor who was "close to discovering" mismanagement of foreign aid and bribery in that Southeast Asian country.
After an irregularly lower trend during last year and early 1959, commodity prices hit bottom in February and have turned upward since, according to the new 1959 Commodity Year Book.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., June 14 -- New York State's Legislature was criticized here tonight for its failure to enact the Metcalf-Baker bill outlawing racial and religious discrimination in private housing.

United States producers shipped a total of 96,300,000 pounds of acetate yarn and rayon in May, a decline of 1.5 per cent from the April level, but 30 per cent above that in the 1958 month, the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc., reported over the week-end.
Sixteen American scientists who have won Nobel prizes showed, in letters released yesterday, varying degrees of fear that the Government's secrecy policy was hurting scientific progress.
Medals for heroism during 1958 will be presented to twenty-one city firemen and the next of kin of six firemen who died in the line of duty.
The state wants to keep its revenues coming in and its taxpayers on a pay-as-you-go basis.

PHOENIX, Ariz., June 14 -- The United States has approximately 1,100 symphony orchestras. Already many of them have aided young American artists in their professional careers. Steps to have the orchestras help still more were taken at the dinner that closed the fourteenth convention of the American Symphony Orchestra League here last night.

A new agreement between the French Line and Local 153 of the Office Employes International Union was announced over the week-end by Guy de Berc, general manager of the company in this country and Canada. This two-year pact covers 100 office employes of the French Line here.

The nine faculty members who resigned recently from New York University's social service faculty have written an open letter saying they did so because "there was no possibility here for an acceptable program of professional social work education."
The twelve-story Wentworth Hotel at 59 West Forty-sixth Street and 56-60 West Forty-seventh Street has been sold by the Barka Realty Company, representing Walter A. Baron and Herbert Katz.

An American businessman signed a contract in Moscow last week that opens the way for possible manufacture in this country of Soviet medical instruments. Some physicians believe the instruments may bring major advances in surgery, obstetrics and other fields.

" Valley Forge," a new book by Donald Barr Chidsey, scheduled for publication this month, will be issued July 28 by Crown. It is an account of the terrible winter of 1777-78 at Valley Forge and of how Washington created an efficient, hopeful army out of a disorganized collection of half-starved, near-frozen men.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 14 (UPI) -- Beverly Hanson of Fargo. N. D., playing steady golf through intermittent rain, shot a three-under-par 73 today for a fifty-four-hole total of 223, five strokes under women's par, and an undisputed lead in the American women's open golf tournament.
There are about 48,000 fewer persons on the city's relief rolls now than estimated in February, Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy said yesterday.

If there ever is another summit meeting, surely the most sensible place to hold it would be on the high seas, somewhere in the Northeast Atlantic area. The United States, Great Britain, the Soviet Union and France are all naval powers.

RYE, N. Y., June 14 -- Al Feminelli of Dellwood had a 33, 33 -- 66, to win first prize in all except one division of the sixth annual benefit pro-amateur tournament at The Apawamis Club today.
BOSTON, June 14 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox today revoked the pitching half of their recent trade with Washington, reclaiming Murray Wall and sending Dick Hyde back to the Senators.
A willingness to "sacrifice self in the image of Christ" is the mission of the priesthood, Msgr. Thomas A. Donnellan said yesterday at the l0 A.M. solemn mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

NATURE puts on her prettiest face at this time of year. A June setting of tender green leaves and fragile flowers deserves outdoor furniture as fresh as the atmosphere. Crisp colors will stand out against the foliage without fighting for prominence.
A program of unusual interest was performed at Carnegie Recital Hall last night by Connie McNeil, lyric coloratura; Julio Prol, guitarist, and Ralph Freundlich, flutist.
LONDON, June 15 -- Prices in the main industrial sections moved in pennies on the stock market here today. The turnover remained small.
AN angler from Manhattan would have a pretty fair chance of hitting some bluefish, at last now, around Montauk Point and an outside chance of muckling onto big stripers.
On the smallest volume since Aug. 29 -- the day before the 1958 Labor Day week-end -stocks slipped again yesterday, losing about $1,400,000,000 in market value.
A modest - sized, medium - range jet airliner designed for service to cities where giant jets would not be economical, was put on the market yesterday by the Douglas Aircraft Company.
The bond market gave a furthe show yesterday of stabilizing at the low price levels reached recently. Trading was quiet, however, on all fronts.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Until National Chairman Thruston B. Morton spoke out in last Sunday's newspapers, the Republican National Committee had been taking lying down the regular attacks of the Democratic Advisory Council. Yet these attacks have not often been exceeded in national partisan warfare as farragoes of undemonstrable charges asserted as incontrovertible facts.
MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., June 15 (UPI) -- A Detroit business man charged today that churches were being used "to brainwash" the country with Communist-inspired issues.
Billy Flamio, the Bronx welterweight, staged a comeback and gained a unanimous decision over Peter Schmidt of Yorkville at the St. Nicholas arena last night.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today a drastically revised foreign aid bill. It provides $3,165,000,000 in new money and $1,000,000,000 in new lending authority for the fiscal year that begins July 1.

A FILM of the first television pictures to be sent across the Atlantic Ocean on the international telephone cable was seen privately yesterday. The images were transmitted last March in a service that is scheduled to be opened formally at 10:15 A. M. Thursday between London and North America.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -The Supreme Court held today that witnesses questioned by a judge in a New York investigation of ambulance chasing had no constitutional right to have lawyers with them in the courtroom.
A man whose guessing on horse races had been poor lately bet yesterday he could recover his losses at a bank. He lost again.
VIENNA, June 15 (AP) -Chancellor Julius Raab's efforts to put together a new coalition Government suffered a setback today from his own conservative People's party.
An indictment charging two Brooklyn detectives with taking an illegal fee was dismissed yesterday by Kings County Judge Nathan R. Sobel.
DANNEMORA, N. Y., June 15 (AP) -- Hordes of rats are invading homes in this northern New York community and "the women in the village are petrified," Mayor William Donahue said tonight.
CHICAGO, June 15 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 15 -- The metamorphosis from the hot hello to the cold good-by, a pattern as meticulously developed in the movie business as the transition from caterpillar to butterfly, has long deserved examination.
SCARSDALE, N. Y., June 15 -- Mrs. Joseph A. Nesbitt of the Westchester Country Club won the qualifying medal in the fifty-sixth annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship today.

YONKERS, June 15 -- Belle Acton, the pacer who has earned more prize money than any other horse in harness racing history, has retired. The mare, who cost George Landers of Kittery, Me., $1,600 as a yearling, earned $353,039 in purses after four and a fraction seasons of campaigning.

CHICAGO, June 15 (AP) -- A net worth increase of more than 50 per cent in the employes' profit-sharing fund of Material Service Corporation during the last year was reported today by Col. Henry Crown, chairman.
GENEVA, June 15 -- The Western foreign ministers failed today to lead Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union back to discussion of negotiable proposals on Berlin.

OTTAWA, June 15 (Canadian Press) -- The Government here today announced the immediate offering of a new $200,000,000 short-term Government bond issue -- at high yields -- to help finance repayment of a $500,000,000 issue maturing July 1.
ALBANY, June 15 -- The possibility of legislating George P. Monaghan, the State Harness Racing Commissioner, out of office was under study today by the Rockefeller administration.

In his article on Soviet penal reform published June 3 Averell Harriman reports on his visit to a correction colony which is classified as a general prison "ranking between a strict security prison and an open labor camp."

At last the American Medical Association has officially given up its stubborn resistance to medical care dispensed by groups of physicians and paid for on the insurance principle -- as is done by the Health Insurance Plan here in New York. At the association's convention in Atlantic City the delegates voted approval of a policy which now calls for cooperation and a closer "liaison" with such "closed panel plans" rather than opposition and obstruction.

PARIS, June 15 (AP) -- Henri de LaMaze won his tenth French amateur golf championship today at the expense of an American who played so badly he used six putts on the last two greens. The Frenchman beat Paul Coste, a native of Jamestown, R. I., who lives in France, 9 and 7, in the 36-hole final.

CHICAGO, June 15 -- "The same home furnishings recipe is to be found everywhere in Western Europe. Take two parts Danish furniture, mix with Swedish drapery fabric, garnish with glass from Italy, set the table with German stainless steel flatware and light the room with Japanese lanterns."

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused today to review a $100,000 damage award won by Dairy Distributors, Inc., of Amalga, Utah, against the Teamsters Union for alleged violation of the Taft-Hartley labor law's ban on secondary boycotts.

The five-story apartment house at 1391 Nelson Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Nelson Associates to Benjamin Housman, who immediately resold the purchase contract to investing clients of Goodman Mabel, lawyers. M. Kenner was the broker in the deal.
HAVANA, June 15 -- The Free Dominican Radio Hour said here today that fighting had broken out in the Dominican Republic.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, June 15 -- The recent visit to the United States by Tom Mboya, Kenya nationalist leader, was brought up by Sir Roy Welensky today in an informal discussion with Joseph Satterthwaite, United States Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs.
Objects from an ancient realm that is associated with two myths--those of King Midas and the Gordian knot --will be on view today at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The show will run through Aug. 2.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- The Air Force Academy Board of Visitors recommended to President Eisenhower today that primary pilot training be added to the school's curriculum.
Hal Price Headley of Kentucky, who used to cut quite a figure in the winner's circle in New York, paid another visit to that exclusive enclosure at Belmont Park yesterday.

An investment bankers group managed by Reynolds Co. and Lester, Ryons Co., Los Angeles, are offering today $8,000,000 of 5 per cent convertible debentures of Thriftimart, Inc., Los Angeles supermarket chain, at a price of 100.
TRIVANDRUM, India, June 15 -- Five persons were killed and more than thirty injured today in the continuing campaign of opposition to the Communist-run government of Kerala.
Secretary of the Navy William B. Franke declared here yesterday that the Navy lacked enough carriers. He said he would ask the Senate to restore a $260,000,000 supercarrier in the new budget.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -The Eisenhower Administration today answered Congressional critics of its aid program in Laos.

RELIGION and politics are closely allied in Equatorial Africa. Messianic faith is deeply rooted in the people, and the Premier of one of the new self-governing republics that have grown out of French Equatorial Africa is an ordained Roman Catholic priest.
The 115th commencement of Hunter College will be held today at 5 P. M. on the Bronx campus, Bedford Park Boulevard West.
MOSCOW, June 15 -- The Soviet Capital has lost its heart to the brilliant new 17-year-old ballerina, Elena Ryabinkina.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 15 -- The appointment of Dr. James B. Allison as the director of the Rutgers Research Council was announced today by Dr. Mason W. Gross, president of Rutgers University.

The current war over the charity dollar is being fought between the independent fundraising health agencies on one side and the United Fund on the other. Before examining the major combatants, it might be well to take a look at the "guerrilla fighters" in this war -- the housewives.

Sales of the Gabriel Company for the first six months of this year will be about 40 per cent above the 1958 level, John H. Briggs, president, told a special meeting of stockholders yesterday in Cleveland. The company makes automotive shock absorbers and has several divisions serving the electronics, aircraft and missile industries.

NICE, France, June 15 -- The world of wrestling, as everyone knows, is divided into good guys and bad guys. Good guys usually are young, handsome, clean shaven, always wrestle according to the rules and take a frightful mauling from the bad guys before winning in the end.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 15 (AP) -- Radio Station WHAS said today it was quitting the Columbia Broadcasting System to join a new network to be known as Radio World Wide.

After increasing gradually for four consecutive weeks, the nation's steel production dipped slightly in the week that began June 8 and was well below the record output that had been scheduled at the start of the week.

Some 3,000 of the country's top purchasing agents were urged yesterday to prepare for major changes in business management. Mark W. Cresap Jr., president of Westinghouse Electric Corporation, told the international convention of the National Association of Purchasing Agents at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel that this era was "one of bold experimentation and great discovery."
PARIS, June 15 -- A threatened strike, scheduled to begin tomorrow on the nationalized French railroads, was called off by the unions today.
LANARK, Ont., June 15 (UPI) -- A quick-spreading fire destroyed almost half of this eastern Ontario town today, causing damage estimated at more than $2,000,000 and leaving 150 persons homeless.

A dual biography of two seventeenthcentury English poets, by Marchette Chute, will be issued in September by Dutton under the title "Two Gentle Men." The author portrays George Herbert, aristocratic, idealistic, "almost a saint," and Robert Herrick, lusty, extravagant, "triumphantly earthbound."
DARIEN, Conn., June 15 -The school system here is planning what is believed to be the first foreign-language laboratory in this area on a junior high school level.
BOSTON, June 15 (AP) -Cleveland went 2 percentage points ahead of idle Chicago into the American League lead tonight with a 5-1 victory over Boston.

The complexity of, Negro-white relationships in the South has been vividly illustrated this past week-end. In Tallahassee, Fla., an all-white jury convicted four white youths charged with raping a Negro girl, but saved them from execution by a recommendation of mercy. A report released in Atlanta by three distinguished organizations paints a grim picture of wide-scale violence in the South, primarily by those who would deny Southern Negroes their rights as citizens.

GALVESTON, Tex., June 15 -- Court - appointed attorneys silenced a reluctant Gov. Earl K. Long today. They prevented the fiery 63-year-old Louisiana official from testifying during his battle for freedom from a Texas psychiatric clinic.
LONDON, June 15 -- The British Government announced today an increase in the size of National Assistance grants to needy persons.

June, 1959, like twenty-two Junes before this, is Dairy Month. Noting the quantities of dairy products all about us today -- when New Yorkers drink their own health in milk at the rate of 1,200,000,000 quarts a year -it is hard to believe that once it was otherwise.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 2 points (10 cents a bale) off to 10 points (50 cents) up yesterday. Near July was unchanged and near October showed the only fall -- down 2 points.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- The formula under which income tax is collected from mutual insurance companies was held constitutional today by the United States Tax Court.

CHICAGO, June 15 (AP) -Grain futures dealers boldly bid wheat, rye and new crop soybean contracts sharply higher today on the Board of Trade, and then squelched a threat of profit-taking shortly before the close.

The most recent dispatches from Jakarta have confirmed fears on behalf of the Indonesians. Inflation is now rampant and bankruptcy is admitted. The tragedy is not that of the regime but of the poor Indonesian people who can't afford the bowl of rice, who will go hungry in a land "flowing with milk and honey."
The Somoza regime has emerged triumphantly in Nicaragua from the severe test of invasion and a general strike. President Luis Somoza now faces an equally severe test of his statesmanship.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI) -- The Senate Preparedness subcommittee reported tonight that a $1,451,059 expenditure by the Navy on missile facilities would "largely be wasted" because the Navy now planned to close its ammunition depot at Hingham, Mass.

After eleven years of incessant propaganda on the Arab refugee issue the Arab Information Center has at last admitted that this refugee question is regarded by them as political rather than humanitarian.
The A. P. food-store chain was struck early yesterday morning by 1,400 warehouse employes who handle meat, produce, canned foods and other commodities sold in retail outlets throughout the metropoli-
The Public Service Commission rejected yesterday a request by Mayor Wagner that it suspend a general rate increase granted to the Consolidated Edison Company last Wednesday.

MADISON, Wis., June 15 -Senator Hubert H. Humphrey flew home today confident that his three-day campaign for "sane liberalism and prudent progressivism" in Wisconsin had consolidated his old support and won him new adherents.
VALLETTA, Malta, June 15 -- The people of the sun-drenched islands of Malta are painfully seeking a new reason for existence.
The Jewish Theatre for Children yesterday announced two winners of its annual Golden Pen Playwriting Contest.
LOS ANGELES, June 15 (AP) -- Carl Erskine, who pitched two no-hit games and set a world series strike-out record for the Dodgers, is retiring from baseball.

Gas lamps have been restored to Worth Street, the downtown heart of the textile business, in a move to glamourize the neighborhood.

HAVANA, June 15 -- The Cuban Government rejected today a United States request for prompt compensation for millions of dollars' worth of North American owned sugar cane land to be expropriated under the new agrarian reform program.
The Fort Wayne Corrugated Paper Company merged yesterday with the Continental Can Company, which immediately sold three of Fort Wayne's four corrugated box plants and liquidated the company.

Copper futures registered the sharpest decline of the year yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York. The volume, 877 lots (50,000 pounds to a lot), was the third largest this year. Final prices tumbled 95 to 107 points (hundredths of a cent a pound).

TRENTON, June 15 -- The Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad asked the State Public Utility Commission today for permission to discontinue twenty more daily passenger trains, several of them traditional commuter runs.
LONDON, June 15 (AP) -Ninety-eight men, ten Americans among them, were picked up from lifeboats 500 miles off Ireland today after fire swept the British cable-laying ship Ocean Layer.
Seven men were arrested last night in a raid on a $50,000-a-day policy ring allegedly operating in an East Side apartment.
Two films will open at firstrun theatres today.
HARTFORD, June 15 -- A Lutheran layman criticized today the "tax-exempt status enjoyed by all religious bodies" and discount privileges extended to ministers.

It is now definite that "A Loss of Roses" will be William Inge's next Broadway play. A few months ago the holder of the Pulitzer Prize and the Critics Circle Award was uncertain when the drama, based on an Oedipus relationship, would reach New York.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- Congress passed swiftly and sent to President Eisenhower today a $230,000,000 authorization bill for atomic energy construction.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- A House subcommittee investigating undue influence to obtain Federal favors was advised today to watch members of Congress.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 15 -Heart operations so advanced that they have been performed for only a few years were cited by a physician here today as occasional sources of brain damage.

PARIS, June 15 -- Premier Fulbert Youlou's party won at least forty-nine seats out of sixty-one in elections yesterday for the Assembly of the Congo Republic, according to incomplete results reported from Brazzaville.

The convictions for narcotics conspiracy of Harry Stromberg, a gambler known in the underworld as Nig Rosen, and eleven other persons were upheld unanimously yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals.
DUBLIN, June 15 -- Prime Minister Eamon de Valera made what was probably his last political speech to a rally of his Fianna Fail (Party of Destiny) followers here tonight.
A small group of income taxpayers has suddenly discovered that the amount being withheld from their pay is falling considerably short of their probable state tax liability.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -President Eisenhower was told today that the United States was being greatly outdistanced by the Soviet Union in educational exchanges and cultural activities with uncommitted nations.

Mayor Wagner summoned representatives of the seven struck voluntary hospitals to a joint meeting with labor leaders at City Hall today. He wants them to start negotiations to end the thirty-eight-day hospital strike.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -Dr. Arthur F. Burns and Frank Pace Jr. will be co-chairmen of the National Goals Committee proposed by President Eisenhower in his State of the Union message last January, White House sources said tonight.

Thomas J. McDermott, the advertising agency executive who was the foremost candidate to become head of television programs for the Columbia Broadcasting System, was reported yesterday to be no longer under consideration for the job.
ADEN, June 15 (Reuters) -The Red Sea kingdom of Yemen is in the grip of an army uprising that became "serious" today, according to reliable sources here.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -President Eisenhower is weighing a direct appeal to the nation to back his legislative program on labor reform, foreign aid and other major bills.
KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., June 15 -- Top management in industry and business was scored here tonight for what was termed its "ignorance and neglect" in supervising fair employment practices.

CLEVELAND, June 15 (AP) -- The Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen, last of the five operating brotherhoods to serve wage demands on the nation's railroads, asked today for a 14 per cent wage increase.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 15 -- Class Day exercises at Princeton University today included the presentation of prizes and the commissioning of 136 seniors -- one fifth of the graduating class -- into the armed forces. The university also elected a new trustee.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -Officials here do not rule out a summit meeting with the Soviet Union this year despite the stalemate and pessimism at the Big Four foreign ministers' meeting in Geneva.

NEW HAVEN, June 15 -- The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad agreed today to extend the deadline for the purchase of its Old Colony lines by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts from Aug. 15 to Oct. 1.

A feature-length compilation of three Charlie Chaplin silent films with new music and narration written by Mr. Chaplin has been acquired for showing here later this year by Lopert Films, Inc.

A new phase of the city's 1959 pedestrian safety campaign got under way yesterday with the installation of "Walk -- Don't Walk" signals at the corners of Forty-second Street and Broadway. The signals have been in operation on Seventh Avenue at Forty-second Street for some time.

Extensive incompetence and mismanagement in the former Bureau of Real Estate led to that agency's scandals last year, the city charged yesterday.

Five hundred society figures, diplomats and civic leaders steamed out of New York harbor aboard the Liberte last night for a gala dinner-dance for charity.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Industrial production jumped another two points in May, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

LONDON, June 15 (AP) -Two United States Davis Cup players, Peruvian Alex Olmedo and Barry MacKay of Dayton, Ohio, had their troubles with Australian opponents today in their opening matches in the London grass courts tennis championships today.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., June 15 -- Three young women made their bows to society tonight at parties given by their parents and attended by the debutantes of this season, their house guests and escorts.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized an increase in charges by Western railroads for handling mail. It is estimated the additional revenue will be about $7,200,000 a year.

CHICAGO, June 15 -- The days when Chicago was hog butcher to the world are dim memories in the Chicago stock yards, where the country's two largest meat packers, Swift Co. and Armour Co., have stopped or are preparing to stop within two months all Chicago slaughtering operations.

LOS ANGELES, June 15 (AP) -- Wally Moon slammed a three-run homer after an unusual obstruction play in the seventh inning tonight and the Los Angeles Dodgers blanked Milwaukee, 4 -- 0, on Don Drysdale's four-hit pitching.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., June 15 -- Raytheon Manufacturing Co., one of the nation's -- largest manufacturers of electronics, announced today it would build a $2,000,000 electronic anti-submarine warfare and sonar center in Portsmouth, R. I.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- Appraisal requests in connection with proposed construction of homes under the GI home loan program increased 9.9 per cent during May, the Veterans Administration reported today.

CHICAGO, June 15 -- Recommended changes in the Investment Company Act of 1958 now before Congress may result in a secondary market for small business securities totaling several billion dollars a year, Wendell B. Barnes, Administrator of the Small Business Administration, said today.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -The House passed and sent to the Senate today a veterans' pension reform bill increasing payments for 70 per cent of those now on the pension rolls. Action came on a standing vote of 226-34.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- A bill to impose import taxes on lead and mine was introduced today by Senator James F. Murray, Democrat of Montana and chairman of the Senate Interior Committee.

IT was sixty minutes before H-Hour of D-Day at the United States Open championship and the tension which gripped the Winged Foot locker room grew increasingly brittle. Some contestants gnawed at their fingernails. Others paced about. Others whispered quietly among themselves. And still others, needing more violent release from jittery nerves, rushed out to the practice area and expended their energies in hitting golf balls.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -The Government's short-term borrowing costs declined in the last week. LONDON, June 16 -- Business remained subdued on the stock-market here today. Price movements were small and without a real trend, although losses outnumbered gains.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Senate subcommittee on problems of the aging opened hearings today on what further Federal programs should be set up for those past the retirement age.
SCARSDALE, N. Y., June 16 -- The winds dropped and so did the scores in the first round of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's Fifty-sixth annual championship today.
The City Council passed Mayor Wagner's $90,000,000-a-year package of five taxes yesterday after a wild demonstration by 200 taxi drivers against the 10-cent-a-ride taxicab tax.
Former Senator William Benton of Connecticut urged Hunter College graduates yesterday to go into politics in one form or another as soon as possible.

With the deadline for a Congressional vote on the mutual security program close at hand the program itself is still being kicked around as a political football in the interplay of individual and party interests. Indeed, the differences between those who find the program too "timid" and would enlarge it and those who find it too costly and would slash it are still widening and its final shape remains uncertain.

A dramatization of the trial of Capt. Henry Wirz, commander of the notorious prison at Andersonville, Ga., which claimed the lives of thousands of Northern soldiers during the Civil War, is being prepared for Broadway next season.
TRENTON, June 16 -- A broad plan for solving New Jersey's commuter transportation problems was outlined here today by Gov. Robert B. Meyner.

CHICAGO, June 16 -- If the furniture industry starts to practice what it is preaching at the wholesale furnishings market here, homemakers will have a nice long rest from fashions in furnishings. Everyone in the trade has been demanding a cease-fire in the battle of producing two new and different looks in furniture a year.

The specter of inflation, which is threatening the nation's solvency and security, can be met, if the people take increased interest and participation in elections and political processes, Senator Thruston B. Morton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, asserted yesterday.

HAVANA, June 16 -- Americans and all other foreign residents of Cuba were advised by the Government today that they would not be able to leave without special permits secured individually from the Bureau of Investigations of the revolutionary police.
A bill designed to end haphazard planting of trees along city streets was introduced in the City Council yesterday.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., June 16 (AP) -- A furniture industry report today said there was every indication that 1959 would be a year of record volume for furniture manufacturers. The survey was compiled by Seidman Seidman, industry analysts. It said:
GENEVA, June 16 -- With the diplomats about to suspend their trial of endurance and skill, the figure of Richard M. Nixon looms as the next contender in the East - West Olympics.

City College will hold its 113th commencement exercises this evening before an audience of 18,000 persons in Lewisohn Stadium. Degree and certificates will be awarded to 2,812 graduates and undergraduates.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Government's top official dealing with Far Eastern policy said today communism was losing its appeal for Asians.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (UPI) -- Senator John L. McClellan branded "absurd" today the criticism that labor leaders have aimed at his "bill of rights" amendment to the Senate-passed labor reform bill.

LONDON, June 16 -- The Government defeated in the House of Commons tonight an Opposition motion of censure arising from the beating to death of eleven Mau Mau prisoners in a Kenya detention camp last March.
PLAINFIELD, N. J., June 16 -- The lack of a quorum prevented the Metropolitan Regional Council from voting today on whether to seek legal status.
The Youth Board and the Welfare Department received a helping hand from the City Council yesterday in their efforts to recruit applicants for certain jobs that had been difficult to fill.

It was a combination of party-going and a hope for business deal that brought him to the estate of Joseph Barbara Sr. in Apalachin, N. Y., on Nov. 14, 1957, Vito Genovese told the State Investigation Commission yesterday.

" Academic Procession," the recollections of Henry M. Wriston, president emeritus of Brown University, will be issued July 6 by Columbia University. The author tells of his dealings with trustees, faculty, students and alumni and gives his concept of the purposes of higher education.
Prof. Walter Hallstein, chief executive of the European Common Market, said yesterday that opportunities for private American investment within the six-nation, union "are practically unlimited."
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- The United States Military Academy Board of Visitors recommended to President Eisenhower today that new housing facilities and a new library be constructed at the academy.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- The Senate rackets committee said today it would ask the teamster union president, James R. Hoffa, what he had done to fulfill his clean-up pledge.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- The Senate Interior Committee today approved a bill to authorize regulation of fluorspar imports.
HARTFORD, June 16 -- Howard S. Ives of North Stonington, a former officer in the Connecticut National Guard, was appointed State Highway Commissioner by Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff today.
ASCOT, England, June 16 (AP) -- Queen Elizabeth today saw her colt, Above Suspicion win the last horse race of the day at Royal Ascot. It was the first day of a four-day meeting.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Treasury reported today that two countries, two international financial institutions and the Vatican bought gold from this country in the first quarter of the year, and the Philippines sold gold here.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Shoe manufacturers met here today to discuss the threat of mounting imports.

Child welfare experts have been "sabotaging family strength" by saying that the social worker, pediatrician and psychiatrist know more than anyone else about raising children, Dr. Leona Baumgartner, the city Health Commissioner, said yesterday.
The New York City office of the Weather Bureau fell in line with Washington headquarters yesterday and adopted a new name for the Discomfort Index.
Rabbi Theodore L. Adams, spiritual leader of Congregation Ohab Zedek, was praised last night for his "creative leadership." He has recently retired as president of the Synagogue Council of America.

A new bureau to audit both paid and free circulation of business papers was proposed yesterday by William A. Marsteller, president of Marsteller, Rickard, Gebhart Reed, Inc., an ad agency, in a speech at the annual convention of the National Industrial Advertisers Association in San Francisco.

Many thanks to you for three fine editorials in recent months referring to the need for improved housing and working conditions for America's agricultural migrants. I hope that people read thoughtfully your June 10 editorial "Migrant Workers' Tragedy."
MILTOWNPASS, Ireland, June 16 -- In this small Westmeath town about forty-five miles from Dublin, most of the talk in the pub of late has been of proportional representation.

As a former Olympic competitor I was deeply shocked by the action of the International Olympic Committee in withdrawing recognition from the Nationalist Government of China as the representative of China in future Olympic games. This action was reported to have been taken in response to a threat from Communist China not to participate in future Olympic contests if the legitimate Government of China took part.
Two issues of public utility bonds totaling $14,500,000 will be offered to investors today.

The ancient notion that government must have nothing to do with the arts has been fading away slowly in the United States. We do not yet devote Federal moneys to support literature, painting, music, dance and theatre at home, but we have accepted the principle that the Government should provide funds to send our artists abroad. We have learned that through art we can state the democratic case eloquently.

Nine grants, covering fellowships and scholarships, for the 1959-60 term at the Yale School of Drama were announced yesterday by F. Curtis Canfield, dean of the school. A total of $12,450 was distributed. Of this sum, the largest donor was the John Golden Foundation with $5,750 for two fellowships and a scholarship.
The city starts accepting applicants today for the first public housing project here that will integrate middle-income and low-income families.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (UPI) -- The Senate Appropriations Committee approved today a $715,328,500 bill carrying funds for the Commerce Department and related agencies in the fiscal year beginning July 1.
TRIVANDRUM, India, June 16 -- A government school was set on fire a block from where the Chief Minister of the state of Kerala was addressing a Communist open-air rally here tonight.

Just when some racegoers were beginning to ask: "Whatever became of Charley Burr?" the lanky riding lad from Arkansas City, Kan., booted three winners yesterday at Belmont Park. Burr won the first, third and fifth races. Each was a five-furlong sprint for 2-year-olds.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- President Eisenhower told the Republican Congressional leadership today he was "deeply concerned" about the $160,000,000 cut in military-aid funds to be voted on tomorrow in the House of Representatives.
A Queens liquor store clerk was killed yesterday in an exchange of shots with a hold-up man.
Stamford, Conn., raised $5,398,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance public school construction and other public improvements. Of the total borrowing, $4,565,000 will be for schools.
LONDON, June 16 (AP) -- Barry MacKay of Dayton and Jack Frost of Monterey, Calif., entered the quarter-finals of the London tennis championships at the Queen's Club today.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (UPI) -- Members of the House space committee were told today of gases that could make them dance a jig or kill them in thirty seconds.

PHILADELPHIA, June 16 -- An appeal to American labor to "support a few more Republicans in the elections next year" was made here today by Senator Thruston B. Morton, chairman of the Republican National Committee.

More than 80 per cent of the nation's life insurance companies are opposed to variable annuity policies, a poll made public yesterday indicated. Results of the study were announced by Frederic W. Ecker, president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, which conducted the survey, at a press conference in the offices of the company.

In any Big Four negotiation such as the discussion in Geneva, more countries, in fact, take part than the quartet officially represented. Thus Russia speaks for a Communist empire extending from the Elbe to the China Sea and the Western trio speaks for all of NATO.
MONTREAL, June 16 (UPI) -- E. D. Brockett, president of British American Oil Company, Ltd., today predicted record Canadian crude oil production for 1959.

YOKOSUKA, Japan. Wednesday, June 17 (AP) -- The Navy patrol plane crippled by MIG's 45 miles off North Korea Tuesday was about to return fire when its tail gun was knocked out in the attack, the pilot said today.
PARIS, June 16 -- Premier Michel Debre told the Senate today that the Government would publish a list of private concerns helping the Algerian rebels.
AN Atlantic salmon was taken in the Connecticut River last week, which makes a fine start for a review of what the official press agents are saying here and there along this coast.
ALPINE, N. J., June 16 -- The American Cyanamid Company dropped today its plan to erect an administrative building here that ultimately would have housed 1,500 employes.

Stockholders of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation at a special meeting in Wilmington, Del., on July 28, will be asked to approve a new incentive plan for the compensation of the company's executive staff.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- The Department of Justice opposed today any Federal "fair trade" law permitting manufacturers to set minimum retail prices. Robert A. Bicks, acting head of the department's anti-trust division, told a Senate Commerce subcommittee such legislation would cause "tremendously higher prices to consumers."
Two brothers who founded thirty years ago what has become the world's largest retail fur business were honored last night as "fur men of the year."
JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 12 -- President Sukarno will act to insure the reinstatement of the 1945 Constitution by Aug. 17, Indonesia's Independence Day, according to officials here.

Copper futures were firm at the beginning of today's session on the Commodity Exchange of New York, reflecting the early strength in London. Later, the London market turned weak on rumors that custom smelters here again would reduce prices. Futures prices in New York closed near the lows of the day.

A "rebellion against the policies of the International Monetary Fund" has been shaping up in Latin America, The Times' correspondent Tad Szulc reports. The issues involved go to the heart of the relationship between economic crisis and political instability in the hemisphere.

THE man who runs India's first Communist-ruled state was having a political chat one day with a Socialist leader. As Elamkulam Mana Sankaran Namboodiripad, chief minister of the State of Kerala, recalls it, it was a conversation of great delicacy and tact.
Freight-laden railroad cars were stalled on both sides of New York Harbor yesterday as a wildcat walkout by tugboat crewmen passed its second day.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 16 -- More than 600 neurologists were warned here today that some epileptics who seemed in perfect control of themselves had occasional seizures without knowing it.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (UPI) -- The New York Stock Exchange and American Stock Exchange today protested Administration proposals to impose $100-a-day penalties on companies failing to file required information with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, June 16 (AP) -- President Luis A. Somoza Debayle said today he had reports that a rebel force of about fifty men had invaded Nicaragua from Honduras. Another group, he said, is poised to strike from Costa Rica.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 16 (AP) -- A man who quit the Little Rock School Board only a few days after being appointed said today he had learned he could not serve because of a prison record in the nineteen thirties.

A National Open championship of four days, instead of the customary three, will be considered by the executive committee of the United States Golf Association. Many committee members feel this would be one way of softening any blows inflicted by the weather.

BUENOS AIRES, June 16 (AP) -- Dissatisfied officers at the army garrison in Cordoba today asked the Minister of the Army, Gen. Hector Solanas Pacheco, and his Under Secretary to resign, well-informed sources said.
MIDDLEBORO, Mass., June 16 (AP) -- Two brothers who held a Philadelphian captive for ten days were still at large today, despite a hunt by 300 men.

Sports car racing in this hemisphere has reached a peak in public interest. In the years since World War II it has flourished despite bungling promotion, a lack of showmanship, outmoded rules and silly amateurism.
The city school system is taking two more steps to improve science and mathematics instruction.

LIMA, Peru, June 15 -- The Government plans to expain its economic policies to the nation this week in the face of Opposition charges that the foreignbacket stabilization program had failed and a record budget deficit was in prospect.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 2 points (10 cents a bale) up to 3 points (15 cents) off yesterday.
OMAHA, Neb., June 16 -- Thirty-nine scouts, representing all sixteen major league baseball clubs, are sitting in on the National Collegiate world series here.

MADRID, June 16 -- The security police arrested a Spanish career diplomat today on a charge that he had distributed propaganda calling for a nation-wide strike against the Government, authoritative sources said.
CLEVELAND, June 16 (AP) -The financial problems of eastern railroads are spreading to roads in the west and south, James M. Symes, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad said today.
Volume remained low on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday as every major group lost ground and aggregate market value declined about $2,000,000,000.
Mayor Wagner pointedly repeated yesterday, in commenting on an action by Park Commissioner Robert Moses, that all city commissioners were expected to observe Administration policy.

HARTFORD, June 16 -- The president of the National Council of Churches hailed here tonight the growing unity of American Christianity as "the brightest sign of hope on the horizon of a broken and divided world."

IT'S a wonder that the Catchers' Union has not preferred charges against Al Lopez for cruel and inhuman conduct against one of the brothers. Defying all rules of unionism and decency, the crafty senor has been using Sherman Lollar, a catcher with seniority, as a first baseman.
YONKERS, June 16 -- Stanley Dancer was the winning driver and Reed's Knight the winning horse in the Ritter Pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Democratic Advisory Council assailed the Administration's defense policies today and advocated increased military spending of $7,500,000,000 a year for the next four or five years.
The Fund for Adult Education yesterday announced a nation-wide effort to bring closer the day when education is a cradle-to-grave process.
PARIS, June 16 -- Allied planners favor maintaining Western rights of access to West Berlin by air rather than by ground action should the Communists renew their challenge to those rights.
Yeshiva University's annual commencement dinner will be held tonight at the Savoy Hilton Hotel. Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, will be the principal speaker.
FLORENCE KNOLL may be blueprinting a new course for furniture design.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (UPI) -- Cranston Williams, general manager of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, said today that newspapers and their news agencies should be given a special teleprinter rate because their service kept the public informed.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Railway Express Agency, Inc., told Congress today that it would be forced out of business if size and weight limits on parcels post packages handled by first class post offices were increased.

There is no more loyal partisan of a voluntary health organization than the unpaid volunteer who rings doorbells, telephones prospective donors and prospective volunteers and hands out educational material. The volunteer is passionately devoted to the cause, which is generally worthy and admirable.
CHICAGO, June 16 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
SUMMIT, N. J., June 16 -- "I think I'm ready now, 100 per cent in fact," Floyd Patterson said today as he continued work for his heavyweight title fight with Sweden's Ingemar Johanson.

OMAHA, June 16 (AP) -- Oklahoma State pushed across two runs in the last of the ninth tonight and beat Penn State, 4 to 3. The setback eliminated the eastern team from the National Collegiate baseball world series.
ATLANTA, June 16 (AP) -- Federal judge formally directed the Atlanta Board of Education today to submit a plan for the desegregation of Atlanta's schools.

BONN, Germany, June 16 -- The East German press agency A. D. N. indicated today that the Russians would reject the forthcoming Western proposals on Berlin and allow the Geneva conference to break up in failure.

SAN DIEGO, June 16 -- Confronted with the challenge posed by the introduction of jet transports to the world's airlines, the twelfth triennial session of the International Civil Aviation Organization opened today in Balboa Park.

Sales and earnings of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company for the six months ended April 30 were the highest for any initial fiscal half-year period in the company's history, Harvey S. Firestone Jr., chairman, and Raymond C. Firestone, president, reported yesterday.
Charlie Dooley, the man who fractures the English language in the interests of a cleaner New York, is in trouble again, this time with some citizens of Utah.

IN light of the Federal Communication Commission's refusal yesterday to reverse itself on the issue of equal time for political candidates appearing in television newscasts, tomorrow's hearings of the Senate Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce in Washington become vitally important.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -The Federal Communications Commission refused today to change its ruling that the "equal time" edict for political rivals applied to news programs as well as other broadcasts.

PARIS, June 16 (UPI) -- The Rev. Dr. Billy Graham, American evangelist, said today on his arrival from the Soviet Union that he had found a great "moral purity" among the people of Moscow as well as a "great spiritual hunger" for God despite the country's official atheism.
CLINTON, N. Y., June 16 (AP) -- The Rev. Dr. J. Kenneth Miller, pastor of the United Presbyterian Church in Garden City, was elected moderator of the Presbyterian Synod of New York tonight.

The first American showing of Cine-Panorama, a Russian-made wide-screen system comparable to the Cinerama process, will take place on June 30 at the Mayfair Theatre, it was officially announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -The Senate Democratic leadership bowed once again today to the budgetary wishes of President Eisenhower, cutting a controversial housing item for direct loans to veterans from $300,000,000 to $100,000,000.

A Federal mediator said that he had been in touch yesterday with both sides in the strike of 1,400 warehouse employes of the A. P. food-store chain, but that the situation was not yet ready for a resumption of bargaining talks.
With a strike deadline for 500,000 workers just two weeks off, top company and union negotiators in the steel industry spent two and one-half hours yesterday negotiating on how to negotiate.

GENEVA, June 16 (AP) -- Avery Brundage of Chicago, president of the International Olympic Committee, said today he would return to the United States next week, and reply personally to the "completely unjustified attacks" on the I. O. C. following its recent decision on China.

GALVESTON, Tex., June 16 (AP) -- Gov. Earl K. Long of Louisiana battled closer to freedom today from a Galveston mental clinic, apparently winning the fight with members of his family who had sought his committment as a mental patient.

America's stockholder population continues to grow apace. Early this year it stood at 12,490,000 individuals, compared with an estimated 8,630,000 in 1956 and 6,490,000 in 1952. The latest figure is contained in a shareowner "censusu" conducted by the New York Stock Exchange. The 1966 and 1952 surveys were also made by the Big Board in collaboration with Alfred Politz Research, Inc.

OCEANPORT, N. J., June 16 (AP) -- Merrick Stable's Sandy's Joy created a large minus pool as she survived a claim of foul and won The Nellie Flag Purse in 1:112/5 at Monmouth Park today. It was her final tune-up for Saturday's Regret Handicap.

THE word "barbecue" has strayed rather far from its original meaning. It derives from the French word, "barbe-a-queue," and referred originally to roasting a whole animal carcass from "snout to tail."
One of the state's highest judges asserted last night that the state needed legislation authorizing a complete official list of everybody licensed to practice law in the state.

Directors of the American Marietta Company yesterday authorized a five-for-four split of the common stock to be effected in the form of a stock dividend. The company also announced that directors planned to continue the 25-cent quarterly cash dividend on the increased shares outstanding starting with the Nov. 1 distribution, in view of the rise in earnings this year.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 16 (AP) -- George Reeves, television's Superman, killed himself early today. Seconds earlier his fiancee had predicted his death.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- House and Senate conferees tentatively adopted today a wheat bill providing for an increase in price supports that the Administration opposes.

GROSSINGER, N. Y., June 16 -- Ingemar Johansson proved today to a group of skeptics that he was serious in his approach to his fight with Floyd Patterson. The Swedish heavyweight, who will seek to lift the world title from Patterson at the Yankee Stadium on June 25, had a vigorous workout today before 200 observers.
