The General Dynamics Corporation is expanding its industrial and medical business through the acquisition of the gas enterprises of LaVerne W. Hench Assoc.

I believe that it is of the utmost importance for the United States to keep its power to negotiate the establishment of a carefully balanced area of demilitarization in Central Europe. This should be made a vital first step toward general disarmament down to a police level under a strengthened U. N.

Lawrence M. Lyons, realty investor and builder, has purchased the taxpayer at 271-01 to 271-13 Eightieth Avenue, corner of Langsdale Street, in Bellerose, Queens. Joseph R. Ruffino of the Kraham Realty Company was the broker in the sale.
Alexander P. de Seversky, noted aviation engineer and author, has received the Air University Award, it was announced here yesterday.

The Yankees smacked down Al Lopez' White Sox, 5 to 1, at the Stadium last night. What is more, they did it at the expense of Billy Pierce, Chicago's classy left-hander who had beaten the Bombers twice this season.

Advertising men are showing new interest in closed-circuit television as an effective promotion and marketing tool for clients, Nathan I. Halpern, president of Theater Network Television, said yesterday.

MILWAUKEE, June 16 (AP) --The city of Milwaukee will intervene in a Tennessee court action against a lViilwaukee policeman who was stopped on / vacation trip through Tennessee and relieved of his service revolver.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -Senator Wayne Morse, Democrat of Oregon, blocked today a Senate agreement for an early vote on the nomination of Lewis L. Strauss to be Secretary of Commerce. However, Mr. Morse expressed the hope that a vote could be reached by the end of the week.
ROME, July 16 -- Scattered violence and demonstrations were reported today in the wake of spreading strikes.

The United States Olympic Association, Inc., shortly will have a new home. It has acquired the six-story house, originally built for J. P. Morgan, at 57 Park Avenue, between Thirty-seventh and Thirty-eighth Streets, for its headquarters.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -The Defense Department reported today that two MIG jet fighters with Communist markings had attacked a United States Navy patrol plane over international waters of the Sea of Japan.

The Allied Stores Corporation will "definitely show improvement in earnings" for the six months ending July 31 compared with profits for the first fiscal half a year earlier, B. Earl Puckett, chairman, told the annual meeting here yesterday.
A proposal from ten New York newspapers for a new contract with their union printers will be discussed at a membership meeting of New York Typographical Union No. 6 (Big Six) on Sunday.
Next season's television specials will bring something old as well as something new.

The City Planning Commission urges that the city set aside, while there is still time, adequate land for recreation on Staten Island, our "last frontier." The island has been accurately so described because, up to now, Richmond has been largely by-passed by the intensive urban growth that has occurred on all sides. This isolation is due to end soon.
A ticker-tape parade believed to be unique in the annals of New York paid tribute yesterday to men of the United States Second Fleet.
The Transit Authority announced yesterday that the Rockaway Special, a one-stop IND train to Playland Amusement Park, Rockaway, would be resumed Saturday.

INFLAMMATION of the ring finger underneath the marriage band may be an indication of marital strife. Similarly, an inflamed thumb may be an expression of a desire to return to one's thumb-sucking infancy.
Magistrate Walter H. Gladwin broke up the marching activities of the Virgin Islands Steel Drum Band yesterday.
DUBLIN, June 16 (AP) -- Track and field athletes from Yale and Harvard won six of the nine events they entered tonight in a meet against Ireland's best.
New issues of industrial securities valued at more than will be offered to $39,500,000 investors today by syndicates as follows:

CRANSTON, R. I., June 16 (AP) -- New England's all-star college sailing squad beat the Midwest, 5 -- 1, today in a best-of-nine series for the national intersectional team racing championship. The Midwest district had held the title for two years.
GENEVA, June 16 -- The Soviet Union hinted today that its demand for a veto over the staff assigned to posts for policing a nuclear test ban was negotiable, a Western source said.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 16 (AP) -- Gov. John Patterson came home to Alabama today carrying the banner of Senator John F. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, for President. Some of the home folks sounded not too happy about it.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., June 16 -- The recently elected president of B'nai B'rith declared here tonight it was a "false notion that Jewish life in America must revolve as a cultural satellite of Israel."

The Steel Pier in Atlantic City, N. J., an amusement center, will increase its advertising budget for the coming summer season by 30 per cent over the level of last summer, George A. Hamid Jr., executive vice president and general manager, announced yesterday.
JERICHO, L. I., June 16 -- Parties were given tonight for four debutantes, all of whom will also be presented in the autumn at holiday entertainments in New York.

ST. PAUL, June 16 (AP) -Joey Giardello of Philadelphia knocked out Del Flanagan tonight with a savage right smash to the head at 2:50 of the first round. The defeat was the second home-town loss for Flanagan in his ten-year career.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The United States is gravely concerned about deteriorating relations between Japan and South Korea, two of its most important allies in the Far East.
A proposal to search space near the earth for evidence of anti-matter has been submitted to the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

Electric power production rose to 13,503,000,000 kilowatt hours last week from 13,023,000,000 in the preceding week, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. This was the highest level since the week ended Jan. 10, when output was a record 13,554,000,000 kilowatt hours.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Disclosure that a United States plane was virtually helpless to defend itself against an attack by Communist MIG's over the Sea of Japan evoked criticism and expressions of dismay from members of Congress today.
MONTREAL, June 17 -- Pictures were televised successfully across the Atlantic today.

TWENTY-EIGHT fresh-faced young women this week climbed into the new clothes they will wear in Moscow next month. This marked the beginning of a frantic week filled with fittings, press conferences, television filmings and a visit with President Eisenhower.
The A. P. food chain announced yesterday that it would close all its stores in the metropolitan area at 6 P. M. Saturday unless a strike of warehouse men was settled before then.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Foreign-aid supporters in the House of Representatives staved off today an additional cut of $140,000,000 in military assistance. Action was then sped toward approval of the full program without substantial reductions.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower said today that it would be "foolish" to expect 100 per cent protection from any agreement to ban tests of nuclear weapons.
MIDDLEBORO, Mass., June 17 (UPI) -- A ninety-second gun battle with the police today ended the crime career of two Philadelphia brothers. The younger brother was fatally wounded.

LOS ANGELES, June 17 -- Moscow's famed Bolshoi Ballet was named as one of ten defendants in unfair labor practice charges sent to the National Labor Relations Board district office here by the Musicians Guild of America, independent.

BONN, Germany, June 17 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer, speaking at a ceremony in the Parliament Building here today in memory of the 1953 uprising in East Germany, said the free nations of the world stood at the side of the German people in the struggle for freedom. The United States in particular, he said, is the spokesman for all who love freedom.

Herbert H. Lehman added Michael H. Prendergast, state chairman of the Democratic party, yesterday to his list of Democratic officials he wants replaced to erase what the former Senator calls the taint of bossism in the party.
City and Federal mediators met last night with railroad officials and representatives of tugboat crewmen in an effort to end a three-day tie-up of railroad marine operations in the Port of New York.

JERSEY CITY, June 17 -- Ground was broken today for a $7,500,000 housing project at Journal Square, to include a 70,000 - square - foot shopping center, a three-story underground parking garage and a twenty-three-story, 500-family apartment building. At the same time City Commissioner James F. Murray Jr. announced plans for a 250-unit housing development.

Stockholders of the H. L. Green Company at the annual meeting yesterday were concerned mainly with the course of action the company planned to take against the former president, Maurice E. Olen, and with the more than $4,000,000 shortage in the Olen account.
THE two-part cliffhanger, a device used for some of television's more ambitious dramatic efforts, including "For Whom the Bell Tolls," went out West last night.
Two boys were arrested last night, charged with having caused a four-alarm fire that seriously damaged a six-story East Bronx tenement and burned out two abandoned buildings.

The employment of Hulan E. Jack Jr., 24-year-old son of the Manhattan Borough President, in a Civil Service post in his father's office was confirmed yesterday by Acting Borough President Louis E. Cioffi.

The usual seasonal decline in the nation's gasoline inventories is finally showing up. Figures issued yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute disclosed a dip in both stocks and production -- welcome news, undoubtedly, to an industry that has been plagued by an oversupply and some scattered price cuts.
GALVESTON, June 17 (AP) -- Louisiana residents are anxiously awaiting Governor Long's first action.

OTTAWA, June 17 (UPI) -- A sharp gain in mining production, increasing inventory accumulation and rising national and personal income put Canada's gross national product for the first three months of the year about 2 per cent above the final quarter of 1958.
HARTFORD, June 17 -- The merger goal of one Lutheran Church in this country may be reached earlier than its most optimistic proponents have been predicting.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Senate and House conferees informally agreed today on most features of a compromise omnibus housing bill designed to meet President Eisenhower about half way. The conferees, seeking to adjust differences between versions passed earlier by the Senate and House, neared approval of a final measure entailing major concessions to the President's demand for economy.

RYE, N. Y., June 17 -- The debutantes who will attend the Westchester Cotillion this season and their mothers were honored here this afternoon at a tea given at the American Yacht Club by the Rye committee. Mrs. Miller P. Longbotham was chairman of the tea and Mrs. Jonathan F. Butler heads the Rye committee.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The drive to pass a labor reform bill progressed today, but pressures by diverse interests continued to be a serious threat.

For the past two years the Fund for the Republic has been making a continuous study of what it calls "basic issues." This study is directed at clarifying fundamental questions concerning freedom and justice, especially those constitutional questions raised by the emerging power of twentieth century institutions. The goal has been to stay within the framework of the Founding Fathers in maintaining a free, just and democratic society under contemporary conditions in this country.

The plastics industry and several national health and civic groups set in motion yesterday a massive education campaign designed to halt the rising death toll of young children resulting from the misuse of plastic bags.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- President Eisenhower refused today to intervene personally or through any Federal agency in the steel industry wage negotiations.

A top prize of $5,000 in the annual Robert E. Sherwood television awards was issued yesterday to a "Playhouse 90" drama, "Made in Japan," which was presented March 5 over the Columbia Broadcasting System network.
It may come as a surprise to some oil men, but the Chase Manhattan Bank's petroleum department wonders if promotion of individual brands of gasoline "achieves any lasting gain" for the oil industry.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 17 -- Dr. Djalal Abdoh informed Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold today that he would leave for Teheran next week to take up his duties as Foreign Minister of Iran.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 17 -- Jack L. Warner, president of Warner Brothers, today told subordinates from many parts of the world that their company had a very bright future.

Richard Lewisohn, a 43-year-old-pencil manufacturer, was elected last night to replace former Representative Frederic R. Coudert Jr. as Republican leader of the Ninth Assembly District. Mr. Coudert had resigned.
IN "No Leave for the Captain" on Channel 2 last night Maurice Evans played the role of a British Army officer who was, to put the matter indelicately, a sot.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 17 (AP) -- Tomy Lee's owner, furious because his star bore out and ran sixth after a disputed jockey change, today carried out his threat to quit racing.

A proposal to reduce by $609,000 the cost of gas to 103,000 customers of the former Brooklyn Borough Gas Company is contained in a new rate schedule filed yesterday with the Public Service Commission by the Brooklyn Union Gas Company.

United Gas Corporation's net income for the first five months of 1959 was slightly behind the year-ago level despite a 10 per cent increase in natural gas revenues, Ed Parkes, president, told yesterday's annual meeting at Shreveport, La.
Yeshiva University has decided to seek one or more partners in an effort to win sponsorship of the Riverside-Amsterdam slum redevelopment.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 17 -- Important chemical clues to the causes of several common diseases of the nervous system were suggested here today.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 17 -- The Legislature approved today a $1,750,000,000 program to develop the largest water system in the world.

The steel industry told representatives of its 500,000 unionized workers yesterday that any rise in wages and fringe benefits this year would have to be matched by union cooperation to increase efficiency and thus keep total employment costs stable.

LONDON, June 17 (AP) -- The International Sugar Council today decided to cut export quotas by 2 1/2 per cent, the maximum allowed under the International Sugar Afreement, in another effort to bolster the sagging price of the commodity.

BUENOS AIRES, June 17 -- Brazil has asked oil supplers in the United States and Britain to provide eighteen months credit for petroleum imports to ease the burden of foreign payments, according to oil circles here.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Federal Reserve Board announced today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member bank in ninety-four leading cities, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Wednesday, June 10:

BOSTON, June 17 (AP) -- One-Eyed King surged from far behind, fought off a stretch challenge by Noureddin and won the $35,000-added John R. Macomber Memorial Handicap by a head today at Suffolk Downs.
For a club that is still dragging its anchor in the second division, the Yankees suddenly are kicking up a disturbance that is making itself felt in the upper levels of the American League.

Revelation that the Soviet Union is spending well over ten million dollars in foreign exchange for its exhibit in the Coliseum here later this month points up the importance Moscow attaches to this event. The amount involved is well over half of the dollar revenue the Soviet Union earned all last year by exports to this country.
A three-page explanation of a mortgage transaction involving the vice chairman of the Mayor's Slum Clearance Committee and the sponsor of a slum project was sent to City Hall yesterday.

COOKS who never make brioche waste a great deal of time. That is to say they do not know what they are missing. This inspired continental bread with a superb flavor and texture can add elegance to a week-end menu for breakfast or brunch. The confection, accompanied by sweet butter, marmalades and jams, is a boon companion for a freshly brewed cup of coffee.

AKRON, Ohio, June 17 (AP) -- A two-for-one split of common stock of the McNeil Machine and Engineering Company was approved by shareholders at a special meeting here today. Record date for the split is July 25.
Thirty-two apparel trade groups in the city have joined forces to protest two recent Supreme Court decisions that permit individual states to tax interstate transactions.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- President Eisenhower said today that he was eager to meet with President Charles de Gaulle of France in an effort to resolve United States-French differences over the defense and strategy of the West.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- Eastern railroads will cut their rates on export grain movements between Midwestern points and North Atlantic ports by 20 to 25 per cent effective midnight tonight.

BERLIN, June 17 -- West Germany and West Berlin marked today the sixth anniversary of the uprising by East German workers as "the day of German unity." Hundreds of ceremonies were held throughout the country.
CHICAGO, June 17 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- The Eisenhower Administration strongly opposed today a bill to permit self-employed persons such as doctors and lawyers to set up tax-deductible old-age pension funds.
GENEVA, June 17 -- The United States and Britain struck back today at the Soviet Union's demand for a throttlehold on the finances of the proposed organization for a nuclear weapons test ban.

Manufacturers and retailers of men's furnishings should break away from traditional prices and ensure both segments of the industry a realistic profit, according to John W. Swanson, president of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers.

A new apartment building will replace the four old faded brick houses at the southwest corner of Ninth Avenue and Forty-fifth Street, which have changed hands for the first time since soon after the Civil War.

Top coats and top choices were in evidence yesterday at Belmont Park where, in sub-60-degree weather, four favorites triumphed. Among the successful chalk-horses was Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Village Idiot, who encountered no trouble at all while winning the $27,500 Stymie Handicap.
NEWARK, June 17 -- The Archdiocese of Newark will be host to the Second World Congress of Sodalities of Our Lady, on Aug. 20-23.
SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, June 17 -- Gov. George Dewey Clyde of Utah wrote New York's Mayor Wagner today, formally protesting further unwelcome references to Utah by Charlie Dooley and others.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The United States and three British Commonwealth countries have responded favorably to the idea of participating in a $1,000,000,000 development plan for the Indus River.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- A union official testified today that organized labor was not responsible for mandatory retirement clauses in negotiated contracts.

An investor has purchased the six-story apartment house for fifty-six families at 1229 to 1237 Franklin Avenue, northwest corner of East 168th Street, the Bronx. Morris Schneps was the seller. The building, 201 by 164 feet, has eleven stores.
PURDYS, N. Y., June 17 -- New York City's water drinkers should be as gratified as a group of fishermen and watershed engineers were here today with the findings on the Titicus Reservoir.

Copper prices fell, recovered, fell again and then rallied to close at or near the highs of the session yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York. The volume, 809 lots (50,000 pounds to a lot), was the fourth largest of the year. Prices closed 15 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) off to 15 up.
Gay hostess aprons in gorgeous colors mark the exhibit of Lighthouse Craftshop products that opened yesterday at the Design Center for Interiors, 415 East Fifty-third Street.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (UPI) -- Eight postal unions agreed today to draft a constitution for a federation and an eventual merger.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 17 (AP) -- A 70-year-old remedy may be advertised as Carter's Little Pills but not Carter's Little Liver Pills.
Governor Rockefeller yesterday opened the state's newly expanded defense warning system, under which air-raid alerts can be heard simultaneously and instantaneously in each of the sixty-two counties.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., June 17 -- Support of the United States Supreme Court's decisions on civil liberties and denunciation of those who have indulged in a "series of calumnious attacks" on the court was voiced here today.
AT the height of World War II one of Sir Winston Churchill's faithful assistants, Gen. Sir Leslie Hollis, wrote a note about something or other to the great man. He opened a sentence with the words:

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., June 17 (AP) -- Foreign manufacturers sharply underbid United States companies yesterday on steam-electric generators sought by the Tennessee Valley Authority. The generators of various sizes would have a total capacity of 6,100,000 kilowatts.

TROUT fishermen ought to do reasonably well this coming week-end, whether they are going into near-by Westchester and Putnam waters or a little farther out. They ought to, that is, if the weather is right.
Five justices in the Appellate Division decided unanimously yesterday that William Shakespeare and his plays ought to have another opportunity to try to use Central Park this summer.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower said today that the International Olympic Committee had overstepped the bounds of athletics to enter politics when it ousted the Chinese Nationalists.

SUMMIT, N. J., June 17 -- "This has none of Grossinger's luxury," said Cus D'Amato in the understatement of the century. "It's dilapidated and somewhat the worse for wear. This is simply a training camp."
WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- The American Bar Association contended today that some new powers sought by the Securities and Exchange Commission could have unfair and oppressive effects.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- President Eisenhower indicated today that he would use every influence at his command to obtain Senate confirmation of Lewis L. Strauss as Secretary of Commerce.

MADRID, June 17 -- The Spanish Communist party, both outside and clandestinely inside Spain, is putting the final touches on plans for a national twenty-four-hour "peaceful" strike tomorrow to protest against the dictatorship of Generalissimo Francisco Franco.
NEW ORLEANS, June 17 (UPI) -- Gov. Earl K. Long returned to Louisiana tonight from a Texas mental hospital. He immediately went to a New Orleans hospital for further medical care.
A 22-year-old Bronx woman was blinded Monday by a corrosive liquid hurled at her in the doorway of her apartment at 1124 Grant Avenue, near 164th Street.
The Port of New York Authority raised $30,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance outlays at the La Guardia and New York International Airports.
TRIVANDRUM, India, June 17 -- Opponents of the Communist government of Kerala continued to picket schools and government offices today but there was no violence.

Investment bankers managed by Alex Brown Sons are offering today to the public 150,000 shares of common stock and $1,250,000 of 9 per cent unsecured subordinated bonds of the Jim Walter Corporation, a home builder of Tampa, Fla.

BUENOS AIRES, June 17 -- A political conflict within the army forced the resignation today of Col. Manoel R. Reimundes, Under Secretary of War. He was a strong supporter within the armed forces of President Arturo Frondizi's economic program.

The name role in "Simone" has been reserved for Jenny Hecht, 15-year-old daughter of Ben Hecht, film writer, dramatist and novelist. It will mark the second local appearance of the young actress, who made her Broadway debut six years ago when she was chosen for an important part in "Mid-Summer."

The Geneva conference of foreign ministers is now set to decide whether it can still salvage anything from its thirty-nine days of talk or whether it is doomed to complete failure -- at this time. Yesterday Mr. Gromyko asked and obtained a twenty-four-hour delay for his final answer to the last Western compromise plan on which the West proposes to make its final stand.
ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., June 17 -- A heavy fog caused alternate plans to be made here for the arrival of Queen Elizabeth II tomorrow.
GENEVA, June 17 -- Andrei A. Gromyko postponed a showdown in the Big Four foreign ministers' conference today for at least twenty-four hours.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 17 -- Through his country's political tides and tempests, Dr. Djalal Abdoh, Iran's new Foreign Minister, has maintained such a sure, steady helm that the diplomatic course he set out on fourteen years ago has continued without interruption.
WASHINGTON, Thursday, June 18 (UPI) -- The Senate approved a compromise "stopgap" wheat bill early today designed to cut surpluses by lowering planting allotments and increasing price supports.
ROME, June 17 (Reuters) -- Italy's labor crisis worsened today as hospital workers, including nurses, scheduled a strike for next Wednesday.

The tragedy of John Foster Dulles had a profound effect on me. It must have also affected millions of other thinking citizens. Here was a devoted national public servant who literally fought his life away with unyielding courage and persistence for what he felt was best for America. Yet he was subjected to cruel and unreasonable abuse and criticism, with few defenders, until he was close to death.

A $5,000,000 anti-trust suit was filed yesterday in Federal Court here against Volkswagen of America, Inc., and fourteen of its distributors by the National Imported Car Dealers' Association, Inc., and ten of its members.
An application for a habeas corpus writ to free Carmine Lombardozzi, an Apalachin defendant, on bail pending a Federal Court trial this fall was argued yesterday in Supreme Court.
A new flashlight battery with a life expectancy of fifteen to twenty years is going into mass production at Sonotone Corporation plants.
DUBLIN, Ireland, June 17 -- Eamon de Valera resigned as Prime Minister of Ireland tonight, about half an hour before the close of polling in the Presidential elections.
Robert Battipaglia obtained a court order yesterday temporarily restraining a majority of the Queens Democratic executive committee from ousting him as county leader.
LONDON, June 17 -- Wladziu Valentino Liberace, American entertainer better known as just Liberace, was awarded 8,000 ($22,400) damages in a libel action today.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- Nine United States scientists were named today to attend Geneva technical talks starting Monday on how to detect high-altitude nuclear explosions.

Recently you published a most encouraging editorial which not only commended the work of the World Health Organization in the field of mental health but spoke of World Mental Health Year, for which the World Federation for Mental Health is responsible, with the active cooperation of WHO, UNESCO, International Cooperation Administration and many other inter-governmental, governmental and voluntary bodies throughout the world.
LONDON, June 17 -- Declines predominated on the stock market here today, although most changes were less than a shilling (14 cents).

The large shopping center near the railroad station at Great Neck, L. I., is an unusual place for a dog-training school. The school is unusual, too. It specializes in "problem" dogs, though owners who just want well-mannered pets are welcome, too.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., June 17 -- Paul Kelly finished his second round in the rain and won the William Rice Hochster Memorial golf tourney today. The 28-year-old former metropolitan amateur golf champion added a 71 to a 75. His aggregate of 146 at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club enabled him to triumph by a stroke.
TRENTON, June 17 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner's proposal to use $630,000,000 of New Jersey Turnpike reserve funds to help ease the railroad commuter crisis has drawn cautious comment by legislators.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- President Eisenhower complained with a chuckle today that he had not been allowed to see an actual test explosion of an atomic or hydrogen bomb.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- An early end to the current critical depression in the poultry and egg industry was forecast today by an official of the Agriculture Department.

The CEM Securities Corporation, a holding company of the C. E. McManus family, last month sold 153,728 shares of Crown Cork and Seal Company common stock, according to the New York Stock Exchange. The exchange also reported yesterday that C. E. McManus Jr., a director of the company, had sold 11,352 shares of Crown Cork stock.
New diplomatic identification cards to replace the "courtesy cards" now in use will soon be issued to representatives of foreign nations here and at the United Nations.
Trustees of the Union Dime Savings Bank yesterday elevated Walter R. Williams Jr., vice president and treasurer, to president to succeed the late J. Wilbur Lewis, who died on May 20.

GROSSINGER, N. Y., June 17 It is the immediate ambition of Ingemar Johansson of Goteborg, Sweden, to add one more title to a business card that at present could contain many legends. "Bulldozer owner, steam-shovel owner, truck owner, fishing trawler owner, landscape gardener and European heavyweight champion," are some of the designations he can claim now.

Back in the early Nineteen Twenties Chock Full O' Nuts Corporation had its origin in a basement store selling nuts. Yesterday its common stock was listed for the first time on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol "CHF."
LONDON, June 17 -- A renounce-the-H-bomb movement is gathering strength in the Labor party.

LONDON, June 17 (AP) -- United States Ambassador John Hay Whitney today came to the aid of fifteen forlorn Texans who flew to London especially to hear Maria Callas sing in the opera "Medea" and then found they couldn't get tickets.

The Pennsylvania Railroad, which sought unsuccessfully last year to have Congress create a Federal agency to purchase new railroad equipment and lease it to the carriers, announced yesterday that it had arranged financing for the addition to its fleet this year of 23,500 new freight cars, valued at $215,000,000.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The first step toward new civil rights legislation was taken in Congress today.

A mysterious $200,000 payment in 1954 to Dave Beck by two prominent trucking company executives was the basis for an indictment yesterday charging the three men and three companies with violating the Taft-Hartley Act.
LONDON, June 17 (UPI) -- Alex Olmedo, Barry MacKay, Earl Buchholz and Jack Frost gained the quarter-finals today at the London grass court tennis championships.

The refusal of the Federal Communications Commission to reverse its stand on equal time for political candidates appearing in radio and television newscasts leaves only one alternative: new legislation that will end a situation that President Eisenhower accurately has called "ridiculous."
The Fifth Avenue Association yesterday elected Andrew Goodman as president. He also is president of Bergdorf Goodman. He succeeds Grover A. Whalen, who has retired.
Investors continued in May to purchase mutual fund shares at a higher volume than a year ago although the pace was a bit slower than in April.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 16 -- Random sounding of public opinion in Jakarta today showed puzzlement and criticism that President Sukarno was still abroad while Indonesia was beset with constitutional and economic difficulties.
TOKYO, June 17 -- Japan's largest labor organization, the General Council of Trade Unions, has joined with the Communist party in a common program of political significance here.
Steels, motors and electronics took the lead yesterday as the stock market made an almost general advance and added about $2,400,000,000 to aggregate market value on the New York Stock Exchange.
ALBANY, June 17 (AP) -- An appellate court held today that the state must grant unemployment insurance benefits to a man who had worked for the Communist party.

Much of the recent record of the United States Government in trade policy has appeared to reflect response to special problems at home rather than the principle of reduced barriers to imports. That is added reason for welcoming the decision of Leo A. Hoegh, the Director of Civil and Defense Mobilization, against restriction of imports of hydraulic turbines and associated heavy electrical equipment.
Newspapers, magazine, radio and television are contributing in many ways to a decline in the city's morals, a committee of 104 religious leaders said in a report presented yesterday to Mayor Wagner.
Justice Lester Lazarus signed eviction orders yesterday affecting thirty-three commercial tenants of the Lincoln Arcade Building at 1947 Broadway.
TULSA, Okla., June 17 -- American Airlines will dedicate a $20,000,000 jet maintenance and engineering center near this city tomorrow afternoon.
At about 3 P. M. today Judo Joe Cassius, a professional wrestler, will ascend the graduation platform at Yeshiva University. When he steps down, he will be Joseph Cassius Doctor of Philosophy.
SEATTLE, June 17 (AP) -- A new drug has scored a major breakthrough in the treatment of depressed mental patients, a psychiatrist said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts is attempting to win the support of Maryland's delegation to the 1960 Democratic National Convention without entering the state's Presidential preference primary.

BONN, Germany, June 17 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer indicated today that he planned to withdraw as Chancellor in 1962 after the next West German general elections. The elections are to be held in September, 1961.
MOSCOW, June 17 -- Anastas I. Mikoyan, Soviet First Deputy Premier, has reaffirmed Soviet determination to proceed "systematically" to achieve greater confidence and less tension in world relations.

Although the awesome strength of nuclear energy dominates the thinking of the age, education remains the most powerful force at man's command, Dr. George N. Shuster told the graduating class of City College last night.

The Atlas Corporation, a holding company, has exercised options to buy 1,271,000 shares of the common stock of the Summers Gyroscope Company, Santa Monica, Calif., for about $750,000. The stock is being held in escrow by the Security First National Bank of Los Angeles pending final approval of the purchase by the Civil Aeronautics Board.

Despite some dark spots, the outlook generally is bright in nine important industries, top trade association executives in those fields reported yesterday. They spoke at a special press conference sponsored by the American Society of Association Executives, Washington, D. C., in the Biltmore Hotel.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower signed legislation today increasing the United States contribution to the International Monetary Fund by $1,375,000,000 and adding $3,175,000,000 to the United States subscription to the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank).

JOHNSON CITY, N. Y., June 17 -- Joseph Barbara Sr., who was host to more than sixty underworld delegates at the gangland convention nineteen months ago in Apalachin, N. Y., died tonight at Wilson Memorial Hospital after a heart attack.
Traders observed yesterday a broadening of activity in the market for fixed-income investments of high rank.
TOKYO, June 17 (AP) -- The stock market average dropped 30.70 yen (eight cents) to 785.01 yen ($2.18) today for the second biggest decline in a day since the end of World War II.
The Soviet Exhibition is experiencing the pangs of the high cost of American living and labor.
Labor and hospital officials met jointly last night for the first time since May 18, when a "memorandum of understanding" intended to end the strike at voluntary hospitals was drawn up at City Hall.

TRENTON, June 17 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner today signed measures establishing referendums on two issues: the legalization of boardwalk and amusement-park games of chance, and the prohibition of Sunday business in counties.
The rules of golf will be relaxed for 1960. In a one-year trial beginning Jan. 1, penalties for out-of-bounds, lost and unplayable bails will be less severe.

YONKERS, June 17 -- Speedy Pick, from the Blue Hen Stables, in Dagsboro, Del., will be the even-money favorite tomorrow night for the tenth annual Good Time Pace at Yonkers Raceway. The one-mile event is valued at $40,750.

The summer seems lately to have come upon us, and as every suburbanite knows, the summer is the time for starting brave new projects. This does not mean taking a firm vow to see every home game at the Stadium, or to fish every trout stream in the Catskills, Such are not for suburbanites.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- When the President at his news conference today observed in passing, "by the Constitution I am part of the legislative process," this was a reminder of a fundamental fact of the American system of government that is obscured by the prevailing generality used to describe this system.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (UPI) -- Following is a transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today:

FOR most children, the playground is down the block. But for the children of Bellevue Hospital, it is down seven stories to the street level. In the playground and garden overlooking the East River, many of the youngsters can escape the antiseptic atmosphere of the hospital for an hour or two to sit or play together in the sunshine and fresh air.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 17 -- The Radiation Committee has decided to focus immediate attention on investigation of the effects of nuclear fall-out.
MIAMI, Fla., Thursday, June 18 -- Hundreds were reported injured or homeless early today in the wake of furious funnel-shaped winds that smashed through Miami last night.

Sylvester L. Weaver Jr., former chairman of the National Broadcasting Company, yesterday was elected chairman of McCann - Erickson Corporation (International), a division of McCann-Erickson Inc., the nation's second largest advertising agency.

RICHMOND, Va., June 17 (UPI) -- Virginia's Pupil Placement Board notified Charlottesville school officials today that they were breaking the law in assigning eleven Negro children to two white schools.
Charges of membership-raiding were exchanged at a hearing yesterday by the Transport Workers Union and Local 1-2 of the Utility Workers Union of America.

With shock and incredulity I read in the press the brazen announcement that the Senate Foreign Relations Committee had voted astronomical sums of tax money, still unearned, for foreign aid, notwithstanding the fact that the American people have nationally protested the continuation of taxation for foreign aid.

The Federal Reserve Board's monthly index of production continued its uninterrupted rise through its thirteenth month in May. At its latest figure of 152 the index was up 2 points from a revised April figure of 150; it represents a recovery of 26 points from its low of 126, touched in April, 1958, and exceeds by 6 points its previous all-time high, touched in February, 1957.
CHICAGO, June 17 (AP) -- Manassas, owned by John Zitnik, won the $18,150 Grassland Handicap at Washington Park today when Benedicto was disqualified.

I have just read the letter you published June 15 from James H. Scheuer, president of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council, in which he makes the dogmatic assertion that there is no worthwhile over-all planning being done in New York City, especially as to housing.
ALL fathers do not like Father's Day. As a matter of fact, some of them are embarrassed or irritated by it, mostly because of the gifts they receive.
SCARSDALE, N. Y., June 17 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone and Mrs. Bruce McGhie, the co-favorites, advanced to the quarter-finals of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship today.

Mayor Wagner expressed the "deep condolences" of the city yesterday to the families of six firemen killed in the line of duty last year. He also paid tribute to twentY-one other firemen for acts of bravery in 1958.

YOKOSUKA, Japan, June 17 -- The attack on the United States plane over the Sea of Japan was intended to increase Communist pressure on the Big Four foreign ministers' meeting at Geneva, the commander of United States naval forces in Japan declared today.

CHICAGO, June 17 (AP) -- The first general setback of the week hit the grain futures market today, knocking prices of wheat and rye futures down more than a cent a bushel in spots on the Board of Trade.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- The Government announced today that the personal income rose in May to a record annual rate of $376,200,000,000.
George P. Monaghan declared last night that he would never resign as state Harness Racing Commissioner.

MIAMI BEACH, June 17 (UPI) -- Unbeaten Louis Manuel Rodriguez won a unanimous ten-round decision tonight over a tiring and bleeding Virgil Akins, sending the former welterweight champion to the fourth loss in his last five fights.
Plans for a new East Side office building to provide additional office space for the United Nations were weighed yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

Hugh K. McGovern, realty investor, has purchased the four four-story rooming houses at 239 to 245 East Thirty-fifth Street, near St. Gabriel's Park, for cash over a first mortgage of $235,000. The property, 83 by 98 feet, is between Second and Third Avenues.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP)--The chief author of the veterans' pension bill passed by the House conceded today that it would cost the Government an extra $10,000,000,000 in the next forty years rather than save $12,000,000,000.
Thomas G. (Teddy) Gleason, a dock union leader, "answered all questions" yesterday in a two-hour interrogation by the Waterfront Commission, the agency reported.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, told the Senate today that 721 high-ranking retired officers were on the payrolls of the top defense contractors.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 17 -- The Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space is expected to recommend that the General Assembly set up a permanent committee of governmental representatives to encourage international cooperation in this field.

Mayor Wagner has decided, prudently we think, that it is at least ostentatious, and perhaps somewhat extravagant, for most city department heads and some other officials to ride around in city-owned limousines assigned for their exclusive use. Beginning July 1, under a new Wagner executive order, most city officials entitled to city-owned cars will use automobiles of the "medium or lightweight type."
New York will have to wait a little longer to find out whether a husband and wife serving on a criminal jury in the oldest court in the country can agree.
The State Rent Commission announced changes in its regulations yesterday to restore controls on rooming houses that had charged higher rents by calling themselves residential hotels.
Former Premier Bourges-Maunoury of France praised Israel last night for her ability to absorb immigrants, to progress as a nation and to develop her economy.

PARIS, June 18 -- The idea of a meeting between Presidents Eisenhower and Charles de Gaulle, joined later by Prime Minister Harold Macmillan of Britain, was warmly received in French official circles today.
Lumber production rose to 261,127,000 board feet from 256,727,000 in the prior week, according to reports to The New York Times by regional associations.

A collection of profiles of today's world leaders has been made by William H. Stringer and will be published under the title "Summit Roundup." The twenty-one portraits will present the personal views of each of the personalities regarding his country's role in world affairs and "particularly encouraging" domestic developments.

Away from the local stage for seventeen years, Lauren Bacall has decided to return in "Goodbye Charlie." She was persuaded to do so by Leland Hayward, producer of George Axelrod's new comedy. Mr. Hayward is curently represented as co-sponsor of "Gypsy," starring Ethel Merman.
PARIS, June 18 -- Today was the nineteenth anniversary of Gen. Charles de Gaulle's call to arms to the Free French, broadcast from London.
NEWARK, June 18 -- The New York, Susquehanna and Western Railroad received permission today to discontinue twenty-eight more passenger trains of its remaining total of forty-four.

Your editorial of June 11 "Trees No Longer Enemies" is most timely in view of Park Commissioner Moses' willingness to sacrifice trees and shrubs in Central Park when they impede the march of concrete or interfere with his fancy for vistas.

SYRACUSE, June 18 -- A three-mile time trial of 15:52, the fastest recorded by any of the crews in training here on Onondaga Lake, has pushed the University of Washington into the position of the crew to beat in the regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association on Saturday.

REDDING, Conn., June 18 -- A glowing appraisal of Mark Twain as the "founder of American realistic literature" is contained in an article prepared for a bi-weekly newspaper here by the Gorky Institute of World Literature in Moscow.

ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, June 15 -- Rotterdam, which can handle 250 sea-going ships at a time, is the biggest port for the European Economic Community, or common market. But it is not sure that the common market is good for Rotterdam.
WASHINGTON, Friday, June 19 -- The Senate rejected early today the nomination of Lewis L. Strauss to be Secretary of Commerce. The vote was 49 to 46.
IT would be interesting to know if more restaurants specializing in Chinese food have opened in New York within the last year than have opened in Shanghai, Canton or Taipei.
WASHINGTON, June 18 (UPI) -- The American Legion said today it would withdraw all its financial and other support from the 1960 Olympic games unless Nationalist China was allowed to participate.
Prospective buyers representing hundreds of American electronics manufacturers crowded into the Statler-Hilton Hotel yesterday to view the Japan Electronics Show.
The IRT's Yonkers Raceway Special made its first run last night. Some 650 persons climbed aboard at Grand Central for the one-stop trip to the Jerome Avenue-Woodlawn terminal in the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The House of Representatives approved today a $3,542,600,000 foreign aid authorization for the coming fiscal year. The roll-call vote was 271 to 142.
Sidney J. Ungar, lawyer and real estate operator, was acquitttd yesterday in Special Sessions of ninety alleged violations of the Multiple Dwelling Law at 10 West 104th Street.

BUSINESS is at its peak at the Day Meyer, Murray Young Corporation, 1166 Second Avenue, near Sixty-first Street. In this fantastic warehouse, which contains an indescribable maze of tracks and vaults, virtually anything can be stored.
If Joseph Papp, producer of the New York Shakespeare Festival, can raise $20,000 he will be allowed to operate in Central Park this summer.
MADRID, June 18 -- A Communist - inspired nation - wide strike, projected as a political gesture against the regime of Generalissimo Francisco Franco, failed today.
A boatload of 1,900 physically handicapped persons of all ages made a tour up the Hudson River yesterday.
W. R. Grace Co. plans to expand its chemical business by acquiring the Hatco Chemical Company.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 18 (AP) -- The Naval Academy's Royona was named scratch boat today for the Annapolis-to-Newport (R. I.) yacht race beginning at noon Saturday.
LISBON, Portugal, June 18 (Reuters) -- The National Assembly approved tonight a bill proposing that future Presidential elections be carried out by direct vote of the people.
SCARSDALE, N. Y., June 18 -- Mrs. Bruce McGhie of Whippoorwill continued to beat par as she reached the semi-final round of the fifty-sixth annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship.
A constitution to unite two Protestant denominations with vastly different forms of government was proposed here yesterday for the United Church of Christ.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., June 18 -- Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip arrived here by air from London today to begin a six-week tour of Canada. Brilliant sunshine broke through three days of fog to greet the royal couple. and youngsters in the various uniforms of the Cadet Corps.
Two new films will arrive at first-run theatres this morning.
Lions Club members who work in the neighborhood of the International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, were honored at Belmont Park yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 18 -- The synagogue in a Ukrainian city was reliably reported today to have been closed by Soviet authorities last month in the Kremlin's campaign against the practice of the Jewish religion.
A memorandum of understanding to end the forty-two-day hospital strike was reached at City Hall at 2:30 A. M. today.

Yonkers, N. Y., borrowed $11,608,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance school construction and other public improvements. The money was raised by the sale of serial bonds due from 1960 to 1979 to a syndicate headed by First National City Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (UPI) -- The "population explosion" in under-developed countries poses a grim threat to free society, Rabbi Maurice N. Eisendrath of New York; president of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, said tonight.
CLEVELAND, June 18 (AP) -- Strip steel can be produced without blast furnaces and the melting process, Republic Steel Corporation announced today.
OTTAWA, June 18 (AP) -- Robert M. Fowler, president of the Newsprint Association of Canada, indicated today that an increase in newsprint prices before 1962 was unlikely.
WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- Albert E. Kahn, writer and publisher, was called today a leading Communist who specialized in anti-American and pro-Russian propaganda.
The departure of Queen Elizabeth II from London was seen two hours and twenty-one minutes later on American television yesterday morning.
LONDON, June 18 -- The Newspaper Society announced today that about 1,100 provincial daily newspapers would be affected by a strike in the British printing industry that began last night.
BATON ROUGE, La., June 18 -- Gov. Earl K. Long, cursing and fighting with sheriff's deputies, was committed tonight to a Louisiana state mental hospital.

Rabbi Max Felshin of the Radio City Synagogue, 110 West Forty-eighth Street, was indicted yesterday on charges of attempting to bribe state inspectors to overlook violations of kosher dietary laws at the Cafe Sahbra.

ASCOT, England, June 18 -- After a tremendous battle over the last furlong, Baron G. de Waldner's Wallaby II won the Ascot Gold Cup for France today by a nose from the favorite, Sir Humphrey de Trafford's Alcide.
An experimental program of short-term psychiatric treatments for a sample group of 75,000 persons in the Group Health Insurance "Family Doctor Plan" will begin here on July 1.
ROME, June 18 -- Pope John XXIII granted a state audience today to Prince Rainier and Princess Grace of Monaco. The Vatican received the couple with the honors it usually accords to visiting royalty.
DENVER, June 18 -- A Maine-to-Colorado sidewalk poll spiced the convention of the Young Republican National Federation today.

CLIFTON, N. J., June 17 -- The defending champion, Lloyd Monroe of Rockaway River Country Club, won first and second round matches today in the fifty-eighth annual New Jersey Golf Association amateur championships at Upper Montclair.

In the stock market yesterday, the most interesting news came after the close. It concerned the holiday that has been a center of discussion lately. The question: Will the New York Stock Exchange close on Friday, July 3, to make the Independence Day week-end a long one?
WASHINGTON, June 18 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower said tonight that a home was the most valuable thing a man could buy with one exception -- "the purchase of a wedding ring."

HAVANA, June 18 -- Four small bombs exploded in Havana and its suburbs last night and early today as Premier Fidel Castro spoke to the nation in a televised interview. At the same time, an attack on a police patrol car resulted in the outbreak of firing in the Victoria suburb.
AUSTIN, Tex., June 18 -- The Texas Railroad Commission today again ordered a drastic slash in the allowable statewide oil production for July of 226,044 barrels a day.

GLEN COVE, L. I., June 18 -- The Trijon, a thirty-three foot, steam-powered cabin cruiser, was launched today with champagne and appropriate ceremony after more than five years' labor by a 76-year-old man.
CHICAGO, June 18 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

The First Boston Corporation marked its twenty-fifth anniversary as an independent investment banking business yesterday by throwing open its tenth-floor suite of offices at 15 Broad Street for a party for the families of employes.
TULSA, June 18 -- The prospect of larger and greatly faster jet airplanes in commercial services was discounted here today by air operating officials.
SURAKARTA, Indonesia, May 22 -- "Now is the time people go to the mosque," said the Communist Mayor with a glance at the clock. "I've told you my story, so please excuse me."

A plot of vacant land on Cruger Avenue, between North Oak Drive and South Oak Drive, the Bronx, has been purchased by the Imperial Oak Construction Corporation. It will be improved with a twelve-story apartment house for 144 families. The property was sold by Bridget Cambassio through Harold L. Rockmore, broker.

TENAFLY, N. J., June 18 -- A ruby-throated hummingbird, injured last week in Grayling, Mich., is recovering here with eighteen other maimed birds in a sanctuary at the home of Mrs. Herbert Carnes, an ornithologist.
Once the word "yacht" connoted to many an ocean-going palace with swank and pomp and with crews as large as forty or more. Today most of those craft are just memories.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The two Communist planes that attacked a United States patrol aircraft Monday appeared to be North Korean, Neil H. McElroy, Secretary of Defense said today.
VIENNA, June 18 -- A nationalist politician from Innsbruck, capital of the Austrian Tyrol, reasserted today Austria's territorial claim to South Tyrol, known in Italy as the Alto Adige.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- Frank Stanton, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, said today the public would be blacked out from political news on radio and television if all candidates must be given equal time on newscasts.
RALEIGH, N. C., June 18 -- The General Assembly adopted a biennial revenue bill today that contains a withholding plan for individual income-tax payers and major corporations.
Mediation efforts in the four-day-old tie-up of railroad tugs in New York harbor were temporarily suspended yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission presented its case to Congress today for tightening of the Investment Company Act of 1940.

ANYONE who conscientiously read the front page of this newspaper last week read once again about the United Steelworkers of America insisting that the steel industry can afford to pay higher wages and about the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and the International Longshoremen's Association having more of their dirty linen washed publicly in the courts.

The Transit Authority deserves a big bouquet for its ingenious plan to provide parking lots at ten or more subway terminals. The first of these lots has just been opened. The admirable way in which this plan combines increased revenue for the subway system with a substantial public service in reducing traffic congestion should be a shining light to other officials.

LONDON, June 18 (Reuters) -- A courageous innings of 81 by Nari Contractor, India's left-handed opening batsman, who batted four hours with a cracked rib, could not atone for failure by his colleagues when the second cricket test match against England began at Lord's today.
The oft-postponed introduction of the Superba, the passenger-car version of the Checker taxicab, will take place next week.
HARTFORD, June 18 -- The 600,000-member Augustana Lutheran Church came out here today in opposition to any extension of the Protestant parochial system on the high school level.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- In an isolated valley in the mountains of West Virginia the Navy is building a massive radio telescope that should be able to peer out to the edges of space. It is expected to answer age-old questions about the creation and nature of the universe.
LOUVECIENNES, France, June 18 (UPI) -- Brigitte Bardot was married for the second time today in a home-town ceremony delayed briefly by tears and foot-stamping rage at intruders.

Heavy liquidation of July and September holdings, hedging against sales of actuals and stop-loss selling lowered cocoa prices yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Trade purchasing and manufacturer buying for price fixing absorbed the offers.
Stocks pushed ahead strongly in the early hours of yesterday's session, lost momentum, held their own until near the close and then tobogganed. The net result was an unimportant gain.

Loans to business by the larger New York City banks rose $376,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with an increase of $268,000,000 in the week of last year.
MOSCOW, June 18 -- There were indications in Moscow tonight that the Soviet Union had by no means abandoned hope for an agreement of some kind at Geneva.

If the definition of "originality" -- the capacity of originating or creating something -- can be extended to mean finding a new use for something that has been right under one's nose for years, then David P. Morgan should qualify as an original thinker.
One of New York's senior musical institutions entered its forty-second year last night in the Music Grove in Prospect Park, Brooklyn.

THE most important track meet of the Season will take place in Colorado today and tomorrow when the Amateur Athletic Union holds its seventieth national championships. From the rarefied air of the Rockies will emerge the team which will represent the United States in the great international dual meet with the Soviet Union at Philadelphia's Franklin Field on July 18 and 19.
The Rockefeller Institute held its first graduation ceremony yesterday morning, one dedicated to "the furtherance of excellence and not numbers."
LONDON, June 18 -- Graham Greene's new play "The Complaisant Lover" opened tonight at the Globe Theatre here and won great acclaim from audience and press. Sir John Gielgud was the director.
The agent for a tenement owned by a Harlem religious leader sought yesterday to change her plea of guilty to charges of 38 violations of the multiple dwelling law in the building.

MONTREAL, June 18 (Canadian Press) -- Al Balding sent Canada into the lead today in the first round of the Canadian open golf championship. He carded a spectacular six-under-par 66 over a rain-soaked Isles-mere course.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Representative Ludwig Teller, Democrat of Manhattan, offered a compromise labor-reform bill today. The immediate effect on the House Education and Labor Committee was confusion.
A two-man team appointed by the Board of Education has submitted a program for improving the business operation of the school system.
Mayor Wagner's $90,000,000-a-year package of five special taxes or tax increases, including the 10-cent levy on taxicab rides, was approved by the Board of Estimate yesterday.
The personnel of Mitchell Air Force Base, Hempstead, L. I., will give blood to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program today.
KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., June 18 (AP) -- A Jewish leader said today that anti-Semitism was no longer of paramount concern in this country, but that the cultural survival of American Jews was.
The Italian Line will continue its efforts to accommodate passengers affected by the ten-day Italian seamen's strike, Capt. Ezio Bonfanti, general manager in this country, asserted yesterday.

GROSSINGER, N. Y., June 18 -- Ingemar Johansson today put the "bright light of truth" on the condition of his right hand. The 26-year-old Swedish heavyweight held out for inspection the fist with which he hopes to batter down Floyd Patterson next Thursday night and become heavyweight champion of the world.
At least 25,000 homeward-bound Queens residents were stranded in the evening rush hour yesterday when an IRT Flushing line train broke down near Times Square.

William A. Shea, chairman of Mayor Wagner's baseball committee, identified yesterday the members of a syndicate that had pledged $4,500,000 to assure New York's entry into the proposed third major league.

Diocesan directors and members of the National Catholic Resettlement Council called on Congress and the Administration to make a generous appropriation for a permanent solution of the displaced persons problem.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- West Germany is again pressing the United States to reimburse German nationals for property seized here during World War II.

The Senate has acted to approve an increase in the price-support level for wheat -- a support level based upon the so-called "parity" principle which is, in fact, a guaranteed purchasing power given to the farmer. It is very difficult to understand why a system that has been proved both costly and useless is being persisted in.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 18 -- The state's first cigarette tax, 3 cents a pack, became law today.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (UPI) -- The Senate Armed Services Committee brushed aside charges of "smear" by the chamber's only woman member today and voted 12 -- 1 to grant a fourth star to Lieut. Gen. Emmett O'Donnell Jr.

Operations of the Glidden Company in the nine months ended on May 31 resulted in substantial gains in sales and earnings over the prior year's period, the report of Dwight P. Joyce, chairman and president, disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (UPI) -- Harmon Killebrew hit his twenty-third home run of the season and Roy Sievers his fifth to help the Washington Senators beat the Kansas City Athletics, 7 -- 5, tonight. It was the fifth defeat in a row for the Athletics.
OTTAWA, June 18 (Canadian Press) -- The Seafarers' International Union was suspended today from the 1,000,000-member Canadian Labor Congress for raiding another Congress union.

FROM Kathryn Hulme's novel "The Nun's Story," which gives an amazing account of a young Belgian woman's experiences in becoming and being a nursing nun, screen writer Robert Anderson and director Fred Zinnemann have derived an equally amazing motion picture of an extraordinary dedicated life.
DUBLIN, Friday, June 19 -- Eamon de Valera has capped a remarkable career in politics with election as President of Ireland.
MONTICELLO, N. Y., June 18 -- Despite rain and unseasonably cold weather, officials of Monticello Raceway opened the Sullivan County half-mile harness racing plant on an optimistic note tonight.
EUGENE, Ore., June 18 (AP) -- The way was cleared today for an $80,000,000 lumber deal in which the U. S. Plywood Corporation would acquire the Booth-Kelly Lumber Company.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The effort, instituted and largely manned by Senate Democrats, to dodge the hard choice presented by the Administration's request for authority to raise interest rates on Government borrowings, is a current instance of the unwillingness of many politicians to face difficult facts.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 18 -- Dr. John W. Behnken of Houston, Tex., was chosen to lead the Lutheran Church-Missouri Synod for three more years today on the fifth ballot of an unusually long election.
BONN, Germany, June 18 -- West German Deputies heard a warning today that the Soviet Union would consider it "a provocation" if the election of a Federal President were held in West Berlin.
Industry must step up advertising and promotion by at least 9 per cent, if it is to prevent the worst pile-up of inventories in this country's history, according to Sales Management magazine.

LONDON, June 18 (UPI) -- Alex Olmedo staged a "sit-down strike" today while reaching the semi-finals at the London grass court tennis tournament and Barry MacKay, his Davis Cup team-mate, smashed his racket in disgust after losing to an unheralded Australian teen-ager.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- A new Government report on profits of manufacturers showed today after-tax earnings of the steel industry, measured as a percentage of stockholders' equity, were higher in the first quarter of this year than earnings of manufacturers generally.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 18 -- Australia and Sweden offered ideas today designed to induce the Soviet Union to end its boycott of the United Nations outer space program.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Senate and House conferees agreed today on a compromise omnibus housing bill that is calculated to soften President Eisenhower's opposition and avert a veto.
The post of district director of the Immigration and Naturalization Service here has been assumed by P. A. Esperdy.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (UPI) -- The Senate approved two money bills today carrying $715,328,500 to run the Commerce Department in the next fiscal year and $128,797,380 to operate Congress and its subsidiaries.

A ringing new appeal for unions to form a standing Conference on Transportation Unity was made yesterday by Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union and a vice president of the merged labor movement.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday hit a nineteen-month high at 709,139 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
WASHINGTON, June 18 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower asked Congress today for money to plan the world's largest linear atom smasher at Stanford University.

The New York Philharmonic will play at least one American composition at each of the fifty concerts it will give during its ten-week tour of Europe and the Near East. Samuel Barber, Leonard Bernstein, Aaron Copland, George Gershwin, Charles Ives and David Diamond will be the American composers represented.

In his press conference on Wednesday President Eisenhower made the understatement that "there are differences of opinion" between the United States and France. He suggested that a personal meeting with his "old comrade in arms" General de Gaulle might solve these differences.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Soviet Ambassador Mikhail A. Menshikov called in reporters today to promote the exhibition his country will stage in New York's Coliseum from June 30 to Aug. 10.
WASHINGTON, June 18 (UPI) -- Congressional investigators discussed today the question whether Congressmen exerted undue pressure on Federal regulatory agencies.

YONKERS, June 18 -- Most of the 27,081 fans at Yonkers Raceway rated Speedy Pick a cinch to win the tenth annual Good Time Pace tonight. They sent off the gelding, who a year ago set the track mile record of 1:58 4-5, as the 9-to-20 favorite. Before long the chalk players were sorely disappointed.

A Greenwich Village landmark has passed to new ownership with the sale of the blockfront on the west side of Washington Street between West Tenth and Charles Streets. Leonard S. Kandell sold the property to an investor. George E. Maran was the broker.
DJEMMAL, Tunisia, June 18 -- President Habib Bourguiba told France today that the status of the big Mediterranean naval base of Bizerte must be defined on terms "consonant with Tunisian sovereignty."

The knockout prowess of the six boxers, three of them from Cuba, in the three ten-round bouts at Madison Square Garden tonight is so great that, for the first time in the Eighth Avenue arena's history, four emergency bouts have been arranged.
Three New York City signed yesterday a $25,000,000 loan agreement with Instituto Mobiliare Italiano, the largest Italian financial institution for medium and long-term industrial credit.
The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court found a meeting of minds yesterday in the matter of doing laundry on Sunday.

American scientists have been all but unanimous in warning of the danger that the national preoccupation with "getting results" will lead to a distortion of the nation's research effort. As the typical, and impressive, warning goes, the unglamorous area of "basic research" will be starved while "applied research," whether for new products or missiles or cures for disease, will receive a disproportionately large amount of support.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 18 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold indicated today that he might not go to Cairo next week to try to settle the dispute over the seizure of Israeli cargoes going through the Suez Canal.
WASHINGTON, Friday, June 19 -- Lewis L. Strauss, the eighth Cabinet appointee in United States history to be rejected by the Senate, early today expressed his "confidence that history will be just."

TOKYO, June 18 -- Premier Nobusuke Kishi appointed a new seventeen-member Cabinet today. The new line-up is expected to strengthen the pro- Western statesman's personal leadership of the disunited Liberal- Democratic party.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 18 -- African women rioted in Durban today in anger at the destruction of illicit liquor stills.
Lawrence G. Derthick, United States Commissioner of Education, yesterday urged the development of college programs emphasizing "the humanities as well as the sciences."

The recently described state plan for housing families of middle income, like so many other proposals for middle-income housing, flies in the face of facts concerning such families in the State of New York.
CHICAGO, June 18 (AP) -- Wheat, rye and soybean futures had a good rally going today on the Board of Trade until profit takers took over and squeezed it dry.
The Police Department said yesterday that it had received forty-one complaints of intimidation in a survey of underworld influences in the city's juke-box industry.
New issues of railroad and public utility debt securities totaling $12,050,000 will be offered for public subscription by banking syndicates today as follows:
BEDFORD, N. Y., June 18 -- Miss Barbara Stuart Bijur and Miss Emily Ann Arents were honored this evening at a dance given by their parents at the Bedford Golf and Tennis Club.
THE porringer, a baby's dish used commonly for serving porridge centuries ago, has survived the ravages of time and the babies.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 18 -- Ethel Barrymore, last of the trio known to Broadway and Hollywood as "The Royal Family" of acting, died here today of a heart ailment. She would have been 80 years old on Aug. 15.
Business slackened in the bond market yesterday, with prime-risk corporate bonds tending to decline slightly, while certain war-issued United States Government bonds scored a further improvement.
Compulsory registration and fingerprinting of the 25,000 narcotics addicts in the city was urged yesterday by Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The House of Representatives rejected today a compromise plan to control the wheat surplus further. The vote was 214-202.
CHICAGO, June 18 (UPI) -- James R. Hoffa said today the Teamsters Union would choose a national committee soon to map a campaign to organize the air freight industry.

CRANSTON, R. I., June 18 (AP) -- Harvard clung to its 5-point lead over Boston University today at the end of twenty-four races in the twenty-third annual Morse Trophy regatta for the national intercollegiate dinghy championship.

The relative advance of communism and retreat of the non- Communist area of the world "bursts the bubble of complacency." Dr. Charles Malik, president of the United Nations General Assembly, declared yesterday.
HARTFORD, June 18 -- A bill to reduce the penalty for shoplifting was vetoed today by Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff. Then the veto was vetoed before it had been formally processed.
LONDON, June 18 -- The stock market threw off most of yesterday's despondency today and a wide range of industrials advanced. Gains were generally under a shilling (14 cents).

The most famous line that Ethel Barrymore spoke during more than half a century on the American stage was this: "That's all there is -- there isn't any more." The voice in which she said the words was unlike any other voice in the memory of the oldest playgoers. It may not have been more beautiful than other voices, but it was entirely unforgettable.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- Titus Haffa, chairman of Webcor, Inc., Chicago, said today he was trying to cancel a contract under which he sold 20 per cent of Webcor's outstanding common stock to the Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation and has offered to rebuy the shares at the price he received for them.
As the scoreboard in the Stadium flashed 4:57 yesterday Casey Stengel drew a deep breath and found it most refreshing.
Texaco, Inc., is planning to buy the Superior Oil Company of California for the equivalent of $765,000,000.
Irving Rifkin, sportswear, leased a floor at 17 West Seventeenth Street and has moved from Broadway and Thirteenth. Williams Co. negotiated the lease.

GLEN COVE, L. L., July 18 -Mr. and Mrs. John Hall Allen f 480 Park Avenue, New York, d Meadow Spring in this community, gave a supper-dance tonight to introduce to society s, Allen's daughter, Miss Jeanne Yon oecklin.
TRENTON, June 18 -- New Jersey's life insurance companies will be permitted to sell variable annuity contracts under a measure approved today by Gov. Robert B. Meyner, effective immediately.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Ezra Taft Benson urged the public today to eat more eggs in an effort to alleviate the critical depression in the poultry industry.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals upheld today the right of the Federal Power Commission to suspend increases in natural gas rates even though an escalator clause in the sales contract provides for the increases.
Federal mediators continued their efforts yesterday to bring the A. P. food chain and a union of striking warehouse men together for new contract talks.
ALBANY, June 18 -- A broad plan under which the state would help stimulate the use of atomic energy for industry and research is under development by the Rockefeller Administration.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 18 -- Little Sailor, ridden by his owner, Peggy Augustus of Cobham, Va., won the ladies working hunter blue in the opening program of the four-day Fairfield County Hunt Club horse show today.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 18 -- A three-judge Federal court dealt Gov. Orval E. Faubus a setback today in his fight against racial integration of Little Rock's public high schools. It declared a state school-closing law unconstitutional.

PITTSBURGH, June 18 (AP) -- National Steel Corporation announced today it had let three contracts for projects at plants of its subsidiaries in Weirton, W. Va., and Detroit as part of its $300,000,000 expansion.

MIAMI, Fla., June 18 (AP) -- Thunderstorms and wind gusts up to sixty miles an hour lashed Miami today in the wake of a tornado that injured at least 100 persons and caused damage estimated at $5,000,000.
The private secretary of Monroe Goldwater, long a power in Democratic politics here, was revealed yesterday as the owner of record of most of a proposed slum clearance site in the Bronx.
Beginning Sunday, ten daily New Haven Railroad trains will have connections at Providence, R. I., with motor coach service to and from Cape Cod points.

It is possibly nobody's business how Mrs. Sarah Nelson, 100 years old, fractured her right hip yesterday afternoon. She told a policeman who had been assigned to find out that she had taken a spill while practicing ballet steps in her living room.
ALBANY, June 18 -- Controller Arthur Levitt proposed today that he be given the power to check on expenditures by harness racing tracks for the construction projects they build with state funds.

CHICAGO, June 18 (UPI) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates rallied for two runs in the thirteenth inning today to beat the Chicago Cubs 4 -- 2, and help Elroy Face gain his eleventh victory in relief without a defeat.
WHEN hot, humid weather settles over New York, a woman's hairdo often shows it. Curly hair often becomes kinky and unmanageable; soft, very fine hair loses its curl and wilts.

The short interest position on the New York Stock Exchange amounted to 3,244,393 shares as of June 15. That was a decrease of 77.939 shares from the 3,322,332 reported on May 15 and the lowest figure since Jan. 15, 1958 when it was 2,832,740 shares. It has declined for six straight months.
LONG BEACH, L. I., June 18 -- Governor Rockefeller told the Carlino scholarship fund dinner tonight that more than half the state's population would live in suburban areas before very long.
The "Today" show will become yesterday starting in September.

BALTIMORE, June 18 (UPI) -- Chico Carrasquel's single with the bases loaded and two out in the ninth inning lifted the Baltimore Orioles to a 7-6 triumph over the Detroit Tigers today. The Tigers had enjoyed a 6-1 lead in the eighth.
GENEVA, July 18 -- The mists that have veiled the distant Alps all these weeks drifted away for a few moments this morning and Mount Blanc was revealed in all its snowy splendor.

GUATEMALA, June 18 (AP) -- The Guatamalan Government and the United Fruit Company expect a settlement to be worked out for squatters who have built on the company's land near the northeastern village of Entre Rios.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- James Hugh Trexler, a radio engineer at the Naval Research Laboratory, is the first man to talk to the moon and get a reply. On July 24, 1954, his voice was reflected off the face of the moon and received back on a radar antenna scooped into the ground, thus completing the first voice-radio circuit with the moon.

THERE have been a number of inquiries about the new deer law passed by the 1959 Legislature, and what it means and how it works. The season is still more than five months away but the 500,000 deer hunters of this state do nothing all year long except talk about deer hunting.

A "fighting mad" Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack flew back from a Puerto Rican vacation yesterday to "stand by the side" of his son, Hulan E. Jack Jr., criticized for taking a Civil Service job in his father's office.
A drug that attacks mental depressions rapidly and apparently without dangerous side effects was described here yesterday.
GENEVA, June 18 -- Andrei A. Gromyko kept the foreign ministers' conference dangling today.
Pennsylvania's Secretary of Labor charged here yesterday that major farm lobbies were seeking to strip away state reforms for migrant workers and to block Federal efforts in the field.

FRANKFURT, Germany, June 18 (AP) -- Two Soviet MIG jet fighters buzzed an Iranian airliner five times yesterday when it strayed over the Baltic Sea, an airline spokesman reported here tonight. The plane's co-pilot said it was a "close call."
