Federal mediators arranged yesterday for a meeting Monday between the A. P. food chain and a union representing 1,400 striking warehouse men.

" YOU recently mentioned a French dish, duck with cherries. Could you send me a recipe for it? I have always made duck with orange and would like to try the other dish for a change." Mrs Anthony Zega, Stockton, N. J.

It is strange to feel a sense of regret, as if at the passing of an era, now that Eamon de Valera has become President of the Republic of Ireland. Born in New York and only half an Irishman by blood, he has exemplified for more than forty years and more than any individual the Ireland of our times.
The razing of a 137-year-old building at 225 Park Row, one of eighty-seven structures in the area to be replaced by a middle-income housing project, began yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- Attorney General William P. Rogers announced today the entry of an anti-trust consent judgment against six major oil companies operating on the West Coast. It prohibits any price-fixing or other alleged practices about which the Government complained in 1950.
MILWAUKEE, June 19 -- A scientist presented a new theory here today and said it settled a thirty-year controversy over whether matter exists as particles, waves, or both.

An American edition of a study of the personality and life work of Queen Elizabeth II will be published by World on July 6, the day the Queen visits this country. Called "How The Queen Reigns," the book has been written by Dorothy Laird, British author.
MANISTEE, Mich., June 19 (AP) -- Hunters face a serious shortage of wild ducks because of drought conditions in United States and Canadian prairie potholes, a Government official said today.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 19 -- Expeditions from the Harvard College will go to Europe and the Near East next month to study the atmosphere of Venus, the unversity said today.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The index of average wholesale primary market prices remained at 119.4 per cent of its 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Joseph C. Foust, M. D., a 35-year-old general practitioner from Ionia, Mich., left yesterday to spend a lifetime in the back country of Tanganyika.
MONTCLAIR, N. J., June 19 -- Three men walked through heavy underbrush and a narrow cleft this morning to reach the top of a ninety-foot cliff in the second ridge of Watchung Mountain.
NEWARK, June 19 -- The New York, Susquehanna and Western Railroad told the State Board of Public Utility commissioners today it would not press for complete abandonment of its passenger service.

Operating revenues of Virginia Electric and Power Company increased by 6.8 per cent in May and in the twelve months ended on May 31. Net income for May ran 4.4 per cent higher and for the twelve months 3.7 per cent higher, the company has announced.
HARTFORD, June 19 -- Churchgoers were firmly assured here today that Christianity and its percepts would not be destroyed by the explorations of science in outer space.

I hope you will allow me to express a word of appreciation for your editorial of June 16 commenting favorably on the decision of the American Medical Association to withdraw its opposition to group medical care paid for by prepaid insurance.

The Geneva conference of foreign ministers, foredoomed by the Soviets from the start, has collapsed for the present in complete deadlock, with but one saving grace. Instead of breaking off all further negotiations, as amply justified by Soviet provocations, it decided to "recess" for a three-week cooling-off period and to meet again for a new beginning on July 13.
The Northrop Corporation yesterday reported a consolidated net income of $5,350,000 for the nine months ended on April 30 against $5,070,406 cleared in the prior year's period.

To a child brought up on a run-down street where houses are in a state of disrepair and sidewalks are perpetually littered, these surroundings seem quite normal. So much so that a well-cared-for house on a clean street invites the artistic touch of a blemish, at least a window smashed or a door unhinged, to make the sight bearable.
The owner of a tenement at 276 West 119th Street, where a 4-year-old girl was badly bitten by a rat, was summoned yesterday to appear in Municipal Term Court June 30 for violating the Sanitary Code.
Another longshore leader has "talked freely" to the Waterfront Commission of New York harbor.
DENVER, Colo., June 19 -- Republicans, young and old, assailed the Democrats today over the Senate's rejection of Lewis L. Strauss as Secretary of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Pan American World Airways has signed agreements with four more unions providing assurance that transport of personnel and cargo essential to national defense will not be interrupted by a dispute affecting commercial airline service.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 19 -- The Little Rock School Board voted 3 to 2 today against appealing Federal Court decision holding the Arkansas school closing law invalid.

The long strike against the voluntary, nonprofit hospitals is ended, if terms of settlement are ratified. Even though it lasted six weeks, it produced no results that should not have been attainable without use of the improper strike weapon.
LAKEHURST, N. J., June 19 -- The first airship designed specifically for use in defense patrol and the largest non-rigid lighter-than-air craft ever built was delivered to the Navy here today.
Maj. Gen. Evan M. Houseman has been promoted to deputy commandant of the Industrial College of the Armed Forces at Fort Lesley J. McNair, Washington.
BONN, Germany, June 19 -- West Berlin has been chosen as the site of the July 1 election of a West German President.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- The tire industry does more for its retail dealers than any other industry, a Senate subcommittee was told today.

MOSCOW, June 19 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev proposed today that another effort to reach a formula on the German question be made at Geneva, buthe warned that there was a limit to the price the Soviet Union would pay for a summit meeting.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- Two radio-TV networks called today for quick legislation to undo the Federal Communications Commission's "equal-time' rule on newscasts.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- As Lewis Lichtenstein Strauss sat in a hearing room recently, he looked up at his Senatorial judges, his large brown eyes welling with tears, and defended himself as "a plain man who has only tried to do his best for his country as he sees it."
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- Cases of paralytic poliomyelitis are continuing to run far ahead of the comparative 1958 figures, the Public Health Service said today.
The alumni of the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism have protested to the Turkish Government the conviction of an alumnus, Ahmet Emin Yalman, an Istanbul publisher.

OTTAWA, June 19, (Canadian Press) -- The deportation of Hal C. Banks, Canadian head of the Seafarers International Union, was suggested today in the House of Commons. Mr. Banks was born in the United States.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 19 (UPI) -- Silky Sullivan, back at a sprint distance, today captured the $10,000 Monterey Purse at Hollywood Park with his customary stretch run, coming from twelve lengths off the pace to score.

LONDON, June 19 (Reuters) -- Following, in translation from the Russian, are excerpts from Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's speech today at a Kremlin reception honoring a visiting East German delegation:

The vacancy rate in office buildings in Manhattan is 2.5 per cent, the same as a year ago, in spite of the completion during the year of ten competitive structures containing 4,528,000 square feet. The ten new buildings brought the number of such structures finished since the end of World War II to ninety-eight with 28,497,000 square feet of space.
BATON ROUGE, La., June 19 -- Lieut. Gov. Lether Frazar took over as Acting Governor of Louisiana today.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- "What's good for the city is good for the country."

A departmental trial has been scheduled for a Hunter College faculty member who figured prominently in the controversy over whether teachers who were once Communist party members could be compelled to become informers.

Farmers and farm groups interested in exploiting the labor of children of migrant workers are again seeking a Federal order that would have the effect of making the child labor law unenforcible, it was charged here yesterday.

Supreme Court Justice Morris Spector yesterday restored to the calendar a motion by Jacob Brownstein, Brooklyn attorney, to set aside a contempt sentence pronounced on him by Magistrate Robert F. Mahoney.
The riding of Robert Ussery and Manuel Ycaza and the lowest daily double in New York racing history marked yesterday's program before 16,275 at Belmont Park.
WHEN Maxim Gorky visited Luna Park in 1906, he concluded that Americans must be a very sad people. Why else, the Russian novelist asked, would they have to go to such lengths to amuse themselves ?
Steels, drugs and aircrafts did well yesterday as the New York Stock Exchange plodded through its dullest session since Aug. 19. Motors, rubbers, oils and electronics were weak.

LONDON, June 19 (UPI) -- Ramanathan Krishnan, a 22-year-old Davis Cup star from Madras, India, upset Alex Olmedo today in the semi-final round of the London grass court tennis tournament, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 1.
The Air Force Academy football team would like to include as many New York games on its schedule as possible.
A YEAR IN PARADISE,"* by Floyd Schmoe, is an appealing memoir of seasons spent in a glorious American wilderness -- the slopes of Mount Rainier.

Consumers Power Company announced yesterday that it would build a $30,000,000 nuclear power plant on Lake Michigan at Big Rock Point, between Charlevoix and Petoskey, on the northern shore of Michigan's Lower Peninsula.
Park Commissioner Robert Moses himself asked the Board of Estimate yesterday to appropriate the $20,000 needed to allow free Shakespeare performances in Central Park this summer.

If Superior Oil Company (California) merges into Texaco, Inc., as expected, the New York Stock Exchange will lose its highest-priced common stock. Yesterday the shares closed at $1,825. Its successor as the costliest stock will be Coca-Cola International Corporation for which the latest bid is $1,000 a share, with no takers at that price.

FARMINGDALE, L. I., June 19 -- A taxpayers' revolt may force educators on Long Island to revise their concept of the role schools should play in the community, a group of specialists on youth problems was told here today.
LONDON, June 19 -- Stock market prices moved irrigularly here today with turnover small and demand selective.
SYRACUSE, June 19 -- Thirty-one eight-oared crews from twelve colleges will race tomorrow on Onondaga Lake in the fifty-seventh regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., June 19 -- A dinner dance at the Creek Club and a supper dance at the Piping Rock Club served as settings in which two debutantes of this "little season" made their bows to society tonight.
DURBAN, South Africa, June 19 -- New clashes occurred here today between African women and the police.
BUENOS AIRES, June 19 -- President Arturo Frondizi clung to the military ministers of his Cabinet today for armed support against a conspiracy to overthrow his Government.

THE woman whose hairdo still looks like a tossed salad is out of step. According to Leon Amendola, director of the Charles of the Ritz School of Advanced Hair Fashions, summer coiffures should be smooth, not ruffled, and curled at the ends.

Police Inspector George H. Redding, commanding officer of the Nineteenth Division in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, was promoted yesterday to the rank of Deputy Chief Inspector. He is the first Negro ever to hold that rank.

YOKOSUKA, Japan, Saturday, June 20 -- The 20-year-old United States Navy gunner who was injured when his plane was attacked by two MIG jet fighters said today that he would like "another chance" at the Communist planes.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 19 (AP) -- A touring track and field team from Harvard and Yale won four of the six events they entered tonight at the opening of a two-day international meet.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 19 (UPI) -- Delegates to the triennial national convention of the Lutheran Church-Missouri Synod voted today to expand the foreign exchange study program.

WITH buffet entertaining increasing in popularity, oversized dining accessories for such events top the gift list of many of this year's brides. Aware of this dining trend, New York stores have accumulated many table accessories appropriate for such occasions.

EAST LANSING, Mich., June 19 -- A group of 200 Michigan citizens set up a state-wide organization here today with the avowed purpose of helping to solve Michigan's financial and industrial problems on a nonpartisan basis.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- The Interior Department said today that William F. Quinn of Hawaii was eligible to continue in office as Territorial Governor while he was a candidate for election as Governor of the new state.

The prospective sponsor of a slum clearance project offered as evidence of "good faith" to deposit $700,000 in a bank headed by Thomas J. Shanahan, it was disclosed yesterday. Mr. Shanahan is vice chairman of the Mayor's Slum Clearance Committee.
Dull trading, with prices moving narrowly marked the activity on most commodity exchanges here yesterday.

Ten railroads serving the Port of New York were directed yesterday to reinstate 125 tugboat oilers by midnight tonight. The dismissal of the oilers last Monday set off a tie-up of railroad marine operations here.

DUBLIN, June 19 -- Results from Dublin County, the last constituency to report, showed today that voters in the Republic of Ireland had decided to retain the proportional representation system of voting.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- President Eisenhower praised Senator Albert Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, today for the Senator's vote to confirm Lewis L. Strauss as Secretary of Commerce.
Leo Kerz and George Justin will bring Marcel Ayme's comedy "Moonbirds" to Broadway on Oct. 14. Rehearsals have been scheduled to begin Aug. 31 under the direction of Jules Dassin.
The United Steelworkers of America made its first major move yesterday to break the seven-week deadlock in negotiations for a new wage agreement.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., June 19 -- Mrs. Pat Cici of Lido and Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches will meet in the final round of the fifty-sixth annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship tomorrow.
Six youths were arrested in Corona, Queens, yesterday in the rape of a 14-year-old girl on Thursday.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 19 -- Two hundred office workers petitioned the Board of Selectmen today for additional parking facilities in the downtown business district.

BATON ROUGE, La., June 19 (UPI) -- A psychiatrist who has examined Governor Long said today that there had been a danger that Mr. Long might have killed himself through extended manic excitement had he not been hospitalized.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- Highs in airport traffic were reached during 1958, the Federal Aviation Agency reported today.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- President Eisenhower sent a message of praise today to scientists and explorers of eleven nations who are wintering in the Antarctic.
CHATHAM, N. J., June 19 (AP) -- The world heavyweight champion, Floyd Patterson, impressed a former titleholder, Jack Dempsey, with his speed and condition today in a four-round boxing tune-up.
ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., June 19 -- Queen Elizabeth II departed from her tightly planned schedule today and delighted Newfoundlanders by mingling with them.

CHICAGO, June 19 (AP) -- A Greek freighter, the Taxiarhis, is under orders to keep her crew aboard while the vessel is docked in Calumet Harbor, the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service reported today.

Marino Sbuttoni, 43-year-old pneumatic driller, was shocked and burned this morning when he drilled into a secondary electric cable. He was working at an excavation at Third Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street at the time.
General Instrument Corporation is looking forward to another year of record sales and improved earnings in fiscal 1959-60, Martin H. Benedek, chairman, told the annual meeting yesterday in Newark.
Cardinal Spellman will preside at the seventh annual San Juan Festival on Randalls Island tomorrow at 2:30 P. M.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 19 -- Developments in the Belgian Congo are being studied in Brussels with a mixture of hope and uneasiness.

GROSSINGER, N. Y., June 19 (UPI) -- Johansson staggered a sparmate, Clarence Floyd, four times today with straight rights and pulled him out of the ring-ropes once to prevent his falling to the canvas.

Figures that may mark a significant turn in the downward trend of attendance at motion pictures during the last decade have been reported by Sindlinger Co. The business analysis concern, in its latest findings, has indicated that the motion-picture industry may be heading for its best summer in ten years.

GENEVA, June 19 (Reuters) -- Following are the texts of a statement today by the United States, British and French delegations to the foreign ministers' conference, of the Western proposals on Berlin and of Soviet proposals:
GENEVA, June 19 -- The Big Four foreign ministers agreed today to recess their conference on the German and Berlin problems to July 13. Geneva will again be the meeting place.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that producers of wool would receive subsidy payments of 25.6 cents a pound for wool marketed during the 1958 marketing year.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (UPI) -- The Senate Public Works Committee approved today President Eisenhower's nomination of former Representative Brooks Hays to be a member of the Tennessee Valley Authority's board of directors.
PARIS, June 19 -- The Ministry of Interior ordered today the seizure of a book accusing police officials in Paris of torturing Algerian rebel suspects arrested here.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The Senate's 49-46 rejection of Lewis L. Strauss for Secretary of Commerce was attributed by Senators today to three major factors.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The chances of any early Federal legislation to aid the distressed egg and poultry industry appeared dim today.
NDOLA, Northern Rhodesia, June 2 -- A square mile of typical African bushland near here has been transformed into a woodland laboratory.
YONKERS, June 19 -- Steamin' Demon, a free-for-all pacer two years ago, tonight recorded his first triumph as a free-for-all trotter.

LONDON, June 19 (Reuters) -- India, with a first-innings deficit of 58, reached 108 for four wickets in its second innings on the second day of the second cricket test match against England at Lord's today.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Fortunately, and at long last, there is real prospect of a de Gaulle-Eisenhower meeting. Neither the time nor place has yet been fixed; but both Presidents appear to recognize the urgent need for conference.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- Congress was urged today to ease restrictions on mineral leases in Alaska.

NEWARK, June 19 -- The National Labor Relations Board today filed a second complaint against the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers under the Taft-Hartley Law provisions prohibiting secondary boycotting.
Major debt financing in the public capital market will aggregate more than $125,000,000 next week.

GENEVA, June 19 -- A conference that had its conception in Soviet threats last November recessed today with similar threats echoing from the Kremlin. Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's speech today was received by Western delegations here as a playback of his note of Nov. 27.
CRANSTON, R. I., June 19 -- Harvard finished first in the last two races today and won the twenty-third annual national intercollegiate dinghy championship.
Thomas J. McDermott has resigned as head of broadcast programing for the Benton Bowles advertising agency.
PHILADELPHIA, June 19 Victor H. Blanc, District Attorney, announced today that Edward J. Cooney Jr., 15 years old, who strangled a little girl on June 4, would not be tried for murder.
Engineers yesterday sought a more appreciative evaluation of their technological role in the space age.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (UPI) -- Anthony Arpaia, member of the Interstate Commerce Commission, surprised a hearing today by suggesting that the agency be given fewer regulatory powers.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The Navy received a patent this week for a portable machine that dumps aviators head over heels into a swimming pool. It shows a trainee what it will be like if he ever has to "ditch" his plane at sea.
WILTON, Conn., June 19 -- A property revaluation program this year was voted last night at a town meeting attended by 800 persons.
Angry bickering over the drafting of the agreement to end the hospital strike here threatened to wreck Mayor Wagner's peace plan last night.

GENEVA, June 19 -- When the foreign ministers' conference recesses tomorrow until July 13, it will have lasted forty-one days through eighteen plenary sessions in the Palais des Nations and thirteen private meetings in the villas of the four ministers.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (UPI) -- The United States turned down today a Soviet invitation to compete in an international film festival in Moscow in August.
The Chrysler Corporation and Aluminium, Ltd., of Canada have joined forces to produce and supply aluminum alloys for Chrysler's automobile plants in the United States and Canada.
The New York Board of Rabbis noted with concern yesterday reports of "the accelerated liquidation of the remnants of Jewish religious life in the Soviet Union."

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- President Eisenhower assailed today the Senate's refusal to confirm Lewis L. Strauss to be Secretary of Commerce. He called it a "sad episode" that had cost the American people a servant of "proven character, ability and integrity."
The Cuban boxing invasion of Madison Square Garden last night proved a complete success.
JOHN BRENNAN is at it again, trying in the national interest to keep track of every trout in the State of New Hampshire. Few escape his burning eye.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 19 (AP) -- Jackie Brandt singled home two runs in the tenth inning tonight as the San Francisco Giants edged Milwaukee, 1 -- 3, and took first place in the National League.
Your pungent editorial of June 15 "This Museum Closed" is a well-deserved rebuke to our city government. I am glad you also included the progressive cutting down of hours by the public library.

Plans for two twenty-eight-story buildings with a total of 1,350 apartments, to be built at a cost of $13,200,000 as part of the Lincoln Square redevelopment, were filed yesterday with the Department of Buildings.
Robert Moses designated the dummy-held Soundview bungalow tract in the Bronx as a slum clearance site after its owners had failed to obtain city approval of tax abate-...

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- Senator Milton R. Young took off from the Minot, N. D., Air Force Base last night in a jet tanker plane to speed here to vote for Lewis L. Strauss for Secretary of Commerce. The North Dakota Republican never got here.

The President, under the Constitution, has the right to appoint the members of his Cabinet subject to the approval of the Senate. This approval is not usually withheld and should not be, for the Chief Executive must be free to choose the members of his official family.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- An Army private first-class has been cleared by a court-martial of a charge that he destroyed Government property.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- A witness charged before the Senate Internal Security subcommittee today that the Russians had misled the Rev. Dr. Billy Graham into reporting that they had "high morality and religious fervor."
HONG KONG, June 19 -- What were called the worst floods in the history of Kwangtung province were reported today in a Chinese Communist newspaper here.

A plastic dome and a "space frame," both new to New York, will be erected next month on the premises of the Museum of Modern Art. They will rise on land adjoining the museum garden on Fifty-fourth Street west of Fifth Avenue.

New Jersey will have to do some hard bargaining to get holders of New Jersey Turnpike bonds to give up their control over the surplus earnings of the toll expressway, according to opinion in the financial district yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The United States Consumers' Price Index set a record in May, the Government reported today.
A Federal grand jury yesterday indicted six leading companies in the printing machinery and related equipment and supplies industries on charges of price fixing and restraint of trade.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The House of Representatives approved today a $7,000,000,000 increase in the national debt limit, as requested by President Eisenhower.
The Yankees grimly continued to cut down the front-runners in the American League last night.
Voting machines will be used in Manhattan and Queens in the primary election on Sept. 15, the Board of Elections announced yesterday.
BUFFALO, June 19 (AP) Robert Clark Jr., 32 years old, of Des Moines, won the presidency of the United States Junior Chamber of Commerce today.

BONN, Germany, June 19 -- The dispute between Dr. Ludwig Erhard, Minister of the Economy, and Chancellor Konrad Adenauer broke out again today. Dr. Erhard declared: "The fate of the party is at stake."
BALTIMORE, June 19 (UPI) -- Superb pitching by Billy O'Dell and Skinny Brown led the Baltimore Orioles to a sweep of their twin bill with the Kansas City Athletics, 8 -- 2 and 2 -- 0, tonight.

The Brotherhood Synagogue at 139 West Thirteenth Street conducted a fifth anniversary Sabbath Service last night to commemorate its founding by the Rev. Irving J. Block. The congregation shares a common sanctuary with the Village Presbyterian Church.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 19 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold urged today that the United Nations continue its aid program far Palestinian Arab refugees until they could be absorbed into the economic life of the Middle East.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 19 -- There never were more cruising yachts in this Naval center than there were today. They were assembled for the ocean race to Newport that begins tomorrow. If there weren't seventy-one of them riding at anchor in Spa Creek or tied to piers, some were delinquent in reporting themselves as withdrawn from the biggest of these coastwise contests since the event began in 1947.

We won't try to pretend that things have been the same around here since the Giants and the Dodgers left. A ghastly void remains, with nothing to fill it. When the Yankees became early season underdogs it helped some, for the traditionally divided opinion among fans turned to pity, and everyone could admire their manly effort to regain habitual eminence.

The market for prime-risk debt investments closed the week yesterday on a note of cautious optimism. In line with the pattern of trading over much of the past fortnight, business continued on the light side in all areas.

The Board of Estimate has agreed to sponsor bills at the next session of the Legislature to protect certain benefits of employes affected by the sale of the city's three rapid-transit power plants to the Consolidated Edison Company.

A FAR cry from the fringed mantel and the stuffed bird under glass, Victorian jewelry -- the pretty extravagances of an era -- has proved of enduring charm. Witness to this is Emely Bramson, Altman's buyer of old, one-of-a-kind jewelry.

Activity in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange increased yesterday. The near July contract dropped 16 points (80 cents a bale) but the other months rose 1 to 18 points. The new October and December options were the strongest.

The Realty Equities Corporation has purchased the thirteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 789 West End Avenue, southwest corner of Ninety-ninth Street, for cash over mortgages amounting to $405,000. The Philip Fogel Company was the broker.

We have heard quite a bit in recent times of various "five-year plans." The number has seemed to exercise an odd fascination. Now another one has come up that makes an abundance of good sense. It has been originated in Britain. This "five-year-plan" will be a concerted attack in the United Kingdom, the Commonwealth and the various British dependencies on the problem of blindness, its prevention and cure.
An unusual collection of postage stamps went on display yesterday at the Sheraton-McAlpin Hotel. It will be open to the public today and tomorrow.
WESTPORT, Conn., June 19 --Chappaqua and Cameda were double winners in the second program of the four-day Fair-field County Hunt Club horse show today.

NEW DELHI, India, June 19 -- A leader of the Indian Communist party declared today that if agitation to oust the Communist regime in Kerala was not curtailed, his party would begin a similar "struggle" against Congress party governments in other states.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., June 19 (UPI) -- The Air Force fired rockets from both Florida coasts today in separate projects aimed at developing a bomber-launched ballistic missile and an escape capsule for human space voyagers. Both tests apparently were successful.

BOULDER, Colo., June 19 -- First-day results in the Amateur Athletic Union's national track and field championships assured the United States of a solid core of tried-and-true performers for this summer's dual meet against the Soviet Union and the Pan-American Games.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- If any man can take personal credit for the defeat of Lewis L. Strauss, it is Clinton Presba Anderson, the junior Senator from New Mexico.

LE MANS, France, June 19 -- In this country amid the sprawling farmlands of the Midwest, hogs and cattle are sold, as is wheat and other produce. Le Mans is, in its way, as unlikely a place for an automobile race as Indianapolis.
The Board of Education was urged yesterday to carry out its plan to transfer an overflow of Brooklyn public school pupils to five underutilized Queens schools.
OTTAWA, June 19 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's exports fell by 10 per cent in May to $434,500,000, down $49,700,000 from last year's record of $484,200,000, the Bureau of Statistics reported today.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., June 19 (AP) -- Former Gov. John S. Fine says he did not date back a pardon granted to John LaRocca, Pittsburgh racketeer. He says he signed it, then withheld it until he received a personal report on LaRocca.

MONTREAL, June 19 (AP) -- Bruce Crampton, a curly-haired, 23-year-old Australian who hasn't had much success this year in his annual golfing tour of America, took the lead at the halfway point of the Canadian open tournament today. He had a 36-hole score of 135.

ROME, June 19 -- Impressive remains of an imperial private circus, or arena, built in the third century A. D. have come to light in excavations on the southeastern outskirts of Rome. Emperor Heliogabalus, the youthful monarch whose short reign from A. D. 218 to 222 marked an extravagant period in the decline of Rome, is believed to have watched horse and chariot races on the site. more than 100,000 spectators.

Your editorial of June 10 in which the French are now castigated for demands made many months ago concerning the French role in NATO seems to be part of a new national pastime -- criticizing the French every summer.
CHICAGO, June 19 -- Heavy buying of all kinds of home furnishings was reported today at the International Home Furnishings Summer Market in progress here.

CHICAGO, June 19 (AP) -- A Government outlook for a fall pig crop about 8 per cent larger than last year's set off a strong rally in the distant futures contracts for feed grains on the Board of Trade today.

Your June 15 editorial "Leave It to the [Traffic] Experts" begs for rebuttal. The impartiality you praise is not a quality of experts but of judges. No expert recommendation can avoid hurting one side while helping another.

The proposal of Texaco, Inc., to take over Superior Oil Company (California) took the oil industry and Wall Street by surprise. But observers agree that it was "an entirely logical move" with considerable potential benefits to both parties.

GENEVA. June 20 -- Late on Friday night. after the Big Four foreign ministers had agreed to recess their deadlocked conference, a weary British diplomat was asked what the point was in resuming the talks on July 13.
Whenever a swarm of bees alights uninvited on someone's doorstep or in a yard, the police call on Stanley Einzig.

BALTIMORE, June 20 -- Bud Daley, with help from Bob Grim, defeated Hoyt Wilhelm in a battle of knuckleballs tonight. The result was that the Kansas City Athletics beat the Orioles. 6 -- 2, and snapped a seven-game losing streak.

MONTREAL -- The problem of insuring that next Friday's formal opening of the St. Lawrence Seaway by Queen Elizabeth and President Eisenhower takes place smoothly and punctually, and that the throngs of visitors who want to witness the historic ceremony can do so comfortably, is occupying the attention of officials on both sides of the border this week.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 20 -With blues in the open and the stake events. Another Foggy Morn, owned by Mr. and Mrs. James Dioguardi of Bedford N. Y., gained the green jumper championship of the Fairfield County Hunt Club Horse Show today.
PRESENTING a show in, around and under the water is an undertaking of many dimensions.

GENEVA, June 20 -- The negotiations here for a ban on nuclear weapons testing have developed into a marathon in which the Soviet Union accuses the United States of tossing in conditions to break up the sessions with the connivance of Britain.
Associate Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court said last night that this country and Asian nations needed Israel as "a great bastion of freedom and justice along the Mediterranean."

THIS week, as for hundreds of weeks in the past and no one knows how many weeks in the future, Konrad Adenauer sat down at the huge oval table in the West German Chancellery's long and elegant Cabinet room. In front of him lay a great brass bell with its own hammer, a replica of the bell he used more than forty years ago when he presided at town council meetings as Oberbuergermeister of Cologne.
ANNANDALE - ON - HUDSON, N. Y., June 20 -Senator Paul H. Douglas said today that it was "a cause of wonder that with so much of the beast in us, moral principles are so powerful and guiding."

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- The Pentagon says it does not object to saying how much arms aid the United States sends to each of its allies around the world. But the State Department wants the figures kept secret.

BOSTON -- Within an area bounded roughly by Boston Harbor, the Charles River and Massachusetts Avenue, the tourist can retrace three centuries of history in the ancient seaport. New skyscrapers and snarled traffic, of course, are symbols of the impatient twentieth century.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The State Department, faced with a hard choice in Brazil's financial crisis, has chosen a way out. Officials believe the move will not undermine the drive toward financial stability elsewhere in Latin America.

After six weeks of wrangling, the Geneva conference has taken a recess without answering the two questions that were raised when it began: whether an interim solution of the West Berlin problem can be reached and whether the issues will be referred to a summit meeting.

SUBTITLED "a collection of first picture ideas," Ruth Krauss' latest book is a series of pictorial jokes and free-wheeling fancies, inspired in part by school children and drawn by Remy Charlip. It would be interesting to know just where the children's ideas left off and those of the author and artist began.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (UPI) -- A panel of experts said today that low intensity radioactive waste might safely be dumped in twenty-eight shallow areas, all lying within 118 miles of major Atlantic and Gulf seaports.

BATON ROUGE, La., June 20 -- There is a political axiom in Louisiana that when a Long -- any Long -- runs for office he automatically starts off with 25 per cent of the votes and almost as automatically picks up another 25 per cent on the way.

" LIAR," "barbarian," "seditionist," "cynic." Those are some of Richard H. Rovere's words for Joseph Raymond McCarthy, United States Senator from 1947 until his death ten years later, and for a few of those years -- again Mr. Rovere's language -- "in many ways the most gifted demagogue ever bred on these shores."

When the German Federal Republic celebrated the tenth anniversary of its basic constitutional document a month ago many commentators were full of optimism. It looked to them as if the Bonn Republic were soundly established and a new democratic tradition in the making.

YOKOSUKA, Japan, June 20 -- High officers at this United States naval base south of Tokyo indicated today that patrol flights in Far Eastern waters would continue without protection by fighter cover or the arming of the reconnaissance planes themselves.
ALGIERS, June 20 (AP) -- The regional rebel leader in the Macarasaida area of eastern Algeria has surrendered, the French Army announced yesterday.
LAKE ARROWHEAD, Calif., June 20 (AP) -- Jascha Heifetz, the violinist, now is a Professor of Music and artist in residence at the University of California at Los Angeles.
Six prominent American plastic surgeons will leave for Europe Thursday on a trip in which they hope to make a close evaluation of the state of their specialty in the Soviet Union.

DENVER, June 20 -- Young Republicans roared approval today of a resolution that censured two Republican Senators, Margaret Chase Smith and William Langer, for having opposed the confirmation of Lewis L. Strauss as Secretary of Commerce.
HONG KONG, June 20 -- The Chinese Communists have reported that agricultural goals will not be met this year.
Hundreds of boys and girls who usually take father for granted, took him to Central Park yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, June 20 -- An experimental auto insurance "merit plan" has been revamped to make it easier on careful drivers and tougher on reckless ones.

KITTY HAWK, N. C. -- Long before the Wright brothers made the world's first powered flight from Kill Devil Hill here in 1903, this area and the narrow, low-flying finger of sand known as the Outer Barrier which projects south from here 160 miles to Cape Hatteras before curving westward, had established its place in history.

An estimated one-third of the nation's elementary teachers lack college degrees and the bulk of its high school science teachers are inadequately prepared. BEFORE the Italian sea-men's union tied up the Italian Line's ships with a world-wide strike on June 9, that line had booked 6,000 passengers to leave New York for Europe during June. Of this number, only 1,200 of them actually had reached Europe by last week.

MOSCOW, June 20 -- There were indications in Moscow tonight that the Soviet Union still expected not only an accord of some kind when the Big Four foreign ministers meet again at Geneva but also a full-scale summit session later this summer.

" AT the risk of disillusionment," writes Fred Astaire in his autobiography, '"I must admit that I don't like top hats, white ties and tails." Nevertheless, these have become the classic Astaire symbols over the years and they seem as much a part of him today as do his nimble, tapping feet, perfectly individual style and unfailing sense of rhythm.

HYANNIS, Mass. -- Weekends at the railroad stations here and at Woods Hole will not be the same this season. New York fathers will still come down on Fridays for a week-end with the family. HARRY MOORE, in his critique of Lawrence Lipton's "The Holy Barbarians," is obviously in familiar territory when dealing with the literary achievements of the Beat writers, but he isn't when he writes of their philosophy and way of life.

Antonino Rocca of Argentina and Miguel Perez of Puerto Rico were again the winners in the tag-team wrestling exhibition at Madison Square Garden last night. Before 12,838 fans they gained a popular decision over John Valentine of Seattle and Abdullah (The Sheik) Farend of Lebanon.

SQUARE Kodacolor transparencies (31mm x 31mm) are offered by Eastman Kodak in a new service available from the Rochester firm through dealers. Kodacolor pictures taken on the popular 127, 120 and 620 sizes, with cropping held to a minimum, are returned in the regular 2x2-inch mounts that fit standard projectors.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 20 (AP) -- Athletes from Harvard and Yale won four of the nine events in which they competed at an international track and field meet in Balmoral Stadium today. The touring collegians also took four seconds.

Few places in the world are as devoid of life as the lofty Greenland icecap. Its vast reaches are fringed with almost impassable mountains and glaciers. A few weeks ago, however, six unarmed Frenchmen found it terrifyingly alive.

THE thirteenth annual International Lily Show of the North American Lily Society will open at 2 o'clock on Thursday at Longwood Gardens, Kennett Square, Pa. Visitors also can see the displays, which will be set up in the Azalea House of the conservatory, on Friday, Saturday and next Sunday, starting at 10 A. M. There is no admission charge.

YONKERS, June 20 -- Kenny J., an 8-year-old bay gelding ] by Calumet Adam, scored a one-and-one-half-length victory over Hundred Proof in the Monitor pace in 2:04 1/5 before 30,919 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
Floyd Patterson has been heavyweight champion of the world for almost three years now, and has defended the title successfully against four rivals.

ALTHOUGH garlic has been one of the most maligned of seasonings it has, for nearly five thousand years, been a source of palatal joy for those with lusty appetites. In Provence and in the region around Naples it is on a par with tomatoes as a cherished addition to savory dishes.
COPENHAGEN -- American tourists who remember the Albany night boat on the Hudson River will find the overnight boat trip on the North Sea between Copenhagen and Oslo in Norway a nostalgic experience.

CLARKSBORO, N. J., June 20 -- Ch. Ruanme Blockbuster, a golden retriever owned by Mrs. M. Hartley Dodge of Madison, N. J., acquired his third best in show award today at the Gloucester County Kennel Club's event. The 4-year-old dog led a field of 360.

TWO well-known American musicians, Alan Hovhaness and Howard Boatwright, will go to India this year to study her ancient system of classical music. They have been awarded Fulbright grants for a year and will study at the Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan, a major force in India's cultural revival.

The Yankees moved to a game and half from first place yesterday by routing the league-leading Indians, 10 -- 2. Bill Skowron drove in five runs for the fifth-place Bombers with two homers and a triple. The Tigers downed the Senators, 7 -- 4, and now trail Cleveland by half a game.
A full-length portrait of George Washington by John Wesley Jarvis will be among the offerings at auction tomorrow at Villa Freba at Great Neck, L. I.

KUTZTOWN, Pa. -- The tenth consecutive annual Pennsylvania Folk Festival opens here next Saturday, and as they would say around here, "Olles faddich. Koom and breing dei friend mit." For those not schooled in Pennsylvania Dutch, that means, "All is ready. Come and bring your friends."

WESTPORT, Conn., June 20 -- An elm tree will be planted June 28 on the east lawn of Christ and Holy Trinity Protestant Episecopal Church at a spot where George Washington is believed to have stopped for a drink of water June 28, 1775.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 20 -- The Indonesian Army will play an increased role in drafting and executing Government policy following the return here of President Sukarno at the end of this month from his two-month world tour, the army's chief spokesman said tonight.

PHOTOGRAPHERS are invited to submit pictures of life on the Lower East Side for an exhibition sponsored by the Lower East Side Neighborhoods Association. The selected entries will be displayed Dec. 4 to Jan. 16 at Cooper Union.
A daylight hold-up in down-town Brooklyn netted three neatly dressed men $6,913.02 in cash and checks yesterday. Their victim was a porter carrying money to a night depository.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., June 20 -- In the New Canaan Country Club this afternoon, Mr. and Mrs. George A. Murphy of New Canaan and Mr. and Mrs. Luther Loomis of Darien gave a tea dance in honor of their debutante daughters, the Misses Louise Addison Murphy and Sarah Winslow Loomis.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- A new estimate that peak demand requirements on electric utility systems in this country will reach 366,000,000 kilowatts by 1980 was made public this week by the Federal Power Commission.

TRENTON -- From the rocky, forested slopes of High Point near Port Jervis, southeast for 150 miles across rolling green hills and through scrub-pine barrens to Cape May, lies one of the most inviting areas in the East for vacation-bound urbanites who prefer the hinterlands to the ocean.

EARLY inauguration of the stamp - issuing program for 1960 is announced by Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield. Decisions regarding four themes have thus far been reached. These are: (1) Fiftieth anniversary of the Boy Scouts of America, A 4-cent stamp will appear on Feb. 8.
Six boys graduating from East Coast high schools this month were named yesterday as winners of $1,000 scholarships on the basis of potential leadership and proficiency in American history.
Queens gained 43,000 new residents in the year ended March 31, according to a statement yesterday by Ira H. Gent, president of the Queens Chamber of Commerce.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Top Administration authorities have resumed studies of the control of nuclear weapons situated in West European countries.

THE baldcypress, which grows wild in swamps, readily adapts to dry, upland situations. Hardy throughout much of the Eastern half of the United States, it makes an excellent lawn and shade tree. Home owners in the New York area should be able to grow baldcypress successfully on a dry ridge or a swampy site.

Regarding Mr. Baldwin's article, can anyone suggest a reason why the B. B. C. broadcast the signal for the attack in the code message "The arrow pierces steel" the evening before the invasion? Was it a mistake, a chaste belief that the code was still intact, or was it a piece of Machiavellian psychology?
The officers and the wagescale committee of New York Typographical Union 6 (Big Six) called upon the members yesterday to reject the proposed newspaper contract at a referendum on July 1.

Marianne Probst of Germany, the winner on Saturday of the World Accordion Competition sponsored by the International Confederation of Accordionists, was the featured performer at a Carnegie Hall concert Saturday night.
BOULDER, Colo., June 21 -- "The greatest men's field and track team in the world" will represent the United States in the return match against the Soviet Union.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 7 -- Eastern Europe's Communist Governments are punching holes in the Iron Curtain to let in a flow of tourist dollars.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (UPI) -- Paul M. Butler, the Democratic national chairman, urged Congress today to make sure that any changes in the equal-time rule for radio and television stations did not lead to "serious abuses."
National Airlines' success in attracting new customers with a $35.10 night coach fare to Miami is outlined in a report by G. T. Baker, National president.
When I last visited Stalingrad in 1943 after the 160-day battle that marked the turning point in the war, all that was left of the city was a statue of children dancing around a fountain.
The American Civil Liberties Union called on Congress yesterday to enact legislation to insure internal democracy of labor unions.

PITTSBURGH, June 21 -- Steel customers were still on pins and needles last week over the question of sufficient steel supplies. Since most steel users have ordered heavily for months to avoid a shortage in case there was to be a strike, this has presented problems for those not in the vanguard.
CHICAGO, June 21 (AP) -- John Buzhardt, a 22-year-old right-hander, limited Philadelphia to one hit today in pitching the Chicago Cubs to a 4-0 victory.

It is almost exactly one hundred years since the great Blondin, a king among acrobats, made the second of three trips across the Niagara River gorge on a high tightrope. Now a real Queen among queens joins President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Diefenbaker to see a twentieth-century spectacle along another river at the opposite end of Lake Ontario. Blondin is said to have skipped across his rope over the Falls in five minutes flat.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The Export-Import Bank (Eximbank) announced today its first loan combining dollars and a foreign currency.
Thirty-five thousand New Yorkers from Puerto Rico participated in the seventh annual San Juan Fiesta yesterday at Randalls Island.
The frenzied dash of the Yankees toward the top of the American League flag race ground to a halt yesterday when Casey Stengel's gears jammed and his machine went into reverse.
DENVER, June 21 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon flew back to Washington early today with a political plum in his pocket.
SUMMIT, N. J., June 21 -- The first impression that hits the newcomer to Floyd Patterson's workouts here at Ehsan's training camp is that the heavyweight champion of the world strikes fast.

ELLENVILLE, N. Y., June 21 (AP) -- Michael H. Prendergast, Democratic state chairman, said tonight that Governor Rockefeller's "promises of economic prosperity must have an especially hollow ring" to egg and poultry producers.

BUENOS AIRES, June 21 -- President Arturo Frondizi took counsel with his political advisers today to find a way to overcome the crisis resulting from the military's lack of confidence in his Government. The armed forces, which stopped an anti-Frondizi conspiracy only last week, rested on their arms and waited.
What might prove to be a great breakthrough in the setting of Chinese characters for printing has been reported by an electrical engineer at Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

Fifteen years ago today the Allied armies, pushing bloodily inland from the Normandy beachheads, sought the ultimate "liberation" of a symbol of Hitler's monstrous tryranny -- the City of Berlin. The British and American Air Forces were dropping bombs on Berlin that would come to more than 70,000 tons before the city fell.

NEW DELHI, India, June 21 -- An official Indian delegation has returned from Communist China impressed with some of the agricultural practices there but unable to accept Peiping's claim of a "big leap forward" in production.
The Napoli Football Club, one of Italy's finest soccer teams, got off to a good start on its five-game tour of the United States and Canada at Ebbets Field in Brooklyn yesterday.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, June 21 -- Developments on the stock market here in the last few weeks clearly reflect its increased dependence on foreign markets.
Two children alone in their mother's apartment died last night when fire swept through a wooden tenement at 156-158 Beach Seventy-fifth Street, Rockaway Beach, Queens.

The National Maritime Union, which represents 40,000 unlicensed seamen, has informed the operators of 590 American-flag deep-sea vessels that it wants to review wage and overtime provisions of existing contracts.

LONDON, June 21 -- Randolph Churchill charges in his book, "The Rise and Fall of Sir Anthony Eden," that the 1956 attack on Egypt was the result of collusion between Britain, France and Israel. The book will be published tomorrow.
Six new films will arrive in local theatres this week. The programs follow:
ED SULLIVAN'S eleventh anniversary on television brought a generally pleasant hour of entertainment to Channel 2 last night.
Ch. Hassen-Ben of Moornitan, a 2-year-old Afghan hound, was selected best in show yesterday at the twentieth annual dog show and obedience test of the S' ten Island Kennel Club at Cromwell Center.
LONDON, June 21 -- The Conservative party has joined the nuclear debate that has wracked the Labor party in recent weeks.

Market Commissioner Anthony Masciarelli said yesterday that experts of the United States Department of Agriculture had agreed with him that the proposed $25,000,000 fruit and produce terminal market in the Bronx would benefit both the city and the industry.
After holding to a narrow trading range during most of the last week, cotton prices in the domestic market fluctuated more widely in the final day's session.

GENEVA, June 21 -- United States and British scientists had preliminary talks over the weekend in preparation for their meeting tomorrow with Soviet experts to study the detection of nuclear explosions in outer space.
Volume and rates tumbled again last week in the steamship charter market.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 21 -- Alejandro Olmedo, the United States Davis Cup player from Peru, and Christine Truman, a baby-faced Briton with the build of an Amazon, are favored to win the All-England lawn tennis championships beginning tomorrow.
DURBAN, South Africa, June 21 -- The seething slum area that bred last Thursday's bloody rioting was sealed off today from sightseeing whites.

Robert Moses revealed yesterday that the city had already built a bulkhead for the extension of a shorefront park that he had planned as a part of the proposed Sound-view slum-clearance project in the Bronx.
Father's Day meant something extra yesterday for the family of Robert Reynolds. Mr. Reynolds' quick thinking, with his Brooklyn house on fire, may have averted tragedy.

WOMEN travel for the same compelling and pleasant reasons that men do. They want to escape from their ordinary lives and responsibilities and, for a short time, find a new identity in a different atmosphere.
ZURICH, June 21 -- Chiefly because of the heavy dip of prices in New York at the beginning of last week, business in Zurich was quieter than it has been in a long time.
PHILADELPHIA, June 21 -- The election of Robert A. Maes as president of the Donner Foundation was announced today. He was formerly executive vice president.

Arnold T. Milton and Alan Rabinowitz, owners of the Maxine Elliott Theatre at 109 West Thirty-ninth Street, have purchased the abutting five-story business building on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 104-06 West Fortieth Street. The sellers were the estate of Louis B. Frank and Edward M. Nash, who owned the parcel for twenty years.

Now that the Loewenberg case has become common knowledge, I think there can be no question that other first-rate American scholars will become hesitant about applying for a Fulbright teaching award as long as the procedures of President Eisenhower's Board of Foreign Scholarships remain so mysterious and inscrutable.
" The key to the church universal lies in the spirit of its local congregations," the Rev. Dr. Norman Goodall said yesterday in a sermon at the Broadway Congregational Church, at Fifty-sixth Street.

Seldom in history has a leader made a more moving appeal on behalf of his people than that contained in the first official and personal statement of the Dalai Lama, made public Saturday in Mussoorie, India. It is an appeal for freedom, for justice and, above all, for peace.
The approval by striking hospital workers of a proposed "declaration of policy" for eighty-one voluntary hospitals here is expected to end the forty-six-day dispute this afternoon.
Under administrative rulings most veterans over 65 years old are at present eligible for pensions if their income is within certain limits

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Two liberal organizations generally favorable to the Democratic party joined today in denouncing the Democratic leadership in Congress and the record of the present Congressional session.

COME summer and New York restaurants do not as a rule follow the custom of their European counterparts, which shift tables, chairs and most of their meal service out onto the sidewalk. The outdoor cafe is not a necessity in this city, where air-conditioning makes most restaurants cool, if not down-right chilly.
Universities in California and Texas are planning to borrow $28,000,000 on serial revenue bonds next month.
American Newspaper Guild delegates held preliminary meetings yesterday for their "organization year" convention that will mark a drive to increase membership by at least 60 per cent.
MONTREAL, June 21 (AP) -- Doug Ford of Paradise, Fla., overcame a one-stroke deficit today and won the Canadian open golf championship with a 72-hole total of 276.

IN recent weeks national attention has been focused on the threat to children in the misuse of plastic bags. The danger of suffocation posed by this new source as well as the dangers of summer play in and out of water suggests the need for parents to take steps to prevent trouble and to prepare themselves to deal with it.

A $38,900,000 contract has been awarded by the Air Force to the Airborne Instruments Laboratory, a division of Cutler-Hammer, Inc., Mineola, L. I. for the development and design of airborne electronic equipment.

BOSTON, June 21 (AP) -Richard Cardinal Cushing urged tonight that high schools and colleges give courses on communism. He explained, "I don't know how we can arouse our people from apathy and indifference unless we teach communism."
HAVANA, June 21 -- Increased fighting between rebels and Government troops is going on in the Dominican Republic, according to reports from Santiago de Cuba.
Roman Catholic and Protestant clergymen in the city joined yesterday in support of a morality study made last week by 104 religious leaders of the three major faiths.
American Stevedores, one of the largest concerns of its kind in the harbor, will begin operations on June 30 at the new two-berth Pier 10 in the Atlantic Basin area of Brooklyn.

Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa has estimated the city's general-fund revenue for the fiscal year starting July 1 at $730,458,000. This includes an expected cash carryover of $7,632,000 from the 1958-59 general fund.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (UPI) -- The National Association of Broadcasters announced today that the television code seals of thirteen stations had been revoked recently because of their advertising policies.
The John Hay Whitney Foundation yesterday announced Opportunity Fellowship awards to fifty-two young Americans for college study and travel.

MELBOURNE, June 21 -- Arthur Augustus Calwell, Deputy leader of the Federal opposition, said here today that General Motors-Holdens, Ltd., was a menace to Australia's future. He asserted that the company was guilty of "ruthless preoccupation with profit-making."
NEWCASTLE, N. B., June 21 (AP) -- Twelve fishermen were known to be dead and twenty-two missing tonight in the wake of a storm that whipped across Northumberland Strait Friday night.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- Representative Wright Patman said today that audit reports on Federal Reserve banks had disclosed "unbelievably shocking" management deficiencies.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanganyika, June 21 -- Julius Nyerere, chairman of the Tanganyika African National Union, and of the Pan-African Freedom Movement of East and Central Africa, will leave for London tomorrow.
A former Jesuit missionary in Iraq who is now the managing editor of Jesuit Missions yesterday described living and working conditions in that country.
The United Jewish Appeal announced yesterday that it had attained a midyear accumulation of $38,150,000 in cash against pledges to help meet Jewish needs over the world.

Ashley Cooper and Mal Anderson, the mainstays of Australia's Davis Cup tennis teams the past two years, scored first-round victories yesterday as Jack Kramer's professional Tournament of Champions started in the West Side Stadium at Forest Hills, Queens.
TRIVANDRUM, India, June 21 (Reuters) -- Two members of Opposition parties were reported today to have been stabbed to death by Communist sympathizers.

New York's summer symphonic concerts at Lewisohn Stadium begin their forty-second consecutive season tonight when Leonard Bernstein appears with the Stadium Symphony Orchestra in the double role of conductor and piano soloist.
The workmen's compensation system in New York State seems to be in for an extensive overhaul.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., June 21 -- Only thirty-two boats in four classes managed to finish within the time limit today in the Long -Island Sound Yacht Racing Association regatta.
The Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman said in his sermon yesterday at Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, that "there must be some good instincts behind the Iron Curtain."

NEWTOWN, Conn., June 21 -- Stanley Simon has built a covered bridge on his summer place here, and now he finds he has a collector's item on his hands. Mr. Simon, a New York management consultant, built the bridge because he is a lover of antiques and, well, he also likes covered bridges.

THE music lovers who return to the Lewisohn Stadium tonight for the opening of a new season of outdoor concerts will hear Beethoven, Barber, Copland Gershwin -- and Minnie. The first four are explicit on the program.
A jet airliner dipped suddenly while landing at New York International Airport yesterday, but it came to a safe stop after crashing through a steel runway barrier.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Gift-giving continues in the capital -- but in at least one case with a new air of caution.
The visit to the United States of Frol R. Kozlov, a Soviet First Deputy Premier, is being planned along lines similar to the tour of Anastas I. Mikoyan, a State Department source reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Selection of an electrodialysis process for the Government's third saline water conversion demonstration plant was announced today by Fred A. Seaton, Secretary of the Interior.
WESTPORT, Conn., June 21 -- Sunset Hill, a Virginia-bred brown gelding, won the green conformation title at the Fairfield County Hunt Club horse show today.

TOKYO, Monday, June 22 -- Joseph P. Crowley, a former Yale football player, was acquitted by a Tokyo court today of a charge that he had caused the death of his brother-in-law, T. A. D. Jones Jr., in a hotel-room brawl here.

On June 17 you printed an editorial entitled "A Commission on the Arts" in which you commend the role of the Federal Government in the area of the arts. Lest there be any misunderstanding as to the role of state governments in the arts -- not only for the sake of the arts but also for the general economy of the state -- certain facts should be noted.

KATONAH, N. Y., June 21 -- To spend a balmy evening in the bosky Venetian theatre at Caramoor is to rejoice the senses. To add music performed with precision and grace is to create enchantment. And that was the accomplishment last night at the opening of the annual festival at Mrs. Lucie Bigelow Rosen's spacious estate.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 21 -- In the movie business, where it can be vital to be on both sides of a fence at the same time, a language ideal for the forked tongue is of value.

Huntington Hartford, financier and art patron, announced yesterday that he was purchasing most of Hog Island in the Bahamas from Dr. Axel Wenner-Gren, Swedish industrialist, to develop a vacation resort for a "discriminating" clientele.
Efforts of the United Fund to take over the fund-raising activities of national independent health agencies were assailed yesterday from two quarters.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., June 21 -- Roy Fairman Jr., 13 years old, frequently caddies for President Eisenhower at the Gettysburg Country Club. Today young Roy and his mother, who are Protestant Episcopalians, decided to go to the President's church, the Gettysburg Presbyterian.
LONDON, June 21 -- Prices on the stock market fluctuated last week, partly in sympathy with Wall Street but also in response to domestic and world factors.

Hoarse, hungry and exhausted, the remnants of the largest major league crowd of the season filed out of Yankee Stadium shortly before 10 o'clock last night, almost eight hours after the start of the double-header between the Yankees and Cleveland Indians.
The Irish of New York and its environs -- 6,000 strong, along with a number of other Gaels -- held their annual Feis on the sunny Hunter College campus in the Bronx yesterday.

LONDON, June 21 (UPI) -- The presses of most provincial newspapers in Britain stood silent today after more than 100,000 printing workers stopped work in support of demands for more pay and shorter hours.
Broadway and Paris productions of "The Complaisant Lover," Graham Greene's new London hit, are under way.
GASPE, Que., June 21 (AP) -- Queen Elizabeth II went to services at St. Paul's Anglican Church here today and heard her husband. Prince Philip, read a biblical lesson on humility.
Following are the texts of a statement by Robert Moses, chairman of the Committee on Slum Clearance, concerning the Soundview project and a telegram by Mr. Moses to The New York Times:
May I take this opportunity to present some comments concerning the recent land reform program of the Cuban Government.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- After five years under a security cloud, William Vincent Vitarelli is going back to teach handicrafts to the natives of the Pacific trust islands.

LISBON, Portugal, June 9 -- Dr. Antonio de Oliveira Salazar, dictator of Portugal for thirty years, has resumed total control over national affairs. In recent months Premier Salazar's illness led to wide disquiet and increased agitation for his resignation.
An increase in childhood cancer deaths may be caused by radiation levels almost as low as those that come from fallout and natural background, according to a chemist at Argonne National Laboratory.
Trygve Lie, first Secretary General of the United Nations, will return to its headquarters today to visit old friends and do research.

The New York Shipping Association will present silver and bronze plaques and citations to twenty-six steamship lines and contracting stevedores for reducing accidents in waterfront operations here last year.

BATON ROUGE, La., June 21 -- A former candidate for State Attorney General on a slate backed by Gov. Earl K. Long will lead the Governor's fight for release from a mental hospital and restoration of his executive powers.
PORT ANGELES, Wash., June 21 -- Science and the great American motoring public have begun their 1959 summer invasions of Olympic National Park.

CLIFTON, N. J., June 21 -- Norman Jenkins, a 32-year-old tile setter and public course golfer, won the New Jersey amateur championship today by defeating Lloyd Monroe of Rockaway River, 1 up, in the 36-hole final at the Upper Montclair Country Club.
MOSCOW, June 21 -- The Government newspaper Izvestia declared today that a "good basis for agreement" between East and West had been laid by the Geneva discussions.

For more than twenty-five years, official Washington has had custody of $9,114,400 of Russian assets assigned to the United States by the Soviet Government during the Roosevelt Administration to satisfy private claims.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 21 -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff of Connecticut spent the day here today eating, golfing and talking with California's Governor, Edmund G. Brown.

IN a way it was like a pilgrim visiting an abandoned shrine. This recent visitor to Ingemar Johansson's training camp at Grossinger left the palatial ranch house where the handsome Swede is concluding his chores for Thursday's fight with Floyd Patterson for the world heavyweight championship at the Yankee Stadium. Instead of wending down the road, he drove up the hill to the airport.
PRINCETON, N. J., June 21 -Engineers in the Radio Corporation of America Laboratories here calculate that a common housefly doing one push-up uses about an erg of energy.

The appointment of Dempster McIntosh as United States Ambassador to Colombia has been rushed through the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and the Senate without discussion. This is surprising, considering the recent controversies over political appointees.

LE MANS, France, June 21 A bright green Aston Martin piloted alternately by Carroll Shelby of Dallas and Roy Salvadori of Britain outlasted rather than outran the field this week-end to win the twenty-seventh edition of the twenty-fofur hour endurance race.
HAVANA, June 21 -- Premier Fidel Castro painted a glowing picture today of the benefits of his agrarian reform law.
Harry Horwitz, realty operator, has purchased the two five-story store and apartment buildings at 818 to 822 Third Avenue and 155 East Fiftieth Street, the northwest corner, from Peter Doelger, Inc.

The Columbia Pictures Corporation has acquired the outstanding 50 per cent of the common stock of Columbia Pictures of Canada, Ltd., from the Premier Operating Corporation. Principal stockholders of the Premier Operating Corporation are Louis Rosenfeld, president of Columbia Pictures of Canada, Jule Allen and Herbert Allen.
TALARA, Peru, June 4 -- This modern, neat oil town in northern Peru is facing a gradual process of withering away -- along with the country's entire petroleum industry.

The Wool Bureau, Inc., will start a record advertising and promotional drive starting next month to reinforce the strong resurgence that wool has been demonstrating as an apparel and furnishings fiber and to exploit new "easy-care" trends in wool technology.

Title to the new fourten-story cooperative apartment house at 475 Park Avenue, southeast corner of Fifty-eighth Street, has been taken by the 475 Park Avenue Corporation, which bought it recently from Henry Goelet, the builder, John W. Lonsdale, president of Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., was the broker.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter returned from Geneva today convinced that the Soviet Union's goal was to absorb West Berlin and then all of Germany into the Communist world.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- The Republican "dream ticket" for 1960 was described by Senator Jacob K. Javits of New York today as either Nixon-Rockefeller or Rockefeller-Nixon.
BONN, Germany, June 21 -- Friends and foes of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer are agreed that the most crucial period of his long and stormy leadership of West Germany is just ahead.

Sales of the Dana Corporation, Toledo, Ohio, a leading supplier of parts for the automotive, farm equipment and other industries, during the first nine months, ended May 31, of this fiscal year totaled $165,477,036. This was a 26 per cent increase over the $131,477,412 reported in the period of last year.
FALL brides will discover -- almost certainly with delight -- that new fashions are old-fangled at Martin's.
Konstantin Rozhdestvensky's eyes gleamed proudly yesterday as he gazed a a speckled aluminum alloy representation of the heavens that curved upward fifty feet.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The Geneva conference did not succeed in clarifying Allied policy on Berlin. If we do not employ the next three weeks to repair this lamentable situation -- before the foreign ministers meet again -- the consequences could be tragic.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 21 -- Walter S. Gubelmann's seventy-one-and-a-half foot yawl Windigo from Oyster Bay, L. I., continued in the lead today in the ocean race to Newport.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Federal officials were reported today to have suggested a compromise settlement plan in the steel-labor dispute. The proposal would concentrate labor gains in pensions and welfare benefits.
A 67-year-old Bronx man will leave Montefiore Hospital today with an electric device implanted in his heart to maintain its rhythm and keep him alive.
Arthur Godfrey, currently on leave from broadcasting because of a lung cancer operation about two months ago, plans to star in a one-hour special television show on Sept. 16 from 10 to 11 P. M.
CHICAGO, June 21 (AP) -- Setbacks were few and small in grain futures trading last week and all but a few contracts on the Board of Trade made good gains for the second successive week.

LONDON, June 16 -- Some 1,700 British advertising men are studying for an M. I. P. A., an A. M. I. P. A., or a D. A. A. These are the initials they will be privileged to use after their names upon completion of comprehensive post-graduate studies in advertising.
A recent news item stated that a small group of Manhattan citizens have been helping the police patrol in Central Park. I offer an idea with a more practical approach.

In 1931, or twenty-five years before he was invited here to take over the post of managing director of the International Monetary Fund, Per Jacobsson joined the Bank for International Settlements at Basle, Switzerland, as its economist. In the interval between these two dates, Dr. Jacobsson undertook an ambitious, if unpretenious, task.
The search for love was termed a matter of "capacity rather than discovery" in a sermon yesterday by the Rev. Donald Harrington.

A critical report on the use of consent decrees in antitrust cases, issued recently by four Democratic members of the House antitrust subcommittee, inevitably carried overtones of politics. The document has a partisan and none too persuasive flavor in its charge that a "weak" decree ending the case against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company resulted from "partiality" to the company by former Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. and other Republican officials.
The mutual fund industry is battling in Washington to maintain the flexibility of management during times of changing market conditions that it considers vital to success.

LE MANS, France, June 22 -- A 15-year-old boy weighing 132 pounds and standing less than 5 feet tall flew from Casablanca to Paris the other day. The squad of journalists and photographers who met the plane were stunned by the sight of him.
BOULDER, Colo., June 22, (UPI) -- Twenty-six of America's leading track and field stars were named today for three overseas tours.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (UPI) -- A food wholesaler told House investigators today he was "positive" there was collusion among food chain stores in setting grocery prices.

After forty-seven years as public school teacher and principal, John H. Tully received yesterday Fordham's Insignis Medal. It was inscribed "for extraordinary distinction in the service of God through excellent professional performance."

THE American novel is in peril. If our authors don't watch out they're going to smother it in the spreading morasses of the flashback. Straightforward narrative should be given a chance again instead of these flashbacks that seldom flash but generally meander infuriatingly through events far away and long ago -- while the main story waits and waits and waits.
TRENTON, June 22 -- The Legislature has agreed to reconvene July 27 to consider a plan advanced by Gov. Robert B. Meyner to solve New Jersey's commuter transportation problem.
DURBAN, South Africa, June 22 (Reuters) -- Renewed African disturbances struck the Durban area today. The police used tear gas against 200 women. About 15,000 Africans started a bus boycott.

It seems odd to read in the press of so many arrests made daily and yet, apparently, so many more crimes being committed. Perhaps one of the reasons is that the police spend a disproportionately large amount of their time enforcing morals rather than preventing what people generally regard as crimes.

Members of the union that conducted the long strike against the voluntary, nonprofit hospitals in New York City have wisely ratified a settlement. The strike is over. We hope there will never be another like it, threatening adequate care of the sick.
A radar device that might have prevented two airline crashes in the East River will be installed this fall at La Guardia Airport.
ROME, June 22 -- A gambling casino that is to be opened in semi-autonomous Sicily in defiance of Italian officials in Rome is becoming a national issue.

Now that the American Medical Association has withdrawn its objections to "closed panel plans" of medical care it is a fitting moment to pay tribute to those who forty-six years ago were convinced, as your editorial of June 16 says, "that 'group practice' is better than 'solo' -- both for doctors and patients."

BUENOS AIRES, June 22 -- President Arturo Frondizi bowed to military pressure tonight and began a major Government reorganization. In an attempt to save his Government, the President received the resignations of all his Cabinet members. But he rejected the resignations of his three military secretaries.
The president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America gave fresh impetus last night to plans to build a chain of labor-sponsored hospitals in the metropolitan area.
ENDICOTT, N. Y., June 22 (AP) -- Only four Apalachin delegates gathered today as Joseph Barbara Sr. carried to the grave his secrets about the gangland convention at his home on Nov. 14, 1957.
Federal mediators reported no progress yesterday after trying for more than three hours to settle the eight-day strike of warehouse employes against the A. P. food-store chain.

The market for prime fixed-income investments resumed a drift to lower levels yesterday. Top-risk corporate bond section was an exception, with buying interest tending to push prices higher by 1/8 to 1/4 of a point. Business was light in all areas.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 22 -- An Indonesian Army staff officer urged today that the United States send 40,000 tons of rice and 35,000,000 yards of textiles here to help this country overcome accelerating economic difficulties.
BONN, Germany, June 22 -- The peacemakers went to work today in an effort to end the leadership struggle threatening to tear apart West Germany's ruling Christian Democratic Union.

Stocks went through an unexcited session yesterday. More stocks fell than rose and of the major groups only the aluminums and industrial chemicals showed anything like consistent strength. Rubbers, electronics, oils, drugs and building materials were notably weak.

NOTHING may succeed like success, but the Yankees aren't doing too badly with failure. At least they are not doing too badly financially. Their stumbling start this season has been paying off handsomely at the box office as the owners get rich and the fans get aggravated.

YONKERS, June 22 -- To some horse-players, the races at Belmont Park are the "flats" and those at Yonkers Raceway are the "trots." There are others who label the parties of the first part "thoroughbreds" and those of the second "standardbreds."
CHICAGO, June 22 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
A fairly fast but not the fastest of the biennial ocean yacht races from Annapolis to Newport appeared to be in the making yesterday.
RYE, N. Y., June 22 -- The seven metropolitan qualifiers for the National Professional Golfers Association championship were selected today after a thunderstorm had interrupted play
Persons who have the designation of Honorary Chief in the Fire Department were officially stripped of their principal insignia yesterday.

" The Gold-Hatted Lover" is Leslie Stevens' newest play. The author's favorite producer, Paul Gregory, is to put it on as soon as several stars can be engaged for the "old-fashioned love story," requiring three men and three women.
