A former Haitian Senate President, Charles Fombrun, and his son, Marcel, twice a Cabinet Minister, have sought asylum in embassies in Port-au-Prince, the Haitian Democratic League reported here last night.

Joseph A. Sarafite, a Special Sessions Justice, and James E. Mulcahy, a City Court Justice, were designated yesterday as the Democratic organization candidates for two General Sessions places to be filled in this fall's election.

Hirsch Co., in association with Bache Co. and Equitable Securities Corporation, is offering $4,000,000 of fifteen-year 5 1/2 per cent convertible subordinated debentures of Alsco, Inc., Akron, Ohio, aluminum door and window manufacturer. The debentures are priced at 100.

BATON ROUGE, La., June 22 -- It was touch and go for a while back in 1955 whether Lether Edward Frazar was going to get on the ticket as a candidate for Lieutenant Governor of Louisiana. Earl K. Long finally made up his mind to accept him.

LONDON, June 22 -- The Board of Directors of Harrods, Ltd, which controls the noted department store of that name here, and other stores, recommended today that a merger proposal from Debenhams' be accepted, ganization in the department store field, controls stores valued at 55,000,000 ($154,000,000).
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- The Senate tonight approved a bill that would raise the wheat price support level to 90 per cent of parity. It would also order a 25 per cent cut in acreage allotments.
LONDON, June 22 -- The British Government will spend 500,000 ($1,400,000) a year to subsidize the export of about 2,000,000 books "that have a wide mass appeal, reflecting British thought."

After a slow start, Canada's recovery from the recession has gained momentum, with the index of industrial production reaching a new high early this year. The National Industrial Conference Board has charted the course of the recovery in its latest issue of Current Trends of Business in Canada.
GUATEMALA, June 22 -- Two Right-wing and two Left-wing candidates have entered the July rescheduled mayoral election to be held July 5 in the Guatemalan capital.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court ordered a Federal District Court in Little Rock today to reexamine four so-called anti-H. A. A. C. P. laws enacted by the Arkansas Legislature last year.

THE increased mortality rate among infants has brought charges of over-reliance on antibiotics and the downgrading of asepsis. The latter is a method of avoiding infection by creating a germ-free atmosphere through sterilization procedures.
With the college commencement season about over, the real estate industry is looking to recent graduates for the "young blood" that, like most industries, it needs.

The belief of ancient Greek mythology that every person's span of life is measured by three supernatural beings called the Fates strangely enough has been transformed into a stark fact of present-day reality in human affairs. For the continuance of life of virtually the entire population of the world has now come to depend on the action of those relatively few individuals who compose the world's principal governments.
Forty thousand delegates and members of their families will attend the Lions International Convention at Madison Square Garden for four days, beginning Tuesday.
Anthony (Tough Tony) Anastasia moved yesterday to promote and enforce integration of white and Negro workers on the Brooklyn waterfront.
Senator Jacob K. Javits called yesterday for more Federal and private aid to higher education, including a "learn now, repay later" Federal loan program.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Proponents of a states rights bill won easily today the first round of what is expected to be a major contest in the House of Representatives.
ROME, June 22 (UPI) -- The Italian Government threatened today to requisition more strikebound ships and warned striking seamen it would refuse to negotiate with them until they went back to-work.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., June 22 -- A $3,500,000 redevelopment project for a part of Inwood is planned by the Hempstead Town Board.
Former Senator Herbert H. Lehman called last night for the eradication of the spoils system in politics, asserting that it was not only costly to taxpayers but detrimental to political organizations.

LENINGRAD, U. S. S. R.. June 22 (AP) -- The United States free-style wrestling team suffered its second defeat in two matches on its tour of the Soviet Union, dropping a 7 -- 1 decision today to a picked team of the Russian Federation.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court reversed a lower court order today that would have required the Government to pay an Illinois concern $25,000 for revoking a lease given to the company on a Navy airfield.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- The Social Security trust fund is expected to decline until June 30, 1960, and then start climbing again, the Board of Trustees reported to Congress today.

Rumors that Brazil soon would devalue the cruzeiro for purposes of coffee exports weakened prices yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. But the possibility that meetings of producing nations scheduled in Washington this week might result in tighter export controls, tended to limit the decline.
MOSCOW, June 22 -- Communist China has refused to give W. Averell Harriman an entry visa as a newspaper man.
LONDON, June 22 -- The Labor party began today to seek a compromise policy on nuclear disarmament to avert a split that might insure its defeat in the next general election.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to consider the question of whether an alien deported as a Communist could collect old age benefits under the United States Social Security system.

The Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation had a consolidated net income of $3,567,472 in the fiscal year ended April 30, the largest in eight years. The net equaled $2.88 a common share after preferred dividends. It compared with $2,423,299, or $1.81 a share, the preceding year.
NEW ORLEANS, June 22 -- Some 1,500 architects, together with members of allied professions, gathered today to discuss building design at the annual convention of the American Institute of Architects.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 22 -- Very few movie makers here were as delighted to see the latest Sindlinger statistics on movie attendance than was Ross Hunter. The figures show that the motion-picture business is getting better, because women are finding movies to their liking.
MONTICELLO, N. Y., June 22 (AP) -- Notre Dame's football offense next fall will feature not just one, but two lonely ends, Coach Joe Kuharich said today.

NOW begins the season, especially in the suburbs, when the home freezer is at its busiest. Into it go the fresh fruits and vegetables that have just reached their peak of maturity in back yard gardens.
Mayor Wagner indicated yesterday that the Board of Estimate or private contributors, or possibly a combination of the two, might save free Shakespeare for Central Park this summer.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Nuclear attack on the United States could severely damage about half of the nation's homes and force evacuation of large areas contaminated by radiation, a Congressional subcommittee was told today.
The Kayser-Roth Corporation plans to expand the hosiery phase of its business through the purchase of the controlling stock of the Phoenix Hosiery Company of Milwaukee.
LONDON, June 22 -- A mystery developed today around the release of Dr. Claus Fuchs, an atom spy, from Wakefield Prison.

The opening of the forty-second season of the Stadium Concerts was postponed last night because of rain that started to fall forty minutes before starting time. The first-night program will be presented tonight at the Lewisohn Stadium.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

By that curious juxtaposition found so often in the daily newspaper, a matter of only days recently separated news stories describing the old and the newest in man's writings. First we read of the discovery of a unique Sumerian tablet on which a romantic and literary soul 3,500 years ago inscribed what appears to be a love message to a then-current goddess.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanganyika, June 22 -- The Tanganyika Government has prohibited the hunting of lions for three years in the Northern Province and the hunting of rhinoceroses for five years throughout the country.
KANSAS CITY, June 22 (AP) -- Dr. Anna L. Rose Hawkes of Orleans, Vt., was nominated today for her second four-year term as national president of the American Association of University Women.

WHETHER a woman wears a Bikini or a covered-up maillot this summer, how she looks on the beach will depend on many things other than her bathing suit. She may look lobster red or dead white. Both shades can be rectified by the use of a good sun cream.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review a decision blocking construction of a power project reservoir on lands of Tuscarora Indians in Western New York State.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter outlined today for President Eisenhower the results of the recessed foreign ministers' conference in Geneva.
KANSAS CITY, June 22 -- The Yankees needed only the refreshing sight of some of their former playmates wearing Kansas City uniforms to get back into winning stride tonight.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 14 -- Earl (Butch) Buchholz Jr. of St. Louis, who holds every junior title worth mentioning, jumped dramatically into the very top flight of tennis today.

A biography of the Finnish composer Jean Sibelius, who died in 1957 at the age of 91, will be published by Knopf on July 20. Called "Jean Sibelius," is has been written by Harold E. Johnson, a fellow of the American Scandinavian Foundation, who went to Finland in 1956 as a Fulbright Research Scholar.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- In the aftermath of the Senate's rejection of the President's appointment of Lewis L. Strauss to be Secretary of Commerce in his Cabinet the anomalies of the episode are more clearly apparent.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission objected today to a House bill that would prohibit former members of the commission from handling legal matters before it for two years after leaving office.
The Port of New York Authority will begin tests to determine whether a steel fence should be moved or eliminated at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

The SunOlin Chemical Company, a jointly held subsidiary of the Sun Oil Company and the Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation, announced yesterday that it had started construction of the first major urea plant on the East Coast, an $8,000,000 facility at North Claymont, Del.

American Newspaper Guild leaders opened the group's twenty-sixth annual national convention here yesterday with charges that publishers were trying to break down newspaper unions by "massive retaliation" against strikers.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., June 22 -- Upstate Republican Assemblymen failed today to muster enough strength to block the advancement of Joseph F. Carlino from majority leader to Speaker in the lower house.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Treasury bill rate rose this week, with 182-day bills reaching a record high, the Treasury disclosed tonight. The average interest rate on $1,200,000,000 of 91-day bills was 3.281 per cent compared with 3.276 per cent last week.
TRENTON, Tuesday, June 23 -- A forty-day strike against the Public Service Electric and Gas Company came to an end early today.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- The Supreme Court unanimously struck down contempt convictions of three Ohioans on the ground that they had been entrapped by the Un-American Activities Commission of Ohio.
When someone asked Bill Rosensohn, the promoter of the Floyd Patterson-Ingemar Johansson fight in his office last night, "Who are you betting on in the fight, Bill?" Rosensohn had a ready answer.

BALBOA, Canal Zone, June 22 -- Despite measures taken by the Panama Canal to break the worst traffic jam in its history, more vessels, including a high proportion of superships, continue to seek transit.

The Board of Estimate has approved of the widening of the roadways of Thirty-sixth and Thirty-seventh Streets from Third to Eleventh Avenue in order to facilitate the flow of traffic through these streets.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (UPI) -- Arthur S. Flemming said today that 1,800 youths in Virginia and Arkansas had suffered a "lost year" of education because of the closing of schools in integration disputes.
About 1,500 retailers viewed thousands of musical instruments and other products yesterday at the opening of the annual music industry trade show.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Dr. Albert Sabin told the International Scientific Congress on Live Virus today that his live poliomyelitis vaccine had been safety administered to 4,500,000 persons.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 22 -- Trygve Lie paid a return visit today to the United Nations, which he headed for seven years as the first Secretary General.
GENEVA, June 22 -- A six-man Hungarian Government delegation was denied seats today in the annual conference here of the eighty-nation International Labor Organization.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (UPI) -- The Army's chief chemical officer has told Congress the Russians would resort to germ warfare in any future war "if it is to their advantage."
VIENNA, June 22 -- Prosperity has brought on a wave of alcoholism and "the climax does not seem to have been reached," Dr. Karl Schindl, head of the Austrian Department of Public Health, said today.
DETROIT, June 22 (AP) -- United States automobile manufacturers apparerntly are going to build about 3,300,000 cars in the first six months of this year.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- The Supreme Court struck down today the conviction of Vincent J. Spano of the Bronx, N. Y., who is under death sentence for the 1957 slaying of Frank Palermo Jr., former boxer.

The committee for the seventeenth annual Grosvenor Debutante Ball has announced the names of debutantes who will be honored at the fete. It will be held Nov. 28 at the Plaza and will benefit the Grosvenor Neighborhood House.
BATON ROUGE, La., June 22 -- A district court judge signed an order tonight setting a hearing Friday to determine whether Gov. Earl K. Long was legally, committed to a mental institution.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., June 22 (UPI) -- About 100 prisoners at the United States medical center, a correctional institution for criminally insane, rioted tonight. They took over a wing and held five guards hostage under threat of death.
CHICAGO, June 22 (AP) -- The grain futures market ranged out broadly both ways today from Friday's closing prices with soybeans well ahead and rye sharply lower.
Prices of cotton futures moved 6 points (30 cents a bale) off to 3 points (15 cents) up on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Nine Governors about to visit the Soviet Union were advised by President Eisenhower today to try "to stay in good humor and don't get too mad" about what they saw and heard.
TRIVANDRUM, India, June 22 -- Tens of thousands of demonstrators chanting slogans against communism and the Communist state government of Kerala greeted Prime Minister Jawaharial Nehru here today.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 22 -- Senator John F. Kennedy probably will not enter California's Presidential primary, and hopes other Democratic aspirants will refrain.
A group of Murray Hill residents yesterday intensified a campaign to prevent the widening of Thirty-sixth and Thirty-seventh Streets between Third and Eleventh Avenues.
Jack Kramer's $15,000 professional tennis tournament of champions gets into full swing tonight in the Forest Hills Stadium of the West Side Tennis Club.

FREEPORT, L. I., June 22 -- Eighteen anglers made a dent in the sea bass and whiting population off this port in the Atlantic today. Sixteen men, one woman and a child took part in the assault that must have caught the fish by surprise.
OAKLAND, Calif., June 22 -- Henry J. Kaiser Sr. announced today top management changes in four of the principal companies in the industrial group he founded.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., June 22 -- A circuit judge handed out life sentences today to four white youths convicted of having raped a Negro co-ed. Sentencing came seven weeks after the crime.

The Geneva conference of foreign ministers has "recessed" in deadlock, but another older and equally important conference continues to keep alive hope for some kind of East-West agreement. This is the conference between the United States, Britain and Soviet Russia on nuclear weapons tests.
DENVER June 22 (AP) -- David Eisenhower, the President's 11-year-old grandson, arrived by train today for a five-week vacation near Estes Park.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury indicted a Teamsters Union local and an association of filling station operators today on charges of conspiring to fix retail gasoline prices in Lake County, Ind., and Calumet City, Ill.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today upheld the antitrust convictions of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company. Galax Mirror Company. Mount Airy Mirror Company and J. A. Messer Sr. for alleged conspiracy to fix prices of mirrors.
Following is the text of the "statement of policy" made by the voluntary hospitals, containing the proposals for ending the strike:
The steel industry made it plain yesterday that it considered pension and welfare benefits just as inflationary as higher wages for its 500,000 unionized workers.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- The Supreme Court denied today a hearing to Ben Jack Cage, who had been convicted of embezzling $100,000 from the ICT Corporation, a Dallas, Tex., concern of which he had been vice president.

The three leading independent sales finance companies announced increases yesterday in the interest rate charged automobile dealers to finance their inventories. The rise from 4 1/2 to 5 per cent in their so-called floor plan rates restored them to the level prevailing before April last year.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (UPI) -- The Senate Appropriations Committee, approved today three regular appropriations bills carrying a total of $7,218,335,300 for a variety of Government agencies.
MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 22 -- Rain stopped play in the women's New York State tennis championship today after ten opening-day matches had been completed at the Beach Point Club.
LONDON, June 22 -- Quotas for Antarctic whaling fleets were discussed here tonight by representatives of five of seventeen nations at the annual meeting of the International Whaling Commission.
The annual report of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund showed yesterday that $3,608,556 had been made in grants last year to more than a hundred agencies and programs.
Hospital strikers roared approval yesterday to an agreement ending the bitter forty-six-day strike at voluntary institutions.

PARIS, June 22 -- An attempt by Leftists to arouse public opinion against the fighting in Algeria drew a warning today from the Government. It said it would not tolerate any defense of rebellion or attack on the French army.
FARMINGDALE, L. I., June 22 -- A chamber capable of simulating space conditions for humans at an altitude of 150 miles will be built here for the Republic Aviation Corporation.

A need exists for a greater voice in industry for the accounting profession, the National Association of Accountants was told yesterday at the opening session of the group's fortieth annual international accounting conference at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Department of Justice brought a major antitrust suit today against the Kennecott Copper Corporation, largest domestic producer of copper.
NEW CITY, N. Y., June 22 -- Eight men, including the former police chief of Piermont, have been indicted on gambling charges as the result of a midnight raid in that village three months ago.
CANADAIGUA, N. Y., June 22 -- Governor Rockefeller told the state's newspaper editors tonight that currently the public's need to know about government problems overshadowed even its right to know.

ATHENS, June 19 -- The fifth annual Athens Festival will take place this year between Aug. 1 and Sept. 15. There will be diverse performances, principally of ancient Greek drama but also two French plays, symphonic concerts featuring Dimitri Mitropoulos, who was born here, and ballet.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 22 (AP) -- Eddie Fisher staged a brilliant major league debut today giving up three hits in seven innings as the San Francisco Giants beat the Pittsburgh Pirates 4 to 1.

Dictatorships on this side of the Iron Curtain grow scarcer. In Europe two are outstanding, one in Spain and one in Portugal. The Portuguese survival of fascism under the control of Dr. Antonio de Oliveira Salazar is the gentler of the two. There was confusion amounting to anarchy when Dr. Salazar took office as Premier three decades ago, but there was little bloodshed.

There has been gold in these here Eastern hills for better-than-average bowlers this year. The amount has been larger than in previous years and the attraction for bowlers from other parts of the country has thus been strong.

KARACHI, Pakistan, June 22 -- Pakistan's President, Gen. Mohammed Ayub Khan, challenged today statements made in the United States Senate that the United States was supporting a military build-up in Pakistan in excess of that nation's requirements for external defense.
A 67-year-old silverware salesman walked out of Montefiore Hospital yesterday afternoon with his heartbeat in his hand.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Federal Power Commission was told by the Supreme Court today that it should often condition its approval of new natural gas supply contracts on a reduction in the price of the gas.

Ouija Board, M. J. Spiegel's 2-year-old colt by Sea Charger-Ouija, won the colt and gelding division of the National Stallion Stakes by three lengths at Belmont Park yesterday. Second out of the starting gate for the five-furlong test. Ouija Board made an immediate move to first place and held it.

LOS ANGELES, June 22 (AP) -- Sandy Koufax just missed tieing Dizzy Dean's National League record when he struck out sixteen men tonight in a 6-2 victory by the Los Angeles Dodgers over the Philadelphia Phils.
Steel production increased slightly last week, following a moderate decline the week before, and was expected to edge up a little more this week.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Supreme Court upheld today the 1957 Congressional statute limiting its decision in the case of Clinton E. Jencks.

GENEVA, June 22 -- East and West offered concessions today on the staffing of control posts that would police a ban on tests of nuclear weapons. But each side called the other's concession unacceptable.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 -- The largest audience in Robin Hood Dell history, a crowd estimated at 27,000 listeners, turned out tonight to hear the concert by Pierre Monteux and the Philadelphia Orchestra, which opened the thirtieth season of Dell concerts. Zino Francescatti was violin soloist.

The investigation of the official conduct of George P. Monaghan, State Harness Racing Commissioner, is expected to lead soon to drastic changes in the system by which the state finances capital improvements at the tracks.

Dr. Benjamin M. Steigman, a slight, energetic and rather paternal pedagogue who battles all who "stuff the heads of students with mathematical formulas and French irregular verbs," will retire Friday after twenty-two years as principal of the High School of Music and Art.
" PERILOUS," an occasionally diverting drama about espionage against Nazi Germany just before World War II, was shown on "Desilu Playhouse" over Channel 2 last night.
LONDON, June 22 -- Industrials generally were neglected in the stock market here today and had minor mixed movements.
Legally the book was closed yesterday on a story of murder on the high seas that might have come from a novel by Joseph Conrad.

THOSE chic, little East Side shops that specialize in individual, avante garde sportswear clothes are still going strong. This, despite the casual, just-open-for-the-summer appearance that permeates most of them.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., June 22 (AP) -- A "sunshine satellite" apparently burned up in the earth's atmosphere today when the second stage of the Vanguard launching vehicle failed to function properly.
Employes of concerns at 575 Madison Avenue will give blood to the New York regional Red Cross blood program today.

The problem of how to deal with attacks on our lightly armed reconnaissance planes in neutral waters and over the high seas is more complex than it might seem to be on the surface. We were rightly outraged when a Navy patrol plane was attacked and badly damaged last week in waters at least thirty-five miles off the coast of North Korea by two Communist jet fighters.

EVANSTON, Ill., June 22 (UPI) -- Top-seeded Whitney Reed gained the third round of the National Collegiate tennis championships today. The San Jose State player scored a 6-3, 6-2 victory over Doug Bashrum of Rice after drawing a first-round bye.
A new era in plastics, marked by greater durability and heat-resistance of the chemical-derived materials, was pictured yesterday as the key to a large reduction in home construction costs.

Consolidated net income of the Southern Company and its subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on May 31, totaled $40,102,220, or 10.8 per cent above the $36,179,627 in the preceding period, it was reported yesterday. The Southern is a utility holding company.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Emerson Greenaway, president of the American Library Association, said today that free men in a free world must have free access to printed materials.

Mayor Wagner yesterday promised a "top-to-bottom" investigation of the city's Committee on Slum Clearance "if the facts warrant it." He said he would make his decision after getting a report from Deputy Mayor Paul T. O'Keefe, who has been looking into growing complaints of irregularities in the administration of the Title I program.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., June 22 -- Dr. Grant Sanger and Michael Sanger of the Bedford Golf and Tennis club won the fortieth annual tournament of the Father and Son Golf Association at the Garden City Golf Club today.
TERRE HAUTE, Ind., June 22 (AP) -- Two defense motions -- to delay the tax evasion trial of eight accused gamblers and to switch the case to another jurisdiction -- were turned down today.

IN hot weather, quick-to-prepare egg dishes are frequently used in place of meat. And, because of the high protein and valuable iron content of eggs, such dishes are an excellent choice for summer meals.

Today is the last day the solemn countenance of Gov. De Witt Clinton (1769-1828) must seal the top of cigarette packs. The Internal Revenue Service issued a reminder yesterday that starting tomorrow cigarettes may be sold without the familiar blue 8-cent tax stamp.
BALTIMORE, June 22 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles decided today to find if history could repeat.
A special report on James R. Hoffa and his activities as president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters will be televised tomorrow from 10 to 11 P. M. In the Columbia Broadcasting System.

The National Foreign Trade Council released yesterday a statement protesting recent moves in Brazil for restriction of foreign investment earnings and capital transfers. The council said it had sent the statement to United States Government departments and agencies, international financial institutions and American chambers of commerce in Brazil.
The Chrysler Corporation of Canada, Ltd., yesterday appointed Grant Advertising of Canada, Ltd., as agency for its Dodge and DeSoto passenger cars and Dodge trucks.

WARSAW, June 22 -- Poland's peasants were urged by the country's Communist chief today to get off their horses and climb aboard collectively owned tractors for a faster ride toward socialized farming.
New evidence of Soviet missile progress has reached the United States.

The State of Ohio announced yesterday plans for the sale of $30,000,000 of capital improvement construction bonds, series C, on July 21. The obligations will be dated Aug. 1, 1959 and will come due serially from Dec. 15, 1959 to June 15, 1974.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Senate passed a trimmed-down housing bill tonight amid loud controversy within the Democratic party about leadership efforts to make it acceptable to the White House. The vote was 56 to 31.
LISBON, Portugal, June 10 -- Opposition groups are continuing to protest to Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar against use of torture by the secret police.
Express train service from Manhattan to Brooklyn on the IRT East Side subway was disrupted for two hours in yesterday morning's rush hour by a small fire in an East River tunnel.

CANANDAIGUA, N. Y., June 23 (AP) -- The New York State Society of Newspaper Editors reaffirmed its Opposition today to the state's Youth Court Act, and declared that the act's secrecy provision "merely sweeps the problem under a rug."

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., June 23 (AP) -- A five-pronged attack by 125 trained prison guards broke open a barricaded wing at the United States Medical Center today and crushed a fifteen-hour revolt by 106 mentally unstable inmates.

Congress faces a new test on an old issue of principle in the question whether it will increase the 3-cent tax on gasoline to 4 1/2 cents. President Eisenhower has repeatedly urged the tax increase, to keep solvent the Highway Trust Fund. Congress has shown no signs of doing so, the prevalent mood being for borrowing to delay a day of reckoning on the huge Federal aid program for road construction.

Manuel Ycaza, the 21-year-old Panamanian jockey who does not spend as much time on the ground as he does on horses -- it only seems so -- did not work yesterday at Belmont Park. Although he was listed to ride seven horses, Ycaza passed them up.
The masters and second officers of the cruise liner Santa Rosa and the tanker Valchem were charged yesterday with negligence in the collision of the two ships last March 26 off New Jersey.

With a loud gulp of nostalgia, and with the futility of spilled whisky, Toots Shor held his final black-tie party last night at his restaurant on 51 West Fifty-first Street. The restaurant, opened on April 30, 1940, will soon be torn down for the Zeckendorf Hotel.
Capt. William V. Bradley announced yesterday that "regardless of what happens" he was going to run for re-election next month as president of the International Longshoremen's Association.

BABYLON, L. I., June 23 -On a day that humans could have been expected to head for storm shelters rather than for the sea, a party of twenty-two hardy souls embarked on the good ship Ever Ready this morning in a hunt for fluke.
ST. CATHARINES, Ont., June 23 (Canadian Press) -Downbound shipping through the Welland Canal began at 8:30 P. M. tonight after a delay of about two and a half days.

MILAN, Italy, June 23 -- President Charles de Gaulle of France arrived here today for a five-day state visit to Italy. His program started with a trip from the Milan Airport to Magenta, seven teen miles west of the city, for a commemoration of the Italian campaign of Napoleon III 100 years ago. speeches today as a milestone in Italy's progress toward national unity.
Benton Bowles, Inc., has been chosen to handle the advertising program of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York.
LAWRENCE, Kan., June 23 -- The "egghead" is gaining new stature and respect in this country, a national meeting of educators was told here tonight,

BRETTON WOODS, N. H., June 23 -- The president of the central Conference of American Rabbis urged his colleagues tonight to formulate "minimum standards" for guidance in Sabbath and holiday observance, ritual and theology.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 23 -- Mrs. Beverly Baker Fleitz, regarded as most likely to continue America's twenty-two-year hold on the women's title, advanced in the Wimbledon tennis championship today. But it wasn't easy.

YONKERS, June 23 -- Television viewers who take in the trotting at Yonkers Raceway each Tuesday night may be getting the impression that Stanley Dancer is unbeatable. Though not completely true, it's not too far from wrong.

IT'S official. Summer is here. New York City began its salute to the warm, sometime gracious, season at Lewisohn Stadium last night. The Stadium Concerts began their forty-second season. And Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer -- Minnie to everybody -- began her forty-second season as the mother superior of symphony time in shirt sleeves.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Representative Francis E. Walter, Democrat of Pennsylvania, told the House today that a recent Supreme Court decision had made it "unnecessary" to pass a so-called states rights bill.

The first fruits of the garden are coming along now, and for good eating you simply can't beat them. To be sure, the first fruits are perhaps not so fully developed as they will be later on, and often are harvested through impatience.
MADRID, June 23 -- World economists and Spanish officials are drawing up final plans here for a large international loan to Spain in return for Spanish guarantees of economic reform.
The bond market was irregular again yesterday.

LONDON, June 23 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan told the House of Commons today that he hoped the Geneva foreign ministers' conference, which is to reconvene July 13, would lead to a meeting of heads of government.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 23 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold will arrive in Cairo July 1 in a new attempt to settle the dispute between Israel and the United Arab Republic over seizures of Israeli cargoes in the Suez Canal.

THE person who likes to eat at home without the attendant fuss of food preparation need not necessarily resort to frozen dishes. Freshly prepared foods with a homemade flavor may be purchased at William Poll's Delicatessen, 1051 Lexington Avenue, near seventyfifth Street.

The spot July wool positions were sharply lower yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Reports that heavy tenders would be made today, the first notice date, and that sizable supplies were available for delivery depressed the near months.

CHATTANOOGA, June 23 (AP) -- Justina Bricka of St. Louis entered the quarter-finals in the 18-year-and-under division of the Southern girls' tennis championships today. She scored a 6-0, 6-2 triumph over Rocky Sullivan of Louisville.
BALTIMORE, June 23 (UPI) -- The Baltimore Orioles sent Whitey Lockman to the Cincinnati Reds today for Walt Dropo, a first baseman, in a waiver deal.

NEWPORT, R. I., June 23 -- The finishes of only six yachts of twenty-five starters in the division were enough to establish H. Irving Pratt's conventional deep keel, 56-foot sloop Caper as the Class A winner in the ocean race from Annapolis tonight.

An assessment of Soviet strength in the air has been made by a team of American, British, German and Russian experts and will be published Aug. 13 by Praeger under the title "The Soviet Air and Rocket Forces."

INWOOD, L. I., June 23 -- Mrs.Pat Cici of the Lido Golf Club, the runner-up in last week's Metropolitan tournament, set the pace in the Women's Long Island Golf Association's fifty-four-hole medal-play championship at the Inwood Country Club today.
LONDON, June 23 -- Dr. Klaus Emil Julius Fuchs, who passed vital British and United States atomic bomb secrets to the Soviet Union during and after World War II, was released from prison today.
MOSCOW, June 23 -- Averell Harriman, former Governor of New York, discussed major international questions with Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev for several hours today.

A Board of Education spokesman said yesterday that one of the twenty-eight Brooklyn high school seniors who had admitted obtaining answers to Regents examinations in advance last week had told the full story, including the source of the answers.
LONDON, June 23 -- Trading in the industrials in the stock market here today was concentrated on shares involved or thought likely to be involved in takeover bids.

GENEVA, June 23 -- The delegations of eight countries of the Soviet bloc walked out today when the International Labor Organization's forty-third conference completed its rejection of the credentials of the Hungarian delegates.

The Municipality of Metropolitan Toronto, Ont., is offering $39,982,000 of debentures on the United States market today through Harriman, Ripley Co., Inc., and the Dominion Securities Corporation, Toronto.

Lewis Hoad and Kenneth Rosewall, formerly associated in winning the Davis Cup for Australia, reached the semi-final round of the professional Tournament of Champions at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills last night.

The Transit Authority made public yesterday its 1959-60 operating budget and with it this prospect for its employes: No wage increase without a fare increase. In a happier mood, the agency foresaw a rise in passenger totals, reversing the steady downward trend since the end of World War II and contrary to the picture in other major cities.

Adolf A. Berle Jr., former Assistant Secretary of State, predicted to the Newspaper Guild last night that in thirty years the world would be living in harmony, without any intervening world war. He advocated a major change in United States policy to achieve that result.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Three witnesses asked Congress today for legislation that would clarify the distinction between "investment advisers" and "investment counsel."

" The city should pay to voluntary hospitals the actual cost of patient care in municipal hospitals and I will vote for such an increase in the Board of Estimate." -- Robert F. Wagner, in the 1953 election campaign that made him Mayor.
PHILADELPHIA, June 23 -- The directors of the Reading Railroad took no action today on its common stock dividend. The carrier paid 25 cents a share in February and May.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., June 23 -- The women sailors from the Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club won the Morgan Cup for the third straight year today by defeating sailing teams from the Seawanhaka-Corinthian and Manhasset Bay Yacht Clubs in team completition on outer Oyster Bay Harbor.

Of the thousands of New York City families "on the move" in 1958 -- many in the normal course of changing to new apartments and homes -- it is interesting to learn from a new survey by the City Planning Commission that 13,746 families were relocated from sites where publicly sponsored redevelopment projects and other municipal improvement programs were under way.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Administration won important financial support in the Senate today for its "master plan" for continental air defense.
CHICAGO, June 23 -- A smoldering feud between Thomas M. Evans, chairman of Crane Company, and Alfons Landa, a director, flared up today at a directors' meeting, even though Mr. Landa was in Europe.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- President Eisenhower asked Congress today for $2,700,000 to be used for construction of the first underground civil defense regional center.

MASSAPEQUA, L. I., June 23 -- A 15-year-old boy with fractured ribs pulled a critically injured companion one mile to shore today after a third youth had been thrown overboard and drowned. The boating accident occurred in Cross Bay Channel, West Amityville, L. I.

OCEANPORT, N. J., June 23 (AP) -- Mrs. William G. Helis' Lastborn, under a driving ride by William M. Cook, wore down Perne L. Grissom's Royal Native in the last sixteenth of a mile to win the Gray Flannel Purse at Monmouth Park today.
Carmine G. De Sapio undertook last night to forge a new link between polite society and Tammany Hall.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- Gen. Frank F. Everest was named today chief of the Tactical Air Command.
The $70,000,000 Time and Life Building on the Avenue of the Americas at Fiftieth and Fifty-first Streets was the scene of a cornerstone laying ceremony yesterday.

The driver of a Yonkers Railroad Company bus was injured yesterday when it struck four parked cars and crashed into a tree on Broadway near 253d Street in the Bronx. The accident occurred at 7:10 A. M.
A court summons was issued yesterday for the agent for a Brooklyn tenement owned by a Harlem religious leader.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department reported today that auditors had found unexplained losses running into tens of thousands of dollars worth of surplus food sent to Westmoreland County, Pa., for donation to needy families.
The old July cotton futures contract on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 9 points (45 cents a bale) yesterday. The other months moved 1 point up to 2 off.
A plea for International Red Cross medical aid for Dominican wounded was made public yesterday by the Dominican Liberation Movement.

A former stock boy was named yesterday to run the whole store. The job as executive head of Gimbels New York and its branches went to Julius Schutzman, 43 years old. Mr. Schutzman started in merchandising as a stock boy at Bloomingdale's in 1930, when he was 14.
The music of Alan Jay Lerner and Frederick Loewe, who composed songs for "My Fair Lady" and other Broadway shows, will be featured on a ninety-minute television program being planned for the fall.
BUENOS AIRES, June 23 -Argentina drifted on a sea of political indecision today while the Government scanned the horizon for a new Cabinet.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 23 -- Connecticut made a formal pitch today to induce California manufacturers to consider East Coast operations.
In the month April 15-May 15 the consumer price index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics broke out of the narrow range of 123.6-123.9 to which it had been confined since May of last year.

A large-scale transfer of pupils by bus from overcrowded schools in the Bedford-Stuyvesant area of Brooklyn to other districts including Queens was announced yesterday for this fall by Dr. John J. Theobald, Superintendent of Schools.
Eddie Machen, who recently lost a Federal Court suit to stop the championship fight, filed a $1,229,375 damage suit yesterday in the same court.
ALBANY, June 23 -- The State Department of Mental Hygiene reported today that a decentralization program was being undertaken at Pilgrim State Hospital in West Brentwood, L. I.
Governor Rockefeller was urged again yesterday to press for legislation banning discrimination in private housing.
STANTON, Del., June 23 (AP) -- A racing rarity -- three daily double pay-offs, including the biggest of the twenty-two-day old meeting -- highlighted today's racing program at Delaware Park.
The city's proposed new zoning law slated for enactment late this year or early next year will not take effect until July 1, 1961, the City Planning Commission decided yesterday.

A strike threat against the city's proprietary hospitals was revived late yesterday. The threat followed the breakdown of negotiations between thirty-seven of the private, profit-making institutions and Local 144 of the Hotel and Allied Service Employes Union.

With the fighters safely past their heavy training chores, Bill Rosensohn can concentrate now on selling tickets for the world heavyweight championship bout between Floyd Patterson and his challenger, Ingemar Johansson of Goteborg, Sweden.
Samuel Goldwyn's production of "Porgy and Bess" is one of three new arrivals on local screens today.
Negotiations for a new steel wage agreement moved into the make-or-break stage yesterday, with the industry preparing to make its final bid to avert a July 1 strike.

Allow me to express my appreciation and approval of the statesmanlike suggestion made by James Reston in your June 12 issue: "In the long run, the way to reach an accommodation with the East might very well lie in the unification and strengthening of the West."

Deputy Mayor Paul T. O'Keefe gave Mayor Wagner yesterday a written report on one aspect of the slum projects in the city. On the basis of this, the Mayor is due to announce today whether he will order a full investigation of the Committee on Slum Clearance.
LONDON, June 23 -- A Stradivarius violin was sold at auction today for 7,800 guineas ($22,930), more than double the previous record for a Stradivarius at a public sale.
CHICAGO, June 23 (AP) -Heavy general selling battered down almost all grain futures prices fairly sharply today on the Board of Trade.
Sarah G. Blanding, president of Vassar College, was elected yesterday to head an organization of twenty-three non-tax supported colleges in New York State.
NEW ORLEANS, June 23 -- Automobile makers and the motor oil producers were challenged today to help the nation's cities fight their way out of an automotive stranglehold.
Kieran Tunney, the young Irish playwright who was co-author with John Synge of this season's short-lived tragi-comedy, "God and Kate Murphy," has written a play called "Royal Enclosure."
MILLION-DOLLAR decorating advice is now a free commodity at Baruch Houses. A model apartment decorated for under $2,500 was put on view yesterday in the low-income development at 90 Columbia Street.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- President Eisenhower's proposal to repeal ceilings on the interest rates of Government bonds was termed unacceptable today by the House Democratic leadership.

BONN, Germany, June 23 -- Dr. Ludwig Erhard, Minister of the Economy, agreed today to remain in the Cabinet of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer. Before doing so, he forced the aged Chancelor to concede that Dr. Erhard's resignation was "unthinkable."
The Lehigh Valley Railroad, one of the most hard-pressed of the Eastern carriers in the last year or so, reported yesterday it had a net income last month of $87,121.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- In perhaps this Administration's last significant shift of diplomatic personnel, two of the United States' most able Ambassadors will be leaving their posts before the end of the current year. These are Charles E. Bohlen and David K. E. Bruce, now our envoys in Manila and Bonn.
Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation announced yesterday that it had obtained from the Federal Power Commission authorization to increase its natural gas re serves 1,000,000,000,000 cubic feet.
DUBLIN, June 23 -- Sean Lemass was elected Prime Minister tonight by the Dail Eireann (Parliament) in succession to President-elect Eamon de Valera. The vote was 75 to 51.
AMONG the six generations of public men who have trooped across the American political stage, none matches Richard Milhous Nixon, 46 years old, of Whittier, Calif.
MILLVILLE, N. J., June 23 -- The Millville Historical Society has a new headquarters, the 155-year-old Wood Mansion House.
QUEBEC, June 23 -- Queen Elizabeth II presented new colors today to the renowned French Canadian Royal Twentysecond Regiment, of which she is colonel in chief.

TORONTO, June 23 (AP) -- Ed Meister, an amateur from Willoughby, Ohio, sank a 12-foot birdie putt on the first hole of a sudden-death play-off today and brought the United States its first victory in the international Canada-United States pro-amateur golf tournament.
BATON ROUGE, La., June 23 -- Top lieutenants of the Long political machine urged a reluctant Lieut. Gov. Lether E. Frazar today to assume the acting governorship.

Bankers across the nation are feeling optimistic about the economy -- and perky about their own business. The economic outlook for the next six months is described as "good," "excellent" and "very favorable" by bankers responding in the semi - annual survey just completed by the American Bankers Association.

The most talked-about country in Latin America in the last few weeks has been the Dominican Republic. A cloak-and-dagger drama seems to have been taking place in the obscurity that normally blankets the country.

Tammany's failure to designate a Negro for either of two places on the General Sessions bench to be filled at this fall's election was seized upon yesterday by Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. as a Democratic primary campaign issue.
A SUBLIME lesson in the evils of intemperance and the rewards of virtue, called "The Drunkard" or "The Fallen Saved." was given a spirited revival last evening at the Gate Theatre.
Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama is of the opinion that membership in the Roman Catholic Church will prove a handicap to any Presidential candidate next year.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 23 -- President Juscelino Kubitschek was reported tonight to be under heavy pressure to employ "shock treatment" to induce the United States to grant Brazil substantial aid.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The deficit in this country's international balance of payments remained large in the first quarter of this year, the Department of Commerce reported today.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The long-term danger of radioactive fall-out from a major nuclear war has been greatly overestimated by civil defense and military agencies, a panel of scientists told a Congressional committee today.

The blockfront on Twelfth Avenue between Forty-second and Forty-third Streets has been purchased by North River Properties, Inc., from Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc. The property has a frontage of 208 feet on Twelfth Avenue, 154 feet on Forty-second Street and 121 feet on Forty-third Street.
LONDON, June 23 -- Another chapter was written today in Britain's success story in the field of exports.
HAVANA, June 23 -- Premier Fidel Castro announced late today that the Government would immediately take over all cattle ranches of more than 3,300 acres in Camaguey Province.
The Ward-Garcia Corporation will resume ship operations this morning after a sitdown strike, a lockout and the collapse of negotiations for the purchase of the company -- all in five days.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- An Army expedition of forty-one men has set up a base camp 500 miles south of the North Pole before pushing on to conduct scientific studies along the Arctic Ocean coast of Greenland.

The basic issue between West and East that led to the suspension of the Geneva conference of foreign ministers was outlined in grim clarity last night by Secretary Herter in a report to the nation and the world.
Two groups of a lawyers announced their support yesterday of the action taken by General Sessions Judge Mitchell D. Schweitzer on June 10 in sealing the television quiz show presentment.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23 (AP) -- For five days six Navy men have been sealed in a make-believe space ship. They are testing a new concept in oxygen-breathing gear for flights beyond the earth's atmosphere.
Eleven men and a magazine distributing company were indicted here yesterday on antitrust and extortion charges involving the wholesale distribution of newspapers and magazines.

Draft indebtedness of Latin American importers to United States exporters rose $3,600,000 to $149,800,000 in May, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The bank based its information on its monthly survey of the experience of thirteen large commercial banks.

TORONTO, June 23 (Canadian Press) -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) has granted a loan of $11,600,000 to Brazilian Traction, Light and Power Company, Ltd., Henry Borden, president, announced today at the company's annual meeting.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter said tonight that the Soviet Union was trying to make West Berlin a "slave city."

The higher operating pace of the automotive industry enabled the Kelsey-Hayes Company to show substantially larger sales and earnings in the quarter and nine months ended May 31, Lester R. Downie, vice president and treasurer, reported yesterday.

Fashions, even in golf course architecture, often change. A recent announcement that a course would soon be constructed in Virginia with some holes copied from famous British links, serves as an illustration.
Additional public confusion over the nature and extent of our foreign assistance effort may be generated by the editorial "Latin America and the I. M. F." published June 17.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 23 -- The Soviet Union touched off a battle of words today by protesting the right of Nationalist China to a seat on the United Nations Trusteeship Council.

A dedicated band of women weeded and cultivated the flower beds in the Brooklyn Botanic Garden yesterday -working "just out of love for the place," as one of them explained. They and others like them have helped to keep the garden flourishing since mid-April, when a strike of employes began.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -The Senate Foreign Relations Committee criticized the Administration's foreign-aid proposals today as being inadequate for the nation's present policy requirements.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, June 23 -- A Cuban-supported invasion force against the Dominican Republic was crushed in an "inferno of fire" and every one of its members killed, the Government reported tonight.
Stocks performed sluggishly in a heavy atmosphere yesterday and closed with little change in the averages.
Russian women, who long have believed in the "natural," no make-up look, will see and sample American cosmetics at the American National Exhibition in Moscow. The sevenweek fair opens on July 25.
Following is the text of a statement on housing issued yesterday by Robert Moses as chairman of the Slum Clearance Committee:

The election of Harry Huberth Jr. as president and Arthur I. Kravitz as executive vice president has been announced by Huberth Huberth, Inc., real estate concern. The election was announced coincidentally with the incorporation of the fifty-five-year-old partnership.
A proposed appropriation of $422,500 to widen most of Thirty-sixth and Thirty-seventh Streets would be an illegal diversion of funds, the Board of Estimate was told yesterday.

Your issue of June 16 disclosed the fact that two beautiful granite figures which now adorn the Centre Street portal-of the old Hall of Records are being removed to allow for the widening of the roadway.
The Appellate Division yesterday reversed the convictions and prison sentences of Johnny Dio, the labor racketeer, and John J. McNamara, a local teamster union official.
The Pink and White Ball, a dinner dance to be held at the Bath and Tennis Club of Westhampton Beach, L. I., on Saturday, will benefit the Memorial Cancer Center at 444 East Sixty-eighth Street.

BUFFALO, June 23 (AP) -Since the opening of the St, Lawrence Seaway this yea, nearly ten times more fore ig cargo has arrived in Buffala than the'city received in alI o 958. Customs Collector Harold R. Becket said yesterday that 27,990 tons have been 'dcharged this year, compax:ecl Wi'th 2,855 'tons during the entire navigation season in 1958,

TRIVANDRUM, India, June 23 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru conferred with political, social and professional leaders today and far into the night in seeking a solution for the crisis in the Communist-run State of Kerala.

The 1,110 residents of Glenrock, Wyo., are no longer afraid that their town will be added to the growing list of ghost towns. They credit coal strip mining and the Pacific Power and Light Company for averting such a disaster.
OSLO, Norway, June 23 -- Twenty-five United States tourists are believed to have died in a fire that destroyed a resort hotel at Stalheim early this morning.
Following is the text of Secretary of State Christian A. Herter's radio-television report to the nation last night from Washington, as recorded by The New York Times:
An analysis of the Le Mans (France) twenty-four-hour race by Rene Dreyfus, a former French champion, credits the Aston-Martin victory to astute team management.
YONKERS, June 23 -- A new concrete retaining wall behind an apartment house at 480 Riverdale Avenue here collapsed at 7:55 A.M today. It crushed ten automobiles in a parking area.
A power failure in a thirty-one story midtown skyscraper stalled elevators, yesterday, marooning hundreds of workers and keeping thousands more from work almost four hours.
SARK, Chanel Island, June 23 (AP) -- Nearly half the people of this tiny British island in the English Channel off the Norman Coast boycotted a garden party for Princess Margaret yesterday.

A SUPERB "liquid lunch" that is designed to keep one cool from the inside out is today's aid to the heat-oppressed. Gazpacho, a Spanish dish, may not give as lasting relief as an air-conditioner, but it should be welcomed for its refreshing quality by wilting New Yorkers.

The Soviet Union has conducted a dock trial of the world's first atomic-powered surface ship. It is the icebreaker Lenin, which is soon to be joined by two other icebreakers, all of them dwarfing anything in the West.

ABOUT 2,500 future brides and their attendants crowded into the Grand Ballroom of the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn Monday night. They came to see bridal fashions, get free blue garters, eat wedding cake, drink fruit punch, peruse table settings and sign up for wedding trips to Bermuda and Nassau.

Five friends, who are Thomas Moore enthusiasts, presented a program last night at Carnegie Recital Hall, which their leader, Wilbur Strong Broms, said had the hope of conveying to others some of the pleasure they have had from Moore's poetry and the music associated with it.

New York City has borrowed $30,000,000 on short-term tax anticipation notes bearing 2 3/4 per cent interest, Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa announced yesterday. The sale completed the financing of the city's expense budget for the year ending June 30, he said.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- A live virus vaccine that, by a single feeding, is said to immunize against all three types of poliomyelitis was described today.
MONTPELIER, Vt., June 23 (UPI) -- Vermont National Guardsmen have been issued Lake Champlain Festival buttons and asked to buy or sell them to help finance a parade.
PARIS, June 23 -- Finance Minister Antoine Pinay called today for continued austerity.
CHICAGO, June 23 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock market here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
David Dubinsky and Jacob S. Potofsky, American trade union leaders, were honored last night for promoting understanding between the people of this country and those of Israel.
Northeast Airlines announced yesterday that it planned to start daily jet service from New York to Miami in September.
GENEVA, June 23 -- The Soviet Union promised today to clarify its quota plan for inspections under the proposed ban on nuclear weapons tests.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (UPI) -- The Senate passed two money bills today for the fiscal year beginning June 30.
WARSAW, June 23 -- The biggest news in the Polish publishing world these days is the smash success of an American author who has written just one book.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The House of Representatives approved and sent to the White House today a compromise omnibus housing bill that Administration spokesmen had assailed as too costly.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, the Senate Democratic leader, challenged President Eisenhower today to cooperate with Congress in speeding the completion of the current session.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- A Senate Judiciary subcommittee was urged today to continue, with safeguards, a program under which adopted orphan children can enter this country as non-quota immigrants.

KANSAS CITY, June 23 -- Showing little mercy to a procession of former mound playmates, the Yankees tonight battered the Athletics, 10 to 2, for their second straight triumph over their Kansas City "cousins."

Informal discussions looking toward the reintroduction of branch banking and bank holding company legislation at Albany next year will begin in a few weeks, state legislative and Banking Department leaders announced yesterday.

DETROIT, June 23 (UPI) -- A young Detroit-area student said today that he was partly responsible for the omission of the name of Sherman Adams' son, Sam, from a list of Dartmouth graduates sent to newspapers in New Hampshire.

THE ballplayers were at the mercy of the fans in the old days when any sports follower was privileged to vote for starters in the All-Star game. Some of their selections were more weird than wonderful and grumbling among the sterling diamond heroes was constant. So the election rules were changed last year and the franchise was bestowed on the big leaguers themselves.

NEWARK, June 23 -- Most striking employes of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company returned to their jobs this morning. A compromise agreement, which settled a forty-day strike, was ratified by the union membership early today by a vote of 2,077 to 1,581.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., June 23 -- A $1,500,000 recreational center will be built in the proposed Elmont-North Valley Stream Park District, the Town of Hempstead announced today.
LONDON, June 23 -- The Labor party moved closer today to agreement on a nuclear policy when a group of trade-union leaders accepted suggestions from the party's political wing.

Free Shakespeare in Central Park this summer appeared certain yesterday. Mayor Wagner announced two private contributions of $10,000 each to provide the $20,000 the Park Department needs to prepare the park for a production.

Cenco Instruments Corporation is expanding its line of laboratory instruments through the acquisition of Soiltest, Inc., Chicago designers and makers of scientific instruments to test the condition of soil, concrete and asphalt.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- A move to eliminate the 10 per cent Federal tax on communications and passenger travel was started today in the Senate Finance Committee.
James A. Phillips, a former Queens Democratic leader, announced yesterday that he would seek the Democratic nomination for Borough President in the September 15 primary.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., June 23 (AP) -- A dispatch filed from this city Saturday told about Eastern Air Line's desire to hire 560 new stewardesses. The article said the concern was dropping the age limit from 27 to 19 for beginners.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Buried in the large volume of business of that the Supreme Court disposed of yesterday was a brief order with an unusual history behind it.

PARENTAL lethargy is making pre-school children the target for paralytic poliomyelitis. According to the city's Department of Health, about 50 per cent of the pre-school youngsters in some areas of the city are insufficiently immunized.
LONDON, June 23 -- Klaus Emil Julius Fuchs had perfected self-discipline to such a point that he called it, in his own diagnosis, "controlled schizophrenia."

The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court upheld yesterday a $4,500,000 judgment obtained by minority stockholders of International Railways of Central America against the United Fruit Company.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- President Eisenhower was quoted today as having said he would have preferred the presidency of a small college in a rural area to the top post at Columbia University in New York.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower will lay the cornerstone of the new east front extension of the Capitol in Masonic ceremonies July 4, the White House announced today.
Net new orders for machine tools, climbing steadily for several months, have taken a sharp dip.

JERSEY CITY, June 24 -- Hudson County's grand jury today questioned eight witnesses in a dock case. They were investigating charges that nine dock workers, supposedly employed on the American Export Lines' ship piers in Hoboken, had been working, instead, on the Holmdel, N. J., home of Francis Murphy. He is business agent of the Hoboken Checkers Local 1.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 24 -- The level of coffee exports in forthcoming months will determine how soon Brazil's foreign exchange crisis will reach a climax.

The world premiere of the screen version of "Porgy and Bess" drew a large audience to the Warner Theatre last night. Well-known figures in the entertainment, social and diplomatic fields were present. Proceeds went to the American Friends of the Hebrew University and the Multiple Sclerosis Society.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -The Senate Finance Committee unexpectedly voted today to abolish the 10 per cent Federal tax on travel.

WANDLITZ, Germany, June 24 (Reuters) -- Klaus Fuchs, atom spy freed from a British prison yesterday, said here today that he was eager to get a job in East Germany and "help in the build-up of the new society here."

Net income of the Bulova Watch Company for the fiscal year ended on March 31 amounted to $2,527,168, equal to $1.30 a share on 1,949,286 shares, against $2,232,738, or $1.15 a share, in the previous fiscal year.
CHICAGO, June 24 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Group insurance, on which premiums now top $5,000,000, 000 a year, is three and one-half times its size of ten years ago, the Institute of Life Insurance and the Health Insurance Association reported yesterday.
A report submitted to the Board of Estimate yesterday recommended $33,045,000 in public and private building construction to complete the $200,000,000 Brooklyn Civic Center.
Earnings of $4,512,912 for May enabled the Pennsylvania Railroad to report a profit of $2,248,000 for the first five months.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Administration tried to prod Congress into action today on the President's five-month-old request for an increase in the Federal tax on gasoline.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- A Russian report on the success of Sabin live poliomyelitis vaccine in three Soviet republics brought high praise today from an official of the World Health Organization.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Army's prospects for a manpower increase dwindled further today as the Senate Appropriations Subcommittee for Defense accepted the Administration's plea to keep the force at 870,000.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 24 -- The second revolution in the movie universe may be under way, if some writers are correct. The first upheaval came when the screen acquired a tongue and writers who could handle dialogue were suddenly in urgent demand.

ALBANY, June 24 -- Power-driven midget autos are subject to all regulations that apply to full-sized cars if they are operated on the public highway, William. S. Hults, Commissioner of the Bureau of Motor Vehicles, said today.
WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -Arthur S. Flemming, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, today urgedextension of the Federal air-pollution control law.
WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- The Senate Rules Committee gave unanimous approval today to a measure that would require the making public of the names and salaries of all Senate employes.

If reports are correct, Generalissimo Franco of Spain has made a historic decision. This is to accept the terms of the International Monetary Fund and the Organization for European Economic Cooperation and at last set his financial house in order.
ROME, June 24 -- Pope John XXIII has begun to take English lessons and hopes to become fluent in it within a year, the Rome radio has reported.
ALGIERS, June 24 -- Violent fighting broke out at dawn today between French forces and an Algerian rebel band five miles from the center of the eastern port city of Bone.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Senate heeded today the appeal of its Democratic leader, Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, and added $365,061,000 to President Eisenhower's request for funds to run the Department of Health, Education and Welfare and other agencies.

Your editorial stand on "The 'Equal Time' Folly" published June 18 is heartening support for those who have long sought to broaden, rather than diminish, the responsibility of radio and television broadcasters in their coverage of news, public affairs and their interpretation.
Moscow, June 24 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev opened a plenary session of the Communist party's Central Committee today. The meeting was called to discuss modernization of Soviet industry.

BUENOS AIRES, June 24 -- President Arturo Frondizi named Argentina's foremost champion of free enterprise as Minister of the Economy today. The office is the keystone of a new Cabinet molded to the military's demands.
BATON ROUGE, La., Thursday, June 25 -- In a broadcast tape-recorded at a mental institution, Gov. Earl K. Long asked the people of Louisiana last night to "pray" for his release.

LONDON, June 24 -- Formation of a British-American partnership for the manufacture of wrought aluminum products was announced today as a move to improve British production methods. Imperial Chemical Industries, Ltd., and the Aluminum Company of America, Inc., will establish a joint company to be known as Imperial Aluminium Company, Ltd.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -President Eisenhower asked Congress today to approve permanent legislative authority for foreign miltiary aid, instead of the present annual authorizations.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Senator Barry Goldwater wants Senator Wayne Morse to watch his language.
The steel industry proposed yesterday an indefinite postponement of a scheduled strike of 500,000 workers at midnight Tuesday.

KANSAS CITY, June 24 -- Harry Craft, the patient manager of the Athletics, changed the script tonight. He stuck with pitching that carried no Yankee label and it finally won a game for him in this current four-game series with the Bombers.

The Corlears award, made on behalf of the East Side community for devotion to "the cause of educational and civic enrichment," was presented yesterday to Mayor Wagner at the commencement exercises of the Corlears Junior High School.
Robert Moses, addressing the graduates of the High School of Music and Art yesterday, said he favored combining that school with the proposed High School of Performing Arts at Lincoln Square.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., June 24 (AP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested six men today, five here and one in Connecticut, in an alleged kickback racket involving home-improvement loans.

HAMPTON BAYS, L. I., June 24 -- It was just like a scene in a crossroads general store at world series time. A group of fishing captains and mates were huddled around the radio at Angler's Rest, the drinking and eating emporium here that caters to the needs of fishermen.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 24 -- The army indicated today that it now believed Indonesia's political and economic crisis had to be dealt with by the army, not politicians.
YONKERS, June 24 -- A new solar cooker is one of a host of patio, garden and pet care items on exhibit at the "Design for Suburban Living" show at the Cross County Shopping Center here.

NEWARK, June 24 -- Property taxes levied by local governments in New Jersey's twenty-one counties are at a record high of $773,123,000 this year, the State Chamber of Commerce reported today. The total is $62,179,000 more than last year.

The five-story apartment house at 2323 Creston Avenue in the Bronx has been sold by Nathan Meisel to an investing client of Hyman Wiener, lawyer. Murray Kenner was the broker in the sale, which was for cash above mortgages of $122,000.

Two former champions of Wimbledon and the United States waged battle for two hours and twenty-seven minutes through fifty-four games last night in one of the longest sets ever played in the Forest Hills Stadium of the West Side Tennis Club.
The wife of a Columbia University law student yesterday gave birth to quadruplets, three boys and a girl, in the Public Health Service Hospital on Staten Island.
Dr. Charles W. Hughes yesterday replied to questions that he had previously refused to answer about Communist party activities at Hunter College.
TRIVANDRUM, India, Thursday, June 25 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said this morning that intervention by the Indian Central Government in Kerala was not planned at present.

DOWNINGTON, Pa., June 24 -- The score was 10 to 6, and a Japanese boy was at bat. A Swedish girl was on first base and an Austrian boy took a modest lead off second. There were two out. The batter, encouraged by team-mates who cheered in several languages, hit a short ball to left field that the fielder, a Mexican girl, pegged to third base. It was a close play.

" Kings, Lords and Commons," an anthology of Irish poetry, translated, by Frank O'Connor, will be issued July 20 by Knopf. The volume contains selections from four books now unavailable: "The Wild Bird's Nest," "Lords and Commons," "The Fountain of Magic" and "The Midnight Court.
Old July futures advanced 15 points on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, but other months were unchanged to 3 points up.

A 24-year-old student suffered second-degree burns on the hand last night when an apparent incendiary bomb that his younger brother had been using as a paperweight exploded. The explosion started a fire in their West Side apartment.
The home has been known to man ever since his most primitive ancestor first discovered that a cave was a great place in which to get away from the elements and the prowling beasts.

JERSEY CITY, June 24 -- An indictment charging the misapplication of $67,000 in funds of the C. F. Mueller Company was handed up today by a Hudson County grand jury against Lawrence A. Larson, the concern's controller.
" A Salute to Alaska and Hawaii" will be the theme of the thirteenth annual Monmouth Turf Charity Ball, to be held on July 25 in the clubhouse of the Monmouth Park Race Track.

FOR twenty-two rounds, Gentleman Jim Corbett, then a gaffer of 34, had methodically slashed Jim Jeffries, a young bull of 25. The bull was blinded by his own blood and staggering from his wounds. One of the great upsets in ring history seemed imminent. Corbett was about to regain the world heavyweight championship from Big Jeff.
Supreme Court order directing Park Commissioner Robert Moses to stop assigning employes to higher jobs without competitive Civil Service examinations has been upheld by the Appellate Division.
Not surprisingly, Robert Moses seems to be well satisfied with the status of over-all planning in New York City. The results, however, are discouragingly small and often inept.

One hundred young men and women are preparing at the Kilpatrick Youth Center, 352 East 137th Street, the Bronx, to be counselors for nearly 100,000 underprivileged children whose summer camps will be the sidewalks of New York.

Fifteen leaders of the apparel and related industries were named yesterday to the executive advisory council of the Fashion Industries Presentation of the American National Exhibition in Moscow. The trade show will be presented in the Soviet capital July 25 to Sept. 4.

In a report to Governor Rockefeller, George P. Monaghan has accused the State Investigation Commission of "open distortions, half-truths and inaccuracies" in its recent public hearings on his behavior as Harness Racing Commissioner.

Mayor Wagner said yesterday that Thomas J. Shanahan, vice chairman of the Committee on Slum Clearance, had made "a mistake in judgment" in his loan dealings with a slum redevelopment sponsor in Brooklyn.
CAIRO, June 23 -- The Egyptian public is again being led to expect that Premier Abdul Karim Kassim will turn sharply against the Communist party in Iraq.
NEW ORLEANS, June 24 -Architects were urged today to strike for serenity in their building designs as an antidote to the turbulent period in which they live.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 24 (AP) -- The official publication of Alabama Methodists criticized Gov. John Patterson today for supporting Senator John F. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, for President. Senator Kennedy is a Roman Catholic.
VALPARAISO, Fla., June 24 (AP) -- Two Bomarc missiles were launched successfully today against a simulated attack by two high-speed jet drones over the Gulf of Mexico.

STALHEIM, Norway, June 24 (Reuters) -- Searchers sifted through smoldering ruins of the Stalheim Hotel today in a hunt that could take at least a week to find the bodies of fourteen missing tourists. The hotel was destroyed by fire early yesterday.

The liberals in Congress and their outside supporters have been tireless in their condemnation of the Democratic leadership for its efforts to curb spending bills and avoid Presidential vetoes. This is understandable. From the liberal view there is no denying that, in the words of the Committee for an Effective Congress, the present session "has not supplied the new national direction, the sense of verve, which optimists expected of the election."

A civil engineer, 28-year-old Gilson Macedo-Soares, is making history in the South American dog world. He is the youngest president in the history of the Brazil Dog Club. And his miniature pinscher, Lady Lety de Guararema, has won more honors than any other dog in Brazil.

David T. Schultz, president of Allen B. DuMont Laboratories, Inc., told stockholders yesterday that he believed the company was now "in the black and I am sure we will be from now on in." He spoke at the company's annual meeting in Clifton, N. J.
ROME, June 24 -- President Charles de Gaulle of France was reported tonight to have expounded to his Italian hosts his plan for a security pact for the Western Mediterranean.
BOSTON, June 24 -- The Maine Central and Bangor and Aroostook Railroads made known today that they would seek to end all passenger service Sept. 12.
WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) Unsanitary conditions exist in many meat plants whose products are marketed with the Government's stamp of approval, Congress was told today.
Organized labor is being misled by the "big business point of view" in newspaper analyses and editorials, the convention of the American Newspaper Guild was told yesterday.
BONN, Germany, June 24 -The United States was reliably reported today to have told Chancellor Konrad Adenauer that it was not interested in a Western summit conference at this time.
LONDON, June 24 -- The Labor party urged today an international agreement under which all nations except the United States and the Soviet Union would renounce nuclear weapons.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- John A. McCone, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, told Congress today that it seemed "entirely feasible" to develop an inspection system for detecting clandestine nuclear tests in space.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn, said today that state legislatures controlled by both major parties shared the blame for setting the boundaries of Congressional districts to gain political advantage.
BOSTON, June 24 -- A successful claim of foul enabled Mrs. Ada L. Rice's Air Pilot to go to the winner's circle today after the twenty-fifth running of the Massachusetts Handicap.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., June 24 (UPI) -- Johnny Dio, convicted labor racketeer, was arraigned on Federal Court charges of income tax evasion and conspiracy today within an hour after his release from Auburn State Prison.
Arthur Godfrey will resume his morning radio program Sept. 28 but will limit his television work next season to four one-hour special shows.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., June 24 -- Nineteen-year-old Timothea Schneider, a University of Michigan sophomore who majors in naval architecture, today won the club trials for the right to represent the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club in the forthcoming Syce Cup competition.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The United States has asked the Dominican Republic to explain why a Dominican naval vessel stopped an American freighter two days ago.
The Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York (mony) announced yesterday a number of top executive changes, effective Sept. 1.
PARIS, June 24 -- Seven Algerians were massacred in a shantytown on the outskirts of Lyon last night.

Copper prices tumbled in heavy trading yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York. Futures dropped 75 to 84 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 908 lots (50,000 pounds to a lot).
