The volume was the third largest of the year and the third largest since trading started on the commodity in 1933.
The Los Angeles Department of Water and Power borrowed $15,000,000 yesterday on bonds maturing over forty years at an interest cost of 4.11695 per cent.

IF you like your entertainment noisy and gaudy; if you enjoy Aquacades; if you get a kick out of "gonk"; if you like to feel you are participating in something Big (you and your 8,239 fellow onlookers) -- in short, if carnivals are your cup of tea, go see "Hell'z-a-Splashin'."

LONDON, June 24 -- Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd told the House of Commons today that when the foreign ministers' conference in Geneva adjourned it was obvious that there still was a wide gulf between the two sides.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department said today that information obtained from field offices indicated Senator James O. Eastland had obtained $243,734 in price-support loans on 1,514 bales of cotton in the last three years.
A 14-year-old school girl, testifying yesterday in Queens Adolescent Court against four Queens youths accused of raping her, admitted that she had promised intimacies to one of them.

Officals of the Board of Education said yesterday that a graduate of a private Jewish parochial school in Brooklyn was the source of the Regents examination papers obtained in advance of the tests by Brooklyn high school seniors.

By enrolling 9,030 subscribers, thirty more than necessary, the Phoenix Theatre, Second Avenue and Twelfth Street, will get two subsidies of $75,000 over a three-year period from the Avalon and Old Dominion Foundations.
The Red Cross here and in many places around the world observed an event yesterday that occurred 100 years ago and has come to be recognized as the Red Cross' starting point.

The threat of a strike against proprietary hospitals here appeared early this morning to have been eliminated. At 3 A. M. union and hospital officials were reported to be working on the language of a contract.
CHICAGO, June 24 -- More than 500 cheering, chanting, booing cab drivers, including their union's baseball team in uniform, turned a National Labor Relations Board hearing into turmoil today.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Administration grounded the nuclear airplane project once again today by rejecting proposals for early construction of a flying model.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- A high Federal court has now broadly explored and sustained Executive foreign policy powers under the Constitution, and implemented by acts of Congress, to limit a citizen's "right to travel." This opinion was written earlier this month by Chief Judge Prettyman of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, for himself, for Associate Justice Burton of the Supreme Court, retired, and for Judge W. K. Miller.
Industrial securities valued at more than $65,000,000 will be offered to investors today by syndicates as follows:
With electronics issues and rails in the lead, the New York Stock Exchange made a strong advance yesterday, adding about $1,400,000,000 to the aggregate market value of its common stocks.
Although most cities permit, and some even encourage, strangers to share taxicabs, New York has a strict prohibition against the practice.
CHICAGO, June 24 (AP) -There was only one weak spot in an otherwise firm to strong grain futures market today on the Board of Trade.
ALBANY, June 22 -- Governor Rockefeller today called the Legislature back to the capital for a special session.

The magazine industry should end the year with increases of 11 per cent in gross advertising revenues and almost 12 per cent in gross circulation revenue over 1958 levels, Robert E. Kenyon Jr., president of the Magazine Publishers Association, announced yesterday.

With the Senate ready for final debate on this year's mutual security program, already approved by the House, President Eisenhower yesterday proposed to Congress a drastic reorganization of that program beginning with the next fiscal year. This proposal, which answers Senatorial criticism that the Administration lacks initiative in the matter, is based on a new report by the Draper committee, which the President endorses in its basic concepts.

LONDON, June 24 -- Business contracted further today on the Stock Exchange. Prices tended to fall in most of the principal groups with the conspicuous exception of gilt-edge issues. However, losses were usually small and the general undertone was said to be satisfactory.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- A major nuclear attack on the United States would leave a generation decimated by death, weakened by radiation and with genetic damage that would be passed on to countless descendants, scientists told a Congressional committee today.
Six members of the Bolshoi Ballet refused yesterday to become involved in the difference of opinion between Igor Moiseyev and a member of his troupe on the merits of the United States.
The new taxicab tax of 10 cents a ride will make New York's basic rate comparable to Chicago's, which is 55 cents for the first mile and 25 cents for each additional mile.

Dorothy Simpson Smith, British-born pianist who lives in California, made her New York debut last night at Lewisohn Stadium. There was poetic justice in the fact that the evening was cool and clear, for last year she lost out on her Stadium appearance because it was toward the end of the season and rain on her scheduled night forced her out of the running.

IT is interesting to speculate, and many manufacturers have, on how many frankfurters will be eaten in the United States between now and Labor Day. No doubt if these were to be laid end to end, as the saying goes, those at the zenith would go into orbit.

Floyd Patterson will risk his heavyweight boxing championship of the world at the Yankee Stadium tonight. The North Carolina-born Negro will fight Ingemar Johansson of Goteborg, Sweden, in a bout scheduled for fifteen rounds.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (UPI) -- Edward J. Barrett, Dean of Journalism at Columbia University, and many broadcasters urged Congress today to exempt news programs from the equal time requirements of the Federal Communications Law.
ALBANY, June 24 -- Political handicappers searching for a positive sign that Governor Rockefeller was planning to enter the 1960 Presidential race thought they spotted one today.

FRANCE met Bloomingdale's yesterday, and the two established an immediate entente cordiale. The unofficial envoys were three French women and four Frenchmen, all members of French resistance and intelligence organizations during World War II. They are part of a group of forty-five now visiting the United States as guests of the Veterans of the O. S. S. (Office of Strategic Services).
Thirty years of American-flag passenger ship service to South Africa ended yesterday.
CAIRO, June 24 -- Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia received a full-dress welcome today on his first official visit to the United Arab Republic.
RABAT, Morocco, June 24 -- Agreement has been reached on a $40,000,000 United States aid program for 1959, the Moroccan Minister of Economy said today.
A cellar-to-roof inspection of twenty-three buildings in mid-Manhattan by two city departments has uncovered 789 violations of Multiple Dwelling and Sanitary Codes.
WASHINGTON, June 24 Frances Lander Spain of New York, president-elect of the American Library Association, said today her chief goal would be to reduce the shortage of Librarians.

BONN, Germany, June 24 -In the long run, it is generally agreed here, the bitter struggle between Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and Dr. Ludwig Erhard, Minister of the Economy, has damaged the political future of both men.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 24 -The president of the New Jersey Medical Society told a convention of pharmacists tonight that the drugs they sold cost too much.
OSLO, Norway, June 24 (Reuters) -- Following is a list, still incomplete, of the known American survivors of the fire yesterday in Stalheim, as made public tonight by the United States Embassy.
" I DON'T think I will like New York," the heroine of Sigrid de Lima's new novel, "Praise a Fine Day," says. It is noisy, she believes, "and everybody's in a hurry and there's no place to sit down."
NEWPORT, R. I., June 24 -"Efficiency is in love with luck. If you do the right thing at the right time you often are in a position to take advantage of the luck."

WIMBLEDON, England, June 24 -- Seventh-seeded Kurt Nielsen of Denmark, twice a Wimbledon finalist, was eliminated in the second round today by Rod Laver of Australia, who thrilled a jammed Center Court with the finest tennis of the week.
Beginning today, notices will be delivered to 76,140 families by the New York City Housing Authority announcing rent increases of 50 or 60 cents a month. The increases will become effective Aug. 1.
GENEVA, June 24 -- Employment is the central issue of social policy facing the world, David A. Morse, Director General of the International Labor Organization, said today.

For the first time an American has been permitted to see the world's largest hydroelectric development here in this area of Siberia, 200 miles north of the Trans-Siberian Railway, hitherto closed to foreigners.

YONKERS, June 24 -- Lumber Bill, rated back in the third spot most of the mile by Joe Lighthill, went through the middle of the field in the stretch and won the Lamp Post Corner Pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

Directors of the H. L. Green Company yesterday voted two dividends of 1 per cent in stock. The first is payable Aug. 1 to holders of record of July 10 and the second on Nov. 1 to stockholders of record of Oct. 9.

Commercial and finance paper outstanding in the United States rose $221,000,000 to $3,555,000,000 in May, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The bank attributed the rise of 7 per cent in large part to the financing of automobile dealers.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Congressional leaders of both parties pledged support today for the firm policy on Berlin outlined by Secretary of State Christian A. Herter last night. The outpouring of favorable comment on Capitol Hill made it clear that the Secretary would have strong backing when recessed negotions with the Soviet Union are resumed July 13.

A special service to travelers is being offered by Hartenstein Furs, Inc., 847 Madison Avenue. This concern, which stores and reconditions furs during the summer, will allow coats and stoles to be taken out of storage for vacation periods and returned without added charge.

Bob Ussery, the riding lad who made the switch from Vian, Okla., to Valley Stream L. I., without any visible strain on his talents, was the biggest of the little men at Belmont Park yesterday. The 23 - year - old jockey was aboard four winners, including John M. Schiff's Bell Hop, with whom he captured the meeting's initial grass stakes event in track record time.
GENEVA, June 24 -- The United States complained today that its concession on the staffing of control posts for policing a ban on nuclear weapons tests was being underrated by the Soviet Union.
The use of tranquilizers is "a polite form of addiction," a seminar on narcotics was told yesterday.

ACCRA, Ghana, June 23 -- The Government of Prime Minister Kwame Nkrumah paved the way today for sweeping legislation on "crimes" against the state." However, it sought to "dispel any fears" that Ghana might become a "dictatorship."

The news of Bela Kovacs' death has shocked all Hungarians both at home and abroad. There are very few people outside the country who know that he was more than a political figure in Hungary; he became, until his death, the living symbol of the Hungarian people's desire for freedom and now he will become a martyr of his nation.

The General Waterworks Corporation announced yesterday acquisition of five water and three telephone companies in six states. This will add some $5,000,000 and 10,000 customers to the Philadelphia-based company. The companies were acquired for an unannounced sum of cash.
A 43,000-pound air-conditioning cooler was hoisted to the fifty-first floor of the new Union Carbide Building yesterday in an operation said to have set an altitude record for a single heavy load.
WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- Bernard Goldfine, Boston industrialist, today lost his bid to avoid standing trial on an eighteen-count indictment for contempt of Congress.

The meeting of the board of directors of the Blue Cross, scheduled for yesterday afternoon, was adjourned until July 22 by Charles Garside, president and chairman. The hospital insurance plan is known officially as the Associated Hospital Service of New York.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Wednesday, June 17:

MILWAUKEE, June 24 (UPI) -- The rebounding Milwaukee Braves scored all of their runs in the first inning, three of them on Hank Aaron's twentieth homer of the season, and defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 4 -- 0, tonight in a game cut to seven innings by rain.
LONDON, June 24 -- An anonymous British collector bought Rubens' vast altarpiece, "The Adoration of the Magi," for 275,000 ($770,000) today.

A police captain was transferred yesterday after he had spoken at a rally protesting plans to transfer pupils from overcrowded schools in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn to schools in Queens.
LONDON, June 24 -- An anonymous British collector bought Rubens' vast altarpiece, "The Adoration of the Magi," for 275,000 ($770,000) today.

BRETTON WOODS, N. H., June 24 -- At least twenty-five Jewish congregations in various sections of the country will conduct research this year to determine whether successful business methods can co-exist with the ethical principles of religion.
The bond market plodded along unevenly again yesterday, with most price assurance showing up in over-the-counter exchanges of high-grade corporate obligations.
The presidents of Electric Bond and Share Company and American and Foreign Power Company painted bright futures yesterday for both companies "despite current problems" in some Latin-American lands.
Once a year there is usually a flurry of interest when magazines and newspapers carry articles about the highest paid corporate executives and their bonuses.

Aeronutronic Systems, Inc., a subsidiary of the Ford Motor Company, will be merged into Ford as a division on July 1, it was announced yesterday by Henry Ford 2d, president, and Ernest R. Breech, chairman of Ford.

The "Great White Fleet" of the United Fruit Company was honored yesterday as the first American ship line whose entire roster of deck officer had successfully completed professional training in the operation of shipboard radar.
The warrant officer, a fixture in the Navy for 184 years, is on the way out.
WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- The Census Bureau disclosed plans today for a dragnet next March 31 to count people who are traveling.

TOKYO, June 24 (AP) -- A devastating flood that has taken at least 187 lives in Communist China's southern province of Kwantung bore down on heavily populated Canton tonight. The Peiping radio said walls of water were surging down the North and West Rivers.
TRENTON, June 24 -- The critical depression that has plagued the nation's poultry industry for four months has eased dramatically in the last nine days.

Mayor Wagner yesterday signed the local bills making up his $90,000,000-a-year package of five new or increased special taxes that will become effective next Wednesday. The measures had been passed by the City Council and approved by the Board of Estimate.

Following is the text of the report, made public yesterday, by Deputy Mayor Paul T. O'Keefe concerning Thomas J. Shanahan, vice chairman of the Committee on Slum Clearance and president of the Federation Bank and Trust Company.

It was almost like a class reunion yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel where, over red wine and chicken, a group of former French Resistance fighters and American soldiers gathered to bend elbows, relive the past, and toast the present.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Thursday, June 25 -- On the ninth anniversary of the Korean war, the Communists today demanded immediate withdrawal of United States troops from South Korea.

Ottawa, June 24 -- Charges of political interference with the free expression of ideas over the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation's networks exploded in the House of Commons here today. An investigation was ordered.
THE Columbia Broadcasting System's news department presented last night an absorbing and devastating television documentary on James R. Hoffa, leader of the teamsters.

The Met-Co Products Company, a miniature manufacturing concern operated by twenty-three high school students under the Junior Achievement program, won first place yesterday in the New York area contest for the best 1959 stockholders' report. sponsoring company. Met-Co, sponsored by the Esso Standard Oil Company, was organized and staffed by teen-age boys and girls from public and parochial high schools in all of New York's boroughs except Richmond.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- A solid coalition of Republicans and Southern Democrats pushed a broad states' rights bill through the House today.
Forty years in Navy blue will end next Wednesday for Vice Admiral John M. Will, commander of the Military Sea Transportation Service, when he retires to take up a new shoreside civilian "command."

Supreme Court Justice Edgar Nathan Jr. yesterday awarded Mrs. Gloria Vanderbilt Stokowski Lumet the custody of the two children of her marriage to Leopold Stokowski, the conductor. He gave Mr. Stokowski visitation rights.
AS one who has had years of relations with Robert Moses in the field of low-cost housing I am disappointed and disheartened by the most recent display of public criticism.
Harry Conover and his agency for models ran into more trouble yesterday.
Brooklyn Democrats are planning a substantial reshuffling of judicial offices as a result of the creation of five $25,000-a-year places on the City Court bench.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, June 25 (AP) -- Mme. Nikita S. Khrushchev will make her first visit to the West this summer, Danish Foreign Ministry sources said today.
Congratulations to C. L. Sulzberger for his "seameet" instead of a summit.

DETROIT, June 25 (AP) -- Rail carloadings will increase by 30.4 per cent in the third quarter of 1959 in Michigan and parts of Ohio and New York, the Great Lakes Region Rail Shippers Advisory Board predicted today.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- President Eisenhower today vetoed bills to control prices and production of wheat and tobacco.
The fifty - eighth annual Music Industry Trade Show ended a four-day run yesterday with record attendance, substantial business booked and heavy commitments for orders in the near future.
GRAHAMSVILLE, N. Y., June 25 -- Conrad Eck, among the most enthusiastic fishermen hereabouts, was stirring well before the roosters today.
ALBANY, June 25 (AP) -- The state's highest court upheld today the validity of Buffalo's controversial redistricting laws.
Since it takes something like a hurricane or a breakdown of the pari-mutuel mechanism to postpone a racing program, business went on as usual yesterday at Belmont Park.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- Following are the texts of two messages President Eisenhower sent to the Senate today in connection with his vetoes of wheat and tobacco bills:

An evening of dinner and the races at the Cloud Casino of the Roosevelt Raceway in West bury, L. 1.0 on Sept. 10 will benefit the Hospitalized Veterans 'Serv/ce of the IViusicians Emergendy Fund. Guests at the casino will be able to see all the races without leaving their tables.

LONDON, June 25 -- A third competitor entered the takeover battle today for Harrolds, a department store. United Drapery Stores, which owns more than 750 shops throughout the country, outbid its rivals with an offer of 36,000,000 ($100,800,000).

A syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., is offering for public subscription $5,000,000 of 5 1/8 per cent first mortgage bonds of the Mississippi Power Company due on July 1, 1989 at 100.38 to yield 5.10 per cent to maturity.

The House of Representatives has just passed by a vote of 225 to 192 a bill correctly described in our dispatch from Washington as a broad States' Rights bill. What the backers of the measure have in mind, however, is not so much to make the states more independent as to teach the Supreme Court what some people regard as a needed lesson.
Francis T. Mylott, a member of the Public Service Commission, was arrested on a charge of driving while intoxicated last night after an automobile he was driving struck a woman, the police reported.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25 -- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals has turned down appeals in which two minority stockholders of the Pennsylvania Railroad sought to prevent the management from voting its proxies at the annual meeting on May 13, 1958.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 25 -- The Soviet Union complained today that it had been consistently slighted in the appointment of high officials to the United Nations Secretariat.

World sugar and copper positions tumbled to new lows for the life of the contracts yesterday in the New York futures markets. Wool, on the other hand, registered one of the sharpest gains of the year. Volume was heavy in all three commodities.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The United States told President Syngman Rhee of South Korea today that it would not approve the use of force to unify his divided country.
STAMFORD, Conn., June 25 -- Nearly half as many people commute from New York to work in Stamford, Greenwich and Darien as commute from the three communities to work in New York.

THERE is more to the Russian diet than caviar and vodka. This is just one of the many facts Soviet officials will hope to convey to the American public when the Soviet Exhibition of Science, Technology and Culture opens at the Coliseum here next Tuesday.
MONTREAL, June 25 -- Representatives from the United States Congress and the Canadian Parliament met tonight on problems affecting both nations.
The dispute over further integration of the city's schools flared again yesterday with picketing at City Hall and at Board of Education headquarters in Brooklyn.

The City Health Department yesterday recorded the first death here resulting from rat bites. The victim was 3-month-old Richard Fox, who lived in a beach bungalow in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn.
Amid the fanfare surrounding the formal opening today of the St. Lawrence Seaway, the Bank of Montreal has a few quiet words of reservation.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (UPI) -- Congressional representatives of mining states accused the Administration today of permitting foreign metals to "glut our markets" while domestic mining floundered in "real distress and hardship."

The recent quiet strength in the high-grade corporate bond market swelled into a vigorous upward price surge yesterday. The best prices of the day appeared at the close, as if to celebrate the fact that the Treasury announcing plans to raising new cash, was still avoiding of the long-term market.

CHICAGO, June 25 (AP) -- Johnny Pott, a bridegroom of twenty days, celebrated today with his best golf round -- a seven-under-par 63. It shattered the course record and sent him into the first-round lead in the $57,000 Chicago open.

LONDON, June 25 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan said today that the degree of flexibility shown by the West at the Geneva foreign ministers' conference was based on complete unity among the Western Allies.
Carmine Lombardozzi, a delegate to the Apalachin, N. Y., gangland convention, has offered to answer questions before the State Investigation Commission, but at a private hearing.

WASHINGTON, Friday, June 26 -- The Senate voted early today to make the salaries of all its employes public. Under the resolution, adopted by voice vote, the name, title and salary of each Senate employe will be published four times a year by the Secretary of the Senate.

The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that its Board of Governors had approved for listing 4,869,819 capital shares of Canadian Javelin, Ltd. No date had been set for trading, the Exchange said.
Jack Kramer's $15,000 Tournament of Champions will continue today in the Forest Hills Stadium of the West Side Tennis Club after being held up by rain.

E. Newton Cutler Jr. was named chairman of the 1960 Red Cross fund campaign here yesterday. Mr. Cutler is a senior vice president of the National City Bank of New York. The campaign will be held next March. A goal has not yet been determined.

Joining forces with the Playwrights Company in the sponsorship of "Duel of Angels," which ran for seven months in London last year, will be the producing combine of Jose Quintero, Theodore Mann and Leigh Connell.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 25 -- This was a day for confusing statistics. Depending on which set of figures and which interpretation was chosen, the movie business seemed bright as today's noon-day sun or glum as the morning mist.
TWO brothers were arrested yesterday after a brawl aboard a freighter docked in lower Manhattan in which a fellow longshoreman was stabbed and another less seriously injured.

A controversial item awaiting Presidential action is a bid by the British Overseas Airways Corporation to include the bustling city of Tokyo in a projected Pacific run from Hong Kong to San Francisco.
Floyd Patterson and Ingemar Johansson will try again tonight to go through with their scheduled fifteen-round fight for Patterson's world heavyweight title.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- A second group of eleven engineers and five deck officers will take a special training course in operating the world's first nuclear merchant ship, the N. S. Savannah.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission vetoed today a proposal by radio station WIP, Philadelphia, to combine business with pleasure during the last two weeks of July by originating most of its programs in Atlantic City.
Top executive posts at the Cities Service Company changed hands yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Officials of the Alleghany Corporation and the New York Central Railroad asked Congress today to reject proposed legislation that would make Alleghany subject to regulation as an investment company by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The Government's new regulations for the tax exemption of nonprofit organizations have been adopted in final form, but without the one paragraph that stirred the most controversy.

THE rain spattered against the windows of the weighing-in room yesterday morning and coursed down the panes like tears. They could have been the tears of Bill Rosensohn, the ill-starred Boy Promoter of the fight scheduled for the Yankee Stadium last night between Floyd Patterson, the world heavyweight champion, and Ingemar Johansson, his challenger from Sweden.
Cotton futures moved narrowly on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. Prices were 5 points up to 1 point off. (A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.)

Following are the texts of the original industry proposal for a postponement of the steel strike, the union's counter-proposal, a resolution adopted by the union's wage policy committee, a statement by R. Conrad Cooper, chief negotiator for the twelve biggest steel companies, the industry's response to the union counter-proposal and the union's rejoinder:

The terms of a three-year contract covering 3,500 nonprofessional employes at thirty-seven proprietary hospitals here were reached early yesterday. The agreement came after a fourteen-and-a-half-hour bargaining session.

When the New York State Athletic Commission designated tonight as an alternate date for the Floyd Patterson-Ingemar Johansson world heavyweight title fight in case of a postponement, Madison Square Garden officials set up an indignant hullabaloo.

Freight traffic handled by the nation's railroads and intercity trucking companies continues to soar. In the week ended last Saturday 723,738 railroad cars were loaded. This was 14,599, or 2.1 per cent, above the level of the preceding week and 95,728 cars, or 15.2 per cent, more than in the like week last year. Inter-city truck loadings last week were 1.1 per cent ahead of the preceding week and 13.1 per cent above 1958 level.
MONTREAL, June 25 -- Montreal gave Queen Elizabeth II a royal welcome today.
Motors, oils and textiles led a brisk rally in the final thirty minutes of yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange. Metals were weak and other important groups mixed.

The proposed widening of parts of Thirty-sixth and Thirty-seventh Streets in Manhattan continued to be stalled in the Board of Estimate yesterday. But it developed that some steps preliminary to the widening have been taken.
ALBANY, June 25 -- The special legislative session called by Governor Rockefeller for next Wednesday will cost the state's taxpayers about $5,000 a day, according to estimates here.

FARMINGDALE, L. I., June 25 -- A fifteen-week experiment indicates that educational television places more demands on the student, is still too costly and disrupts the close teacher-student relationship.

NOW that the winter is passed and the time of singing birds has come, "The Song of Norway" is being heard again in the land and on the water. Which is to say that the opulent operetta based on the life and music of Edvard Grieg has opened its second consecutive engagement at the Jones Beach (L. I.) Marine Theatre, hard by Zach's Bay.

GENEVA, June 25 -- Semyon S. Tsarapkin of the Soviet Union accused the United States today of pursuing "negative aims" in proposing to hold underground explosions to collect data for policing a ban on nuclear weapons tests.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 25 -- The United Nations has been advised of two unusual problems in the Australian-administered territory of New Guinea: laughing sickness and a "cargo cult."
YONKERS, June 25 -- Honick Rainbow came out of the fog down the stretch and captured the mile-and-a-sixteenth Bronx Filly Pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
New advertising and promotional campaigns have been planned for the copper and stainless steel industries.

Average borrowings by member banks fell $100,000,000 to $876,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Excess reserves, on the average, rose $24,000,000 to $497,000,000.

MOSCOW, June 25 -- W. Averell Harriman said today that he had found Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev strongly interested in improving relations with the United States. However, the American visitor saw no sign of flexibility in the Soviet position on Germany.

MILWAUKEE, June 25 (UPI) -- Ken Boyer singled across the winning run in the seventh inning and Lindy McDaniel hurled four hitless innings in relief as the St. Louis Cardinals beat the Milwaukee Braves, 3 -- 2, today.

CHICAGO, June 25 (AP) -- July soybeans -- the only weak spot yesterday on the Board of Trade -- was the only strong spot today. The July soybean contract advanced 2 cents a bushel, while almost all other soybean and grain prices prices sagged.

The New York Central Railroad was able to write its income statement in jet black ink last month as a result of a sharp improvement in railroad operating revenues, non-railroad earnings and a continued tight rein on operating expenses.

Blood will be given today at Roosevelt Hospital, Fifty-ninth Street and Ninth Avenue, to the New York Regional Red Cross Program. Bloodmobiles will also visit the Allied Purchasing Corporation, 401 Fifth Avenue; the Lane Bryant store, Fortieth Street and Fifth Avenue; Socony Mobil Oil Company, Inc., Kingsland Avenue and East River, Brooklyn, and Fort Totten, Bayside, Queens.
PARIS, Friday, June 26 -- Four of the best-known left-of-center personalities of the defunct Fourth Republic made comeback appearances yesterday in the French Senate's debate on Algeria.
Fog settled on the city last night and forced all planes scheduled to land at two major airports to be diverted to airports as distant as Boston and Baltimore.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., June 25 -- Dr. Niels Bohr, whose research helped make atomic bombs possible, said today that mankind's "common inheritance" of science and technology presented both opportunities and obligations for promoting international understanding.
The achievement of an "integrated and diversified" community continues to be a goal of the Urban Renewal Board, according to James Felt, its chairman.

MINEOLA, L. I., June 25 -- The Nassau-Suffok Lutheran High School Association and the Brookville Village Board have worked out an agreement that will permit the use of a thirty-one-acre estate as a Lutheran school.

In calling attention to the plight of the Ravensbrueck Lapins (the Polish women who were experimented upon by Nazi doctors and recently visited this country for physical and psychological rehabilitation), Samuel Weiss in his letter of June 12 asks: "Isn't there enough justifiable anger left in the world to make criminals pay for their crimes?" He adds: "Why don't the Poles speak up?"
BERLIN, June 25 (Reuters) -- A record total of forty-four countries are represented at the ninth West Berlin Film Festival, which opens here tomorrow with three simultaneous ceremonies.
Some Florida creators and producers have patented a "Floater Shirt." It will save lives.
A machine that automatically assembles new machines in its own image was demonstrated yesterday at Brooklyn College.

Rain kept the audience to a minimum, but there was quite a show for sidewalk superintendents at Fifty-seventh Street yesterday morning. First, a fully loaded cement-mixer truck fell into an excavation, and for a while it looked as if a chunk of Third Avenue would fall in too.
The Industrial Water Board of Birmingham, Ala., borrowed $22,750,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance installations in the city's water supply system.
BALBOA, C. Z., June 25 (AP) -- The daily backlog of ships kept out of the Panama Canal by a week-old traffic jam dropped to ten yesterday.

GENEVA, June 25 -- The International Labor Organization may have suffered irreparable damage during its forty-third session, which ended here today, Cola G. Parker, United States employer delegate, said in a concluding address.
ALBANY, June 25 -- Governor Rockefeller hinted strongly today that he would ask the Legislature to pass a state law banning discrimination in private housing at its regular session in January.

KANSAS CITY, June 25 -- The Yankees squeezed through to a 5 -- 4 victory over the Athletics tonight in the series finale before a crowd of 21,006. But it took a combination of circumstances to bring all this about.
The right of a newspaper reporter to refuse to disclose his confidential sources in all cases was maintained by a slim margin yesterday at the convention of the American Newspaper Guild.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 25 (Reuters) -- A large Australian hotel and financial organization has bought a fifteen-story building at Fifth Avenue and Forty-third Street in New York to display and sell Australian goods, it was announced today.

SPRING LAKE, N. J., June 25 -- The Franklin National Bank of Long Island, Franklin Square, L. I., has petitioned the Federal Reserve Board to increase from 3 to 3 1/2 per cent the maximum interest rates commercial banks may pay on savings and other time deposits.
WASHINGTON, Friday, June 26 -- The Senate has converted a routine tax-extension bill into a major tax-revision measure.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (UPI) -- The Department of Justice announced today that Texaco, Inc., has agreed to supply information to Federal attorneys investigating its proposed merger with Superior Oil Company for possible anti-trust violations.
The election of William P. Worthington as a member of the board of directors of the Young Men's Christian Association of Greater New York was announced yesterday.

There are certain serious defects in New York's legislative procedure that cry for correction but which, somehow, go on their merry way. Particularly indefensible is the procedure which fails to make available recorded debates in the Senate and Assembly, and even upon offered payment at stenographic rates, unless the consent of the Member can be obtained.
MOSCOW, June 25 (AP) -- The Soviet Union called officially today for a zone in the Balkans and Adriatic free of atomic weapons.
The city formally accepted yesterday gifts of $10,000 each by two private donors to assure free Shakespeare in Central Park this summer.
Mayor Wagner and Robert Moses are to meet today in Massena, N. Y., for a talk that may affect the administration of New York City's slum clearance.
The city's property owners will have to pay record real estate tax bills in 1959-60 because of basic and borough rates set by the City Council yesterday.

The General Tire and Rubber Company experienced its best half-year period, with both sales and earnings setting new marks, in the six months ended May 31. The half-year profit, in fact, exceeded the earnings for every preceding full year in the company's history.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 24 -- A report that tribal leaders of the Lower Congo favor the establishment of a Central Congo Republic in 1960 disturbed political circles here today.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- A major nuclear attack on the United States could kill one fourth of the nation's population and leave survivors to eke out an existence on land contaminated by radioactivity, swept by forest fires and eroding into new dust bowls, a Congressional committee was told today.
COVINGTON, La., June 25 -- Gov. Earl K. Long filed a request late today seeking a legal separation from his wife, who has had him committed to a mental institution.
MOSCOW, June 23 -- A tender tribute to Anna Akhmatova, Leningrad poet, was published today by Literaturnaya Gazeta on her sixty-sixth birthday.
Eddie Machen and the Chicago Stadium Corporation obtained a Federal Court order yesterday attaching Ingemar Johansson's purse for tonight's heavyweight title fight with Floyd Patterson.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., June 25 -- The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad and the town have agreed on final plans for a new, larger commuter parking lot and station about half a mile from the present one.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 25 -- The Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space ended its work today by approving a preliminary work plan for future United Nations action in this field.
PHILADELPHIA, June 25 -- Six crewmen of a dummy space ship were performing their tasks haphazardly or not at all today toward the end of a simulated flight into outer space.

General Public Utilities Corporation stockholders approved at a special meeting yesterday a two-for one split of the company's $5 par shares. This will increase outstanding shares to 21,741,406 following mailing on July 9 of certificates representing the additional shares. Holders of record yesterday are eligible for the split.

" My Philosophical Development," a new book by Bertrand Russell, will be issued by Simon Schuster on July 6. The work traces the speculations and the developing opinions of the author from his student days to the Nineteen Fifties. He writes of his philosophy of religion, mathematics and science and answers some criticisms of his work.

BRETTON WOODS, N. H., June 25 -- The Central Conference of American Rabbis, representing Reform Judaism in this country and Canada, is taking a new look at its traditionally rigid opposition to any violation of the doctrine of the separation of church and state.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The Cuban Government is shopping around for second-hand naval equipment, United States officials said today.

Lubavitcher High School, a private Jewish parochial school at 1352 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, was named yesterday by the Board of Education as the institution from which Regents tests and answers were stolen.
DETROIT, June 25 (AP) -- A second group of Michigan Fifty-niners started today on the long trail to Alaska.

DUBLIN, June 25 -- The booming of twenty-one guns from the esplanade of Collins Barrack signaled to this gaily be-flagged city today that Eamon de Valera had taken office as Ireland's President. He defeated Gen. Sean MacEoin in the election June 17.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The Treasury announced plans today to borrow $5,000,000,000 of cash by selling two issues of short-term securities on an auction basis in early July.
A ninety-day test of revised bus routes that virtually bypass Washington Square Park will go into effect July 6.
The Public Service Commission was asked by three groups yesterday to rehear its recent order permitting the Consolidated Edison Company to abandon conjunctional billing.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The United States and the Soviet Union have agreed upon most of the arrangements for the visit of Vice President Richard M. Nixon to the Soviet Union next month and that of Frol R. Kozlov, a Soviet First Deputy Premier, to the United States starting Sunday.
SPOLETO, Italy, June 25 (AP) -- Louis Armstrong, the trumpeter, was seriously ill tonight in Spoleto Hospital. But physicians disagreed in their announcements on the exact nature of his illness.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- A Senate committee heard testimony today that a Pittsburgh newspaper had paid more than $100,000 to a teamster official over a nine-and-a-half-year period.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor said today that frustration in his efforts to modernize the Army had led to his decision to retire as an "obsolescent" general.
TRIVANDRUM, India, June 25 -- E. M. S. Namboodiripad, Communist Chief Minister of Kerala, put forward today what he called a new basis for settlement of the crisis in his state.
A clue to human emotional problems may lie hidden in the brains of three whales just received at New York Medical College. Norwegian whalers sent the specimens to the college from Antarctica.

The nation's gold stock fell below $20,000,000,000 in the week ended last Wednesday for the first time since June 26, 1940, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Gold holdings dropped $364,000,000 to $19,771,000,000. Of the decline, $343,750,000 represented payment by the United States to fulfill its increased gold subscription to the International Monetary Fund.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (UPI) -- The Senate Small Business Committee recommended today that Congress limit the power of states to tax the earnings of interstate businesses while a commission develops uniform standards for such state taxes. The commission would report in February, 1961.
A local aviation industry committee announced yesterday its own "voluntary" rules for minimizing jet and other aircraft noise at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, June 25 (AP) -- Generalissimo Rafael L. Trujillo Molina declared today that his forces "have the invaders from Cuba about cleaned up."
MONTREAL, June 25 -- The British Queen and the President of the United States will join tomorrow in colorful ceremonies dedicating the new St. Lawrence Seaway.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 25 (AP) -- Roman Mejias smashed a two-run homer in the twelfth inning today, enabling the Pittsburgh Pirates to post a 3-1 victory over the San Francisco Giants.

A Negro civilian entertainer filed a $100,000 damage suit yesterday in Federal court against the Government and an Army major. He charged that he had been willfully beaten by the major at an Army installation in Germany last August.

CAIRO, June 25 -- The Egyptian War Prize Commission, meeting in Alexandria today, upheld the seizure by the United Arab Republic of an Israeli cargo from the Liberian ship Kapitan Manolis at Port Said last March.
HAVANA, June 25 -- The first seizure of land under the new Cuban agrarian reform law was carried out today.

The long pending television dramatization of W. Somerset Maugham's "The Moon and Sixpence," which stars Sir Laurence Olivier, will be presented next fall over the National Broadcasting Company network.

SARANAC INN, N. Y., June 25 -- The leadership of the State Bar Association took the United States Senate to task today for its failure to fill a vacancy on the United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit. The circuit includes the districts of New York, Connecticut and Vermont.

SPRING LAKE, N. J., June 25 -- An inflow of Swiss and other European funds to this country is said to be holding down bank lending rates to consumer installment buyers and automobile and appliance dealers in New York State. This view was advanced today at a press conference opening the sixty-third annual convention of the New York State Bankers Association.

Polaris ballistic missiles mounted on railroad flat cars, trucks and other movable launchers are recommended as one of several weapons-modernization projects for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in the fiscal year that begins next Wednesday.
Fight fans seeking refunds on tickets for the Floyd Patterson-Ingemar Johansson heavyweight championship match were politely but firmly turned down yesterday after the postponement was announced.
DETROIT, June 25 -- The Army Ordnance Corps awarded the Ford Motor Company today a contract for 4,050 quarter-ton trucks of a new design intended to replace the familiar jeep.

Not long ago the head of the house was leafing through a slim little volume of household hints. He hoped to find there some way by which he could turn the dust of the bookshelves into gold or, failing that, discover a quick, easy method for mowing the lawn.
NORWICH, Conn., June 25 -- A move to establish "a more understanding place in history" for Benedict Arnold was started today in the city where he was born.
LONDON, June 25 -- The Westminster Tiara was sold at auction here today for $308,000. The buyer was believed to be Harry Winston, New York jeweler.

VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., June 25 (AP) -- The fourth Discoverer satellite rocket roared aloft today in a test of equipment expected to carry monkeys into space later, but it failed to go into orbit.

I think that a new evaluation should be made of alternate side parking. That it succeeds in harassing the motorist, diverts valuable time of enforcement officers whose time could better be spent, is only one part of the picture.
Industry and union proposals for postponing a national steel strike collapsed last night over the issue of retroactive pay.
The sponsor of a huge cooperative housing project in Brooklyn threatened yesterday to withdraw unless the Board of Estimate acted on its proposal by the end of July.

The St. Regis Paper Company plans to acquire the Chemical Packaging Corporation of Savannah, Ga., through an exchange of stock. The acquisition would extend the company's multiwall bag business into the chemical fertilizer packaging field not presently served by St. Regis.
LAWRENCE, Kan., June 25 -- A move is under way in education to ring down the curtain on William Shakespeare.

A POSSE of small children on large horses swirled around the big ring at the Boulder Brook Club in Scarsdale, N. Y. In the center of the ring, an eighth-grader, pigtails flying, took a gray jumper over a two-rail fence.

Sunray Mid-Continent Oil Company of Tulsa, Okla., announced by the Securities and Exchange Commission, to offer to exchange one share of Sunray common stock for each three shares of Suntide Refining Company common stock.
Cut the right number of holes in the right places of a blimp's projecting fins and the airship will be able to fly farther and faster than it would without the holes.

BUENOS, AIRES, June 25 -- The Argentine Government announced today that eleven military leaders of a reported conspiracy to overthrow President Arturo Frondizi were still at large. The reported conspiracy was announced a week ago.
ARTICLE 12 of the Constitution of Ireland provides that "there shall be a President of Ireland (Uachtaran na h Eireann) * * * who shall take precedence over all other persons in the State * * * "

It is now nine years since the Communists staged their assault on the free people of South Korea. With an almost unprecedented effrontery, the Reds at Panmunjom celebrated the anniversary by a demand for the immediate withdrawal of all United States troops from the free Republic of Korea. In a nutshell, the free world should celebrate the memory of the assault by asking for the next one.
ROME, June 25 -- Italy has asked that a meeting of the foreign ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization be held before the Geneva conference reopens July 13.
OLGA G. BAYAR, commenting yesterday on the Russian three-room apartment at the Coliseum, was worried.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 25 -- Alex (The Chief) Olmedo knocked Ramanathan Krishnan of India out of the All-England lawn tennis championships, 6 -- 4, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 7 -- 5, today in what assuredly must rank as one of the great matches in the Wimbledon tradition.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- In a number of the papers which have been issued by the Advisory Council of the Democratic National Committee, excessive partisanship and slurring personal references to members of the Eisenhower Administration have obscured whatever objective research and sound proposals there may have been in them.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 25 (AP) -- Southern church leaders joined today in a denunciation by the Lutheran Church-Missouri Synod of racial discrimination in the United States.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (UPI) -- Hughes Aircraft Company today announced development of an airport aid device that it described as a major break-through in long-range observation of jet airplanes.

The Waterfront Commission's top lawyer said yesterday that he would not obey an order by one of the commission's "judges." He refused on the ground that it would require him to violate a Waterfront Commission regulation.

NEW ORLEANS, June 25 -- Officials of large cities with decaying downtown areas were warned today that a policy of retrenchment could only worsen their problems. They were advised instead to engage in forthright redevelopment, even if the cost seemed great.
Landlords and agents accused in a crash inspection disclosed Wednesday of twenty-three tenements in mid-Manhattan appeared yesterday in Manhattan Housing Court with two exceptions.

Dr. Alonzo G. Moron, the first alumnus and the first Negro to serve as president of Hampton Institute in Virginia, has been relieved of his duties "at his own insistence," Arthur Howe Jr., chairman of the school's board of trustees, announced last night.
Two town houses figure in realty deals reported by Manhattan real estate brokers.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- President Eisenhower told Congress today the world trade agreements program was an indispensable instrument in fighting Communist attempts at economic penetration.
A move to ship a collection of art valued at more than $2,000,000 for exhibition in Cuba next month was blocked yesterday by an order of Surrogate Joseph A. Cox.
TO the eighteenth-century clockmaker, a timepiece was not just a mechanism for measuring the fleeting minutes and hours; it was also thought of as a work of art.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 25 (Reuters) -- The Iraqi Army has been armed with nuclear weapons, the President of the People's Court said today.
Continued construction gains in housing and in industrial and commercial structures increased the volume of building contracts throughout the country in May to $3,541,858,000.
VOSSESTRAND, Norway, June 25 (UPI) -- Five more bodies were recovered today from the ruins of the Stalheim Hotel which was swept by fire Tuesday while crowded with American tourists.

TUNIS, June 25 -- Ferhat Abbas, Premier of the nationalist Provisional Government of the Algerian Republic, flew to Rome from here today, en route to Cairo for a major policy meeting of the Algerian Ministers-in-exile.

LONDON, June 25 -- The industrials took a modest turn for the better in the stock market here today, partly in response to yesterday's advance on Wall Street and a Government forecast of a further reduction in unemployment.

Samuel A. Sinn has been elected president of the Real Estate Board of the Bronx. Other oficers are Michael Erceg and Edward P. Stachnik, vice presidents; Warren S. Jampol, treasurer, and James G. Houlihan, secretary.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Two large hydrogen bombs dropped near the Brooklyn Bridge on a typical mid-October day would kill at least 6,098,000 persons in the New York area.

A definitive two-volume edition of "The Adams-Jefferson Letters" is planned for publication in November by the University of North Carolina Press for the Institute of Early American History and Culture. The 378 extant letters between Thomas Jefferson and Abigail and John Adams begin in May, 1777, and continue to April 1826.

CLEVELAND, June 26 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians erupted for nine runs in the first three innings and went on to defeat the Boston Red Sox, 11 -- 5, tonight. The game was spiced by a player brawl in the third inning.

ISLAND PARK, L. I., June 26 -- Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Martin, their daughter and their dog live in the world's largest clam cracker. It is a six-room house with a big flat roof, Seagulls drop clams on it to break the shells and then swoop down to eat them.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 26 (UPI) -- Mike McCormick shut out Philadelphia for the third time this year and Jackie Brandt hit a bases-loaded homer in an 8-0 victory by San Francisco tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The Army Corps of Engineers awarded a contract today for eight power-generating turbines to the low foreign bidder.
SPRING LAKE, N. J., June 26 (AP) -- The Agricultural Committee of the New York State Bankers Association said that 25 per cent of the state's farmers had gone out of business since 1950.

The Corbetta Construction Company, Inc., 220 East Forty-second Street, submitted the low bid to the Department of Marine and Aviation yesterday for the construction of the superstructure framing for the $18,723,000 Holland-America Line ship terminal at West Houston Street and the Hudson River.
A WELL-CHILLED strawberry eggnog has great appeal to both children and adults as a lunch-in-a-glass.
Ben Shahn, one of the artists whose works will be shown in Moscow next month, has been subpoenaed to testify before the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

General Precision Equipment Corporation is offering holders of its common and convertible preferred stock 105,928 shares of new cumulative convertible preference stock with a $50 liquidating value. Each common shareholder is entitled to subscribe to one share for each eleven shares of common, and each holder of preferred stock one share for each sixteen and one half shares.

The directors of the General Dynamics Corporation and the Material Service Corporation unanimously approved yesterday a proposal to merge the concerns through an exchange of stock. The proposal is subject to the approval of stockholders.
Alexander H. Cohen, Broadway producer, has organized the London Company for the purpose of acquiring West End properties.

Ingemar Johansson jabbed lightly to Floyd Patterson's head. He was short with four more jabs as Patterson moved cautiously. Johansson was short again with three left jabs and then missed a left hook. Patterson scored with a looping left hook and a left jab to the head.
Nearly 150 men seeking jobs as cleaners in city buildings began lining up yesterday at 5 A. M. -- twenty-eight hours before applications were to be taken for the $3,000-a-year jobs.

Fight buffs at Madison Square Garden and along rainy Eighth Avenue may have had mixed feeling last night following the outcome of the main bout, in which Ralph (Tiger) Jones, a middleweight from St. Albans, Queens, defeated Victor Zalazar of Argentina. However, they were in virtual agreement on one hard fact.
FAIRFIELD, Conn., June 26 -- Residents of Fairfield Beach are engaged in a lively controversy over a proposed $2,250,000 Federal flood-protection project.
It began two centuries ago when Canadian fur trappers chafed at the frustrations imposed by the great rapids of one on the world's most beautiful rivers.
HAVANA, June 26 -- Cuba broke off diplomatic relations with the Dominican Republic today.

Negotiations to head off a national steel strike broke down yesterday. Company and union leaders gave orders for a shutdown at midnight Tuesday in mills that produce nine-tenths of the country's steel.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 26 -- Today, June 26, is Freedom Day for South Africa's 9,000,000 Africans. It has become a national day celebrated with protests and boycotts to emphasize the hostility of the country's Africans toward apartheid (racial segregation) with its pass laws and discrimination.
A 23-year-old woman, the wife of a part-time interpreter for the State Department, was killed in Brooklyn last night by a single stab wound in the back.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan was granted permission yesterday to appeal an Appellate Division ruling that set aside the sentences of John (Johnny Dio) Dioguardia and John J. McNamara, convicted for extorting money to insure labor peace.
FLOUR and leavening agents, two essentials in home baking, cause considerable trouble for some home cooks. Here are the answers to questions readers ask most frequently about these two products.

HAVERFORD, Pa., June 27 -- Tory Fretz, Harrisburg, reached the final of the Middle States grass court tennis championship for girls 18 years of age and under by upsetting Wendy Stone, Oyster Bay, L. I., 6 -- 3, 6 -- 0, today at the Merion Cricket Club.
THE "play value" of a toy is more important to a child than its dollar value or its proclaimed "educational" value.
LAKELAND, Fla., June 26 (AP) -- A one-armed fruit picker who died in a house fire Saturday was identified by his sister today as a gangster of the Nineteen-Twenties.
Fifty-six handicapped and underprivileged children left the city's heat and hospital drabness yesterday for a two-month stay in the country.
A BUTTON-NOSED cast performing with button-eyed hand puppets of their own making recently entertained their parents, brothers and sisters with their version of a morality play.

CAMDEN, N. J., June 26 -- Attorneys for Frank Carbo, reputed head of the boxing underworld, indicated today that at a habeas corpus hearing they would wage a full-scale legal battle to keep him from being extradited to New York.
Senator Jacob K. Javits took his case for the Kennedy-Ervin labor reform bill to the American Newspaper Guild convention yesterday.

Ingemar Johansson's right-hand punch is as deadly as advertised. It came booming through the moist air at the Yankee Stadium last night and exploded against the jaw of Floyd Patterson in the third round of their fight for the heavyweight championship of the world.

HAVANA, June 26 (AP) -- Officials said tonight that Cuba's decision to sever relations with the Dominican Republic had been formally made known in Washington by Minister of State Raul Roa in a letter to the Organization of American States.
