ST. LAMBERT, Que., June 26 -- Following are the texts of the remarks by Queen Elizabeth II and President Eisenhower today at ceremonies dedicating the St. Lawrence Seaway. Two sections of the Queen's speech and a sentence of the President's were given in French.

Taxicab owners will have from 12:01 A. M. Wednesday until midnight Sept. 9 to adjust their meters to register the new 10-cent tax on rides, the city's Treasurer, Hilda G. Schwartz, announced yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 26 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold appealed today to governments and people everywhere to assist the world's millions of homeless refugees.

PORT - AU - PRINCE, Haiti, June 26 -- A quick swing through the Caribbean observation posts of Havana, Miami, San Juan, Puerto Rico, and this Haitian capital has given the impression that movements in the area that were being directed against the Dominican Republic have in recent days been considerably lissipated.
PHILADELPHIA, June 26 (AP) -- "We saw it coming -- he didn't."
WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission opposed legislation today that would require the railroads to file more extensive monthly reports on accidents.
LULEA, Sweden, June 19 -- "It is routine," the Social Democratic editor said of the anti-Communist article.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -Senate and House conferees agreed today on legislation to prevent the Government from losing about $3,000,000,000 in revenues in the next fiscal year.

RIDGEWOOD, N. J., June 26 -- The water resources of this area are adequate if steps are taken soon to regulate consumption, according to Lucas E. Bannon, chairman of the Northwest Bergen County Regional Planning Association.

Wearing a rueful expression but otherwise unmarked after seven knockdowns by Ingemar Johansson, Floyd Patterson said last night that he hadn't seen the punch that put him on the road to losing the world heavyweight title.
TRAVELING today is more popular than ever. And no matter what the mode of transportation or the destination, there are certain accessories that are bound to make the trip more pleasant.

The American public will buy some $1,650,000,000 worth of toys this year, or 6.4 per cent more than last year's $1,550,000,000. This was predicted yesterday by Charles S. Raizin, vice president of the Toy Manufacturers of the U. S. A., Inc., at a press conference today at the group's headquarters at 200 Fifth Avenue.
PITTSBURGH, June 26 (AP) -- Louise Suggs of Sea Island, Ga., bidding for her third women's national open golf title, stepped out in front at the halfway mark today with a 36-hole total of 145.
A baleful look from Floyd Patterson may have put a little more purpose into the right-hand punches that brought Ingemar Johansson the heavyweight championship of the world last night.
SPRING LAKE, N. J., June 26 -G. Russell Clark, New York State Department of Banks, called today for the development of a state policy on banks and mergers.
An arbitrator ruled yesterday that 13,000 A. P. food chain employes who were laid off as a result of a strike by another union were not entitled to their wages.
ALBANY, June 26 -- Governor Rockefeller called today for sweeping changes in the structure and powers of the State Harness Racing Commission.
Borough President Hulan E. Jack confirmed yesterday that he would accede to the demands of a civic organization and name a parent to a vacancy on an East Harlem school board.
TRENTON, June 26 -- Unemployment in New Jersey in mid-June was the lowest in nineteen months. In May, for the second straight month, the average earnings of industrial workers set a record.
Ingemar Johansson knocked Floyd Patterson down seven times in the third round at the Yankee Stadium last night and won the world heavyweight boxing championship.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The wholesale price index of average primary market prices rose 0.2 per cent, to 119.6 per cent, of its 1947-49 average during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- The State Department reshuffled its offices today to set up a bureau devoted exclusively to Soviet affairs.

HONG KONG, June 26 -- Flood's in almost every province of China this year have caused vast damage to agricultural production and the shaky Communist Chinese economy, according to reports received here this week.
SPOLETO, Italy, June 26, (UPI) -- Louis Armstrong American jazz trumpeter stricken three days ago with pneumonia, appeared today to be on the road to recovery.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 26 -- Arthur L. (Skipper) Herbst, 10 years old, and Richard G. (Rich) Thomson, 11, are known in small-business circles here, as Two Guys From Mamaroneck. For a reasonable fee, they will do almost any job around the house or yard.
TEL AVIV, Israel, June 26 -- Premier Ben-Gurion said tonight Israel would fulfill Germany's order for Israel-made armaments despite efforts to torpedo the deal.

Francis T. Mylott, a member of the Public Service Commission, pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges of drunken driving and failing to give a pedestrian the right of way. He was continued in $1,000 bail in Vehicle Accident Court and the case was adjourned to July 21.
The American Negro's newfound cultural kinship with Africa was one of the themes developed here yesterday at the opening session of a four-day conference on Africa and African culture.

The action of the President in vetoing the so-called "compromise wheat bill" this week has a significance that goes well beyond the fate of that particular piece of legislation. In it is to be detected the bitter fruit of the experience gained at such extraordinary expense by the Administration in its effort of the past six years to bring the farm surplus problem under control.
The means announced by the Treasury for raising $5,000,000,000 in cash in early July caused hardly a ripple in the United States Government securities market yesterday.
CHICAGO, June 26 -- A new world heavyweight may have been crowned tonight, but there was no checking the world champion Yankees, who now appear bent on retaining their laurels for another year.
LONDON, June 26 -- The stock market maintained its better tone today, and although industrials were still irregular, there was a slight predominance of gains.

The seven Soviet-made films, purchased by American companies in a reciprocal agreement with the Soviet Union, have been allocated to individual distributors. The annoucement was made yesterday after a meeting of the board of directors of the Motion Picture Export Association of America.

FRANKLIN, N. J., June 26 -- A Brooklyn community of ultra-orthodox Jews has contracted for land here to build a village in which they can live by their own strict rules, apart from outside influences.
MILAN, Italy, June 26 -- A Trans World Airlines Constellation crashed in a thunderstorm near here today and all sixty-eight persons aboard were killed. They included thirtyfour Americans.
Ingemar Johansson's knockout victory over Floyd Patterson created so much excitement in the Forest Hills Stadium last night that play in the tennis Tournament of Champions was interrupted briefly.

A curious kind of foothill summit dialogue begins Monday when Vice President Nixon comes to New York to join Khrushchev's First Deputy Premier Frol Kozlov in opening a Soviet exhibition. Nixon will go out of his way to treat the Russian official as his peer.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., June 26 (AP) -- A Jamaica Negro clergyman and his white wife have been awarded $10,442 damages in Federal court as a result of an attack on them by a white man on a bus at Perry, Fla.
JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector) June 26 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion was faced with new political difficulties today over the sale of Israeli-made arms to West Germany.
The highlight of yesterday's racing at Belmont Park before 16,323 fans was the riding of Paul J. Bailey.

WHITE PLAINS, June 26 -- John H. Downing of Yorktown, chairman of the county board, said today that the sooner the state takes over Westchester's parkways the better. He said Robert Moses' report that an agreement was near had not been unexpected.
LONDON, June 26 -- Pickets clashed with policemen today as a nation-wide strike of about 100,000 printers in more than 1,100 shops reached the end of its first week.

Now that income taxes on life insurance companies have been raised by Congress, the lawmakers' interest appears to have changed to mutual savings banks and the savings and loan associations. Representative Noah Mason, Republican of Illinois, introduced a bill recently to increase levies on mutual thrift institutions.

Events tonight: American Ballet Theatre, Lewisohn Stadium; Guggenheim Memorial Concert, the Goldman Band, Richard Franko Goldman, director, Prospect Park, Brooklyn; Brooklyn Philharmonia, Siegfried Landau, conductor, Malcolm Frager, pianist, Walt Whitman Auditorium, Brooklyn College, all at 8:30.
Jose Torres, the Puerto Rican middleweight who has been described many times as merely sensational, has been shortchanged. He deserves the superlative without qualification.

Plans have ben approved by the new New York City Junior Achievement Advisory Board for the expansion of Junior Achievement's business education program here, it was announced yesterday by George Alpert, chairman of the board.
SYRACUSE, June 26 (AP) -Joseph F. Carlino agreed today to look out for upstate interests in the fields of economics, home rule and court reform if elected Speaker of the Assembly.
" THE HORSE SOLDIERS" may not be precisely the Fort Sumter, or the opening gun, of Hollywood's coming celebration of the Civil War centenary. But it could be.
ST. LAMBERT, Que., June 26 -- Canada and the United States formally dedicated the St. Lawrence Seaway today.

The automobile industry is in a good position to weather a steel strike -- provided it is not prolonged. Dealers' stocks of new cars are at a two-year high and production is at the fastest pace in four years. This month, according to Ward's Automotive Reports, auto makers will assemble more than 560,000 units, the highest level for the month since the record year of 1955.

Despite the deceptive summer calm, the specter of a serious crisis over Germany and Berlin continues to haunt Western minds and has prompted proposals for a new meeting of Western statesmen to review the situation, to reaffirm their solidarity and to prepare for any possible Soviet aggression before the Geneva conference of foreign ministers reopens July 13.

Dr. Margaret V. Kiely, the only Dean of the Faculty that Queens College has had, announced yesterday that she would retire Aug. 31. Thus she will have rounded out twenty-two years at Queens, which opened in September, 1937.

DENVER, June 26 (AP) -- An increased demand for acreage was reported yesterday at a meeting of the American Beet Sugar Industry Policy Committee. Several growers and processors said that a number of corn and wheat farmers wanted to switch to the sugar crop.

LIVE coverage of the dedication of the St. Lawrence Seaway was provided yesterday morning by the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation; its program was relayed for two hours by the Columbia Broadcasting system and for a lesser time by the American Broadcasting Company.
LONDON, June 26 -- British archaeologists believe they have located the foundations of a mighty palace that vanished nearly 300 years ago.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 26 -- Grizzled Gardnar Mulloy, Florida's Fountain of Eternal Youth at the age of 45, confounded the critics and had the center court in an uproar this afternoon when he spanked Earl (Butch) Buchholz, 18, in straight sets, 6 -- 4, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 4.
Stuyvesant High School, the oldest of the city's public schools specializing in science, held its 100th commencement yesterday.
LAWRENCE, Kan., June 26 -- Although the nation's schools are still short about 135,000 teachers, school officials have stopped ringing doorbells in their quest for new teachers.
The right of an insurgent Republican club in the Bronx to the use of the party name was upheld yesterday in a 5-to-2 decision by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, First Department.
Six state and local government bond issues amounting to $302,000,000, will account for nearly all of the new financing in the public capital market next week.
TRENTON, N. J., June 26 (AF) -- The State Supreme Court today upheld an Atlantic City hotel company in its decision on distribution of earnings to stockholders.

MASSENA, N. Y., June 26 -- Mayor Wagner and Robert Moses spent an interrupted hour and a half this afternoon in "very pleasant" discussion. Later, Mr. Wagner said he might have something to say about their talk tomorrow.

Ingemar Johansson is the first native Scandinavian to hold a world boxing championship. He was born in Goteborg, Sweden, on Sept. 22, 1932, to Jens and Ebba Johansson. The new champion has five brothers and one sister.
The July cotton position on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 3 points yesterday, but other months dipped 3 to 19 points. (A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.)
VIENNA, June 26 -- Austria's unusual political system of government by "proporz" appears to have reached a dead end after thirteen years.

Charlie Dooley, the portly fellow who bids New Yorkers on public service posters to keep the city clean, is purely a "product of a state of mind, to wit, Madison Avenue," Mayor Wagner wrote yesterday to Gov. George D. Clyde of Utah.
NEW ORLEANS, June 26 -- A higher level of performance by architects in executing routine commissions was advocated today by a prominent architectural educator.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- Congress was told today that domestic metal mining industries were dying and had to be revived or the nation would be helplessly dependent on imports in any emergency.
WILLIAM FAULKNER'S saying that people love in spite of, as well as because of, this that and the other is borne out in Carol Bartholomew's warmly perceptive book, "My Heart Has Seventeen Rooms."*
In an effort to head off a possible strike of 1,200 drivers of cement mix trucks, the State Mediation Board yesterday summoned management and labor to a meeting on Monday.
CHICAGO, June 26 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- Iowa reported seventeen polio cases last week, one-fifth of the national total of eighty-five.
HOUGHTON, N. Y., June 26 (AP) -- The Rev. Dr. Roy S. Nicholson was elected president emeritus of the Wesleyan Church of America today.
Your very able coverage of the eight major steel centers regarding views and prospects of a strike that most of them do not want brings out a startling deficiency in our whole economy.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 26 (UPI) -- The Kansas City Star submitted a new proposal today to striking typographers in the eight-day strike that has closed The Star and The Kansas City Kansan.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI) -- House Investigators ended today two weeks of hearings that had been designed as an open-forum discussion into the practices and ethics of the six Federal regulatory agencies.

DAVIDSON'S MAIN, Scotland, June 26 (AP) -- Willie Goggin, 53-year-old United States Professional Golfers Association senior champion, won the world professional senior golf title today by defeating Arthur Lees, his British counterpart, 5 and 3, in the first twilight championship match on record.
The "active ingredient" in several widely advertised reducing remedies has been found by four physicians to be about as effective in controlling weight as an ordinary sugar pill.
The city's Presbyterian churches gave their support yesterday to the plan to transfer pupils from crowded Brooklyn schools to less-used ones in the city.

FARMVILLE, Va., June 26 (UPI) -- Rural Prince Edward County's plan to close its twenty-one public schools was given formal approval today only a few hours before the United States Supreme Court denied a plea for an integration delay.

At the annual meeting of the Municipal Forum of New York held yesterday, David H. Callaway Jr. was elected president to serve during the 1959-60 fiscal year. Mr. Callaway, senior vice president of the First of Michigan Corporation, succeeds William-E. Bachert, assistant vice president of the Bank of New York.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 26 -- Maj. Gen. Abdul Karim Kassim has curbed the pro-Communist militia known as the Popular Resistance Forces. Premier Kassim said the nation was secure and had no immediate need of such forces.
OCEANPORT, N. J., June 26 (AP) -- Joe Culmone scored a triple at Monmouth Park today, including a victory astride Dorchester Farm Stable's Gygis in the feature race.
DULUTH, Minn., June 26 -- The first impact of the Seaway on the Port of Duluth-Superior has been a larger increase in export-grain shipping than had been expected.
STOCKHOLM, June 27 (UPI) -- Ingemar Johansson's knockout punch today set Sweden off on one of its biggest and noisiest celebrations.
PARIS, June 26 -- The French Government has offered taxpayers lower rates in exchange for greater honesty.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- A Virginia letter carrier has done something about the biting dog problem. He received a patent this week for a muzzle that is humane both to the postman and to the dog.
RANGOON, Burma, June 26 (AP) -- A young Soviet diplomat who said that "I desire a life of freedom" has been granted refuge in the United States Embassy here, American officials announced today.

With the heating season over, owners of many apartment houses and other buildings will forget about boiler operations until the fall. Such forgetting, however, may prove to have been costly when the heating season comes around again and boilers are about to be re-fired.
Following is a list of passengers and crew aboard the Trans World Airlines plane that crashed near Milan yesterday:
TEL AVIV, Israel, June 23 -- the total grazing land in Israel would not fill a corner of a West Texas county, but Israel has made a modest start on a beef cattle industry.

OTTAWA, June 26 -- Bennett John Roberts, president of Canada's St. Lawrence Seaway Authority, is a modest man. Although he has spent most of his life in government service, he has said that he had no aspirations for the job and no special qualifications.

TWA and Italian Government officials investigating the accident will be joined by a group of five technical specialists and an aviation safety representative of the United States Federal Aviation Agency. The group will fly from New York to Milan today.
The Board of Education contended yesterday that the Board of Estimate's selection of a Harlem school site was "null and void."

WASHINGTON, June 26 -State Department officials said today that Secretary of State Christian A. Herter planned to offer Charles A. Bohlen, Ambassador to the Philippines, a job as his special adviser on Soviet affairs.
MADRID, June 26 -- The study bull session has hit Spain, and parents of students don't like it.

Fairbanks, Alaska, decided to reject all bids received Thursday for $7,500,000 in utilities revenues bonds due from 1960 to 1981 and callable in 1964. A syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc., and B. J. Van Ingen Co. had submitted the best bid, equal to an interest cost of 4.8751 per cent.

MANALAPAN TOWNSHIP, N. J., June 26 -- Mrs. Phyllis Silvergladt, 26 years old, was held today on a murder charge in the drowning of her 6-week- old son, Barry, in a near-by brook on Englishtown-Freehold Road.
CHICAGO, June 26 (AP) -- The wheat futures market easily absorbed an increasing amount of hedge selling today on the Board of Trade, then mounted a rally which carried most contracts higher.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The Boston and Maine Railroad received final approval today for a fifteen-year, Government-backed $3,000,000 loan.

Directors of Lanston Industries, Inc., declared a 100 per cent stock dividend yesterday. Common stockholders will receive on Aug. 17 one share of stock for each one held. In addition, the regular quarterly cash dividend of 15 cents a share was voted on the present shares for payment Aug. 10.

ALBANY, June 26 -- Following is the text of a special message Governor Rockefeller will submit to the special session of the Legislature next Wednesday. The message was released in advance of the session:

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The seventy-eighth annual conference of the American Library Association closed tonight with the inauguration of Benjamin E. Powell, librarian of Duke University, Durham, N. C., as president.
Four promotions were made yesterday by Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy. A deputy inspector was elevated to a full inspector and three captains were made deputy inspectors.
MILWAUKEE, June 26 -- Since the opening of the Seaway, the Milwaukee Port has doubled the tonnage it formerly handled to or from overseas ports.
The Federal Government called a halt yesterday to spending any more of its money on plans for the controversial Soundview redevelopment "until the air has been cleared."
M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc., textile manufacturer and distributor has obtained substantial control of Chiquola Manufacturing Company, Inc., of Hones Path, S.C.
CLEVELAND, June 26 -- The promise of the Seaway has been fulfilled in Cleveland, exceeding the fondest expectations of its proponents.

A barber in Times Square is quoted as saying that men are becoming more difficult to cater to than women when it comes to shaping the hair. Styles have changed so drastically in the last decade, he notes, that it is no longer possible to count on the element of speed to produce income.
YONKERS, June 26 -- Victor and Morris Zeinfeld's W. D. Direct scored a nose victory over the favored Speedy Pick in the $25,000 Hyde Park free-for-all at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 26 (UPI) -- The Government reported today that a revolt had broken out in Santa Cruz, major oil center in southeastern Bolivia.

AT an age when many men would be planning retirement, Lewis Gould Castle, whose life had been a matter of milk and money, made a major switch in his way of living. He got into water, in a big and restless way.
ST. LAMBERT, Que., June 26 -- President Eisenhower put aside his role of personal leadership of his Administration and party today to become in fact a "ceremonial President."

The latest issue of the international Communist movement's monthly organ concedes that Communist economists have "unduly belittled the effectiveness" of anti-depression measures taken in the United States.
COVINGTON, La., June 26 -Gov. Earl K. Long won release today from a mental institution by discharging its superintendent and appointing an old political friend to succeed him.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- Thurston B. Morton, the Republican National Chairman, today joined those seeking to amend the equal time clause of the Federal Communications Act to exempt radio and television newscasts.
READING, Pa., June 26 (UPI) -- Law enforcement officials should break up the Mafia or acknowledge that it does not exist, the leader of the National Order of the Sons of Italy said today.
BRETTON WOODS, N. H., June 26 -- For the first time in the history of Judaism a broadly representative organization has been incorporated for the specific purpose of propagating that faith.
A new constitution, said to be more democratic than its predecessor, has been approved for the Soviet Academy of Sciences by the Soviet Government.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- The United States Government ordered stricter safety rules today for the transportation of Mexican and other farm workers in the United States.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 26 -- Rumors have been circulating that the navy's chief of staff in effect has been stripped of his command.
Your editorial of June 16 entitled "Tragedy in Indonesia" was astonishing. A newspaper with a reputation for responsible and balanced writing gave an object lesson in vituperative journalism.

If there are overcrowded public schools on one side of a borough boundary and under-used schools on the other side, it makes sense to move some pupils across the border. This is what the Superintendent of Schools, Dr. John J. Theobald, and the Board of Education have decided to do.
Stocks went through a generally encouraging session yesterday but the result at the close depended entirely upon the yardstick used.

LUBBOCK, Tex., June 26 (AP) -- Mexico has ordered that its nationals be forbidden to work on farms in this area because a Lubbock beauty salon had refused to accept two Mexicans as customers, Miss Cecilia Molina, the Mexican Consul, said yesterday.

The opening of the St. Lawrence Seaway has brought new hopes and new headaches to United States ports on the Great Lakes. Tonnage so far has run ahead of expectations and so have problems of berthing and cargo handling.

BONN, Germany, June 26 (Reuters) -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, told Dr. Nahum Goldmann, president of the World Council of Jews, today that West Germany was determined to complete compensation for victims of the Nazi regime "as quickly and as well as possible."
STEUBENVILLE, Ohio, June 26 (Ap) -- A private plane crashed into rugged eastern Ohio hills during a rainstorm today, killing Daniel R. Anthony 4th, co-publisher of the Leavenworth, Kan, Times.
ROME, June 26 -- The strike wave in Italy reached a new high today when close to 1,000,000 metal workers were called out for a two-day stoppage.
In almost simultaneous bank hold-ups yesterday afternoon a woman was captured in Manhattan after getting $1,500 and a man in Queens escaped with $76.
PHILADELPHIA, June 26 -- The competitive effect of the Seaway on the Port of Philadelphia area is now believed to have been overrated.

Now that the strike of nonprofessional workers in several of the voluntary hospitals in New York City is over, I would like to voice my opinion about the registered nurses and licensed practical nurses.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -James R. Hoffa stood by his convicted associates in the Teamsters Union under three hours of questioning by Senate investigators today.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower formally asked Congress today to appropriate funds for his proposed $3,929,995,000 foreign aid program for the coming fiscal year.
Plans are being completed for the formation of the British Sportleigh Corporation of America, which will sell British coats in this country.
SPRING LAKE, N. J., June 26 -J. Henry Neale, the new president of the New York State Bankers Association occupies a somewhat unusual place in the New York metropolitan banking community.

MONTREAL, June 26 (Canadian Press) -- John Masefield, Britain's 81-year-old Poet Laureate, hailed Queen Elizabeth's visit to Canada in a ninety-eight-line poem. The poem, "Lines by John Masefield on the Occasion of Her Majesty's Visit to Canada, 1959," was commissioned by the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and was broadcast today. The poem follows:

Net income of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad fell by 48 per cent last month to $610,914 from $1,185,851 in May of 1958, despite a gain of 9 per cent, to $21,591,377, in the line's operating revenues.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI) -- The Federal Aviation Agency announced plans today to ground all airline pilots more than 60 years old and to impose age limits on pilots allowed to command jet-powered aircraft.

JACKSONVILLE, N. C., June 26 (AP) -- A Marine sergeant has been accused of slugging three young trainees in the stomach two and one-half weeks after taking over as a troop trainer. He also is accused of asking men under his command for money.
The crash in Italy yesterday was one of the most disastrous in the history of aviation.

Carmen Basilio of Chittenango, N. Y., and Gene Fullmer of West Jordan, Utah, yesterday signed contracts to fight for the National Boxing Association version of the world middleweight championship in August. Both are former champions.
ZANZIBAR, June 23 -- Broadcasts from Communist China in English are bombarding East and Central Africa these days with a strong, clear signal.
Lewis Hoad of Australia and Tony Trabert of Salt Lake City won the doubles final last night in the Tournament of Champions at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.
MONTREAL, June 26 -- Queen Elizabeth II and President Eisenhower greeted each other like old friends this morning when they met before the dedication of the St. Lawrence Seaway.
EAST WILLISTON, L. I., June 26 -- Family golf occupied the schedule of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association today.

World sugar prices which hit a new low on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange on Thursday rebounded yesterday. The rally carried futures contracts as much as 4 points (hundredths of a cent) higher. There was much less activity than the day before with some trade short covering and some new trade and commission house buying.
The Kroger Company, the nation's third largest retail food chain, set new records for sales and earnings in the twenty-four weeks ended on June 13, according to the results announced yesterday.

LIVINGSTON MANOR, N.Y., June 26 -- Rocky Disbrow said there was no use prospecting for trout this morning. When Rocky says there's no use, an angler should stay at home and oil his reels and steam his flies.
The Harness Racing Commission today provided a breakdown of state allocations of betting revenue to harness racing tracks for construction improvements.
BONN, Germany, June 26 -- The state of Hesse has decreed that history lessons in the last grade of all state high schools must in the future concentrate on the period after 1918.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- Unless it can amend some long-term contracts, the Government may have to continue stockpiling strategic materials that are already about $4,000,000,000 in excess of estimated needs.

With the summer officially under way, this is a good time to reflect on the hazards to life and the dangers of property destruction that vacation pleasures may bring. Primary among these hazards and dangers are the possibilities of drowning and of destroying valuable woodlands through carelessness with fire.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 26 (AP) -- The Episcopal Church's Trinity Interim Academy announced today that it planned to operate again next fall on the assumption that Little Rock public high schools would not be open then.

SPRING LAKE, N. J., June 26 -- G. Russell Clark, New York State Superintendent of Banks, expressed "concern" today that a Southwestern savings and loan association soliciting savings by mail from the East had encountered difficulties.
Some big stores in the city will remain open, as before, on Saturdays during the summer.
MADRID, June 26 -- Spanish and foreign fiscal experts reached agreement here today on a sweeping financial stabilization program for Spain.

Attorneys for battling factions of the Queens County Democratic organization announced yesterday that a truce had been reached in the legal dispute over the proposed ouster of Robert T. Battipaglia as county leader.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- The Republican National Committee today described the $1,375,000,000 housing bill passed by the Democratic-controlled Congress as a cheap political trick.
I want to extend my sympathy to "Taxpayer," who in his letter published June 18 voices the fear that he will be taxed to promote the vacuities of non-objective art, etc.
More than 200 films from a score of nations have been entered in the second annual Vancouver, B. C., film festival, which will run from Aug. 3 to 15.
DETROIT, June 26 -- In the last two years the Port of Detroit Commission has gone to the voters twice seeking funds to expand port facilities here. On both occasions the proposals have been defeated.

MINEOLA, L. I., June 26 -More than 300 residents crowded into the Municipal Building here today to protest the proposed construction of apartment houses near the center of this village. Representatives of civic associations agreed before the Village Board that a proposed rezoning bill would permit apartment construction along Mineola Boulevard.
The American tanker North Dakota rammed the anchored Swedish tanker Seven Skies in fog near the entrance to New York Harbor shortly before noon yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI) -- Senator Thomas C. Hennings Jr. said today that the speed with which Senators voted this morning to lift the secrecy from their staff payrolls was recognition that the public's right to know was a "two-way street."
HAVANA, June 26 -- Cuba's agrarian reform law will be the subject of national and international discussion with the opening here Sunday of a forum on the issue. The forum will run through July 12.
Union and hospital officials differed yesterday on the effectiveness of a strike of nonprofessional workers at the Brooklyn Hospital, DeKalb Avenue and Ashland Place.

SARANAC INN, N. Y., June 26 -- Congressional investigating committees are seriously weakening the constitutional privileges against self-incrimination by forcing witnesses to invoke it needlessly, a prominent criminal lawyer declared today.
CHICAGO, June 26 -- Civic and business leaders are proud and elated over Chicago's new role as an "ocean port." But an occasional doubt arises.

DETROIT, June 26 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles cashed in on Detroit Tigers errors and the pitching of Jerry Walker to sweep a twi-night doubleheader tonight, 12 -- 7 and 4 -- 1. The games drew a sweltering crowd of 51,082, largest of the season here.

BERGEN, Norway, June 26 (AP) -- The body of Mrs. Irene Brown of Wilmette, Ill., a victim of the Stalheim fire, was identified today. Mrs. Brown was a sister of Sigurd S. Larmon, chairman of the board of the Young Rubicam advertising agency.
MASSENA, N. Y., June 26 -Robert Moses reported to the State Council of Parks today that substantial agreement had been reached on a plan for the state to take over the Westchester County parkways.

Coin collectors -- the non-human type -- are bobbing up in just about every part of the land. There was a time when their natural habitat was a street car or bus. Now the devices are gulping coins in amusement parks, parking lots, bridge and tunnel approaches and turnpikes.
CLEVELAND, June 27 -- Gifts of $20,000,000 to University Hospitals and the Western Reserve University Medical School were announced here today by trustees of the Leonard C. Hanna Jr. Fund.
NEWARK, June 27 -- A general overhauling of the high school curriculum in Newark was recommended in a report adopted this week by the city's Board of Education.
NANTUCKET, Mass. -- This tiny island, thirty miles at sea south of the forearm of Cape Cod, is observing its 300th anniversary this year. It is doing so in a manner befitting its particular charm.

EVERYONE knows what happened at Sarajevo on June 28, 1914. Archduke Franz Ferdinand, heir to the Habsburg throne, was killed by a' Bosnian schoolboy, Gavrilo Princip. Everyone knows, too, the consequences.
Despite a temporary restraining order issued Friday night, nonprofessional employes at the Brooklyn Hospital continued their strike yesterday.

James O'Connor, chief non-technical executive for Lloyd's Register of Shipping in this country since 1954, will retire on Tuesday as secretary of the British ship classification society's American committee. He has been with the society nearly forty-three years.

Antique jewelry and contemporary furnishings will be auctioned on Thursday at the Plaza Art Galleries, 406 East Seventy-ninth Street. The jewelry, which will include rings, brooches, pendants, necklaces and bangles, will be auctioned at 11 A. M.
MIAMI, June 27 -- A youthful brother of King Saud of Saudi Arabia was burned to death in his apartment here today about two hours before he was to have entertained friends at dinner.

THE summer visitor to the Whitney Museum has an opportunity to obtain a good sketchy outline view of American art since the beginning of the century by reason of the selection of paintings, sculpture and drawings from the permanent collection which the museum has installed for the three months before another busy New York art season gets under way.
CAIRO, June 26 -- The government is trying to get Egyptian men out of their flowing robes and into trousers.
NICE, France, June 27 -- The Tour de France, the world's longest, richest, most punishing and most famous bicycle race, began at Mulhouse, near the German frontier, on Thursday.
Cuba's chief representative at the United Nations announced yesterday that his country would ask United Nations action in support of rebels in the Dominican Republic.

ON July 5, 1779, British troops invaded New Haven, Conn., and, on their way, burned the houses of East Haven. A minor casualty of the raid was the townspeople's first celebration of Independence Day (planned for the fifth because the Fourth fell on Sunday).

FOR THIS WEEK: Mosquitos breed in standing water. Clean out likely breeding areas . . . Spray needled evergreens with dieldrin or chlordane where taxus weevils have been nibbling needles . . . Keep after aphids with nicotine sulfate or malathion . . . Feed hybrid tea roses after June bloom fades . . . Always rinse the sprayers after each use.

The Shinnihon Steamship Company, operators of cargo services between Japan and the East and Gulf Coasts, has revamped its schedule to provide faster transit time, according to the Texas Transport and Terminal Company, general agents for the Japanese line in this country.
VIENNA, June 27 -- The Hungarian Government plans to transfer industrial plants to the provinces as an answer to the overcrowding of Budapest.

ARUSHA, Tanganyika, June 26 -- United States attitudes toward Africa are being subjected to new criticism by white elements. They tend to equate American and Soviet aims as being directed at ending British influence on the continent.

GEORGE STROUD has been nine years in the mountains of the West, trapping, hunting, trading with the Indians and using his fists and guns to stay alive and in business. He has married one squaw and lost her in a tragedy that haunts him.

Indian Prime Minister Nehru has now completed his three-day tour of the Communist-ruled, riot-torn state of Kerala. While there, he met all parties to the deadly dispute but did not commit himself. Back in New Delhi, Reuters news agency reports, he has broken his silence and has told the Congress party's parliamentary board that a new election would be the best solution of the problem.

BERNARD J. MALAHAN has inadvertently libeled my alma mater, the Law School of William and Mary College at Williamsburg, Va. In his article in last Sunday's Times about Litchfield, Conn., he describes Judge Tapping Reeve's law school (founded 1782) as America's oldest law school. This is erroneous.
CHICAGO, June 27 -- This business of climbing toward the top in the American League continues to be more difficult than shinnying up a greased pole.

Ingemar Johansson is eager to give Floyd Patterson a return match and Bill Rosensohn is ready to promote the contest. Johansson, who took the world heavyweight championship from Patterson by a knockout victory in three rounds on Friday night, said yesterday that he would be pleased to honor a ninety-day return bout contract that he has with Cus D'Amato, Patterson's manager.

Interest by non-Jewish groups and individuals in Jewish religious, philanthropic and cultural activities in the United States is increasing, according to a report yesterday by the Jewish Information Bureau.

FOR countersinking nail heads when putting up gypsum board walls, a ball-peen hammer makes an excellent tool. Drive the nail till it is almost flush with the surface. Then place the ball side of the ball-peen hammer against the nail head. Strike the flat side of the hammer head lightly with another hammer.

When it comes to the so-called obscene words, I should say that hardly one person in a million escapes mob-reaction.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- On paper, the Democratic party has seldom looked better than it does today, with hefty majorities in both houses of Congress, a stable full of attractive and eager Presidential hopefuls, and a Republican President who cannot succeed himself.
LONDON, June 27 -- The Labor party's new program for nuclear disarmament ran into criticism on many sides today.

Arthur B. Bisguier defeated Bernard Zuckerman of Brooklyn and Bernard Hill of Manhattan yesterday in the first two rounds of the Greater New York open chess championship. A field of 107 is competing at the auditorium of the West Side Y. M. C. A.

ALTHOUGH the butterfly weed (Asclepias tuberosa) attracts butterflies by the dozen, in my garden it is not a weed. Flowers are attractive and long lasting, and the plant is hardy and vigorous without being aggressive. A color range of yellow through orange to deep scarlet offers interesting possibilities for the home gardener interested in selecting and hybridizing.
This is the tenth of a series of articles on new bidding conventions in contract bridge. The last will appear next week.

Retail trade is living up to advance predictions. MILWAUKEE, June 29 -- Perhaps it will be just as well if the Yankees, currently having trouble keeping out of the American League's second division, don't get into the world series.

YONKERS, June 29 -- If a person had a dollar for everyone who ever had a system for beating the races, he would have no need for even trying to do it -- beat the races, that is For the "system players" are almost as vital to the prosperity of the horse parks as the $2 bettors.

IF visitors to the Soviet Exhibition at the New York Coliseum pass the electronic wonders and displays of all sorts of manufactured articles and reach the far right-hand corner of the third floor, they will find an art display.
Eddie Lubanski, the Detroit bowler who looks more like a professional football linebacker, shook the bowling world when he reeled off two consecutive 300 games last week.
June Havoc, who recently wrote a book about her early years in vaudeville, will star in the "United States Steel Hour" in the role of a woman who is determined to make a stage star of her daughter.

PROGRESS may be a wonderful thing in this mechanized age of jet propulsion, motorized golf and push-button television, but pity the poor fish and birds. The modern way even has infringed on their breathing space.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- A plea for increased caution in driving over the Fourth of July weekend was made by the National Safety Council today. The council reported that traffic deaths across the nation went up again in May for the fifth straight month.

The board of directors of Children's Village, a treatment center for disturbed and delinquent boys, yesterday elected George S. Leisure as vice chairman. Frederic W. Ecker is board chairman of the institution in Dobbs Ferry, N. Y.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, June 23 -- Africans eligible to vote here have been encouraged by an official announcement that the days of the traditional all-white Parliament were numbered.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 29 -- There was signs today that the usually docile movie industry may make a fight against groups that attack it as a refuge for Communists.

John A. McCone, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, and a Congressional delegation will find in Geneva a new and complex political problem confronting the conference on a ban on tests of nuclear weapons.

Blood will be given today at the Saks Fifth Avenue store, at Forty-ninth Street, to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program. Bloodmobiles will also call today at the International Paper Company, 220 East Forty-second Street, and American Airlines at La Guardia Airport in Queens.
THE problems of unpacking, wrinkles and getting the right model for the right clothes harassed four Russian designers at the Coliseum yesterday.

What might be called a double showdown is due tomorrow in Berlin when the West German Electoral College meets in that beleaguered city, in defiance of Soviet protests and East German threats of a blockade, to elect a new President of West Germany.

Two films will arrive in first-run theatres today. "Great Is My Country," a Russian-made documentary in color, produced as the first feature in the Soviet Kinopanorama wide-screen process, is the offering at the Mayfair, Seventh Avenue and Forty-seventh Street.

It cannot have been really true that President Eisenhower flew to this city yesterday because of a suddenly aroused curiosity as to what he would find in the Soviet Exhibition of Science, Technology and Culture in the Coliseum, nor was he impatient to meet Frol Kozlov. He would have met Mr. Kozlov, anyhow, and he could have read all about the exhibition without leaving the White House.
The tenuous hydrogen gas in space between the galaxies of stars in the universe probably has a temperature of 100,000,000 degrees.

SUMMER is not only for vacations, but also for resort shopping. Out on the end of Long Island, the main streets of Southhampton are bustling with activity. The small specialty shops that travel with the seasons are back with both newly painted premises and new things to sell.

In a city with the abundance of convenient public transportation that New York offers it is questionable whether governmental employes should be provided with free parking at the taxpayer's expense unless their work requires use of their cars. But when provision of such parking space requires cutting down the size of a public school playground it is even more questionable.
The storm center in a decade of controversy over New York City's Title I slum-clearance program has been the Mayor's Committee on Slum Clearance, headed by Robert Moses.

NICE, France, June 29 -- There is only one word for the Tour de France, which reached the flat farmlands of Normandy yesterday and is now pedaling unflaggingly down the west coast toward the Pyrenees. That word is enormous.

" THE STARS ARE TOO HIGH,"* by Agnew H. Bahnson Jr., is an enjoyable variant on the good-gracious-what-next, or science fiction, story. Why? Well, because at the last minute we are spared the printed gruesomeness of another lit'ry venture in uncannily prophesying World War III.
The leader of 500,000 unionists in the basic steel companies called on the industry yesterday to use a two-week strike truce as an opportunity to display "some negotiating statesmanship."
The First National City Bank of New York has leased the corner store in the new twenty-story apartment building at 166 East Sixty-third Street for a new branch office.
MELBOURNE, Australia, June 29 (AP) -- There have been green men at a military repatriation hospital near here since physicians have applied a new method of treating severe burns and bone infections.
A legal barrier was placed in the city's path yesterday toward acquiring title to six blocks of West Side real estate for redevelopment as union-sponsored cooperative housing.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Malcolm A. MacIntyre of New York is resigning in August as Under Secretary of the Air Force and will be replaced by Dudley C. Sharp of Houston, Tex.

Premier Fidel Castro moved abruptly and drastically last week to start the seizure of land under his new agrarian reform law. Troops are taking over some 2,350,000 acres of cattle land in Camaguey Province in the center of the island.
Most commodity prices advanced yesterday on the New York exchanges, with wool, coffee and hides in the lead.

First Deputy Premier Frol R. Kozlov opened a brilliant Soviet exhibition at the New York Coliseum last night. He declared that it showed the Soviet Union so intent on peaceful development that it "cannot harbor any evil intentions in regard to other nations."

Pan American World Airways, Inc., has asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to register $46,962,100 of 20 year convertible subordinateda debentures to be offered to stockholders on a basis of $100 of debentures for each fourteen shares of capital stock held.

Directors of Raymond International, Inc., yesterday proposed a three-for-one split of the common stock and an increase in the authorized shares to 4,500,000 of $3.33 par from the present 1,500,000 of $10 par. There are 987,675 shares outstanding.

A Chinese-born business man, who was named Hempstead's Man of the Year in 1958, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn on charges of smuggling Chinese aliens into the United States.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- A New York State ban on the movie version of "Lady Chatterley's Lover" was unanimously upset today by the Supreme Court.
Politics is threatening to delay for at least two months the planning phases of the city's $100,000,000 West Side Urban Renewal Project.

The thirteen-story-and-penthouse apartment building at 929 Park Avenue has been sold by Borchard Affiliations, Inc., to Abraham Hirschfeld. The sale, in which the Blakeslee Company was the broker, was subject to a ten-year purchase money mortgage of $625,000.

Stockholders of the Continental Insurance Company approved at a meeting yesterday absorption by their company of the Fidelity-Phenix Fire Insurance Company. Fidelity-Phenix is Continental Insurance's companion company in the America Fore Loyalty Insurance Group.
The graphs and captions on the educational page of The New York Times of June 21 contain both errors of fact and of interpretation of these facts.

RANGOON, Burma, June 29 (UPI) -- A Soviet diplomat who sought political asylum in the United States embassy last last week left Rangoon today aboard a United States Air Force plane for an undisclosed destination.
There were indications at Belmont yesterday that the dearth of thoroughbreds for the nine-race programs this season may have ended. Some racetrack followers have been critical of the small fields.
An imposing side show, the Soviet TU-114 airliner that landed here Sunday, is to be an annex of the Soviet exposition.
DETROIT, June 29 (UP) -- Chevrolet has widened its lead over Ford to almost 100,000 units in the 1959 auto production race.
KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., June 29 (AP) -- "Anti-Semitism has ceased to be an issue of paramount concern today to the Jews of America," the national president of the American Jewish Congress said today.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that broadcasting stations could not be sued for libelous statements made by political candidates to whom they were forced to give equal broadcasting time.
The Most Rev. John J. Maguire, a vicar general of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, was consecrated yesterday as an auxiliary Bishop to Cardinal Spellman.

Your editorial of June 24 on the subject of families relocated to make way for public projects cites the figure of 13,746 families forced to move during 1958. You further state that of this number 7 per cent, or 962 families, were moved to "other city-owned property."
TORONTO, June 29 -- Hundreds of thousands turned out in torrid-temperatures to greet Queen Elizabeth II in Toronto today.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- A Cabinet committee's report on inflation was criticized today by the Senate Democratic leader, Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, as offering no solution.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 29 (Reuters) -- A one-year trade agreement that becomes effective Wednesday was signed here today between Britain and Yugoslavia after a week of negotiations.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., June 29 -- The Suffolk County Board of Supervisors today allocated $900,000 for a 3.23-mile bypass to relieve traffic congestion on the Montauk Highway in the Moriches communities.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- Individual Americans added $5,500,000,000 to their financial savings in the first quarter, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today. The increase was the same as in the first quarter of last year, when incomes were substantially lower. But the gain was $2,000,000,000 more than in the final quarter of 1958.

Initial arrangements are being made by members of the New York Wellesley Club for a theatre party at the Oct. 20 performance of Shakespeare's "Much Ado About Nothing" at the Lunt-Fontanne Theatre. John Gielgud and Margaret Leighton will enact the leading roles.

AMAGANSETT, L. I., June 29 -- Plans for the third annual fashion show and luncheon to be held at Gurney's Inn on the Montauk Highway for the benefit of the Amagansett Village Improvement Society have been announced by the group's president, Mrs. E. V. Parsons. The event will take place on July 14.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 4 to 11 points (20 to 55 cents) yesterday.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., June 29 -- Plans for an emergency medical service in Nassau County were announced by the Nassau Medical Society today.
OFFENBACHS' "Tales of Hoffmann" in concert form, under the direction of Thomas Scherman, opened the second week of concerts at Lewisohn Stadium last night.
COVINGTON, La., June 29 -- Three physicians declared tonight that Gov. Earl K. Long was now "rational with no intellectual impairment."
LOS ANGELES, June 29 (AP) -- New York University won the finals of the men's foil team event at the national fencing tournament last night.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The Supreme Court struck down today the Government security program covering 3,000,000 defense plant workers. The vote was 8 to 1.
The Liberal party moved further yesterday to disengage itself from the major political parties.
TOKYO, June 29 -- Japan today notified the United States Government, the depository of the International Whaling Convention, that she would not withdraw from the convention.
LONDON, June 29 -- Dr. Kofi A. Busia, leader of Ghana's Opposition United party, said here tonight that he might withdraw from politics temporarily to take up academic posts in the Netherlands.

In his State of the Union Message in January President Eisenhower announced that he was appointing a Cabinet committee, under the chairmanship of Vice President Nixon, to undertake a continuing study of the related problems of Price Stability and Economic Growth.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today agreed to review a Federal judge's decision that portions of the 1957 Civil Rights Act are unconstitutional.

PITTSBURGH, June 29 (AP) -- Thomas J. Hamilton, the director of athletics at the University of Pittsburgh since 1949, resigned today to become executive officer of the newly formed Athletic Association of Western Universities.

A one-week strike of office, warehouse and sales employes in forty-two retail furniture stores throughout the city was ended over the week-end, Louis Yagoda, district director of the State Board of Mediation, announced yesterday.

THE general director of the Soviet fair at the Coliseum, Aleksei Nikolayevich Manzhulo, who describes his job as "just an assignment," confided yesterday that he has another special assignment in New York.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, June 29 -- A Soviet ballet tour that was scheduled to begin in New Zealand on Wednesday has been canceled at the last minute without explanation. The tour had been arranged by the Soviet Ministry of Culture and Kerridge Odeon, Ltd., a leading New Zealand theatre chain.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The Administration is preparing a major organizational change to prevent duplication and competition between the civilian and military space programs.
ST. LOUIS, June 29 -- A dispute over how strong a stand the National Education Association should take on public school integration broke out again today.

The recent attack by a London newspaper on the bowler hat shows vividly, as if we needed further evidence, that there are essential differences between us and our British cousins despite the common language and the long traditions of friendship.
Benjamin Cymrot denied yesterday that he was guilty of misconduct and incompetence as executive officer of the old Bureau of Real Estate.

BONN, Germany, June 29 -- Leaders of Chancellor Adenauer's ruling Christian Democratic Union expressed confidence tonight that their candidate, Agriculture Minister Heinrich Luebke, would win the Presidency of West Germany in Wednesday's election in Berlin.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, June 29 -- The Administration of President Francois Duvalier issued a warning yesterday to the Senate, in which the Government has been accused of "criminal operations."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 29 -- An official of the Dominican Republic charged today that the "maneuvering" in the Caribbean by Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba was "part of a continental conspiracy organized by international communism."

UNDERSTATEMENT is an art and it is one that Ruth English, Rosette Pennington's bridal expert, has mastered to perfection. Twenty years of guiding more than 10,000 flawlessly dressed brides into matrimony have given here a sure hand.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (UPI) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, 72 years old but young enough to start "another busy day" with a swim, recorded a record of service today as Senator from Virginia.
JERSEY CITY, June 29 -- A Hudson County grand jury today charged two employes of a steamship line and a longshoremen's union official with conspiracy to defraud the line.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The Supreme Court today let stand indefinite contempt sentences against three delegates to the 1957 crime convention at Apalachin, N. Y.

Directors of the Diamond Gardner Corporation and the United States Printing and Lithograph Company have agreed to merge. Such a move would make the surviving concern a leader in the printing and packaging field with consolidated sales of about $250,000,000 for this year.

Soon after the Government filed a civil antitrust suit yesterday in Federal Court here against Hamilton Cosco, Inc., of Columbus. Ind., manufacturer of metal and plastic furniture, the case was ended with the signing of a consent decree.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court set aside, 5-4, today the one-year suspension from practice of Harriet Bouslog Sawyer, Honolulu lawyer censured because of a public speech she made while representing a defendant at a 1952 Smith Act trial.

Louis E. Wolfson's Harbor View Farm colors flashed in front yesterday in both ends of the two-division seven-furlong turf course feature at Belmont Park. Loyal Lady II, a brown 3-year-old filly, won the first division and Quiz Star, a bay 3-year-old colt, took the second.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 29 -- The Government crisis that has developed over the sale of Israeli-manufactured arms to West Germany, remained unsettled tonight after Premier David Ben-Gurion walked out of an inconclusive Cabinet session.
Anthony (Tough Tony) Anastasia ended five years of waterfront speculation yesterday. He proclaimed his candidacy for president of the powerful, unaffiliated International Longshoremen's Association.

Herbert H. Lehman declared last night that "the most wicked and harmful" offense of the Democratic city and state organizations "has been to choke off the channels by which vigorous, idealistic and dedicated young people can get into politics and public service."
ALBANY, June 29 -- Governor Rockefeller today named Westchester County Judge Hugh S. Coyle of Cross River to a new seat on the State Supreme Court created by the 1959 Legislature.
BABYLON, L. I., June 29 The unavailability of medical p in an emergency is being arged again as the result of ice efforts to reach a doctor attend a victim of a heart ack.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower today nominated Lane Dwinell, former New Hampshire Governor, to be Assistant Secretary of State for Administration.
TRIVANDRUM, India, June 29 -- The police arrested 1,158 demonstrators in Kerala state today as non-Communist workers staged a one-day sympathy strike in the campaign to oust the Communist government.
CAIRO, June 29 -- The Soviet Union's plans for construction of the first stage of a dam at Aswan have been accepted, the Cairo press reported today.
President Eisenhower made a whirlwind trip to the city yesterday to become the first American visitor to the Soviet Exhibition of Science, Technology and Culture at the Coliseum.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (UPI) -- The Senate rackets committee was told today that a friend of James R. Hoffa had made more than $62,000 on jackets bought by the Team sters Union for its members. Some had no union labels, a committee investigator added.
The flagship of the American merchant marine, the superliner United States, will round out seven years of active service when she arrives here this morning with 1,688 passengers from Europe.
The city Board of Education announced yesterday that it would explore the possibility of providing car parking space for faculty members in school playgrounds during school hours.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The New York Central Railroad asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for a Federal guarantee of a $40,000,000 capital improvement loan.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that Government officials were absolutely immune from libel actions for public statements on policies committed to their charge.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- A $4,500,000,000 compromise bill to finance farm programs headed today for final action in the House of Representatives and Senate. The measure limited somewhat the total price support loan any one farmer could get.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 29 -- President Sukarno returned tonight from a sixty-eight-day world tour abroad.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, June 29 -- The Communists suffered a surprise setback and the Independence party gained in yesterday's general elections.
SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, June 30 -- Gen. George H. Decker, outgoing United Nations commander, said today Allied forces in Korea were "prepared to meet any attack" from North Korea.
HAVANA, June 29 -- A 134,-500,000-peso ($134,500,000) public works program was announced tonight by Premier Fidel Castro following a Cabinet meeting.
Two persons were seriously wounded here last night in a fight that began when a car was sprayed with water from an illegally opened fire hydrant.

THE moment of truth in Paul Goodman's "The Cave of Machpelah" comes during the very last moment when Isaac and Ishmael, sons of the patriarch Abraham, having mourned for their father, sit down at the same table and Rebekah observes, "Look here! How goodly and how pleasant when the brothers sit together again."
E. Vincent Curtayne's term as a member of the Transit Authority expired yesterday, but because no successor has been named, he will continue to serve on an interim basis.
The elevation of R. Peter Straus to the post of president of radio station WMCA was announced yesterday.

ALBANY, June 30 -- A Traffic Engineering Advisory Committee to help achieve uniform traffic regulation and control devices was named today by William S. Hults, New York State Commissioner of Motor Vehicles.

VANCOUVER, B. C., June 30 (Canadian Press) -- MacMillan Bloedel, Ltd., and the Powell River Company, Ltd., two giants of the British Columbia forest industry, announced plans today to merge subject to shareholders' approval.
BEAUFORT, S. C., June 30 (AP) -- A jury of six white and six Negro men tonight convicted a young Negro of breaking into the home of a white woman and attempting to rape her.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The United States is prepared to include Italy in a meeting of Western foreign ministers before the Allies confront Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Foreign Minister, in Geneva July 13, Government sources here said today.

Francisco Goya's brilliant portrait of the Duchess of Alba, at the Hispanic Society here, was cleaned recently, and in the cleaning a word was revealed that has been hidden since its painting in 1797.
ALBANY, June 30 -- The New York State Thruway Authority told truck operators that effective today "tandem-trailer rigs are welcome on the Thruway any time you want to put them there."

G. Russell Clark, State Superintendent of Banks, has appealed to the Federal Home Loan Bank Board to permit the insurance of savings accounts of a new state-chartered savings and loan association in Oceanside, L. I.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) -- The Justice Department was accused today of being moved by "expediency rather than principle" in seeking to overthrow the controversial equal-time ruling of the Federal Communications Commission.
The Basic Products Corporation of Milwaukee announced three top-level management changes yesterday growing out of the recent acquisition of two new divisions.

MASSENA, N. Y., June 30 (AP) -- The Lebanese grain ship Taxiarhis, a huge wedge sliced from her bow, lay aground in Lake St. Lawrence today after a collision with the Carl Julius, out of Hamburg, Germany.

MOSCOW, June 30 -- A young American couple took their wedding vows in Russian today in Moscow's only Roman Catholic church. It was the first time in memory that Americans had been married in the Church of St. Louis.

Several large industrial bond calls raised the total of bonds called for redemption in June before maturity to $68,065,000 from $21,975,000 in May. It was the largest amount for any month since last August, when $79,814,000 was redeemed.
New York State borrowed $50,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance the construction of educational and mental health institutions and the elimination of railroad grade crossings.
ST. LOUIS, June 30 -- A new campaign to obtain Federal aid for school construction and teachers' salaries was started today by the National Education Association.
The nation's department stores did better last year than ever before.

The letter from Ruth Matthews headed "Taxation for Foreign Aid" which appeared in your issue of June 18 reveals a misunderstanding of and illusion about our Government which is at once so natural and so dangerous that it demands an answer.
GLEN COVE, L. I., June 30 -- The City Council here applied for Federal funds today to help finance a $2,556,000 urban-renewal program.

NAHA, Okinawa, Wednesday, July 1 (UPI) -- The Okinawa police commissioner announced today that sixteen persons had been killed and 118 injured Tuesday when a flaming United States jet fighter crashed into a school and a crowded housing area.
Stocks ended the first half of 1959 with a new historic high for the New York Times combined average.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Frol R. Kozlov, a First Deputy Premier of the Soviet Union, appealed tonight for a return to the Soviet-American "comradeship" of World War II.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 30 -- Jack L. Warner, president of Warner Brothers, took issue today with the California branch of the American Legion on the subject of communism in the movie industry.

MAIMON BAY, Dominican Republic, June 30 -- The scattered debris of battle that littered this quiet, sunny cove today eloquently told the story of the ill-fated June 19 invasion of the Dominican Republic.
For ten years, through the Title I slum-clearance program, New York City has sought to attract private capital to the enormous task of eradicating the city's spreading slums.

BERLIN, June 30 -- The question of whether to count West Berlin's votes became a delicate question tonight on the eve of the balloting to elect a new President of West Germany. Despite official denials from all sides, reports persisted that the Western powers had suggested to the West German authorities that the city's votes should not be counted in tomorrow's election.

STRIPPED to its essentials, "Dear Friends and Darling Roman"* can be said to be a book about pappagallismo, if not about cicisbeismo. Neither dialect word appears in standard dictionaries nor in Mary Chamberlin's breezy personal story of her romance with the Italian capital, but they wink at the reader in almost every chapter.

LONDON, June 30 -- Three Western Ambassadors called today at the British Foreign Office with suggestions from their Governments on Western meetings to be held before the foreign ministers' conference reconvenes in Geneva.
KARAGANDA, U. S. S. R. Here in Kazakhstan I have found considerable evidence that the Soviet Union is well on its way to solving its No. 1 problem -- food.

CINCINNATI, June 30 (UPI) -- Elroy Face, unbeaten relief ace of the Pittsburgh Pirates, and Warren Spahn and Lew Burdette of the Milwaukee Braves were named today to the National League All-Star team.

Man's memory seems to be so short that inevitably we forget, in the excitement about today, what yesterday was like. Primitive man, soon after he had developed the first wheel or the first crude boat and learned joyfully how much both of them had simplified his life and extended his horizons, probably soon forgot what life was like without the wheel or the boat.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- The Senate rackets committee today injected the names of James R. Hoffa and one of his aides into its hearings on an airplane deal in which an alleged international gun smuggler had become involved.

An American edition of Roberto Ridolfi's biography of the Florentine friar Girolamo Savonarola will be published Aug. 17 by Knopf. Translated from the Italian by Cecil Grayson, it will be called "The Life of Girolamo Savonarola."
NEW DELHI, India, June 30 -- The Indian Government declared today that it would not recognize the Dalai Lama as heading a "separate" Government of Tibet functioning in India.
The city condemned yesterday and then sold for redevelopment the six blocks area known as Penn Station South.
The Utility Workers Union was found not guilty yesterday of raiding the Transport Workers Union here.
The city had its second day in succession of 90-plus temperatures yesterday, but wilting New Yorkers were promised "fair and pleasant" weather today with mercury readings near 80.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) -- Senator J. W. Fulbright urged the Senate tonight to approve its $4,164,820,000 foreign aid bill in recognition that the key to national survival "lies in the strength of many besides ourselves."
BOSTON, June 30 -- Passenger service on the Old Colony division of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad ended tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- The head of one of the largest bakeries said today that increased labor costs had caused most of a 45 per cent rise in white-bread prices over the last eleven years.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Surgeon General Leroy E. Burney said today that, on the basis of scientific information available, the Public Health Service would not license live polio vaccines.
HONG KONG, June 30 -- The Peiping radio announced today that thirty-seven major cities in China would begin growing their own food to overcome shortages.

Sharp price rises marked copper futures trading yesterday on the Commodity Exchange. In what was termed a technical reaction to recent lows, copper futures closed 40 to 60 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) higher on 448 lots (a lot is 50,000 pounds).
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Senate committee action on civil rights legislation was blocked for another week today by parliamentary maneuver.

" Who says American industry cannot compete with foreign imports?" asks Marc B. Rojtman, president of J. I. Case Company. The head of the large maker of farm equipment makes it a rhetorical question that he proceeds to answer.
BALTIMORE, June 30 -- A spanking breeze that blew out of the north snapped Baltimore's 100-degree heat wave tonight. But that wasn't all that gave way.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, June 30 -- The new session of Parliament opened here today in an atmosphere of tension and uncertainty. The uneasiness stemmed from a week-long strike of Colombo port workers and the possibility of an early Government crisis.

CHICAGO, June 30 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals defeated the Chicago Cubs, 4 -- 1, today in a game in which baseballs were thrown simultaneously by two players attempting to stop Stan Musial from taking second base.

A subscription offering of 108,904 new shares of capital stock at $30 a share is being made to stockholders of the Federation Bank and Trust Company on the basis of one new share for each five held. In addition, a 2 1/2 per cent stock dividend has been declared on the present shares, payable on Aug. 7 to holders of record of July 24.
WARSAW, June 24 -- There are a couple of hundred girls in Poland who will be brides in the United States before the summer is out, but they do not know it yet.
In a long Federal court session yesterday at Foley Square, the publishers of "Lady Chatterley's Lover" questioned the right of the Postmaster General to ban the novel from the mails.
Today is Fiscal New Year's Day for the city. Last night the municipal cash registers were playing an appropriate holiday tune to ring out the fiscal year 1958-59.
A confusion of counsel from Washington besets steel union and industry negotiators as they begin today their efforts to agree on a contract in the two-week truce arranged by President Eisenhower.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- To the man on the street the Supreme Court's reason for being is to expound and enforce the Constitution. There is bound to be some bewilderment, then, at the court's consistent avoiding of constitutional questions whenever possible.

HAMPTON BAYS, L. I., June 30 -- The Atlantic Chapter of the Blue Shark Society of Oceanic Waters must have been holding an important convention today. At least thirty of them were spotted by a party of four aboard the 34-footer Tern.

LONDON, June 30 -- Prices remained irregular on the Stock Exchange most of today and business dwindled under the influence of end-of-account selling and the printing strike. However, the undertone remained firm on the Chancellor of the Exchequers optimistic account yesterday of Britain's economy and the improvement on Wall Street.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) -- Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor ended his military career today with a new decoration pinned on him by the President and a full-dress Army retreat review.

The New York Legislature convenes today in extraordinary session with only two subjects on the agenda. The Assembly will elect a Speaker to succeed the late Oswald D. Heck, who had served in that office since 1937. The almost certain choice is Joseph F. Carlino of Nassau County. The second subject, the concern of the whole Leglislature, is the regulation of harness racing.
HAMILTON, N. Y., June 30 -- Dean Acheson accused the Eisenhower Administration tonight of slighting vital defense needs for the sake of budget economy.
PARIS, June 30 -- An Algerian writer who once served as an intermediary between France and the Algerian rebels published today a bitter attack on French policy in Algeria.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- Prices of farm products declined about 1 per cent between mid-May and mid-June.

WAYNE, Pa., June 30 -- As a prelude to the inter-city junior girls' golf team match, a practice round was held today at the St. Davids Golf Club. Three girls were drawn from each district of New York, Boston and Philadelphia to play in a best-ball contest.
NEWARK, June 30 -- An indictment charging Harvey O'Connor, a writer, with contempt of Congress was handed up today by a Federal grand jury to Judge Raynier J. Wortendyke Jr.
A former Government secretary was sentenced yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, to three years in prison for slaying an ex-pilot.
One of the oldest names in American-flag shipping, the Ward Line, still pass from the local maritime scene today as its services from North Atlantic ports to Cuba and Mexico are terminated.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Preliminary work has begun on launching a large satellite telescope that would view the heavens with "unprecedented clarity" and shed new light on the nature of the universe, the National Science Foundation announced today.
Several American companies announced plans yesterday to build new manufacturing facilities in this country and abroad.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 12 points up yesterday. The far months were strongest.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) -- Senator Clifford P. Case said today that Republicans and Democrats should redeem their campaign pledges to revise the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act. He said "decency and compassion" demanded it.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Lewis L. Strauss left the Cabinet today, a move that brought an expression of "personal sadness" from President Eisenhower.
TOKYO, Wednesday, July 1 (AP) -- Japan assumed control today of all military and civilian planes in flight over her territory for the first time since World War II.
Bond prices lost more of their recent assurance yesterday, especially those of United States Government securities.

THERE will be some big explosions on the Hudson River tonight. At 9 P. M., Macy's will stage its second annual Fourth of July fireworks display. For safety reasons, the fiery, colorful explosives will be touched off from a barge that will be anchored 1,000 feet offshore between Ninetieth and 100th Streets.
The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) yesterday made a loan equivalent to $35,000,000 to help develop high-grade manganese deposits in the Gabon Republic.
Representatives of the twelve biggest steel companies met yesterday to discuss specific proposals for contract language to be submitted to the United Steelworkers of America.

An entry of 125 cars was reported from Lime Rock, Conn., yesterday for the Sports Car Club of America national race meeting there on Saturday. The events will be under supervision of the New England region of club.
The Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor has experienced considerable changing of top-level personnel in its less than six years of existence. A further change in the near future seems indicated.
ESSEX FELLS, N. J., June 30 -- Mark J. Stuart and Mark Jr. retained the Metropolitan father-son golf championship today at the Essex Fells Country Club.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- The Senate passed a bill today authorizing $1,211,270,000 in military construction projects and approving the Administration's "master plan" for air defense. The vote was 89 -- 3.

Representative Wilbur Mills and other senior Democrats on the House Ways and Means Committee have reportedly come to the sensible and responsible conclusion that the Administration's request to abolish interest rate ceilings on Government bonds should be granted. But they are also reported to be under heavy pressure from the rank and file of the party to refuse this assent, under a threat of defeat of the legislation in the House.
The Appellate Division ruled unanimously yesterday that Mayor Wagner's Executive Order 49 on grievance procedures for city employes did not apply to uniformed policemen.

GENEVA, June 30 -- The Soviet Union insisted today that the number of on-site inspections of suspected sneak nuclear explosions under its quota plan was a political issue to be divorced from all scientific considerations.

The long search for an actor to portray Fiorello H. La Guardia in the forthcoming musical 'Fiorello!" has ended. A comparative newcomer, Tom Bosley, who has not appeared on Broadway, was engaged for the major role.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Following are the texts of Lewis L. Strauss' letter of resignation as Secretary of Commerce and President Eisenhower's reply:

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Four economists told the Joint Congressional Economic Committee today that the United States would now have to worry for the first time about deficits in its international balance of payments and the outflow of gold.

Peace, a word easy to interpret and to understand, has virtually disappeared from the lexicon of our times. Instead we find turgid and unsatisfactory phrases: cold war, peaceful coexistence or competitive coexistence.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 30 -- The Supreme Court of Errors, the state's highest court, upheld a ruling today by the New Canaan Zoning Board that specified that building lots in certain areas of the town could not contain less than four acres each.
