UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 30 -- The Dominican Republic charged today that Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba was training 3,000 men in the Pinar del Rio, a western province of Cuba, for "Caribbean subversive activities."
Mayor Wagner said yesterday the City Center of Music and Drama would be part of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.
COVINGTON, La., June 30 -- The specter of the Louisiana scandals of twenty years ago arose today to haunt Gov. Earl K. Long.

The letter published June 19 from Herbert Askwith, member of Governor Rockefeller's Committee on Transit Problems, attacked "Commissioner Wiley's stubborn effort to get the city to squander" money for "multistory municipal garages, chiefly in the heart of the city" and referred to this as "one of the most wasteful and dangerous schemes ever wished upon us."

The director of the School of Dramatic Arts at Columbia University, Prof. Milton Smith, retired yesterday at the age of 68. Professor Smith became identified with dramatic arts thirty-eight years ago, when he joined the faculty of Teachers College at Columbia.
A city Labor Department spoeksman said early today that agreement had been reached to end the five-day strike against Brooklyn Hospital.
Heavy buying at firm prices is marking the summer furniture market being held in manufacturers' showrooms this week.
An infant in a nurse's arms was mysteriously wounded yesterday when a shot was fired in the customs inspection room of the Arrivals Building at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.
What appears to be a bumper crop of talented junior golfers is bringing joy to metropolitan officials these days. For years the association has been sowing the seed for more golf for juniors.

ACCRA, Ghana, June 30 (Reuters) -- Ghana's Attorney General, Geoffrey Bing, started libel proceedings today against the opposition leader, Dr. Kofi A. Busia, who was reported to have said in Britain yesterday that he had fled Ghana to avoid arrest.
ROME, June 30 -- Italy greeted with satisfaction President Eisenhower's invitation today to Premier Segni to visit Washington.

AN unusual tribute to the playing of violinist Jeanne Mitchell was paid by last night's audience at Lewisohn Stadium. So intent were listeners upon her performance of the Mendelssohn Concerto in E Minor that only a handful of them noted the collapse, presumably from heat prostration, of a member of the audience.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Government wound up a trying fiscal year tonight. When all the figures are counted in a few weeks, the year will show a record peacetime budget deficit of about $12,500,000,000.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, June 30 (AP) -- Harvard's lightweights tomorrow open the Crimson's bid for a sweep of two of the Royal Henley Regatta's most prized trophies -- the Grand Challenge and Thames Challenge Cups for eight-oared crews.

OLD WESTBURY, L. I., June 30 -- Old Westbury Gardens, a seventy-one-acre portion of the estate of John S. Phipps, was dedicated as a public botannical garden in a ceremony here today. State Park Commissioner Robert Moses spoke.
The dispatch from Albany dated June 13 captioned "Unlisted Phone to Cost $6 a Year More in '60" calls forth some disturbing thoughts.
LONDON, June 30 -- The Government intervened today as the nation-wide printer's strike spread to concerns manufacturing printers' ink and threatened to close all Britain's national newspapers.

MOSCOW, June 30 -- Moscow's staid Tchaikovsky Conservatory will never be the same again. And if there's a single piano or bass fiddle left in one piece after today it won't be the fault of the two American Negro jazz artists who rocked the hall with the hottest music ever heard in Moscow.
LAKE HOPATCONG, N. J., June 30 -- A 21-year-old man was charged with manslaughter today in the motorboat death of a swimmer yesterday on Lake Hopatcong.
James Kelly will move to Compton Advertising, Inc., later this month as a vice president and creative group head.

A share-the-expense plan has been worked out by the Board of Education and the State University of New York for a joint venture that will constitute the newest addition to the Brooklyn Civic Center at Borough Hall.

Obligations of the Ann Arbor Railroad Company, Minneapolis and St. Louis Railway Company, Bangor and Arrostook Railroad Company and Southern Railway Company are among new additions to the list of investments legal for savings banks in New York State.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that he was inquiring into the selection by the Slum Clearance Committee of a former business associate of Frank Costello as sponsor of a Title I slum-clearance project.
CHICAGO, June 30 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

HELSINKI, Finland, June 30 (UPI) -- Two American world record holders suffered unexpected setbacks tonight during the concluding program of a two-day international track and field meet at the Olympic Stadium.
ALBANY, June 30 -- A $553,000-a-year fare increase for Westchester County commuters who use the New Haven Railroad was authorized today by the Public Service Commission.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) -- Construction spending rose to a record total of $24,905,000,000 in the first half of the year, or 15 per cent more than in the comparable period last year, the Government reported today.

One horse-player among the 15,550 at Belmont Park yesterday was confronted with a serious problem. It was almost post time for the mile-and-three-eighths grass-course feature and he still was looking for "someone to beat the favorite."

New securities of the Montecatini Mining and Chemical Company of Milan, Italy, were placed on the market yesterday by investment bankers headed by Lazard Freres Co., Lehman Brothers and Kuhn, Loeb Co.

MUIRFIELD, Scotland, June 30 (AP) -- Peter Thomson of Australia and Joe Carr of Ireland played their way into the record books today in qualifying for the first round of the British open golf championship.

MOSCOW, June 30 -- The Communist party's Central Committee has given Soviet economic leaders strict orders to come up within the next three months with specific projects to end Soviet industrial shortcomings. They were told to increase productivity, cut costs and widespread waste, and give workers better pay.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) The Oil Import Appeals Board today turned down requests of five companies for an increase in their quotas under the mandatory oil import control program.
Eleven men pleaded not guilty in Federal Court yesterday to charges of conspiracy in the wholesale distribution of newspapers and magazines in the metropolitan area.

WITH the persistency of an echo the same question has kept pounding at the eardrums of each ringsider at the recent heavyweight championship fight between Ingemar Johansson and Floyd Patterson. How about the next time?

TRENTON, June 30 -- An average state-wide increase of 9.9 per cent in automobile liability insurance rates was authorized today by Charles R. Howell, State Commissioner of Banking and Insurance. Collision policy rates also were increased an average of 5.3 per cent.

Dore Schary, author and producer who is now devoting most of his time to the Broadway theatre, has agreed to produce a one-hour television drama for the National Broadcasting Company if a suitable story property can be obtained.
DETROIT, June 30 -- The Coast Guard opened a hearing today into the collision of a Liberian freighter and a Canadian grain vessel on fogbound Lake Huron Thursday.
New bonds publicly offered here in June declined in volume from May, while stock flotations increased. But both classes of financing were substantially higher than a year ago.

The Topics column of June 23 is to be congratulated for its perceptive and imaginative insight into the common human element in two separate news stories which at first glance seemed to be totally unrelated.
ALBANY, June 30 -- An easy victory at tomorrow's special session of the Legislature was forecast tonight for the harness racing law changes requested by Governor Rockefeller.

Robert Moses, chairman of the Committee on Slum Clearance, has sent a letter to The New York Times taking issue with an article published yesterday concerning Title One projects. The text of Mr. Moses' letter follows:
WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) -- Chief Justice Earl Warren has denounced as a "damned liar" the author of a biography of Vice Perisdent Richard M. Nixon.
Plans are being made for a theatre party on Oct. 21 for the benefit of the New York City Mission Society. There will be an after-theatre supper party in the North and East Ballrooms of the Astor.
TORONTO, June 30 -- The hundredth running of the Canadian classic, the Queen's Plate, took place today at the New Woodbine track before Queen Elizabeth II and some 20,000 racing fans.

KARACHI, Pakistan, June 30 -- Despite marked improvement in Pakistan's economy, the country will continue to lean heavily on United States economic and military assistance for her development, the finance minister indicated today.

WHEN David Ben-Gurion, who lost the votes of two Israeli coalition parties yesterday, was a young colonist in the rocky hills of Turkish-ruled Galilee, he persuaded the members of the little Zionist community of Sejera to dismiss their Arab watchmen and to guard their flocks themselves.

An issue of $195,000,000 of public revenue bonds to finance construction of the Wanapum Dam, a hydroelectric development, on the Columbia River, Washington, is being offered for public subscription today by investment bankers.
DESPITE the popular theory that April in Paris is unbeatable, now is the time when this city prepares most lavishly for its visitors.

The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday continued gains in gross revenues and net income in May. The company has shown consistent gains in both categories in each month of this year. The gains have been traced to a combination of the improved business climate, higher rates than those of 1958 and improved volume, particularly in leased wire services.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Congress sent to the White House today a $4,686,000,000 bill to finance farm programs in the next year and to limit price-support benefits to farmers for the first time.

BOSTON-BOUND vacationers will find more to look at this summer than Old North Church and Faneuil Hall. Right across the Charles River from these hallowed edifices is equally hallowed Harvard Square, which is now playing host to a show of avant-garde Finnish designs.

LOS ANGELES, June 30 (AP) -- Pilar Roldan, 19 years old, of Mexico City won the women's foil title last night in the national fencing championships. A tournament spokesman said she was the first Latin-American to win an American fencing title.
BUENOS AIRES, June 30 -- Argentina's army chief resigned today rather than face a showdown with eleven rebel officers who are still at large.
CHICAGO, June 30 (AP) -- The grain futures market mustered a good rally shortly before the close of the Board of Trade today and finished with most of the contracts higher.

City Labor Commissioner Harold A. Felix announced early today that a new package offer by representatives of the Green Bus Lines had averted for the time being a strike threatened for last midnight. The lines serve 100,000 passengers daily in Queens and Brooklyn.

FALLSBURG, N. Y., June 30 -- A ranking Jewish Orthodox theologian and religious philosopher denounced here today what he termed the "attempts" of both Jewish and Christian spiritual leaders to berate the importance "of further scien tific discoveries in the atomic age."

In its first decision on the Government's industrial security program the Supreme Court has acted with commendable restraint and wisdom. It did not decide whether a defense plant worker can constitutionally be found a security risk -- and often deprived of his job -- without being allowed to confront and cross-examine his accusers.

STRATFORD, Ont., June 30 -- On the plausible assumption that "As You Like It" is a feeble script, Peter Wood has staged a desperate performance. Also, a performance that is largely unintelligible. It opened the seventh season of the Stratford Shakespearean Festival without much theatrical festivity last evening.
J. M. Mathes, Inc., the favorite in the running for the account of the Underwood Corporation, has emerged victorious.

The Long Island Rail Road's net income dropped in May by more than 50 per cent to $90,766 from $189,852 a year before. For the first five months of this year, the line reported a net loss of $522,745. In the like period last year it sustained a deficit of $1,176,943.
Stock trading in the first half of this year was the heaviest since 1930. The volume was also the third largest in the history of the New York Stock Exchange.

ONE side effect of England's enforced austerity during World War II was the near-loss of many of her centuries-old cheesemaking secrets. Fortunately, however, they survived and the principal varieties are once again available on both sides of the Atlantic.
The Maryland State Roads Commission borrowed $25,000,000 in the bond market yesterday on serial bonds due from 1960 to 1974.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Representative Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas, started a floor fight today on a bill to revise reserve requirements for member banks of the Federal Rserve System.
CAIRO, June 30 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser accused Israel today of "aggressive actions" in trying to send ships that she had chartered through the Suez Canal.
Operations of the Champion Paper and Fibre Company in the fiscal year ended on March 31 resulted in sharply reduced earnings. "But the future looks good," the annual report states.

Yesterday marked the end of the Federal Government's fiscal year 1958-59. Final figures on the national budget will be released in a few weeks, but on the basis of the most recently available estimates they should reveal a deficit of close to $13 billion.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 30 -- Israel's latest Cabinet crisis neared a climax today after two parties in Premier David Ben-Gurion's coalition voted against him in a Parliamentary committee meeting.
A union of drivers of ready-mix concrete trucks told fifty employer concerns last night it would strike throughout the metropolitan area today, a management spokesman said.

The ten-story office building on the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Fortieth Street will change hands soon. J. P. Sloane and Lloyd Hauser, realty investors, have contracted to buy the structure from the heirs of the late Col. Edward M. Knox, son of the founder of the Knox Hat Company, who erected the building in 1901.
LOVE and marriage are two splendid institutions that are bound to go on forever. This Bloomingdale's recognizes.
The beleaguered city taxpayer will slip a bit more deeply into the morass today.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 30 -- Two Californians, Sally Moore and Darlene Hard, kept alive America's hopes of retaining the women's Wimbledon tennis title by gaining the singles semi-finals today.

LOS ANGELES, June 30 (AP) -- Sad Sam Jones came within a cheap infield single of pitching the second no-hit no-run game of his major league career tonight at the San Francisco Giants downed the Los Angeles Dodgers, 2 -- 0, before 59,312 fans at the Coliseum.

HAVANA, June 30 -- The chief of Cuba's Air Force resigned today, charging there was Communist influence in the armed forces and Government. It was the first open break in the unity of the revolutionary armed forces.
Hordes of Americans flocked into the Soviet exhibition in the Coliseum at its public opening yesterday.

The importance of emotional stability of a population in a civil defense crisis was stressed here yesterday by the Dr. Paul H. Hoch, New York State Commissioner of Mental Hygience. He told a New York County American Legion meeting that the main objective should be reduction of fear, control of anxiety and prevention of panic.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 30 -- "This Island Is Mine," a play based on Shakespeare's "The Tempest," had its world premiere last night as part of Bermuda's 350th anniversary celebrations.

The great disillusion about communism that began with the subjugation of Czechoslovakia, gained intensity during the anti-Communist revolts in East Germany, Poland and Hungary, and is now spreading through Asia because of the rape of Tibet, has led to another Communist defeat in a tiny but strategically important Western bastion -- Iceland.
The Appellate Division ordered a new trial yesterday on the prices for four parcels of land condemned for the Throgs Neck Expressway in the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Senate Republican leadership moved tonight, with White House backing, to cut financing for the Development Loan Fund nearly 60 per cent by June 30, 1962.
In a quiet conclave, surrounded by a double drama on the outside, Dr. Heinrich Luebke, member of Chancellor Adenauer's Cabinet and party, has been elected as the new President of West Germany.

SINCE photographers can't resist the unusual, they dreamed up a picture sequence at the recent United States Open golf championship. John Brodie, a professional golfer, would throw a forward pass with a football to Mike Souchak, also a professional golfer. It was a noble idea but slightly impracticable because two distant figures couldn't stay in focus and still be recognizable.
CHICAGO, July 1 (AP) -- The grain futures market turned weak shortly before the close on the Board of Trade today. But wheat withstood the pressure and finished with small gains.

CONSTANZA, Dominican Republic, July 1 -- Dominican troops working with air support and backed up by machete-swinging peasants are beating the heavily wooded mountains of the Central Cordillera in an attempt to flush the survivors of an invasion force that landed here two weeks ago.
Four hundred drivers for the Green Bus Lines won wage increases of 25 cents an hour yesterday in a two-year contract.
A MINK coat, a typewriter, a kitchen sink, a work of art and a bus are but a few of the hundreds of commodities that can be rented in New York.
KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., July 1 (AP) -- Maurice Goldstein, a New York banker, was elected today grand master of Brith Abraham, national Jewish fraternal order.
WHITE PLAINS, July 1 -- The New York State Thruway Authority's new policy of providing free gasoline, water and tools for stalled cars was challenged in State Supreme Court here today.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 1 -- Maurice van Hemelrijck, Minister of the Belgian Congo, told the House of Representatives here today that the Government should act firmly in preparing the African region for self-rule.

STRATFORD, Ont., July 1. -- By adhering to the text, the co-directors of "Othello" have given the Stratford Shakespearean Festival one of its best productions. It opened last evening in the gay Theatre in the Park with Douglas Campbell in the title role.

Sales of the Wesson Oil and Snowdrift Company, Inc., in the nine months ended on May 31 were somewhat lower than those of the preceding year's period. But earnings rose, according to the report of the cottonseed oil processor.

Robert Moses, chairman of the Mayor's Committee on Slum Clearance, declared in a letter published yesterday by The New York Times that in Tuesday's article about the Title I program "there are misstatements and omissions."
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- A bill to preserve 5,000 acres of Indiana duneland as a national monument was rejected, 4-3, today by a Senate Interior subcommittee.

HAMILTON, N. Y., July 1 -- Turkey's Foreign Minister said here tonight that Russian moves for a summit conference were diversionary tactics to draw attention from their efforts to outflank Western defenses and penetrate Africa and the Middle East.

BUENOS AIRES, July 1 -- President Arturo Frondizi named a new Secretary of War today. He chose Brig. Gen. Elbio C. Anaya, retired, 69 years old, a participant in the so-called colonels' revolt of 1943 that started the former dictator Juan D. Peron to power, to fill the post.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev took a very tough line on Berlin in his conversations with W. Averell Harriman June 23, an informed source here reported today. "Khrushchev was very rough in his talks with Harriman," this source said.
LONDON, July 1 -- Twenty-five Impressionist and modern paintings and four drawings from the collection of Walter P. Chrysler Jr. were sold at auction here today for 219,020 ($613,256).
A dinner dance celebrating the fortieth anniversary of the founding of the Soldiers, Sailors and Airmen's Club will be held on Oct. 29 in the Grand Ballroom of the Astor.
BALTIMORE, July 1 -- The Yankees' long and arduous climb out of the dank depths of the American League's second division showed its first appreciable gain on this hot and humid night.

The series of four Monday evening outdoor concerts to be started Aug. 3 under the auspices of the Washington Square Association this year will open with a fanfare of "Aida trumpets" from atop the Washington Arch.
TORONTO, July 1 (AP) -- Crawford Gordon has resigned as president and general manager of A. V. Roe Canada, Ltd.
MEAD, Neb., July 1 (AP) -- Three members of a pacifist group went to jail today after attempting to enter a missile construction area in protest against the missile project.
ALBANY, July 1 -- James E. Mulcahy of Manhattan submitted his resignation as a City Court justice to Secretary of State Caroline K. Simon today. It takes effect July 31.
PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, July 1 -- President Francois Duvalier has in effect told the nation's lawmakers that he still is boss, despite his long absence from office because of a heart attack.
DUBLIN, June 26 -- "Three to one, bar one," goes the hand-bookmakers' chant as they offer the odds against any runner except the "bar one," which will be a short-priced favorite.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 1 -- The United States has sent a young agricultural specialist to Rongelap Atoll to live with the Marshall Islanders in the Pacific, share their work and eat their diet of fish and coconuts in an attempt to convince them that they are no longer in danger of atomic radiation.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- The Erie Railroad and the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad today submitted a formal merger proposal to the Interstate Commerce Commission. They projected a new corporation to be known as the Erie-Lackawanna Railroad Company.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- The Treasury has mailed about 3,000 signed blank checks to retired Government workers in all parts of the country.
Drivers of ready-mix concrete, sand, gravel and asphalt trucks struck yesterday morning over the city and in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

Dr. Dietrich von Bothmer has been appointed curator of Greek and Roman art at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. He has been associate curator in the department since 1951 and is an authority on Greek art, notably vase painting.
OTTAWA, July 1 -- Queen Elizabeth II spoke to the people of Canada today on the nation's ninety-second birthday anniversary.

A plant to manufacture pre-stressed columns, beams and other building components will be the first structure to be built on the sixty-seven-acre Empire State Industrial Park, in northwestern Staten Island.
LONDON, July 1 -- The Government declined today to bar the British Broadcasting Corporation from choosing birth control as a subject for its weekly "Good Cause" program.
LONDON, July 1 -- The new account on the Stock Exchange here today started with many small gains among the industrials, although the total turnover continued to fall slightly.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- President Eisenhower conferred for seventy minutes today with Frol R. Kozlov, a First Deputy Premier of the Soviet Union.

ROME, July 1 -- All pinball machines, known here as "flippers," went out of business throughout Italy today. The police saw to it everywhere that the Government's ban on an estimated total of 15,000 machines was observed.

General Motors Acceptance Corporation, largest sales finance company in the country, yesterday increased from 4 1/2 to 5 per cent the interest rate it charges to finance dealer stocks of new automobiles.
The return match between Rapid of Austria and Napoli of Italy produced more expert exciting soccer but no further brawls at Ebbets Field last night.

The Chesapeake and Ohio Railway reported yesterday a 20 per cent jump in profits last month on a 13 per cent gain in gross revenues. Net income was $4,898,000, compared with $4,002,000 in June of last year, while gross reached $32,614,000, up from $28,892,000 in the like 1958 month.

The State Department indignantly denied here yesterday that the late John Foster Dulles had softened his basic policy toward the Soviet Union, as alleged several times recently by Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev.

HAVANA, July 1 -- The Cuban revolutionary armed forces are searching for the former chief of the air force, Maj. Pedro Luis Diaz Lanz. Major Diaz resigned yesterday on the ground that there was a great deal of Communist influence in the revolutionary army and the Castro Government.

MUIRFIELD, Scotland July 1 (AP) -- Two unheralded British golfers, Fred Bullock and Arnold Stickley, today shot 68's and took the first-round lead in the British open championship. Then they sat back and enjoyed themselves as high winds and rain sent later scores rocketing.

ROME, July 1 -- The Italian Communist party acknowledged today a slight loss in its membership. At the same time it proclaimed that a "change of direction" favorable to communism was maturing in Italy and called for "new alliances" to hasten it.

BEDFORD VILLAGE, N. Y., July 1 -- John M. Young Jr., 20-year-old son of a partner in Morgan Stanley Co., investment bankers, was accused tonight of being the hit-and-run driver who killed one boy and injured another here at 12:35 A. M. today.

The suggestion offered by your contributor Nathan Frankel that New York's police force would be better occupied in devoting its total energies to the more obvious forms of crime prevention seems an oversimplification of a complex problem.

BOSTON, July 1 -- The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court upheld today the life sentences imposed on eight men convicted of the $1,218,211 robbery of Brink's, Inc. The decision denied a contention that the trial had been prejudiced by publicity.
A new contract offered by ten New York newspapers to their union printers was rejected yesterday in a referendum of New York Typographical Union 6 (Big Six).

" THE CLOUDED FOUNTAIN,"* by McCready Huston, is an amiably satiric novel about Philadelphia's suburban dynasts. Their citadels along the Main Line are forever being imperiled. Yet somehow they manage to survive the ultimate implications of democracy that began to seem disquieting to their ancestors about the time George Washington encamped at Valley Forge.

LOUISVILLE, July 1 (UPI) -- Rudell Stitch, a Louisville church elder, stopped Rudy Sawyer of New York in 2 minutes 15 seconds of the first round tonight. The welterweight contest was scheduled for ten rounds.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Following are the highlights of President Eisenhower's news conference today:
WASHINGTON, July 1 (UPI) -- Gen. Lyman L. Lemnitzer was sworn in today as the forty-second chief of the Army, succeeding Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor.

DARIEN, Conn., July 1 -- A new golfing team, Paul Kelly and Dave Mance of Sleepy Hollow, won the British Victory Tournament today. Kelly, the 1957 metropolitan champion, and his 19-year-old club-mate turned in a best-ball score of 35, 32 -- 67.
The Kudner Agency, Inc., has learned that half a loaf sometimes leads to the whole.
Safety messages were sent out from many sources yesterday to the 1,600,000 drivers who will be on the roads of the metropolitan area during the Fourth of July week-end, which for many begins tonight.

We who love peace welcome the exchange of visitors between the United States and the U. S. S. R. We welcome Deputy Premier Frol Kozlov in the spirit in which we believe the Russians will welcome Vice President Nixon.
BURGESS MEREDITH was in France when he discovered that there was more to a picnic than hard-cooked eggs and ants.

In the decision of the State Insurance Department announced on June 28 to permit Blue Cross to raise its rates by 26.5 per cent, Deputy Commissioner Cantor commented that an increase was needed now to maintain reserves but that the relief "granted must be on an interim basis and limited to the minimum amount" to safeguard statutory surpluses through 1960.
Two of America's top business leaders lent their names yesterday to the growing mutual fund industry.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 1 -- President Sukarno will hand down a decree in the next few days reinstating the controversial 1945 Constitution, Lieut. Gen. Abdul Haris Nasution, Army Chief of Staff, announced today.

The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday charged the Belmont Oil Corporation and five brokerage houses with selling unregistered Belmont common stock and filed a complaint in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York in an effort to halt such sales.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The American people have "changed their minds" since last November's election on the issues of Government spending and inflation, President Eisenhower said today.
Cedar Brook outsped seven other 3-year-olds without much trouble and won the thirty-second running of the Shevlin yesterday at Belmont Park.

ST. LOUIS, July 1 (AP) -- Four major barge lines suspended all operations on the nation's rivers today after negotiations were deadlocked with the National Maritime Union, the Masters, Mates and Pilots Union and the Marine Engineers Beneficial Associations.

American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., has asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to register $22,500,000 of convertible subordinated debentures due in 1982. The issue is to be offered by a syndicate headed by the First Boston Corporation and Lazard Freres Co.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- A Federal agent today linked officials of a New York Teamsters Union local with narcotics peddling.
Imports of foreign steel mill products rose to the highest monthly level on record in April, on a tonnage basis. And for the fifth consecutive month, those imports exceeded exports.

In the summer of 1900 Chinese Boxers, a society of anti-foreign fanatics, trapped 1,000 European, Japanese and American men, women and children and 2,000 Chinese converts to Christianity in the walled legation area of Peking.
WASHINGTON July 1 (UPI) -- Dr. Herbert York, the Defense Department's research chief, believes the over-all price tag for developing an atomic-powered plane will be at least $10,000,000,000.

Seventh-grade classes that learned mathematics from television lectures scored 9.6 percentage points higher in a test in New York City public schools than classes taught in the orthodox way, without television.
Higher interest rates on an increased volume of loans are producing sharp gains in operating earnings for the nation's banks, reports for the first six months of 1959 indicate.

Sol and Irving Goldman and Alex Di Lorenzo, realty investors, have purchased the two sixteen-story apartment buildings at 15 and 17 Park Avenue, southeast corner of Thirty-fifth Street. The deal was negotiated by L. V. Hoffman Co., brokers.
Russia's towering TU-114 airliner, one of which landed here Sunday, was reported yesterday to be in "serial production" with twelve to fifteen already built.
With fresh exteriors and renovated interiors, New York University is giving a new look to its buildings in Washington Square Center.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (UPI) -- Congress swiftly passed and sent to the White House today two big compromise money bills. One included funds to set up a special "brain trust" to mastermind global economic warfare against the Communists.
The shot in the arm that Title I slum clearance was supposed to give to private enterprise has, in New York, been unexpectedly delivered to cooperative housing.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., July 1 (AP) -- Archibald S. Alexander of Bernardsville was elected chairman of the Rutgers University board of governors today.

MARION, Ohio, July 1 (AP) -- At least three persons, and possibly a fourth, were killed near here today in the crash of an airplane believed owned by Continental Can Company of New York City, the Marion County Sheriff's office reported.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 1 -- Youngsters resembling United States or French beatniks have made their appearance in Prague.

The appointment of Walter L. Price as president of the Board of Commissioners of Finance of Baltimore has been confirmed unanimously by the City Council. The board is the key fiscal agency in the Baltimore municipal government.

RABAT, Morocco, July 1 -- Morocco and the United States moved nearer solution of the base problem today when a Moroccan organization replaced the French group charged with recruitment of local labor for the United States bases.

ALBANY, July 1 -- A 42-year-old Nassau County attorney with a strong background in keen legislative debate today became the ninety-third Speaker of the Assembly. Joseph F. Carlino of Long Beach, backed by the vote of every Republican in the House save himself, thus joined a line of presiding officers that stretches back unbroken to 1777.
FARMVILLE, Va., July 1 (UPI) -- Prince Edward County officially closed its twenty-one public schools today to avoid the effects of an integration decree.

Electric power production climbed to a record of 13,749,000,000 kilowatt-hours last week from 13,331,000,000 in the week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. The previous record of 13,554,000,000 kilowatt-hours was set in the week ended on Jan. 10, 1959.

HARTFORD, July 1 (AP) -- State Police Commissioner Leo J. Mulcahy assumed command of the Connecticut State Police Department today and immediately announced several changes in departmental organization and administration.
BALBOA, C. Z., July 1 -- For the first time in the Panama Canal's hsitory more than 11,000 vessels of all types transited the waterway in a year.
Senator Jennings Randolph, Democrat of West Virginia, called on the Eisenhower Administration yesterday to negotiate with the Russians only "on the hope of some agreement."
The bond market was mostly on the defensive again yesterday, with the trading pattern largely a re-enactment of recent sessions.
MINEOLA, L. I., July 1 -- Confusion over educational financial policy is increasing among school officials as they attempt to deal with the consequences of a taxpayers' revolt on Long Island.

Great Britain continues to show improvement in its balance of payment -- exports in excess of imports. Yesterday, the British Treasury reported a sharp improvement in exports in April and May -- an increase of about 9 per cent above those in the 1958 months.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Treasury's $3,000,000,000 offering of March tax anticipation bills sold today at prices which averaged a yield of 4.075 per cent.

EAST MEADOW, L. I., July 1 -- Mrs. Dorothy Hardy is a woman of distinction among dog show devotees. During World War II she was the only woman officer assigned to the K-9 Corps. Now she is one of the most successful of the growing coterie of professional women handlers.
The Port of New York Authority yesterday passed the mid-point in its seven-year $85,000,000 Brooklyn waterfront development program with the dedication of a gleaming new marine terminal.
COVINGTON, La., July 1 -- Gov. Earl K. Long has suffered "a slight heart failure," his doctors announced tonight. They said they were concerned over his condition.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (UP) -- Following is a transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today:

Twentieth Century-Fox has reported the acquisition for $1,125,000 of African Film Productions, a South African motion-picture company that has been producing newsreels, short subjects and feature films in the Afrikaans language.
Oshkosh, Wis., received bids yesterday on $4,600,000 of improvement bonds secured by general taxation. Most of the money is to be spent on school and waterworks construction.
PARIS, July 1 -- Belgium's proposal for a July meeting of Atlantic alliance foreign ministers got little support and a polite postponement of decision from the alliance's Permanent Council today.

An extra shopping day last month helped the eight major department stores and their suburban branches in the New York area to achieve a gain of 7 to 8 per cent over June, 1958. Every store reported an increase.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- Every American is a little heavier and a little taller than yesterday.

Directors of Electric Auto-Lite Company voted yesterday to sell 322,900 shares of Crane Company back to Crane. The decision followed Crane's recent offer to buy 800,000 shares of its outstanding stock at $45 a share.

A program to expand sales to this country of handloomed fabrics made in India was announced yesterday by officials of the Handloom Export Organization of Madras. The program marks the first organized effort to increase sales of these distinctively designed fabrics in the United States and other countries.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- Domestic producers of gold, silver, antimony, chromite, fluorspar and tungsten told Congress today they needed Government help to keep their mines open.
ST. LOUIS, July 1 -- The campaign to get the National Education Association to take a stronger stand on school integration appeared headed for defeat today.
A warrant was issued yesterday for the arrest of Dave Beck after the former president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters had failed to appear in Federal Court here.
HUNTINGTON, W. Va., July 1 (AP) -- Montecatini, a big Italian chemical concern, plans to build its first United States plant near here in the next two years, a company official reported today.
SAN DIEGO, July 1 -- Five savings and loan associations in the San Diego area raised their annual dividend rate today from 4 per cent to 4 1/4 per cent.

Lehman Brothers, Hallgarten Co. and Hemphill, Noyes Co. are offering to the public today 150,000 shares of common stock of Telemeter Magnetics, Inc., computer maker of Los Angeles. The stock is priced at $5.50 a share.
OH, to be a moth at Bergdorf Goodman! According to James N. Feldman of Bergdorf's Fur Department, 7,000 fur coats are stored in this shop annually.
A flurry of wildcat strikes took 30,000 steel workers from their jobs yesterday in defiance of a two-week truce arranged by President Eisenhower.
William A. Shea, chairman of Mayor Wagner's baseball committee, has been offered a legislative club over the major leagues by a Senate antitrust subcommittee and has declined to accept it.
CAIRO, July 1 -- The United States has agreed to resume substantial economic and technical aid to the Government of President Gamal Abdel Nasser.
MONTAUK, L. I., July 1 -- The swordfishing business can be habit-forming.

World sugar prices closed mixed yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. However, a report that the Cuban Sugar Institute would not sell any sugar in the world market as long as private stocks are available touched off a brisk rally in the near positions.

" The Grass Is Greener," the London comedy success by Hugh and Margaret Williams, is to be imported by the Theatre Guild. Associated with the guild in the presentation, a late fall entry depending on the booking situation, will be Anna Deere Wiman, daughter of the late Dwight Deere Wiman, Broadway producer.
Two former officials of the International Jewelry Workers Union were indicted here yesterday on charges of stealing union funds. They were also charged with forging accounts to cover the thefts.

A Matter of Luck Occasionally even the unread and unversed among us are gifted with a turn of speech that a novelist or poet might envy. This rare talent, which is vital to literature (though not to everyday life), is not something that can be borrowed from those unaware of their talent, or acquired merely as a result of the decision to become a writer.

Despite protests that two recent Regents mathematics examinations were too difficult and the passing mark too high, Dr. James E. Allen Jr., State Commissioner of Education, ruled yesterday that no changes would be made.
The Ford Foundation announced yesterday a second round of long-term grants for teacher-training programs. They amount to $6,317,000 and go to ten colleges and universities.
The New York Stock Exchange opened the second half of 1959 yesterday by setting historic highs in The New York Times industrial and combined stock averages and in its industrial bond average.

" Speaker Heck" had become an almost indivisible identity of office and man, so long had the late Oswald D. Heck held the title, for twenty-three years. Now there is a new Speaker, Joseph F. Carlino of Nassau County, elected by the Assembly in the Legislature's special session at Albany yesterday.
PEARL RIVER, N. Y., July 1 -- Plans to mass-produce three-in-one doses of a live oral polio vaccine were announced by the Lederle Laboratories Division of the American Cyanamid Company here today.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 1 -- Israel's Knesset (Parliament) approved today Premier David Ben-Gurion's policy of selling Israeli arms to West Germany. Two parties in the Premier's coalition Government voted against him.

There was a turnabout at the Waterfront Commission headquarters yesterday. The New York-New Jersey agency halted a hearing into alleged wrongdoing by nine dock workers and a Hoboken pier hiring boss until it could look into two rulings handed down by the hearing officer it had assigned to the case.

KAY AMBROSE, who "plumbed" her way into the ballet world twenty years ago, will be wielding monkey wrenches, turning valves and sawing pipes at Abraham Straus today and tomorrow. Yesterday morning, as this tall Irish beauty was selecting the tools for her demonstration in the store's Livingston Street annex, she explained her plumbing avocation.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The complaint that, on the grounds of constitutional privilege, the Executive Department is withholding from Congress and the public information to which they are entitled has been heard ever since the Federal Government was formed.
The seasonal decline in the nation's inventories of gasoline picked up speed last week.
YONKERS, July 1 -- Thalia Hanover, leading from wire to wire, captured the Hudson Filly Trot for 3-year-olds at Yonkers Raceway tonight before a crowd of 22,414.

The nine-story apartment house for forty families at 1608 Ocean Parkway, corner of Avenue P, Brooklyn, has been sold by B. G. Equities, Inc., to a client of Jack Linett, attorney. The buyer resold it to an investor who was represented by Moses Honig.

Stockholders in the Pennsalt Chemical Corporation approved yesterday a three-for-one split of the common stock and an increase in the authorized common to 10,000,000 from 2,000,000 shares. The voting took place at a special meeting in Philadelphia.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 1 -- Officials of the Esso Standard Oil Company, S. A., headed by Scollay Moore, today presented to Dr. Enrique Delgado, Minister of Economy, a proposal for the erection of an $8,000,000 oil refinery at Corinto, the most important port on the west coast of the republic.
AN all-Puccini program at Lewisohn Stadium last night had Licia Albanese, soprano, and Richard Tucker, tenor, as soloists, with Alfredo Antonini conducting the Stadium Symphony Orchestra.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (UPI) Paul M. Butler, Democratic National Chairman, joined the networks today in advocating that radio and television news programs be exempted from the equal time political requirement of the law.

The political crisis in Israel is extraordinary in its cause. Fortune's wheel has certainly taken a turn when Israel sells arms to Germany. It is less than twenty years since the Nazis massacred 6,000,000 Jews.

CAIRO, July 1 -- Dag Hammarskjold was reported today to have proposed that the International Court of Justice decide whether the Danish freighter Inge Toft should be allowed to pass through the Suez Canal.
PARIS, July 1 -- The Constitutional Council gave strong support today to the executive power in France by passing severe judgment on the working rules of the National Assembly and the Senate.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- President Eisenhower said today he would remain neutral in any party contest that might develop for the 1960 Republican Presidential nomination.
The old July cotton future declined 15 points and other months were off 8 points to 1 point up in trading here yesterday. A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.

Models of sputniks, steel mills and electronic computers got a close inspection yesterday from thousands of visitors at the Soviet Exhibition of Science, Technology and Culture in the Coliseum. But it was nothing compared with the inspection that the fashion models got.

HENLEY, England, July 1 -- Harvard University's undefeated lightweight eight, favored to retain the Thames Challenge Cup, won its heat easily at the opening today of the four-day Royal Henley regatta.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- With the grin of an abashed bridegroom, President Eisenhower said today he had no formula for a successful marriage. It was his forty-third wedding anniversary.

ALBANY, July 1 -- Legislation to end George P. Monaghan's one-man control of harness racing in the state was overwhelmingly approved today at a special legislative session. Governor Rockefeller signed it into law tonight.

Clergymen of six denominations have agreed to set up a welcome program for Brooklyn children being sent to schools in the Glendale-Ridgewood area of Queens, the City of New York Commission on Integroup Relations reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) --_A physicist at the University of California won today an eighteen-year fight for payment for an invention that helped United States planes and ships hide from enemy radar in two wars. The device is still in use.
Senator Hubert E. Humphrey called upon the United States yesterday to use its "God-given abundance of food" to further its foreign policy.
PHILADELPHIA, July 1 -- The United States District Court today enjoined the Sun Oil Company from compelling any service station operator to handle Sun Oil products exclusively.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- President Eisenhower said today that United States art selected to be shown abroad should include "what America likes."
Gabriel Genovese, convicted last month of being an unlicensed boxing manager, was sentenced yesterday to two years in jail.
LEWISTON, Me., July 1 -- The Raytheon Company of Waltham, Mass., will start constructing a transistor plant here next fall. The company expects eventually to employ about 2,000 persons.
Mayor Wagner criticized one phase of the work of the Committee on Slum Clearance yesterday and ordered it to alter its policy in another matter.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended June 24:

OSLO, Norway, July 1 (AP) -- United States army marksmen finished one, two, three in the rapid-fire pistol competition of the international military tournament today and lifted the United States team to first place.
WIMBLEDON, England, July 1 -- Top-seeded Alex (The Chief) Olmedo will be in the Wimbledon singles final Friday against Rod (The Rocket) Laver, who wasn't seeded at all.
The label of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union was sewn yesterday for the first time on a blouse manufactured here.
The Republic Pictures Corporation, which has been under attack by several dissident stockholders over management affairs, yesterday announced the election of Victor M. Carter as president.

Slackening or reversal of the build-up of steel inventories in the hands of fabricators and of automobile inventories in the hands of dealers will reduce the over-all rate of inventory growth during the third quarter, the First National City Bank of New York said today.

Alexander J. Clarke, agent for a tenement at 120 West 116th Street, was fined $75 yesterday in Housing Court. He had pleaded guilty to eighty-one violations discovered after a visit to that building by Borough President Hulan E. Jack and Deputy Building Commissioner Harold Birns, and eighteen in another.
BERLIN, July 1 -- Dr. Heinrich Luebke was elected President of West Germany today on the second ballot in a special electoral college.

The New York Legislature's extraordinary session was so brief and businesslike that it inevitably fathered the wish that the regular sessions, beginning each January, were equally efficient. The two subjects specified by Governor Rockefeller in his call, election of an Assembly Speaker and revision of harness racing law, were disposed of in a single day and members were on their way home by sundown.
Taxicab drivers buzzed around the city yesterday like a swarm of angry hornets.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The first cash register was presented to the Smithsonian Institution today by the National Cash Register Company of Dayton, Ohio. It is eighty years old.
The 77-year-old father of Benjamin Cymrot testified yesterday that he had given his son $27,000 in cash between 1954 and 1957 from bundles of money he kept in an old laundry bag.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The State Department said today that it had no intention of seeking a change in the Atomic Energy Law to permit a greater sharing of nuclear weapons secrets with such nations as France.

GENEVA, July 1 -- The United States, British and Soviet delegates marked the first anniversary today of East-West talks here on the banning of nuclear tests by expressing the hope that their negotiations would succeed.

Discussing the record Federal peacetime deficit in the fiscal year just ended -- a deficit that is tentatively placed at between $12.5 billion and $13.0 billion -- it was observed here yesterday that "this should be Exhibit A in the Administration's (and the public's) case" against those who would continue in the present period of powerful recovery the policies of cheap money and Government spending that are appropriate only to periods of recession.

GREENSBORO, N. C., July 1 -- The theatre of Woman's College is sending a special musical production of Clare Boothe Luce's "The Women" on a six-week tour of Pacific bases. The eleven girls and four faculty members will travel 20,000 miles.
ZAPOROZHE, U.S.S.R., June 24 -- Visible from the great Dnieper Dam in this Ukrainian city are landmarks of history.

TRENTON, July 1 -- The Appellate Division of the Superior Court upheld today the Legislature's right to override a conditional veto by the Governor. The constitutionality of such an action had not previously been tested.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan made an unusual appearance as an advocate yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, July 1 (AP) -- "I did it, maw, and I'm sorry, for Sam Jones' sake * * * but I'd call it the same way again."

McPHERSON, Kan., July 1 -- Raymond Hugh Garvey, reported to be the richest man in Kansas, died last night at County Hospital here from injuries suffered in the crash of a truck and a car. He was 66 years old.
A 14-year-old boy admitted last night that he killed a 7-year-old boy earlier in the day in a vacant tenement at 311 East Seventy-fifth Street, the police reported.
ALBANY, July 1 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller cleared the way today for early parole of Nelson Silver Cantalupes, who testified against racketeers Vito Genovese and John Ormento in a narcotics trial.

FALLSBURG, N. Y., July 1 -- The Rabbinical Council of America formulated plans here today for the establishment of an academic center in Israel. The center would serve as "an instrumentality for the building of a cultural and religious bridge between Israel and American Jews."
The first direct view portable television receiver operated by batteries was introduced yesterday by the Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation.

The Mutual Broadcasting System, a company devoted exclusively to operating a national radio network, filed a petition in Federal Court yesterday to arrange a settlement of more than $3,000,000 in debts while continuing in control of its business.

ROME, July 1 (Reuters) -- The Vatican City newspaper L'Osservatore Romano, in a new appeal for racial equality, said today that it had received "insolent" protests from the United States after it published a similar plea two weeks ago.
Plans to put a clock in orbit around the earth were announced here yesterday.

The Half Moon Ball on Sept. 16 will serve as a benefit for the Travelers Aid Society of New York and also will commemorate the 350th anniversary of the voyage up the Hudson River of Henry Hudson's ship, the Half Moon.

Bache Co., brokers, yesterday opened a branch office in Frankfurt, West Germany. Bache previously has had representation in that country through its branch in Geneva which handled security transactions for German investors and through agents in Hamburg, Bremen and Frukfurt who handled commodity transactions.

BERLIN, July 1 -- A public-opinion survey made about a month ago found that about three-fifths of West Germany's adult population had no idea of the identity of the country's Minister of Agriculture, a quiet-spoken, silver-haired man of 64 years named Heinrich Luebke. Th'at situation' has now been corrected.

ALTHOUGH Frank Lloyd Wright is gone, he is still producing houses. Families who order one of his prefabricated homes from Marshall Erdman Associates in Madison, Wis., will find that, from foundations to furnishings, Mr. Wright is still very much in charge.
Benjamin Cymrot moved yesterday for dismissal of the charge that he had failed to explain satisfactorily where he obtained $27,000 in excess of his city salary between 1954 and 1957.

HAMILTON, N. Y., July 2 -- Henry Kearns, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, said here today that support of friendly countries through trade was more important to security in the long run than the stockpiling of hydrogen bombs.

YONKERS, July 2 -- Tomorrow night will belong to the pacers, but tonight at Yonkers Raceway the trotters dominated the scene. True, the trotters worked for half the $50,000 purse in tomorrow night's National Championship Pace, but the race couldn't have been more exciting.
ROME, July 2 (UPI) -- Following are excerpts from the official English text of Pope John XXIII's first encyclical:

Today some sixty Redskin braves impersonating an Algonquin war party, plus three whites impersonating Samuel de Champlain and two French companions who had all started off together on the same date 350 years ago in birchbark canoes on the Richelieu River at St. Jean, Que., are to paddle out from the same place.
GENEVA, July 2 -- Isolationism remains a "potent force" in the United States, Dr. Grayson Kirk, President of Columbia University, said here tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- There were three reasons why Senate Minority Leader Dirksen was able to persuade Majority Leader Johnson and the Senate to put the foreign development loans program on a two-year -- two-billion, instead of a five-year -- five-billion, basis and require that the annual amounts be channeled through the Appropriations Committees of Congress.
A courageous truck driver gambled with death yesterday to avoid injuring others when the brakes on his twenty-ton tractor-trailer failed at the New Jersey entrance to the Lincoln Tunnel.

The United States Government's decision to resume substantial economic and technical aid to the United Arab Republic and therefore to its leader, President Nasser, is doubtless calculated on realistic grounds. It is often necessary in politics or international affairs to get along with dictators and dictatorial governments, although it is a necessity sometimes abused by Washington in recent years.

The Canada General Fund Ltd., has reported gains of 25 per cent in net assets and 23.5 per cent in share value in the twelve months ended May 31. The report placed assets at $98,174,742, equal to $15 a share, compared with $78,312,770, or $12.15 a share, a year before. Three months earlier net assets were $98,933,788, or $15.03 a share.

Mayor Wagner yesterday barred Louis I. Pokrass, former business associate of Frank Costello and other racketeers in a television company, from taking any part in the proposed mid-Harlem slum redevelopment.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Frol R. Kozlov, Soviet First Deputy Premier, proclaimed in Washington today his Government's unyielding stand on the Berlin crisis.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., June 16 -- Another big building wave has hit Minneapolis. The main focus is on putting even more vigor in a healthy downtown. And each stage of construction is being carefully plotted and planned.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- A Congressional delegation returned from Geneva today with the general conclusion that an agreement with the Soviet Union to ban nuclear tests was still not in sight.
Robert T. Battipaglia was unseated last night as Queens Democratic leader.

A State Supreme Court Justice ruled yesterday that the name of the International Longshoremen's Association must be stricken from a complaint alleging that its president, Capt. William V. Bradley, allowed George A. Brenner to cash forged I. L. A. notes in return for 15 per cent of their face value.

PARIS, June 29 -- At the end of my long trip through the Soviet Union, covering about 17,000 miles, I have had two extensive discussions with Premier Nikita S. Khru shchev. He revealed with unmistakable clarity his complete confidence that the Soviet Union can within relatively few years gain supremacy over the United States.

LONDON, July 2 -- Selective buying stimulated a further modest expansion of business on the stock exchange here today. Demand slacked toward the close but it was enough to bring another fairly long list of small gains.

Rochester, N. Y., is planning to borrow $3,967,500 on bond anticipation notes to finance public improvements. The sale will be held Wednesday. All of the notes will come due in one year except $250,000 of sludge disposal building construction obligations, which will come due April 15. The notes will be dated July 15.

The editorial of June 26 contrasting de Gaulle and the British Labor party strikes me as an excellent index of the military metaphysics with which the world is currently afflicted. The former is praised for pressing for entrance into the "nuclear club," while Hugh Gaitskell and his colleagues are condemned for wanting out, leaving a Soviet and American monopoly.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 2 -- The California Department of the American Legion is compiling a list of names to substantiate its charge that "Communists and fellow travelers" are "re-infiltrating" the movie industry.
NEWPORT, R. I., July 2 -- The annual Newport Jazz Festival opened a four-day program tonight in an unaccustomed atmosphere of serenity.

Ethel D. Jacobs' Hope is Eternal won the mile race for 3-year-old fillies that topped the Belmont Park program yesterday. The gray daughter of Turn-to was the favorite by a narrow margin over the Brae Burn Farm's Shirley Jones in a field of seven and she raced to the wire a length and a half in front.
HAVANA, July 2 -- Counter-revolutionary activities against Premier Fidel Castro's revolutionary Government are reported to be increasing throughout Cuba.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI) -- James R. Hoffa, Teamsters Union president, charged today that Senator John F. Kennedy was "afraid" to debate labor-reform legislation with him on a national radio or television hook-up.

MOSCOW, July 2 -- The advance guard of the biggest group of Soviet dancers and musicians yet to invade the United States left here today in a chartered plane for New York. The rest of the company of about 200, including fifteen from the Moiseyev troupe, is expected to leave tomorrow if all get their visas in time.
GOTEBORG, Sweden, July 2 (AP) -- United States track and field stars won four events at Ullevi Stadium tonight as the. International July Games opened.
WIMBLEDON, England, July 2 -- It will be Darlene Hard of North America against Maria Bueno of South America in the final of the women's Wimbledon singles on Saturday.
A woman with a shy smile and a bundle of picture books approached youngsters in Washington Square Park yesterday afternoon with the invitation:

The downward drift of prices in the market for United States Government securities continued yesterday, but firmness and strength prevailed in over-the-counter trading in high-grade corporate bonds and in the obligations of local government.

Playing separate but undoubtedly coordinated roles, Premier Khrushchev and Deputy Premier Kozlov are obviously utilizing the interim period before the reopening of the Geneva conference of foreign ministers to launch another attempt both to frighten and to cajole the West into capitulating to the Soviet "peace" terms.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 2 to 8 points (10 to 40 cents a bale) yesterday.
SPRINGFIELD, Mo., July 2 (AP) -- Four prominent Tulsa men were killed today in the crash of a twin-engine plane. An 11-year-old boy was critically injured.
The city will save $58,000 a year by eliminating thirteen chauffeurs through Mayor Wagner's order discontinuing the use of limousines by seventeen city officials.

Governor Rockefeller had his first meeting yesterday with the Advisory Commission on Atomic Energy that he named last month to advise the state's new Office of Atomic Development. The group met with the Governor for lunch at the St. Regis Hotel, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.

FALLSBURG, N. Y., July 2 -- Spiritual leaders of all faiths in the United States were urged today to stage a conference protesting the "recent renewal of Soviet assaults and oppressions" against Jewish citizens in that nation.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission today announced this recommendation by hearing examiners:

LEVITTOWN, L. I., July 2 -- School officials here have modified their system of assigning pupils to classes on the basis of ability. A study has convinced them that diversity among pupils is necessary to promote learning.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, July 2 -- Dominican warplanes and Navy ships are reported guarding the coasts of Haiti as part of an unpublicized joint defense effort against any attempt at invasion from abroad.

The one-story brick taxpayer building at 2262-68 Grand Concourse, near 183d Street, the Bronx, has been purchased by Harry Horowitz for cash over mortgages amounting to $167,643. It is 125 by 80 feet and has six tenants, including the Vic Tanny chain of health shops.

A Wall Street banker was arrested early yesterday after leading the police on an automobile chase from midtown to 116th Street and the Franklin D. Roosevelt (East River) Drive. He is John Davison, 28 years old, of Peacock Point, Locust Valley, L. I.
Undaunted by the approaching three-day week-end, stocks pushed vigorously ahead yesterday and established new historic highs for both The New York Times combined and industrial stock averages.
The recent lack of spectacular achievements in the race for space is misleading; intensive effort to plumb the mysteries of the skies is continuing in both Russia and the United States.
Robert Moses complained yesterday in a letter to The New York Times about the publication of "some very misleading statements" in articles dealing with Title I housing projects.
NEW ORLEANS, July 2 -- Gov. Earl K. Long arrived here tonight from his motel retreat near Covington, La. He immediately underwent an examination by a heart specialist.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -"Cash"-type savings increased in the first quarter of this year by less than in any quarter of 1958, the Home Loan Bank Board reported today.

PITTSBURGH, July 2 (UPI) -- Dick Groat singled with the bases loaded and none out in the tenth inning tonight and the Pittsburgh Pirates gained a 4-3 victory over the Mfiwau-I kee Braves, who committed four costly errors.

THE only sentimentalist left in baseball, it once seemed, was Horace Stoneham of the Giants. But the announcements of squad personnel for the All-Star game at Pittsburgh on Tuesday reveal that the sport has a couple of other soft-hearted romanticists who are not adverse to yielding to emotion.

CHICAGO, July 2 -- Marshall Field Jr., president of Field Enterprises, Inc., announced today that The Chicago Daily News would be merged with The Chicago Sun-Times. He described the merger as a "legal step" and said operation's of the two newspapers would be unaffected by the "technical change."

ONE recent afternoon, Elmer Haines glanced at the skies over New Lisbon, N. J. They were heavy with threatening clouds. The blueberry producer looked at the plump, ripe beries on the bushes on his forty-five-acre farm.

The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations was confronted with a major embarassment yesterday. It will have to decide whether to expel a 325,000-member union because the group gave 525 Long Island workers an opportunity to quit another federation union.

The directors of the Railway Express Agency, Inc., voted unanimously yesterday to try to save it through a three-and-ahalf year reorganization project, but the director representing the largest stockholder made it clear that his ballot was subject to second thoughts.
HENLEY, England, July 2 -All the United States entrants but one advanced today in their contests for the climax of the Royal Henley Regatta on Saturday.

The committee that selected the American art to be shown at the Moscow fair commended President Eisenhower yesterday for his refusal to withdraw any of the works. It sent an open telegram to the President.
HONG KONG, July 2 -- A Chinese Communist program to train financial aides for commune management was announced in reports that reached here today.
THE CURRAGH, County Kildare, Ireland, June 29 -- "Breeding tells, and the green grass of Ireland" is the slogan in this green-as-green center of Irish thoroughbred racing.

Men's hats will cost more in the fall. The Hat Corporation of America posted another suggested increase yesterday on its Knox and Dobbs lines of felt hats for men, and other manufacturers, whose lines also were advanced at the March openings of fall lines, are expected to reprice their retail lists similarly.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- Illness of a juror halted proggress today toward a verdict in the conspiracy trial of Richard A. Mack and Thurman A. Whiteside.

The combination of John Patrick (author) and Robert Lewis (director) that figured so prominently in the success of "The Teahouse of the August Moon" is getting together again. In their respective stints, both will be involved with "Juniper and the Pagans." derived from James Norman's novel, "Father Juniper and the General," published by William Morrow Co.

The Mergenthaler Linotype Company yesterday reported a net income of $2,175,000 for the thirty-six weeks ended on June 7 on net sales of $17,115,000. For the thirty-nine weeks to June 30, 1958, the company cleared only $420,000 on a larger volume of $21,329,000.
WHEN is the right time to begin wearing cottons in the spring and is it a firm rule that only wools are suitable after Labor Day?

In remaining at the Dominican Foreign Minister's press conference and allowing himself to be photographed shaking hands with the Dominican Army pilot, Ventura Simo, the United States Ambassador to the Dominican Republic, Joseph Farland, was evidently not adding two and two to make four.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities pursued today its fight to force withdrawal of at least a part of the exhibit.
Abe Burrows, the author, play director and raconteur who specializes in comedy, will serve as dialogue director for the series of television variety shows to be sponsored next season by Revlon, Inc.

Dave Beck pleaded not guilty in Federal Court yesterday to a charge of having accepted a $200,000 loan from two trucking executives in violation of the Taft-Hartley Act. At the time in question, 1954, Beck was head of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

IN "Rendezvous With Destiny," the Bancroft History Prize book of several years ago that is now in a paperback, Prof. Eric Goldman of Princeton showed how the New and Fair Deals fit into the framework of liberal reform in this country from Reconstruction to the first half of the twentieth century.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Frol R. Kozlov chuckled heartily here this evening as he told Vice President Richard M. Nixon how he had put one over his American escort on a sightseeing tour this afternoon.
DETROIT, July 2 (AP) -United States automobile manufacturers turned out 3,284,037 passenger cars in this year's first half, indicating the possibility of an output of 6,500,000 cars in 1959.
A NEW show called "Who Pays ?" shuffled onto Channel 4 last night.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- The United States today agreed to make $500,000 available to the Philippines for a nuclear research reactor.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -Rail loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 697,633 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
ROME, July 2 -- Pope John XXIII, in his first encyclical, appealed today to the world's statesmen to "try every approach" that might lead to international unity and peace.

Average member bank borrowings increased $45,000,000 to $921,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Excess reserves on the average declined $130,000,000 to $369,000,000.

VIENNA, July 2 -- Twenty-five internationally-known scientists from the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and other countries have been holding a private conference near Vienna since June 25 on nuclear armament controls and world security.

Peace efforts in the seventeen-day warehousemen's strike against the A. P. food-store chain were broken off indefinitely yesterday after Federal mediators had brought both sides together for the first time in ten days.

In an editorial of June 24 entitled "Relocation Last Year" The New York Times summarizes the recently issued City Planning Commission analysis of statistics on families relocated in New York City during 1958, and points out the "need for great-care" in handling the families to be relocated.

Twentieth Century-Fox has acquired screen rights to the play "Goodbye, Charlie" in a pre-production deal with authordirector, George Axelrod. It is understood that the film company has paid $150,000 down, plus a percentage of the picture's profits, which could bring the price to a maximum of $400,000.
LONDON, July 2 (AP) -- Army experts flirted with death for ten hours today to take most of the blast out of a booby-trapped bomb dropped by the Germans in World War II.

Negotiations to avert a national steel strike were torpedoed again yesterday by wild-cat walkouts. Union leaders succeeded in ending three major tie-ups, but a fourth persisted in the face of union back-to-work orders and a court injunction.

Sales of the Hamilton Watch Company are 35 per cent higher than they were a year ago despite a "chaotic United States watch market," according to Arthur B. Sinkler, president of the Lancaster (Pa.) company.
DETROIT, July 2 -- General Motors called upon an expert yesterday to rebut competitive propaganda that its new rear- engine compact car, the Corvair, was hard to steer and unsafe on turns.

OTTAWA, July 2 -- The Canadian Government announced today that its eight fighter squadrons in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization would be re-equipped with an interceptor plane of United States manufacture that has a speed of 1,400 miles an hour and is designed for low-altitude strike reconnaissance.
A dispute between ten New York newspapers and their union printers over a new contract was referred yesterday to the International Typographical Union at Indianapolis.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., July 2 (AP) -- The Hoboken Housing Authority today was upheld in awarding a 208-unit housing construction project to a second lowest bidder. The authority had argued that the lowest bidder lacked "moral integrity."
PARIS, July 2 (Reuters) -Two French airlines are planning round-the-world passenger service if they win hoped-for approval from the United States, airline sources reported today.

LONDON, July 2 -- The Cuban Ambassador said here today he had discovered that the Dominican Republic has a vast network of agents in Europe, North Africa and the Middle East who are buying arms and recruiting mercenary soldiers on a "fantastic scale."

Local, state and national law-enforcement officials met for more than two hours yesterday with Governor Rockefeller to plan a coordinated front against crime. The conferees discussed in general terms strengthening cooperation between the various agencies of government by exchanging information on such matters as narcotics and other criminal problems.

The owner of a tenement house branded as one of the two "most sordid" visited on a recent crash inspection tour of the West Side pleaded guilty in Housing Court yesterday to eighty-four violations of the Multiple Dwelling Law.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The State Department said today that United States officials were not worried about Nikita S. Khrushchev's threats, whether public or private.

TRIVANDRUM, India, July 2 (Reuters) -- The Police of Communist-ruled Kerala state were reported to have injured nineteen persons in club-swinging charges today. An Opposition leader accused the police of "brutal repression."
Dr. Charles Malik, president of the United Nations General Assembly, said yesterday that the United Nations "cannot achieve miracles," and was not designed to "solve all the problems of the world."

MUIRFIELD, Scotland, July 2 (UPI) -- Fred Bullock of England, playing casually through rain with his 15-year-old daughter as his caddie, took a two-stroke lead in the second round of the British open golf championship today with 34,36 -- 70 for a total of 138.
LONDON, July 2 -- The sterling area's reserves of gold and convertible currencies rose by 19,000,000 ($53,200,000) last month, the Treasury announced today.
Governor Rockefeller met privately yesterday with a group of twenty-six bankers to enlist their support for his middle-in-come housing program.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Joseph L. Rauh Jr., vice chairman of Americans for Democratic Action, urged Congress today to enact a "code of fair procedures" for all security cases.
CAIRO, July 2 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser called upon Egyptians and Syrians today to make their own great leap forward.

The taxpayer containing eight stores at 84-42 to 84-54 Eliot Avenue, corner of Eighty-fifth Street, in Rego Park, Queens, has been sold by an estate represented by Samuel Kolatch, lawyer. The deal was for cash over a first mortgage held by the Roosevelt Savings Bank.
BALTIMORE, July 2 -- The weather in this torrid town cooled off perceptibly tonight and so did the Yankees.
CHICAGO, July 2 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board chose today to lose a lawsuit to a union rather than answer questions the board considered confidential.

Combined net operating earnings of the First National City Bank of New York and the First National City Trust Company for the six months ended June 30 were $31,667,000, or $2.64 a share, compared with $29,835,000, or $2.49 a share, in the 1958 period.
Louis (Satchmo) Armstrong, gravely stricken with pneumonia in Italy a week ago, returned to New York last night exuberantly discussing plans for future tours with his famous trumpet.

The nation began the Fourth of July holiday week-end yesterday, but the "fair and warm" predicted here for tomorrow may turn to scattered showers Sunday. Fair to partly cloudy weather was indicated for much of the country.
Visitors who can't see the trees for the forests in the American Museum of Natural History are now able to use a new exhibition as a guide.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 2 (AP) -- A Snark intercontinental guided missile successfully completed its third 2,000-mile round-trip flight over the Atlantic Ocean today.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI) -- Senator Leverett Saltonstall, Republican of Massachusetts, challenged Democratic critics of United States defense policy today to tell how they would finance their proposals for a big increase in military spending.
ST. LOUIS, July 2 -- President Eisenhower has urged the country's teachers "to play a more active role in the political life of our country."
LONDON, July 2 (AP) -The International Rubber Study Group said today that world rubber stocks at the beginning of May were 70,000 tons less than at the start of 1959.
A contract for automatic entrances at all public parking fields at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, was awarded by the Port of New York Authority yesterday.
Most executives of business organizations in the city feel that the recession is definitely over, that trade has been rising in the first half of 1959 and will continue to gain in the second half.

MARION, Ohio, July 2 (AP) -- Authorities confirmed late today that ten persons were killed yesterday in the crash of a Continental Can Company airliner near here. Tomorrow Civil Aeronautics Board engineers will check the widely scattered wreckage to try to determine the cause of the accident.
LONDON, July 2 (Reuters) -- Britain has rejected Communist China's accusation that the United States and Laos had violated the 1954 Indochina truce, a Foreign Office spokesman said today.
CAIRO, July 2 -- Dag Hammarskjold appeared tonight to have failed to find a way to resolve the dispute over Israeli shipping in the Suez Canal.

The building containing 127 apartments at 900 West End Avenue, northeast corner of 104th Street, has been purchased by Abraham Uzell from a client of Fred Weitzner, attorney. The property is assessed at $850,000, of which $160,000 is land value.

Loans to business by the larger New York City banks increased $58,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with an increase of $14,000,000 in the same week last year.

PARIS, July 2 -- President Charles de Gaulle flew to Madagascar today to preside over the fourth session of the Executive Committee of the French Community. He will also visit the Comores and Reunion Islands.

PHILADELPHIA, July 2 -- The State Supreme Court today outlawed provisions of the Pennsylvania Penal Code that prohibit exhibitions of a "lascivious, sacrilegious, obscene, indecent or immoral nature."
LOS ANGELES, July 2 (AP) -- The Salle Santelli team of New York retained its saber title at the national fencing championships last night.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Capt. James W. La Belle, master of the luxury liner Constitution, has filed an appeal from the one-year suspension of his ship master's license and all other Coast Guard maritime documents.

Herbert Hoover said yesterday that Soviet Government authorities had promised undying friendship in return for the free famine aid given by the United states in 1921-23, but "they have been trying to forget our help ever since."

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Speaker Sam Rayburn, in a rare outburst of anger, today accused President Eisenhower and Republican leaders of trying to mislead the people by pinning a "spender" label on the Democratic-controlled Congress.
