Pleasure boating no longer needs a body of water as large as an ocean. This has become a small-craft participation sport. The huge trans-Atlantic super yachts, 300 feet long with crews of forty or fifty hands, have just about disappeared.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, July 2 -- Continued political instability seems inevitable in Ceylon regardless of whether Parliament votes next week to confirm in office or dismiss the Government of S. W. R. D. Bandaranaike.

The Wagner Administration announced a plan yesterday to keep families with children from living in single rooms in rooming houses. The goal is eventual elimination of the practice, which is known to be widespread.

" Summer of the Twelves," by Carleton Mitchell, a pictorial and textual account of the defense of the America's Cup, will be published July 15 by Scribner. The author gives details of the four American defenders, Vim, Columbia, Weatherly and Easterner, and of the challenger from England, the Sceptre, describes crew selection and training, sails and gear and their handling.

MOSCOW, July 2 -- Moscow newspapers assailed today an article by Max Frankel on the opening of the Soviet Exhibition in the New York Coliseum that appeared in The New York Times Tuesday. Mr. Frankel, a Times correspondent stationed in Moscow, is on leave in New York.
CHICAGO, July 2 (AP) -- Grain futures prices rallied fairly sharply for a while today on a bullish private crop report but the best gains failed to hold after profit-taking came into the pits.
Following are sketches of the eight executives and two pilots of the Continental Can Company who died in the plane crash near Marion, Ohio.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 2 (AP) -- Three director - trustees of the Seymour Manufacturing Company, long embroiled in a struggle for control of that concern, got it yesterday. They paid $763,049 for a controlling interest.

" The cultural and recreational programs of the City of New York are varied and of high quality. Its libraries and museums, many of which are pre-eminent in their fields, play a significant role in the culture and educational life of the city's citizens and visitors. * * * Our interest is not restricted to repairs, maintenance and protection.

NORWALK, Conn., July 2 -- The Board of Estimate and Taxation declined to appropriate $10,000 last night for restoration of two of the city's landmarks. It was a last-minute effort to trim a large city budget.
A group of twenty tenants of 930 Fifth Avenue failed in an effort yesterday to keep the owners of the apartment house from turning it into a cooperative.
An indicated increase of 40 per cent in the number of fires in the city this year is "shameful and disgraceful," Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. declared yesterday.
NEW HOLLAND, Pa., July 2 (AP) -- The New Holland Machine Farm Equipment division of Sperry Rand Corporation said today it is buying the Farmway Company of Manawa, Wis.

CENTER-STAGE is an unusual place for Thomas Joseph Shanahan. Mr. Shanahan is a quiet, graying banker with well-placed connections in labor, management and politics. Generally regarded as the Democratic party's No. 1 fund raiser in New York, he has usually operated behind the scenes.
Rebellious dockworkers marred the opening yesterday of a new steamship line -- the Cuba, Mexico and West Indies Steamship Company.
A holiday mood prevailed on most New York commodity exchanges yesterday and trading was listless.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, July 2 -- The Dominican armed forces have been buying equipment in Europe for some time. These purchases have increased since tensions began rising in the Caribbean this year.
WILMINGTON, Del., July 2 (AP) -- A stockholder of Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., has filed suit charging fourteen present or former officers with enriching themselves at the expense of the company.

The Immigration and Naturalization Service is pondering what to do with more than a thousand Italian seamen aboard three strikebound Italian-flag ships if the strike that is now in its twenty-fifth day goes beyond the twenty-nine-day stay permitted to foreign seamen in American ports.
BEAUFORT, S. C., July 2 -- A Georgia-born marine, convicted by a jury of Southern white men, was sentenced today to die in the electric chair for raping a 47-year-old Negro woman.
CHICAGO, July 2 (UPI) -- The fleet sailed into the inland port of Chicago today in the Navy's first show of might on the Great Lakes since the War of 1812.
ATLANTIC CITY, July 2 -- This was an unhappy day for Addison J. McKee, an insurance man, who has been fishing local waters for fifty years.

SOME of the pleasures and hazards of outdoor music were available to the audience of 7,000 persons gathered at Lewisohn Stadium last night to hear an all-Tchaikovsky program directed by Thomas Scherman with Michael Rabin as violin soloist.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- A constitutional amendment was proposed in the Senate today to counter the Supreme Court decision striking down New York State's ban on the movie "Lady Chatterley's Lover."

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The Organization of American States tonight delayed until Monday its decision whether to act in response to the Dominican Republic's charge that it faces an invasion organized by Cuba and Venezuela.
LONDON, July 2 (Reuters) -- Labor Minister Iain Macleod and top union officials met tonight in a bid to stave off a threatened closing of most big British national newspapers, starting Monday.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 2 -- Prince Albert, heir presumptive to the Belgian throne, and Princess Paola Ruffo di Calabria of Italy were married here today. Burgomaster Lucien Cooremans performed the civil wedding first in the glittering Empire Salon of the Brussels Palace.

WHITE PLAINS, July 2 -- Channel lines, drawn to preserve the free flow of water in the Yonkers section of the Saw Mill River, were announced today by George J. Natt, director of the Westchester County Water Agency.

Thirty thousand shares of X -- or the United States Steel Corporation -- changed hands yesterday, to make that stock one of the fifteen most active on the New York Stock Exchange. Moreover, the stock hit a record of 103 7/8 during the day and closed at 103 5/8, up 2 3/8 points.

The Tennessee Gas Transmission Company plans to sell publicly $50,000,000 of twenty-year first mortgage pipeline bonds, according to a registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The tentative offering date is July 21.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- At sunrise Saturday, 5:47 A. M., a new forty-nine-star flag will be raised over the White House.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- A bipartisan Senate coalition gave President Eisenhower another budget victory today. It smashed a move by the Democratic leadership to guarantee the Development Loan Fund five years of continuing financing.

Twelve Japanese securities officials visited the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. They found conditions similar to those back home, including a continuing "age soba," or bull market, strong interest in "yurio kabu," or blue chip stocks, and rapidly rising interest in mutual funds.
RABAT, Morocco, July 2 -- Morocco's economic relations with France have been strained by a French measure cutting off Morocco's foreign currency supply.
LONDON, July 2 (Reuters) -- Newcomers to England's test cricket team sparked the squad into a strong position in the first day of the third five-day match against India today.
MOSCOW, July 2 (AP) -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev called this week for stricter controls by the Communist party to keep writers in line.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., July 2 -- Hudson Valley public health engineers and civil defense executives attended a program here today to acquaint them with Federal stockpile equipment that would be available if local water supplies were cut off during an atomic bomb raid.
STRATFORD, Ont., July 2 (AP) -- Queen Elizabeth II, in diamonds and ermine, was caught in the spotlight tonight at the Stratford Shakespearian Festival.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- A fire in a top-secret underground area of the Pentagon today damaged or destroyed computing equipment valued at $30,000,000 and burned classified Air Force statisti cal records.

DETROIT, July 3 (AP) -Mayor Louis J. Miriani said today he would not give official recognition to Frol R. Kozlov when the Soviet Deputy Premier arrived in Detroit Monday despite a special plea from Secretary of State Christian Herter.
MINEOLA, L. I., July 3 -- The apartment house is becoming a familiar neighbor to ranch homes and split-levels in suburban Nassau County.
WASHINGTON, July 3 (UPI) -- House investigators disclosed today that they would broaden their inquiry into possible influence in defense contracts to include the so-called "munitions lobby."

BOSTON, July 3 (UPI) -- Mike Higgins, the American League manager of the year in 1955, was dismissed today as manager of the Boston Red Sox. Washington Senator coach, Billy Jurges, was named to replace him.

FISHERS ISLAND, N. Y., July 3 -- The Fishers Island Country Club was decorated in red, white and blue for the debut party tonight of Miss Emily Starr Ridgway, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Ridgway of Short Hills, N. J., and Fishers Island.

What was it that moved Jefferson and Franklin, Washington and Hancock?
WASHINGTON, July 3 (UPI) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that its losses on surplus farm crops dropped in the last year because sales fell off.

The Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation has announced two new orders for F-27 turbo-propeller airplanes of the business type. Twenty-two of these aircraft have now been purchased by business concerns. F-27's are serving eleven airlines in addition to thirteen corporations.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 3 -- The Board of Education today proposed the highest school budget in the town's history. The requests totaled $7,470,838.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 3 (Reuters) -- The Yugoslav Government has broken off negotiations in Prague on unfulfilled Czechoslovak credits to Yugoslavia and has recalled its delegation, it was announced here today.
PHILADELPHIA, July 3 -- Dry cargo handling in the Port of Philadelphia was stopped today by a dispute over whether wooden pallets or cargo nets should be used to unload a cargo of sugar.

The yacht Great Dane arrived at the Seventy-ninth Street Yacht Basin yesterday afternoon with her crew of three people and one friendly Great Dane, one friendly macaw and one unfriendly feline said to be a wildcat that looked like just a wild cat.

YONKERS, July 3 -- Speedy Pick, clocked in 1:59 4/5 for the mile, won the first National Championship Pace before 32,444 at Yonkers Raceway tonight. The 13-20 choice clearly proved his superiority over the other five pacers in the $50,000 race, the richest of the harness campaign so far.

Major debt financing in the public capital market will total about $60,000,000 next week. The backlog of corporate bonds and preferred stocks rose significantly last week, approaching the billion-dollar mark.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -The United States will attempt this month to launch its biggest, most complex scientific satellite thus far. It will be a 91.5pound vehicle designed to perform a multitude of experiments in space.

BUCHANAN, N. Y., July 3 -- Rapid progress was reported today on the construction of the Consolidated Edison Company's $100,000,000 atomic power plant atop a rocky bluff on the east bank of the Hudson River.
CHICAGO, July 3 -- The film "Anatomy of a Murder" failed to open a run here yesterday because of a censorship ruling and a lawyer representing the director has filed suit to have the ban lifted.
NEWPORT, R. I., July 3 -- A pair of big bands, a type of jazz group that has become almost obsolete in the last decade, helped to breathe life into the Newport Jazz Festival during its second day.

OSWEGO, N. Y., July 3 -- A new judicial test of the state's controversial Condon - Wadlin Law, providing for automatic dismissal of public employes who go on strike, was in sight today.

ACCRA, Ghana, June 30 -- A debating contest was held recently in the main hall of Ghana's sprawling new University College here. The faculty and student body attended and there were many listeners from the city.

HENLEY, England, July 3 -- With close, hard-fought victories over tough British competition, two Harvard eight-oared crews moved within grabbing distance today of the major prizes offered at the Henley Royal Regatta.

On the morning of Independence Day a year ago, the Yankees led the American League by ten and a half games. It took a 4-3 victory over the Senators last night to get them to this 1959 milestone in the first division -- in fourth place, three games off the pace.

One of the most exclusive schools in the world, the Webb Institute of Naval Architecture, held its sixty-third commencement yesterday.

TEL AVIV, July 3 -- Israeli officials today weighed more forceful steps to obtain the passage of Israeli cargoes through the Suez Canal if Dag Hammarskjold's intervention in Cairo fails to produce a solution.

LIME ROCK, Conn., July 3 -Glen Lazar, a 41-year-old driver from Riderwood, Md., was fatally injured here today while practicing for tomorrow's national sports car races.

CHICAGO, July 3 (AP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation has disclosed the indictment of five men charged with the manipulation of more than $8,500,000 in stolen Canadian bonds.
AKRON, Ohio, July 3 (UPI) -- The United States Rubber Workers Union put the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and the Midwest Rubber Reclaiming Company on notice today to reopen contracts.
LENOX, Mass., July 3 -The twenty-second Berkshire Festival opened at Tanglewood tonight. Following a tradition established during World War II, it began with Bach.

Antonino Rocca of Argentina and Miguel Perez of Puerto Rico survived foul play by Jerry and Eddie Graham of Hollywood, Calif., to win an Australian tag-team wrestling match at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island last night. Approximately 5,000 fans were present.

KANSAS CITY, July 3 (AP) -- Herb Score of the Cleveland Indians yielded a grand-slam homer to Bob Cerv in the first inning today, but went on and struck out fourteen batters in defeating the Kansas City Athletics, 8 -- 4.
State and municipal long-term financing totaled $4,525,433,204 in the first half of 1959, or about 2 per cent more than the $4,434,390,988 of the 1958 period.
The Air Line Pilots Association has attacked the Federal Aviation Agency for recent proposals to ground airline pilots at the age of 60 and forbid their learning to fly jets after 55.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 3 -- Tuna pulled a disappearing act today. Nobody knows where they went but there were lots of opinions. One fishing captain said that the recent storms had sent them into seclusion on the bottom.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 3 -- Frol R. Kozlov arrived in California today and said that "we'll even support the Pope if he's for peace."
WASHINGTON, Saturday, July 4 -- "State the facts of freedom and trust in God" is President Eisenhower's Fourth of July message to Americans overseas.

The Republic Insurance Company, which has its main office in Dallas, has purchased the lease on the property at 98 to 102 Nassau Street. The property is a four-and-a-half-story business building occupying the blackfront from Fulton to Ann Streets. The company will use it for its Eastern headquarters.
The case of the Waterfront Commission against nine dock workers and a Hoboken pier hiring boss was delayed further yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- Acting Gov. John William Chapman of Illinois was piped aboard the Navy flagship Willis A. Lee and also was given a nineteen-gun salute today. It was the first performance of these traditional honors on the Great Lakes in modern times.

HAVANA, July 3 -- United States ranchers who bought land and established big ranches in Cuba many years ago will be forced to cease operations under the Agrarian Reform Law, which expropriates all of their land in excess of 3,330 acres.

HAMILTON, N. Y., July 3 -Senator Kenneth B. Keating of New York said here today that the Communist "cold war" offensive had reached a higher intensity than ever before with "the failure thus far of the foreign ministers conference at Geneva to make any notable progress."

CHICAGO, July 3 -- Chicago opened its sixteen-day Internation Trade Fair today to celebrate the emergence of this city as an "ocean port" and to encourage the importation of foreign goods into the Middle West.
NEWARK, July 3 -- Cecil Rhodes Jr., a lawyer and boxing promoter, was ordered today to pay $48,750 for a champion trotting horse he contended had been sold to him under false pretenses.
VERSAILLES, France, July 3 (UPI) -- Thirty-three American debutantes danced with French military cadets and other escorts tonight at the glittering second annual Versailles Palace Ball.

BOMBAY, India, July 3 -- The police fired into a crowd, killing two persons and injuring five, in a new flare-up of violence today in the Communist-run state of Kerala. Several persons were also injured when policemen wielding heavy sticks charged into groups of demonstrators.

The retirement of Dr. Leo W. Tucker, medical officer at the Quarantine Station in New York Harbor, was announced yesterday. He has served for forty years in the United States Public Health Service and has directed the affairs of ship and air quarantine here since 1952.

Commissioner Cavanagh's release of fire statistics for the first four months of this year comes as an unpleasant surprise to the public, grown accustomed to better news from him. The number of fires in the city has been substantially reduced over the past five years. This has been due largely to the Commissioner's mobilization of the city's firemen to prevent, as well as to extinguish, fires.

DETROIT, July 3 (AP) -Auto makers will begin to phase out their 1959 models several days after the present July 15 steel industry contract deadline. They plan to build the last car of the model year by Aug. 26, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., July 4 -- There was a new kind of Fourth of July celebration in Scarsdale There were no conventional rockets or Roman candles, for Scarsdale was celebrating under the slogan, "Independence -- Everybody's declaring it -- Scarsdale is sharing it!"
BOSTON, July 4 -- Edward Dana will retire next Saturday as general manager of the Metropolitan Transit Authority, the trustees announced today.
MUNICH, Germany, July 4 (AP) -- Americans dominated an international track meet tonight, winning four events and finishing second in two others.

My teen-age companion and I agreed after reading and rereading the portion of your article referring to Edward Byrnes that all adults hold a grudge against popular rock 'n' roll singers. Although "Kookie" cannot sing as well as other pop singers mentioned, we believe he is the most promising movie and television star in the entertainment field. His pleasing jive talk thrills us, and was adopted by our whole neighborhood.
A sharp improvement in the city's pedestrian safety record was indicated last week as Pedestrian Safety Education Month reached the half-way mark.
Dorothy Barclay in her article "The Private Life of a Small Boy" (June 21) mentions seven labors of Hercules. But there were twelve.

DURING the current month Henry Morgan will be among the few live attractions on local television. According to present plans. his program, shown on Fridays at 8 P. M. over WNTA (Channel 13) will be live during July.
OTTAWA, July 4 -- Canadian taxpayers learned this week that they had been paying heavily for listening to commercials on sponsored television shows.
BALTIMORE, July 4 (UPI) -- The Baltimore Orioles, led by Walt Dropo, exploded four homers among thirteen hits and sent the Boston Red Sox to their seventh straight loss, 11 -- 5, today.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 4 -- Frol R. Kozlov gamboled today among the capitalists in this city's equivalent of Scarsdale.

An authoritative voice in the steel industry has warned the major steel companies that they may be inviting "labor troubles galore" by the vigor of their effort to recapture the initiative in collective bargaining.

A THREE-WEEK production workshop project involving the making of an experimental film by Maya Deren, frequent prize winner in film festivals, will start tomorrow with lecture discussions at her studio, 35 Morton Street.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 4 -- Riverside Yacht Club's twenty-eighth Stratford Shoal race, an overnighter for cruising yachts, started off Flat Neck Point tonight. There were thirty-eight starters from an entry list of forty-four for the sixty-nautical-mile passage to Middle Ground Light and return.

SINGAPORE'S recent election gives an exceptional timeliness to Robert S. Elegant's detailed study of the place and problem of the overseas Chinese. Singapore is the point of their most conspicuous and most effective concentration.
JENNINGS, La., July 4 (UPI) -- Gov. Earl K. Long's automobile struck a truck in a rainstorm today. A state official and Mr. Long's lawyer were injured.

The Cunard Steam-Ship Company, Ltd., is now in its 120th year of trans-Atlantic operations. Yesterday the company marked the maiden voyage in 1840 of the tiny wooden paddle steamer Britannia from Liverpool.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 4 -- This week's decision by the state's Supreme Court of Errors upholding four-acre zoning regulations in New Canaan met with a mixed reaction throughout Fairfield County.

TULLY, County Kildare, Ireland, June 29 -- As time goes in the Irish Republic, there is only a slight difference of three-quarters of a century between 77-year-old Eamon De Valera, newly elected President, and the 2-year-old colts and fillies he will race under lease from the Irish National Stud here.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., July 4 (AP) -- Glen (Fireball) Roberts drove the fastest stock car race ever run when he captured the National Association for Stock Car Racing Firecracker 250 today.

Your article on the talentless crooners in pop music merely pointed out that the doctoring of voices is still in a primitive stage. Undoubtedly, some bright huckster will rectify this (as well as his protege's) shortcoming soon by making full use of the in exorable trend toward automation.
PHILADELPHIA, July 4 -- The nation's original forty-nine-star flag was raised amid the roll of drums at Independence Hall today.

RONKONKOMA, L. I. -- Starting tomorrow many Long Island air travelers can eliminate one of their most frustrating aggravations by turning to the modernistic terminal building here at MacArthur Airport.

PITTSBURGH, July 4 (AP) -- The twenty-sixth All-Star baseball game will be played Tuesday at Pittsburgh with Stan Musial and Ted Williams sitting on the bench, waiting for pinch-hitting duty.

ST. LOUIS, July 4 -- For the last four years the delegates to the annual meetings of the National Education Association have adopted substantially the same resolution on integration in the public schools.
The eleven out-of-town Federal judges alternating in Brooklyn since April 13 disposed of 675 out of 1,038 cases assigned to them from the court's congested calendar.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 24 -- High in the Anatolian plateau, forty-four miles from Ankara, Baghdad Pact scientists are using atomic-age methods to search for the solution to a crop menace that has plagued the Middle East for centuries.
Buses soon to be used within New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, will announce stops in four languages.

The Fourth of July has seldom been observed in this city with more portent and excitement than was displayed 170 years ago yesterday. On July 4, 1789, not only were the circumstances surrounding the ratification of the famous document thirteen years before fresh in mind, but New York only two months previously had become the temporary capital of the United States of America under the new Constitution.

I FIND a curious paradox in the plight of the young composer who is forced to follow a course of study leading to the Ph. D. in order to compete successfully for positions in our colleges and thereby be able to support himself.

Wall Street entered the second half of 1959 in a confident, almost cocksure mood. Stock prices repeatedly reached new record highs in spirited trading. The week's volume was truncated by the Stock Exchange's closing down on Friday for the long Fourth of July holiday week-end.

DALLAS, July 4 (AP) -- The Teamsters Union and Safeway Stores have signed a contract raising wages for truckers, warehousemen and checkers 61 to 66 cents an hour over a three-year period.
LONDON, July 4 -- London's morning and afternoon newspapers won a brief reprieve today that will enable them to publish at least until Wednesday.

LIME ROCK, Conn., July 4 -- George Constantine of Southbridge, Mass., won the "big car" race on the Sports Car Club of America national championship program here today. He was the victor in an Aston-Martin owned by Elisha Walker of Syosset, N. Y., with an average of 80.04 miles per hour over the 1.2-mile Lime Rock Park course.
LONDON, July 4 (Reuters) -- England's team overpowered India for the third time today and clinched the series of five cricket test matches.

DOWN the street and into The Book Cellar of Brattleboro, Vt., the other day, there firmly marched a monk. Religious order and faith unrevealed, but wearing black cowl and sandals, he quickly found the book he wanted, paid at the desk and departed without saying a word.

WHEN the grandest master of French baroque opera goes on a satirical romp, mocking the theatrical strut of the age of Louis XIV, almost anything can happen. Rameau's "Platee," a ballet bouffon, which we would call an opera today, is a parody of the traditional tragedie lyrique, the French grand opera, which Rameau himself had brought to its highest peak of emotional power and magnificence.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- On Tuesday mornings, from 9 to 11, American business men are invited to talk business at the Soviet exhibition in New York City's Coliseum. Russia wants to trade. Her trade with this country has never been spectacular, but never so negligible as in the past decade.
LOS ANGELES, July 4 (AP) -- A cannon's boom sent forty-one sailing vessels off on the 2,225-mile trans-Pacific yacht race to Honolulu today. An eight-knot wind fanned the sails.
VIENNA, July 4 (Reuters) -- Salzburg is once again preparing to greet thousands of visitors from all over the world who are expected for the music festival to be held from July 26 to Aug. 31.

IT has frequently been held, by a process of legal reasoning which, I confess, I cannot follow, that an author can copyright his text, his characters, his plot -- but not the most prominent feature identifying his property: the title.

RABAT, Morocco, July 4 -- The Moroccan Government has established control over all capital transfers with other countries in the franc zone, the Premier's office announced tonight. The action was an answer to a recent French decision to block Morocco's access to the franc zone foreign currency pool.
DETROIT, July 4 (AP) -- Canada's Miss Supertest III captured the Detroit Memorial Regatta for unlimited power boats today though she jumped the gun in the fifth and final heat.

THE 1,150 blind students in this country's colleges and universities face a special problem in their search for an education: Will enough of them have textbooks to "read" in the years ahead? Some 600 of them have found an answer in the national nonprofit agency called Recording for the Blind, Inc.
TANANARIVE, Madagascar, July 4 -- Massive, typically silent crowds of Malgache citizens welcomed President Charles de Gaulle here today for his second visit within a year.

ABOUT three months ago, in the balmy spring when the minds of tourists and other migratory birds were turning to thoughts of long-distance travel, these columns were devoted to a report on the strange situation then prevailing in the chartering of airplanes for low - cost flights across the Atlantic to Europe.

PARIS, July 4 -- The fight against the Moslem rebellion in Algeria and terrorism in France has reached a turning point favorable to France, according to an optimistic assessment of the situation by French officials.

MOSCOW, July 4 (UPI) -- Russian track and field stars turned in generally mediocre performances tonight in the first night's competition of the Znamnsky Memorial meet. The results will be instrumental in selection of the Soviet team competing in Philadelphia against the United States July 18-19.

DEVELOPMENTS in magnetic tape in the last few weeks promise a reasonably early end to the paralysis caused by an intra-industry war that for a year and a half has hopelessly confused the public and put the tape recording industry flat on the floor.

THE film capital greeted a new kind of glamour girl from overseas just the other day when Haya Harareet, unknown a year ago, arrived to fullfill the contract she signed with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer after playing the top feminine role in "Ben-Hur."
MUSKEGON, Mich., July 4 (AP) -- Wisconsin boats captured three of four divisional titles today in the twenty-second annual Queens Cup yacht race on Lake Michigan.

THE HOUSE OF KNOPF, which has maintained for years a highly intelligent interest in such matters, has designed this book as a companion volume to Freeman Tilden's "The National Parks." The author, Arthur H. Carhart, has made of it a work of comparable charm and distinction.

IN Dudley, England, not long ago, ghost-watchers spotted a ghost wearing lipstick, according to the Birmingham Psychic Society. In New York of late, girl-watchers have also sighted something new -- ghostly girls wearing white lipstick.

Thanks for your article on how no-talent singers get "talent." It constitutes the anatomy of a modern horror, and follows the report, which I read recently, that in the new motion picture "Porgy and Bess" four actors have their songs sung by others.

Records today no longer depend for their success on "musical quality." Today, the emphasis has shifted to such factors as the personality of the singer, the emotional impact of the song, and the beat.
BUENOS AIRES, July 4 -- A political duel with pistols at ten paces between former Vice President Isaac Rojas and a Government Deputy today brought a week of political tension to a climax.

Louis Armstrong's famous trumpet, which had been silenced by illness, was heard again last night, his fifty-ninth birthday, at Lewisohn Stadium. It provided a dramatic, surprise finale to the stadium's fourth annual "Jazz Jamboree."

As a man who is marking his twenty-fifth year as a foreign film importer and distributor Thomas J. Brandon is determined to contribute at least three unusual and, he hopes, outstanding entries to the fall and winter movie seasons.
Business continues brisk as the second half gets under way. That was the majority report of the latest survey made by the National Association of Purchasing Agents.
NORWICH, Conn., July 4 -- Norwich opens a week-long tercentenary celebration tomorrow in the midst of a strike by 150 municipal employes.
WASHINGTON, July 4 -- The number of cases on the Supreme Court's docket this term set a record. The total was 2,062, compared with the previous high of 2,052 two years ago and 2,008 last year.
WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Four years ago -- in mid-1955 -- the United States economy took off on its third wave of post-war inflation.

KANSAS CITY, July 4 -- The Chicago White Sox fell a step farther behind in the American League pennant race as the Kansas City Athletics exploded against Billy Pierce and won the second game of a double-header, 8 -- 3.
Extension of the Federal (Government's authority to provide stand-by marine war-risk insurance for an additional five-year period was supported last week by private and Government shipping leaders.

No doubt Kathleen Morris' letter denouncing the use of public funds for schools devoted to the arts was printed to elicit an outraged response. The undersigned is a musician who has had the pleasure of seeing two children graduated from the public high schools devoted to the arts, one from the High School of Performing Arts and one from the High School of Music and Art.

WHY do they write about disaster? Because disaster is failure, and failure is sometimes more interesting than success in the sense that good news is often no news. You may recall as I do the burning of the Ward liner Morro Castle off the Jersey coast twenty-five years ago.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- The third and most preponderantly Democratic Congress elected during the tenure of President Eisenhower, Republican, has entered the last quarter of its first session with the President able to dictate what money legislation will not become law. He does not possess the power, which he might have in a Republican Congress, to get all the legislation he is willing to approve in the precise form he wishes it to be.
WASHINGTON, July 4 -- The Supreme Court term that ended this week was one of subsiding controversy without but sharpening conflict within.
WARSAW, June 25 -- Poland's economists and propagandists are charging off into the countryside these days to give battle to the horse.

DULUTH, Minn., July 4 (AP) -- Seamen who had defied an earlier demand from their steel union headquarters to end a wildcat strike withdrew their pickets tonight from ore docks in the areas of Duluth and Two Harbors, Minn.

A century ago white church leaders in the South were usually able to reconcile Christianity with slavery. Today, as John Wicklein reports in the first of a series of articles for this newspaper, "no major denomination in the South and few leading churchmen assert that segregation can be reconciled with their religion." That is to say, the religious conscience of the South is uneasy about a far less horrifying problem than that of chattel slavery.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Four Congressmen have introduced bills to help the oyster industry. The identical measures are designed to aid an industry "threatened with extinction because of the excessive mortality of oysters from an undetermined cause."
WASHINGTON, July 4 (UPI) -- The Federal Aviation Agency proposed rules today to curb drunkenness aboard commercial airliners.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 4 -- Adelphi College will open a six-week summer science institute Monday. The first lecture, on radioactive fallout, will be by Dr. Charles W. Shilling, deputy director of the Atomic Energy Commission's division of biological medicine.

HURLEY, N. Y. -- It is going to be open house next Saturday in this historic village on the west bank of the Hudson just outside of Kingston. Seventeen of the community's old stone houses will be open for public inspection.

The upper Midwest's economy is showing continued strength in almost all categories, the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis said in its May report. Bank economists said there were three favorable indications during the month: increased consumption of electric power, heavier demand for bank credit, and a noticeable decrease in new claims for unemployment insurance.

BAY SHORE, L. I., July 4 -- The cornerstone of the new Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Peters was laid this morning by Frank Gulden, president of the Southside Hospital. The Rev. Canon Sydney R. Peters, rector, presided at the ceremony.
The keel for a third vessel to Join the Dow Chemical Company's fleet of tankers was laid last Wednesday in Quincy, Mass.

The churches in the South today are faced with their greatest dilemma since the dispute over slavery. The current crisis is similar to that at the time of the Civil War. Then the question was: "Is slavery Christian?" Today the question is: "Is segregation Christian?"
Albert C. Simmonds Jr., chairman of the 175-year-old Bank of New York, finds nothing wrong with bank mergers -- for somebody else.

THIS comprehensive, vivid, reasonable and well-documented story of the 1956 Hungarian Revolution adds considerably to the world's knowledge of that historic event. The author, a journalist and novelist, recipient of the Kossuth prize, Red Hungary's highest literary award, was a Communist before and during the revolution and from internal evidence, observed it at close range, in fact at the elbow of Imre Nagy, Prime Minister for twelve of the thirteen days.

ROCKLAND LAKE, N. Y. -- Another link has been added to the chain of state parks and recreation areas along the lower Hudson River. This week-end the Palisades Interstate Park Commission is opening picnic and parking areas and dressing rooms for bathers at the east end of Rockland Lake.
WASHINGTON, July 4 (UPI) -- The nation's motorists have about a 50-50 chance of receiving an increase in the Federal tax on gasoline this summer, Congressional Democrats said today.
The nation celebrated 183 years of independence yesterday with emphasis on Alaska's new position as a state, symbolized by the forty-nine-star flag.

HACKENSACK, N. J., July 4 -- Allen Morris of Forest Hills, Queens, defeated Robert Barker of Manhasset, L. I., today in the semi-finals of the Eastern clay court tennis championship, 6 -- 1, 7 -- 5, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 2.

FOR THIS WEEK: Relax from garden chores on the holiday week-end. . . . Afterward, pull off and compost healthy tulip foliage that has ripened. . . . The United States is rightfully proud of its "adopted" son, Alex Olmedo from Peru, who has just won the coveted Wimbledon tennis championship. And Brazil can be equally proud of its little Maria Bueno, who carried off the women's title. These are usually regarded as the highest points to which an amateur can climb.
NO matter what the theatre fare may be (generally mixed), it is always a pleasure to see the opening of two plays of the annual Shakespeare festival in Ontario.

The collection of art being sent to Moscow for the American National Exhibition opening there July 25 consists of forty-nine paintings and twenty-three pieces of sculpture. They were chosen by a committee of four -- a painter, a sculptor, a museum curator and an art educator. The works all date from after 1918 -- as does the Soviet art now on exhibit at the New York Coliseum.
CENTERPORT, L. I., July 4 -- William Gentzlinger sailed Vengeance to a double victory in the Star class in the Centerport Yacht Club regatta in Northport Harbor.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 3 -- The wheat is standing high in Czechoslovakia.

THOSE who want the United States Government to do more for the arts at home sometimes get discouraged. But a factor that gives them hope is that Congress has never had so many members who are active in promoting legislation to aid the arts.
BERLIN, Ohio, July 4 (AP) -- A record two-year budget of $5,625,300 was adopted today at the closing session of the eleventh General Synod of the Evangelical and Reformed Church.
ROME, July 4 -- The Vatican disclosed today that a treasured painting in its celebrated art gallery was a fraud.

EIGHTEEN high school science students will start a summer program tomorrow at the New York Botanical Garden, Bronx Park Sponsored by the National Science Foundation, the course features college-level lectures and laboratory work in the field of botany.

HONOLULU -- Tourists in record - breaking numbers are having the fun this summer of watching history in the making. Last week-end Hawaii held its first state primary election and a statehood plebiscite.

AROUND the turn of the century Gertrude Atherton, a popular lady novelist, decided to write a life of Alexander Hamilton. But her publisher discouraged her. "Nobody reads biographies," he said. Mrs. Atherton responded by writing "The Conqueror," a novel based on Hamilton's career, which delighted a reading public no longer able to stomach the dull pomposities of Victorian biography.
The hotly debated question of how far the Federal Government should go in helping communities meet rising school costs came to the forefront again last week.
THRIVING at the box office as never before, the Metropolitan Opera is under pressure to extend its season. There will be an extra week in New York in 1959-60, making a total of twenty-five weeks.

In past years there may have been better six-month periods for Madison Avenue than the one just concluded, but not many.
SIERRAVILLE, Calif., July 4 (AP) -- A decrease in winds aided near 1,500 men today in gaining 85 per cent control of a forest fire after it had burned over more than 6,000 acres.
WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Space agency officials are viewing with considerable concern a House budgetary reduction that they fear will force a drastic slowdown in the nation's accelerating space program.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 4 -- James B. Moore's Lure dominated the Resolute class in the interclub regatta on Manhasset Bay today. Lure won by 51 seconds from George Gould's Whistler. William Nicholson's Zephyrus was a close third.

In "Letters" (June 21) a reader, in commenting on Flora Lewis' article, suggests that "our occupation authorities in the educational field" failed shockingly in Germany by not using their authority over curriculum content to make German youth "fully informed about Hitler."

GOTEBORG, Sweden, July 4 -- Ingemar Johansson, the world heavyweight boxing champion, said tonight during his homecoming celebration that he expected his first title defense to be held in Los Angeles.

THE once highly regarded piano transcriptions of Franz Liszt, so popular in the nineteenth century, are now, for recital purposes, obsolete. We are such purists nowadays that a concert pianist would no more think of performing them in public than of playing Brassin's transcription of the Fire Music from "Die Walkuere."

At midnight last Tuesday every American gained a little weight and a little height -- on paper -- as the result of the adoption by the six English-speaking nations of common standard definitions for the inch and pound. By the new standards, the American inch becomes a little smaller and the pound a little lighter.

The outlook for aluminum and copper, as well as steel, for the second half of 1959 is thoroughly obscured by the possibility of a steel strike. "We must know if our people in copper mines and plants are going to keep on working this summer before we can form any judgment as to holding the present copper price," one of the largest copper producers said last week.
WASHINGTON, July 4 -- The Government's much - battered security system suffered another legal blow in the Supreme Court this week. It emerged barely alive.
NORFOLK, Va., July 4 -- Attorneys for Negro pupils said this week that they would not appeal a recent Federal District Court ruling upholding the Norfolk pupil-assignment plan.

RICHMOND LATTIMORE is a fine translator of poetry because he has a poetic voice of his own, authentic and unmistakable and yet capable of a remarkable range of modulation. Other verse translators who have dealt with a variety of forms have inevitably imposed a uniformity upon them, as time King James translators did in the books of the Bible.

" There can be only one Prime Minister," David Ben-Gurion has said more than once during Cabinet crises. Last week the 72-year-old Israeli Premier marshaled all his power to assert that position on an issue that, in a historical context, had a wry flavor -- the sale of arms by Israel to West Germany.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- The State Department has advised Congress that there is little prospect of a substantial expansion in United States-Soviet trade and little reason for the Government to promote it.

Flora Lewis is to be praised highly for her article. Rarely do we see the more discouraging sides that emerged from the last war. In fact, Nazism has now been relegated to history -- and history is quiet. No one gets excited about it -- especially not school children. This Nazism that drove our American sons, brothers, fathers and husbands to sacririce themselves is now forgotten by most of us. A chapter without an epilogue.

MONTICELLO, N. Y. -- In Sullivan County's early resort days, vacationists coming here for a southern Catskill holiday were stimulated chiefly by the promise of the fine mountain air, three bountiful meals a day and a bit of swimming and hiking thrown in.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, June 27 -- During Emperor Haile Selassie's current trip behind the Iron Curtain, it will not be overlooked by the Communist countries he is visiting, that Ethiopia is struggling with a five-year development plan that will require much foreign financial and technical assistance.

PARIS, July 4 -- The United States Ambassador to Paris, Mr. Amory Houghton, entertained about 8,000 resident and visiting Americans today at a Fourth of July party that set him back $5,500, not counting tips and breakage.

BONN, Germany, July 4 -- The economic integration of the rich industrial Saar region into West Germany will take place tomorrow at midnight. X-hour, as it has been called, was announced today both here and in Paris.

BABYLON, L. I., July 4 -- The Fourth of July week-end invitation regatta of the Babylon Yacht Club got under way today with Loring Catlin's Stampede taking Star Class honors. The wind was out of the southwest, moderate, for this traditional opener of the Great South Bay Yacht racing season.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 4 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion will resign within forty-eight hours, a Mapai spokesman said today. The resignation will automatically force the fall of the four-party coalition Government.
ROVANIEMI, Finland, June 26 -- This capital of Finnish Lapland is gleaming and white, too new to have much history.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 4 -- Ground has been broken near Kosice, eastern Slovakia, for one of the largest integrated steel plants in Europe.

A NEW line of magnesium levels has replaceable vials. These can be easily adjusted when necessary by loosening the two screws which hold the vial assembly to the level frame. An inner ring is turned with the fingers until proper adjustment is obtained, and screws can then be easily tightened without disturbing this adjustment.
WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Madeline M. Yarnall is a woman not easily dismissed from her job, especially when the White House intervenes.
Bob Turley, who has had his ups and downs this season, came bouncing back on the up beat yesterday with a smashing performance. But at the very end luck again deserted him.

PROGRESS in daylily hybridizing will be the feature of the American Hemerocallis Society's national meeting in Washington, D. C., Thursday through Saturday. In preparation for the event, plants of selected varieties were sent to growers in the Bethesda-Silver Spring, Md., area.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 4 -- Rumor has it that inshore fish on the South Jersey coast are considering filing a complaint with Congress that surf fishermen are unfair to them. The surfcasters, it appears, have become so enthusiastic that they have been swimming after their quarry.

AT this season, activity in a beehive is at its busiest. Several colonies of bees, set on a hill near a field of blossoming timothy grass in Annandale, N. J., are in a frenzy. They whir off to the flowers to gather nectar, then back home to deposit it in the honeycombs. There, other bees, the stay-at homes, frantically flutter their delicate wings to evaporate the water in the nectar and convert it into honey.
Four attributes of the Roman Catholic Church were set forth yesterday in a sermon at St. Patrick's Cathedral as its being unified, holy, catholic and apostolic.

R., June 20 -- On the towering palisades of the right bank of the Dnieper River overlooking the endless steppes of the Ukraine stands one of the Soviet Union's most handsome cities -- ancient Kiev. KAMPALA, Uganda, July 6 -- The African Labor College of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions is engaged in a controversy with the Uganda Government over its exact role in the protectorate.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 3 points (15 cents a bale) off to 7 points (35 cents a bale) up yesterday. The far months showed the most strength.

The deficity of the bankrupt Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company at the end of the first five months of 1959 was $527,944. This was reported yesterday by F. U. Masterson, controller, on behalf of Herman T. Stichman, trustee.

ALTHOUGH the number of Americans who visit Italy each year is formidable, many of them still arrive with misconceptions about that country's cuisine. This is the opinion of Manolita Doelger, director of the Italian State Tourist Office in the United States.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 6 -- President Itzhak Ben-Zvi began consultations with Israel's poltical parties today on the possibility of forming a new government.
CUIDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, July 6 -- The explosion in a midtown restaurant of what is believed to have been a small homemade bomb was officially described today as a kitchen stove accident.
Robert Saudek, producer of "Omnibus," is expected to produce a special one-hour revue to be televised next season as a feature of "Pontiac Star Parade."
Fortified by a week-end of "rest and meditation,'' union and management negotiators in the steel industry resumed their deadlocked negotiations yesterday.
JERSEY CITY, July 6 (UPI) -- Mr. Communale said today he would appear before the Senate committee tomorrow to answer what he called "far-fetched" and "ridiculous" charges.

Atlanta to Birmingham -- 140 miles by air -- makes the difference between moderation and racism in Protestant church groups. If Atlanta is the most liberal city in the Deep South on the race question, Birmingham is the most conservative.
BUENOS AIRES, July 6 -Minister of Economy Alvaro C. Alsogaray urged unions tonight to delay demands for wage increases and attack rising prices.
OBERLIN, Ohio, July 6 -- A twentieth-century "statement of faith" affirming basic Christian convictions was formally presented here today to the new United Church of Christ.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- The third round of Congressional hearings on the commuter problem will be held this week.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- A trucking employer testified today that under the pressure of a Teamsters Union official he had paid $14,000 in "retainers" to a lawyer he had never seen or spoken to.

MEXICO CITY, July 6 -- Officials of the Texas International Sulphur Company announced that their Mexican operations near Minitatlan in the State of Veracruz have now gone into production at the rate of 9,000 tons a month.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Organized labor urged President Eisenhower today to sign the omnibus housing bill now before him.
An investigation into an alleged "munitions lobby" by a House committee, which starts today, will center on the conflict of interest laws governing the employment of retired officers.

PITTSBURGH, July 6 -- When Casey Stengen climbed on the plane at the Chicago Airport after the 1950 All-Star game, his undistinguished career as a manager in these midsummer festivals had started in rather dismal fashion. His American League heroes had been beaten in the fourteenth inning by Red Schoendienst's home run.
DETROIT, July 6 (AP) -- The Independence Day week-end was reflected by a drop in auto production.
ALBANY, July 6 -- Following is a summary of the report to the Governor from his Special Task Force on Protection from Radioactive Fall-Out:
New York City will observe the thirty-fifth anniversary of radio station WNYC today.
SUNDAY is the day when business booms on Orchard Street on the lower East Side.

Baseball Today and Yesterday For a brief period before the All-Star inter-league game there is a pause equally gratifying to over-intense rooters and weary players. It was on one of these off-days that an old fan, whose loyalty to the Giants dates back a few years before the turn of the century, let memory wander nostalgically to his boyhood.
LONDON, July 6 (AP) -Government-sponsored talks to head off a shutdown of Britain's nationally distributed newspapers broke down today.
For the fourth successive trading day stocks yesterday made new historic highs in The New York Times combined and industrial averages.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., July 6 -- Regional agencies that have been working to make higher education more widely available can be used to tackle other problems on a regional basis, Governor Cecil H. Underwood of West Virginia suggested today.

TOKYO, July 6 -- The Japanese Government and ruling Liberal - Democratic party agreed today to delay the presentation of the revised United States-Japanese security treaty to the Diet (Parliament) for ratification until early next year when the ordinary Diet will be convened.
HARTSDALE, N. Y., July 6 -- All favorites won as the New York state girls' tennis championship opened at the County Tennis Club today.
BUENOS AIRES, July 6 -Argentina is opposed to a meeting of American foreign ministers to consider Caribbean tension as a threat to hemispheric peace, it was learned today.

The Savings Banks Association of the State of New York announced yesterday that it had resigned from the American Bankers Association because of A. B. A. support for a bill before Congress to increase Federal income taxes of savings banks and savings and loan associations.

OSCAR MELICK RUEBHAUSEN, a corporation lawyer whose interests run from tennis to atomic energy, was described recently as a man who "likes to do things he's never done before." A recent opportunity occurred a few months ago in Venezuela when his host learned that Mr. Ruebhausen had never been on a horse.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Democratic leaders in Congress poured scorn today on their party's National Chairman, Paul M. Butler, for his assertion that the party would be in bad shape in 1960 if Congress did not write a more progressive record.
GREEN RIVER, Utah, July 6 (AP) -- Sixteen men, women and children feared lost or stranded while defying the Colorado River's deadliest rapids were reported safe late today.
The financially disturbed State of Michigan announced yesterday that it would bring to the market $50,000,000 of highway revenue bonds, due from 1961 to 1985, on July 30.
The first recognized case of rabies in a bat here was reported yesterday by the Health Department.
HONG KONG, Tuesday, July 7 -- The Chinese Communists denied today Nationalist claims of an air victory over the Taiwan Strait.

PITTSBURGH, July 6 -- If a proposal submitted to the player representatives today is adopted, managers eventually will be included in the major league pension plan, which at present is restricted to players, coaches and trainers.

A seventy - member "interim planning committee" has been appointed by Bernard Newman, New York County Republican leader, as a step to strengthen the Manhattan organization. The group is composed mainly of younger members of the party.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- A plan to abolish the present Supreme Court and reorganize it as a seventeen-man tribunal of state judges was introduced today by Representative Overton Brooks, Democrat of Louisiana.

PITTSBURGH, July 6 -- Speculation on the outcome of two spectacular pennant races was tossed to one side tonight as the baseball clans gathered for the major leagues' twenty-sixth annual All-Star game.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -The Organization of American States postponed action again today on the Dominican Republic's appeal for help to head off the alleged threat of an invasion backed by Cuba and Venezuela.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Congress and the Department of Justice have not reached joint conclusions, or apparently not even separate ones, on how to restore the Government security program which covers employes of private companies engaged on secret defense projects.
Washington Square Park assumed almost complete park status yesterday when the last motor vehicle traffic was diverted from it.

GOSHEN, N. Y., July 6 (AP) -- The opening of the Grand Circuit harness racing meeting at Historic Track was marred today by a downpour after the first four races. The balance of the program was delayed twenty-four hours.

BERCHTESGADEN, Get. many, July 6 (AP)--The bod3 of a 22-year-old American Mot, mon missionary who disap, peared in the Alps June 26 ha,, been found, the 'rest Germar police announced today. Frei Harless of Phoenix, Ariz.. hai set out alone to cUmb an $,700, foot mountain near here.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- An emergency program to eradicate starfish in Long Island Sound and adjacent waters was approved by the Senate today.

The Lighthouse has for years provided a broad summer vacation program for blind adults, teen-agers and young children. This year, again, the program is a very active one, utilizing Riverlight, a camp for adults at Cornwall, N. Y., and Camp Lighthouse on Barnegat Bay in New Jersey, for teen-agers and young adults.
RONKONKOMA, L. I., July 6 -- A scheduled air passenger service for suburban Long Island began operating today from and to MacArthur Airport in British-built airliners.

Nathaniel D. Gribin has sold a plot of land fronting 200 feet on the west side of Valles Avenue, 185 feet north of the Henry Hudson Parkway, in the Riverdale area of the Bronx. The property was purchased by David B. Widelitz, Westchester builder, for improvement with an apartment house.

ROME, July 6 -- Vatican workers were told officially today that Pope John XXIII had granted them substantial pay rises. They also were informed that their working hours would be altered to permit more Church business to be conducted in the afternoon.

DARMSTADT, Germany, July 6 (AP) -- The first United States military dependent to be tried by a German court was sentenced today to fifteen months in prison for the fatal stabbing of her soldier husband.

The Crane Company, manufacturer of plumbing supplies, acquired 766,000 shares of its common stock, about one-third of the outstanding shares under the offer of $45 a share it made to stockholders early last month.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, July 6 -- The Government shelved a proposal to give a house in a white suburb here to Jasper Savanhu, the first African minister in the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland, and his family.

The Russian Festival, presented by S. Hurok in conjunction with the Soviet Exhibition at the Coliseum, opens tonight at Madison Square Garden at 8 o'clock, instead of 8:15, as previously announced. More than 210 performers from ten companies of the Soviet Union will appear on the program of dancing and music.

Supreme Court Justice Henry Epstein gave the State Commission Against Discrimination forty-eight hours yesterday to decide whether it will withdraw a ruling that exempts the Arabian-American Oil Company from certain provisions of the State Fair Employment Practices Act.

RHEIMS, France July 6 -- The best soccer team in France is usually Le Stade de Rheims, which represents this small but best champagne-rich city. The best soccer team in Europe is Club Real of Madrid, which has won the European Cup four years in a row.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday that there was no evidence of any slackening in momentum of the business expansion, which has taken sales, production and employment to new peaks in the first half of 1959.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 6 -- Radioactive fall-out from nuclear weapons tests has already passed, its peak and will continue to diminish provided no further tests are conducted, an official of the Atomic Energy Commission said today.
WHITE PLAINS, July 6 -- Westchester County's government was called upon today to start a program at once to combat alcoholism. About 20,000 Westchester residents are numbered among its victims.

The series of graphs dealing specifically with class size in The New York Times of June 21 was an eminently clear and accurate presentation of the deplorable fact that New York City's schools next September will have a larger enrollment of pupils and a smaller staff of teachers, with a consequent increase in class size.

The change in sentiment on the part of the Democratic leadership in this, the first session of the Eighty-sixth Congress, rates high among the more striking political phenomena in Washington in recent years.
BATON ROUGE, La., July 6 -- Gov. Earl K. Long returned to the city today after resting over the week-end at his farm near Winnfield, in northern Louisiana.
BONN, Germany, July 6 -The Social Democrats today began an intra-party discussion on how West Germany's major Opposition party should deal with the Russians.

Charles Schamis, a 46-year-old Queens diamond merchant, was accused yesterday in Criminal Court of stealing more than $315,000 worth of diamonds and other gems from Manhattan jewelers. He already is awaiting sentencing in Queens County Court for attempting to steal $40,000 worth of diamonds.

MILWAUKEE, July 6 -- Paul Benko of New York won the Western chess championship last night for the second straight year. The Hungarian refugee, who first took the title soon after his arrival in this country, finished the third annual tournament with a score of 7 1/2 -- 1/2.

MONROE, Wash., July 6 -- Four rebellious convicts, holding forty men, women and children as hostages, threatened tonight to mutilate their prisoners and then commit suicide unless they were permitted to escape from the Washington State Reformatory.
ST. PAUL, Minn., July 6 (AP) -- M. Lee Lewis, a balloonist who soared to more than 80,000 feet, was killed today while making tests in a gondola three feet above the ground.

Alsco, Inc., declared a 15-cent quarterly dividend on the common stock, payable Aug. 11. In February and May shareholders received 12 1/2 cents a share. Harry Sugar, president, said sales for the fiscal year ended May 31 should exceed $26,000,000, which compares with slightly more than $17,000,000 the year before.

Traffic deaths during the two-day Fourth of July week-end this year surpassed the nation's previous record for the two-day holiday. but fell short of the 350 fatalities predicted by the National Safety Council.
TANANARIVE, Madagascar, July 6 (Reuters) -- Nomad tribesmen greeted Charles de Gaulle with piercing shrieks of welcome today when the French President toured southern Madagascar.

GRAND BLANC, Mich., July 6 (AP) -- Art Wall Jr. beat Dow Finsterwald handily today in an 38-hole play-off that decided the $32,000 Buick open golf tournament. Wall shot a one-under-par 71 to Finsterwald's 73.

The Russians are showing a camera at their Coliseum exhibition that is interesting to visitors who have been bitten by the camera bug. It is called the Leningrad and appears to be ahead of anything in its class produced anywhere else.

President Eisenhower nominated Robert K. Christenberry for postmaster of New York yesterday. The nomination was among a list of fifty-two names for postmasterships sent to the Senate for confirmation.
A NEW summer program for parents and children will start today at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and Eighty-second Street.
This week, most of America's custom millinery designers are presenting their new autumn collections to the press and store buyers.

Idun, the 4-year-old filly owned by Mrs. Josephine Bay Part of New York, increased her earnings on the race tracks to $550,820 yesterday. She did it by winning the second running of the $27,250 Liberty Belle Handicap at six furlongs.

NORWICH, Conn., July 6 (AP) -- Striking municipal employes set up a picket line outside City Hall today to support their demand for higher pay. But they refrained from interfering with the city's 300th birthday celebration.

KUMASI, Ghana, June 28 -Barefoot villagers, having traveled for hours through the bush, arrive every morning at the office of a towering young official here to hand him bundles of pound notes and beg him to spend them wisely.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (UPI) -- The jurior whose illness plunged the Richard A. Mack-Thurman Whiteside conspiracy trial into confusion was released from the hospital today and pronounced ready to resume his duties.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., July 6 (AP) -- Mrs. Elaine G. Lorillard of New York has filed suit in United States District Court here for $100,000 against the Newport Jazz Festival, Inc., of Rhode Island.
BALTIMORE, June 25 - This city played a long shot when it decided to rebuild from the inside out. The gamble is paying off handsomely.

PHILADELPHIA, July 6 (AP) -- The twenty-four-story Packard Building, one of Philadelphia's main office buildings in the heart of the city, has been sold to a syndicate of West Coast investors for a price reported as $7,500,000.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- James C. Hagerty, Presidential press secretary, said today that President Eisenhower was aware of the contents of W. Averell Harriman's report to the State Department on his recent talk with Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev of the Soviet Union.
About 15,000 junior high school students in New York City will start an intensified science curriculum next fall.
LOS ANGELES, July 6 -- One of California's two remaining "loyalty oath" laws was held unconstitutional by the Superior Court today.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 6 -- The issue of communism in the movie industry will be brought before the American Legion at its national convention next month.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, July 6 (Reuters) -- Political opponents of Prime Minister S. W. R. D. Bandaranaike's Government moved in Parliament today to topple the three-year-old regime.
LONDON, July 6 -- Industrial shares continued their slow upward climb in the stock market here today. This raised the Financial Times index of industrial ordinary stocks 0.5 point to a record 241.6.
The 526-man crew of the strike-bound Italian liner Giulio Cesare was asked to go home yesterday by immigration authorities.
LONDON, July 6 (Reuters) A judge here today issued an order for the compulsory dissolution of Frisky Cars, Ltd., of Wolverhampton.

" Proust: The Early Years," the first of a two-volume work on the life and writings of Marcel Proust, had been scheduled for publication this month but has been postponed until August by Atlantic-Little, Brown because of manufacturing difficulties.

Percy Gale Jr., who retired under fire last year as director of the city's old Bureau of Real Estate, defended his executive officer, Benjamin Cymrot, yesterday at the latter's departmental trial on charges of misconduct and incompetence.
The Ampex Corporation plans to acquire 75 per cent of Orr Industries, Inc., by an exchange of one share of Ampex common for every 2.2 shares of Orr.

A 25 - year - old Brooklyn woman who said she had tried to hold up a bank teller to get money for a wedding trousseau was sentenced yesterday to a year's imprisonment in the Westfield State Farm at Bedford Hills, N. Y.

PAGE, Ariz., July 6 (AP) -- Construction was halted at the $421,000,000 Glen Canyon Dam in Northern Arizona today by a strike following a month-long dispute over daily subsistence pay of $6 to each worker. The union argues that Page is a remote area.
ALBANY, July 6 -- A plan to save millions of New Yorkers from death and injury by radio-active fall-out in a nuclear war was made public today by Governor Rockefeller.

Government bonds moved slightly in light trading yesterday. Longer-dated issues were a shade easier, drifting downward no more than 2/32s. Some odd lot buying in the issues of one- to five-year maturities produced increases of the same small amount there.

ROME, July 6 -- The Italian seamen's strike, which has immobilized twenty-six ships in various parts of the world and done considerable damage to the nation's economy, entered its twenty-ninth day today without a settlement in sight.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 6 -- President Sukarno declared today he would not be a dictator under the controversial 1945 Constitution he reinstated by decree yesterday. The charter gives him virtually unrestricted powers.

A behind-the-scenes study of commodities of all types -- clothing, records, toys, magazines and books, health and beauty aids and a host of other items as well as foods -- on their course through chain food stores' distribution is given in a detailed breakdown to be published next week by Chain Store Age.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The interest rate on 182-day Treasury bills rose sharply this week to a record level of just under 4 per cent, the Treasury disclosed tonight. The rate on ninety-one-day bills also rose, though much less sharply.

Newspaper readers have been learning in the last few days who some of their new judges will be in New York City. It is widely believed that these judges will be chosen in popular election next November. This is mostly fiction. They are chosen by political party leaders, like Carmine G. De Sapio, the Tammany boss, and Joseph T. Sharkey, the Democratic leader in Brooklyn, who doubles as majority leader of the City Council.
GENEVA, July 6 -- Semyon K. Tsarapkin of the Soviet Union again accused the United States and Britain today of stalling in negotiations here for a ban on nuclear weapons tests.
James Felt, chairman of the City Planning Commission, disagreed yesterday with Robert Moses' characterization of the city's Title I program as largely "a dead duck."
Railroad fans in the Northeast are not likely to see many of those new aluminum gondolas and hopper cars that the Southern Railway announced it was buying over the week-end.

CHICAGO, July 6 -- Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip received a warm, friendly and often downright folksy welcome today from this Midwestern metropolis, glorying in its new role as a major port for the St. Lawrence Seaway.

The truth of a letter from me published by The New York Times stating that German youth is ignorant about Hitler and even glorifies him is now admitted both here and in Germany. The facts were disputed by a former Reichstag Representative at that time.
Red Cross Blood Centers in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx will curtail their schedules starting this month.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- Congress has been told that the taxpayers are getting a bargain in paying $275,000 for two pieces of sculpture for the new State Department building.
LIMA, Peru, July 6 -- A mutiny by a police unit was crushed last night after a three-hour gun battle with loyal policemen. One policeman was killed and three were injured.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The United States Court of Appeals today in effect reaffirmed its June 9 decision upholding the State Department's right to deny passports to Americans for travel to Red China and other Communist nations with which this country does not have diplomatic relations.
Plans to convert its entire jet fleet to turbo-fan engines were announced by American Airlines yesterday. The line is the first to announce a complete swing to the new engine.
Heavy-lift booms and wash-down systems to counteract radioactive contamination will be standard equipment on new general - purpose, dry - cargo ships built with Federal subsidies.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads today estimated the net income of class I railroads for the first five months of 1959 at $233,000,000, compared with $75,000,000 in the corresponding period of 1958.

Stock splits set a record in the first half of 1959 -- 155 authorized by stockholders, compared with twenty-four in the first six months of last year. Should the rate continue, this year's stock splits should far exceed the peak of 181 for the full year of 1955.

Thirty-four play centers where youngsters can find fun and instruction this summer opened yesterday in the five boroughs. The opening marked the forty-third year of the play school program. About 7,000 boys and girls are expected to participate in the seven-week program, which is sponsored by the Play Schools Association and the Board of Education's bureau of community education.
THE Fourth of July tournaments played last weekend at Sacandaga Park, N. Y., and at Philadephia, reported in this space yesterday came to a close late Sunday night with their team-of-four contests.
Winner of the Eastern clay courts tennis championship on Sunday, Allen Morris started out in quest of the New York State crown yesterday.
CHICAGO, July 6 (AP) -- The heaviest selling of corn futures in several months hit that grain futures pit today on the Board of Trade and prices of the near contracts skidded sharply.
Youths aspire to become ball players, newspapermen yearn to own country weeklies and advertising men daydream about deserting Madison Avenue. John S. Williams is an ad man who has made the move.

PITTSBURGH, July 6 (UPI) -- Warren Giles, the president of the National League, turned down an appeal tonight by Manager Solly Hemus and Coach Harry Walker of the St. Louis Cardinals. They had appealed their suspensions and fines growing out of a run-in with umpires in a game against the Los Angeles Dodgers on July 2.
The Georgia-Pacific Corporation is prepared to offer "well in excess" of $85,500,000 for the Booth-Kelly Lumber Company, Springfield, Ore., a company spokesman said yesterday.

This is the last week for New York City teen-agers to sign up for summer jobs a Junior Red Cross volunteers at municipal and Veterans Administration hospitals, Red Cross blood banks and other agency programs, the local Red Cross announced yesterday.
PITTSBURGH, July 6 -- A year ago, when the All-Star game was played in Baltimore, Mayo Smith was one of Fred Haney's coaches. His Phillies had won seven straight games not too long before that date.

" The Ivy League bunch" was accused yesterday of publishing articles on American public education that were "untrue, low-down, name-calling and mean." The accusation was made at a conference of school superintendents at Columbia University.

LONDON, July 6 -- A couple of Cambridge University men were discussing anti-Americanism a year or so ago and the result is a scholarly sixty-four-page issue of their magazine devoted to "An English View of America."
The Woodward Iron Company reported yesterday that its net profit for the first half of this year was $2,359,852 after all charges and a provision of $1,786,752 for income taxes.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- Long delays to avoid deportation would be denied aliens under a bill passed by the House of Representatives and sent to the Senate today.
Plans have been filed for a nineteen-story building at 425-35 East Sixty-sixth Street and 1231-41 York Avenue to house additional facilities of the Memorial Center for Cancer and Allied Diseases.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 6 -- James R. Hoffa said today that the Teamsters and the long-shore union of Harry Bridges had reached a tentative jurisdictional accord in Hawaii.
NEWBURGH, N. Y., July 6 -- Senator Jacob K. Javits of New York said here today that Americans did not seem to display the same zeal for the American cause as the Communists showed for their cause.

The Chase Manhattan Bank reported yesterday net operating earnings for the first six months of 1959 climbed to $29,430,000 or $2.24 a share from $28,177,000 or $2.14 a share for the like period a year ago.
Some of the luckiest bowlers in the nation are the clan of left-handers that have taken to rolling at ten pins. At least one of the best southpaws in the New York metropolitan area believes so.

GENEVA, July 6 -- Dag Hammarskjold, United Nations Secretary General, said today that governments of industrially developed countries might be over-emphasizing price stability at the cost of economic growth.
Coffee futures rose yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange on a report that Latin-American coffee producers had drafted proposals for a world-wide pact aimed at stabilizing prices.
Eleven more municipal ferry-boats will soon be fitted with radar navigational aids designed and built by a British company.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 6 -A small furry animal that terrorized Bellmore residents and battled the Nassau County police yesterday turned out to be a mink.
DETROIT, July 6 -- Frol R. Kozlov arrived in a quiet Detroit tonight by air from San Francisco.

CHICAGO, July 6 -- Federal Judge Julius H. Miner decided today to view the film, "Anatomy of a Murder," before ruling on a suit seeking to enjoin the city of Chicago from preventing its showing here. He agreed to attend a private screening tomorrow of the film at the Chicago offices of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation.
More than half a dozen American and European managers have been elbowing each other in recent months for the privilege of doing "Irma, La Douce" on Broadway.
CHICAGO, July 6 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Borough President John T. Clancy of Queens defended yesterday his appointment of a former city marshal as a provisional borough works inspector, even though the marshal had quit while his financial accounts were being checked.
MEXICO CITY, July 6 -- The rightist National Action party apparently has been beaten in its first test of strength in its role as a rejuvenated second political power in Mexico.

A public offering of $3,600,000 of 6 1/2 per cent subordinated debentures and 360,000 shares of common stock of the Oklahoma Cement Company is being made today by Laird Co. Corporation and associates. The securities are being sold in units of $100 of debentures and ten shares of common stock.

SANDWICH, Mass., July 6 -- If Cliff Davis had his way, striped bass would replace the turkey on Thanksgiving Day menus. While he concedes that the Pilgrims dined on the plump bird on festive occasions, he insists that it was the "basse" that really helped the Mayflower's passengers get through their first year.

WASHINGTON July 6 -- The index of average wholesale primary market prices fell 0.3 per cent to 119.3 per cent of its 1947-49 base during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

It seems odd that an Israeli Government should resign over the issue of a small shipment of munitions to West Germany. Yet this is what has happened. Premier David Ben-Gurion received a close vote of confidence on this issue, but his coalition showed signs of coming apart. It was for this reason that he felt moved to resign and to turn his administration into a caretaker government which presumably will neither make nor change policies.
MOSCOW, July 6 -- The Soviet Union announced tonight that it had fired two dogs and a rabbit into the upper atmosphere and had brought them safely back to earth.

Promptly at 10 o'clock yesterday morning, when the doors normally would be opened to the public, Mrs. Richard Osser arrived at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Hundreds of other visitors continued to come throughout the day. But all were turned away.

PITTSBURGH, July 6 -- Vice President Nixon didn't steal the show at the Pittsburgh Baseball Writers' All-Star game dinner tonight because he had some pretty stiff competition. But he came close, and the 1,200 guests gave him a big hand.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, July 6 (AP) -- A German Nobel-Prize winner, Dr. Werner Forssmann, who helped open the way for modern heart surgery, got notice of dismissal tonight as chief surgeon at the Duesseldorf Evangelical Hospital.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- A hint of what has made the recovery from last year's recession so brisk was provided today in a fiscal-year-end statement of the Treasury's cash operations.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 6 -- Decreases in percentages of national population active in agriculture over the last twelve years have been consistent in many areas of the globe. Comparative tables presented in the 1958 production yearbook of the Food and Agriculture Organization indicate the tendency toward mechanization of food production, with the number of tractors in use expanding in sharp contrast to the number of workers employed.
