" SANTA FE: The Autobiography of a Southwestern Town,"* edited by Oliver La Farge, should do something to soothe the jangled nerves of all who fret about the perils of conformity in America.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, July 6 (AP) -- The Communist Government clamped travel restrictions on United States diplomats today. They cannot go more than forty kilometers (twenty-five miles) from mid town Budapest unless they get special permission.

Steel production dipped still further last week. The customary summer lag is being felt and many steel users, including the automobile plants, apparently feel that the inventories they built up in anticipation of a steel strike may hold them for the present.

The four-story building at 50 West Seventy-fifth Street has been acquired by the Neighborhood House of the City of New York for use as a community center. The settlement house had its headquarters at 149 West Sixty-third Street for about fifteen years, but had to vacate the premises, which are part of the Lincoln Square redevelopment area.
The police shot and killed a youth last night after he and several other gang members had fired two shots from a speeding car into a group of forty youths, seriously wounding one.

One of our poets said that he who plants a tree "provideth a kindness for many generations, and faces that he hath not seen shall bless him." So the gracious gift from Tokyo of a thousand Japanese flowering cherry trees to the people of New York City is appreciated for the pleasure it will bring and the goodwill it signifies.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 6 -- Al Ciuci, the golf pro at the Fresh Meadow Country Club in Great Neck, was honored by his fellow Long Island pros today at the Garden City Country Club. Ciuci recently stepped down as president of the Long Island Professional Golfers Association after nineteen years in office.
LONDON, July 6 -- Three of Britain's most powerful trade unions opened annual conferences today that may have a vital effect on the future of the Labor party.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The United States announced today that it was willing to give Burma -- and Burma was willing to receive -- up to $37,000,000 in economic assistance in the next four years.
CHICAGO, July 7 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
SAN FRANCISCO, July 7 -- James R. Hoffa declared today he would not be "stampeded" into the "indiscriminate firing" of union organizers with questionable reputations.
LOS ANGELES, July 7 (UPI) -- The world bantamweight champion, Alphonse Halimi of France, tonight remained a 2-1 favorite to defeat Jose Becerra of Mexico in their title bout tomorrow night.
NEW DELHI, India, July 7 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru indicated today at his news conference that he felt the United Nations was not qualified to deal with the Tibetan situation.

While taking the opportunity to congratulate you on the fine editorial of June 29 "A Year for the Refugees" I would like to make a general appeal to the American public, especially to organized foundations, to help the Chinese scholars who are stranded in Hong Kong.

PARIS, July 7 -- Until now the principal atomic striking power placed at NATO'S disposal by the United States has been composed of nine jet fighter-bomber squadrons stationed on airfields in France. Shortly these planes will be transferred to bases in West Germany and Britain.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- The Air Force fired a rocket 750 miles into space today in the first of a series of launchings designed to measure the natural radiation surrounding the earth.
VIENNA, July 7 -- Chancellor Julius Raab surrendered today his mandate to form another coalition government after eight weeks of fruitless negotiations with the Socialists.
FORT LEWIS, Wash., July 7 (UPI) -- Two soldiers convicted of selling choice overseas assignments for up to $200 were held in the stockade here today while their case was being reviewed.

The Beryllium Corporation announced yesterday that it had joined with Imperial Smelting Corporation, Ltd., of London to form a new company that will produce beryllium metal for sale to fabricators in England and Europe.

DETROIT, July 7 -- Frol R. Kozlov declared tonight that he believed the Soviet Union, the United States and Britain were close to an agreement on nuclear control based on a proposal for a quota number of inspections.

YONKERS, July 7 -- Scotch Tape, owned by Arthur Nardin of Miami Beach, snapped a twelve-race losing streak by scoring a neck victory over Reed's Knight in 2:04 in the Blue Ribbon Pace before 22,192 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (UPI) -- The House Agriculture Committee approved today an Administration - opposed increase in Federal milk subsidies for school children.

LONDON, July 7 (Reuters) -- Shareholders of the British publisher, George Newnes, have agreed to a take-over offer by Odhams Press, a big newspaper, magazine and periodical group, it was announced here today.
Dr. John H. Fischer, who will become dean of Teachers College, Columbia University, on Sept. 1, expressed concern yesterday for the growing number of priorities in education.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- The House Ways and Means Committee will start public hearings next week on proposals to provide Government supported medical and hospitalization insurance for all persons receiving benefits under the Social Security program.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., July 7 (AP) -- Russell S. (Rusty) Callow, who attained rowing's highest coaching honors in the twilight of a thirty-seven-year career, stepped down today as Navy's crew coach.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- The United States filed in the International Court of Justice today a $756,604 suit against the Soviet Union for the shooting down of a United States Air Force B-29 over Japan Nov. 7, 1954.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 7 -- President Sukarno is reported to be sifting the names of potential ministers of differing convictions and ideologies, including communism, for inclusion in a new Cabinet. The Cabinet of Premier Djuanda resigned yesterday after twenty-seven months in office.
BONN, Germany, July 7 -- Erich Ollenhauer announced today that he would not become Chancellor if the Social Democratic Opposition won the next West German election in 1961.

THE city's noncommercial radio station, WNYC, celebrated its thirty-fifth anniversary in characteristic style yesterday. It rendered one more public service that, with amusing irony, probably had its most appreciative audience in the least likely place: Madison Avenue.
PITTSBURGH, July 7 -- A few years ago the first line of some verses written for the New York Baseball Writers' dinner read:
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The Administration decided today to add some traditional American paintings to its Moscow exhibit of "modern" art.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The Senate rackets committee heard testimony today that James R. Hoffa tried in 1954 to undercut the wage increase demands of New York teamster officials.
The air skirmish above the Taiwan Strait last week-end and intermittent bombardments of the Nationalist-held offshore islands may be a preface to another Far Eastern crisis.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 7 -- A $7,500 painting of a fishing scene by Winslow Homer, removed from the Parrish Art Museum here yesterday following charges that it had been stolen from another owner, will be returned to the museum tomorrow.
CAMDEN, N. J., July 7 -- Frankie Carbo, boxing underworld figure, was ordered extradited to New York today but the order was stayed when defense lawyers filed an appeal.
The names of two city policemen who died in line of duty were given to two new police launches yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (UPI) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, said today that he would press for a Congressional investigation of a Government sale of cottonseed oil sought by religious agencies for needy people abroad.

GENEVA, July 7 -- The United States and Britain took issue today with United Nations experts who fear that Governments of industrially developed countries may be sacrificing economic growth to price stability.

PITTSBURGH, July 7 -- "I never have got him out." Whitey Ford, charged with the defeat in today's All-Star game, said that about Willie Mays, whose eighth-inning triple drove home Hank Aaron with the National League's winning run at sun-kissed Forbes Field.
The annual mid-winter benefit dinner dance of the Yorkville Community Association will be held at the Plaza on Jan. 22.

EVENINGS - BY - THE-RIVER is the title the Lower East Side Neighborhoods Association picked for its free summer concerts four years ago. Last night, when the association opened its fifth series, the event lived up to the poetry inherent in the title.

The ten-story apartment apartment building at 545 West 111th Street, corner of Broadway, has been purchased by Sidney Freidberg from a client of Fred S. Weitzner. The sale was subject to two mortgages amounting to $994,108. Mr. Freidberg resold his contract of purchase to the Orsid Realty Company through Seeger Co., broker. The building contains 134 apartments and four stores and is assessed at $1,075,000.

PARIS, July 7 (UPI) -- Dave Thomas, a Welsh professional who now lives in London, clippped nine strokes off par in the final two rounds of the French open golf championship today and won the seventy-two-hole event with a 276.

Stockholders of the Bristol-Myers Company yesterday approved a three-for-one stock split, which becomes effective on July 9. They also voted to increase the authorized common stock to 7,500,000 shares of $1 par from 2,500,000 shares of $2.50 par.
OBERLIN, Ohio, July 7 -- The General Synod of the new United Church of Christ deferred today for one year action on a proposed constitution.

Elmer A. Carter, chairman of the State Commission Against Discrimination, won time yesterday to discuss United States policy toward Saudi Arabia with State Department officials in Washington before deciding what to do about the hiring practices of the Arabian American Oil Company.

The promotion of Seymour J. Teich, vice president and merchandise administrator of Bamberger's-Newark, to senior vice president for merchandising of Bamberger's-New Jersey, which operates stores in New Jersey, was announced yesterday by David L. Yunich, president.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- President Eisenhower vetoed the omnibus housing bill today, even though it had been reduced somewhat from the original Democratic program.

TRIVANDRUM, India, July 7 (Reuters) -- The Communist party in West Bengal announced plans today for a statewide "hands off Kerala" campaign to offset the chance of intervention in Kerala by the Central Government.

New Yorkers have been told by Air Pollution Control Commissioner Greenburg that they will be rendering a service if they report motor vehicles -- particularly buses -- giving out smoke from their exhaust pipes. Since his department has only thirty-six inspectors, it needs help.
ANDY WILLIAMS got off to a seasonably easygoing and diverting start on his Channel 2 series last night.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's message telling why he vetoed the housing bill:

LONDON, July 7 -- Industrial and other shares lost some of their recent firmness on the stock market here today despite Wall Street's fresh rise yesterday to new peaks. The turnover contracted; prices became irregular after some early gains, and by the close net rises and falls were fairly evenly balanced.
A $40,000,000 project to reclaim the rundown waterfront of the lower East River in Manhattan was announced yesterday by the Department of Marine and Aviation.
THE most important project the family decorator may have to face is furnishing what may be the newest room in the house -- the survival shelter against radioactive fallout.
Melvin E. Dawley yesterday was elected president and chief executive officer of Lord Taylor, New York department store. He succeeds the late Miss Dorothy Shaver.

The Stauffer Chemical Company and Victor Chemical Works plan to merge, subject to approval of their stockholders. The consolidation would unite two pioneer companies, leaders in their respective fields, with combined assets of about $195,000,000 and 1959 sales projected to exceed $225,000,000.
BUENOS AIRES, July 7 -- President Arturo Frondizi's harassed Administration scored two important victories today.
W. Averell Harriman has reported that he sees a danger of war through miscalculation by Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev, with whom he recently met in Moscow.
Five Brooklyn youths were hospitalized last night, after a bottle containing a yellow powder exploded.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The United States has decided to place strict limits on the travel of Hungarian officials in this country. The move was in retaliation against the Hungarian decision to limit travel by United States diplomats there.
Thomas W. Blazey has been promoted to assistant controller of the B. F. Goodrich Company from chief accountant of the B. F. Goodrich Tire Company, a division.
Yonkers Raceway will open contractors' bids next Wednesday on its projected new $9,000,000 grandstand, it was learned yesterday.
WINFRITH, England, July 7 -- Preliminary designs for an atomic reactor that, it is hoped, will halve the cost of nuclear power in Europe were made public today by the British Atomic Energy Authority.
Tony Vincent, the defending titleholder, made his first appearance in the New York State clay court tennis championship yesterday and played two rounds to catch up with the field.

PHILADELPHIA, July 7 -- The Philadelphia Marine Trade Association appealed to top officials of the longshoremen's union today to intervene in a waterfront dispute over the unloading of 2,500 tons of sugar from the Cuban freighter Caribe.
Organized baseball's third major league will be a reality within two years. That was the word William Shea, the chairman of the Mayor's Baseball Committee, gave to Mayor Wagner yesterday.
CHICAGO, July 7 (AP) -- Near-by wheat futures contracts extended their recent gains today on the Board of Trade, but the distant deliveries came under late-selling pressure and closed weak.
Deane Beman and Bill Buppert of Bethesda, Md., will be back at the Winged Foot Golf Club, Mamaroneck, N. Y., tomorrow. A year ago their play there won the John G. Anderson Memorial tournament.

WHEN Chief Justice Earl Warren wrote the decision outlawing school segregation in 1954 he was joined by a unanimous Supreme Court. Five years later he frequently finds himself on the short end of the 5-4 decisions. So be it. He is now in the distinguished company of such great dissenters in this century as Holmes, Brandeis, Cardozo and Stone.

THE scope of the box lunch has been dramatically expanded; thanks to such marvelous conveniences as insulated picnic bags and air-tight plastic containers filled with salads, pickled vegetables, chopped fruits and such.
THE Presbyterian minister's son from Whiteland, Ind., was only passably pious, and as a youth he rebelled, quietly but unmistakably, against singing in the Sunday choir.

MONTREAL, July 7 -- The Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, long a leader for free world trade, asserted today that the men's clothing industry in the United States and Canada was threatened with destruction by the flow of imports from Japan and Hong Kong.
PARIS, July 7 -- An envelope containing 9,500,000 francs (about $19,000), part of an alleged payment for murder, was turned over to justice officials today.

Title to the forty-one-story Pierre Hotel at Fifth Avenue and Sixty-first Street has been taken by the 795 Fifth Avenue Corporation, representing tenants and others who bought the property for operation on a cooperative basis.
The National Foundation's vaccine advisory committee said after a meeting here last night that mass vaccinations with live, weakened polio viruses would be unwise at this time.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., July 7 -- Governor Rockefeller said today that he had not decided whether to recommend legislation requiring that a shelter against nuclear fall-out be constructed in every building in the state.

After the 10-cent tax on taxicab rides went into effect last week the columns of the local dailies reported the considerable dismay and disgruntlement of the drivers as the tax took its toll on tips. In sympathy with their predicament, I should like to offer them the memory of an afternoon just spent in Philadelphia, when I required the services of three of their colleagues in that city.

PITTSBURGH, July 7 -- For seven innings it was a serene sort of ball game. A. couple of den mothers could have managed Cub Scout troops at the annual picnic with as much competence as Messrs. Fred Haney and Casey Stengel in today's All-Star festival. Eddie Mathews hit a home run in the first inning and Al Kaline matched it in the fourth.

ZURICH, Switzerland, July 7 (AP) -- Martin Lauer of West Germany bettered the world record for the 110-meter hurdles tonight. He later was clocked at an international track and field meet in the fastest time ever for the 200-meter hurdles around a turn.

The sudden spurt of interest in "back-door" financing of certain Government spending programs holds the danger of obscuring, rather than clarifying, the essential issues involved in Congressional control of spending. Unfortunately, most members still seem to be missing the main point in this complex field.
PHILADELPHIA, July 7 (AP) -- A six-year study indicates that cancer does not run in families.

HANKSVILLE, Utah, July 7 (AP) -- The state aeronautics director estimated today that it cost at least $5,000 for a needless rescue operation while fourteen amateur boaters rode through the worst rapids in the Colorado River on rubber rafts.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., July 7 -- The Patchogue Hotel, once the headquarters of the Suffolk County Republican party and the scene of many conventions of both major parties, has been offered for sale to Suffolk and the Township of Brookhaven.

HAVANA, Cuba, July 7 -- The death penalty may henceforth the imposed on any person "who damages the national economy for the public treasury." This is provided in a decree of the Cuban revolutionary Government must published in the Official Gazette.
DETROIT, July 7 (AP) -- New car sales hit their fastest pace in more than three years in June, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (UPI) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, added his voice today to demands for the ouster of Paul M. Butler, Democratic National Chairman, because of his criticism of the party's Congressional leaders.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 7 -- The Asian and African group of nations decided today to ask the United Nations Security Council to look into the "deteriorating situation" in Algeria.
ALBANY, July 7 (AP) -- The Public Service Commission gave its approval today to what the agency said was "a history-making concept of railroad rate-making."

In its first change of ownership in eighty years, the five-story store and loft building sold by the Gardner estate to at 447 Broadway has been an investing client of the Harris Management Corporation, broker. The building, on a plot 25 by 200 feet, runs through the block to Mercer Street.

GOSHEN, N. Y., July 7 (AP) -- Johnny Simpson drove Matora Hanover to victory today in the $17,667.76 Coaching Club Oaks for 3-year-old trotters. Simpson became the first driver to win the Grand Circuit race three times.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday he would appoint one or more new members to the six-man Committee on Slum Clearance to "strengthen" the administration of the city's billion-dollar Title I program.

Edward R. Murrow's year's leave of absence, which began this month, may turn into a busman's holiday. It was learned yesterday that he will be involved in the production of two one-hour documentaries to be televised by the Columbia Broadcasting System during the 1959-60 season.

Federal Judge Edmund L. Palmieri declared a mistrial yesterday in a bank robbery case after eleven jurors and alternates had acknowledged reading a story in The New York Daily News described by the defense lawyer as "inflammatory and highly prejudicial."

It has been clear from the start that Russia did not raise the question of Berlin in order to settle it but in order not to settle it. Communists do not negotiate; they threaten, they blackmail, they demand, they denounce; they use so-called negotiations merely as one more weapon of propaganda and pressure to divide and conquer.
LONDON, July 7 -- Britain expects the four-power foreign minister's conference to pick up next Monday just about where it left off when it adjourned on June 20.
The first public offering of stock of Taft Broadcasting Company is being made today by an investment banking group headed by Harriman Ripley Co. The group is offering 483,322 shares at $15 a share.

" Jack the Giant Killer," the fairy tale, will be brought to the screen as a major color offering by producer Edward Small, it was announced yesterday by United Artists. Mr. Small recently completed "Solomon and Sheba," co-starring Yul Brynner and Gina Lollobrigida, which U. A. also will release.

Fall buying in the apparel market was quiet last week because of the long holiday weekend. Buyers, however, are actively seeking late summer and trans-seasonal merchandise. Resident buying offices reported that reorders for fall were broadening into a variety of departments.

Archbishop Joseph Francis Rummel will integrate the parochial schools of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New Orleans "at the earliest possible opportunity and definitely not later than when the public schools are integrated."

BAASTAD, Sweden, July 7 (UPI) -- Alex Olmedo took only thirty minutes to gain the second round in men's' singles today at Baastad's tennis tournament. His Davis Cup team-mate, Barry MacKay, was upset by Thorwald Moe of Norway.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., July 7 -- Arthur S. Flemming, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, declared today that "the time has come for the Federal Government to become an effective partner in higher education."
Ohio has set Aug. 11 as the new date for its delayed offering of $30,000,000 of capital improvement construction bonds, due from 1959 to 1974. The offering was originally dated for July 21.

THE form of contract bridge called Chicago has become increasingly popular in recent years, especially in clubs where business men drop in to play two or three rubbers late in the afternoon, en route from office to home and dinner.
There have been misquotations and misrepresentations concerning the fight of the Ridgewood-Glendale Taxpayers' Committee against the bus transfer of children to its community.
ROME, July 7 -- A twenty-minute free-for-all in the regional Parliament in Palermo tonight focused national attention again on the shaky political situation in Sicily.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 7 -- The police here will try again to halt speeding by the use of radar even though the Town Court persists in refusing to admit evidence based on the device.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Senate Democrats took the lead tonight in cutting $383,500,000 from the military-aid and defense-support provisions of President Eisenhower's foreign aid bill.

Hiram Walker, Gooderham Worts, Ltd., distiller, in the quarter and nine months ended May 31 increased its earnings above those for the similar periods of the preceding year, according to the report issued yesterday.

Most of America's wholesale dress designers show their fall collections to the fashion press and store buyers in May and June. However, two of the most important, Norman Norell of Traina-Norell and James Galanos, have waited until this week to present theirs.

BONN, Germany, July 7 -- West Germany is letting the Arab countries know that she is prepared to buy arms from them as well as from Israel if they can meet the conditions set by the Federal Defense Ministry.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 7 -- The fourteenth New York Yacht Club junior regatta which sailed off the Riverside Yacht Club had 104 starters and perfect racing conditions today.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- Gov. William F. Quinn of Hawaii invited President Eisenhower today to an Admission Day celebration after the territory becomes the fifty state.

The Illinois Central Railroad cleared $5,740,418, or $1.84 a share, in the first half on gross revenues of $133,972,462, according to a preliminary estimate made by the company yesterday. In the first half of 1958 the road had a net income of $5,477,867, or $1.76 a share, and gross revenues were $127,106,002.
MARION, N. C., July 7 (UPI) -- Twenty-six cars of a Clinchfield Railroad freight train plunged off a trestle today and ten cars filled with alcohol blazed up in an explosive fire.
TANANARIVE, Madagascar, July 7 (UPI) -- France told twelve of her former African colonies today that they soon would be able to send their representatives to international organizations.
A 26-year-old waitress crashed through a plate glass window in Greenwich Village and was killed at 4:30 A. M. yesterday in a fight with another woman.

Several hundred volunteers and guests of the Cancer Care Chapter in Westchester County will be guests of Mrs. Frank A. Vanderlip July 20 on a tour of Beechwood at Scarborough, N. Y., the Vanderlip estate.

MONROE, Wash., July 7 (UPI) -- A successful trick and a blast of tear gas ended the escape attempt today of four convicts who had threatened to kill thirty-eight hostages, including women and children.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The United States will ask the Russians flatly when the Big Four foreign ministers' conference resumes next Monday whether they have withdrawn what the West views as an ultimatum on Berlin.
Actors Equity Association has made a cash gift of $2,500 to the North Jersey Playhouse in Fort Lee, N. J., to keep the theatre in operation.

An unusually clear picture of an advertising agency operating in the television industry was obtained yesterday by the Federal Communications Commission at a hearing in the United States Court House on Foley Square.

James D. Horan, author of several books of Western Americana, will have his newest volume published in November by Crown. Called "A Pictorial History of the Great American West," it will contain 1,500 illustrations, of which 1,000 will be photographs.
WHATEVER happened to the sack dress? Now it can be told. It has gone to Greenwich Village.
News that made a steel strike seem all but unavoidable hit the stock market late in yesterday's session and there followed a sharp reversal of a downward trend.
Lowell M. Birrell, lawyer and financier, was indicted by a New York County grand jury yesterday on charges of stealing stock valued at $14,000,000 from two companies he controlled.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- A House subcommittee's investigation of the so-called "munitions lobby" got off to a slow, polite start today. That start made particular reference to retired military officers who work for defense industries.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (UPI) -- Representative Abraham M. Multer, Democrat of New York, urged Congress today to block a plan by a manufacturing concern to use United States savings bond stamps to promote sales of a "toilet bowl cleanser."
The A. P. food-store chain charged yesterday that it had been forced to close more than 400 retail outlets because of a jurisdictional dispute between two Teamster Union locals.
A 16-year-old boy who was shot in a juvenile gang attack Monday night died yesterday in Metropolitan Hospital.

Copper prices fell in active trading yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York. All months dropped to new lows for the move or for the life of the contracts. Trading was influenced by sharply lower London prices and a reduction of a 1/2 cent a pound in custom smelter prices here.
Although the Fourth of July week-end is but the recent past, many New York society persons have already made some plans for their autumn or winter theatre going.
Donald Boris, president of Hannibal Associates, Inc, 99 Wall Street, was arrested yesterday on an indictment charging fraudulent practices in the sale of securities. He was held in $1,500 bail.

Punta Gorda had little diffifulty taking the nominal feature at Belmont Park yesterday. Under the competent guidance of Sidney Cole, the filly scored by more than four lengths over Tikopia of the Pebblebrook Farm.
It was Borough Hall in Queens -- not Brooklyn -- that housed the city's first rabid bat. The Health Department acknowledged yesterday that it had announced an erroneous location for the bat Monday.

THE Russians have done it again. Some 200 of them swarmed into Madison Square Garden last night at the behest of S. Hurok to put on a "Russian Festival of Music and Dance," as a live supplement to the Soviet Exhibition at the Coliseum, and the building fairly shook with the impact of all that vitality.
DUBLIN, Ireland, July 7 (AP) -- Maria Bueno, the Brazilian girl who won the women's singles title at Wimbledon, upset the Irish -- by not showing up for the Irish open tennis championship today.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Three Administration officials endorsed the main provision of a House bill to stimulate private investment overseas, but said that budgetary considerations required that it be modified.
Dr. Nnamdi Azikiwe, Premier of Eastern Nigeria, got off yesterday to a busy round of promoting American interest in his country's educational and economic systems.

TRENTON, July 7 -- The Essex County grand jury was directed today to conduct a second investigation of a multimillion-dollar project of the Passaic Valley Sewerage Commission. The jury was told to examine the project for possible instances of criminal misconduct.

MOSCOW, July 7 (UPI) -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev told seven visiting United States Governors today that the Soviet Union wanted to be like their "big, rich and strong country." He said the United States was sometimes "selfish" in envying Soviet progress.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 7 -- The new forty-nine-star United States flag took its place today alongside the other eighty-one flags of the members of the United Nations.
Almost everyone is concerned -- in a personal if not also in a business way -- with what the weather is going to be.
Custom smelters trimmed the price of refined copper another half-cent a pound yesterday, to 29 1/2 cents, as copper markets abroad weakened.

The enduring affection of New York audiences for Viennese music was demonstrated last night at Lewisohn Stadium, where a sizable audience turned up for the Stadium's seventeenth annual All-Viennese Night.
Ups and downs were split almost fifty-fifty on the New York Stock Exchange during the second quarter of this year, although the market averages set new highs with some regularity.

This week, most of America's custom millinery designers are presenting their new autumn collections to the press and store buyers. The trends that emerge from these showings will establish the fashion pattern for all hats for fall.

A relocation consultant for the Committee on Slum Clearance said yesterday that committee officials had "asked" him to subcontract part of his work to one man and to take on another as a coordinator. The committee's director denied this.

PITTSBURGH, July 7 -- When the 69-year-old Casey Stengel retires in the not-too-distant future, the job of managing the Yankees could be offered to the 50-year-old Al Lopez, currently the manager of the Chicago White Sox.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The House of Representatives passed today for a second time a bill designed to overrule a Supreme Court decision that freed a youth who had confessed to rape and was sentenced to death.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee approved today a defense money bill carrying more than $40,000,000,000.
Ted Bates, Inc., which has grown rapidly without opening branch offices, has purchased John Hobson Partners, Ltd., of London.

A poll taken recently by the Institute of Student Opinion indicated that one of the most elemental and rewarding of pleasures is losing its battle with progress -- the simple art of reading for enjoyment.

The New York Weather Bureau has placed a translucent fiber-glass ball eighteen feet in diameter atop the R. C. A. Building. If experiments with the ball succeed, the bureau expects to move its headquarters to the building.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed unchanged to 9 points (45 cents a bale) up yesterday. The far months showed the most strength.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (UPI) -- Representative Francis E. Walter, chairman of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, introduced a bill today to revive the industrial security program struck down by the Supreme Court.

STRATFORD-ON-AVON, England, July 7 -- Tonight at the Shakespeare Memorial Theatre expectation ran high for Laurence Olivier's appearance in this centenary season as "Coriolanus." It is a part for which he is equipped beyond most actors and in which he has not appeared for twenty-two years.

A patent for a die-cast, eight-cylinder aluminum engine block for automobiles has been issued to Alfred F. Bauer, assistant general manager and chief engineer of the Doehler-Jarvis division of the National Lead Company, the division announced yesterday.
The United Steelworkers of America notified Vice President Richard M. Nixon yesterday that it would not agree to another strike truce.

KAMPALA, Uganda, July 7 -- Sir Frederick Crawford, Governor of Uganda, today ordered six Africans deported to a remote area of this British protectorate. They are accused of fomenting violence in connection with an African boycott of Asian shops.

The City Council was quietly informed yesterday by Majority Leader Joseph T. Sharkey that it would be kept in session this summer unti it acted on the long-debated Code of Ethics for 225,000 city employes.

EAST FALMOUTH, Mass., July 7 -- Marooned at sea! That's what happened to us today. Cliff Davis, the septuagenarian fishing enthusiast, went after some of those yearling bluefish that have been causing a bit of a stir on Cape Cod. He said they made good eating.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 7 -- The major Opposition parties apparently ruled out today any possibility that Premier David Ben-Gurion could form a minority government that would exclude the direct participation of "rebel" Left-Wing Ministers.
PITTSBURGH, July 7 -- The National League settled an old score with Casey Stengel today.
BATON ROUGE, La., July 7 Gov. Earl K. Long held a series of conferences today in a reported effort to gain support for a special session of the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- The House rejected today President Eisenhower's reorganization plan to give the Secretary of Agriculture greater authority over the transfer of forest and mineral lands. The roll-call vote was 266 to 124.
ATLANTIC CITY, July 7 -- Ten thousand Shriners staged a colorful five-hour parade here today before 75,000 enthusiastic spectators in pleasant summer weather.
Optimism was expressed here yesterday that the worldwide Italian seamen's strike might end by Saturday.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (UPI) -- A financial consultant said today that the small business investment act was of little or no value to 95 per cent of the nation's companies.
KARACHI, Pakistan, July 7 -- Flashy American cars, air-conditioned bungalows and nightclub parties, once the mark of the successful Pakistani, have gone out of fashion.

United States Government bonds gave ground in light trading yesterday, with the greater losses registered by issues in the intermediate and long - term maturities. The mark-downs range to 1/2 point in early trading. There was no pressure on the list, however, and the declines were pared somewhat in afternoon trading.
Our country and its institutions owe much to Massachusetts, as every student of American history knows, for both the concept and the actuality of civil rights.

ALBANY, July 8 -- The state's highest court declined today to remove from office the Democratic Election Commissioner chosen by the Suffolk County Board of Supervisors without the blessing of the Democratic county chairman.

PARIS, July 8 -- Two hundred United States fighter-bombers will be moved soon from bases in France to Britain and West Germany because of a failure to settle the terms for stockpiling nuclear bombs here.
BALTIMORE, July 8 -- The Capital Airlines plane that crashed near here May 12 was about 7,000 feet below its assigned altitude when fire flashed amidships and the craft began to disintegrate.

Vital Force had a neck the better of Ouija Board in the $36,450 Tremont Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday. The margin was satisfactory to the favorite players in the crowd of 21,389, for Vital Force was the closing choice in the test of five and a half furlongs.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended July 1:

" A $40,000,000 redevelopment of lower Manhattan's East River waterfront was announced today by Vincent A. G. O'Connor, Commissioner of the New York City Department of Marine and Aviation. The one-and-three-quarter-mile section of waterfront, extending from the Battery to Corlears Hook, will be rebuilt by the construction of seven new freight ship terminals, a marina and a heliport, Mr. O'Connor stated."

MOSCOW, July 8 (UPI) -- The Soviet Union today selected fifty-seven athletes, headed by Vasily Kuznetsov, Tamara Press and Mme. Nina Ponomareva, to meet the United States in a track meet at Philadelphia's Franklin Field, July 18-19.
A charge of homicide was placed against two youths yesterday as a result of the killing of a 16-year-old gang member at Manhattan Avenue and 109th Street Monday night.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- Backers of a third major league picked up an ally today in one of the local baseball buffs, a fan by the name of Richard M. Nixon.
One of the merchant marine industry's leading executives, Lewis A. Lapham, has resigned as president and director of Grace Line, Inc., to take over one of the top banking posts in this city.
The election of William T. Marx as senior vice president for planning, organization and industrial relations of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation was announced yesterday.
Russian surgeons have succeeded in attaching an artery from the chest to the artery supplying blood to the heart muscle in many human patients with "good results," it was reported here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- An improved Terrier missile, which the Navy said could "intercept any present-day supersonic bomber many miles from its intended target," was announced today.
MORRISTOWN, N. J., July 8 -- A complete diagnostic service for retarded children within one clinic was opened here tonight at Morristown Memorial Hospital.
All box seats have been sold for tomorrow's opening-night program of the Empire State Music Festival at the Anthony Wayne Recreation Area of Harriman State Park.
CAMDEN, N. J., July 8 -- The Senator Robert F. Wagner, New York's new $899,000 fireboat, was launched this afternoon at the John H. Mathis Company shipyard.

ROME, July 8 -- Some of the dock workers in Genoa and the neighboring Ligurian ports have come out on strike in support of the seamen whose walkout has immobilized Italian ships for more than a month.

LONDON, July 8 -- Prices continued to move irregularly within narrow limits in most parts of the stock exchange here today, although the undertone of markets as a whole remained firm. Buying and selling was evenly matched and prices showed no decided trend.
WARSAW, July 8 (AP) -- Twenty to fifty persons were reported today to have been injured in a clash between police and Roman Catholics at a village near Lublin, in eastern Poland on June 26.
Mayor Wagner conferred briefly at City Hall yesterday with his five-man committee studying the economic impact of the 10-cent tax on taxi rides upon taxicab owners and drivers.
BARI, Italy, July 8 (Reuters) -- A man armed with a pistol forced a Yugoslav pilot to land an airliner carrying twenty-seven persons at the Bari airport tonight.

The resignation of Godfrey P. Schmidt from the Board of Monitors appointed by Federal Judge Letts to rid the Brotherhood of Teamsters of dictatorship and corruption, if accepted, will be a setback to teamster reform.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Senate investigators heard charges today that Ohio teamsters' leaders suddenly switched their political support to former Senator George H. Bender, a Republican, in 1954 while trying to quash his investigation of their operations.

This week, most of America's custom millinery designers are presenting their new autumn collections to the press and store buyers. The trends that emerge from these showings will establish the fashion pattern for all hats for fall.
While the United States has been suffering from a steady loss of its monetary gold stocks, the United Kingdom has been enjoying developments quite the reverse.

A contract for the purchase of the four buildings at 203 to 209 East Seventy-seventh Street, east of Third Avenue, has been signed by Louis Goldfarb and Harvey Roer. They are acquiring the property from Thomas M. Graham.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Racial segregation that interferes with a citizen's equality of opportunity in the economic and political fields is "morally wrong," President Eisenhower said today.

Since 1954 dictators in five South American countries have been overthrown. They are the subject of "Twilight of the Tyrants," by Tad Szulc, which Holt will issue in October. Mr. Szulc, a South American correspondent for this newspaper, examines the personalities and motives of the late Getulio Vargas of Brazil, Juan D. Peron of Argentina, Manuel A. Odria of Peru, Gustavo Rojas Pinilla of Colombia and Marcos Perez Jimenez of Venezuela.

A merger of the New York Trust Company into the Chemical Corn Exchange Bank to form the third largest bank in New York and the fourth largest in the country was approved by stockholders at simultaneous special meetings yesterday afternoon.

Now that First Deputy Premier Frol Kozlov has arrived is it too much to hope that someone will raise the question again of the fate of the eleven Americans who are either alive or dead in the Soviet Union as a result of the brutal shooting down of the United States Military Transport plane last September? My recollection is that only one reporter raised this question when Anastas Mikoyan was here.

The Long Island Lighting Company sold yesterday $25,000,000 of thirty-year first mortgage bonds to investment bankers headed by The First Boston Corporation and Blyth Co., Inc. The price was 101.489 for obligations bearing a 5 1/4 per cent interest coupon.
OCEANPORT, N. J., July 8 (AP) -- The Rockburn Farm's Recite scored her fourth straight victory today, romping home five lengths in front in the $24,150 Miss Woodford Stakes at Monmouth Park.

" West Side Story" was named by seventeen of the eighteen London drama critics as the best foreign musical of the 1958-59 season in a poll taken by Variety, trade paper of the amusement industry. Thirteen critics voted for Eugene O'Neill's "Long Day's Journey Into Night" as the best new foreign play.
The Waterfront Commission lost a round yesterday in its efforts to overcome legal delays in a case against nine dock workers and a Hoboken pier boss.
Contract negotiations between a shipyard workers' union and the shipbuilding division of the Bethlehem Steel Company have been recessed until next Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The vetoed omnibus housing bill, of Democratic origin, was modified by the Senate-House conferees in some respects from the drafts separately approved by the two branches of Congress. But the specific features listed by the President as the reasons for his veto certainly do not sustain the implications of this passage in Senate Majority Leader Johnson's protest of the President's action:

LONDON, July 8 -- Government and Labor party leaders expressed confidence today that the four-power foreign ministers' conference reconvening in Geneva Monday could reach some kind of limited agreement.
A Canadian producer of uranium is proposing to revise sinking fund payments on an issue of $51,000,000 of general mortgage bonds in the United States and Canada to avert default.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- President Eisenhower declared today there was no reason why a Roman Catholic should not be elected President of the United States.

A thirty-five-hour week for 2,500 of New York's 35,000 hotel workers will go into effect next June under an agreement signed yesterday by the Hotel Trades Council and the Hotel Association of New York City, Inc. All of the 35,000 will receive pay increases.

All world sugar positions dropped to new lows for the life of the contracts yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The spot price was off 3 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) to 2.72 cents a pound, the lowest level since pre-World War II.
A "thinking man's" cigarette sponsors two television shows that are not necessarily a thinking man's programs, an advertising man said yesterday.
" The Court of Human Relations'' faced an off-screen problem in labor relations yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 8 -- Movie men -- and perhaps only movie men -- can spend two months in Europe and return without a word about politics, museums or historic churches.

TWO soloists were featured with Alexander Smallens and the Stadium Symphony Orchestra at Lewisohn Stadium last night. They were Joseph Szigeti, playing the Brahms Violin Concerto, and Anna Xydis, pianist, heard in the Rachmaninoff Concerto No. 3 in D minor.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- President Eisenhower reiterated today that he and General de Gaulle planned to meet "at the first opportunity."
MIAMI BEACH, July 8 -- A "militant, constructive" approach to contract negotiations was recommended today to the International Longshoremen's Association.

William Z. Foster, 78-year-old former head of the Communist party in the United States, lost a motion in Federal Court yesterday to have two indictments dismissed. He also was refused permission to go to the Soviet Union for medical treatment.

GOSHEN, N. Y., July 8 (AP) -- Hickory Pride won the $7,350 Historic-Dickerson Cup in two straight heats on the Grand Circuit card at Historic Track today to further his claim as the favorite for the Hambletonian Stake for 3-year-old trotters at Duquoin, Ill., Sept. 2.
MOSCOW, July 8 (AP) -- The Harlem Globetrotters were strolling through the Kremlin today when a big Russian car stopped and out stepped Nikita S. Khrushchev.
A semi-automatic navigation system that will permit a missile-firing submarine to fix its position with a probable error of less than a mile was "launched" yesterday on Long Island.
The Transport Workers Union accused the Transit Authority yesterday of contract violations, demanded a meeting by next Monday and threatened "job action to end this stalemate."

Petroleum product inventories reflected marked seasonal patterns last week. Gasoline stocks fell sharply as more motorists took to the road for holiday and vacation driving. The decrease was more than offset by a rise in supplies of light fuel oil, used mainly for heating purposes.

Following is a report on the fall fashion collection of James Galanos, the last of the leading American designers to show their new styles to store buyers and the press. The clothes will be in the stores in September.
" ANATOMY OF A MORAL,"* by Milovan Djilas, is the story of a personal tragedy heightened by two love affairs. Both took place in Yugoslavia. Both ended in disenchantment.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- The Senate Appropriations Committee approved today a bill carrying $1,258,836,300 for the construction and planning of water projects in the current fiscal year.
CHICAGO, July 8 -- The National Safety Council cited twenty-six domestic airlines today for "outstanding" 1958 passenger safety records.
The present millinery showings include a number of hat shapes that are similar and easily confused. Following are the original definitions of the most prevalent styles.

An investment banking group managed jointly by Phelps, Fenn Co., Glore, Forgan Co., C. J. Devine Co., and F. S. Smithers Co. entered the best bid yesterday for $10,000,000 of Texas permanent university fund bonds, due from 1960 to 1979.
Teamster Union officials agreed yesterday on a formula for settling the intra-union dispute that has hampered negotiations in the twenty-three-day strike against the A. P. food-store chain.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- Representatives of the National Cotton Council today urged Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, to start action designed to limit imports of cotton textiles.
HAVANA, July 8 -- All contractors have been ordered to present full records of their negotiations with the Batista regime to the present Government within thirty days.
MASSENA, N. Y., July 8 (AP) -- The Reynolds Metals Company's $88,000,000 plant, drawing power from the St. Lawrence Project, begins smelting aluminum tomorrow.
DUBLIN, July 8 (AP) -- The world lawn tennis officials today set up a special committee to study rules governing amateurism in a move that could lead to open tournaments.

BRIDGE hands played in New York clubs -- or in clubs anywhere, for that matter -- are often handed around from player to player for opinions, especially when the hands confronted their holders with agonizing problems or when they resulted in large and avoidable losses.

The Southern Nitrogen Company, Inc., announced plans yesterday to offer a block of 136,400 shares of common stock, subject to approval of the Securities and Exchange Commission. The offering is to be handled by underwriters managed by Harriman Ripley Co., Inc.

A 28-year-old Wall Street banker who was arrested last Thursday after a three-mile chase waived hearings on four charges yesterday. He was continued free in a total of $1,000 bail pending trial in Special Sessions.

CINCINNATI, July 8 (AP) -- Mayo Smith was dropped tonight as manager of the floundering Cincinnati Reds and Freddie Hutchinson, the manager of Seattle in the Pacific Coast League, was named to succeed him.
CHICAGO, July 8 (AP) -- Heavy general selling depressed grain futures sharply, almost all along the line in late dealings today on the Board of Trade.

TANANARIVE, Madagascar, July 8 -- The crucial decision facing the new French Community -- to remain a centralized union and risk secession of its restless African members or to become a loose commonwealth on the British pattern -- came into sharp focus here today.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., July 8 -- The eighteenth annual benefit fair of Christ Protestant Episcopal Church will be held on the lawn and in- the parish house on Saturday. It will feature the Oyster Bay Country Store. Mrs. Malcolm G. Davis of Mill Neck is general chairman.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 8 -- The Twin Cities of Minneapolis and St. Paul are seeking to bury long-standing rivalries in order to support a single entry in a third major baseball league.
CHICAGO, July 8 -- Federal Judge Julius H. Miner enjoined today the city of Chicago from interfering with the showing of the film, "Anatomy of a Murder."
The Fairbanks Whitney Corporation is embroiled in another law suit stemming from the days when it was the Penn-Texas Corporation and seeking to purchase control of Fairbanks, Morse Co.

Your June 30 editorial and the letter from a New York City teacher published July 4 do not give complete background information on the Board of Education's plan to set aside parking space for teachers at "special service" schools.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- President Eisenhower reproached Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev today for threatening war over Berlin.
JERSEY CITY, July 8 -- A sweeping investigation into all phases of cases involving payoffs to Teamster Union officials was promised today by Lawrence A. Whipple, Hudson County prosecutor.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The Treasury's plan for limited tax incentives on foreign investments was criticized on several grounds today by witnesses before the House Ways and Means Committee.
Thousands of fans will mourn Goliathus goliathus, the giant beetle at the American Museum of Natural History, which died yesterday at the venerable age of about seven months.
BRUNSWICK, Ga., July 8 (AP) -- Aviation Metalsmith Lester Landrum Jr., 19 years old, was sucked into the engine of a Navy Banshee jet plane last night at Glynco Naval Air Station.

HAWORTH, N. J., July 8 -- Mrs. Joseph B. Cralle 2d of Montclair took a one-stroke lead as the thirty-sixth annual Wommen's New Jersey Golf Association's fifty-four-hole medal play championship got under way today.

BROOKVILLE, L. I., July 8 -- There were smiles on the faces of a group of children here today as they planted tiny Japanese evergreen trees on a plot of bare ground. The smiles indicated a promising start for a project only partly intended to improve the landscape.
CAIRO, July 8 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser launched a "school for democracy" experiment today with local elections throughout Egypt and Syria.
FORT LEE, N. J., July 8 -- Miss Arlene Nesbitt, 21 years old, a blond registered nurse from Mineola, L. I., tonight won the right to represent New York State in the Miss Universe contest this year.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- The American Farm Bureau Federation declared today that a "food for peace" plan would make underdeveloped nations totally and indefinitely dependent on shipments of surplus United States farm crops.

The purpose of this letter is to point up a recurring problem in the conduct of our foreign relations -- namely, the inhibitions imposed on effective American leadership in world affairs by the political system and politics in the United States.

Governor Rockefeller declared last night that he definitely intended to ask the Legislature to pass measures "along the general lines" proposed by a special executive task force for the protection of the state's population against radioactive fall-out.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (UPI) -- Following is a transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today:
REHOVOTH, Israel, July 8 -- Abba Eban said tonight that the world faced serious peril because the conquests of modern science were not getting through to the nations that needed them most.

BUENOS AIRES, July 8 -- Financial circles were worried today about the effects that a 41 per cent wage increase granted to light and power workers might have on the country's Monetary Stabilization Plan.
MIAMI, July 8 -- Maj. Pedro Luis Diaz Lanz, sought as a traitor by Cuba since his sudden resignation as head of the Cuban Air Force, is in the United States as a resident alien.

Title I is a section of the Housing Act of 1949 designed to bring private capital into slum clearance. It permits cities to acquire substandard areas and resell them at a markdown to private developers. The Federal Government pays two-thirds of the difference between the original cost and the resale price; the city pays the other third.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The House Ways and Means Committee approved today, 18 to 7, a bill giving President Eisenhower the right to disregard the interest-rate ceiling on Government bonds when he finds higher rates necessary "in the national interest."
Ralph J. Bunche said yesterday that he had been told by the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens, that neither he nor his son could join because they were Negroes.
CHICAGO, July 8 -- Frol R. Kozlov toured the great steel plants just south of this city today, but his highest words of praise were reserved for the size of the steak he had for lunch.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- President Eisenhower said today that he did not use his veto "lightly" but rather as a means to promote legislation that would benefit the country and keep it solvent.
CHICAGO, July 8 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Following are the highlights of President Eisenhower's news conference today:

HAVANA, July 6 -- The Government is moving rapidly in Pinar del Rio Province, where Cuba's finest tobacco is grown, toward the agrarian reform that will expropriate millions of acres and distribute it among the landless.
CONAKRY, Guinea, July 8 -- President Sekou Toure, declared, in effect, yesterday that the United States must revise its attitude toward colonial problems if it wants to make friends in Africa.

LANGLEY FIELD, Va., July 8 -- Most of Robert Rowe Gilruth's adult life has been devoted to finding ways for man to travel faster on water and in the air. Now this scientific obsession with speed has carried him to a new dimension of travel -- space flight.
A motion to dismiss incompetency charges against Benjamin Cymrot, suspended executive officer of the old Bureau of Real Estate, was denied yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, July 8 -- The foremost Soviet Union designer of aircraft, Andrei N. Tupolev, wound up a five-day tour of Southern California's airplane and missile plants today.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The Senate passed a heavily cut foreign aid authorization bill tonight after six days of protracted political fighting. The vote was 65 to 26.

LANGLEY FIELD, Va., July 8 -- The seven Mercury Astronauts have lived on a space diet, gone skin-diving in the ocean deeps and tumbled free of the earth's gravitational pull in preparation for the first human flight into outer space.
ROME, July 8 -- An unusually successful posthumous novel by a Sicilian nobleman won Italy's most coveted literary prize last night.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- The retired general or admiral who may sit in the back room while contracts are negotiated, or just gets information from old friends, was nominated today as a target for anti-influence legislation.
LONDON, July 8 -- Britain accepted without serious complaint today the news that more United states aircraft of the Atlantic alliance's defense forces would be stationed here.
Margaret Truman has been invited to make her Broadway stage debut in "The Sound of Music," starring Mary Martin.

MEXICO CITY, July 8 -- A major advance in the program of President Adolfo Lopez Mateos to offer large quantities of food to the laboring classes at low prices was under way today with about 60,000 tons of fish being offered to the public at less than 1 1/2 pesos (12 cents) a pound.

The San Pedro, Calif., plant of the Todd Shipyards Corporation has been awarded a $36,000,000 contract for the construction of three ships for American Mail Line, Ltd., the Maritime Administration announced yesterday.

HADERSLEV, Denmark, Thursday, July 9 (AP) -- An explosion and fire flashed yesterday through an excursion boat loaded with a happy, singing picnic crowd. Early today the police said forty-four persons were known dead.
The Standard Oil Company _ (New Jersey) announced yesterday that it planned to build another large refinery in West Germany.

The Greenway Apartments, a six-story building at 10 Holder Place in Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, has been purchased by an investing client of Emanuel Fein in a deal negotiated by Robert P. Sheldon, Inc., broker. The building occupies the square block bounded by Holder Place, Slocum Crescent and Burns and Bye Streets.
Under the leadership of rails, oils and drugs, stocks made an irregular advance yesterday and achieved new high marks.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, told the Senate today that he had called on Federal housing officials to eliminate Louis I. Pokrass from the sponsors of the mid-Harlem slum clearance project in New York.

EAST FALMOUTH, Mass, July 8 -- Because luck plays such an important part in snaring swordfish, Capt. Bud Tietje of the 30-foot sports fisherman, T. G., thought he had everything working for him this morning as he cruised into Vineyard Sound from this Cape Cod port.
NORWICH, Conn., July 8 -- The future of civilization lies in the hands of English-speaking nations, Lord Mayor Michael W. Bulman of Norwich, England, said here today.

The United States dollar made news among stock buyers in London yesterday. For the first time in months it sold at a premium rather than a discount, in terms of the pound sterling. The premium on dollars used to buy American securities on the London Stock Exchange was 1/4 of 1 per cent, compared with a discount of about 11/32 of 1 per cent the day before.

ROME, July 8 -- A Christian Democrat, Ferdinando Stagno d'Alcontres, tonight became President (Speaker) of the newly elected regional parliament of the semi-autonomous island of Sicily. His election was considered a victory for the Christian Democratic party, which rules Italy and seeks to re-establish its control of Sicily.

CLEVELAND, July 8 (AP) -- The Catholic Daughters of America, at its final session here yesterday, approved a resolution criticizing the recent United States Supreme Court decision in regard to the movie "Lady Chatterlye's Lover."
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- Government figures showed today that business men slowed their build-up of inventories in May and also recorded a smaller sales increase than in April.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 8 -- Adelphi College presented degrees to seventy-nine graduates of its evening division at a ceremony here today.

Electric power production fell to about 13,200,000,000 kilowatt-hours last week from a record of 13,749,000,000 the week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. In the like week of last year output totaled 11,210,000,000 kilowatt-hours.
There is an agency here that handles seventeen competitive accounts, yet about whom it can be said it "really knows its groceries."
Bidding on the Treasury's cash offering of $2,000,000,000 of one-year bills dominated the market for fixed-interest securities yesterday.
The United Steelworkers of America rejected yesterday a plea by President Eisenhower for indefinite extension of the two-week strike truce already granted by the union.

The Nov. 6 performance of "Heartbreak House" will benefit the Park Association of New York City. The revival of the George Bernard Shaw Play, which stars Pamela Brown, Maurice Evans, Sam Levene and Diane Cilento, is scheduled to open at the National Theatre on Oct. 18.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 8 -- A station wagon driven by a man whose license had been suspended for speeding fatally injured a 9-year-old boy today.

Safeway Stores, Inc, reported yesterday the highest first-half earnings in its thirty-three-year history. Sales of the nation's second largest food chain in the initial six months of 1959 exceeded $1,000,000,000 for the first time, Robert A. Magowan, president, said.

MILWAUKEE, July 8 (UPI) -- Ray Sinkowski, Hamtramck, Mich., eighth - seeded United States player, upset the No. 1 seeded foreigner, Ian Vermaak, South Africa, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 1, in the Western open tennis tournament today.
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, July 8 -- The Caribbean radio war, a reflection of the political conflicts raging in the region, is reaching a fever pitch these hot nights.

Control of the Davega Stores Corporation, which operates twenty-seven sporting goods, radio-television, appliance and apparel stores in the metropolitan area, has been acquired by a group headed by Max A. Geller and Joseph and Melvin Axler.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- A Chinese, who once directed a research project for the Navy, and his family were denied admittance to two Maryland beaches on July 4 because they were "not Caucasians."
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The New York Central Railroad disclosed a new plan today for discontinuing West Shore commuter service in New York and New Jersey.

ALBANY, July 8 -- The Court cf Appeals upheld today the freeing of one delegate to the Apalachin crime convention who had been jailed on a charge of contempt before the State Investigation Commission.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 8 -- Dr. Clayton F. Andrews, a surgeon of Lincoln, Neb., was installed today as leader for the next twelve months of more than 800,000 Shriners in the United States, Canada, Mexico and the Panama Canal Zone.

Thomas J. Shanahan, vice chairman of the Committee on Slum Clearance, aroused Mayor Wagner's anger yesterday by declaring that he agreed with Robert Moses, the chairman, that the city's billion-dollar slum clearance program was "a dead duck."

BRATISLAVA, Czechoslovakia, July 6 -- A quiet cultural and economic revolution is spreading from Bratislava into the hinterland of Slovakia. The old pattern of village life there is breaking down under the impact of modern communications and industrial development.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (UPI) -- Representative Gordon H. Scherer, Republican of Ohio, asserted today that there were at least 2,000 potential saboteurs working in United States defense plants.
Field trials for pointers, setters, spaniels and retrievers flourish in the summer, but nothing much is heard about them because they carry little weight.

A floor in Canada House, 680 Fifth Avenue at Fifty-fourth Street, has been leased by the Perini Corporation, heavy construction concern with a home office in Framingham, Mass. The lessee will open a New York office late this summer.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, July 8 -- Queen Juliana of the Netherlands welcomed Baudouin I, King of the Belgians, here today for a visit that emphasized the firmness of the ties binding the Benelux Union.
About 25,000 building trade workers have been laid off in the week since 1,200 truck drivers who haul cement and other materials went on strike.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- Funds to help pay for four more atomic submarines are included in the $39,500,000,000 defense bill now waiting Senate action, Senate sources said today.

The Yankees got started on another climb toward the top of the American League last night as they steam-rollered past the Red Sox, 11 to 5, in the first of a string of six games with the array Billy Jurges has just taken over as manager.

The building containing sixty-six apartments at 8 to 16 East Fourth Street, Mount Vernon, has been sold by Soltzer Lampert, realty operators, to the Sason Realty Corporation of Flushing, Queens. It was sold for cash over mortgages amounting to $270,000 in a deal negotiated by Joseph R. Ruffino of the Kraham Realty Company.

The Alabama Gas Corporation has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering a proposed public offering of $4,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, due in 1984, and a subscription offering of 30,843 shares of $100 par value cumulative preferred stock with common stock purchase warrants.
NEWARK, July 8 -- Representatives of five railroads operating over drawbridges in New Jersey argued today that their safety devices were adequate.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 6 points (30 cents a bale) off to 2 points (10 cents a bale) up yesterday. Prices moved in a narrow range all day.

CHARLESTON, S. C., July 8 (UPI) -- Tropical storm Cindy, no longer of hurricane intensity but still a dangerous storm, hit the South Carolina coast tonight at the south end of Bull Bay north of Charleston.

STRATFORD, Conn., July 8 -- The revels are in full cry at the American Shakespeare Festival. This happy news is relayed as a result of a rollicking performance of "The Merry Wives of Windsor," played here this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Invitations to a "small off-the-record party" honoring the Air Force's chief strategist for missiles have been sent out by officials of three companies holding major defense contracts.
DIONE LUCAS, the doyenne of fine cuisine in America, has opened a new cooking school and catering service.
George Ball was defeated in the New York State clay court championship yesterday. Ball, No. 5, was the first of the seeded players to make his exit.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 8 -- The question of Israel's re-establishing diplomatic relations with West Germany has not been brought up in recent years because West Germany was "not ready for this," an Israeli Foreign Ministry source said today.
BATON ROUGE, La., July 8 -- Gov. Earl K. Long's physicians expressed concern tonight over his sinking condition and his family began gathering at the Executive Mansion.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The Senate Rules and Administration Committee approved unanimously today a bill to "make realistic" the law on election campaign receipts and expenditures.

THE only strategic concept that rates the description of being brilliant is the one that works. Hence it must be stated that Charles Dillon Stengel struck a cerebral clinker or two in his losing venture during Tuesday's All-Star game on a glorious afternoon in Pittsburgh. Fred Haney's mental gymnastics were more productive -- as the 5-4 score for the National Leaguers attests.

OBERLIN, Ohio, July 8 -- In its first major pronouncement, the United Church of Christ called on churchgoers today to 'work and pray" for the elimination of racial segregation and discrimination in every area of American life.

MONTREAL, July 8 (AP) -- Since the St. Lawrence Seaway was opened to traffic April 25, one ship has entered every forty-two minutes, Seaway officials estimate.
LONDON, July 8 -- An agreement by Britain to give tariff concessions to Denmark brought considerably closer today the formation of a seven-nation European free trade area.

In the face of persistent Congressional moves to slash the mutual security program at a time of impending showdown with the Communist bloc, responsible leaders of both parties have now joined forces to prevent a serious blow to the free world's defense structure.

YONKERS, July 8 -- Bye Bye Byrd, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Rex Larkin of Chicago, is a 3-to-5 favorite to capture the $50,000 spring final of the Harness Tracks of America series at Yonkers Raceway tomorrow night.
A second referendum will be held by The New York Typographical Union 6 (Big Six) next Wednesday on a contract proposal from ten New York newspapers.

LOS ANGELES, July 8 (UPI) -- Jose Becerra of Mexico City knocked out Alphonse Halimi of France in the eighth round tonight and won the world bantamweight championship. The end came at 2:02 in the eighth after the Frenchman had been floored for the second time in the round.

Fred Haney's mental gymnastics were more productive -- as the 5-4 score for the National Leaguers attests.
