WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- An examiner for the Interstate Commerce Commission recommended today that the Pennsylvania Railroad be permitted to continue the increases it made in commutation fares between New York City and the New Jersey shore area last January.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture estimated today that growers planted 15,890,000 acres of cotton this year, an increase of 28 per cent over last year's level.

Plans have been canceled for a television show in November that would have featured the music of Alan Jay Lerner and Frederick Loewe, who wrote "My Fair Lady," the motion picture "Gigi" and other shows.
MONTREAL, July 9 -- Coordinated efforts of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Royal Canadian Mounted Police have broken the biggest narcotics case in Canadian history.

Bank clearings for twenty-six major cities of the country in the week ended on Wednesday fell sharply from the week before but were well ahead of the similar 1958 week, a holiday week, Dun Bradstreet, Inc. reported yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:Bernard Baruch once said, "Every man has a right to his opinion but no man has a right to be wrong in his facts." That sums up my reaction to your June 27 editorial on the President's veto of the wheat bill.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art, open every day of the year for nearly seventy years, was closed for the first time last Monday because of the city government's breach of a contractual obligation dating back to 1878. This promises that the city will furnish guards to protect the works of art, valued at many millions of dollars, acquired with privately donated funds.
CHICAGO, July 9 (UPI) -- The National and American Leagues will open their 1960 seasons a week apart, it was decided today.

BONN, Germany, July 9 -- West Germany will seek to have the foreign ministers' conference resuming in Geneva Monday turn away from the search for an isolated Berlin settlement to consideration of the German problem as a whole.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The Senate approved by voice vote today a self-financing plan for the Tennessee Valley Authority. It also placed a geographical limit on the authority's development area.
CHICAGO, July 9 -- The president of the National Safety Council warned today that the nation faces a crisis in highway safety this year.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The Attorney General upheld today the Secretary of Labor's right to withhold the facilities of the United States Employment Service from growers who fail to conform to minimum wage, working and living conditions for migrant workers.

The Controls Company of America, Schiller Park, Ill., has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering a proposed public offering of 191,703 shares of common stock. The offering would be made after consideration of a proposed 50 per cent common stock distribution by stockholders on July 21.

CINCINNATI, July 9 (UPI) -- Willie Mays led off the ninth inning with a single, stole second and scored on Daryl Spencer's infield hit as the San Francisco Giants beat Cincinnati, 3 -- 2, tonight. The loss spoiled Freddie Hutchinson's debut as the Reds' manager.
OBERLIN, Ohio, July 9 -- The Rev. Dr. Fred Hoskins of New York and the Rev. Dr. James E. Wagner of Philadelphia were re-elected co-presidents today of the new United Church of Christ.
ALBANY, July 9 -- The state has provided the special investigation of Suffolk County with enough money to remain in operation for four more months.

A VERDI program last night at Lewisohn Stadium attracted some 10,500 listeners. The announced artists were Mary Curtis-Verna, soprano; Claramae Turner, contralto; Jan Peerce, tenor; Robert Merrill, baritone, and Alfredo Antonini, who conducted the Stadium Symphony.
BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., July 9 -- Some producers here might have trouble identifying Figaro. After all, he has not been up for a screen test lately.

OTTAWA, July 9 -- Howard Green, Secretary of State for External Affairs, indicated today that Canada's foreign policy would remain basically the same as it has been since Prime Minister John Diefenbaker's Conservative Government wrested power from the Liberals.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 9 (AP) -- "The Drunkard" will close here this fan, ending the longest run in the history of the theatre.
DETROIT, July 9 -- The Michigan Bell Telephone Company announced today that it would issue $30,000,000 in thirty-fiveyear debentures to help finance its construction program.
LONDON, July 9 -- The industrials again moved irregularly in the stock market here today, although the turnover increased.
The Cunard Steam-Ship Company, Ltd., is moving its $1,000,000 advertising account to Compton Advertising, Inc., effective Sept. 1.
Sales and earnings of the Scott Paper Company set records in the first six months of this year, Thomas B. McCabe, president, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- The Czechoslovak Embassy disputed today reports that its Government had restricted travel of foreign diplomats. The Embassy said diplomats and foreign visitors were free to travel anywhere in Czechoslovakia.

The urgent need for a Western summit meeting, suggested by Chancellor Adenauer and now again by Prime Minister Macmillan, has been further emphasized by new developments showing that lack of adequate agreements on policy and strategy is producing growing strains within the North Atlantic alliance.

JOHANNESBURG, July 9 -Under an agreement signed today by the South African Industrial Development Corporation, a state-sponsored industrial finance organization, and the Chase Manhattan Bank (South Africa), Ltd., the corporation will receive a revolving credit of $8,500,000.

A motion-picture commitment will prevent Jules Dassin from staging "Moonbirds," the Marcel Ayme comedy as adapted by John Pauker. Mr. Dassin had requested a release from his contract with the producers, Leo Kerz and George Justin, or a postponement.

In line with Governor Rockefeller's call for a revitalization of the state Republican organization, a "top to bottom" examination of the party structure will be undertaken by a twenty-member rules committee.

The Monday closing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, which went into effect this week, was assailed yesterday by Andrew Goodman, president of the Fifth Avenue Association. He called it "false economy" on the part of the city.
IT sometimes comes as a mild shock to parents, especially when their youngsters have left for camp, that they are once again "just husband and wife." What are they going to do for the whole summer?
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The Dominican Republic is represented in the United States by more legal registrants than any Latin-American nation except Cuba.
About $16,000,000,000 of workers' pension funds is invested in corporate bonds and stocks, according to an article in the July issue of Industrial Bulletin, a magazine of the State Labor Department.

The percentage of personal installment loans delinquent thirty days or more increased slightly in May, the American Bankers Association reported yesterday. Its survey of the delinquency experience of almost 300 banks across the country showed a rise to 1.33 per cent from 1.30 per cent the month before.
PORTLAND, Ore., July 9 (AP) -- Denny Moyer, 19 years old, meets the welterweight champion, Don Jordan, in a title bout here tomorrow night.
All copper positions on the Commodity Exchange of New York, except the spot July month, fell to new lows for the life of the contracts yesterday. Trading was influenced by late weakness in London.

NEWARK, July 9 -- Fifteen years of economic expansion were forecast today for the suburban areas west and south of Newark, Elizabeth and Hudson County. In the same period these two major cities in northern New Jersey and all of Hudson County will be economically quiet.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- The Senate passed today a $1,256,836,300 appropriation bill for public works. It includes money to start construction of sixty-nine new flood control, navigation and reclamation projects.

CLEVELAND, July 9 (AP) -- The will of John C. Lincoln, founder of the Lincoln Electric Company here, leaves the bulk of his estate to a foundation to promote the "single tax" theories of Henry George. The value of the estate was not revealed.

Employment of hourly and salaried employes in the iron and steel industry rose to 634,668 in May, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. That was 26.8 per cent above the level for May of last year and was the highest since April, 1957, the organization said.

Whatever other errors Thomas J. Shanahan, vice chairman of the Mayor's Committee on Slum Clearance, may have committed, his error of judgment in evaluating James Felt, his fellow committee member and chairman of the City Planning Commission, is colossal. We quote Mr. Shanahan on Mr. Felt: "That handwringer. In my opinion the Mayor is going to have to make some kind of a decision.

BUFFALO, July 9 (UPI) -- A reward of $10,000 was offered today by the wife of Edward B. Germain, one - time Assistant Secretary of the Navy who has been missing for a month, for information leading to his discovery.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter said today he would return to Geneva for talks with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union in a hopeful but not optimistic mood.
MIAMI BEACH, July 9 -- Anthony Anastasia, overlord of the Brooklyn waterfront, withdrew today from the race for the presidency of the International Longshoremen's Association.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 9 -- Sean Lemass, recently installed Prime Minister of the Irish Republic, made his first bid today to end the partition of Ireland.

The Babcock Wilcox Company released yesterday pictures detailing operations involved in forming the head of the reactor that will house the power source for the N. S. Savannah, the nation's first nuclear-powered merchant vessel.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI) -- A bar association investigator said today that illegal wiretapping was widespread and that even the Supreme Court's telephones were tapped on at least one occasion.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 573,325 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- The House Select Committee on Astronautics and Space Exploration ordered an inquiry today into reports of sagging morale among the Mercury Astronauts, the men chosen for this country's first manned space flight.

PITTSBURGH, July 9 (AP) -- Joe Campbell of Knoxville, a former Purdue University basketball player, shot a course-record 65 at the Pittsburgh Field Club today for the first-round lead in the Western open golf tournament.

CHICAGO, July 9 -- A drug for the prevention of morning sickness in pregnant women and for prevention and relief of other forms of nausea has been made available to the medical profession, G. D. Searle Co., a pharmaceutical house, announced today.

Anne Marie Louise d'Orleans, Duchesse de Montpensier (1627-1693), is the subject of a biography by Vita Sackville-West. It will be called "Daughter of France: The Life of the Grande Mademoiselle." Despite her aristocratic background, her fortune and a "glittering," succession of candidates, she remained unmarried.

Zinc shipments rose sharply last month, reflecting improved consumption and advance buying of zinc products by users concerned over possible strikes in the steel and nonferrous metals industries this summer.
ATHENS, W. Va., July 91 (UPI) -- A former professor of a small college who died more than two months ago, seemingly in poverty, was disclosed today to have amassed $200,000 in stocks and bonds.
CONAKRY, Guinea, July 9 -One morning last week two freighters, tied up side by side in the port of Conakry, were discharging gifts for this small new republic.

A plot 245 by 100 feet at the northwest corner of Bruckner Boulevard and Elder Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by Alfonse Pomilla for improvement with an apartment house. It was sold by David Schor through King King, Inc., brokers of Forest Hills, Queens.
GENEVA, July 9 -- United States, British and Soviet experts were confident tonight that they would complete their report on the detection of nuclear tests in outer space for submission tomorrow.

The Kings County District Attorney's office yesterday reopened its grand jury inquiry into graft and corruption in the Brooklyn office of the City Department of Buildings. The move was a result of a decision by the Court of Appeals Wednesday.
PHILADELPHIA, July 9 -- A single, co - ordinated mass - transportation system operated by a non-profit corporation was proposed for Philadelphia today by Mayor Richardson Dilworth.

A Supreme Court order enjoining 139 concerns and individuals from engaging in monopolistic practices in the private garbage-hauling industry was obtained yesterday by Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz.

Merck Co., Inc., and the Government of Thailand have reached an agreement under which Merck will be the first chemical and pharmaceutical concern to establish manufacturing facilities in that nation in Southeast Asia.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The Senate and House bills on reserve requirements for member banks of the Federal Reserve Systems were merged today at a conference committee from both chambers.
SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 9 -- A water-color fishing scene, seized by sheriff's deputies from the Parrish Art Museum here on Monday, was returned this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Vice Admiral Hyman G. Rickover agreed reluctantly today to supply a House investigating subcommittee with the names of retired military officers who had attempted to influence him on Government contracts.

THE venerable Southern New England tournament, twenty-eight years old, begins today at the Norwich Inn in Norwich, Conn. This tournament always has drawn a representative group of leading New York players.

Although its line-up included none of the thoroughbred stars of the season, the feature race at Belmont Park yesterday was a thriller that had four horses bunched at the finish. The one that had the best position on the wire was Hannah's Hill.

Two new films will open today at first-run theatres. "Lady Chatterley's Lover," a French-made version of the D. H. Lawrence novel, with Danielle Darrieux, Erno Crisa and Leo Genn in the leading roles, is at the Little Carnegie Theatre, Fifty-seventh Street east of Seventh Avenue.

BAASTAD, Sweden, July 9 (AP) -- Playing in 95-degree heat, Alex Oldmedo of Peru today defeated Thomas Hallberg of Sweden, 5 -- 7, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 3, in the quarter-finals of the Baastad international tennis tournament.
KRASNIK FABRYCZNY, Poland, July 9 (AP) -- Arrests continued in this Southeast Polish town today in the wake of a major religious riot that erupted June 26.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter said today that he hoped President Eisenhower and President Charles de Gaulle would meet soon to thresh out the differences between the United States and France.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- The Jury deliberating the influence case of Richard A. Mack and Thurman A. Whiteside failed again today to reach a verdict.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI) -- A Congressional critic of big league baseball pledged support today to efforts to form a third major league.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- The Secret Service announced today that two agents masquerading as mobsters had uncovered a Louisiana gang that peddled counterfeit Treasury checks on a wholesale basis.
A union contract covering 3,500 nonprofessional workers in most of the city's proprietary hospitals was signed yesterday at the City Labor Department.
The year 1958 was the "beginning of the end" for the advocates of massive resistance to desegregation in the South, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People reported yesterday.

PARIS, July 9 -- Parisians in a dozen different walks of life, from pushcart venders to proprietors of swank stores, demonstrated yesterday a high level of honesty and courtesy toward three demanding and difficult foreign "tourists."

MANILA, July 9 (AP) -- The Philippine Government has threatened to cancel imports of United States surplus commodities because the United States is raising the price in pesos to meet the new Philippine foreign exchange tax.

Title I is a section of the Housing Act of 1949 designed to bring private capital into slum clearance. It permits cities to acquire substandard areas and resell them at a markdown to private developers.

WASHlNGTON, July 9 -- Dr. Albert Sabin of Cincinnati told Congress today that the safety and effectiveness of his live virus vaccine for poliomyelitis should be proved by the end of this year on evidence assembled in the Soviet Union.
FOR thirty-five years Saks Fifth Avenue has been putting its best foot forward in keeping pace with the latest fashion trends. Its new shoe collection for fall is no exception.

TWENTY-ONE years ago Phil Wrigley made the reluctant decision to change managers on his Chicago Cubs. Resisting the strong tug of sentiment, the owner of the Bruins was determined to give his faltering team the psychological jolt it seemed to need by replacing Charley Grimm as skipper.
BALTIMORE, July 9 -- New evidence was introduced today indicating that lightning may have had something to do with the crash of a Capital Airlines plane near here May 12.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 4 points (20 cents a bale) up to 9 points (45 cents a bale) off yesterday.
The Mayor of Glen Cove, L. I., hinted yesterday that his community might condemn a private waterworks whose owner was seeking higher rates.
PARIS, July 9 -- Several prominent Socialists sought today to bring their party into total opposition to President Charles de Gaulle and his regime.

POLITICS has almost always been fun for George Harrison Bender since the day in 1912 when, as a boy of 16, he met former President Theodore Roosevelt in Cleveland and enlisted in his unsuccessful Ball Moose campaign.
LONDON, July 9 -- Critics here had a few kind things to say about "Once More, With Feeling," which opened its London run tonight.

The American Enka Corporation, manufacturer of rayon yarns and fibers, viscose tire yarn and nylon, which this month is observing its thirtieth anniversary, made a sharp recovery in this year's first-half results.

Average member bank borrowings increased $106,000,000 to $1,027,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Excess reserves on the average increased $163,000,000 to $532,000,000.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- Testimony made public tonight disclosed that President Eisenhower had overruled his Budget Director in asking Congress for $260,000,000 for the Navy to build another large aircraft carrier.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 9 (AP) -- An Army Jupiter rocket thundered skyward tonight on a 1,500-mile flight.
BATON ROUGE, La., July 9 -- Gov. Earl K. Long, growing weaker from an ailing heart, left here tonight by car for his farm near the northern Louisiana town of Winnfield.
The New York State Communist party wanted to hold a midday street rally in the garment district yesterday, but the Police Department refused permission because of the traffic problem.
The First Army is converting much of its great mountain range of paper into miles of brown tape.

CHICAGO, July 9 -- Frol R. Kozlov made sure today he would be able to brief the eminent Soviet corn expert, Nikita S. Khrushchev, fully on the latest technical revolution in Amerikanskaya kukuruza (American corn).

YONKERS, July 9 -- Bye Bye Byrd equaled the mile record for 4-year-old pacers tonight in winning the $50,000 spring final of the Harness Tracks of America series before 23,984 fans at Yonkers Raceway.
A second Dominican Republic diplomat resigned yesterday, charging that his country was oppressed by a "nauseous dictatorship."

The Brooklyn Division of the New York Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation will gain from Art in Therapy," an art[ exhibition and sale July 18 and/ 19 in the Marine Roof of the[ Bossert Hotel in Brooklyn.
Burton R. Durkee has been made coordinator of creative services in the Detroit office of the J. Walter Thompson Company. He has also been appointed a member of that office's operations committee.
HONG KONG, July 9 -- A Chinese Communist gunboat rammed a Portuguese gunboat off Macao today in a dispute over two fleeing Chinese, according to reports received here.

Magistrate Robert F. Mahoney refused yesterday to permit a woman to plead guilty to creating a hazard after he learned that her alleged offense was the storage of her winter clothing in three cardboard cartons.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 8 -- President Sukarno announced today a ten-man "inner" Cabinet led by himself as Premier. The new Cabinet is made up of ministers regarded as non-Communist. The group will be sworn in tomorrow.

ATLANTA, July 9 (AP) -- A Federal judge ordered Atlanta school officials today to produce a desegregation plan by Dec. 1. But he said the plan might be submitted contingent on action of the Georgia Legislature.

ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, July 9 -- King Baudouin received from Dutch engineers here today the assurance that Belgium's navigation interests would be protected in the building of a set of dams in the delta of the Rhine (Waal), the Meuse (Maas) and the Schelde Rivers.

In one of the most senseless of Communist outrages a small band of terrorists, using submachine guns and a "human bomb," attacked an American Army billet just twenty miles from Saigon, the Vietnamese capital. Several Americans and Vietnamese were killed and others wounded. From the practical point of view, nothing was gained, or could possibly have been gained, from this atrocity.
The market for Treasury bills staged a rally yesterday, carrying with it the rest of the list of United States Government securities.

BOSTON, July 9 -- Bob Turley, who came within a couple of feet and three outs of tossing a no-hitter last Saturday, added another chapter to the season's most baffling mystery: "What's wrong with Bob Turley?"
Loans to business by the large New York banks declined $44,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

TOKYO, July 9 -- Premier Nobusuke Kishi plans a personal exploration of "cold war" tensions in talks with British and Western European leaders this month, he said today. He hopes that as a result of these conversations Japan may find a way to help in easing the EastWest conflict.

I have read with some dismay certain articles in the press of New York City which, collectively and in some cases individually, present a most unfair picture of the work of a great public servant. I refer to the attacks and innuendo leveled against Robert Moses.

Two tests of oral contraceptive tablets over the last three years by 1,000 women were reported yesterday to have given a higher degree of conception control than contraceptives now used. However a third test, using different pills, did not produce the same unequivocal results.

Directors of Artistic Foundations, Inc., reorganized the company yesterday, named it Premier Industries, Inc., and elected a new chief executive officer. Arnold A. Saltzman, who was named president and chief executive officer, has the responsibility of integrating the concern's subsidiaries.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Paul M. Butler, Democratic National Chairman, issued another statement today implicitly assailing his party's Congressional leaders for bowing to President Eisenhower's wishes on legislation in an attempt to avoid vetoes.

LONDON, July 9 -- The Transport and General Workers Union, Britain's largest trade union, rejected by an overwhelming majority today the Labor party's new policy calling for formation of an international non-nuclear club.

The Soviet Deputy Foreign Trade Minister, Mikhail R. Kuzmin, said yesterday 250 American business men had attended a meeting here on expanding Soviet-American trade. But he said United States Government policies were "obstacles."
LONDON, July 9 (AP) -- Brendan Behan, Irish playwright, created havoc last night at Wyndham's Theatre, where his "The Hostage" is being staged.
TRENTON, July 9 -- The New Jersey Association for Mental Health is seeking the 25 per cent discount granted to charitable institutions by the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company.

The employes of Sears, Roebuck Co. as a group have long been the largest single owners of their own company. In effect, they have control through a pension fund which has made a heavy investment in Sears stock.
For the second time in sixteen days, stocks declined yesterday, but before they did so they reached a new historic high for The New York Times combined stock average.

BIENHOA, Vietnam, July 9 -- Increasing Communist terrorism in South Vietnam was emphasized sharply here last night when two United States soldiers, a major and a master sergeant, were killed and a captain was wounded by the Vietminh.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- Public hearings are scheduled for next week in New York's dispute with California over defense contracts.
BUENOS AIRES, July 9 -Argentina's leading jockey was dragged to death by his mount today before an Independence Day crowd of 75,000 at San Isidro race track.
REIDSVILLE, Ga., July 9 (UPI) -- A hunger strike spread at the George State Prison tonight. About 1,000 inmates refused to enter the mess hall for their evening meal.
NEW DELHI, India, July 9 -- The high command of India's ruling Congress party issued today new condemnation of Communist rule in Kerala.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Former Senator George H. Bender said today that he resented any implication that he had taken a bribe.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- Top members of the House Agriculture Committee suggested today that President Eisenhower call a White House conference to solve the surplus wheat problem.
The Dutch round-the-world liner Willem Ruys made a brief and unscheduled call last month at Pitcairn Island in the Pacific to drop off a present for the children there.
The American Newspaper Publishers Association announced yesterday that it would undertake a survey to determine communications costs involved in publishing a daily newspaper.

ABOUT 6 o'clock every summer evening, express trucks laden with ice-packed soft-shell crabs roar out of fishing ports along Chesapeake Bay. By 4:30 or 5 the next morning, the crabs arrive at the Fulton Fish Market here for sale to retail fish dealers and buyers for hotels and other institutions.

HAWORTH, N. J., July 9 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of the Forest Hill Field Club and Maureen Orcutt of the home club shared the lead after the second round of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association fifty-four-hole medal play championship today.

ROME, July 9 (Reuters) -- The strike of Italian seamen, which has tied up liners around the world and cost shipping concerns about $80,000,000, crawled past its thirty-second day today with no sign of a settlement.
Over the coming week-end a pleasure boat may return to her mooring carrying treasure.
BOSTON, July 9 -- The boom of a brass cannon and a blare of trumpets heralded the opening tonight of the Metropolitan Boston Arts Center.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 9 -- Sir Leslie Munro of New Zealand said today that he had been refused admission to Communist Hungary, even on a personal basis, while he remains the United Nations' special representative on the Hungarian question.

The Jefferson Parish, La., School District 1 has turned down a second offer by an investment banking group to buy $10,000,000 of school bonds. The syndicate headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. and Scharff and Jones, Inc. had bid a net interest cost of 4.724 per cent which the school board termed too high.

MANCHESTER, Vt., July 9 -- It has often been said in this Green Mountain community that when Wes Jordan wants to go fishing, only a flood or fire can make him change his mind. This morning Jordan changed his mind. The big barn on the Forrest farm was on fire.

W. Averell Harriman urged yesterday that a summit conference be held in New York. The former Governor of New York and wartime Ambassador to the Soviet Union returned from a Moscow visit and a "tough" interview in which Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev threatened war over Berlin.
Two scientists at the University of Tennessee reported yesterday that they had found a new antibiotic that successfully treated most fungus diseases.

HARTSDALE, N. Y., July 9 -- Sally Wilson of Scarsdale, the defender, and Wendy Stone of Oyster Bay, L. I., seeded No. 2, reached the singles final of the New York State girls' tennis championship at the County Tennis Club today.

I followed with interest the exchange of letters regarding the contemplated destruction of a substantial part of a school playground in order to make room for a parking field for teachers with insufficient public transportation facilities.
BUFFALO, July 9 (AP) -- The nation's chief tax collector called today for a joint Federal-state crackdown on tax cheats.
Staff functions of all Red Cross chapters in New York City will be unified by a coordinating committee.

Wall Street analysts of rail securities have been puzzled in recent stock market sessions about the sudden strong demand that has developed for the stocks of some of the harder-pressed lines. At the same time there has been an almost complete lack of interest in the same lines' bonds.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI) -- Representative Emanuel Celler, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, predicted today that Congress would pass a "good" civil rights bill.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- A duel with political daggers, smilingly pulled away just as they are about to pierce the opponent's hide, is in the best tradition of English-speaking parliaments. Usually it is in the British House of Commons that this kind of match is fought with the highest qualities of skill and urbanity.

HAVANA, July 9 -- Communists will establish a daily Chinese-language newspaper here in the near future, according to an announcement by the New China Democratic Alliance, a Chinese Communist organization.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 9 (AP) -- A Birmingham Methodist and a city official took sharp exception today to a recent article in The New York Times about this city's church-race relations.
Executives of the twelve biggest steel companies met secretly here yesterday to decide whether to make a last-ditch wage offer to avert a national strike at midnight Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The court-appointed monitors of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters won another point today in a supplemental opinion by the United States Court of Appeals.
TRENTON, July 9 -- Federal Judge Philip Forman today ordered five major drug companies to produce documents outlining their pricing policies.

MILWAUKEE, July 9 (UPI) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers knocked the Milwaukee Braves out of first place in the National League tonight, beating them, 4 -- 3, in thirteen innings. Roger Craig allowed only three hits in eleven innings of shutout relief pitching.

The American Bosch Arma Corporation has acquired the Ensign Carburetor Company of Fullerton, Calif., which will be operated as a wholly owned subsidiary, Charles W. Perelle, president of American Bosch, announced.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, July 9 -- The death toll in the explosion and sinking of a motor launch near Haderslev, yesterday rose to 53 today. Haderslev, a port, is near the German border.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Ambassador Jacob D. Beam in Warsaw has reported that broadcasts to Poland by Radio Free Europe lack effectiveness because of misinformation and a too-blatant propaganda line.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Following is a transcript of Secretary of State Christian A. Herter's news conference today:
TWO incidents reported in yesterday's newspapers put the spotlight again on the problem of racial discrimination.

The three major networks have alarmed the leading advertising agencies by scheduling, without prior notice or consultation, thirty-three one-hour television shows for the 1959-60 season, a Federal inquiry heard yesterday.

PARIS, July 9 -- Paul-Henri Spaak, Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, criticized today French action in the alliance, but granted validity to some French objections to its functioning.

CHICAGO, July 9 -- The Acme Steel Company opened a $33,000,000 facility today that turns out molten iron in a continuous jet stream aria whips up a batch of quality-controlled steel in less than an hour.
CHICAGO, July 9 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
On a scarred patch of withered grass -- lately a hard-fought piece of terrain -- a victory was signaled yesterday.

Three teen-agers convicted of beating a man to death in an East Harlem park last year were sentenced to prison terms yesterday ranging from five to twenty years. Two others are still to be sentenced for the first-degree manslaughter.

The Third Street Music School Settlement will benefit from the Nov. 5 performance of the musical, "Connecticut Summer," at the Shubert Theatre, and the Dec. 10 performance of the drama, "Five Finger Exercise," at the Music Box Theatre.

SAN ISIDRO AIR BASE, Dominican Republic, July 9 -- Two United States citizens who served as instructors of rebel troops were reported today to have lost their lives in recent attempts to invade the Dominican Republic from Cuba.
TROY, N. Y., July 9 (UPI) -- A State Supreme Court justice ruled today that student cooperatives at state-operated colleges were subject to local taxes.
The Citizens Union called yesterday for the dismissal of Robert Moses and Thomas J. Shanahan from the Committee on Slum Clearance.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- The new defense money bill should provide commercial airlines with a larger share of the amount spent on flying military passengers and freight, Senator A. S. Mike Monroney said today.
MORONI, Grande Comore Island, July 9 -- President Charles de Gaulle found here today a great rarity in the French Community -- an overseas territory where nationalism is apparently still unborn.

This week, most of America's custom millinery designers are presenting their new autumn collections to the press and store buyers. The trends that emerge from these showings will establish the fashion pattern for all hats for fall.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., July 9 -- A llama has been born on John H. Swan's thirty-acre estate across the street from the New Canaan Country Club.
BUENOS AIRES, July 9 -The Government declared a former Marine Corps commandant, Vice Admiral Samuel Toranzo Calderon, a rebel today and struck him from the officer rolls.

The 77-year-old father of Benjamin Cymrot testified yesterday that he had been threatened by two city investigators who questioned him in Miami Beach last year about the source of $27,000 he reportedly had given his son.

New York received a special award, yesterday from the American Automobile Association for efforts in 1958 to achieve pedestrian safety. This city was a runner-up to Detroit, which won first place for the third successive year in the annual contest.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 9 -- Prices of goods exported by industrial nations have increased 4 per cent since 1953, while prices of exports of primary producing countries have decreased about 7 per cent. The ability of the latter group to pay for equipment purchased abroad has been correspondingly impaired.
MAMARONECK, N. Y., July 9 -- The Bostwick brothers from Long Island, George H. (Pete) Jr. and Jimmy, paired for one of the best rounds in the John G. Anderson Memorial tourney today.

LONDON, July 10 -- Lord Astor announced today his resignation as chairman of The Times Publishing Company. Lord Astor, 73 years old, has been chairman and chief proprietor of The Times of London since 1922. He retains the office of chief proprietor with John Walter and remains a member of the board of directors.

Lumber production fell because of the extended holiday week-end to 224,526,000 board feet from 260,176,000 in the week before, according to reports to The New York Times by regional associations. This compares with 150,877,060 board feet produced in the like week of 1958.

CHICAGO, July 9 (AP) -- Corn and new-crop soybean futures broke a succession of price declines on the Board of Trade today and made a fairly substantial recovery in spots. Wheat again was decidedly weak while rye was firm to strong and oats easier.
Hotel properties figured in three Manhattan realty deals reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- A spokesman for radio station WQXR testified today that chaos could result for United States broadcasting unless the Senate ratified pending international broadcasting agreements.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- George Alpert, president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad offered Congress a bill today to establish Federal subsidies for commuter services.

Officials of the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens, were asked yesterday to appear before the city's Commission on Intergroup Relations for a hearing July 21 on its policy of barring Negroes and Jews.
An African family of rats, rare to zoos because the natives would rather eat them than give them away, went on exhibit yesterday in the Small Mammal House of the Bronx Zoo.
Directors of the New York Central Railroad said yesterday they hoped they could resume dividend payments on the stock in October, but that it would be "premature and imprudent" to do so at this time.
The New York City Youth Board has opened an emergency unit in Harlem to work with anti-social teen-age gangs. It acted after the outbreak of gang warfare there last Monday that killed two youths.
ALBANY, July 9 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller's post-office box at the Capitol was looted last Friday. The executive chamber's mail was taken, the Governor's office reported today.

" GREAT STORIES BY NOBEL PRIZE WINNERS,"* edited by Leo Hamalian and Edmond L. Volpe of the English Department of City College, is a useful collection because it brings together twenty-six diverse works by famous internationally known storytellers. It is interesting to read the stories in one place to try to discover if there is some common theme from one country to another or, at least, clues about what makes for greatness of style.

In the list of favorable impressions made by Americans upon two Moroccan teachers, as reported in C. L. Sulzberger's column of July 6, I do not see good manners and courtesy mentioned as salient features of our life. And no wonder, in view of the crude, ill-mannered

Father's Charcoal Grill Father's day has come and gone, but even at this time -- now somewhat removed from the day itself -- the memory lingers on. In fact, considerably more than mere memory lingers on.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI) -- The Defense Department announced today it would use the main booster from one of the nation's largest intercontinental missiles as the middle stage of a gigantic new space rocket.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 10 (AP) -- Segregation by sex will be tried at some class levels in Charlottesville schools when the city begins racial desegregation next fall.
An impassioned case history purporting to show how illness can be cured by Marxism-Leninism has been printed in an American medical journal.

" IN THE WRONG RAIN,"* by Robert R. Kirsch, is a novel about a man in a shower of trouble. Most of it is brought on by his own heedlessness. But he has enough assistance or interference from others to give his predicament the stature of tragedy.
Continued demand for the Treasury's new July 15, 1960, bills lent strength to the market for fixed-interest securities yesterday.
LOS ALTOS, Calif., July 10 (AP) -- Indiana swimmers smashed two national records tonight in opening sessions of the Amateur Athletic Union's men's outdoor championships.
Earnings of the Bell System applicable to American Telephone and Telegraph Company stock crossed the billion-dollar level in the twelve months ended on May 31.

The five-story building containing thirty-nine apartments at 1205 Nelson Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Elaine Schwartz to a client of Ben Housman. The sale was negotiated by the Philip Fogel Company, broker, for cash over mortgages amounting to $141,300.

The Norwalk Tank Company has purchased through its wholly owned subsidiary, C. S. Mersick Company, 75 per cent of the stock of the New Haven Electric Supply Company. The price was not disclosed in the announcement yesterday of Thomas J. Wall, president of Norwalk Tank.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, July 10 -- The ruling Alliance party, which hopes to win the Federal elections next month by a big majority, is facing one of the gravest threats of its seven-year existence.
SANTA FE, N. M., July 10 (AP) -- Igor Stravinsky will conduct Sunday what is believed to be this country's first concert of sacred music by a secular group in a Roman Catholic cathedral.

A stock listed on the ticker tape as GA, but known in Wall Street as Ga-Ga, has been on the go recently. The symbol stands for Glen Alden Corporation, which was the most actively traded stock yesterday. It closed at 28 5/8, up 2 1/4.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Average wholesale prices in primary markets declined 0.1 per cent to 119.2 per cent of their 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.
VIENNA, July 10 -- The People's party and the Socialists reached agreement today on the formation of another two-party Government coalition under Chancellor Julius Raab.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- The American Federation of labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations urged Congress today to override President Eisenhower's veto of the housing bill.

DOYLESTOWN, Pa., July 10 -- Alexander R. Miller of Easton, an insurance executive, was ordered by the Bucks County Court today to repay $70,633 he collected in salaries and fees while a member of the Delaware River Joint Toll Bridge Commission.
TAMPA, Fla., July 10 (AP) -- Murchison Brothers of Dallas bought $15,000,000 worth of Gulf Life Insurance Company stock from a group of fifty stockholders yesterday.
HAWORTH, N. J., July 10 -- Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches won her tenth Women's New Jersey fifty-four-hole medal play golf championship over her home course today.
REIDSVILLE, GA., July 10 (UPI) -- State prison authorities smashed a hunger strike today by transferring 225 convicts to other prisons.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The Senate subcommittee on Constitutional Rights took a small but significant step today toward moving a civil rights bill to the Senate floor.

OMAHA, July 10 (AP) -- A Federal judge sentenced Karl H. Meyer, 22-year-old son of a Vermont member of Congress, to serve a six-month sentence as the outgrowth of a pacifist demonstration against a missile construction project.
The last known livery stable on the East Side between South Ferry and 106th Street is being prepared for demolition.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., July 9 -- The Silvermine Guild of Artists will open its new Chamber Music Center with a concert Sunday night featuring Paul Creston, composer, and Leonid Hambro, pianist.
The Indian Harbor Yacht Club's second annual Greenwich Cup race around Long Island started off Rockaway Point last night.
JOY GILPIN has an unusual job. She teaches housewives how to boil water.

The city said yesterday it would not try to prove that Benjamin Cymrot, former executive, officer of the old Bureau of Real Estate, had any personal knowledge of alleged irregularities in the handling of relocation contracts.

New York City's success with its pedestrian safety program has earned a special citation in the American Automobile Association's annual pedestrian safety appraisal program. New York was one of two cities in the population-group of 1,000,000 persons or more to be cited by the A. A. A.
DETROIT, July 10 (AP) -- Automobile production increased 15 per cent this week after last week's holiday-abreviated activity, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.
DESPITE the fact that developments in lighting have grown from an occasional flicker to a flood, the barefaced light bulb is still the prime source of illumination in many homes across the nation.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 10 -- Indonesia's ten-man Presidential Cabinet was sworn in today. Under President Sukarno as Premier, the group will implement the change to "guided democracy" in Indonesia.
CINCINNATI, July 10 (UPI) -- The San Francisco Giants downed the Cincinnati Reds, 8--6, in eleven innings tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Support appears to be growing here for a visit to the United States by Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev of the Soviet Union. W. Averell Harriman, former Governor of New York, backed the idea today in talks with top Administration officials.

Negotiations to head off a national steel strike moved into the make-or-break stage yesterday. The industry indicated for the first time its willingness to make a specific money offer if the United Steelworkers of America would give the companies greater authority over plant efficiency.

The Citizens Housing and Planning Council wrote to Mayor Wagner yesterday that it would support him "thoroughly" if he decided to handle the Title I program without the present leadership of the Committee on Slum Clearance.

Proclaiming "I'm only as old as I feel" is not the first step to senility; it is the right slant on life. The young in heart, who think of themselves as only middle-aged even when past 60, are better adjusted than "confirmed oldsters."
TOLEDO, Spain, July 10 (AP) -- Enrique Cardinal Pla y Deniel told Roman Catholics that it was a mortal sin for engaged couples to walk arm-in-arm in the streets or to be alone together.

Recently I was almost hit by a runaway car whose driver had died of a heart attack. Five boys were crossing Fifty-seventh Street when the car bounced two of them aside and ran over another. I dodged the car just before it crashed into the rear of a parked car.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- Senator Stuart Symington of Missouri said today the United States could finance the shipment of more surplus foods abroad at less than it cost to store them.
Just before sunset tonight everything in the Solar System except an undetermined amount of cosmic flotsom will be strung in a gigantic arc above the horizon.
PITTSBURGH, July 10 -- Frol R. Kozlov toured the Homestead Works of the United States Steel Corporation today. He shook hands with workers, but was rebuffed by one.
MINEOLA, L. I., July 10 -- The Long Island State Park Commission has been asked to consider a report that run-down equipment and a shortage of personnel have hampered the commission's police force.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI) -- The Teamsters Union asked the United States Court of Appeals today to hold up its order granting clean-up powers to the Board of Monitors.

BUENOS AIRES, July 10 (AP) -- Four of the rebels who threatened civil war to supplant the constitutional government of President Arturo Frondizi by a military dictatorship have slipped across the River Plate to Uruguay.
Eight persons were injured, four seriously, when a taxi and a private auto collided head-on last night on Fifth Avenue, near Twentieth Street.
Commodity futures closed irregularly lower yesterday on most New York exchanges. Trading was dull. Evening of positions prior to the week-end accounted for most of the volume.

SHREVEPORT, La., July 10 (UPI) -- Attorney General Jack Gremillion of Louisiana filed suit in Federal District Court today asking that the law setting up the Civil Rights Commission be declared unconstitutional.

MOUNT SUNAPEE, N. H., July 10 -- The New Hampshire Fish and Game Department plans to stock its streams and lakes with 130 tons of trout and landlocked salmon by the end of the season. Most of this total already has been placed in suitable waters and, as a result, anglers have fared well.

TANANARIVE, Madagascar, July 9 -- President Tsiranana of the autonomous Malgache Republic announced last night that his Parliament would ask France to give amnesty to seven Malgache nationalists. Their future has become a major political issue on this big island.
WOMEN can put their feet up -- and have them pampered -- at a number of places in New York.
ACCESSORIES designed to help make the summer as pleasant as possible are still inundating New York stores. Some are purely practical; others are in the gracious living category.
CHICAGO, July 10 (AP) -- The top price for butcher hogs hit its lowest level in more than two and a half years today after four consecutive setbacks.
About 50,000 building trade workers were reported yesterday to have been laid off in the city in the ten days since 1,200 drivers who haul cement and other materials went on strike.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The House Ways and Means Committee, apparently dissatisfied with existing and proposed plans to finance the $40,000,000,000 interstate highway program, scheduled open hearings today on every phase of it.
CHICAGO, July 10 (UPI) -- The Cleveland Indians rapped four Chicago White Sox pitchers for seventeen hits tonight in scoring an 8-4 victory.

WINNIPEG, Man., July 10 (AP) -- Improved prospects for wild duck production were reported today by Ducks Unlimited. The conservation organization said a late hatch is appearing in daily increasing numbers in parklands that lie between the agricultural prairies and a line running from Saskatchewan to southeast Manitoba.

The president of the Free Europe Committee said yesterday that he felt the broadcasts of Radio Free Europe to Poland were "effective and good." Archibald S. Alexander said that in his judgment a State Department criticism of the radio transmisssions was unjustified.

ARMONK, N. Y., July 10 -- "Hyphenated" Americans and American factions threaten the soul of the United States, the fortieth annual convention of the Westchester County American Legion was told tonight.

Preparation for the winter cruise season has gathered some midsummer momentum in the last few days. Four operators have announced plans for thirty special voyages to the Mediterranean and the West Indies, sailing from here between November and March.

Just how far the recently announced decision of the Government of Burma to resume the acceptance of aid from the United States reflects a real change in policy remains to be seen. In any case, it is a good thing, because the aid will go into operations that are badly needed in Burma. The stopping of the aid program by the Burmans was impulsive and ill-advised.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- A device that sends a picture from the floor of the New York Stock Exchange to a brokerage office in six or seven seconds was patented this week.
An investment banking group managed by John Nuveen Co. yesterday was awarded $2,700,000 of water and sewer bonds of Pinellas Park, Fla., due 1963 to 1998.
CHICAGO, July 10 (AP) -- The major leagues today approved again the interleague trading rule, then appointed a committee to deal with any group seeking to establish a third major league.
LONDON, July 10 (AP) -- The Moscow radio complained today about the reception given the Soviet exhibition in New York and Frol R. Kozlov, a First Deputy Premier of the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The Senate Banking Committee approved today by a vote of 12 to 3 a "sense of the Senate" resolution aimed at barring the Administration's proposed trade of mortgages held by the Federal National Mortgage Association for outstanding Government bonds.

TOKYO, June 10 -- The annual rally against atomic and hydrogen bombs, held in Hiroshima on Aug. 6, the anniversary of the atomic bombing of that city, has taken on too much of a political tone, the local governing body has stated in canceling its usual appropriation to support the affair.

The nation's steel industry produced more steel last month than ever before in a June. And with that output, production also was at a record high in the second quarter and the first half of this year, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

PARIS, July 10 -- Arranging a de Gaulle-Eisenhower meeting seems to have become almost as difficult as arranging a Khrushchev-Eisenhower meeting. This is both paradoxical and regrettable. For certainly it is even more urgent that the two democratic leaders should thresh out their problems face-to-face than it is to stage another summit.
BOSTON, July 10 -- Casey Stengel took the long chance tonight and again came out on the short end.

Congratulations on your Title I editorial of July 8. Title I is very much alive and will, I am confident, go forward. I do not consider it a "dead duck" and have so stated on the floor of the Senate. On the contrary, Title I urban renewal and redevelopment is indispensable to the rehabilitation of large areas of New York and other cities in the state.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 10 -- Public opinion in the Netherlands and Belgium is concerned lest maneuvers within the North Atlantic Treaty Organization prior to resumption of the Geneva talks will establish that there are three classes of NATO membership.
Edward T. Crinnion, Deputy Commissioner of Buildings, will retire Aug. 8, Commissioner Peter J. Reidy announced yesterday.
WINNFIELD, La., July 10 -- Gov. Earl K. Long plans to leave the state by plane tomorrow for Fort Worth, Tex., the first stop on a lengthy Western vacation trip. A psychiatrist will accompany him.
NEW DELHI, India, July 10 -- The question of aggression by Communist China in Tibet should be raised in the United Nations. Jayaprakash Narayan, Indian Socialist leader, said here today.
Officers of the printers' union here have received permission from their international to take a referendum strike vote in a contract dispute with ten New York newspapers.

NEWARK, N. J., July 10 (UPI) -- The Internal Revenue Service said today that it would ask Michael G. Comunale, ousted prosecutor's assistant, to tell whether he filed income tax returns for 1955, 1957 and 1958.

GLENS FALLS, N. Y., July 10 -- Three relatives of the late Mrs. Helen E. Foulds are seeking to nullify her will, which left the bulk of her $4,500,000 estate to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York
BALTIMORE, July 10 -- An expert expressed the opinion today that chances of a plane crash because of having been struck by lightning were so small they could be discounted.

The General Time Corporation, New York, has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission on $6,260,700 of twenty-year convertible debentures to be offered to stockholders at the rate of $100 of debentures for each eight shares of stock held.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The Senate Labor subcommittee voted today for an increase to $1.25 an hour in the minimum wage for millions of workers.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., July 10 -- The Empire State Festival, in transit between Ellenville and Sterling Forest, has found a lovely temporary home.
LONDON, July 10 (AP) -- Mice exposed to strong doses of cigarette smoke have failed to develop lung cancer in five years of laboratory tests, the British Institute of Cancer Research has reported.
MILWAUKEE, July 10 (UPI) -- Bernard Bartzen of Dallas beat Venezuela's Iyo Pimentel, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 1, today to enter the semi-finals of the Western open tennis tournament at the Town Club.
A four-footed lion, stranded here after the convention of two-footed Lions ended July 3, has caused a flurry of activity in this country and the Philippines.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were 6 points (30 cents a bale) higher on old July, and unchanged to 4 points (20 cents) lower on the other months.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 10 -- Security measures were intensified today as a result of the slaying of two United States Army military advisers by terrorists Wednesday night in Beinhoa, twenty miles northeast of here.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- Senator John L. McClellan charged today that cheats and frauds in the Teamsters Union were "the real union busters."

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The Federal Reserve is strongly opposed to the "sense of Congress" amendment to the bond interest ceiling bill that was approved in principle on Wednesday by the House Ways and Means Committee.

Texaco, Inc., announced plans for another major expansion yesterday. The company said it would acquire the capital stock of the Paragon Oil Company, Inc., of Long Island City, Queens, a major East Coast distributor of home and industrial fuel oils and other petroleum products. Paragon is said to be the largest independent oil company in the New York area.
MOSCOW, July 10 -- Seventy-five young Russian-speaking American men and women rolled up their sleeves and went to work today.

Assistance from private American investment was termed essential yesterday to economic progress by Thailand. This need was stressed by Visutr Arthayukti, newly appointed Thai Ambassador to the United States, at a luncheon given in his honor at India House by the Far East-American Council of Commerce and Industry, Inc.

Eddie Arcaro's return to riding at Belmont Park yesterday was a social success, but it lacked artistic excellence. Eddie had three mounts, and the 19,173 customers established one of them an odds-on favorite. Sad result -- all three lost.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., July 10 (UPI) -- Jack Smith, president of Memphis State University, disclosed in Federal Court today that qualified Negro applicants would be admitted to the university this fall. Memphis State is now an all-white institution.

The announcement by State Industrial Commissioner Catherwood that the Labor Department has begun a study of union elections fulfills a wise promise that Governor Rockefeller made when he urged the passage of the present Labor and Management Improper Practices Act in March.
PORTLAND, Ore., July 10 (UPI) -- Don Jordan cut young Denny Moyer's face in several places tonight as he successfully defended his world welterweight title with a unanimous fifteen-round decision.

The International Business Machines Corporation's profit in the second quarter and the first six months of this year was higher than for any comparable periods in the company's history, according to the results announced yesterday by Thomas J. Watson Jr., president.

" CAN you recommend two or three cheeses to use for au gratin dishes and with vegetables? I would like a good mild cheese that will not overpower the flavor of the foods with which it is cooked and a good strong cheese to make a sauce." K. K., New York.

BONN, Germany, July 10 -- The West should adopt a tough economic policy toward the Communist world if the Soviet Union refuses a reasonable settlement of present political tensions, Dr. Ludwig Erhard said today.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- Bank robbers had their busiest year in the twelve months that ended June 30, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- The New York Central Railroad today formally notified the Interstate Commerce Commission that it planned to abolish passenger service on its West Shore Division on Aug. 10. The service comprises twenty-two trains between Weehawken, N. J., and West Haverstraw, N. Y.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) Crop production this year may dip only about 4 per cent below last year's spectacular record volume.

LENOX, Mass., July 10 -- The first of this week-end's Mozart programs at the Berkshire Music Festival at Tanglewood was held tonight in the Music Shed. Charles Munch led members of the Boston Symphony with Nicole Henriot-Schweitzer, French pianist, as soloist.

SIDNEY LENZ, dean of the world's bridge experts, will be 86 years old tomorrow and the usual group of his cronies and disciples will gather at his annual birthday party, where there is only one rigid rule: No bridge.
BUFFALO, July 10 (AP) -- A threatened strike by housekeeping employes at all twelve nonprofit hospitals in the Buffalo area was postponed indefnitely today.

A one-week program of non-theatrical motion pictures dealing with rehabilitation services for the handicapped will be a feature of the eighth World Congress of the International Society for the Welfare of Cripples.
BAASTAD, Sweden, July 10 (AP) -- American players, led by Mrs. Beverly Baker Fleitz, today gained the finals in three divisions of the Baastad international tennis tournament.
Twenty-eight trains and 20,000 commuters were delayed as much as seventy minutes yesterday by the breakdown of a New York, New Haven Hartford train in the Bronx.
VANCOUVER, July 10 (Canadian Press) -- A net loss of $1,278,925 up to March 31, the end of the first full year of operation, was announced yesterday by Westcoast Transmission Company Ltd.

MONTREAL, July 10 (Canadian Press) -- Canadian Converters Company, Ltd., has acquired controlling interest in Tooke Brothers, Ltd., a clothing concern, through purchase of the majority of Tooke Brothers 5 per cent debentures and preferred and common shares, it was announced today at the annual meeting of Tooke Brothers.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 10 -- Mayor Wagner said today the New York delegation to the Democratic National Convention next year "may well go uncommitted."

PITTSBURGH, July 10 (UPI) -- Dick Stuart belted a three-run homer over the center-field wall with two out in the eleventh inning tonight to give the Pittsburgh Pirates a 7-6 victory over the Chicago Cubs. It was the Bucs' eleventh extra-inning triumph in twelve games this season.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI) -- Senator Herman Talmadge, Democrat of Georgia, said today that the Democratic National Chairman, Paul M. Butler, should resign. If he fails to do so, the National Committee "ought to fire him at the first opportunity," Mr. Talmadge said.
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, July 10 -- This Caribbean capital leads an oddly quiet life under the ever-present reminder of the nation's dictator.
LIEUT. GEN. ABDUL HARIS NASUTION, Jakarta's new Minister of Security and Defense, is a military commander who denies he is anti-Communist or pro-American. He is pro-Indonesia.

MIAMI BEACH, July 10 -- Higher wages and job security in the face of growing automation on the waterfront were listed today as the key union demands in contract talks to be opened soon between the International Longshoremen's Association and waterfront employers.

BOSTON, July 9 -- The Cambridge Drama Festival production of Shakespeare's "Twelfth Night," which opened the New Arts Center Theatre on the Charles River bank in Brighton, is cheerfully entertaining, sometimes brilliant, yet unperfected.

HAVANA, July 10 -- Regulations implementing last week's revision of the Constitution widening the application of the death penalty for various crimes are awaiting the signature of President Manuel Urrutia Lleo.

YONKERS, July 10 -- Moving from eighth to first place without a semblance of opposition during a 32 1/5-second quarter, Great Lullwater, handled by Stanley Dancer, went on to a two-length victory in the $10,000 Oceanside trot at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
Acting Mayor Abe Stark moved yesterday to force the West Side Tennis Club to give up the Davis Cup and national championship matches unless it dropped its discrimination against Negroes and Jews.
For the first time in eight days stocks failed yesterday to make a new historic high. More issues rose than fell and losses were moderate.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commismission is planning to set off some non-nuclear explosions in a Louisiana salt mine as part of its studies on detecting underground atomic explosions.

ACCRA, Ghana, July 10 -- The Ghanaian Parliament approved today without a vote a Government motion that the Ghana-Guinea declaration of May. 1 provides "a sound and workable basis for the formation of a union of independent African states."

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- Representative James Roosevelt of California took his three children to the White House today for a visit with President Eisenhower and a first look at the office once occupied by their grandfather.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The Dominican Republic, in a surprise move today, withdrew charges before the Organization of American States that Cuba and Venezuela were plotting an invasion of its territory.

Two lawyers' associations filed briefs yesterday supporting General Sessions Judge Mitchell D. Schweitzer in impounding and sealing a grand jury presentment concerning the fixing of television quiz shows.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- President Eisenhower suggested today a new kind of bedtime story for children: Tales emphasizing the need for prudent spending.

CHICAGO, July 10 (AP) -- Corn and new-crop soybean futures, long under steady pressure on the Board of Trade, ran into a good general demand again today and scored their best advances in more than two weeks.

The Fairbanks Whitney Corporation, a holding company formerly known as the Penn-Texas Corporation, operated in the black in the first six months of this year in contrast to a deficit incurred in the period a year earlier.

SAINT-DENIS, Reunion, July 10 -- France's southernmost citizens, including a sizable Communist minority, cheered President Charles de Gaulle here today on the final stop in his tour of Indian Ocean territories.
Gunmen took nearly $50,000 yesterday in six separate holdups in Manhattan and the Bronx. Only one man was caught but he admitted three bank robberies in the last month.
HOBOKEN, N. J., July 10 -- An unusual craft, wearing a three-inch coating of a new type of insulating material, left here under tow this afternoon for a 2,800-mile trip.
LOS ANGELES, July 10 -- A brush fire raged through the Hollywood hills for more than six hours late today, devastating more than a square mile and destroying a dozen or more homes.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- A bitter dispute has broken out in the House Labor Committee over alleged leaks of information about votes at the committee's closed sessions.

I was somewhat disappointed but not particularly surprised when I read the item in The Times on June 29 about the Constellation. The fiction that the vessel of this name now at Baltimore is the same as the one built in 1797 has become so firmly established as a fact that it hardly seems worth making another attempt to correct it.
PARIS, July 10 -- Premier Michel Debre ordered the arrest today of a prominent Madagascar nationalist who was on his way back to his homeland with apparent French approval.
NEW DELHI, India, July 10 (Reuters) -- The Congress party of the strife-torn, Communist-ruled state of Kerala urged President Rajendra Prasad today to call a general election there.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Admiral Arthur W. Radford, former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told House investigators today that retired military officers wielded little influence on the pentagon in obtaining defense contracts.
MAMARONECK, N. Y., July 10 -- Don Hoenig, former Connecticut open champion and his partner, Jimmy Grant, scored the chief upset in the John G. Anderson memorial golf tournament today.
BROWNSTOWN STUD FARM, The Curragh, County Kildare, Ireland, July 2 -- The ancient Chinese philosophers said one of the great joys of man's existence was to find a familiar face in a strange country.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Through the first half of 1959 there were twice as many cases of paralytic poliomyelitis in the United States as in the same period last year. The totals were 681 for 1959, 329 for 1958.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- A third Chesapeake Bay private beach turned away a Chinese family July 4 because of restrictions against non-white patrons, it was learned today.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 10 -- The first step toward achievement of one of James R. Hoffa's major objectives as general president of the Teamsters Union has come as a result of the annual convention of the 352,000-member Western Conference of Teamsters.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 10 -- Former Gov. Goodwin J. Knight is in the midst of a heated art controversy. He is determined that a portrait of himself by Cameron Booth, a Minnesota artist commissioned to do the job for $3,500, shall not hang in the State Capitol at Sacramento.
TRENTON, July 10 -- The New Jersey Department of Agriculture announced today that 5,590 acres of farm land in Salem County would be reclaimed as a watershed.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The biggest corn crop in United States history is in prospect for this year.

Major debt financing in the public capital market will total about $129,000,000 next week.
An example of alleged coercion of a client by a television network was written into the record of a Federal Communications Commission hearing yesterday.

LONDON, July 10 -- Share prices ended the week on a rising note with demand still highly selective on the Stock Exchange here.
A New Jersey father admitted yesterday that it was a bullet that accidentally discharged from a pistol in his briefcase that nicked his 17-month-old son last June 30.
Taxicabs clocked hundreds of miles on the Harlem River Drive yesterday -- without collecting a nickel in fares.
LONDON, July 10 -- The Soviet Union has assured Britain that Western occupation rights in West Berlin will remain intact during the period of an interim agreement between East and West.
ROME, July 10 -- Hopes for quick settlement of the thirty-two-day-old Italian shipping strike faded again today.
Dr. Ralph J. Bunche will appear on WRCA-TV's "Sunday Special" show tomorrow from 9:30 to 10:25 A. M.
LONDON, July 10 -- Roy Thomson, Canadian newspaper proprietor, was named today as the person negotiating for Kemsley newspapers, one of the largest newspaper groups in Britain.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- One juror who refused to yield to argument or persuasion blocked a verdict today in the trial of Richard A. Mack, a former Federal Communications Commissioner, and Thursman A. Whiteside.

Property on the northwest corner of Central Park West and Sixty-eighth Street has been sold by John A. Dilliard to a builder for improvement with a seventeen-story, air-conditioned apartment house. The proposed apartments will be operated on a cooperative basis.

A revised and up-to-date edition of "The Middle East, Oil and the Great Powers 1959," by Benjamin Shwadran, will be published next Wednesday by the Council for Middle Eastern Affairs Press. It gives the story of oil in the region in the last sixty years and describes the impact of its development on the East-West struggle.
GENEVA, July 10 -- United States, British and Soviet scientists recommended today that satellites be put into orbit to detect nuclear explosions in outer space.
A number of young women from New York, Westchester County and Connecticut will be presented to society at the Mistletoe Debutante Ball, to be held in the St. Regis Roof on Dec. 23.

Title I is a section of the Housing Act of 1949 designed to bring private capital into slum clearance. It permits cities to acquire substandard areas and resell them at a markdown to private developers. The Federal Government pays two-thirds of the difference between the original cost and the resale price; the city pays the other third.
Sixteen housing properties in Manhattan and the Bronx have been sold by Sidney J. Ungar through Schimmer, Kerner Feder, brokers.

A store at the southwest corner of Third Avenue and Sixty-ninth Street has been leased by the Manufacturers Trust Company for a branch. It is in Imperial House, a 380-apartment building being constructed by Fisher Brothers.
SYRACUSE, July 10 (AP) -- Doug Floren of Jackson Heights, Queens, beat Zavis Zavodni of White Plains, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 1, today for the New York State junior tennis championship. Each is 17 years old.

CLEVELAND, July 10 (AP) -- Spending for new equipment in the metal-working industry will reach a near-record level in the second half of this year, Steel Magazine said today.

ALBANY, July 11 -- The state has embarked on a broad critical study of the New York public school system.

RICHMOND, Va., July 11 (AP) -- Virginia Democrats will settle in a primary Tuesday contests involving about a third of the seats in the General Assembly. A few key races are being watched closely in an effort to measure any rise or fall in the slim control of the Legislature held by Gov. J. Lindsay Almond Jr.

The course of retail trade was upward in the week ended July 4, although the size of the average gain was not as large as reported earlier in the year. With 90 per cent of the Kansas wheat harvest completed, the cash crop will begin to have some influence on retail business, especially on the durable goods.

A NEW family of hand tools which trim, shape and form many different materials, is becoming popular with home handymen. Fast and easy to use, these versatile cutting tools speed many difficult jobs such as trimming plywood edges and planing aluminum doors.

HONG KONG, July 9 -- The Chinese Communists have opened China's largest motion picture training center in Shanghai, the Peiping radio announced today. Known as the Shanghai Cinema College, the new school of motion picture arts will train actors and photographers, and artists to create animated cartoons, according to the broadcast.
The X-ray's newest forms are injecting greater efficiency into defense and civilian industry and are creating a mushrooming industry-within-an-industry.

THE Council on Foreign Relations launched its annual reviews of foreign affairs in 1931. If, in the years between, it had done no more than sponsor this admirable series, it would still have placed the student of foreign affairs in its debt.
The work load of the nation's privately owned shipyards dropped last month to the lowest point in three years.

Two giants of the plywood industry are fighting over which one should be allowed to spend some $85,000,000 for an Oregon lumber company. The contenders are the United States Plywood Corporation, a leading manufacturer and largest distributor of plywood products, and the Georgia-Pacific Corporation, the largest manufacturer of plywood.
No labor negotiations in the period since World War II have been so directly affected by the weight of public opinion as the current steel contract talks.

THE National Broadcasting Company has been denied Soviet approval to film a television program in the Moscow Baptist Church. The network had applied for visas in the hope that a production crew, augmented by Russian technicians, could visit Moscow this month and record the program.

REMEMBER, way back before the estival festival movement was started in New York, when summer used to be summer? Then nobody danced between Decoration and Labor Days, except for an occasional evening at Lewisohn Stadium, and even they seemed a bit venturesome.
HACKENSACK, N. J., July 11 -- The high rate of industrial expansion in New Jersey is causing a major problem for Bergen County communities.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The Dominican Embassy denied today that the Dominican Republic had dropped her charges that Cuba and Venezuela were plotting an invasion of her territory.

THE impression one is left with after a half-year's wandering from Kenya to the Cape of Good Hope, from Leopoldville in the Congo to Lourenco Marques in Mozambique, is that the majesty of Africa's natural wonder is matched only by the complexity of her human problem.
ELIZABETH, N. J., July 11 -- The Federal Housing and Home Finance Agency has rejected this city's plea for a $20,000 grant to blueprint a comprehensive revamping of the central business district.

John S. Wilson underlines a point I have been trying to make for some time without success: that adolescents have emerged as a united, self-conscious and cohesive "ethnic" group of tremendous power.

KUNGALV, Sweden, July 11 (Reuters) -- Denmark threw her weight tonight behind proposals for a seven-nation "outer" free-trade area in Europe, clearing the way for final negotiations on the trade bloc.

The fundamental concepts of the "aerodynamics of baseball" were discussed in a recent lecture by Dr. W. Milton Swanson, assistant professor of mechanical engineering at the Case Institute of Technology, Cleveland, Ohio, before the Case Chapter of the Society of Sigma Xi, scientific honor society.
Allen Morris, the Eastern clay-court champion, gained the final round of the New York State tennis championship yesterday at the North Shore Tennis and Racquets Club in Bayside, Queens.

Economic improvement continues in the district. Checks drawn in June totaled $$9,000,000,000, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond. This compared with 7.7 billions a year ago. The rate of increase, 17 per cent, was duplicated in the first six months total.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 11 -- Both sides are arming for another engagement in Tennessee's war of the clock that has been going on, intermittently, for fifteen years.

THE formal Colonial Garden of the Essex County Historical Society is at peak bloom now. Located in Elizabethtown, N. Y., on U. S. Route 9, the garden is an adaptation of one enjoyed by Henry VIII at Hampton Court in England.

A theatre party at the evening performance of "Connecticut Summer" on Nov. 19 will benefit the Kips Bay Boys Club. The new musical version of the Eugene O'Neill comedy, "Ah, Wilderness!" starring Jackie Gleason, Walter Pidgeon and Eileen Herlie, is scheduled to open at the Shubert Theatre on Oct. 22.
The National Maritime Union will press for five wage demands, headed by a 10 per cent increase across the board, in its impending talks with the operators of 610 American-flag deep-sea ships.

The historic "Lowell Trust of Boston," which was turned over to Harvard College last week by its trustees, has grown in value to more than $2,000,000 from an initial capital of $11,350 invested in 1838. The trust was established by seven Harvard graduates in Boston, who felt that the college should not be available only to sons of the wealthy.
TERRE HAUTE, Ind., July 11 (AP) -- Six of ten witnesses pleaded the Fifth Amendment today when asked about dealings with an alleged nationwide gambling syndicate in the fall of 1957.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (UPI) -- A defector from Premier Castro's air force has told Senate investigators of Communist infiltration into Cuban armed forces, it was learned today.

I am afraid the celebrated preview audiences at "Porgy and Bess," who were said to have "collected themselves" for a full minute after the picture ended, were not suffering from emotional catharsis after all. The Red Sox beat the Yankees, 8 -- 4, on Don Buddin's home run with the bases loaded in the tenth inning yesterday. Tony Kubek of the Yanks hit a homer in the ninth to send the game into overtime. The Giants defeated the Reds, 5 -- 3.

Ireland expects its 1959 income from visitors to equal that of last season, according to the Irish Tourist Board. Tourists spent $96,880,000 in 1958 -- a record year -- the board said.
