THE Russian Festival at Madison Square Garden will present an almost entirely different program for its final week, which begins tomorrow evening.
HONG KONG, July 11 -- The Chinese Communists have published a book in English that attempts to justify the recent Communist suppression of the revolt in Tibet.

VIENNA, July 11 -- The Czechoslovak machine tool industry today occupies an important role in the Soviet bloc's economic race against the Western world. Its great expansion to meet the requirements of the European Communist states and Communist China is indicated by export figures published in the July report of the Czechoslovak Chamber of Commerce.

JULY marks the beginning of the annual country-fair season. From now until November, these celebrations will be one of the major types of tourist attractions in the rural areas. Here in the East to date a total of 285 fairs have been announced in ten states from Maine down to Maryland.

WINNFIELD, La., July 11 -- Gov. Earl K. Long left here today for a lengthy western vacation tour after announcing that he might establish two daily newspapers after he returns.

LIMA, Peru, July 6 -- The 1959 mountain climbing season in the Peruvian Andes, roughly from May to October, is attracting an especially large number of foreign climbers this year. Several parties are carrying out geological, topographical and other scientific research.

I AM not the only reviewer to be distressed by Dr. Stein's use of synthesized case-histories. A psychological construct is a scientific monstrosity and we are bound to suspect all theories which are based on it."

The American consumer is paying the lowest prices for coffee since July, 1950. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics the average retail price of vacuum-packed coffee in forty-six cities was 77.2 cents a pound on May 15. Coffee in bags averaged 57.9 cents a pound.

GLEN COVE, L. I., July 12 -- A summer music festival, which will offer concerts on alternate Sunday evenings, opened tonight in the Glen Cove High School.
BOGOR, July 12 (Reuters) -- Following is a complete list of Indonesia's Cabinet members:
CAIRO, July 12 -- Final results in the elections to the United Arab Republic's National Union, the organization from which a Parliament will be selected, were announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -The Government of Chile has proposed that any meeting held by the foreign ministers of the twenty-one American republics to consider unrest in the Caribbean area take place at the Chilean capital of Santiago in August.

Mack Trucks, Inc., plans to acquire its parent, the Northeast Capital Corporation, under a merger plan announced over the week-end. Northeast owned 739,000 shares, or 29 per cent, of Mack Trucks common stock at latest report.
KUNGALV, Sweden, July 12 -- Four Nordic countries endorsed today the formation of an "outer" free-trade area in Europe, as proposed by Britain.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Another warning that politically explosive hog prices were heading for "critically low" levels was issued today. Together with the warning, a stop-gap program involving direct Government subsidies was proposed.

FORT WORTH, Tex., July 12 (AP) -- Gov. Earl K. Long of Louisiana rested here today after having apologized for some stormy action that attended his arrival last night. His plans for a Western vacation remained vague, while he awaited a possible invitation to address the Texas Legislature.
THE sudden bounty of pork comes at a season when that meat usually is scarce. It also comes at a time when shoppers tend to shun pork as "too rich" or "too fatty" for hot-weather menus.

"Road to Revolution," a new book by Avrahm Yarmolinsky, will be published July 21 by Macmillan. It is an account of those men and women of nineteenth-century Russia who revolted in moral protest against the established order.

DEACON BILL McKECHNIE had just been fired as the manager of the Cincinnati Reds. The mild-mannered Deacon accepted his fate with dignity, a gracious and courtly gentleman to the end. But he walked right out of baseball when he stepped from the office of the man who had dismissed him, Warren Giles, now the National League president but then the top executive of the Reds.

PITTSBURGH, July 12 -- The steel outlook for the third quarter is much firmer than had been expected by many steel makers. Order volume last week totaled more than 70 per cent of operations. Furthermore it was said that the number of cancellations that might have been made because of the extension of the strike deadline a few weeks ago had failed to materialize.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Attorney General William P. Rogers cautioned Government officials today to use the greatest care despite their "absolute privilege" for defamatory statements issued in the course of official duties.

MILWAUKEE, July 12 (AP) -- Eddie Mathews drove in all four Milwaukee runs with a home run and a sacrifice fly and Lew Burdette scattered seven hits as the Braves gained a 4-2 victory over the San Francisco Giants today.
CHICAGO, July 12 (AP) -- Pressure on the grain futures market was steadily bearish last week until a late rally raised some contracts to the plus side with rye and new crop soybeans the best gainers.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Reports reaching the State Department today indicated that a revolt in Honduras had been crushed after considerable casualties.
Protestant and Eastern Orthodox leaders will gather next month on the island of Rhodes, Greece, for one of the major religious meetings of the year.
BOSTON, July 12 -- As if there weren't enough startling events stirring in the current Yankee-Red Sox series here, what with the Bombers blowing the first four games, a new development arose today.

Some weeks ago the director of the foreign student office at Cornell University was asked to recommend a foreign student who could serve as the main speaker on June 22 for the senior class commencement at West Leyden Central School.

HAVANA, July 12 -- Premier Fidel Castro accused the United States last night of interfering in Cuba's internal affairs in granting asylum to the former chief of the Cuban Air Force and in questioning him before United States Senators.

Geisinger Germain, realty operators, resold a contract they signed recently for the purchase of the five-story apartment house for twenty-four families at 114 Field Place in the Bronx to Joseph Teller. The Taylor Company was the broker in the purchase and Leonard, Levites Schiller arranged the resale.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -Backers of Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas for the Democratic Presidential nomination have suffered their first major setback in a Southern state.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 12 (AP) -- A team of fifty-nine Soviet track and field athletes, men and women, arrived today en route by air to New York. They will compete against United States athletes Saturday and next Sunday in a meet at Philadelphia.
Orders to shut down the steel mills went out last night after efforts to head off a national strike had come to a dead end.

CLEVELAND, July 12 (UPI) -- Rocky Colavito's twenty-seventh and twenty-eighth homers of the year sparked the league-leading Cleveland Indians to an 8-4 comeback victory over Detroit in the second game of a double-header today. The Tigers won the opener, 6-2, on Paul Foytack's six-hit pitching.

A virtual end to lynching and the strengthening of constitutional safeguards for all Americans were cited yesterday as accomplishments of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People in its first fifty years.
A Federal inquiry into steamship conferences and their cargo rate practices will resume in Washington today before a subcommittee of the House.

CINCINNATI, July 12 (AP) -- Gus Bell picked on the first pitch of Roger Craig in the ninth inning today and singled in the winning run in the Cincinnati Reds' 4-3 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

The final moments before the successful landing of the crippled Pan American jet Clipper yesterday morning were marked by growing tension. This was the exchange of radio messages between the plane and the airport tower:
WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- United States officials said today that Communist China was intensifying its wooing of Latin-American nations to the point of a major propaganda campaign.
Chesebrough-Pond's, Inc., and McCann-Erickson, Inc., are terminating their forty-seven-year relationship on Oct. 15.
Drastic action next fall to cut an increase in fire hazards in schools was threatened yesterday by Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr.

PATCHOGUE, L. I., July 12 -- Charley Axtmann's Teaser IV scored a series sweep today among the Narrasketucks as the annual regatta of the Domino Yacht Club ended. Teaser beat George Palmer's Ambition II for the second straight day.

Last Wednesday, at a luncheon in Whiting, Ind., Frol R. Kozlov voiced one of the few major public complaints he made during his tour of the United States. "Please reduce the size of your beefsteaks," he told the luncheon group, adding, "They are enough for two people."

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- A small storm was blowing up this week-end among Senate Republicans over the possible appointment of Charles E. Bohlen as special adviser on Soviet affairs to the Secretary of State.

JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector), July 12 -- President Itzhak Ben-Zvi neared the end of his consultations with political parties today without any workable suggestions for a new coalition to replace the present caretaker Government.
ON two occasions early yesterday, Capt. Edward Foster Sommers of Pan American World Airways demonstrated the steady, clearheaded qualities essential to the complete airman.

Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. charged yesterday that Port Authority personnel had hindered rescue operations at New York International Airport for the landing of a crippled jet airliner early yesterday. The jet put down safely with 113 aboard after circling the airport for nearly four hours.

The report entitled "Union Constitutions," published today in pamphlet form by the Fund for the Republic, is especially timely now that dictatorship as well as corruption in labor organizations has been so widely advertised by the hearings of the McClellan committee. The author, Leo Bromwich, has taken an objective look at the American labor movement as a "political society."
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Has the official design for the fifty-star flag been selected already?

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Economists here are taking heart from a little noticed development in the price indexes -- a period of stability in industrial wholesale prices that has now lasted for three months.

BOGOR, Indonesia, July 12 -- President Sukarno announced today a list of twenty-three deputy ministers that excluded avowed Communists. However, the list included one man who is widely regarded as pro-Communist and at least one other who is Leftist.
A week after winning the Eastern clay-court tennis championship, Allen Morris of Atlanta and Forest Hills, Queens, carried off the New York State title yesterday.

BAASTAD, Sweden, July 12 (AP) -- Ramanathan Krishnan of India, who upset the Wimbledon champion, Alex Olmedo of Peru, yesterday, in turn was beaten today in the final of the Baastad international tennis tournament.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- Hoyt Wilhelm finally got back on the beam today after four straight losses. He halted the slugging Washington Senators with four singles as Baltimore won, 5 -- 1.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey called today for a full debate before permitting the Administration to go ahead with agreements on sharing nuclear weapons data with West European countries.
PITTSBURGH, July 12 -- Steel mills in the Pittsburgh area began today the costly and complex operation of shutting in anticipation of a strike at midnight Tuesday.
Cotton prices in the domestic market held to a narrow trading range last week and closed with small mixed net changes.
A record of limited success in combating foreign discrimination against United States flag ships by negotiation has led the Maritime Administration to develop new retaliatory weapons.

LOS ALTOS, Calif., July 12 (AP) -- Frank McKinney of the Indianapolis Athletic Club broke the world record for the 200-meter back-stroke tonight in the Amateur Athletic Union's men's national outdoor swimming championships.

Eighty-seven jetborne travelers arrived in London at 6:16 P. M., New York time, yesterday, fourteen hours late but happy to be alive after the air drama in which they had taken part Saturday night over Idlewild, Queens.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 12 -- The Food and Agriculture Organization expects global production of rice to reach a new peak of 135,000,000 metric tons this year.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, July 12 -- Rebellion against the Government broke out early today and gunfire is continuing here in the capital.

MILWAUKEE, July 12 (AP) -- About fifty persons were pitched into Lake Michigan today when a section of dock collapsed as they were preparing to board a Navy launch for a tour of the cruiser U.S.S. Macon.

The Brill Estate, William Brill, president, has sold the six-story apartment house at 2330 Ocean Avenue, near Avenue P, Brooklyn, for more than $300,000. The building, which was erected by the seller's father in 1938, contains forty - eight apartments and occupies a plot 75 by 100 feet.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., July 12 -- Rutgers University today announced promotions for eighty-nine members of the faculty. The promotions include twenty-six full professorships or their research equivalents, thirty-one associate professorships and thirty-two assistant professorships.

A Negro woman's charge that she had been refused a job as hostess by Capital Airlines "because of my color" will be the basis for a hearing at 10:30 A.M. tomorrow before the State Commission Against Discrimination at 270 Broadway.
THE curtain will rise today on Bloomingdale's new exhibit of model rooms and it will reveal this year's story of furniture and decorating: a plethora of styles and colors.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 12 -- One of the most burning laments of writers here has been the failure of the movie business to appreciate their value. This fact has been pushed into the open by Edmund Hartmann, national chairman of the Writers Guild of America.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 12 (AP) -- The prosecutor's office of the Taipei District Court has found no substance to charges that Kiang Pao, former Minister of Economic Affairs, had been guilty of dereliction of duty. It also cleared King Kai-ying and Hsia Ching-tu, officials of the state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corporation.

The Armco Steel Corporation announced plans yesterday for building at Middletown, Ohio, what it called the steel industry's largest, fastest and widest continuous coating unit for producing zinc-coated steel sheets.
LONG BEACH, L.I., July 12 -- A program to develop "special ties" between Long Beach and the town of Saint-Marc in Haiti has been started by city officials in cooperation with the Haitian government.

Production of men's suits during May was 20 per cent greater than in the 1958 month, according to the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A. While the rise is substantial, it was noted by Harry A. Cobrin, executive secretary of the association, that the industry was depressed in 1958.
The Great Northern Railway's net income in the first half of this year was $10,637,000, a gain of 83 per cent over the level of the first six months of 1958, when the carrier cleared $5,823,000.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12 (AP) -- Earl Averill's three-run homer helped Chicago to a 7-6 victory over Philadelphia today in the opener of a double-header. However, the Phillies took the second game, 4 -- 1, behind the five-hit pitching of Ray Semproch.

Nobody, except possibly the Commissioner and staff of the Internal Revenue Service, danced in the streets yesterday to celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of Congress' approval of the Sixteenth Amendment. We respect the Commissioner and his staff but we do not really love them. We realize the necessity for the income tax but we prefer to let our minds dwell on happier subjects.
THE Russians have sent America a smash hit fashion show.
People aren't supposed to speculate in mutual funds. But they do.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., July 12 -- Fifty-seven high school boys interested in specific areas of science are being exposed here to other, unfamiliar areas -- and they like it.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 12 -- The Air Force School of Aviation Medicine is moving from Randolph Air Force Base, northeast of the city, to new $10,000,000 quarters at Brooks Air Force Base, on the southern edge of town.
SANTIAGO DE CUBA, July 12 -- Anyone seeking the spirit of the Cuban revolution has to come to Santiago de Cuba, in Oriente Province at the eastern end of the country.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (UPI) -- Representative Samuel S. Stratton, Democrat of upstate New York, urged the Government today to consider the feasibility of stockpiling milk to help feed the country in a nuclear attack.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Paul M. Butler, the Democratic National Chairman, asserted today that "the noise and the fury" aroused by his criticism of the Democratic leadership in Congress had been prompted by the desire of some Democrats to replace him with a Western Senator.
DUBLIN, July 11 -- The dominating motif in Irene Gilbert's fall and winter collection was her "side line."
TOKYO, Monday, July 13 (AP) -- The Chinese Communist party indicated today that mainland China would fail to achieve the ambitious 525,000,000-ton of grain production for 1959 set by the party.

NEW ENGLANDERS won most of the victories in the Southern New England Championships played at Norwich, Conn., over the weekend, but the principal title -- the open pairs -- went to Jack Van Gelder and Paul Trent of New York.
A spiceless dish was added to the international soccer menu at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island, on Sunday.
Stuart Sherman, long a leading figure in advertising, has resigned as corporate vice president for marketing at the Colgate-Palmolive Company.
GENEVA, July 12 -- The second stage of the Big Four foreign ministers' conference, starting here tomorrow, is being narrowed down ever so slowly to a single major question.

"The housewife baking a cake. the miilhand at his daily labor, the actor, the artist and the journalist, all share in the building of the Kingdom of God; these are the servants of the Kingdom," the Rev. A. Stephan Hopkinson said yesterday.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 12 -- Thomas J. Watson Jr., president of International Business Machines Corporation and commodore of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club, was established as the winner of his club's ocean race today.

The sharp advance in prices of common stocks, together with the rise in long-term interest rates, has created a more favorable climate for equity financing than has existed in many years, the Morgan Guaranty Bank of New York said today in its monthly publication, the Morgan Guaranty Survey.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa declared yesterday that recent test bidding on school construction had upheld one element of his charge of waste and extravagance in that field.

Again and again items appear in the news that should remind us that the war on disease and the conservation of health present world-wide problems. There are no regional or national boundaries that confine these problems. They are essentially human, and while they vary in intensity from place to place and time to time, they offer a continuing challenge to all men.

The National Bureau of Economic Research was the principal beneficiary of $6,621,916 in grants announced yesterday by the Ford Foundation. The bureau will receive $2,500,000 for its long-term research program on the nation's economy.
PITTSBURGH, July 12 (AP) -- Elroy Face scored his fourteenth victory without a loss as a relief pitcher this season as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 6-5, in ten innings today.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., July 12 -- The first weekend of the Empire State Music Festival ended tonight with a concert of works by the Brazilian Heitor Villa-Lobos. The program was played by the Symphony of the Air, under the composer's direction, in the festival's temporary quarters at the Anthony Wayne Recreation Area in Harriman State Park.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 12 -- Regular racers of the Long Island Sound Yacht Racing Association have learned that in one of the regattas annually conducted by the Orienta Yacht Club they may expect, if weather conditions are right, a downwind start.

W. Averell Harriman said yesterday that the Berlin crisis could be solved by limited Western "acceptance" of the East German Communist regime without giving it diplomatic recognition. He declared that he considered control of nuclear weapons the vital issue and Berlin largely a diversion.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., July 12 -- Deane Beman, the British amateur champion, putted in incredible fashion today as he and Bill Buppert of Bethesda, Md., won the John G. Anderson Memorial golf tournament for the second year in a row.

We applaud your editorial of July 9, "Going Wrong Downtown," in which you properly point out that the Rockefeller-Butt blueprint deserves precedence over any pier schemes of the Department of Marine and Aviation.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 12 -- The Soviet Union is believed here to have no serious objection to Finland's joining in a free-trade area with the "outer seven" countries of Western Europe. This was reported in official circles following the disclosure by Premier Sukselainen yesterday that Finland might make it the "outer eight."

The almost unbroken tradition of disparagement by the nation's press of efforts by Congress to bolster our free-enterprise system through aids to small business is assured continuity by The Times' editorial of June 27.
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., July 12 (AP) -- Sixteen persons were injured today when a Greyhound bus smashed into the rear of a tractor-trailer loaded with circus equipment.
LENOX, Mass., July 12 -- The striking new acoustical shell in the Music Shed here in Tanglewood was dedicated last night immediately preceding a program of Mozart symphonies.

NEW DELHI, India, July 12 -- The Chief Minister of the Communist Government of Kerala returned here today from discussions in Simla with Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru and expressed "full confidence" that there would be no central Government intervention in Kerala.
CHET HUNTLEY'S news and commentary program over Channel 4 explored yesterday the plight of the college president who must apportion his time between fund-raising and more strictly academic pursuits.
Following is the text of an exchange of letters yesterday by David J. McDonald, president of the United Steelworkers of America, and the industry's contract bargaining committee:
ROME, July 12 -- The longawaited amnesty bill was promulgated in today's Official Gazette, and judges worked overtime drawing up lists of prison inmates who are to be freed, beginning tomorrow.

Frol R. Kozlov said yesterday his visit to this country had confirmed rather than changed his previous picture of the United States. He expressed agreement with Soviet Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's prediction two years ago that the grandchildrenof present-day Americans would live in a Socialist society.

The Link Belt Company has announced that it has acquired from the Turbine Equipment Company the patents and assets of the Teco continuous automatic metal chip handling system. The system, in combination with other conveying equipment, permits the metal working industries to realize a premium on the sale of oil-free metal chips and turnings.
Following is an unofficial translation of a statement by Frol R. Kozlov, a Soviet First Deputy Premier, at a press conference here yesterday:
A New York City policeman who has written seven plays says "gossiping" is the way he gathers his material.
ALBANY, July 12 (AP) -- New York State reasserted today its opposition to allowing Chicago to divert more water from Lake Michigan.
A new survey indicates that most labor union constitutions are "democratic in intent" but have serious procedural flaws that limit individual rights of members.
A floor in the office building being constructed by Samuel Rudin at 80 Pine Street has been leased by Arthur Andersen Co., certified public accountants.
Record first-quarter sales and earnings were reported by the Grand Union Company in the statement issued today by Lansing P. Shield, president.
WARSAW, July 12 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev will tour Poland this week as the honored guest and full-voiced supporter of the Government he tried to destroy less than three years ago.
BOSTON, July 12 -- The Yankees didn't wait to get themselves knocked out today. This time they took it on the chin for four runs in the first inning and dropped a 7-3 decision to the Red Sox.

It is reassuring to learn that Messrs. Nixon and Herter straightened out Frol Kozlov on his claim that we demanded gold payment for our relief to Russia during the 1921-23 famine. As one who served with Herbert Hoover's ARA (American Relief Administration) in the Soviet Union I can testify, that the Russian people profoundly appreciated America's good neighborliness in coming to their aid.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., July 12 -- The Empire State Music Festival refuses to be intimidated by obstacles. Under a tent in a park recreation area it had the temerity to attempt a full stage production of an opera last night and succeeded in performing it with complete professional aplomb.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., July 12 -- Dr. George W. Brooks' 68-foot yawl Black Watch, out of Larchmont, N. Y., and De Coursey Fales schooner Nina were leading the fleet four hours after the start of the 360-mile Marblehead-to-Halifax race.
A flock of non-paying passengers swarmed aboard a Jamaica-bound "E" subway train yesterday afternoon, led by Frol R. Kozlov, a Soviet First Deputy Premier.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (UPI) -- Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, who recently retired as Army Chief of Staff, said today there had been no over-all reappraisal of the nation's defense forces since shortly after President Eisenhower took office in January, 1953.

While music played and stewardresses served dinner aboard the crippled jet Clipper as it circled over the city Saturday night, a radio broadcast told some of the passengers about the grim preparations being made below for a crash landing.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, July 12 -- Reports from industry continue decidedly optimistic. There is again great activity in the building industry so that many sectors complain of a labor shortage.

Prudence becomes a true virtue when it is applied in seeking spiritual goals rather than material gains, the Rev. Raymond T. Powers said yesterday at the 10 A. M. solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
The many rewards of a binding trust in God was the subject of the sermon yesterday at Broadway Congregational Church, at Fifty-sixth Street.
The Georgia-Pacific Corporation has offered to pay more than $93,000,000 for the stock of the Booth-Kelly Lumber Company, Springfield, Ore.

Title I is a section of the Housing Act of 1949 designed to bring private capital into slum clearance. It permits cities to acquire substandard areas and resell them at a markdown to private developers.

WESTPORT, Conn., July 12 -- American elementary and high school students are getting too much "Pablum" and not enough food for serious thought in their history courses, a report by a citizens' group here charges.
DUBLIN, July 5 -- One way to lose your membership quickly in the Gaelic Athletic Association in this green land is to go in for cha-cha-cha on the dance floor.
The National Science Foundation has awarded eight research grants totaling $253,400 to Columbia University faculty members. The grants, to support basic research projects, run from two to four years.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 12 -- The world's second largest telescope will be dedicated Thursday evening.

Assets totaling $49,680,300,000 were held in personal trust accounts in banks and trust companies in the United States in 1958, the American Bankers Association said yesterday. The association based its figures on the first nation-wide survey of bank-administered personal trust holdings ever made.

Many thousands of radio and television listeners were painfully aware night before last that a London-bound Pan American World Airways jet clipper, Flight 102, was having landing-gear trouble over Idlewild. Yesterday the captain and most of the passengers resumed their journey on the first available substitute plane. That is the way with our airborne generation.
The United States Department of Commerce recently reported that Americans spent more money on foreign travel in 1958 than in any previous year in history. It sees even greater expenditures in 1959.
SLOATSBURG, N. Y., July 12 -- Ten mycophiles roamed the woods near here today in search of their love -- mushrooms.

The Russian Festival of Music and dance will open its second and final week at Madison Square Garden tonight with a program consisting largely of new numbers, though all the same groups of performers will participate.

Leaders of the New York Committee for Democratic Voters warned yesterday that the party's present policies could lead to Republican victories in national, city and state elections in the next three years.

SHREVEPORT, La., July 12 (UPI) -- A Federal judge granted a restraining order today preventing the United States Civil Rights Commission from looking into complaints that Negroes were denied voting rights in north Louisiana.
State Controller Arthur Levitt, a Democrat, predicted yesterday that Governor Rockefeller would be the Republican candidate for President in 1960.
An $8,000,000 Air Force contract for electronic "filters" to minimize natural, accidental and intentional interference with defense radar signals was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 12 (AP) -- Jim McAnany hit a bases-loaded triple in the first game and duplicated the feat in the second contest to lead the Chicago White Sox to 5-3 and 9-7 victories over the Kansas City Athletics today.

A spot check of private clubs sponsoring public sports events in the metropolitan area discloses that virtually all of them have membership policies similar to those of the West Side Tennis Club, which bars Jews and Negroes.

The payment of unemployment insurance benefits to furloughed employes of the A. P. food-store chain was suspended pending a hearing yesterday by the Division of Employment of the State Labor Department.
The Western Maryland Railway reported yesterday gross revenue of $4,726,000 for June, the largest for any June in the company's history. In the 1958 month the gross was $3,646,000.
MOSCOW, July 13 -- The world's most traveled space dog has made another rocket flight into the upper atmosphere and returned safely to the Soviet Union.
The General Electric Company announced yesterday sizable price cuts in its line of large steam turbine generators.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Dr. T. Keith Glennan told the Senate Appropriations Committee today that House cuts in the Space Administration budget would have "disastrous consequences" for the nation's space program.
Governor Rockefeller will recommend a state-wide law against discrimination in multiple-dwelling private housing when the Legislature meets in January.

Russell A. Kimes, director of American Machine and Foundry Company's General Engineering Laboratories, Greenwich, Conn., has been appointed divisional vice president of AMF's Government Products Group.
Steel production turned slightly upward last week, although the rise was far less than had been forecast by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

YONKERS July 13 -- Sally Wilson of Scarsdale, the defending champion, and Wendy Stone of Oyster Bay, the newly-crowned New York State girl's champion, won their opening matches in the Eastern girls Tennis Tournament at the Racquet Club on Park Hill today.
ALGIERS, July 13 (UPI) -- President Charles de Gaulle ordered the release of 5,000 rebel suspects from internment camps tonight on the eve of Bastille Day.

Cocoa prices fell 30 to 38 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 345 lots yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The decline followed disappointing estimates for chocolate production. Grindings of cocoa beans during the second quarter were estimated to be 1 1/2 per cent greater than in the 1958 period but traders had expected an increase of 5 to 10 per cent.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- A special committee of the National Academy of Sciences reported today that a fleet of 300 nuclear-powered ships could safely dispose low-level radio-active wastes in the oceans "without undue hazard to human health."

HAMBURG, Germany, July 13 -- The British Labor party's proposal of a "non-nuclear club" of nations will get a test of acceptability at the meeting of the Socialist International here this week. Formal sessions will begin tomorrow.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 13 (UPI) -- Treason charges against three Americans who published a Communist-line magazine in Shanghai during the Korean War were dismissed today because the Government had failed to obtain indictments. A sedition indictment is still pending.

The Federal Aviation Agency said yesterday that "someone was guilty of very poor management" in handling the crowds that swarmed over New York International Airport late Saturday and early Sunday while efforts were being made to land a crippled jet airliner.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- In denouncing the President's veto of the omnibus housing bill as indicating his position that the legislative product shall not vary from the Presidential wishes in the slightest particular, Senate Majority Leader Johnson said the bill exemplified his policy that Congress should try to go "more than half way" to adjust differences with the Executive.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 13 -- This is the time of year when television fever sweeps the movie lots. Movie companies, through their subsidiaries, are not ashamed to compete with full-time television companies for the rights to make video films for the fall showings.
The Greenwich Village Association said yesterday that it had complained to the city that its area lacked litter baskets.
An advertising executive who operates closer to Wall Street than to Madison Avenue has completed forty years at Doremus Co.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy endorsed today agreements permitting closer cooperation in atomic weapons with seven Atlantic allies of the United States.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The Senate defeated an attempt today to add $234,000,000 to the defense budget for Army modernization. The vote was 48-43.

JUNCTION CITY, Kan., July 13 (UPI) -- Wilber M. Brucker. Secretary of the Army, said today the United States had "the power and the will to fight and win" if the Soviet Union pushed it too far in Berlin or elsewhere.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 13 (AP) -- Premier Abdul Karim Kassim of Iraq expanded his Cabinet tonight in what some observers interpreted as a further step away from the nation's powerful Communist organization. The Cabinet changes were broadcast by the Baghdad radio.
Producers' prices for copper fell abruptly yesterday after four months of unchanged high quotations.
NAIROBI, Kenya, July 13 -- After a three-year absence the returning visitor to Africa finds many changes in Nairobi -- and some things unchanged.
The railroad industry has finally been offered insurance against a contingency that has concerned it for the last several years.
A million-dollar project to publish a definitive edition of President Woodrow Wilson letters and papers has been advanced by a grant of $175,000 from the Ford Foundation.
The Italian Line said here yesterday that the thirty-sixday world-wide strike by Italian seamen might be near an end.

A group of garden apartments occupying an entire triangular block in the Bronx has been acquired by the Realty Equities Corporation. The property, which consists of eight three-story buildings, is bounded by Wilson Avenue, 214th and 215th Streets.

MOSCOW, July 12 -- A top American space physicist said today that Soviet scientists had presented the "first real evidence" that variable currents of electrons in outer space had influence on the earth's magnetic field.

PHILADELPHIA, July 13 -Fifty-nine track and field athletes, the first such Soviet sports group to visit this country, arrived shortly before noon today to prepare for their contest against teams of United States men and women.

SEATTLE, Wash., July 13 (UPI) -- Victor Denny, president of the United States Lawn Tennis Association, said today that he would have a statement tomorrow or Wednesday on the controversy involving Dr. Ralph J. Bunche and the West Side Tennis Club at Forest Hills, Queens.
The Board of Education pledged yesterday to eliminate all fire violations -- no matter how minor -- from the city's public schools before the fall term begins.

HAVANA, July 13 -- President Manuel Urrutia Lleo criticized the United States today for having given political asylum to Major Diaz. He said Cuba should send a diplomatic note of protest to the United States expressing her displeasure that the Senate had received information about alleged Communist infiltration from a "traitor and deserter."
THE joys of loafing were expounded to Casey Stengel during the All-Star break last week by an old buddy who had just begun to bask in the glow of his recent retirement. Stengel sighed.
LONDON, July 13 -- About a hundred ways of remaking injured or defective human faces and limbs were described at today's inaugural sessions of the International Congress on Plastic Surgery here.
With 500,000 steel workers poised to strike at midnight tonight, a climactic peace effort by President Eisenhower failed last night to produce agreement.

A new foreign-language program will be introduced next fall in twenty-three of the city's junior high schools. About 20,000 pupils are expected to take part in the program, which will offer French, Spanish, Italian and Hebrew.
GENEVA, July 13 -- West Germany has moved to head off what its leaders regard as the imminent danger of a major Western concession to the Soviet Union at its expense.

CINCINNATI, July 13 (AP) -- Cincinnati's seventh place Reds unlimbered their heavy artillery tonight with fifteen hits and three home runs -- two by Frank Robinson -- and routed the Los Angeles Dodgers, 13 -- 5.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 13 -- Three Connecticut girls, another from Westchester County and a fifth from Long Island qualified today for the Long Island Sound girls' sailing championship.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 13 (UPI) -- Cliff Lumsden of New Toronto, Ont., won the twenty-five-mile Atlantic City professional marathon swim today. He beat the 1958 winner, Tom Park of Bellflower, Calif., by 6 minutes.
The fifth and final copy of Lincoln's Gettysburg Address was turned over to the Federal Government yesterday by the Chase Manhattan Bank.
United States Government securities were marked up in price yesterday in quiet trading.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The short-term Treasury bill rate rose sharply this week and 182-day bills crossed the 4 per cent mark to another record, the Treasury disclosed tonight. The average interest rate on $1,200,000,000 of ninety-one-day bills was 3.401 per cent, compared with 3.266 per cent last week.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 13 -- The international wool market, tamed to the meekness of its own lambs by recession conditions since mid-1957, has begun to roar again. World prices reported to the statistical division of the United Nations have climbed steadily in each month of 1959 through April, with later but incomplete data implying an even steeper rise in May and June.
It will cost more to sail to Europe in season next year. Twenty - six trans Atlantic passenger steamship lines announced yesterday that they would raise their fares Jan. 1.
YONKERS, July 13 -- Fifteen 3-year-old pacers today were entered in the $64,457 William H. Cane Futurity Pace to be held at Yonkers Raceway Thursday night.

The Chicago and Eastern Illinois Railroad plans to call for redemption its 75,358 shares of $2 Series A stock. Although the stock is redeemable on ninety days' notice at $40 a share, plus any accumulated dividends, the railroad said it intended to retire the issue through an exchange for common stock.
BUENOS AIRES, July 13 -- The end of the wheat trading monopoly by the State Grain Corporation was announced today by Argentina's new Secretary of Agriculture and Livestock, Ernesto Malaccorto.

Branson Instruments, Inc., ultrasonic device maker of Jersey City yesterday registered a proposed secondary offering of 40,000 shares of common stock. Of the 40,000 shares, 10,000 would be sold for the company's account and 30,000 for stock-holders.
The eighty-inch lens with which the National Broadcasting Company on Sunday made it possible for parlor pilot and kitchen coach to become real experts has "stolen" its last "sign."

ELIZABETH, N. J., July 13 -- A Union County grand jury charged today that former Sheriff Alex C. Campbell had taken $2,200 from the prisoners' canteen fund at the county jail to use "for political purposes."
WASHINGTON, July 13 -The friends of Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota will make it official tomorrow. He's off and running for the 1960 Democratic Presidential nomination.
NEW DELHI, India, July 13 -- The Tibetan refugees who have trekked into relief centers in the Indian lowlands are being slowly dispersed back northward into the Himalayas.

It was with sympathy and understanding that I read your correspondent Paul Hofmann's dispatch from Rome to the effect that Pope John likened the plight of Roman Catholics in Communist countries to "the martyrdom of the Apostle Peter."
GENEVA, July 13 (Reuters) -- Following are the texts of addresses at the foreign ministers' conference today by Secretary of State Christian A. Herter and Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Foreign Minister:
LONDON, July 13 -- The Rev. Dr. Bernard J. Bamberger of New York urged tonight that Jews throughout the world acquire the missionary zeal of their ancestors.

It is unfortunate that Frol R. Kozlov was permitted, in The Times of July 9, to accuse me of untruthfulness in reporting our conversation about the situation in Eastern Europe, with no opportunity being given to me in The Times to reply to this charge.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- Illinois supporters of a bill to permit Chicago to divert more water from Lake Michigan insisted today that no damage to other Great Lake states and Canada would result.

PAMPLONA, Spain, July 13 -The first seven-day fiesta of San Fermin dragged to a close today. More than 100 impromptu bands had marched through streets clashing cymbals. Countless rockets and bombs had been fired -- sometimes to herald bulls loose in streets, more often as part of long fireworks displays that set the sky ablaze every night.

The Knights Templars, the military and religious order founded at Jerusalem in 1118, is the subject of a history by Edith Simon. The title of the book -"The Piebald Standard" -- refers to the varied colors in the banner under which the order rode to protect pilgrims as well as the Holy Sepulcher.
OMAHA, July 13 (AP) -- Two more pacifists were sent to jail today as the outgrowth of demonstrations against missile base construction.
WHEN Verdi's Requiem ended last night at the Lewisohn Stadium, the audience of 7,000 persons burst into cheers.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Bartley C. Crum, New York lawyer, implicated James R. Hoffa and his attorney, Edward Bennett Williams, today in attempts to pack the courtappointed Board of Monitors of the Teamsters Union.
TEGUCIGALPA, June 13 (AP) -- The fighting in the capital reached its height when loyal army troops counter-attacked against rebels holed up in several strategic buildings yesterday.
A noisy crowd of about 500 persons collected outside a Harlem police station last night to protest the arrest of a postal worker who had tussled with a policeman making another arrest.
The Railway Express Agency today will start a new concept in the through-container movement of small shipments.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 13 -- Surrounded by 10,000 supporters at Enniskillen, County Fermanagh, Viscount Brookeborough repeated today Northern Ireland's familiar "no surrender" answer to Irish nationalism.

The Allied Chemical Corporation in the three months ended June 30 had the highest sales and earnings for any quarter in its history. Earnings and sales for the first six months also set a record for any half year, according to the results announced yesterday.
LONDON, July 13 -- An enterprising, daredevil British Army officer traveled by motorcycle, dinghy, helicopter and jet aircraft from central London to central Paris in 57 minutes 48 seconds today.

As a working mother I have become aware of how unfair the income tax laws are to this group. We have traveling expenses, restaurant lunches and extra wardrobe expenses which going to business necessitates. There are also additional expenditures at home, incurred because we work, yet we are not permitted any deduction from our income tax, as we are not the "head" of the family.
GENEVA, July 13 -- Modern diplomacy, Geneva style, is beginning to resemble the old parlor game of "Twenty Questions."
A letter published July 8 from M. L. Awerman, "Taxi Service in Philadelphia," prompts this taxi driver to reply -- though I have never written before to any editor or public official.
CHICAGO, July 13 (AP) -- The butcher hog market remained under strong pressure today with prices sagging another 25 to 50 cents a hundred pounds.

Those who manage the city's schools, both public and private, have a great deal to answer for, and correct, as a result of the Fire Department's spring school inspection report. Commissioner Cavanagh has called the findings "astonishing." They are also shocking and the conditions they reveal are inexcusable.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, July 13 -- Rifle, machine-gun and mortar fire kept the Honduran capital in terror today for the second day.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The Council of the Organization of American States voted unanimously today to call together the foreign ministers of the twenty-one American republics. The meeting will deal with unrest in the Caribbean and the problems of representative democracy and human rights throughout Latin America.
A landing gear on a KC-135 jet tanker, the military version of the Boeing 707 airliner. was broken while being jacked up last fall, it was learned yesterday.

Title I is a section of the Housing Act of 1949 designed to bring private capital into slum clearance. It permits cities to acquire substandard areas and resell them at a markdown to private developers. The Federal Government pays two-thirds of the difference between the original cost and the resale price; the city pays the other third.

Despite the growing popularity of blends of man-made fibers and wool, pure wool and worsted fabrics have shown a marked gain in recent months. The revival of interest in wool fabrics has brought about a 40 per cent increase in apparel wool consumption in the first five months of this year compared with the 1958 level.

MIAMI BEACH, July 13 -The readmission of the International Longshoremen's Association into the merged labor movement would help that movement as much as it would the union, the orphaned east and Gulf coast docker organization was told today.

For some months now reports have been circulating to the effect that Charles E. Bohlen would be recalled from his Manila embassy to become special adviser on Russian affairs to the Secretary of State. The chances are that no American knows more about Russian affairs than Mr. Bohlen, who has been studying them for close to thirty years.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., July 13. The United States Coast Guard cutter Yakutat, the escort ship for the Marblehead-Halifax ocean race, reported tonight that a group of four yachts -- believed to be the leaders -- were within a five mile area approximately thirty-two miles southwest of Brazil Rock

WASHINGTON, July 13 (UPI) -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter has assured protesting Senate Republican leaders that he will make no decision on whether to use Charles E. Bohlen as a special adviser on the Soviet, Union until after the current Geneva conference, it was learned today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 13 -The shutdown process of banking furnaces was started early today at the Fairless works of the United States Steel Corporation and at the Bethlehem plant of the Bethlehem Steel Company.
DETROIT, July 13 (AP) -The nation's auto makers returned to normal production schedules last week after a drop because of the Fourth of July holiday in the preceding week.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., July 13 -- A top leader in the nation's housewares field said today that the industry would take steps over the next five to ten years to obtain a larger share of the consumer dollar.
Your editorial of July 7 "Our 'Elected' Judges" quite correctly states that the present method of selecting judges for the various city benches leaves much to be desired.

One of the largest offerings of Federal Home Loan Bank securities on record will be marketed today. The Federal Home Loan Bank Board is offering the public $310,000,000 of 4 7/8 per cent non-callable consolidated notes dated July 23 and due Feb. 15, 1960. The notes are priced at 100.

IT was Gertrude Stein who explained Picasso to the Americans," Father R. L. Bruckberger tells us in his new book, "Image of America." Now, I suppose, all we lack is to have Picasso explain Gertrude Stein.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -The Senate Internal Security subcommittee heard secret testimony today by Maj. Pedro Luis Diaz Lanz, former chief of the Cuban Air Force in Premier Fidel Castro's regime. One member described the testimony as "shocking."
WASHINGTON, July 13 -The State Department asked Congress today to permit it to deny passports to "really dangerous participants in the international Communist conspiracy."

FRESH plums will be very much in evidence on the fruit stands this month and next. The fruit is, of course, delicious to eat for breakfast as for a simple dessert. Plums also may be presented with other fruits in a salad or fruit cup.

Recently this corner touched in passing upon the hard lot of the inventor, a potential benefactor to society who almost always has to struggle against ignorance and conservatism before he is permitted to share with his fellow men the fruits of his genius.
Cotton futures on the New York market moved 10 points (50 cents a bale) higher to 1 point (5 cents) lower yesterday. The near months showed the greatest strength.
BOSTON, July 13 -- Perhaps not since Bunker Hill has this staid metropolis had occasion to celebrate so smashing a victory as unfolded itself today.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., July 13 -An educator proposed here today that Federal taxpayers be allowed to deduct a certain amount from their tax bills and donate the money directly to private and public colleges and universities.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 12 -Teen-agers here have been firing .45-caliber pistols and swooping over Jones Beach in planes. Diligence, not delinquency, dictates their ventures.

New York City has awarded $65,000,000 in tax anticipation notes to nineteen banks and trust companies participating in the city's short term financing group. The awards consisted of $40,000,000 payable October 29, and $25,000,000 payable November 2. The notes bear interest at the rate of 2 1/2 per cent a year.
Janet Gaynor, for many years one of Hollywood's top-drawer performers, will make her debut on the Broadway stage this season.

The New York Herald Tribune announced yesterday that Robert M. White 2d had been named president and editor. Mr. White, who will assume his duties Aug. 3, is the editor and publisher of The Mexico (Mo.) Ledger.

PETROS, Tenn., July 13 (UPI) -- Ninety-five convicts holding three prison employes hostage in a coal mine shaft near Brushy Mountain State Prison tonight defied orders to surrender. Officials gave little hope of rescuing the hostages before daylight.
The Lehman Corporation reported yesterday record high net assets as of June 30.
GENEVA, July 13 -- The three-power conference on a ban on nuclear weapon tests bowed to the Big Four foreign ministers today.
Federal Judge Edmund L. Palmieri found three men and a woman guilty yesterday of robbing the First National Bank in Yonkers of $49,093 on April 27. They will be sentenced on Friday.

SOUTH AMBOY, N. J., July 13 -- First things come first with William Kurtz, and so for the next two weeks he won't let his being Acting Governor of New Jersey interfere with his duties as Acting Superintendent of Schools here.
SPRING LAKE, N. J., July 13 -- Senator John F. Kennedy called upon Congress tonight to override President Eisenhower's veto of the national housing bill.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 13 -- John Buckley of Glen Cove, an 18-year-old Manhattan College sophomore, led the qualifiers in the Long Island junior golf championship today.

Another European economic bloc, in addition to the six-nation European Economic Community with its 170,000,000 people, has become a virtual certainty following endorsement by a conference of four Scandinavian countries of the British-sponsored project for a "little free trade area." This would comprise seven "outer" nations with a combined population of 85,000,000.
TRENTON, July 13 -- Approval of a measure requiring the humane slaughter of livestock in New Jersey could be the first step in depriving Jews of their religious freedom, a rabbi declared here today.

LOS ANGELES, July 13 -- The United States Conference of Mayors reverberated today with bipartisan criticism of the national Administration for its asserted stinginess in Federal aid to cities, particularly in respect to housing and urban renewal.
Millions of workers have a far greater stake in the stock market than they may realize. In fact, their very retirement income depends in no small part on the unpredictable course of that market.
The Columbia Broadcasting System plans to bring back "Woman!"

Ralph Branca, Bobby Thomson's favorite baseball "cousin" again is going into a business where strikes will be to his credit but where late-inning homers never will be part of the scheme of things. The former Brooklyn Dodger pitcher plans to open a bowling establishment in late August.

RYE, N. Y., July 13 -- Mrs. Robert Stern, the captain of the Beach Point Yacht Club crew of Mamaroneck, took a 6 1/4-point lead for the women's sailing championship of Long Island Sound as the first three races in the Syce Cup series were held off the American Yacht Club today.

FREQUENTLY, Austin Joseph Tobin stands quietly looking out of one of the windows in his softly lighted, pine-paneled office. He is watching some freighter or ocean liner moving slowly up the Hudson River.

HONG KONG, July 13 -A pro-Nationalist Chinese-language newspaper here reported over the week-end that Communist China's communes in Swatow had undergone a general reorganization since June 1. Swatow is in the northeast corner of Kwangtung Province.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Ramon Marerro-Artisti, press coordinator of the Dominican Republic, said here today that his Government kept constant vigilence to eliminate any "human tendency toward administrative and political corruption."
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare testified today against financing health insurance for the aged through the Social Security system.

THE last event in the Southern New England Championships played at Norwich, Conn., last week-end, the team-of-four contest, went to the Boston team of Lawrence Weiss, Stephen White. Charles Coon and William Levin.
ROME, July 13 -- Italian leaders today urged private capital to help develop the backward South.

A break in the Berlin deadlock is near, in the opinion of former Gov. W. Averell Harriman, probably through the formation of a joint committee of the East and West German Governments to study their problems.
DESPITE the fact that summer stocks are dwindling and fall merchandise is just beginning to trickle into the stores, the canny shopper can still find clothes to take her in almost any direction.
Greek Star -- $81.80.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission has approved an examiner's decision allowing Sinclair Oil and Gas Company, Tulsa, Okla., a subsidiary of Sinclair Oil Corporation, a natural gas rate increase of about $560,000 a year.

GENEVA, July 13 -- The Soviet Union snarled the opening session of the second phase of the Big Four foreign ministers' conference today in a procedural wrangle that the Western powers had thought was well out of the way.

MILWAUKEE, July 14 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves defeated the National League-leading San Francisco Giants, 3 -- 0, tonight on a two-run homer by Eddie Mathews and six-hit pitching by Warren Spahn. The victory pulled Milwaukee to within a half-game of first place.
THE Russian Festival of Music and Dance last night opened the final week of its engagement at Madison Square Garden with an almost entirely different program from that of the preceding week.

With a steel strike looking more and more likely as the day progressed, stocks yesterday had their sharpest decline since June 8. Steels and heavy chemicals led the movement downward and losses outnumbered gains in practically every major group. Only the aluminum list held up.

In a season when all of America's dress designers have outdone themselves in presenting beautiful fall collections, New York's Pauline Trigere and California's James Galanos have done the most brilliant jobs of all. For their efforts, each will receive the ultimate honor an American designer can get from a jury of fashion critics. This is the Hall of Fame award given only to those who have twice won the Coty Award.
CHICAGO, July 13 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture's July crop report hit the grain futures market on the Board of Trade with more than the usual wallop today.
LENOX, Mass, July 13 -- The twentieth century got its licks in at Tanglewood, although it usually turns up at less publicized events.
LONDON, July 13 -- The stock market turned dull today and losses predominated in most sections.
First-half earnings of the General Electric Company were 13 per cent above the 1958 level on a sales gain of 4 per cent.

CHICAGO, July 13 -- The National Safety Council bestowed its Public Safety Activities award on seventeen United States and Canadian railroads for their "outstanding public safety programs for the general public and their employes."
PITTSBURGH, July 13 -Shutdown operations continued at the steel mills today on the eve of the strike deadline despite the resumption of negotiations in New York.
Bondholders reported to be blocking a reorganization plan for the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company aroused the ire of Federal Judge Archie O. Dawson yesterday.

The twenty-block West Side Urban Renewal project, which the City Planning Commission is expected to approve tomorrow, was criticized yesterday as being potentially "one of the hugest real estate grabs the city has ever known."
With owners of the city's prestige office buildings trying to achieve "balanced" tenancies, users of small space, once shunned by office builders, are being welcomed.

CHICAGO, July 13 (AP) -Bernard (Tut) Bartzen, the defending champion, advanced to the second round of the national clay court tennis championships today without lifting a racquet Bartzen, a 31-year-old competitor from Dallas, won from Nick Schraf of San Jose, Calif., by default.

The Soviet press has given its readers a bright picture of Mr. Kozlov's visit to the United States. Moscow thus represented the trip as having been more successful than it appeared to United States correspondents who accompanied the Soviet First Deputy Premier.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- The Miami Indian tribe of Oklahoma won a court ruling today that it should be paid more than 75 cents an acre for 4,291,500 acres in central Indiana.

TRIVANDRUM, India, July 13 (Reuters) -- Three Praja (People's) Socialist Party members of the Kerala State Assembly were arrested here today for picketing government offices and private schools. The campaign against the Communist demonstrators were report-its second month today.

The Vic Tanny Gymnasium chain and Guild Films Company, Inc., have completed merger negotiations, subject to agreement between counsel for the respective parties, arrangements with Guild creditors and Guild shareholder approval.

An automobile convoy of New Yorkers will leave here on July 31 for a three-day tour of historic Columbia County, N. Y. The event is being planned by the month-old Women's Architectural Auxiliary of the ninety-one-year-old New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects.

MINERVA, N. Y., July 13 -- There are a couple of people at the Northwoods Club here who go around identifying such little birds as the yellow-throated chat and such flowers as the snake-mouth bog orchid.

MOSCOW, July 13 (UPI) -- Frol R. Kozlov, a Soviet First Deputy Premier, returned from his United States tour tonight and expressed gratitude to President Eisenhower and Vice President Richard M. Nixon for the opportunity to become acquainted with your great country."

Investment bankers led by Newhard, Cook Co., will offer to the public today $6,000,000 of 5 per cent convertible debentures of Mallinckrodt Chemical Works, St. Louis, due in 1974. The debentures are priced at 100.
FARMINGDALE, L. I., July 13 -- A garden of snap beans, turnips and carrots growing in pressurized glass jars here may some day be growing on the moon.

There can be little doubt that President Eisenhower reflected widespread public opinion when he intervened again yesterday in the steel labor negotiations and secured at least their temporary resumption after their collapse Sunday night.
LONDON, July 13 -- Britain rejected today a Soviet proposal for the prohibition of nuclear and rocket weapons from the Balkan-Adriatic area.
SINGAPORE, July 13 -- The governments of Singapore and the Federation of Malaya announced tonight that restrictions on the direct import of dollar goods would end on Aug. 1.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said yesterday that a grand jury's findings on rigging of television quiz shows were of "utmost" interest to the public and would, if disclosed, lead to corrective legislation.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -(UPI) --President Eisenhower's proposal for participation in a billion-dollar InterAmerican Development Bank won approval today from the House Banking Committee.

LONDON, July 14 -- Industrials declined all along the line today on the stock exchange as yesterday's shakeout continued. Again, the declines were generally not more than a shilling (14 cents), although some of the higher priced issues lost much more.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI) -- The House approved compromise legislation today that ultimately would give the Federal Reserve System's 6,331 banks a new opportunity to increase their earnings.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -James R. Hoffa testified today that not he but his accuser, Bartley C. Crum, had promoted a plan to replace Godfrey P. Schmidt on the Teamster's Board of Monitors.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Scientists raised the possibility today that man might be forced to make a radical revision in his age-old concept of space as he probes deeper and deeper into the heart of the atom.
LOS ANGELES, July 14 -Pleas for more Federal assistance to cities in coping with mounting metropolitan problems dominated the annual assemblage of the nation's principal mayors for a second day.

The Bostwick brothers of Long Island, George H. (Pete) Jr. and Jimmy, are versatile athletes who have turned to golf. Long before those young men were swinging clubs, their father, Pete Sr., was an international polo player and the nation's top steeplechase rider.

National Theatres, Inc., of Los Angeles is planning to reopen an exchange offer to shareholders and warrant holders of National Telefilm Associates, Inc. under which N. T. A. became a subsidiary of National Theatres.

Capital Airlines was accused yesterday before the State Commission Against Discrimination of not hiring a Queens woman as a flight hostess because she was a Negro. She said the airline had never flatly refused her but was "evasive."

WASHINGTON, July 14 -The United States is exchanging copies of its current patents for copies of those issued by the Soviet Union. Prints of about 2,000 Soviet patents granted this year have been received so far by the United States Patent Office.

Barzel Associates, Inc., David I-Ierman, president, sold the sixstory apartment house for thirty families at 660 Riverside Drive, northeast corner of 145d Street. The r. j. Phillips-Wood, Dolson Company was the broker. The house is on a plot 100 by 65 feet and is assessed at $125,000. The buyer was the Nedal Realty Corporation, Burton S. Laden, president.
Futures price moves on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday ranged from a gain of l point in old July to declines of 3 to 14 points in other positions. (A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.)

Mayor Wagner has taken a step toward ridding the city of a major housing evil -- the occupancy by entire families, including children, of single rooms in rooming houses. City Administrator Preusse and Corporation Counsel Tenney have been directed by the Mayor to prepare legislation for new procedures designed to wipe out this slum-breeding practice.

CHICAGO, July 14 -- Robert B. Crane, a director of Crane Company and a great-grandson of the founder of the Chicago plumbing manufacturer, was dismissed today as assistant to the vice president in charge of sales.

The governors of the West Side Tennis Club announced yesterday that they had accepted the resignation of the club's president and would give "courteous and prompt attention" to a membership bid in behalf of Dr. Ralph J. Bunche or his son.
WHITE PLAINS, July 14 -The 20-year-old son of a New York investment banker who is accused of running down two bicyclists was committed today for psychiatric tests.
MAX MEADOWS, Va., July 14 (UPI) -- A tank truck loading propane gas caught fire in a storage yard today, threatening to erupt into a blaze engulfing this small southwest Virginia town.
MOSCOW, July 14 -- The Central Statistical Board reported today that steel production during the first six months of 1959 rose to 29,300,000 tons from 27,000,000 in the same period last year.

YONKERS, July 14 -- Flashing a burst of speed in the final Sixteenth, Duration, driven by George Phalen, scored a nose victory over Chuck Counsel in the pacing feature at Yonkers Raceway tonight. A crowd of 18,428 was on hand.
RICHMOND, Va., July 14 -Virginia's segregation moderates won most key races in the state's Democratic primary today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 14 -The Rev. Dr. J. S. Ladd Thomas, prominent Methodist churchman and dean emeritus of the Temple University School of Theology, died today in Roxborough Memorial Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived in the Roxborough section here.
PARIS, July 14 -- The average Parisian thoroughly enjoyed the luxurious Bastille Day party put on for him today without inquiring too closely into its motives.
LONDON, July 14 (AP) -The world premiere of a Noel Coward ballet was greeted tonight with eight curtain calls. The work was titled "London Morning."

At the end of last month there were 1,501 stock issues aggregating 5,463,336,956 shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange. These had a combined market value of $298,785,388,731. The average market price was $54.69 a share. The exchange has broken the list down into industry groups, with the latest overall market value and average share price for each.
LONDON, July 14 -- A group of British aviation experts proposed drastic reductions in international civil air transport fares today.

HALIFAX, N. S., July 14--Peter Richmond's new fifty-six-foot yawl Magic Carpet, from Riverside Conn., sailed into Halifax Harbor this afternoon as the fifth finisher in the 360-mile Marblehead - to - Halifax ocean race.

In June of 1939, with home visits to six children, the Handicapped Children's Home Service began making its contribution to physically handicapped boys and girls in the metropolitan area. This year, with a record of more than 25,000 hours of home visiting, and the number of referring agencies grown from one to fifteen, the service is celebrating its twentieth anniversary.

Sales of the nation's leading chain and mail-order companies in the first half of 1959 showed their best year-toyear gain since 1951. The rise was 10. 4 per cent. A survey made yesterday by The New York Times indicated a rise of 13.5 per cent for June from the 1958 level. This compared with a gain of 9.1 per cent in May.

DURING May, while The New York Times was publishing in its Sunday bridge department a series of articles on the most popular bidding conventions of the day, the American Contract Bridge League made a survey of the conventions used by its members in the principal tournaments.

There will apparently be no unanimous approval of the latest reorganization plan for the Railway Express Agency, Inc., when the 178 carriers that use the Agency's service meet in Chicago today to vote on the proposal.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -What the Democratic party needs to win the White House next year, according to Senator Hubert Horatio Humphrey, is "a walking, talking liberal" as its candidate. "Who else but Hubert?"
PITTSBURGH, Wednesday, July 15 -- The long-threatened steel strike became a grim reality here early today.
PETROS, Tenn., July 14 (AP) -- Ninety-four convicts gave up their thirty-two-hour rebellion this afternoon and came out of the coal mine of the Brushy Mountain State Prison.
Gamal Abdel Nasser sees himself as a nationalist but not a fanatic, and views his "positive neutrality" policy as essential to Arab independence.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 14 -- The selection of Freeport, Texas, as the site for the nation's first plant to convert sea water to fresh water was announced today by Fred A. Seaton, Secretary of the Interior. The Freeport plant will be designed to produce 1,000,000 gallons of fresh water daily.

Amos Parrish Co., a concern serving retail organizations as a consultant on advertising, merchandising and marketing, is merging with Fred Gaertner Jr. Associates, a similar firm. The merger, effective Aug. l will produce probably the largest organization of its kind.

Paperboard production fell last week to 180,359 tons from 275,478 in the preceding week, the National Paperboard Association has reported. The sharp drop in output, the association said, reflects the effects of the extended Fourth of July holiday week-end, which curtailed production at the beginning of the week.
LIGHT foods are usually the order of a hot summer's day and this may apply even to accompaniments to that long, cooling drink.
RANGOON, Burma, July 14 (AP) -- The police arrested a young Chinese medical student today for the alleged knifing of Liu Ping-yi, an official at the Communist Chinese Embassy.
WARSAW, July 14 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev flew into Warsaw today, and neither the cheers nor the silences were deafening.

The Jersey Central Power and Light Company sold $8,000,000 of thirty-year first mortgage bonds yesterday to investment bankers headed by Halsey Stuart Co., Inc. The price was 101.579 for obligations bearing a 5 1/4 per cent interest coupon.
HAVANA, July 14 -- No new rebel invasions of the Dominican Republic from Cuba are likely, informed sources said today. They also discounted any plans for invasions through Haiti.
United States industries consider themselves relatively well protected against a drawn-out strike in steel, key material for the nation's booming industrial economy.

GENEVA, July 14 -- The Western powers agreed today that the Soviet Union's latest assurances about their future rights in Berlin were unsatisfactory. They wanted the Soviet Union to be more specific and to put the guarantees of their rights in writing.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The nation's active money supply declined in June, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The drop was so small that there was essentially no change from the May level.
The State Supreme Court was asked for an injunction by taxi drivers, riders and company officials yesterday to stop the city from collecting its new 10-cent tax on taxi fares.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI) -- Democratic and Republican leaders of the House Judiciary Committee have set Wednesday or Thursday of next week as the date for completing action on a broad civil rights bill.

The annual luncheon of the Young Women's Christian Association of the City of New York will be given on Oct. 21 at the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Albert Francke Jr. is association president and Mrs. Edward Ewen Anderson is luncheon chairman.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -The Civil Aeronautics Board ordered a public hearing today into the turmoil surrounding the landing of a crippled jet airliner at New York International Airport early Sunday.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -The former head of the Cuban Air Force testified today that Premier Fidel Castro was the chief Communist in Cuba and a member of the international Communist conspiracy. The witness appeared at a Senate hearing that was interrupted by a bomb scare.
General Electric Company extended yesterday sizable price cuts to a line of turbines designed specifically for the petroleum and chemical industries.
Parents concerned about their teen-agers' seemingly insatiable desire to spend are advised to relax. The youngsters are suffering from "planned obsolescence," according to a marketing expert.

Young patients at Bellevue Hospital will receive many additional pleasures and comforts as a result of the eleventh annual dinner dance to be given at the Plaza on Oct. 8. The fete will benefit the Recreation Service for Children of Bellevue.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI) -- Members of a House Foreign Affairs subcommittee complained today that some American diplomatic employes overseas were housed in "ghetto-type compounds" that insulated them from the ordinary people of the nations involved.

PHILADELPHIA July 14 -The Soviet Union's track and field athletes had their first full-scale workout today at Franklin Field. Surprisingly, it was in company with their United States opponents in this week-end's concurrent but separately scored matches between the men's and women's teams of the two nations.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., July 14 -- A faculty that no university could buy began giving its sailing skills away today in an unusual yachting enterprise. It was the first practical application of the Sailboat Training Facility, Inc., opened to qualified persons interested in learning more about the arts of the racing sailor.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- President Eisenhower will offer a balanced budget for his final year in office, Senator Thruston B. Morton, Republican of Kentucky, predicted today.
MONROVIA, Liberia, July 14 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana arrived here today for a meeting of the heads of government of Ghana, Guinea and Liberia.

Half of the outstanding common stock of First Charter Financial Corporation, Beverly Hills, Calif., savings and loan association holding company, is being offered to the public today by an investment group headed by Eastman Dillon, Union Securities Co. and William R. Staats Co.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 14 -- Asian and African states asked the United Nations General Assembly today for another full - scale debate on the continuing conflict in Algeria.
SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 14 -- Taxpayers here tonight rejected a proposed school budget of $1,058,500 by a vote of 261 to 188.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- A spokesman for the United States Chamber of Commerce testified today that the whole Social Security program would be jeopardized if it were broadened to provide hospital, nursing home and surgical services for the aged.
The Anaconda Company cut prices of copper 1 1/2 cents to 30 cents a pound yesterday to meet similar reductions posted on Monday by the Kennecott Copper Corporation and the Phelps Dodge Corporation.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Chicago's long fight to draw more water from Lake Michigan is being torpedoed with "false and exaggerated charges," Senator Paul H. Douglas said today.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 14 (AP) -- A fight against any school integration in Little Rock took shape today. The Capital Citizens Council said it would do everything in its power to block racial mixing in the public schools.
FRANKFORT, Ky., July 14 (AP) -- Gov. A. B. (Happy) Chandler took a full wind-up today and delivered a high, hard pitch at big league baseball and some of its leading figures.
The Police Department was asked yesterday to find the disposessed owner of a tenement from which eight families were evicted over the week-end.

The United Steelworkers of America, with 500,000 members in basic steel mills, iron ore mines. Great Lakes ore carriers and other operations affected by the stoppage. The union has another 500,000 members in aluminum, can manufacturing and steel fabricating plants whose wages are usually affected by the basic settlement.

An American fashion presentation scheduled to be shown at the United States exposition in Moscow this month has been attacked by a group of fashion editors as unrepresentative of this country's way of life. annual Press Week of the New York Dress Institute's Couture Group.

The Citizens Utilities Company announced yesterday the acquisition of a water company in Illinois and several electric facilities in Vermont. Purchase prices were not disclosed; Involved in the latest acquisitions were the Arrowhead Water Company near Wheaton, Ill.; transmission lines and substation facilities in the Sheldon Springs-Highgate Falls area of Vermont and the distribution system formerly operated by Missisquoi paper division of Standard Packaging Corporation near Sheldon, Vt.
The Metropolitan Opera wants to make more money from its programs. Because of this, it has worked out an arrangement to have them printed by The Saturday Review.
DETROIT, July 14 (UPI) -- A package of radioactive isotopes fell off a loading truck and was crushed by the wheels of another truck at the Detroit Metropolitan Airport today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 14 -- Managers are always confronted by problems. The first one to face Bill Rigney today came when he phoned room service early this afternoon. The Giants had escaped from twin defeats in-Milwauke under cover of darkness and had flown here at 4 A. M., tired and sleepy but still leading the National League.
FRENCH LICK, Ind., July 14 -- A nation-wide program to dramatize the social contributions of state-supported universities and to defend them from attack was outlined here today.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture has expressed opposition to the proposal. It estimated the cost of the program at $37,500,000 a year.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Secretary Arthur S. Flemming urged today that proponents of aid for school construction agree on President Eisenhower's plan to provide joint Federal-state payment of bond indebtedness over a twentyyear period.
GENEVA, July 14 -- The United Nations is playing a curiously limited role in the foreign ministers' conference here.
Sports car racing in the East shifts this week-end to the twomile course at Thompson, Conn., for a New York regional meet under the direction of John Meyer of Locust Valley, L. I.
