NEW DELHI, India, July 14 -- India's young men and women are hammering at the doors of the country's thirty-eight universities this year in greatly increased numbers. Tens of thousands are finding they cannot get in.
A Federal mediator continued to meet with airline and union representatives yesterday to head off a strike at midnight tonight by stewards, stewardesses and pursers on Pan American World Airways.
A NEW day is dawning here for the harassed furnishings shopper.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -The number of Americans holding jobs reached a record of 67,342,000 in June, the Department of Labor reported today.
Supreme Court Justice J. Irwin Shapiro has ruled that the state is not compelled by law to grant incorporation certificates to "hate" groups.

All world sugar positions fell to new lows for the life of the contracts yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The market continued to be influenced by sizable supplies in the market and by fears that Cuba may release reserves normally held off the market at this time.

Japanese Premier Nobusuke Kishi has embarked upon a month-long tour of the some of the freeworld capitals to explore attitudes toward the "cold war." He will not visit the United States "officially." But he is spending some time in Great Britain to discuss the British policy in respect to Red China.
MIAMI BEACH, July 14 -Capt. William V. Bradley acted today to clear the last major obstacle to his re-election as president of the International Longshoremen's Association.
More than 300 residents of a West Side area slated for urban renewal protested last night that the plan does not provide for the needs "of even a small fraction of the people" living there.

ARCADIA, Calif., July 14 -- (UPI) -- A bus carrying boys home from a camping trip careened out of control at a busy intersection today, killing a small girl in one car and ramming two other autos before it overturned. The bus carried ninety-nine persons, including eight Catholic Youth Organization counselors, according to the California highway patrol. At least twenty-nine children were treated at a hospital.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Wednesday, July 15 -- The air force issued yesterday what was interpreted as a "hands-off" warning to the new Minister of Defense, Lieut. Gen. Abdul Haris Nasution, who is also army Chief of Staff. The air force suggested that Indonesian armed forces be placed "directly" under President Sukarno.
VIENNA, July 14 -- Chancellor Julius Raab's coalition Cabinet was designated today.
A contract for the purchase of the vacant blockfront on East 233d Street, between Hill and Murdock Avenues, in the Baychester area of the Bronx, has been signed by Strategic Properties, Inc.

DANBURY, Conn., July 14 -The National Semiconductor Corporation, an electronics concern formed here recently by eight former employes of the Sperry-Rand Corporation of New Haven, today denied Sperry-Rand's charge that they had taken documents and secrets from their former employer.

Six members of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union were indicted yesterday on charges of conspiracy and extortion involving shakedowns totaling $110,000 from representatives of newspaper distributing companies.
Hulan E. Jack charged last night that the flare-up between two policemen and an angry crowd in Harlem Monday was an outgrowth of "rising race tension" in that area.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI) -- The Senate Labor Committee approved today a bill that would set up a Youth Conservation Corps patterned along the lines of the Civilian Conservation Corps of early New Deal days.

LONDON, July 14 -- Five American Surgeons who have just visited the Soviet Union told the International Congress of Plastic surgery today of major Soviet surgical advances, including transplantations of whole limbs of animals.
Whitey Ford provided the answer to a manager's prayer last night.

A huge, heat-absorbing shield is being readied for America's first space capsule to carry a man in orbit around the globe. The shield, made of beryllium, the lightweight metal, is the joint product of Brush Beryllium Company and Aluminum Company of America.
This year should see a record in sales volume for the nation's department stores, barring unforseen events, the Controllers' Congress of the National Retail Merchants Association said yesterday.
MANILA, July 14 (AP) -The United States has agreed to limit its military holdings in the Philippines to four major bases, informed sources said today.

Is there a relatively painless way by which the Treasury could sell more long-term bonds without paying higher interest rates? Are there devices by which the Federal Reserve System, without pumping up the nation's bank reserves and money supply to inflationary proportions, could help solve the Treasury's problem?

" Man of Reason, the Life of Thomas Paine," a new biography by Alfred Owen Aldridge, will be published by Lippincott on Aug. 12. The author recreates Paine's stormy life as "a paradoxical one of alternating acclaim and rejection by a fickle public in three countries."
The State Commission Against Discrimination declined yesterday to withdraw a finding that exempted the Arabian-American Oil Company from certain provisions of the Fair Employment Practices Act.

National Telefilm Associates, which in a few years has grown from a supplier of films to television to a major force in the entertainment world, is in the process of expanding its motionpicture activities. This was learned yesterday from Harold Goldman, president of N. T. A. International.

CHICAGO, July 14 (AP) -Sally Moore, 19, of Bakersfield, Calif., and Gwyneth Thomas, 18, Shaker Heights, Ohio, won first-round matches under a broiling sun today in the national clay court tennis tournament.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Representative William H. Meyer, Democrat of Vermont, denounced as "judicial dictatorship" today the jailing of his son by a Federal judge.
SHELTER ISLAND, L. I., July 14 -- Three hundred years ago a small band of persecuted New England Quakers took refuge on this island nestled between the forks that form the eastern end of Long Island:
The examples set forth in your July 6 editorial "Bona-Fide Home Rule" are but a few of the many local matters which the municipalities of our state should be empowered to handle at home.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Nearly unanimous creditor acceptance of a 1958 reorganization plan for the Florida East Coast Railway was announced today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, July 14 -- The army announced today that it had gained control of the city, where a revolt has been in progress since Sunday.
CHICAGO, July 14 (AP) -About one-third of the grain futures contracts on the Board of Trade closed at new high prices for the season today after another broad advance.
GENEVA, July 14 -- If the Big Four reach any kind of Berlin agreement here, the hardest job each side will have is selling this arrangement to its particular German client.

The New York City Housing Authority borrowed $38,351,000 on short-term notes yesterday to finance state-subsidized lowrent development projects. The average cost of the borrowing was 2.60928 per cent.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -An oil painting from among art that President Eisenhower admired at the Soviet exhibition in New York is hanging today in the White House.
Good buying was reported yesterday for fixed-income investments of all basic classifications.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People "cannot fight for racial integration in public schools and acquiesce in segregated suburbs," the vice chairman of association's board declared yesterday.
CHICAGO, July 14 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
PARIS, July 14 -- France paid homage to herself, her new regime and the French Community today in a dazzling celebration of the 170th anniversary of the storming of the Bastille.
A group of influential Democrats, espousing progress but eschewing revolt, came forward last night with plans for building the party "for the long pull beyond 1959 into 1960, 1961 and 1962."
Officers of New York Typographical Union 6 (Big Six) urged its members yesterday to approve a new contract proposal of ten New York newspapers in a referendum today.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI) -- The Senate Agriculture Committee today approved a bill designed to subsidize the American textile industry to enable it to compete in the world market with cheaper textiles from other countries.

TOKYO, Wednesday, July 15 (UPI) -- Crown Princess lVHchiko I 'is believed to be expecting a{ -baby, the Imperial Palace an-] ounced today. Takeshi Usami, ,director of the Imperial Household Agency, said an official 'announcement would be made! when the finding of three doc-: tors yesterday was ascertained. 'The Princess and Crom Prince kihito were married April 10.
PITTSBURGH, July 14 (UPI) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates hammered across five first-inning runs off Johnny Podres and rolled to a 9-1 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers at Forbes Field tonight.
MORRISVILLE, Pa., July 14 -- David J. McDonald told a cheering crowd of 2,000 steel workers tonight that "we're going to win" with the "finest labor agreement any union ever had."

A consecutive triple by Manuel Ycaza heartened the favorite players at damp Jamaica yesterday. The daring rider from Panama capped his performance by taking the feature event, the Bastille Purse, on the Cain Hoy Stable's Hoist Away.
Another bumper crop of ragweed rapidly ripening across the nation. It is a crop to which even urban New York City will contribute.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -(UPI) -- The Senate Agriculture Committee approved a bill today providing for a one-year extension of the law under which the United States sells farm surpluses overseas for foreign currency.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 14--Premier Abdul Karim Kassim promised tonight to restore political life in Iraq and hold elections within the next year.

The second installment of the Geneva conference of foreign ministers is off to an inauspicious start which does not enhance trust in Soviet intentions.
Prospects brightened yesterday for a settlement of the strike by A. P. warehouse workers, which has forced the food-store chain to close 400 retail outlets in the metropolitan area.
Qualified support was given yesterday by the National Industrial Traffic League to the steampship conference system of ocean freight rate-making.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI) A bill aimed at controlling harmful automobile exhaust fumes was approved today by a House subcommittee. It would require auto manufacturers to produce cars that create only a limited amount of air pollution.

NEW BERN, N. C., July 14 (AP) -- Children of Negro personnel at the Cherry Point Marine Corps Air Station who meet "certain conditions and requirements" will be admitted to two all-white Craven County schools this fall.

The Ford Motor Company's new series of Tuesday evening television shows will present a musical revue titled "The Fabulous Fifties" as its premiere on Oct. 6 from 9:30 to 11 P. M. over the National Broadcasting Company network.

THIS week a new book is out from the capital of apartheid, South Africa, where the official Government policy is separate and unequal. Reading Alan Paton's "Hope for South Africa,"* you discover that any discriminatory incidents anywhere in the world are magnified proportionately; indeed, many of the arguments for racial discrimination there are echoed in this country.
The writer of the following letter is Professor of Economics at Vassar College and co-author of "From the Wagner Act to Taft-Hartley: A Study of National Labor Policy and Labor Relations."
BAG limits and season choices were announced yesterday by the Interior Department in Washington for rails, gallinules, woodcock and doves.

QUINCY, Mass., July 14 -- The Navy's first nuclear-powered surface vessel, the heavy cruiser Long Beach, was christened and undramatically launched today at the Bethlehem Steel Company's shipyard here.
HAMBURG, Germany, July 14 -- The French Socialist party was criticized on its record on Algeria at the opening session today of the congress of the Socialist International.

Reflecting record net sales for the quarter and six months ended on June 30, earnings of the Continental Can Company showed substantial gains above the 1958 levels, according to the semi-annual report of Gen. Lucius D. Clay, chairman and chief executive officer.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI) -- The House Labor Committee removed from the Senate-approved labor reform bill today a section providing strong criminal penalties for union leaders who had violated democratic rights guaranteed to rank-and-file workers.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The general counsel's office of the Federal Communications Commission recommended today the revocation of the award of Boston's television Channel 5 to a Boston Herald-Traveler station. It cited "deliberate efforts to influence" the commission.

OMAHA, July 14 -- Raymond A. Weinstein of Brooklyn, defending the junior championship of the United States Chess Federation, defeated Bruce Evans of Toronto today in the first round at the Hotel Rome.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Arthur S. Flemming, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said today that major interstate waterways show very low levels of radiation from fall-out.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -Senator Hubert H. Humphrey became today the first formally launched candidate for President in 1960 and created a minor flap by being coy about it.

Robert Moses said yesterday that he would "await with interest" the efforts of associates on the Committee on Slum Clearance and of "eager beavers and Citizens Union smart alecks" to attract speculative private investment to future Title I projects.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Senate passed tonight its $40,000,000,000 appropriations bill to operate the Defense Department through the fiscal year that started July 1. The vote was 90 -- 0.

WASHINGTON, July 14--President Eisenhower recommended late this afternoon that steel industry management and labor representatives immediately call on Federal mediators for assistance in reaching a contract agreement.
Seagoing engineer officers have attained another item of job security normally a part of shoreside work.
SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 14 -- Plans for Southampton's annual Midsummer Night Ball, of which Mrs. Alfred Corning Clark is chairman and Mrs. Edgar Leonard, co-chairman, have been completed.
Three major roles in as many forthcoming Broadway stage attractions were filled yesterday.
WHITE PLAINS, July 14 -The New York Central's passenger stations in Westchester began to blossom today in new colors chosen by the commuters.
ANKARA, Turkey, July 14 -Turkey has rejected a Soviet proposal that a zone free of nuclear arms be established in the Adriatic-Balkan area, including Turkey, Greece and Italy.
Stocks opened with a loss yesterday but pushed vigorously ahead most of the day to close with a moderate gain.

A half-million steel workers struck at 12:01 A. M. today. The walkout cut off production of 85 per cent of the country's basic industrial metal and threatened to slow the upsurge of the economy from last year's crippling recession.

Title I is a section of the Housing Act of 1949 designed to bring private capital into slum clearance. It permits cities to acquire substandard areas and resell them at a markdown to private developers.

The Transit Authority submitted its 1960 capital budget to the city yesterday. For the calendar year, the agency asked $158,479,000 to be spent on new rolling stock and for continuing its subway modernization program.
ROME, July 14 -- Romans are divided over a projected Disneyland-type reconstruction of their most illustrious ancient monuments.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 14 -- India moved again today for the admission of Communist China to the United Nations.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 14 (UPI) -- More than 100 steelworkers, charging they were "locked out," picketed the Tennessee Coal and Iron Division of the United States Steel Corporation today, hours ahead of the national walkout.

The election of Guy Cooper as president and chief executive officer of Cooper-Jarrett, Inc., trucking concern, was announced yesterday. Mr. Cooper, formerly executive vice president, succeeds his brother, Robert E. Cooper Jr., who will continue as chairman of the board and chairman of the executive committee.
GENEVA, July 14 -- The three-power conference on a ban on tests of nuclear weapons debated today what to do with 900,000 words that make sense only to physicists.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 13 UPI) -- Gov. Michael DiSalle tonight vetoed the "fair trade" bill in the name of the free enterprise system and in the face of strong objections by a group of Ohio's smaller retail merchants.
The 1958 recession left several categories of employment virtually untouched in New York City, the Department of Commerce and Public Events reported yesterday.
ALBANY, N. Y., July 14 (AP) -- Directors of the State Bank of Albany and the National City Bank of Troy agreed today to merge.

THE Irish, and that means the Irish Irish, are throwing dornicks at the universal maxim that fishermen in general are the dullest and most unimaginative liars on earth. And there is no doubt that the Irish can lie with boldness and dash.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The White House is expected to announce soon the appointment of Vance Brand as manager of the Development Loan Fund. Mr. Brand is now a director of the Export-Import bank.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- President Eisenhower indicated today that Secretary of State Christian A. Herter had the authority to come to terms with the Soviet Union on holding a summit meeting.

A noisy construction job that brought a complaint from the Queens Borough President was quieted temporarily yesterday by the city Housing Authority. The authority ordered the offending pile drivers moved out of earshot of neighboring tenants until Sept. 1.

A small but hardy audience braved threatening weather at Lewisohn Stadium last night to hear Alfred Wallenstein conduct the Stadium Symphony Orchestra, with Harold Cone as soloist in the Cesar Franck "Symphonic Variations" for piano and orchestra.
Real Madrid, en route home after a successful South American junket, turned in a sparkling soccer performance before 13,500 fans at Ebbets Field last night.
A revised preliminary plan for the $100,000,000 twenty-block urban renewal project on the West Side was approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission.
PARIS, July 15 -- Dr. Joseph Raseta, prominent Madagascar nationalist, was taken back to his place of forced residence in Southern France today after having tried to return to his homeland.
LOS ANGELES, July 15 -- Mayors of the nation's principal cities rejected today as inadequate the Administration's new compromise housing bills.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, July 15 -- A total of 258 Malays, Chinese and Indians became contenstants today for 104 seats in the first Malayan parliamentary election next Sunday.
KATOWICE, Poland, July 15 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev, barnstorming through Poland's coal belt, told Roman Catholic miners today to look to their commissars and not to the priesthood for their future.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 15 -- A closing round of par 71 enabled Paul Kelly of Sleepy Hollow to win the Ike golf tournament with a 72-hole score of 289 today. The 28-year-old former Metropolitan amateur champion swept off with the big trophy by three strokes at the Tamarack Country Club.
A New Jersey certified public accountant and former egg wholesaler was indicted yesterday on charges of swindling a commercial factoring concern of $592,712.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Industrial production climbed to another record in June, the Federal Reserve Board estimated today.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 15 (AP) -- Mrs. Bruce McGhie of New York, the 1951-1952 champion, scored a 2-and-1 victory in the first round of match play in the New York State women's amatuer golf championship today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 15 -- Twelve nations asked today that the forthcoming session of the General Assembly consider afresh the racial segregation policies of the Union of South Africa.

HAVANA, July 15 -- Dr. Carlos Marquez Sterling, who long opposed former President Fulgencio Batista in Cuban politics and ran as Presidential candidate of the opposition Free People's Party in 1958, has sought political asylum in the Venezuelan Embassy.
LONDON, July 15 -- A first edition of "The Myrrour of the Worlde," printed by William Caxton in 1481, was sold at auction today to a New York dealer for u14,000 ($39,200).

Scratch the Dec. 17 premiere of "Mrs. 'Arris Goes to Paris," which had been scheduled for the Alvin with Thelma Ritter in the title role. Kermit Bloomgarden, who is co-sponsoring the musical with Ray Stark, confirmed the cancellation yesterday.

THE home, not the highway, is still the scene of the greatest number of accidents in the United States. This fact is reported in figures compiled by the Census Bureau for a study by the Public Health Service.
NEWARK, July 15 -- New Jersey filed a protest with the Interstate Commerce Commission today against the New York Central Railroad's plan to discontinue its West Shore Division.

There was a graduation day a few days ago at the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals' shelter in Glen Cove, L.I. Diplomas went to fourteen dogs. They had completed an obedience training course.
George V. Allen, director of the United States Information Agency, suggested in Washington yesterday that more changes be made in United States fashion show scheduled to open in Moscow on July 25.
What is said to be the world's costliest restaurant will open soon on the lobby floor of the Seagram Building at 375 Park Avenue.

One of the giants of American industry has just "administered" some of its prices downward. The General Electric Company has announced on successive days reductions in prices of its turbines, both large and small.

A syndicate managed jointly by the First Boston Corporation and A.E. Ames Co., Inc., is offering to the public today $50,000,000 of twenty-five-year 5 per cent debentures of Quebec Hydro-Electric Commission.
LONDON, July 15 -- Most industrials receded on the stock market again today, although modest new buying and some bear covering stemmed part of the losses.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The Senate Commerce Committee approved a bill today to exempt news broadcasts and other news programs from the requirement that political candidates be given equal time on radio and television stations.
An employment interviewer for the State Department of Labor was accused at a departmental hearing yesterday of misconduct in unlawfully engaging in discriminatory practices.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 15 -President Juscelino Kubitschek's Social Democratic party nominated Marshal Henrique Teixeira Lott, Minister of War, as its candidate for the Presidency tonight. The election will be held in October, 1960.

AT 21 years of age, childis things generally have been put aside. But the Toy Guidance Council, now observing it year of majority, is more end grossed in playthings than even before. There is nothing juvenile about its interest, however. To the council, play is serious business and a big one.
CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -- Moderate profit-taking turned the grain futures on the Board of Trade generally lower today for the first time this week. But the losses held mainly to fractions of a cent.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., July 15 (UPI) -- Scientists at the University of Notre Dame announced today development of a sterile, plastic room for experimenting with germ-free animals.
MONTCLAIR, N.J, July 15 -- Minority groups in Montclair are viewing the town's proposed urban-renewal program with misgivings.
TOBAY BEACH, L.I., July 15 -- About fifty public officials proved today that they were less affected by wet weather than Long Island's wild ducks.

The State Banking Department has asked savings banks not to announce expected increases in dividend rates for the October-December period until it has had an opportunity to determine whether the banks have the earning power to permit an increase.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- President Eisenhower said today that emergency conditions were not yet present to justify invoking the cooling off provisions of the Taft-Hartley Law to halt the steel strike.

HACKENSACK, N.J., July 15 -- A leaky roof in a New Jersey Motor Vehicle inspection station on Hackensack Avenue here forced the closing of one lane yesterday and today, forcing motorists to wait as long as four hours to get through the inspection line.

World sugar futures continued to fall to new lows for the life of the contract yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The spot price tumbled 5 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) to 2.65 cents a pound, the lowest level since before World War II.
BUFFALO, July 15 -- Striking steelworkers in the Buffalo area are resigned but determined in the walkout that has idled 30,000.
DETROIT, July 15 -- The Corvair, the compact car that General Motors Corporation plans to introduce in October, is already in production, Chevrolet Motor Division said today.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- A spokesman for the American Medical Association said today that financing hospital and surgical care for the aged through a Social Security payroll tax deduction "simply proposes a form of national compulsory health insurance."

The City Planning Commission denied yesterday the application of the Greyhound Corporation for approval of its plan reconstruct and expand its is terminal on Thirty-fourth Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues.
PIERMONT, N. Y., July 15 -Columbia University's research schooner Vema docked here this afternoon after a nine-month scientific cruise in Atlantic, Pacific and Caribbean waters.

Police reinforcements took up duty yesterday in four predominantly Negro areas here. Meanwhile, Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy bitterly assailed criticism of his men, and warned against potential race riots.

This is another record year for the city's summer high school program -- fourteen schools are serving 43,342 students. A year ago only twelve schools were conducting summer programs, and the enrollment in those programs 26-39,000.

NEWARK, July 15 -- The complaint of a man who thought he had had a traffic ticket "fixed" led to the arrest tonight of a man the police said headed a ring that contended it could fix tickets, but actually could not. Two policemen were implicated in the fraud.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI) -- The House Labor Committee tentatively approved today a watered-down five-point "bill of rights" for rank-and-file union members as a substitute for the tougher provisions of the Senate-approved labor reform bill.
SHREVEPORT, La., July 15 (AP) -- Three Federal judges in Louisiana will consider the constitutionality of the United States Civil Rights Commission on Aug. 7.

Trans Caribbean Airways, Inc., which owns the D.C. Transit System, Inc., had a net income in the first half this year in excess of $5,000,000 from both operations and non-recurring credits, according to O. Roy Chalk, president.
The repeal of legislation that outlaws the use of deferred rebates by steamship companies was urged yesterday as a means of strengthening the American merchant marine.

JOSEPH FRANCIS FINNEGAN, a jovial, gray-haired, gray-eyed 200-pounder with a salty vocabulary and a ready wit, is in the midst of a sea of trouble once again. But trouble is Mr. Finnegan's business. For him to be without it would be as unnatural as a summer sky without a bit of blue.

The Monsanto Chemical Company in the three months ended on June 30 turned in the biggest sales and earnings for any quarter. These records lifted the results for the first six months to new highs for any half year.
Ohio borrowed $31,000,000 yesterday on serial bonds to further the financing of a $1,000,000,000 state highway building program that has been in progress since 1954.
The opening of the new Hudson Celebration Theatre-in-the-Park, scheduled for last night but postponed because of rain, will take place tonight instead.
SYRACUSE, July 15 -- Syracuse University has received $176,000 under the will of J. Robert Rubin, New York corporation lawyer and a university trustee, who died last September.

James Felt, chairman of the City Planning Commission, testified yesterday that he had always had a "most favorable" impression of Benjamin Cymrot, suspended executive officer of the old Bureau of Real Estate.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- A Senate Judiciary subcommittee approved a "skeleton" civil rights bill today. It postponed indefinitely all other civil rights measures.

Executone, Inc., a maker of electronic communications systems, has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering a proposed public offering of 136,000 shares of common stock. Shearson, Hammill Co. will head the offering group.

MIAMI BEACH, July 15 -- James R. Hoffa called on the International Longshoremen's Association today to "cast aside questions of propaganda and personal feelings" and work together with him and Harry Bridges for the benefit of all American labor.
HAMBURG, Germany, July 15 -- Hugh Gaitskell, leader of the British Labor party, appealed today at the congress of the Socialist International for curbs in the production of nuclear weapons.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration selected today the concerns to build the world-wide tracking network for manned satellites in Project Mercury.
RICHMOND, Va., July 15 (AP) -- Gov. J. Lindsay Almond Jr. invited today the winners of yesterday Democratic primary elections to work with him to find a better answer to the school problem.
THE forty-seven men, women and children who will model fashions at the American National Exhibition in Moscow this month went through the stiffest competition of their lives before they were chosen.
The New York, Chicago and St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad announced yesterday the election of Myron B. Phipps as executive vice president, effective August 1.
DUBLIN, July 8 -- "If you can see the Aran Islands from Galway, thirty miles away, it's a sure sign of rain," they say. "If you can't see them, it's raining."

Pier 40, the new $18,700,000 passenger and cargo ship terminal on the North River at West Houston Street, which will be completed by the city for the Holland-America Line next spring, received its first vessel yesterday.

Austria, once known as "Felix Austria" because of a dynasty that married rather than conquered an empire, has neither dynasty nor empire today, but it is still "Happy Austria." This is because it has attained unprecedented prosperity and well-being under a marriage of convenience between its two principal parties, which have just agreed to continue their union in a new coalition government.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The House Labor Committee is buckling down at last to the job of redrafting the Senate's trades union bill. This provides in part for some of the reforms in the labor movement that testimony before the Senate McClellan committee has revealed to be essential if equality under the law and a true free-enterprise system are to prevail in the United States.

Drexelbrook, a garden apartment development in Drexel Hill. nine miles from downtoxm Philadelphia, has been purchased by a syndicate of investors headed by John E. liarqusee and William L. Kay 2d, both of Kay Co., Vestchester County realty interests, and Jeremiah J. l%ahoney.

Westinghouse Electric Corporation indicated yesterday that as far as it was concerned there would be no "white sale" in the field of steam turbine generators. This followed announcements on two successive days that General Electric Company, the largest maker of such heavy equipment, was cutting its prices on heavy units above 200,000 kilowatts and on small, specialized units from 500 to 4,000 horsepower.

The question of final authority in emergencies at airports here was still unresolved yesterday after a chilly conference between Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. and Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Port of New York Authority.
HALIFAX, N.S., July 15 -- Peter Richmond's new keel-centerboard yawl. Magic Carpet, was declared the winner today of the ninth biennial race from Marblehead, Mass., to Halifax.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 15 -- Wilson Lineburgh of The Pequot Yacht Club became the girls' sailing champion of Long Island Sound today by winning the final race of the Founders' Trophy series. She defeated Janet Lethen of the American Yacht Club.

YONKERS, July 15 -- Fifteen of the best 3-year-old pacers in the nation will go to the post tomorrow night at Yonkers Raceway in the William H. Cane Pace, the first leg of the pacing triple crown. This will be the fifth time the event has been staged.
TORONTO, July 15 -- Canada has developed an entirely new strain of grain, which holds promise of "astounding" production, it was announced today by J.Q. Duffy of Seagram Sons, distillers.

RIVER FOREST, Ill., July 15 (UPI) -- Larry Nagler of Hollywood, Calif., turned in the biggest upset of the national clay courts tennis championships today by eliminating second-seeded Barry MacKay in the sehond round of the men's singles. The scores were 6 -- 4, 6 -- 2.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- A newspaper man provoked a show of anger from President Eisenhower today with a question about the use of Executive privilege "to hide imprudence, mismanagement and fraud."

Sandy's Joy of the Merrick Stable retained her speed in the stretch to take the feature race at Jamaica yesterday. The 5-year-old daughter of Sun Again achieved a three-quarter length success over Charles Handelman's Betty Linn in the six-furlong test for fillies and mares.
LONDON, July 15 -- The organization that backs British motion-picture producers with public money came out today for "substantially" lower payment to movie stars, producers, directors and authors.

MEXICO CITY, July 15 -- Neale Fraser, Australia's top-ranking tennis player, is suffering from a slight attack of appendicitis and may not be able to take part in the Davis Cup match against Mexico starting here Saturday.
Cotton futures of the New York Cotton Exchange moved 3 points (15 cents a bale) above to 5 points (25 cents) below Tuesday's close yesterday. Prices held in a narrow range all day.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 15 -- The furor about Dr. Ralph Bunche and the West Side Tennis Club in New York has brought to light a much more unusual form of discrimination here. In this area made famous by the movie business, there are two country clubs that do not accept men or women who make their living as actors.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- In the United States Court of Claims the following proceedings were had today:
GENEVA, July 15 -- The Western powers failed today to persuade the Soviet Union to get on with negotiations for an interim settlement of the Berlin crisis.

Bond prices surged forward again yesterday on all fronts. The steel strike, with its prospect for a slackening of economic activity, gave impetus to the improved demand for fixedincome securities that has been under way over the past week.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 15 -- Minister of Information Maladi announced today that an "agreement" had been reached ending what the army called "tensions" between it and the air force.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI) -- House investigators asserted today that "incompetent or deliberately careless" defense contract negotiations had cost the Government millions of dollars in overcharges.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- President Eisenhower declared firmly today that his Secretary of State, Christian A. Herter, had given him only "completely negative" reports on the prospective selection of Charles E. Bohlen as Mr. Herter's top adviser on Soviet affairs.
An extremely large solar flare disrupted global radio ommunications yesterday afternoon.

SHELTER ISLAND, L.I., July 15 -- Officials of the Shelter Island-Greenport ferry service, "suddenly realizing that we had been operating since 1892 without a franchise," legalized their operation yesterday in Suffolk County Court.

For the 500,000 idle unionists the strike will not mean an immediate pocketbook pinch. Most have two weeks' pay due and many also will collect an extra two weeks in vacation pay. With weekly earnings averaging $125, this would mean a total of about $500.
CHICAGO, July 15 (UPI) -C. Douglas Dillon, Under Secretary of State, predicted today that American exports would rise $1,000,000,000 within the next twelve months.
Faculty members and trustees of the General Theological Seminary joined workmen yesterday in a ground-breaking ceremony on the Ninth Avenue premises between Twentieth and Twenty-first Streets.

GENEVA, July 15 -- State Department officials confirmed here tonight that Secretary of State Christian A. Herter had talked to Charles E. Bohlen, United States Ambassador to the Philippines, about returning to Washington as an adviser on Soviet affairs.

The United Steehvorkers of America, with 500,000 members in basic steel mills, iron ore mines, Great Lakes ore carriers and other operations affected by the stoppage. LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 15 -- The Little Rock School Board asked Gov. Orval E. Faubus today to present his plan -- if he has one -- for legally preserving segregation in the city's public high schools.
The State Supreme Court yesterday barred the Arabian-American Oil Company from asking job applicants in the state questions about their religion.
CLEVELAND, July 15 -- The strike has cut 18,500 Cleveland area workers off payrolls, but a survey today disclosed that only a few are idle.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower said today he had drawn up a plan streamlining the top echelon of Government to relieve the President and other high officials of certain administrative chores.
BIRMINGHAM, July 15 -- About 25,000 steelworkers here and at near-by Gadsden, feel about the same today as they did a month ago.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The Senate voted for the fifth time today to give home rule to the capital of the United States. The decision was made by a voice vote.

Arnold T. Milton has purchased a triangular plot of land containing 15,000 square feet bounded by North Conduit Avenue, Farmers Boulevard and 144th Road, Springfield, Queens. He will improve the site with a three-bay gasoline station that has been leased for a long term on a net basis to Texaco Inc.
JERUSALEM (Israeli sector), July 15 -- Premier David Ben Gurion agreed today to try to form a new Government. But he said that under present conditions he had little chance of succeeding.

MOSCOW, July 15 -- Soviet scientists were reported today to have established that the basic gases in the ionosphere are composed of atomic oxygen and atomic nitrogen ions plus combinations of these elements in molecules of nitrogen oxide ions.

TRENTON, July 15 (AP) -Two unidentified aides of David J. McDonald smashed a television newsreel camera early today and removed a roll of sound film after the United Steelworkers' president had heatedly objected to a question about his future.

Sixty probationary patrolmen, students at the New York Police Academy, will give blood today to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program at the chapter house, Thirty-eighth Street and Lexington Avenue.

PITTSBURGH, July 15 (UPI) -- Don Drysdale pitched three-hit ball and doubled home two runs tonight to help the Los Angeles Dodgers blank the Pittsburgh Pirates, 3 -- 0. The triumph lifted the Dodgers into second place.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The United States Court of Claims upheld the Dixon-Yates private-power contract today. It assessed cancellation costs of $1,867,545 against the Government.
Officials in the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced yesterday they were "beginning to crack down" on landlords who fraudulently applied for rent increases.

The nation's inventories of gasoline showed another seasonal decline in the latest week. A decrease of 2,237,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 192,725,000 barrels, compared with 194,989,000 a week earlier and 182,169,000 a year ago.
The two-week strike of concrete truck drivers has caused 100,000 other construction workers to be laid off in the city and on Long Island, industry spokesmen said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- Harmon Killebrew clouted his thirty-first home run tonight as Washington won a rain-shortened five-inning game from Detroit, 3 -- 0, and moved past the Tigers into fifth place.

JERSEY CITY, July 15 -- Public resentment over the alleged beating of three Negro men by three Jersey City policemen last Sunday night broke into the open today. Five hundred Negro residents, many of them carrying placards protesting police brutality, demonstrated for five hours in a block-long street meeting.

LUSAKA, Northern Rhodesia, July 15 -- The African nationalist movement in Northern Rhodesia is split over charges that its chief leader has been overly influenced by white persons and has softened his attitude on nationalism.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- Everyone at the wild horse hearing in Congress agreed today that he was against cruel and inhuman treatment to any animal.
The first steps toward a return to self-government were taken yesterday by Local 88 of the International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots.

A complaint made by the English Electric Company, an unsuccessful bidder on a contract to supply equipment for the Wanapum Dam development on the Columbia River, will not affect the closing of the $195,000,000 financing deal, scheduled for today.
MORRISVILLE, Pa., July 15 -- "Management's been spoiling for a fight for a year and they're sure as hell going to get it."
Whether Tuesday night's 1-0 triumph over the Cleveland Indians marked the beginning of a long-awaited upsurge of the Yankees is a question that must remain unanswered a while longer.

JACK GELBER'S play about jazz and junk, "The Connection,'' which opened last night at The Living Theatre, Avenue of the Americas and Fourteenth Street, is an attempt to depict the sordid world of the narcotics addict.

SMITHTOWN, L. I. July 15 -- The Smithtown Town Board approved a $1,000,000 paper-cup manufacturing plant in Commack yesterday. The action had been bitterly opposed at a three-hour hearing by home owners in the community.

PHILADELPHIA, July 15 -- The United States men's track and field squad will be sternly challenged by the Soviet Union in several traditional American specialties in the international dual meet here on Saturday and Sunday.

PITTSBURGH, July 15 -- None of the bitterness that marked the negotiations in New York was reflected in the milltowns of the Pittsburgh area today.

The United States, which has declined to enter the competition at the Moscow Film Festival next month, will nonetheless be represented by an out-of-competition showing of "The Diary of Anne Frank." This was announced yesterday by Twentieth Century-Fox, the distributor of the George Stevens film. The competition will be held Aug. 3 through Aug. 17.
CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -- Glen Hobbie continued to weave a pitching spell over the Milwaukee Braves today, holding them to five hits en route to a 5-2 victory for the Chicago Cubs.
New York's traditional harbor welcome for a new liner will be extended this morning to the 32,336-ton liner Bremen, the largest ship in West Germany's merchant marine.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., July 15 -- All of New York State's 208 legislators will be invited to attend the races here next month, Mayor Addison Mallery said tonight.

CHICAGO, July 15 -- As the industry-wide steel strike went into its first day, the profound impact of the loss of millions of dollars in wages each day to the almost 90,000 strikers in this area was almost immediately felt in other quarters.

RYE, N.Y., July 15 -- Mrs. James M. Mertz of the host American Yacht Club captured the women's sailing championship of Long Island Sound for the fourth time today as the twenty-second Syce Cup Series drew to a close in a fine easterly breeze.

Rails eased as the steel strike began yesterday but the market as a whole held fairly firm, with steels, meat packers, papers, industrial chemicals and coppers in the lead.
PHILADELPHIA, July 15 -- Mike McCormick studied the situation with thoughtful care as fifteen major league ball clubs frantically dangled large chunks of folding money before his eyes.

JERSEY CITY, July 15 -- City Commissioner James F. Murray Jr., director of the Department of Revenue and Finance, today announced major personnel changes in his department. A grand jury presentment recently criticized the department's assessment practices.

NEW ORLEANS., July 15 (UPI) -- Federal Judge J. Skelly Wright ordered the New Orleans School Board today to submit a plan of desegregation by March 1, 1960, and pleaded with the public to keep New Orleans from becoming another Little Rock.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -The Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy said today that agreements for cooperation with seven North Atlantic Treaty nations on nuclear weapons were necessary to give those allies "confidence and strength" to withstand Soviet nuclear forces.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- Attorney General William P. Rogers said today he knew of no nation-wide crime ring "consisting solely of criminals of any particular national origin."

Despite the West Side Tennis Club's statement that it has no racial or religious bias, the city's Commission on Intergroup Relations decided yesterday to press its investigation of the Forest Hills club and other clubs.
PITTSBURGH, July 15--Private relief agencies in this area were told today that the steel strike might last eleven weeks.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, July 15 -- This capital approached normality today after three days of rebellion against the Government of President Ramon Villeda Morales.
Everett S. Preston, who heads Ohio's billion-dollar highway construction program, believes that the price of modern highways is not high when the benefits are considered.
The Celanese Corporation of America has organized three new companies to manufacture and market its fiber, chemical and plastics products. The activities formerly were conducted by divisions.

India's national railways received another $50,000,000 loan from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) to help finance modernization and expansion. The new loan brings to $257,000,000 the amount advanced to India for upgrading its railway system, the fourth largest in the world.
VANCOUVER, B.C., July 15 -- In the presence of Queen Elizabeth II the new Vancouver Civic Auditorium became the Queen Elizabeth Theatre tonight.

Sales and earnings of the Johns-Manville Corporation in the quarter and six months ended June 30 substantially exceeded those of any previous quarter or half-year in the company's history. The results were disclosed in yesterday's semi-annual report of A.R. Fisher, chairman and president.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -Charges of communism and procommunism such as those made yesterday against Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba and his Government are not easy to prove, President Eisenhower said today.
PARIS, July 15 -- President Charles de Gaulle installed the Senate of the new French Community today "in the name of 82,000,000 men" who want "progress, security and peace."

Blankarn who has resigned from the board, was announced yesterday by the commercial financing and factoring concern. WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Relations between the White House and the Democratic Congress are "no bed of roses," President Eisenhower said today. But he told his news conference he still hoped that "the necessary bills" would be passed, [Questions 6 and 10, Page 8.]

BATON ROUGE, La., July 15 (UPI) -- Gov. Earl Long will call a special session of the Louisiana Legislature Aug. 10 to pass a law making it more difficult to commit a person to a mental hospital, it was announced today.

WHITE PLAINS, July 15 -- New York State Thruway accidents caused by cars crashing into disabled vehicles have increased so markedly that the Thruway Authority has been forced to act to aid stalled autos, the agency said here today in State Supreme Court.
FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 15 -- The Board of Selectmen is seeking an ordinance to limit the height of fences here because of complaints from irate residents.

The rains fell yesterday -St. Swithin's Day -- and a ninth-century legend says it will rain for forty days. The Weather Bureau, which gives no scientific approval to the myth, said it would rain again today, but that tomorrow and Saturday would be partly cloudy and warm.

MIAMI, July 15 -- Land reform is to be part of the revolutionary program in the Dominican Republic if the dictatorship of Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina is overthrown, rebel leaders have indicated.
HAVANA, July 15 -- Half a year after the revolt against the Batista regime, Cuba is in the midst of the first great social revolution in Latin America since the Mexican Revolution of 1910.

DETROIT, July 15 -- Detroit area steelworkers settled down to sweat out the nation-wide steel strike today, unhappy that it had to be but apparently convinced there was no alternative.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Gov. Edmund G. Brown of California gave important political backing today to Paul M. Butler, the Democratic National Chairman, by deciding to join the Democratic Advisory Council.

ST. CATHARINES, Ont., July 15 (Canadian Press) -- Although there may be some advantage in twinning the single locks on the Welland Ship Canal, the canal now is operating at close-to-maximum speed, the St. Lawrence Seaway's western division superintendent, T. J. Ryan, said today.

LONDON, July 16 -- Details of a complicated deal whereby Roy Thomson, Canadian owner of a rapidly expanding newspaper empire, is to acquire the Kemsley Newspapers chain were announced here tonight.

MOUNT HAMILTON, Calif., July 16 -- The world's second largest telescope was dedicated here tonight.

Union printers who voted on Wednesday to accept a contract proposal of ten New York newspapers suspended contract negotiations yesterday with the city's commercial printing employers.
TORONTO, July I6 (AP) -- Vast post-war expansions in Canada's steel industry will help ease the effect of the steel strike in the United States on the Canadian economy.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The New Haven Railroad has told the Interstate Commerce Commission that it does not intend to honor its agreement to repurchase 131,385 shares of its preferred stock until the legality of the pact is settled.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- (AP) -- Vice Admiral Hyman G. Rickover says the Russians will have atomic submarines in a relatively short time and may outstrip the United States in this field.
It has been learned that Thomas J. Lipton, Inc., is considering moving its $3,500,000 tea advertising account from Young Rubicam, Inc.
A warrant was issued yesterday for the arrest of the owner of a tenement branded as one of the two "most sordid" after a crash inspection tour of the West Side on June 24.

LONDON, July 16 -- Industrial shares drifted lower for the fourth straight day today with buyers still hesitant and demand selective. The tone appeared to improve toward close and losses, although widespread, were generally limited to a few pence.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 16 (UPI) -- Willie Shoemaker, in one of his great riding exhibitions, today captured both divisions of the Vanity Handicap at Hollywood Park, each a $30,000 added race, with Tender Size and Zevs Joy.
PARIS, July 16 -- The extreme nationalist movement of Madagascar, the Independence Congress party, appears to be falling under Communist influence, according to reliable information reaching Paris.
Mayor Wagner moved yesterday to ease complaints and tensions in Harlem. He called a meeting of community and political leaders and city officials at City Hall on Tuesday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 16 -- Sympathetic British authorities and United Nations officials have provided a happy ending for the odyssey of an Estonian seafarer, his wife and their young daughter.
BALBOA, C. Z., July 16 -Panama Canal pilots with three years of fully qualified service will receive an annual pay increase of $250 effective July 26, an official source said today.

A biography of Harry Houdini, the great escape artist, has been written by William Lindsay Gresham and Holt will publish it Aug. 3. In "Houdini: The Man Who Walked Through Walls," the author delves into many of the mysteries of Houdini's ways of slipping out of confinement and describes the war he waged against "spirit" mediums.

LONDON, July 16 -- Aircraft workers urged the House of Commons today to reverse "the Government's strangulation policy toward the British aircraft industry and cancel orders for jet airliners made in the United States.

THE annual Brooklyn Championships will begin today at the St. George Hotel, Brooklyn, and will last through Sunday.
Consumption of newsprint in the United States rose to a new high in the first six months of 1959, the American Newspaper Publishers Association reported yesterday.

HAMBURG, Germany, July 16 -- A cautiously hopeful view that forces are at work "that slowly prepare the ground for an accommodation" between the Arab states and Israel was given to the Socialist International Congress here today by Moshe Sharett.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- A little more than sixteen years ago, Dr. John Harry Williams, a handsome and promising young nuclear physicist, arrived at a boys' camp atop a mesa at Los Alamos, N.M. He was the first scientist at the secret outpost that was to become the arsenal of the atomic bomb.

A dance in the Terrace Room of the Roosevelt on Oct. 23 will benefit Planned Parenthood of Manhattan and the Bronx, one of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America's ninety-eight affiliates. This is the third annual dance to be sponsored by the junior auxiliary of the organization.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- Representative John V. Lindsay asked Congress today to liberalize laws governing the import of art works and art exhibits.
The Hudson Celebration Theatre-in-the-Park, on the site of the Wollman Memorial Rink in Central Park, opened last night with Andre Eglevsky's Ballet Advertissements. It was not very good.
