CHICAGO, July 16 (AP) -- A freakish unassisted double play by Al Dark and Ernie Banks' twenty-fifth homer helped the Cubs defeat the Milwaukee Braves today, 4 -- 2.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- George Meany pledged the support of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organization today to the striking steelworkers. He said they had leaned over backward to avoid a strike.
Each of the buildings in the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts will have a visitors' viewing room overlooking the stage.
In a letter to members of the New York delegation in Congress, the Liberal party yesterday urged "quick and decisive" action on a number of issues.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- The nomination of James Stewart to be an Air Force Reserve brigadier general was approved today by the Senate Armed Services Committee.

CHICAGO, July 16 -- Angry officials threw the Wimbledon champion, Alex Olmedo, out of the national clay court tennis tournament today after he had disappointed spectators with a sloppy, listless performance in losing to Abe Segal of South Africa, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 0.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 16 -- With the aid of electronic instruments, a Rutgers University scientist is studying the likes and dislikes of blowflies in "messages" received from the insects.

BUENOS AIRES, July 16 -- President Arturo Frondizi halted today the resignations of most of Argentina's Navy officers while he studied the question of appointing a new Navy Secretary. The President acted under provisions of the state of siege, which has been in effect since last year, to keep the officers on duty.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI) -- The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations declared today that unions were threatened by the heaviest attack on the labor movement in more than a generation. It said the survival of unions was at stake.

The New York Stock Exchange yesterday suspended for six months Stephen M. Jaquith, an allied member and a general partner in the stock brokerage firm of Model, Roland Stone, Leo Model, Rolf R. Roland, Frits Markus and Robert Rosenberg, allied members of the exchange and general partners in the same concern, were censured and fined $5,000 each.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter has invited Vice President Richard M. Nixon to drop in at Geneva on his way back from Moscow. Although the Vice President's office declined comment and State Department officials said they had not heard about it, other sources confirmed that Mr. Herter and Mr. Nixon had discussed the matter during their two meetings before Mr. Herter flew to Geneva last Saturday.

For the fifth time the Senate has voted to give home rule to the District of Columbia. Under a bill hopefully passed on Wednesday the District could elect a Mayor, a city council and a nonvoting delegate to the House of Representatives. Thus its people would be almost as well off as the people of Alaska were during their territorial days.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Walter P. Reuther told Congress today that a proposal to provide hospital insurance for those receiving old-age and survivors insurance through an added payroll tax would not destroy voluntary medical care insurance.
A Bronx real estate executive declared yesterday that the city's new real estate transfer tax would prove unworkable because of a loophole in the state law that authorized it.
The Railway Express Agency will continue in business.

THE metronomic beat of New York can be slowed or speeded by a slight personal adjustment. This ability to change the tempo is one of the city's great gifts. It is akin to E. B. White's "gift of loneliness." To help underscore the libretto for today look at three current books about New Yorkers and New York, all played in different keys.

GENEVA, July 16 -- The Soviet technique at Geneva is a mystery. What the Russians emphasize one day they say is of no real importance the next. What they complain about bitterly on Monday they blithely accept on Wednesday.
SOSNOWIEC, Poland, July 16 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev said today he saw no difference between "a Harriman" and "a Rockefeller." He expressed the view that a capitalist was a capitalist.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., July 16 -- Stanley M. Hawkins has been named national director of the engineering service of the Boy Scouts of America.

MEXICO CITY, July 16 -- Despite his mild attack of appendicitis, Neale Fraser was named today with Rodney Laver to represent Australia in the singles against Mexico in their opening-round Davis Cup match in the American zone starting here Saturday.

BONN, Germany, July 16 -- The finance ministers of the six European common market nations gathered in Bonn today for a two-day conference to discuss future coordination of their countries' currency and tax policies.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Senator Johnson, the majority leader, and five Democratic colleagues who include critics of his leadership policy have united in dissenting to a recent favorable analysis in this space of the reasons given by the President for vetoing the housing bill.

Title I is a section of the Housing Act of 1949 designed to bring private capital into slum clearance. It permits cities to acquire substandard areas and resell them at a markdown to private developers.

The September, January, March, July and October world sugar positions fell to new lows for the life of the contracts yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The other months equaled the old lows. The market was influenced by ample supplies of sugar and concern over reports that Cuba might be damping supplies.
ROME, July 16 -- Every sidewalk cafe in Rome these days is crowded with people listlessly spooning ices. The current heat wave is so overwhelming that even a snail might win a race.
MONROVIA, Liberia, July 16 -- The leaders of the three independent states of West Africa are meeting in northern Liberia today in search of a compromise between conflicting views on African unity.
The appointment of Hedley Donovan as editorial director of all Time, Inc., publications was announced yesterday.
Sales of the American Cyanamid Company set records in the quarter and six months ended June 30, Dr. W. G. Malcolm, president, said in the report issued yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- A committee of the Organization of American States recommended today that the twenty-one American foreign ministers meet in Santiago, Chile, between Aug. 3 and 10.
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation has joined the growing price war in the steam turbine generator field.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -Bernard Goldfine abandoned his plea of not guilty today and placed himself at the mercy of a Federal court.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Treasury offered today to pay 4 3/4 per cent interest -- the highest since 1929 -- to induce holders of nearly $6,000,000,000 of maturing securities to take one of two new securities offered in exchange.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI) -- Senator Clinton P. Anderson, Democrat of New Mexico, said today that election returns have shown that the party's Congressional leadership was more popular with the voters than the men who headed its national campaign organization.

Public offering of $5,000,000 of Reading Tube Corporation 15-year 5 3/4 per cent sinking fund debentures with attached stock purchase warrants is being made through a syndicate headed jointly by Emmanuel, Deetjen Co. and Bache Co.
BOSTON, July 16 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox hustled past Cleveland into the American League lead today as they split a double-header with Boston.

EAST WILLISTON, L. I., July 16 -- Colman McCarthy of Sands Point, a 21-year-old college golfer, led the qualifiers in the Long Island amateur championship today. In a field of 136, McCarthy was the only one to clip par with a 71 at Wheatley Hills.

The fifth week of summer concerts at Lewisohn Stadium, beginning Monday evening, will feature the Stadium debut of the Mexican composer-conductor Carlos Chavez. Leonard Bernstein will take over the baton later in the week.

VANCOUVER, B. C., July 16 -- While communities in the United States talk about new concert halls and opera houses, the cities in western Canada are building them. The new Queen Elizabeth Theatre, dedicated here last night by Queen Elizabeth II, is the third to be finished in this part of the world in recent years.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI) -- Representative F. Edward Hebert of Louisiana accused the Defense Department today of trying to undermine an inquiry into military contract practices by his House Armed Services Investigating subcommittee.

TRIVANDRUM, India, July 16 (Reuters) -- The Communist state government of Kerala, battling an opposition campaign to oust it from office, announced today an indefinite postponement of municipal elections. They had been scheduled for Aug. 28.
NIAROBI, Kenya, July 15 -- The political activities of Tom Mboya, Kenya nationalist leader, are being restricted in a number of ways.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 16 -- Evidences in late 19 that some western Europe countries were faltering in the economic recovery were reported by the Economic Commission for Europe. Its latest bulletin designates last March as the point at which a fresh spurt activity began and apparent continued through April a May with rising momentum.

The placement of proceeds of the Wanapum Dam financing and the announcement of the Treasury's $13,973,000,000 refunding produced cross currents in the market for United States Government securities yesterday.

The "skeleton" civil rights bill which squeaked through a subcommittee of the Senate Judiciary Committee this week is not all that the Administration asked, and it is far from being what Senator Douglas of Illinois suggested. It is approximately the same modest program that Senator Lyndon Johnson, Democratic leader in the upper house and a Texan by birth, residence and politics, laid out on Jan. 20.
City detectives and agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported yesterday that they had broken a ring of auto thieves who had been operating here since February.

The Russian Music and Dance Festival, which closes tomorrow evening at Madison Square Garden, will play a return engagement there Aug. 21-23. Because of the great demand for tickets, S. Hurok will bring it back for three evening performances and two matinees at the close of its engagements on the West Coast.
If the Yankees can wait until about 1970 they may have a recruit with a very keen eye to help them out of their slump.

PHILADELPHIA, July 16 -- At a considerably lower level than the summit, the United States and the Soviet Union will meet here this week-end. Not one issue will become befogged by words. Muscles will decide everything. Hence the happy spirit of camaraderie prevails among the competing athletes in this rain-soaked City of Brotherly Love as they await their international track and field games at Franklin Field Saturday and Sunday.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 554,426 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
SOSNOWIEC, Poland, July 16 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev gave his "solemn pledge" today that the Soviet Union would "never, never, never" start a war.

GENEVA, July 16 -- Andrei A. Gromyko agreed today to renew secret negotiations with the West for an interim settlement of the Berlin crisis. But he made it clear that the Soviet terms for a settlement were as hard as ever.

YONKERS, July 16 -- Out of the cavalry charge that resembled a fifteen-horse stampede at the start stormed Adios Butler to a clean-cut victory in the surprisingly cleanly contested William H. Cane Futurity pace tonight.
FORTY-FIVE invited guests scooped the press Monday morning in viewing one of off-Broadway's most popular shows -- Macy's semi-annual display of model rooms.

The daffy index of wholesale commodity prices of the Bureau of Labor Statistics eased to 86.6 on Wednesday from 86.7 on Tuesday. On July 18, 1958, the index stood at 87.1. The table below gives the index and its components for the elates listed, based on 100 for the period 1947-49:

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Representative Cornelius E. Gallagher, Democrat of New Jersey, charged in a statement today that the contributions that Charles E. Bohlen might be able to make in handling relations with the Soviet Union were being "compromised by a few Republican leaders in the Senate."
Two separate productions of a ninety-minute musical revue titled "The Fabulous Fifties" are being developed by two producers for competing television networks.

The steel strike is the testing ground for a new management approach in collective bargaining. It is an approach built on the belief that industry has surrendered too many of its prerogatives to labor and that it is time to reverse a trend that began with Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal a quarter-century ago.

Through a generous gift of money, to be repeated next year, the Park Department and the Police Athletic League are able to announce a new program of year-round competitive activities for teenage boys and girls of all five boroughs of the city. An anonymous donor has provided $50,000 for this purpose, designating it the Robert Moses-Police Athletic League Fund, and has promised to duplicate the gift next year.
The Yankees, it develops, have only begun to learn how to thrive on adversity.

The union and company negotiating teams in the strike-bound steel industry were as idle yesterday as the 500,000 strikers and the mills that produce 85 per cent of the country's steel. Joseph F. Finnegan, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, returned to Washington to inform the White House that he had got nowhere in his initial efforts to find a basis for ending the costly strike.
RALEIGH, N. C., July 16 AP) -- A Wake County jury convicted a white man, a former convict, today of raping an 11-year-old Negro girl and recommended mercy, which carries a mandatory life sentence.

Hair -- the Long and the Short of It When the Lady Godiva Stakes (a horse race named for the patroness of Coventry, England) was run in a place called Mousford the race was newsworthy chiefly because none of the young lady jockeys had naturally long hair.
General Foods Corporation reported earnings and sales in the three months ended on June 30 set records for the period, which is the first quarter of the company's fiscal year.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 16 (AP) -- A Juno II rocket was exploded 100 feet off its launching pad today when it veered toward the Florida mainland. No one was injured.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- The Senate Select Committee on Improper Activities in the Labor or Management Field plans to start a preliminary investigation of the United Auto Workers in closed hearings.
Word that copper production was being reduced in Northern Rhodesia strengthened refined copper prices in London and New York yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- President Eisenhower told foreign exchange students today that their visits were helping to erase conflicts and bring about a better world.
HONG KONG, July 16 -- The Chinese Communists called on commune dwellers today to diversify their economy.

Three men, all officers of a union organized earlier this year ostensibly for building superintendents, were accused yesterday of sociliting bribes from landlords in an attempt to gain "sweetheart" contracts.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- The Todd Shipyard Plant in Houston was awarded a contract today to build a ship-side servicing barge for the Savannah and other nuclearpowered ships of the future.

PHILADELPHIA, July 16 -- With the arrival of seven more athletes today, the United States men's track and field team that will oppose the Soviet Union squad on Saturday and Sunday took on a more imposing cast.

MR. JOHN, the Napoleon of the millinery world, christened his new salon as well as his fall collection yesterday. The popping of champagne corks caused some viewers to wonder if the original little emperor and his armies might not be packed in among the guests. The salon is now at 24 West Fifty-seventh Street.
Loans to business by the large New York banks rose $11,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday. This compared with a $44,000,000 decrease in the week before.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota was adjudged today, against his will, to be an avowed Democratic Presidential aspirant.

LVOV, U. S. S. R., July 16 (UPI) -- Two American musicians had the city conservatory of this Ukrainian cultural center jumping yesterday with an impromptu East-West jazz session that shook the pictures on the walls.
LONDON, July 16 -- The restoration of expression in cases of facial paralysis was described in today's sessions of the International Congress on Plastic surgery here.
SOSNOWIEC, July 16 (AP) -- Premier Khrushchev's antiwar pledge today was similar to previous statements he has made. At a Kremlin reception Nov. 14, he said:
ABOARD U.S.S. SARATOGA, at Sea, July 16 -- Sea power of the atomic age was on parade yesterday and today in blue water 250 miles off the South Carolina coast.
The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized the Jersey Central and the Lackawanna Railroads yesterday to increase commuter fares between New Jersey points and New York by an average of 15 per cent.
The Freedom Fund has published a Russian-language "guide book" to New York City for the benefit of the 150 Russians now in New York with the Soviet exhibition at the Coliseum.
Nearly 200 teen-agers yesterday fingered a copy of what in the next few days may be the first object ever fired into orbit and retrieved.

OMAHA, July 16 -- Gilbert Ramirez, 19-year-old player from San Francisco, today took the lead after five rounds of the annual tournament for the junior championship of the United States Chess Federation.
CHICAGO, July 16 (AP) -The grain futures market eased again today on the Board of Trade, taking soybeans along for the first time this week.

West Germany's first post-war entry into the North Atlantic luxury passenger trade, the Bremen, came into New York Harbor yesterday with all the grace her namesakes had shown in the past. The fifth North German Lloyd liner to bear the name of the German port in a century made her maiden entry here in poor visibility.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI) -- The United States Court of Appeals ruled today that the Sperry Gyroscope Company improperly dismissed a machinist in 1954 on security grounds.
ELY, Minn., July 16 (AP) -- Pickets paraded before the non-unionized Zenith underground iron-ore mine here today and were met by taunts from workers wives.
Announcements of new foreign enterprises by American companies have come almost daily in recent years. Yesterday proved an exception, however, with three substantial foreign ventures reported.

All five horses in the feature race at Jamaica yesterday finished less than a length apart. This was small solace to the favorite players in the crowd of 21,116 who made Mabel Scholtz' Warhead the 1-to-2 choice.

Members of the Council of Administration of the New York State Bankers Association oppose continuation of the "freeze" on formation and expansion of bank holding companies in the state, the association announced yesterday.
CHICAGO, July 16 (AP) -- The report I o, today's Livestock markets here by the Department ot A:rteulture follows:
In answer to your editorial of July 13, "Flight 102," we feel that the chaos at Idlewild resulted from the premature publicity on radio and television.
MOSCOW, July 16 -- Americans who want to have useful conversations with Russians here these days had better know where "the tickets" are.

PRINCETON, N. J., July 16 -- Deadly putting and strong iron play carried Mrs. Jack Silberberg of Crestmont and Mrs. Betty Whelan of the home club to the final of the Garden State Women's Golf Association's sixth annual championship today at the Springdale Golf Club.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -Dr. John H. Williams, a prominent pioneer in nuclear physics, was named by President Eisenhower today to be the new scientist member of the Atomic Energy Commission.

The five-story apartment house at 2710 Bainbridge Avenue, the Bronx, was sold by Minna Tonkelson to Irving B. Neiditch, president of the Bridge Realty Company. Helmsley-Spear, Inc., was the broker. The sale was the first involving the property in thirty years.
GENEVA, July 16 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of an address by Secretary of State Christian A. Herter today at the foreign ministers' conference:

A new off-Broadway theatre is in the offing. It is to be erected by Irving Maidman, realty investor and builder, at 416 West Forty-second Street, near Ninth Avenue. Mr. Maidman said yesterday the unnamed showcase, which is to have a seating capacity of 292, wound utilize a proscenium stage.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Senate and House conferees agreed today on a $1,400,000,000 military-aid authorization as part of a compromise Mutual-Security bill.
TUNIS, July 6 -- An Algerian rebel leader asserted tonight that his forces had burned alive 200 French soldiers in destroying a French post on the Algerian-Tunisian frontier.
Personnel of Mitchel Air Force Base, Hempstead, L. I. and the New York Army Ordnance District, 770 Broadway, will give blood today to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program.

The great post-war trend toward diversification in business and industry shows no sign of slackening. If anything, the urge to seek greener fields far from the old home base appears stronger than ever -- impelling companies to enter activities completely unrelated to their traditional operation.
The Soviet exhibition at the New York Coliseum is interesting in many ways. Apart from the actual displays, it affords many Americans their first opportunity to meet a Russian face to face.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -The House Education and Labor Committee completed the major work tonight on a labor reform bill.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 16 -- Heads of major movie studios here have agreed that the film industry must answer the American Legion's charge that the industry has permitted "re-infiltration" of Communists and fellow travelers.
GENEVA, July 16 -- The Soviet Union gave ground slightly today on its veto demands after accusing the United States of sabotaging the three-power conference here on a nuclear test ban.

White supremacists are making plans to neutralize northern opinion and if possible to enroll the North under their banner, the convention of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People was told yesterday.

GARY, Ind., July 16 -- John Mayerik, president of United Steel Workers Local 1014, will pass through his own picket lines tomorrow to confer with officials of United States Steel who have been holed up inside the main company plant here since the strike began.

PHILADELPHIA, July 16 -- Dusty Rhodes, a familiar hero out of his club's New York past, made it possible tonight for the Giants to maintain their one-game lead over the Dodgers in the tight National League race.
ZINO FRANCESCATTI, Alfred Wallenstein and the Stadium Symphony collaborated to give a program of excellent quality last night at the Lewisohn Stadium. An audience of 5,500 turned out to enjoy it.

ASHEVILLE, N. C., July 16 (AP) -- A Federal judge, blaming union leaders "for most of the trouble in labor today," imposed a $50,000 fine today on a local of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. He also sentenced one of its officials to eighteen months' imprisonment for criminal contempt of court.

Mayor Wagner indicated yesterday that he would add City Administrator Charles F. Preusse to the Committee on Slum Clearance. This would be a step toward bringing more order to the administration of the city's billion-dollar Title I program.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Edward N. Gadsby, said today he doubted there could be a repetition of the stock market crash of 1929.
The Black Decker Manufacturing Company, a leading producer of portable electric tools and accessories widely used in factory operations, plans a two-for-one stock split.
With Premier Khrushchev continuing to boast of Soviet superiority in atomic arms, the United States is moving to bolster the nuclear deterrent strength of the North Atlantic alliance.
Cotton futures market was unchanged to 16 points (80 cents a bale) up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The near months showed considerable strength toward the close.
The State Commission Against Discrimination will appeal a State Supreme Court decision that would prohibit the Arabian-American Oil Company from asking job applicants about their religion.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Following is the text of a union members' "rights" title adopted by the House Education and Labor Committee as a substitute for the so-called "bill of rights" in the Senate-approved Kennedy bill.

MIAMI BEACH, July 16 -The International Longshoremen's Association rejected today an appeal by James R. Hoffa to forget its ideological differences with Harry Bridges, leftwing president of a rival, Pacific Coast dock union.
SCRANTON, Pa., July 16 (AP) -- The police clashed with pickets in front of the plant of the Capitol Records Company in South Scranton today. Two pickets were said to have suffered minor injuries.
VIENNA, July 16 -- The Hungarian regime appears to have achieved a significant success in the first six months of 1959 with its accelerated industrialization program.
LONDON, July 16 -- Harry Ferguson, the inventor and industrialist, offered today to put up u10,000 ($28,000) to further a campaign to reduce prices here.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI) -Senator Prescott Bush, Republican of Connecticut, predicted today that Democratic leaders would see to it that Congress passed a new housing bill acceptable to President Eisenhower.

MOSCOW, July 16 -- "Serious shortcomings and errors" in virtually every branch of the economic and political life of Azerbaijan have been charged to the republic's Communist party chief and some members of the Politburo he headed.
On Monday Pan American World Airways will start using a Boeing 707 jet on one of the world's longest routes -between New York and Buenos Aires.
A 285-pound, two-year-old lion quit his role as Central Park Zoo's star boarder yesterday and padded gently into a plywood crate marked: "Manila, the Philippines."

Lumber production fell to 199,101,000 board feet last week from 224,526,000 the week before, according to reports received by The New York Times from regional associations. The latest figure compares with 175,524,000 board feet produced in the same week last year.
The Georgia-Pacific Corporation has won its fight with the United States Plywood Corporation for control of the Booth-Kelly Lumber Company of Springfield, Ore.

GOLDENS BRIDGE, N. Y., July 17 -- Three men were killed this evening when a pick-up truck they were in was struck by a New York Central Railroad passenger train at a grade crossing a mile south of here.
YONKERS, July 17 -- A $10,000 junior free-for-all trot topped the program at Yonkers Raceway tonight. For many of the 28,166 fans, no $100,000 stake race could have been more exciting.

Waterways and woodlands that provide vacation pleasures for thousands face a common danger of being spoiled by persons who thoughtlessly discard cans, bottles and assorted refuse. Apart from the obvious fact that such trash is a blight on the beauty of vacation areas, it often is a menace in the case of waterways. For floating cans and bottles are capable of piercing the hulls of lightweight pleasure craft.
HAMBURG, Germany, July 17 -- The Congress of the Socialist International voted today an expression of hope "that an early summit conference will make it possible to end the cold war."

When Fidel Castro in Havana yesterday, six months and seventeen days after his seizure of power, offered the resignation that he later withdrew, he had himself become a practitioner of one-man rule where he had been the symbol of resistance to dictatorship.
ULAN BATOR, Mongolia, July 14 -- Premier Yumzhagiin Tsedenbal of Mongolia expressed hope last night that Mongolia and the United States would establish diplomatic relations soon.

Steels, motors, industrial chemicals and building materials were notably weak in yesterday's lackluster session on the New York Stock Exchange. Prices registered another moderate decline but it made the week's loss the heaviest of the year to date.
STETTIN, Poland, July 17 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev charged today that the West was plotting to make Scandinavia a decoy for Soviet atomic bombs in case of war.
We read the letter from Winberg Chai on the refugee Chinese scholars of Hong Kong, published on July 8, with interest and sympathy.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 17 (AP) -- The Jerusalem radio said today that Premier David Ben-Gurion had abandoned his attempts to form a new Government.

A subpoena ordering the General Motors Corporation to produce tons of documentary material in an antitrust investigation was put aside by a Federal judge here yesterday. The request was called "unreasonable" and "extravagant."
The city yesterday withdrew its charge that Benjamin Cymrot, suspended executive officer of the old Bureau of Real Estate, had permitted excessive payments of "finders' fees" to landlords.

Early Wynn, a 39-year-old campaigner of diamond warfare, and Ralph Terry, a tall stripling of only 23, engaged in a tremendous mound duel at the Stadium last night with a crowd of 42,020 hanging breathlessly on every pitch.
PHILADELPHIA, July 17 The track and field match between teams of men and women athletes from the United States and the Soviet Union will get under way tomorrow.

The National Broadcasting Company said yesterday it had never attempted to suppress the release of a grand jury presentment on television quiz shows. The presentment was impounded last month by General Session Judge Mitchell D. Schweitzer.

The United Industrial Corporation, Grand Rapids, Mich., diversified industrial manufacturer, and Topp Industries, Inc., a West Coast maker of electronic products for the aircraft and missiles industries, have entered into negotiations for consolidation.

MONTREAL, July 17 (Canadian Press) -- Dominion Engineering Company (Montreal), Ltd., today announced the acceptance of its bid to provide ten hydraulic turbines for the Wanapum Development on the Columbia River in Washington. A company spokesman said the order totaled $10,000,000.

The United Steelworkers of America, with 500,000 members in basic steel mills, iron ore mines, Great Lakes ore carriers and other operations affected by the stoppage. The union has another 500,000 members in aluminum, can manufacturing and steel fabricating plants whose wages are usually affected by the basic settlement. These plants are not on strike.

Striking drivers of ready-mix concrete trucks have made an exception to their shutdown of deliveries for fifty city and Long Island concerns. It was to remove a potential danger to four BMT tracks under which a new subway spur is being built on the Lower East Side.

The directors of the Mesabi Iron Company have authorized the management at its discretion to purchase the company's stock listed on the American Stock Exchange. The funds for the purchase of the stock will come from $1,081,541 received from the Reserve Mining Company.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (UPI) -- The President's Committee for Traffic Safety called today for increased nation-wide efforts to promote highway safety. It noted that a record traffic-death toll had been predicted for this year.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The Council of the Organization of American States decided today that the foreign ministers of the twenty-one American republics should meet in Santiago, Chile, next month to try to ease tensions in the Caribbean area.
BALTIMORE, July 17 (AP) -- Federal Judge R. Dorsey Watkins ordered today that the Commercial Savings and Loan Association and three individuals must stand trial on charges of mail fraud.

LATEST combat bulletins from fishing waters off the State of New Jersey indicate that the situation is completely out of hand and the United States Navy may have to be called out to quell the rioting and murder.
TAMPA, Fla., July 17 (UPI) -- Hoodlums threw a bottle of sulphuric acid into the face of a nonunion truck driver early today shortly after he had crossed a picket line of the Chemical Workers Union.

Title I is a section of the Housing Act of 1949 designed to bring private capital into slum clearance. It permits cities to acquire substandard areas and resell them at a markdown to private developers.

The fifteen-story Knickerbocker Hotel at 120 West Forty-fifth Street has been sold by the Harris hotel chain to a syndicate represented by Charles H. Kelman, lawyer. On a lot 95 by 100 feet, the building has 400 rooms, stores and commercial space. It is assessed for more than $1,000,000, and was sold for cash over mortgages exceeding that amount.
TOKYO, July 17 -- New York's juvenile deliquency problems were aired today in Tokyo, a city that is also struggling with juvenile crime, by a member of the New York City Board of Education.

LONDON, July 17 -- Industrial shares scored the first rise of the week today. Buyers returned to the stock market on a small scale, but the improvement was caused mainly by a cessation of recent selling prompted by election uncertainties.

BLOOMFIELD, N. J., July 17 -- Stan Mosel, who hadn't been playing his best golf this season, did today. The Essex Fells professional shot a 6-under-par 65 and took the lead in the New Jersey open with 138.
PITTSBURGH, July 17 (AP) -- The San Francisco Giant belted four doubles and capitalized on an error tonight as the whipped the Pittsburgh Pirate 4 -- 1, behind the effective pitching of Sam Jones.

A railroad executive spoke yesterday of an "extra $7,000,000,000" that could have gone into rail improvements since the end of World War II, if the carriers had been able to remove the make-work or "featherbedding" rules on train operations.
Lewis Mumford, in a letter you published on July 6, says, "The chief enemy we must come to grips with is ourselves." Our "self-induced fears of Russia" are said to be leading us to destruction.

Three members of an alleged auto theft ring rounded up by New York City police and the Federal Bureau of Investigation were charged yesterday in Federal Court in Brooklyn with conspiring to take stolen cars across state lines.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) -- The merged labor federation assailed today President Eisenhower's proposal to remove the interest-rate ceiling on new Government bonds. The federation said it would enrich money lenders and bankers.
NEW DELHI, India, July 17 -- The Indian Communist party has rejected a proposal that Kerala State's Communist government hold mid-term elections on its own initiative.

HILLSBORO TOWNSHIP, N. J., July 17 -- A Marine Corps pilot who shot down eleven enemy aircraft in World War II was killed today on a routine flight when his Navy jet crashed and burned in a cornfield near here, at the base of Sourland Mountain.

TEL AVIV, July 17 -- A concession giving an international investment group the right to operate a sixteen-inch oil pipeline between Elath and Haifa was signed here today. The segment of the new pipeline from the port at Elath to Beersheba is now under construction and is scheduled to be completed by July of next year.
The Immigration and Naturalization Service yesterday revoked the conditional landing permits for the twenty-eight-man crew of the strike-bound Italian freighter Punta Alice.

HAVANA, July 17 (AP) -- Premier Castro called on Presi dent Urrutia in mid-morning today, but the Presidential Palace said he did not submit his resignation at that time. Dr. Castro then retired to Camp Libertad, the military headquarters in Havana.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- Housing starts rose to 136,000 in June, an increase of 2,000 from May. This represented the highest volume of new residential activity in June for any year except 1950.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N. Y. July 17 -- The General Motors Corporation today advanced one of two major phases of its expansion program here. It offered $658,750 for twenty-nine-a-half acers of land on which to establish parking facilities just east of its Chevrolet and Fisher body plants.
The 2,400,000-member United Lutheran Church in America is in "urgent" need of 429 ministers to fill its pulpits.
Bob Ussery had another fine riding day yesterday at the Jamaica race track. He scored a triple that included a victory in the feature race.

LONDON, July 17 -- The visitor who wondered what comes over these nice, civilized chaps, the Britons, when they get in the driver's seat and take to the road now has an answer. They are suddenly back in the Stone Age.

PHILADELPHIA, July 17 -- Harry Anderson's seventh-inning home run and courageous pitching by Jim Owens carried the last-place Phillies to a 3-2 victory over the Dodgers tonight before 16,686 spectators at Connie Mack Stadium.
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, July 17 -- Brig. Gen. Jose Rene Roman Fernandes took over today as Army Chief of Staff here.
NEWARK, July 17 -- A drive to put a Sunday closing law to a referendum in the November election is getting under way this week in a number of New Jersey counties.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed points (40 cents a bale) up 1 point (5 cents a bale) off yesterday.
The first of a series of Monday night concerts in Washington Square sponsored by the Washington Square Association will begin on Aug. 3.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- President Eisenhower authorized today a public declaration of his "great confidence" in Charles E. Bohlen.

The annual Angels Ball for the benefit of the philanthropies of the New York Section of the National Council of Jewish Women will be held on Nov. 11 in the Astor. It will be co-sponsored by the New York Section and by Helena Rubenstein.

REDDING, Calif., July 17 (AP) -- Two world swimming records fell to Americans tonight in the Amateur Athletic nation's women's national outdoor championships. Carin Cone won the 220 yard back-stroke in 2 minutes 37.9 seconds and Sylvia Ruuska the 440-yard individual medley in 5:40.2.

MEXICO CITY, July 16 -- Financial and business circles here have reacted favorably to the Presidential decree announced on Wednesday which allowed Mexican banks to trim their reserves to 15 per cent instead of 25 per cent.

The long fight by American women to win the right to vote is told by Eleanor Flexner in "Century of Struggle: The Woman's Rights Movement in the United States." The book will be issued Aug. 10 by Belknap Press and distributed by Harvard University Press.
HONOLULU, July 17 (AP) -- Peter Grant's 46-foot sloop Nalu II was the apparent winner today of the twenty-first Trans-Pacific race from Los Angeles.
Smith, Kline French Laboratories achieved record sales and earnings in the first six months this year.
An 8-year-old boy who had received only one injection of Salk polio vaccine died of bulbar poliomyelitis in a city hospital last Sunday. It was the first polio death in the city this year.
EL, PASO, Tex., July 17 (UPI) -- Gov. Earl K. Long tried today to kick down the door of a hotel room to get at aides who had left him during a tour of night clubs in Juarez, Mexico.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- Army psychiatric cases requiring hospitalization have hit an all-time low for two consecutive years, even under the constant-readiness conditions of the "cold war."

CHICAGO, July 17 (AP) -- Art Ceccarelli, a southpaw, turned his second National League start into his second victory today. He blanked the Cincinnati Reds on six hits and scored Chicago's run in a 1-0 triumph.
The city's Commission on Intergroup Relations plans to investigate clubs in the city that are said to bar Jews, Negroes or others from membership on the basis of race or religion.

PITTSBURGH, July 17 -- More than 200 supervisors of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation have been stranded by the Steel strike since midnight Tuesday inside the huge Hazelwood and South Side plants of the corporation here.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Dr. Donald Stubbs, spokesman for Blue Shield Surgical Insurance Plans, testified today that coverage for the aged had increased dramatically since last year.
GENEVA, July 17 -- The Western powers ran into a Soviet stone wall today in trying to get Andrei A. Gromyko to talk about an interim settlement of the Berlin crisis.

While Premier Khrushchev barnstorms through Poland, boasting of Soviet prowess as the gravedigger of "capitalism," his chief class competitors for the allegiance of the "workers of the world" have issued a counter-manifesto for freedom and democracy. This manifesto was issued by the Sixth Congress of the Socialist International in Hamburg, Germany, at the very moment when Mr. Khrushchev was visiting not too far away in Polish-annexed Stettin, now called Szczecin.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) -- A House committee sent to the Justice Department today charges that a private concern had spied on a Government official who was trying to reduce its multi-million dollar Government contract.

HOME cooks of a generation or so ago sometimes added rose hips to jams and jellies to give them greater tartness. Nowadays, interest in rose hips is generally prompted by the knowledge that they are one of the richest sources of Vitamin C.
The promotion of four executives has been announced by William J. Demorest, president of William A. White Sons, realty concern that recently completed ninety years of activity in this city.

SHREVEPORT, La., July 17 (AP) -- A children's book depicting the marriage of a "Grumpy black man and a white lady" was taken off the shelves of the Shreveport Memorial Library today after being attacked as "insidious interracial propaganda."
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The anti-recession program of unemployment benefits came to its delayed end on June 30 with about 45,000 jobless workers still collecting, the Labor Department reported today.

Annual savings of more than $600,000, effective July 27, are expected for former customers of the Brooklyn Borough Gas Company as a result of a rates schedule approved yesterday by the Public Service Commission.
PRINCETON, N. J., July 17 -- Mrs. Betty Whelan captured the Garden State Women's Golf Association's sixth annual championship at the Springdale Golf Club today.
WASHINGTON, July (AP) -- An allotment of $2,629,114,000 in new funds for the Atomic Energy Commission was recommended today by the House Appropriations Committee.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- Senator Kenneth B. Keating said today the groundwork had been laid for pushing through Congress a civil rights bill that "would be a fraud on the American people."
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., July 17 -- It's good to get back to nature, and there is a group of campers here doing just that. But not so far back that they cannot commute to work every morning.

THE Brooklyn Championships in bridge, now being played at the St. George Hotel, lived up to their name in the opening sessions yesterday. More of the contestants came from Brooklyn than from all the other boroughs (and suburbs) put together.
I refer to the editorial in the July 17 issue of The Times concerning the handling of the emergency jet aircraft landing at New York International Airport, Saturday, July 11.

Four hundred Puerto Rican inmates at the City Penitentiary on Rikers Island attended a ceremony in the prison auditorium yesterday to celebrate the 100th anniversary of the birth of Luis Munoz Rivera. The Puerto Rican poet and journalist was the father of Gov. Luis Munoz-Marin of Puerto Rico.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The House Education and Labor Committee completed all but the formalities today on a bill aimed mainly at corruption and dictatorship in unions.

It is said that the consumer is usually the "forgotten man" when the Government makes laws and writes regulations. At the moment the consumer is being rivaled by the saver for this dubious distinction.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower today proclaimed next week as Captive Nations Week. He urged Americans to "study the plight" of countries held captive by "imperialistic and aggressive" Soviet communism.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 17 (Reuters) -- The first land was distributed under the Iraqi agrarian reform plan today. About 1,200 peasants received a total of 10,000 acres carved from a big estate.
BONN, Germany, July 17 -The Finance Ministers of the common market countries agreed today to work out common principles to guide their budgetary policy.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) -- Senator Henry M. Jackson, chairman of the Joint Atomic Energy Committee's panel on military uses of atomic energy, said today that the United States had no effective way of stopping a nuclear-missile attack from Soviet submarines.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- National Airlines protested today a proposal by Northeast Airlines to apply bargain-rate New York-Miami night coach fares to every night in the week.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., July 17 (AP) -- Mrs. Harry Nevil of Cooperstown, the defending champion, and Mrs. Virginia Guilfoyle Allen of Syracuse, champion in 1941, gained the final in the New York State women's amateur golf tournament today.
A. P. warehouse workers will meet at 2 P. M. today at St. Nicholas Arena to hear a report from their union officers progress toward settling the month-old strike against the food store chain.
A partnership between the patient and electronic data-processing equipment can produce preliminary diagnoses of disease without a physician's help, according to a medical report.
A provisional agreement has been signed for the construction of a shipyard in Israel, according to a report issued yesterday by Allalouf Co., shipping agent in Near East ports.

The proposed meeting of the Foreign Ministers of the Organization of American States in Santiago, Chile, in August should act as a safety valve. There are pressures, tensions, emotions, revolutionary forces and national rivalries, especially in the Caribbean, that need to be talked out instead of fought out.

The Merchants National Bank of Boston is offering its shareholders rights to subscribe to 72,500 additional shares of capital stock at $43 a share at the rate of one additional share for each 6 1/2 shares held.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 17 -- Harry Bridges accused Senate investigators today of "deliberately and maliciously" trying to create the impression that longshore and teamster union leaders were "up to something evil, subversive and illegal."
Two liners with oddly entangled histories lay at the same pier on the North River last night.

The bond market maintained its strong tone yesterday except for certain downward adjustments in Treasury securities prices. These declines were brought on by the terms of the Government's $13,973,000,000 debt conversion operation coming up next week.
Psychological studies of ducks have provided what may be two clues to the problem of how early human experience determines adult behavior.
Carmine G. De Sapio made it clear yesterday that he was supporting Paul M. Butler, the Democratic national chairman, in the dispute over Mr. Butler's criticism of the party's leadership in Congress.

VANCOUVER, B. C., July 17 -- By all that is logical, the Vancouver International Festival has no more compelling justification than the Shakespeare Fete at Stratford, Ont. But, like the Stratford enterprise, it is alive and bursting with energy.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Eugene Meyer, board chairman of The Washington Post and Times Herald, died here today. His age was 83. He had been under treatment in George Washington University Hospital for a heart ailment and cancer.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- Dividend payments by corporations issuing public reports amounted to a record $6,009,100,000 in the first half of this year, the Department of Commerce reported today.
LONDON, July 17 -- Plastic surgeons urgently need central banks of processed human tissue, such as skin, bone and cartilage, a New York surgeon said here today.

Jack Brause, realty investor, has purchased two four-story brownstone houses and a one-story brick store building at 397 to 401 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn. The property, assessed at $137,000, was sold subject to a first mortgage of $130,000 for fifteen years.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- John M. Olin, an executive of Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation and an enthusiastic sportsman, has invented a metal shotgun shell that, he says, won't stick in the chamber.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Average wholesale prices in primary market fell 0.1 per cent to 119.3 per cent of their 1947-1949 base during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
HAVANA, July 17 (AP) -- Minister of State Roa cleared the United States State Department of any link with the reported plot against Cuba.

EAST WILLISTON, L. I., July 17 -- Art Silvestrone of Levittown, L. I., eliminated Colman McCarthy of Sands Point, the medalist, in the second round of the Long Island amateur golf championship today. Silvestrone, who won the William D. Richardson Memorial tournament last spring, scored by 3 and 2 at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club.
With the approach of mid-summer, activity in the public market for new capital is diminishing noticeably.
SHANNON, Ireland, July 17 (UPI) -- The Shannon International Airport, a key point for many trans-Atlantic flights, faced a shutdown today as a result of a strike call by airport security workers.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy yesterday criticized the president of the New York branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People for calling Harlem a "police state."

The United States Steel Corporation told its 210,000 striking employes yesterday that their walkout was a "needless waste." The company, traditional pacesetter for the steel industry, vowed that it would not capitulate to union demands.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) -- The Navy, accused of "incompetent" or "deliberately careless" negotiation of defense contracts that cost the Government millions, admitted to House investigator's today that it did a "bad" job on fourteen awards.

GENOA, Italy, July 17 -- Two important personnel problems of United States diplomacy are now in the process of being settled. The first involves selection of a new American Ambassador to West Germany when David Bruce, our present envoy in Bonn, resigns late this summer or early in the autumn.

PARIS, July 17 -- The Senate of the community formed by France and her former colonies elected Gaston Monnerville, 61-year-old native of French Guiana, as its President today. He is also President of the Senate of the French Republic, to which he was elected last April.

CHICAGO, July 17 (AP) -- Soybeans futures teetered over a fairly broad price range today on the Board of Trade, but finished in a moderate flurry of buying at their highs for the day, up moslyy in major fractions.

The Great Northern Railway announced yesterday the election to the board of J. Howard Laeri and William H. Lang to succeed Frank J. Gavin, who retired as chairman and director in May, and the late Archibald Witherspoon.

HAVANA, July 17 -- Minister of State Raul Roa charged last night that a conspiracy was being prepared against the Cuban revolutionary Government among elements in the United States and the Dominican Republic.
The resignation of Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy, effective Aug. 21, was announced by Mayor Wagner yesterday.

The language barrier which exist between American forces in Germany, France and Italy and the native populations, more specifically the medical groups on the two side is a very serious one. In Germany for example, many of our hospitals for the armed services start out with great enthusiasm for inviting local German physicians to our medical conferences.
GENEVA, July 17 -- The Soviet Union gave more details today about its latest position on the veto powers that should exist in the proposed organization for policing a ban of nuclear weapons tests.
JAMES STEWART presented an absorbing half-hour documentary about the Strategic Air Command last night on Channel 2
CHICAGO, July 17 (UPI) -- The National Safety Council warned today that motorized children's cars were dangerous vehicles, not toys.

The wife of a prominent bridge teacher and her partner swept the opening contract bridge event in the Brooklyn Championships yesterday at the St. George Hotel with the unusually high score of 230 1/2 match points.
CHICAGO, July 17 (AP) -- Alex Olmedo expressed regret today for his listless showing yesterday in the national clay courts tennis tournament.

MANILA, July 16 -- President Carlos Garcia signed into law today legislation imposing a margin fee on the sale of foreign exchange through the central bank. His action changed the relationship of the Philippine peso to the United States dollar, which heretofore had been maintained at two-to-one.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board decided today that newsmen covering the United Nations in New York City could take part in a United Nations flying club's trans-Atlantic charter flight.
ROME, July 17 -- Sometimes the new trends that come out of the European fashion collections are revealed even on the second day of the showings.

CAMAGUEY, Cuba, July 17 (AP) -- The Government has taken over operation of the 10,000-acre farm property of Richard D. Burford of Fort Smith, Ark. It was the first known intervention of sugar land owned by a United States citizen.

Nikita Khrushchev's favorite sport, as his visit to Poland has shown again, is rocket rattling. But this week-end the eyes of sports enthusiasts both here and in the Soviet Union will be centered upon a more interesting and more wholesome type of competition: the Soviet-American track and field meet at Philadelphia's Franklin Field.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- The Air Operations Bureau of the Civil Aeronautics Board has recommended that the board order "across-the-board percentage reductions" of airline fares.
BOSTON, July 17 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians halted a ninth-inning Boston Red Sox rally tonight and scored an 8-7 victory.

The summer week-ends now are drifting by, until it no longer takes two hands to hold them. Once they numbered a great many, for by anticipation the week-ends of the spring were lumped with those of summer, and they extended from one to another in a seemingly endless chain.
The Committee on Slum Clearance, divided within itself and beset by criticism from the outside, has put off its July meeting one week, from next Tuesday to July 28.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People yesterday upheld the suspension of the president of a North Carolina chapter who had advocated combating' "violence with violence" and "lynching with lynching."
PHILADELPHIA, July 17 -- The migration into Philadelphia of about 500,000 persons from the South and from Puerto Rico since 1930 was blamed today for the city's juvenile-delinquency problem.

A MAN with a strong sense of mission but a healthy regard for what is practical will become official "family provider" for more than 350,000 New Yorkers when he takes over the helm of the city's Welfare Department on Aug. 21.

CUIDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, July 17 -- Cuba's former dictator, Gen. Fulgencio Batista, has been prevented by Dominican authorities from escaping to the United States without an entrance visa.
ALBANY, July 17 -- The State Education Department sketched a portrait today of the typical school district troubled by the refusal of taxpayers to approve spending programs.
Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, said yesterday that equal-time restrictions could make a "shambles" of public service programing on radio and television.

A long life and a rich one in its many-sided contacts with three generations of Americans ended yesterday with the death of Eugene Meyer. Here was a man born on the West Coast, schooled in the East, equipped by his own skill and industry to serve in many positions of national responsibility.

CAIRO, July 17 -- The United Arab Republic has decided to increase sharply its participation in both the International Monetary Fund and International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank).

SYRACUSE, July 17 -- Rory Calhoun of White Plains, N. Y., solved the sharp punching tactics of Dick Tiger of Nigeria and scored a split decision in their ten-round middleweight fight in the War Memorial Auditorium tonight.

MEXICO CITY, July 17 -- With his blood count back to normal following his mild attack of appendicitis, Neale Fraser will lead the Australian Davis Cup team against Mexico tomorrow as it begins its quest for the world championship tennis trophy it lost to the United States last December.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July l7 -- If tradition held true, this spring should have seen a record number of weddings in Tunisia. The country has emerged during the last three years as the world's largest exporter of olive oil, and the 1959 season produced a harvest that set a new peak at 135,000 tons.

LENOX, Mass., July 17 -- Another week-end of the Berkshire Festival got under way this balmy evening. Charles Munch was the conductor, and the program had one novelty on it -- Bohuslav Martinu's "The Parables." Berlioz' "Corsair" Overture and Tchaikovsky's "Pathdtique" Symphony were the other works.

Another Turkish editor has been sentenced to sixteen months in jail and a stiff fine for reprinting articles critical of the administration. Unfortunately this is not the first case. Time after time the efforts of the Turkish press to raise an opposition voice have met with stern repression.
Advice on domestic relations will be televised weekdays at 1 A. M. over WRCA-TV immediately following "The Jack Paar Show," starting Aug. 10.

DETROIT, July 17 (AP) -- Fire destroyed the interior of the home of Charles O'Brien, a teamsters' union business agent, in suburban Bloomfield Township last night. Damage was estimated at a total of $35,000.

Help-wanted advertising in 113 major labor markets came close to record levels last month. The month of June had almost 1,500,000 more advertisements in the category than in the 1958 period, when there was a sharp drop.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Senate and House conferees agreed today on a $3,556,200,000 authorization to carry forward the Mutual Security Program another year.
HAVANA, Saturday, July 18 -- Fidel Castro succeeded late last night in forcing out Manuel Urrutia Lleo as President of Cuba.

Three buildings at 26 and 27 Washington Square North and 6 Macdougal Alley have been sold by the estate of George E. Chisholm. The property, assessed at $295,000, was bought by Lloyd Hauser and J. P. Sloane, realty investors.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- There have been more cases of polio over the nation this year than last year and the number is continuing to rise. The Public Health Service said today that the proportion of paralytic cases also was greater this year.
Final steps were taken by New York State savings banks and other fiduciary institutions last week to arouse the memories of depositors with dormant accounts.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- A strike of half a million steel workers began Tuesday night in considerable part because a group of the most powerful industrial managers have come to believe in a relatively new economic theory -- the theory of "wage push" inflation.
MOSCOW, July 18 -- The Kremlin's official commentator charged bitterly today that the West German Government was trying to sabotage the foreign ministers' conference at Geneva.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI) -- The Kansas City Athletics made it two in a row with a 10-3 victory over the Washington Senators today but each team came out of the game poorer because of an injury to a key player.
Public, private and parochial schools in New York City were warned last week that they must eliminate all fire hazards by the fall term or face drastic action.
TWO thousand acres of the Adirondacks have been added to the open public hunting and fishing territory of the State by a paper lumber company.

A REVIEW of a recent novel about World War II compared its qualities to those of Arnold Zweig's "The Case of Sergeant Grischa." The reference had an archaic ring. People are still strongly aware of the accepted canon of World War I books -- Hemingway's "A Farewell to Arms," Cumming's "The Enormous Room," Remarque's "All Quiet on the Western Front," Dos Passos' "Three Soldiers."

Sumac comes to fruit, its spikes or berries already forecasting the war paint that will mark its leaves by September. Look closer, however, and you will see that those berries are still green -- odd little green seeds covered with maroon hair and clustered in characteristic spikes. And the shrub's leaves are still as green as any leaf in the woodland, green plumes reaching for their share of sunlight.

THIS being the season of madness (isn't that what they say mid-summer is?), there probably is no logical accounting for some of the odd things that have occurred recently. But being a logical fellow, we would like to have someone explain a couple of these madness manifestations, just to keep us from going mad ourself.

THESE two books are subtly designed to acquaint young listeners and readers with the lores of far-away places. "The Busiest Boy in Holland" tells of little Toontje, who lives on the island of Marken by the Zuider Zee, and his pet goldfish Albert. Toontje and his brothers were invited to help their uncle with his tulip farm in Amsterdam; in return they would be helped in making a float for the flower-festival parade.
OAK RIDGE, Tenn., July 18 -- A home here will be the scene Tuesday afternoon of tests that could have implications for every residence in the country.

EMPHASIZING the "pleasures of being human," a thirty-four-print exhibit on the theme of "TLC" (tender loving care) is on display until Aug. 2 in the East Nassau Medical Group building, a health center affiliated with the Health Insurance Plan of New York, at 350 South Broadway, Hicksville, L. I. Participating Long Island photographers are Arthur Leipzig, Edward Lettau and William Steinberg of Levittown. Others are from New York and Washington.

CARMEL, N. Y., July 18 -- Champion Crikora Commotion, imported miniature poodle owned by Mrs. J. Donald Duncan of New York and handled by Jane Kamp, captured the best-in-show award at the Putnam Kennel Club's event today. Cyrus Rickel of Fort Worth judged.
LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., July 18 -- The Circle F. poloists from Dallas, Text., scored a crushing 11-5 victory over Meadow Brook in the national twenty-goal final at the Piping Rock Club today.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- President Eisenhower, reversing his earlier opposition, has pledged White House cooperation in a forthcoming Congressional study of the Government's organization for reaching national policy decisions.

As the Yankees walked sadly off the field at the Stadium yesterday, they seemed to share a feeling in common with the majority in a crowd of 27,959. This was that Casey Stengel's Bombers finally had run up against the real thing.

CHICAGO, July 18 (UPI) -- Sabre, Roman Brotz' eighty-seven-foot yawl from Sheboygan, Wis., got away to a perfectly timed start today as the expected pace-setter for seventy-three yachts in the fifty-second annual Chicago-to-Mackinac Island race.

Last week the Navy launched its first nuclear-powered surface vessel, the guided-missile cruiser U. S. S. Long Beach, and on Tuesday the N. S. Savannah, the world's first nuclear-powered merchant ship, is to slide down the ways. These events mark the beginning of a new era in the atomic age, as revolutionary in its promise as the invention of the steamship 150 years ago.

ROME, July 18 -- The forty-day-old Italian seamen's strike was suspended today pending the resumption next week of negotiations between the ship-owners and the seven striking unions. The seamen were ordered back to work immediately.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI) -- The Senate Republican Policy Committee has distributed a sharp attack one of its key members has made on President Eisenhower's foreign aid program.

PITTSBURGH, July 18 -- The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation announced today that it would seek injunctions to restrain three locals of the striking steel union from what was described as illegal picketing.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- An expression common in the cornhog country is likely to be heard more often in the months ahead: "The cure for ten-cent hogs is ten-cent hogs."

BILTMORE Estate, the former home and vast acreage of George Vanderbilt in Asheville, N. C. has been selected by the Holly Society of America as one of eight holly arboretums. Such a selection is gratifying because of location of the 12,000-acre property and its long history of holly growing.

I wish to travel by boat on inland waterways from Alpine, N. J., to Traverse City, Mich., leaving Alpine the first week in August. My boat is a 40-foot Chris Craft Conqueror. I would greatly appreciate any information you could give me in connection with such a trip.

RABAT, Morocco, July 18 -As French-Moroccan tension rises over military movements in the Sahara border areas, Morocco's Premier will fly to Paris tomorrow to prepare the ground for the forthcoming talks between King Mohamed V and President Charles de Gaulle.

WHEN Samuel Gompers, who had guided the affairs of the American Federation of Labor for more than forty years, died in 1924, a loyal follower declared that "the stars by which we guided our ship have suddenly been blotted out."

CHICAGO, July 18 -- Robert J. Braidwood, Professor of PreHistory at the Oriental Institute, University of Chicago, left this week for Iran to head an expedition investigating "man's progression from a food gatherer to a food producer."

WASHINGTON, July 18 -With no official fanfare, two atomic cooperation agreements go into effect at midnight tonight. They portend a significant change in the defensive strategy and capability of the Western Alliance.

ONCE limited to professional cameras, the variablefocus or zoom lens has become an amateur trend of impressive proportions, one that promises to match, before long, the remarkable growth of the electric-eye principle of automatic exposure settings. The zoom lens is so called because it is continuousuly adjustable, as to focal length, by moving a lever or turning the lens barrel, from wide angle to normal to telephoto.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- A mounting multiplicity of favorite -son Democratic Presidential candidates now appears likely to make the 1960 Presidential preferential primaries less meaningful than they have been in recent campaigns.

RIVER FOREST, Ill., July 18 (UPI) -- Bernard Bartzen of Dallas gained the final round of the men's singles in the National Clay Courts tennis championships today. The defender beat South Africa's Abe Segal, 12 -- 10, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 1.

The zigzag tactics pursued by the Soviet Union in the cold war have kept the West constantly mystified about Soviet objectives. Last week zig followed zag quickly as the Russians kept up the pressure on the West in multiple ways.
The tide of public opinion is running against the Communist party in Iraq, political observers in Baghdad believe.

With Sammy Boulmetis doing an excellent job of keeping him on course, Bally Ache of the Edgehill Farm won the sixty-ninth Great American Stakes at Jamaica yesterday. The event of five and a half furlongs for 2-year-olds attracted a field of seven. The crowd of 33,151 made Tinkham Veal's Vital Force the favorite.
NORWICH, Conn., July 18 -- Members of the city's Public Works Department, who have been on strike for higher wages since July 2, acted today to correct a health condition.

HARTFORD, July 18 -- Connecticut's new law on minority representation for all public boards and commissions, elective or appointive, has brought up so many questions that the State Attorney General has been asked to interpret it in many respects.

MADRID, July 18 -- Spain, celebrating today the twenty-third anniversary of the rebellion against the Republican Government, is at a historic crossroads. Harried by inflation, the Franco regime is about to permit broad economic reforms while retaining the total political dictatorship.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -Bernard Goldfine offered to purge himself of contempt of Congress charges by answering questions posed by House investigators, but was turned down by the Department of Justice.

LOS ANGELES, July 16 -- California, perennially among the nation's top states in agricultural income, is heading toward record production this year in several of its highly diversified farm commodities.

AT noon on a recent, hot, sunny day, about 400 persons in full evening get-up were hustling through brisk Paris traffic into the Theatre des Champs-Elysees on shady Avenue de Matignon to hear "maestro" Yul Brynner conduct "The Stars and Stripes Forever."

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- A the import of some art works muesums, educational associations and collectors to end customs discrimination against the import of some art works is finally winning support in Congress.
SOME ancient murmur of tales of trials and roguery, told around an open fire, is echoed today in a program called "Famous Trials."

THIS is the author's eighth book in seven years -- not a bad record for an old party in his sixties who took to fiction after retiring from the diplomatic service. Paul Hyde Bonner's objective is to entertain rather than to elevate or educate, and in this respect he can give pointers to some of his more experienced confreres.

LONDON, July 18 -- A group of private citizens have banded together to provide legal counsel for an alien arrested by Scotland Yard Thursday in connection with the fatal shooting of a police detective Monday.

GRIM old Fort Sumter, standing on a shoal at the entrance to Charleston Harbor, is being definitively -- if only partly -- restored in preparation for the Civil War Centennial. Excavations recently completed there involved the removal of 18,000 cubic yards of fill, consisting of sand, rock, cement, brick and granite.

Marybeth Weston takes the arrival of the "pallid look" (white lipstick) as occasion for considering why we women use make-up ("And Now the 'Pallid' Look," July 5). She considers three explanations: to fool men, to impress other women, to give ourselves a "lift."

Intermittently for more than two years the Senate Committee on Improper Activities in the Labor or Management Field has looked into the affairs of James R. Hoffa and his International Brotherhood of Teamsters. Up to last week Mr. Hoffa had appeared before the committee thirteen times.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -The National Science Foundation reported today that Soviet scientific literature was becoming increasingly available to United States scientists. A detailed survey issued by the foundation listed 76 Soviet journals now available in English translations.
The Joint Distribution Committee, a major American agency aiding distressed Jews abroad, assisted more than 200,000 men, women and children last year, the organization reported yesterday.

The United Steelworkers of America, with 500,000 members in basic steel mills, iron ore mines, Great Lakes ore carriers and other operations affected by the stoppage. I have noticed that one's reaction to the film version of "Lady Chatterley's Lover" is likely to be influenced to an unusually strong degree by which of the protagonists one unconsciously identifies with while seeing it -- especially the male protagonists.

THERE are times when it seems that the simultaneous arrival of original cast recordings of Broadway musicals and the wellrounded, dramatically valid approach to these musicals may have been a mixed blessing. It will be remembered that "Oklahoma!" started both trends -this first Rodgers and Hammerstein collaboration provided the first full-dress original cast recording and pointed the way toward the new musical of the Forties and Fifties.
BOSTON, July 18 -- The Cleveland Indians scored four runs in the thirteenth inning today and gained a 7-5 victory over the Red Sox.

PHLOX come in so many sizes, shapes, colors and cultural preferences, at least one kind can be included in every garden. They may hug the ground on mat-forming plants only four inches high or carry immense heads of color four feet in the air.

ST. LOUIS, July 18 (UPI) -- Ken Boyer's ninth-inning two-out single scored Joe Cunningham from second base with the winning run tonight as the St. Louis Cardinals scored a 6-5 victory over the Milwaukee Braves. The Braves dropped their fifth straight game.
Federal maritime authorities and other Government agencies are preparing long-range plans to ease the impact of the atomic ship Savannah on the rest of the world.

Although the Interstate Commerce Commission has vehemently rejected the contention of one of its examiners that the passenger train will have become extinct by 1970, too many signs force us to fear that his doleful prediction may be borne out.
The price of raw sugar destined to countries other than the United States is at the lowest level since quotations were suspended in 1941.

A yield of some 14,500,000 bales from this year's cotton crop seems in prospect if conditions throughout the Cotton Belt remain fairly favorable for the rest of the growing season. Although such a yield would be much larger than the 11,512,000 bales produced last year and the abnormally small crop of 10,964,000 in 1957, it would be far below the record production of almost 19,000,000 bales in 1937.
Summertime, 1959, and the living is good on the American farm.

Moderation as a Virginia school of political thought won a victory at the polls in Virginia's Democratic primary last week.
