HAVANA, July 18 -- The revolutionary Government of Dr. Fidel Castro met tonight and resolved to exhort him to resume his role as Premier. The Government reaffirmed its refusal to accept his resignation.
BALBOA, C. Z., July 18 -Discovery of two bats dying of rabies in the Canal Zone has led to a survey by health officers and veterinarians. Until recently the Isthmus has been rabies-free.
Forty-six volumes of the works of Walt Whitman were presented to the Yeshiva University Graduate School by Charles E. Feinberg last week. Many are first editions with autographs of Whitman.
NEWTOWN, Conn., July 18 -This town has been under zoning restrictions for less than a month, but vigorous efforts are already under way to end or modify the regulations.

The Arabian American Oil Company is wholly owned by four American companies -- Standard of California, Texaco, Standard of New Jersey and Socony Mobil. Its principal asset is an exclusive agreement with King Saud of Saudi Arabia under which it exploits that country's vast oil reserves, sharing its profits with the Saudis on a 50-50 basis.

NEWPORT, R. I. PERHAPS the most ambitious attempt ever made at delineating a cross-section of the nation's folk music took place last weekend. There have been regional events for many years, but the program that sailed into Newport was a full-masted craft with a cargo from all over the country.
CONAKRY, Guinea, July 9 -Notes from a correspondent's notebook:

LASHED to a spar, 14-year-old Hans is tossed, bruised and battered by the sea, on to a lonely shore. So begins this five-year odyssey of a Dutch boy in the savage jungles of seven-teenth-century Ceylon. Slowly and painfully Hans learns how to survive in a hostile environment.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -One of the world's most efficient international fire brigades moved swiftly this week to hose down another in the series of explosions that have been keeping the countries bordering the Caribbean in a state of anxiety for the last several years.

TANGIER -- The reputations of cities are as individual as those of prima donnas, and can be just as subject to alteration practically without general notice. I did not realize this when I set out, this summer, to revisit Tangier, once so notorious, lying as it does at such a potentially busy crossroad of internationalism and intrigue, on the northern rim of Morocco, just beside the Strait of Gibraltar.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 18 (AP) -- Major Diaz said today that the resignation of President Urrutia "means that communism will have complete control of the country."
RIVERHEAD, L. I., July 18 -- Long Island farmers, seeking to recoup losses suffered in marketing their bumper 1958 potato crop, will start harvesting early potatoes next week.

" IN politics there are some men who will snipe at you with a rifle, one shot at a time," an Israeli officeholder once said, "but not Ben-Gurion. He is an artilleryman. He brings all his big guns down on you at once. And the devastating thing is that he has the uncanny ability to hit a target so far in the distance that none of us can see it at the time."
Good fortune -- mazel tov -finally caught up with a prospective Israeli bride last Wednesday, the day that seventy-seven members of the wedding departed for Israel without her.
THE professional theatre in Ireland is confined to the two largest cities -- Dublin and Belfast.

BRITISH film-makers of the first rank -- two knights and a most uncommon commoner -- have combined their skills in "Our Man in Havana," a story about an English representative of an Anglo-American vacuum cleaner company caught up in a mysterious spy ring.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 18 -- More boats sailed on Long Island Sound today than ever had sailed on that yacht-scarred piece of water before. There were 442 of them for the begining of the Larchmont Yacht Club's sixty-first annual race week. The highest previous total had been four boats fewer two years ago.

Vice President Richard M. Nixon departs for Moscow this week, thus beginning the first American participation in the exchange of Very Important Persons that has already brought Anastas I. Mikoyan and Frol R. Kozlov, the two Soviet First Deputy Premiers, to these shores.

RUIDOSO, N. M., July 18 (AP) -- Gov. Earl K. Long of Louisiana stalked out of the Ruidoso Downs Race Track today before the program had ended. He complained that he had been manhandled by a New Mexico sheriff.
YONKERS, July 18 -- Wendy Stone of Oyster Bay, L. I., seeded second, won the Eastern girls' tennis championship from Sally Wilson, Scarsdale, N. Y., at the Racquet Club on Park Hill today.

RIDGEFIELD, Conn., July 18 -- Ridgefield's first horse show in forty-four years, a revival sponsored by local civic organizations and equestrian enthusiasts in neighboring communities of Fairfield and Westchester Counties, will be held on Aug. 1 and 2.

TRENTON, N. J., July 18 (AP) -- The Banking and Insurance Department reported this week that deposits in New Jersey's ninety - four state banks and twenty-one savings banks had dropped $44,115,000 since June, 1958.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 18 (Reuters) -- Premier Khrushchev will appear to the West in a new aspect -- that of family man -- when he begins a tour of Scandinavia next month. A recent announcement in Stockholm confirmed that he would be accompanied by his wife and two daughters.
LAKE PLACID, N. Y., July 18 (AP) -- Mrs. Henry Nevil of Cooperstown, N. Y., defeated Mrs. Philip Allen of Syracuse, 6 and 4, today and kept her New York State women's amateur championship.
Richard Bryce has been appointed treasurer and Donald R. Jackson has been named to succeed him as first assistant treasurerof Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation.

WEST GERMANY scheduled for release yesterday a 20-pfennigs violet, yellow and black stamp which the postal administration says illustrates the "Heligen Rocks" (Holy Tunic). The cathedral at Trier, Germany, claims to have the tunic -- Christ's seamless garment for which soldiers cast lots at the Crucifixion -- in its possession and said that it would be placed on exhibition from today through Sept. 19.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., July 18 --The battle-tested Forty-second Infantry Division celebrated its forty-second anniversary today. Its new commander in chief, a civilian named Rockefeller, cut the birthday cake.
A new era of maritime life and the way to a continued usefulness has been opened to the famous T-2 type of tanker -- the floating pipelines of World War II.
OMAHA, July 18 (AP) -There will be a new Miss Omaha in the Miss Nebraska contest because 18-year-old Mary Jean Belitz is not going to jeopardize her Roman Catholic college education.

MEXICO CITY, July 18 -- They carried Mario Llamas from the Chapaultepec Tennis Stadium in triumph this evening after he had given Mexico an even split of the opening two Davis Cup singles matches with Australia in the first round of the American zone.

IN Springfield, Ill., a hundred years ago this summer, Abraham Lincoln was shyly declaring that he did not possess the slightest qualification for the Presidency. And in Maryland, a century ago this past Fourth of July, John Brown was deciding to lease the Kennedy Farm which, located about five miles from Harper's Ferry, seemed ideal as a base for the raid the half-crazed, old abolitionist contemplated.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI) -- The Air Force said today that its bases were ready at any time to receive commercial airliners in distress. No change in regulations is required.

OLYMPIC NATIONAL PARK, Wash. -- Rain forests, with all their tropical associations of impenetrable, tangled undergrowth and tremendously heavy downpours, are proving to be one of the more intriguing attractions for the crowds of summer visitors who are now sweeping over the roads and trails of this fifth largest of the twenty-nine national parks.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -James Riddle Hoffa's sassy performance before the McClellan committee this week raised a question in many minds as to why the teamster's chief was recalled. Were the fresh disclosures worth the cost in damage to Senate prestige and authority?

POZNAN, Poland, July 18 -"Khrush-chev, Khrush-chev," the crowd in the hall chanted. The Soviet Premier shook his hands over his head boxer-style and beamed delightedly. Near him on the platform, a squarejawed Pole clapped and smiled.

IN "Praise a Fine Day," Sigrid de Lima manages to come up with a fresh treatment of the by now somewhat shopworn theme of innocents abroad. Told in the first person, her story recounts a bizarre episode in the life of a rootless young American artist stranded in Rome.

The first U. S. atomic energy law, adopted in 1946, barred the sharing of any nuclear information with other countries. Gradually Congress has relaxed the secrecy provision, and last year it authorized the Government, with certain restrictions, to give nuclear information of direct military value to the United States' allies.
A socially prominent business man was found dead in his apartment yesterday in what the police described as an apparent suicide.

THE oddest discovery to be made in rereading the novels of Dorothy L. Sayers, as Harper Brothers revive them, is their surprising variations in quality. Memory suggests a fairly even standard of professional skill; actually some of the novels are very nearly as poor as others are distinguished -- a contrast particularly striking in the latest pair: HAVE HIS CARCASE (Harper, $3.95) and MURDER MUST ADVERTISE (Harper, $3.50).

ROME, July 15 -- Policemen here are being told to treat foreigners as welcome guests, but not to coddle them. Visitors from abroad have the same duty as Italians to observe the laws, the new instructions point out.
GLENS FALLS, N. Y., July 18 -- A thousand possesions, the accumulation of sixty years and more, are being sold at auction here on the estate of a strange old widow who died last year.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 18 -- President Sukarno has named a young officer from navy headquarters here as the Indonesian Navy's acting chief of staff, replacing Vice Admiral Subijakto, the Ministry of Information announced tonight.

ASCOT, England, July 18 (AP) -- Alcide took the lead with less than an eighth of a mile to travel and held off a strong challenge by Gladness in capturing the King George VI and Queen Elizabeth Stakes today.

GENEVA, July 18 -- The dialogue in the foreign ministers' conference here is conducted mainly by the Big Four -- the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union. It is, in a sense, the future of the world they are talking about. But, specifically, it is the future of Germany.
IT is said that the most sophisticated street in the world is Rome's Via Veneto, a tree-lined promenade that is flanked by expensive hotels, sidewalk cafes, and boulevardiers whose eyes miss nothing.

THE wide range of modern art in themes, approaches and techniques is very well exemplified in the newly opened exhibition of recently acquired drawings and water-colors at the Museum of Modern Art. Work by thirty-four artists of twelve nations is included in the show.

The world's second largest telescope, the 120-inch reflector of the University of California's Lick Observatory, was dedicated last week on Mount Hamilton, a 4,200-foot mountain south of Berkeley. The Lick mirror is second only to the 200-inch Hale Telescope on Mount Palomar, and replaces the 100-inch telescope atop Mount Wilson as the second largest.

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 18 (UPI) -- An economic "position paper" that may be cited in the Presidential campaign next year was drafteed here today by Democrats.
MEXICO CITY, July 18 -- Another attempt to establish diplomatic relations between Mexico and Franco Spain apparently has failed.
LIMA, Peru, July 18 -- The office of President Manuel Prado y Ugarteche announced tonight the composition of a new Cabinet, headed by Dr. Pedro G. Beltran.

CHICAGO, July 18 -- Corn belt experts are asking a lot of questions about the Department of Agriculture's prediction that the corn crop this year would be the largest in United States history.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- A Senate subcommitee complained today that the nation's space program was being handicapped by the Administration's failure to develop a "comprehensive" project for space research.

PITTSBURGH, July 18 -- Willie Mays' third straight hit -- a two-run homer in the eighth inning -- propelled the league-leading San Francisco Giants to a 4-3 triumph today over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

ISLAND BEACH, N. J. -- A 2,200-acre strip of natural, untrammeled oceanfront -- one of the few remaining untouched barrier beaches on the Eastern seaboard -- has been partly opened to bathers here for the last few weeks, and so far "the experiment is proving very successful," according to the state's conservationists.

ALTHOUGH winter temperatures may drop to below 70 and much of the soil is frozen permanently into bedrock, the most popular hobby in Alaska is gardening. It is more than a hobby. With imported foods priced to include the freight from Seattle, Wash., many families have found a garden an effective way to defeat Alaska's high cost of living.
THE American Dance Festival at Connecticut College in New London is getting the programs in hand for its twelfth annual session, which will consist of five performances, Aug. 13 to 16.

The six and a half months since Fidel Castro, 32, took power in Cuba have been months of ferment for his own country and for the whole Caribbean area. Last week the tumultous events that have been taking place in Cuba were climaxed by dramatic changes in Havana.

Congratulations to A. H. Raskin on his full, perceptive and unbiased reports in The New York Times of the events which led to the present steel strike. Instead of getting down to businesslike negotiation, the parties have been engaged in what Mr. Raskin calls "post office bargaining."

Your feature on the seventy-fifth birthday of the Statue of Liberty, "Saga of a Lady of Liberty" (July 5) was a welcome reminder that our Statue of Liberty was born out of the inspiration of a French liberal, Edouard de Laboulaye and the talent of a young French sculptor, Frederic Auguste Bartholdi.
EAST WILLISTON, L. I., July 18 -- Art Silvestrone, who received a special invitation to compete in the event, gained the final of the Long Island amateur golf championship today.

BALTIMORE, July 17 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers, scoring once without the benefit of either of their two hits off Hoyt Wilhelm, salvaged the second game of a double-header and ended a six-game losing streak tonight by beating the Baltimore Orioles, 2-0.

BONN, Germany, July 18 (UPI) -- The White House has appealed to Chancellor Konrad Adenauer to stop quarreling with Britain and close Western ranks in the face of Soviet threats, German official sources said today.

FOR THIS WEEK: Rake up and burn fallen oak leaves browned by tunneling leaf miners. This will reduce infestation next spring. . . . Brown spots in lawns containing bent and fescue grasses could be caused by chinch bugs. Part the grass. If small black bugs with white wings are found use dieldrin or chlordane for control. . . .

WASHINGTON, July 18 -Fewer primaries, with more favorite sons, face contenders for the 1960 Democratic Presidential nomination.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- A four-year examination of this city's transportation needs has produced recommendations for establishment of an interstate transit authority and a system of subways, suburban railroads, express buses, freeways and parking facilities.

THE rare and dramatic bid called the grand slam force was original with the late Ely Culbertson in 1936, or perhaps some time late in 1935. It is not true, as is often said and sometimes written nowadays, that the bid was invented by this writer and A. Moyse Jr. and merely adopted by Mr. Culbertson. It was Ely Culbertson's own.

White -- have described the real or imaginary doings of King Arthur, that chieftain of mixed Roman and British parentage who had learned the art of war from the Romans and successfully fought the Saxon invaders.

SUMMER ushers in a host of chores for iris growers. July to mid-September is the time to divide and resold stock, as well as to plant new iris for bloom next summer. Since iris roots make their growth shortly after the flowering period, the tasks should be more early to give plants sufficient time to become well established before winter.

THE Empire State Music Festival has displayed a capacity for survival that should win the admiration of all people who like a good, game fighter. It has persisted when prudence dictated quitting. It has shaken off blows that should have been good for the full count. Here it is on its feet again, only an hour's easy ride from New York now, more chipper than ever.

WETHERSFIELD, Conn., July 18 (AP) -- Gene Littler cooled off his sizzling pace today, but managed to cling to a two-stroke lead in the $25,000 Insurance City open golf tournament. Littler had a 72 for a 54-hole total of 202.
KAMPALA, Uganda, July 10 -- At Pershing High School in Detroit, Mitch Biedul was a six-letter man.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, July 18 -- A game ranger and his African game scouts attempting to rescue wild animals from the rising waters of Lake Kariba were charged by enraged elephants. The elephants attacked the rescuers' boat and lashed it with their tusks.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- The Post Office and Justice Departments have teamed up for a widespread drive against the advance-fee racket, a bane of small business people reported to be taking $50,000,000 a year from its victims.
A Swiss divinity student attempting to make a pacifist speech created a stir during the intermission at last night's all-Gershwin concert at Lewisohn Stadium.

ROSTOCK, Germany, July 14 (Reuters) -- East German's new deep-sea harbor here, which is due to receive its first ship next May 1, will be able to handle between 25,000,000 and 30,000, 000 tons of cargo a year by 1965, a spokesman told reporters recently.

LOS ANGELES -- Each summer California communities, large and small, are overwhelmed with an urge to dramatize their individuality, even when they do not have much of it to dramatize. Municipal pageantry, to be sure, is a hallowed national tradition. In the East, the American Revolution often provides a handy commemorative peg; this year Henry Hudson and Samuel de Champlain are also doing heavy duty in that area.

IF all goes as scheduled in setting up the American National Exhibit in Moscow, young Russian visitors to that fair will be turned loose on Saturday to enjoy themselves in a playground of highly original design.

ANOTHER Hall of Fame is being planned for the city. This one will enshrine the memory of America's composers. If it materializes the way it is envisioned, it will really be a corridor of fame, for the site planned for it is the underground passageway that will run between Rockefeller Center and the new hotel that William Zeckendorf intends to build on the Avenue of the Americas between Fifty-second and Fifty-third Streets.
It might appear that aviation was engaging in a sort of technical one-upmanship with the public.

THE exchange that took place recently between Soviet First Deputy Premier Kozlov and Secretary of State Herter over the question of who paid for the American relief action during the Russian famine of 1921-22 suggests that few people now recall the detailed circumstances of this episode into which so much American interest and effort were poured at the time.

CARACAS, Venezuela, July 15 -- Twenty-two former members of the National Security Police under the Perez Jimenez dictatorship are being tried here on charges ranging from illegal arms-bearing to torturing and killing. Others have been brought to trial elsewhere in the country.

A subcommittee of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy met last week to consider President Eisenhower's request for $100,000,000 for the construction at Stanford University of a two-mile-long linear accelerator of atomic particles.

THIS short novel carries the young manhood of Jack Duluoz (for which read Jack Kerouac) in Lowell Mass., from the ordeal of latency, as revealed in the author's previous "Dr. Sax" to the joys of adolescence. But whereas "Dr. Sax" was a pretentious and unreadable farrago of childhood fantasyplay, "Maggie Cassidy" is it surprisingly simple and appealing tale of a young student's fumbling search for love among the high school set.

LAST year found a seventeenthcentury setting with Cavalier mistresses in farthingales the height of style for historical novels. This seems to be the year of the sixteenthcentury period piece where all courtiers are dashing lovers, all pirates, roistering adventurers, and all ladies worth a sonnet or two.

LINZ, Austria, July 18 -- The refugee camp clearance program is making steady progress in Austria as a result of the concerted efforts of the Austrian Government, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and the many voluntary agencies involved in the problem.

REDDING, Calif., July 18 -- Fifteen-year-old Becky Collins of Indianapolis swam to a world record for the 110-yard butterfly tonight in the Amateur Athletic Union's women's national outdoor championships. Her time was 1 minute 11.2 seconds.

LONDON, July 18 -- Aneurin Bevan today interpreted the split in the Labor party over nuclear disarmament policy as evidence of the party's concern with "the most dangerous period in the history of mankind."
Ways of predicting the severity and duration of arthritic attacks are being sought in a large-scale research project here.

A FEW of the newest tall bearded iris can be ordered now for a spectacular display next spring. These regal iris, aptly called "orchids of the garden," are best planted from late July through early August.
DETROIT, July 18 -- A major step toward the elimination of duplicate services by the City of Detroit and Wayne County is expected July 30.

IT is not necessary to indite a long tribute to Ernest Newman, who died less than a fortnight ago. His writings speak more eloquently for him than anyone else can hope to do, and fortunately, there is an abundance of them in print.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The slow drift of the Geneva conference toward a summit meeting has the quality, as seen from Washington, of a confused and rather bad midsummer night's dream. In the minds of most officials here the issues which drew the Big Four foreign ministers to Geneva on May 11 have become blurred by time and half-read verbiage.

THE substance of Isabella Holt's new novel is the marriage of Olive Hume and Brian Pell. Behind the narrative there is a panoramic background of American life and topical events from the late Nineteen Twenties up to the recent swarm of Congressional investigating committees.

IN this English novel of patriotic reminiscence by Warren Tute, the pivot of the tale is Sir Giles Fortin, bachelor celebrity of heroic exploit among the Arabs and flower of the imperial system. He arrives in June, 1939, just in the nick, to take over as Governor of complacent Gibraltar.

What Now for Steel? Since World War II production of the nation's basic manufacturing commodity -- steel -- has been halted six times by general strikes. The first five ranged in duration from twelve hours (in 1955) to fifty-eight days (in 1952) and repsented an estimated total loss of 45.8 million tons of steel and $850 million in wages.
MELBOURNE, Australia, July 18 (Reuters) -- What attractions does Australia have to lure immigrants here from the United States?
TOKYO, July 18 -- Two Japanese scientists have announced that tea can serve as an antidote to the effects of strontium 90, a harmful isotopic product of radioactive fall-out.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, July 18 -- Gen. Fulgencio Batista, Cuba's former dictator, indignantly denied today that he tried to escape from the Dominican Republic Thursday to enter the United States illegally.
A timely warning on the care and handling of passports has been issued by the Passport Office in Washington, through the American Express Travel Service.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI) -- Assistant Secretary of State J. Graham Parsons said today that Communist China was failing to achieve its economic goals despite organization of "slave labor" into a "barbaric commune system."
GENEVA, July 18 -- The Western powers decided today to risk a crisis in the foreign ministers' conference by rejecting the Soviet terms for dealing with the German problem.

HOLLYWOOD, as has been reported more than once, is closely attuned to the activities of stage directors on and off Broadway. This is especially true of Jose Quintero, whose youth belies an enviable record that includes "Long Day's Journey Into Night," "The Iceman Cometh" and the current off-Broadway revival of "Our Town."

FORMULA for decorating a small apartment: Plan a budget and buy a yardstick. With the inches and dollars always in mind, rooms can be divided and decorated to serve many needs without inducing claustrophobia or breaking the bank.
MINEOLA, L. I., July 18 -The ravages of Dutch elm disease have reached such a point that authorities have started a program to prevent the extinction of elm trees in Nassau County.
HERE is a closer for storm and screen doors which uses a sealed hydraulic unit rather than the usual air chamber. It operates on the same principle as a heavy-duty, commercial type door closer.

AINTREE, England, July 18 -- Jack Brabham of Australia, driving his Cooper Climax on dangerously thin tires, won the 225-mile British Grand Prix today despite a record-shattering performance by Britain's Stirling Moss.

WE are at the end, or very nearly the end of an age. All over the globe, in the tropics as well as the temperate and arctic zones, the animal life of the world is making a final hopeless stand against the rushing inroads of modern technology.

MILWAUKEE, Wis. -- To the New York vacationist driving west to the Dakota Black Hills, Yellowstone or the Pacific Northwest, Lake Michigan is the great barrier. The quickest way around it is via the big turnpikes to Chicago, then up through northern Illinois and Wisconsin.
PHILADELPHIA, July 18 (AP) -- Two British and two American scientists have been named 1959 winners of John Scott Awards for developing inventions for the benefit of mankind.
A new way of dividing the classes on a liner has been used in the new Holland-America liner Rotterdam.
A leading Methodist monthly will caution churchgoers in its August issue to avoid "any appeal to or from religion" in the 1960 Presidential election.
I would like to suggest a course of action in the steel dispute taking into account the broader issues involved.

A BUSINESS associate of Jack Benny said last week that Harry S. Truman had agreed to make a "guest star" appearance on the comedian's television show next fall. Presumably the former President would be reciprocating for Mr. Benny's fiddling appearance last year at a Kansas City concert that Mr. Truman arranged in an effort to get the orchestra out of debt.

WHITEHORSE, Yukon Territory, July 18 -- (UPI) -- The physician for Queen Elizabeth issued a medical report tonight saying the 33-year-old sovereign was run down physically by the strain of her function-packed trip across Canada.

SOME of the admirers of modern poetry claim that in bulk or collectively it is the greatest body of poetry in the English language. This may or may not be so, but "Modern Verse in English," edited by Lord David Cecil and Allen Tate, provides the poems on which a judgment, either way, can be passed.

THE indignation that the ideas of Sigmund Freud stirred up when they were new has now almost disappeared. Within two decades of his death, we have grown accustomed to his image of man -- an image that differs vastly from the daytime image we hold of ourselves as rational and independent masters of our selves.
Last Sunday, in your paper. I read a letter from Margaret Sheridan who scolded Bosley Crowther for writing probably one of his finest articles (July 5).

GARDENERS who think of gladiolus only as spikes of pale pink blooms can have their minds pleasantly changed by visiting a gladiolus show. Starting this week until mid-September there will be a succession of color-filled shows devoted to this spectacular flower.
MANILA, July 18 -- Ambassador Charles E. Bohlen confirmed today that he had received a wireless message from Washington.

The Cubans are a dramatic people and Fidel Castro is their leading actor. The process of resolving a crisis within the Government has now been accomplished with an extraordinary exhibition of histrionics.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon has been engaged in an intensive program of study to prepare himself for his coming trip to the Soviet Union, an informed source disclosed today.
HONOLULU, July 18 -- "The Great Mahele," the land reform instituted by King Kamehameha 3d in 1848, became the outstanding political issue this week in Hawaii's first state election campaign.

YONKERS, July 18 -- The mighty Speedy Pick, the 9-to-20 choice, suffered defeat in the $15,000 Monitor Pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight. A tremendous closing burst by Widower Creed beat the choice by a half length.
Edgar Alexander, in his left published July 12 regarding Kon Adenauer's views, did a nice job trying to defend his name.

GENEVA, July 18 -- The foreign ministers' meeting here has made some progress in at least one direction. It has brought the Western ministers closer together. It has shown them that they can negotiate effectively with one another, if not with the Russians.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People pledged its resources yesterday to a drive to increase the voting opportunities of Negroes in the South in the 1960 Presidential election.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 18 -- An example of economic cooperation intended to impress the six members of the European common market will be set forth here next week.

STE. MAXIME, Var, France -- The French Riviera having become a summer playground for many thousands of visitors from many lands and its beaches notable attractions, prospective sojourned in this area should know what to expect in the way of wind and surf.
Compromise legislation that would give banks a new chance to increase earnings was passed by Congress and sent to the White House last week.

TO find a Hollywood director filming "Suddenly Last Summer," a Tennessee Williams play, for an American producer in the luxuriant garden of a New Orleans mansion with three Hollywood stars is not remarkable.

A LONG time had passed -- almost two hundred and fifty years -- before New Mexico left Spanish dominion and become one of the United States in 1846. And during that time a strong regional culture, partaking both of Spanish tradition and local Indian mores, had sunk its roots deep into the breathtaking landscape.
PHILADELPHIA, July 18 -- "Rain we do not mind," said Gavril Korobkov in his precise English earlier in the week, "all we want is for it to be cool."

An authorized history of the United States Steel Corporation published several years ago asserted "the right of free men to form unions of their own choosing for the purpose of collective bargaining." Nothing in the current steel strike, we may presume, has changed that position. The steel companies have rejected the proposals of the United Steelworkers of America, but they have not questioned the right of the steelworkers to combine and to make proposals.

A survey of Federal statistics cast doubt yesterday on the popular belief that this city is a high-wage center for factory workers. The survey showed that New York ranked next to last in wage position among the twenty United States cities with a factory population of more than 100,000.
Spurred by tremendous increases in outdoor eating and recreation, manufacturers of paper cups and plates are chalking up their best sales year in history.

Memorandum to marketing executives: if your company is planning a centennial celebration, start working on the event when the organization reaches the age of ninety-seven.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -Alaska's 7,600-foot Knife Peak, the highest of the Katmai National Monument, has been named for its explorer, Dr. Robert F. Origgs.

CIRCUMSTANTIAL evidence is the villain in this didactic little tale of two American soldiers serving time in a prison barracks for being A. W. O. L. One of the men, Gillespie, has broken a framed family photograph while assigned to clean the colonel's quarters.

PHILADELPHIA -- Resort business in the choice vacation spots of the Third Federal Reserve District, which takes in the beaches of southern New Jersey, the coastal areas of Delaware and the scenic mountain playgrounds of Pennsylvania, is booming.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18 -- The Soviet team that is competing against United States track and field athletes has produced at least one first-class prankster, Abram Krivosheyev of Odessa. He's the only Jew on the team and he is one of the two Russian hopes in the 800-meter run.

BRIGHT speckled yellow-orange blossoms make the native field lily or Canada lily (Lilium canadense) one of our most charming summer wild flowers. It is found in rich meadows and marshes, or occasionally along sunny country roadsides.

The tempo of fall buying increased last week. Resident buying offices reported that reorders were received in greater numbers while heavy selling centered on transitional items and summer promotional merchandise.
CAIRO, July 18 -- The United Arab Republic is expected to resume diplomatic relations soon with Tunisia and Jordan.

AMERICAN manufacturers of radio and television receivers traditionally have never experienced much serious competition from abroad. Usually there has been only a trickle of imports from England or West Germany and, to judge from the current exhibition of Russian sets at the Coliseum, the Soviet Union does not yet pose a serious challenge.

ADMIRERS of the work of Peter De Vries (and this reviewer is a stanch one) may find the hilarity in his new book not only rather forced, even for him, but a bit warmed over. In fact, his large and dedicated audience may feel itself somewhat in the role of a spouse gallantly enduring the retelling of a too-familiar joke.

What may or may not have been the biggest thing ever hauled up the side of a building was gingerly pulled up yesterday into the eleventh floor of the new building the Chase Manhattan Bank is erecting at William and Cedar Streets.
BROOKLINE, Mass., July 18 -- A dispute has arisen among members of the Brookline Redevelopment Authority over the choice of a developer for a $12,000,000 urban renewal project in this Boston suburb.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, July 18 -The port strike here, which began June 24 and later spread to clerical workers in commercial, shipping and engineering concerns, and hotels and shops, was called off tonight.
BLOOMFIELD, N. J., July 18 -- Lou Barbaro turned in two straight sub-par rounds today and won the thirty-ninth annual New Jersey Golf Association open golf tournament by two strokes.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 18 (UPI) -- Noble Noor, a 29-1 shot, me running down the stretch day to capture the first running of the $163,850 Juvenile championship Stakes for 2-year-olds by a half length at Hollywood Park.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- The House Interior Committee adopted this week a resolution declaring the maintenance and development of a stable domestic mining and mineral industry to be essential to national security.
Within recent months the number of new drugs introduced to curb the appetite as an aid in weight reduction has almost reached the rate at which new tranquilizers appeared a few years go.
For the second time in the history of the Port of New York monthly Customs revenues surpassed the $50,000,000 mark last month.
NEW DELHI, India, July 18 -- The entire economy of Jammu and Kashmir state is reported to have virtually collapsed as a result of disastrous floods that struck the territory early this month.

BUFFALO, July 18 (AP) -Canada's Department of Transport has "taken under advisement" a proposal to build a new canal between Port Maitland on Lake Erie and Jordan Harbor on Lake Ontario. The Buffalo Evening News reported today.
New York, which became in 1950 the first state to prohibit discrimination in public and publicly aided housing, may become in 1960 the fifth to extend the ban to unaided private housing
NEW DELHI, India, July 18 -- An agreement with a British company to produce turbo-prop transport planes in India for the Indian Air Force has been criticized in some quarters here.
WATERTOWN, N. Y., July 18 -- The Rockefeller Administration is studying the advisability of a compulsory safety education program for private airplane pilots.

CHICAGO, July 18 (UPI) -Lar Daly, perennial candidate for public office, said today he had asked the National Broadcasting Company for equal time to match that given Senator Hubert H. Humphrey on the network's "Today" television show.

" FABULOUS" is an overworked word, but as description of Belle Livingstone's memoirs it is understatement. For a number of years bankers have railed at inequities in the system of calculating reserve requirements for member banks of the Federal Reserve System. Last week Congress passed and sent to the President a measure designed to correct these inequities.

BUENOS AIRES, July 18 -In major South American countries far from the Caribbean and its problems, Fidel Castro is viewed with tolerance and even sympathy, but not as the champion of a new order for Latin America.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -The Communist organizers of the World Youth Festival to be held in Vienna this summer have encountered unexpected difficulties in promoting the affair among young people in many newly independent countries.

HONG KONG, July 18 -- As the Chinese Communists near the tenth anniversary, Oct. 1, of their rule over a fourth of the earth's population, they also face a period of testing that might be their sternest trial in the decade of power.

BERLIN, July 18 -- The West Berlin city government plans to propose to the foreign ministers' conference at Geneva the establishment of an "inter-administrative East-West commission" to deal with the question of free access to West Berlin and other issues between East and West Germany, a spokesman said today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18 -- Powerful Parry O'Brien broke his listed world record for the shot-put today as the United States took a 59-47 lead over the Soviet Union at the half-way point of their track and field match.
Forty members of the Irish National Teachers Organization, embracing all thirty-two counties in Ireland, arrived last week to study teaching methods in several Eastern cities.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., July 18 (AP) -- A secret development in American rocket and missile propellants was disclosed today.

MANY contemporary houses are designed with exterior siding and trim made of redwood, cedar or knotty pine. To maintain the warm, natural beauty of these woods, the surface is usually coated with some sort of "natural" finish, rather than with an opaque paint.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18 -- The Philadelphia Phillies chased Danny McDevitt with a five-run outburst in the fourth inning, including Ed Bouchee's two-run homer, to defeat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 5 -- 2, behind Don Cardwell's four-hitter today.
PHILADELPHIA, July 18 -"Sure I thought I'd win over Connolly, but it was darned hot out there in the field."
DUBLIN, July 8 -- Irish golf and Irish golfers are on the up-beat this summer, with top-quality performances accelerating the tempo.

WINTER had come upon the world. The men out yonder, in the interminable trenches and dugouts that war had made, watched drearily and grimly the beginning of yet another winter of war, drew gloves over their numbed fingers, piled wood into their stoves, and stamped savagely through the slush that squelched about their feet.

ABOARD H. M. S. VICTORIOUS, at Sea, July 17 -- A new three - dimensional air defense radar, the first of its kind in the world, has been used with remarkable effectiveness during a NATO training exercise in the Atlantic Ocean.
DETROIT, July 18 -- A study committee appointed by Mayor Louis C. Miriani has rejected plans for a $255,700,000 monorail system for Detroit as impractical "at this time."

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 18 -- Proposed lowering of the minimum voting age from 21 to 18 will be the chief issue at a convention opening here Tuesday to consider possible changes in the Tennessee Constitution.

DETROIT, July 18 -- Michigan moved deeper into the new fiscal year this week, still operating on a hand-to-mouth basis and without a solution to the critical fiscal problems that have beset the Legislature since Jan. 14.

THE Nan Patterson Case is an unsolved murder trial mystery that has fascinated lawyers, judges, journalists and ordinary folk who are old enough to remember the event. The story of the Florodora Sextet chorus girl who was tried three times but never convicted of the charge of shooting to death her married lover made national news headlines in 1904 and 1905.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI) -- Hal Smith's lead-off home run in the tenth inning gave the Kansas City Athletics a 6-5 victory over the Washington Senators in the second game of a double-header today.

Jackson, Democrat from the State of Washington, believes that today's "fundamental issue is whether a free society can so organize its human and material resources as to outthink, outplan and outperform totalitarianism.'' The International Finance Corporation announced yesterday a commitment to invest $300,000 of United States funds in the Concrete Products and Aggregate Company, Ltd., to expand and diversify its operations.

French Investing Company has purchased the northeast corner of Second Avenue and Fortieth Street and now controls the entire block bounded by Second and First Avenues and Fortieth and Forty - first Streets, with the exception of a parcel at the southeast corner of Second Avenue and Forty-first Street, in Tudor City.

VANCOUVER, B. C., July 19 -- The production of "Orpheus and Euridice," which was presented at the Vancouver International Festival last night, was of major league caliber. The charcoal broiler has been taken out of the basement and set up in the back yard for the rest of the summer. Additional briquets have been purchased, another can of fuel is on hand and the furnishings necessary for setting the scene have been painted and put in place.

PHILADELPHIA, July 19 -- The Russians had hoped that the heat wave would break today. It did. A violent thunderstorm not only swept away the heat, but it virtually swept away the international track meet between the Soviet Union and the United States late this afternoon. With four events still uncompleted, lightning danced off the ramparts of Franklin Field, thunder caromed off the stands and a deluge doused just and unjust alike.

MEXICO CITY, July 19 -- Mexico's hopes of achieving its most notable Davis Cup conquest virtually vanished today with its loss of the doubles tennis match to Australia in the first round of the American Zone.

United Funds, Inc., reported yesterday that its four domestic funds had grown at a record rate during the first six months. Assets increased by $115,717,729 during the first half to $675,369,466. This was 58.3 per cent higher than the $426,691,071 reported a year earlier.

LONDON, July 17 -- Britain is prospering and the outlook for further economic expansion is good. The present business and industrial situation admittedly is somewhat mixed with some segments forging ahead and others lagging. But the over-all picture is far better than it was even a year ago.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI) -- Senator John Marshall Butler, Republican of Maryland, said today the "equal time" provision of broadcasting law "could tie stations and networks hand, foot and throat" in their efforts to cover political news.
Mayor Wagner declared yesterday that one of the steps he planned to restore harmony within his Committee on Slum Clearance was to "pull up the reins" on Robert Moses, its chairman.

Arthur G. Cohen and Zack Osias, realty investors and builders, have purchased the northwest corner of Third Avenue and Fiftieth Street from Harry Horwitz. They are studying plans to build an apartment house or an office building.

ALLIANCE, Ohio. July 19 (UPI) -- Blonde Mickey Wright, of San Diego, rallied from a 7-stroke deficit today and won the $12,500 Alliance international golf tournament for women. The long-hitting Miss Wright totaled 291, 7 strokes over par.

George Seewagen Jr. of Bayside, Queens, successfully defended the boys' 13 years division singles title in the Eastern junior and boys tennis championships yesterday. He defeated Robert Goeltz of Bethesda, Md., 6 -- 1, 6 -- 4, at the West Side Club, Forest Hills, Queens.

"I Belong to Zozo," Preston Sturges' new farce-comedy with a Gallic flavor, is a Broadway prospect for the 1959-60 season. The author will direct the attraction, of which Mark Kroll is the sponsor.

BOSTON, July 19 (UPI) -- The Boston Red Sox staged a whirlwind finish for a 6-5 victory over the Indians today in the first game of a double-header. But they lost their chance for a rally m the second game because a thunderstorm ended the game at eight inings and gave a 5-3 victory to Cleveland.

Fire Department and Port Authority officials agreed yesterday that they would meet today in a more cordial atmosphere to resolve the week-old dispute of who has final jurisdiction at airport emergencies.

SAINT-JEAN-DE-MAURIENNE, France, July 19 (Reuters) -- Nine men and five women, in city clothes and without equipment of any kind, settled down tonight to spend forty-eight hours 9,900 feet up in the snows of the French Alps.

HAMBURG, Germany, July 17 -- The man in the street has started to invest in the stock market here and in other German financial centers for the first time in history. At the same time American speculators have entered the market.
SANOQUELLI, Liberia, July 19 -- The three independent states of West Africa proposed today that a conference be held next year to set up a "community of African states."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 19 (UPI) -- The Peiping correspondent of the Yugoslav Communist newspaper Borba reported today that thousands of Chinese industrial enterprises founded this year were being closed, and that "millions" of workers were being transferred from industry to agriculture.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The Commerce Department estimated today that the national economy is and has been operating at a slightly higher level than it had thought.
The Department of Public Works has submitted to the City Planning Commission a proposed 1960 capital construction budget of $131,416,510, Commissioner Frederick H. Zurumuhlen announced yesterday.
A year ago Doyle Dane Bernbach, Inc., broke into the cigarette advertising business. Now it's acting like a regular.

Directors of the American Fore Loyalty Group of insurance companies have elected Louis S. Cates and Dale E. Sharp to the board of the Niagara Fire Insurance Company, it was announced over the week-end by J. Victor Herd, chairman and president of American Fore.
It's a funny thing, but the mutual funds' worst enemies have a way of tripping themselves.

SANOQUELLI, July 18 -- The leaders of Liberia, Guinea and Ghana apparently have decided to delay practical steps toward unification until three more territories of this region gain independence next year.
RIVERSIDE, Calif., July 19 (UPI) -- Richie Ginther of Granada Hills, Calif., pushed his Ferrari to victory today in the 150-mile Kiwanis Grand Prix at the Riverside International Raceway.

PHILADELPHIA, July 19 (AP) -- Avery Brundage, the president of the International Olympic Committee, said today he would support the Nationalist Chinese in their application for re-admission to the I. O. C. because they have "now applied under the name of their country -- the Olympic Committee of the Republic of China."

WETHERSFIELD, Cor., July, 19 (AP) -- Gene Littler Singing Hills, Calif., captured the $25,000 Insurance City open golf tournament today. His hole total was 272, 12 under and a stroke ahead of Tom Nieporte of Bronxville, N. Y.
PITTSBURGH, July 19 -- Demand for steel up to the strike deadline last week was strong considering the large stocks said to be in the hands of steel users.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 19 -- A number of boats that had acquired class victories yesterday during the Larchmont Race Week sailing did it again today.

Additional offers of assistance for the Mekong River survey project have been announced by the four-nation committee that represents the riparian powers South Vietnam, Cambodia, Laos and Thailand. France will make her third money contribution, this time of fifty million francs. India will give important meteorological equipment needed for the study of the river.

GENEVA, July 19 -- A new phase of the Big Four foreign ministers' conference will begin tomorrow, the start of its eighth week. The Western powers will begin probing to find the price they must pay for a settlement of the Berlin crisis.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- (UPI) -- The seven astronauts vying for the honor of being the first American in space have signed an agreement to share equally in the financial returns of the first space voyager.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 19 (Reuters) -- The Iraqi Government reported tonight that "many people" died last week in clashes in Kirkuk.

President Eisenhower has proclaimed this as Captive Nations Week. He has also signed a Congressional resolution calling for a similar proclamation each year until the captive nations have regained their freedom.

MOAB, Utah, July 19 (AP) -- A family of eight, including six children aged 4 to 12, was rescued today after having been stranded more than two days in the hot southeastern Utah desert without food or water.
Communist-dominated countries in Central and Eastern Europe were prayed for yesterday at the 10 A. M. solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
Canada's largest air transport company, Trans-Canada Air Lines, has announced that it will be operating only turbine-powered airliners by late next year.

There appears to be a strong chance that "Omnibus" will not return to television next fall. The seven-year-old series, owned and produced by Robert Saudek Associates, has been presented for the last two years by the National Broadcasting Company.

MANHATTAN offers a fascinating collection of contemporary and traditional literature on European cuisines. The city's bookstores, while not brimful, have a stimulating assortment of books and periodicals dealing with many aspects of the culinary arts.

PHILADELPHIA, July 19 (AP) -- Gil Hodges' three-run home run clinched an 8-4 victory for Los Angeles today in the first game of a double-header with Philadelphia. Ed Bouchee's two-run double gave the Phils a 3-2 triumph in the rain-shortened five-and-a-half-inning second.

PARIS, July 17 -- French economic conditions have shown "progressive and uninterrupted improvement since the beginning of the year," according to Finance Minister Antoine Pinay in his recent report to the cabinet. This assessment appears to be borne out by most of the statistical evidence available.

THOMPSON, Conn., July 19 -- Newton Davis of Litchfield, Conn., drove his Porsche RS to a narrow victory in the fifteen lap (thirty mile) feature sports car race here today. Davis beat John Meyer, driving his big Cadillac special, by six seconds and averaged 67.2 miles an hour.
ROME, July 19 -- Pope John XXIII moved from the Vatican tonight to the Pontifical Summer residence at Castel Gandolfo, eighteen miles south of here.
CAIRO, July 19 -- The Nasser Government announced today it was beginning open financial support of the Algerian rebels.
The Women's Committee of the George Junior Republic is arranging a theatre benefit as part of its campaign to raise $100,000 for the school and community for teen-agers in Freeville, N. Y.

"Pope John XXIII," a biography by Zsolt Aradi, Msgr. James I. Tucek and James C. O'Neill, will be published Friday by Farrar, Straus Cudahy. The volume traces the life of the Pope from his peasant origin to his position as Supreme Pontiff of the Roman Catholic Church.
"When they play ball, they don't bunt. They slug to the outfield."

The United Steelworkers of America, with 500,000 members in basic steel mills, iron ore mines, Great Lakes ore carriers and other operations affected by the stoppage. The union has another 500,000 members in aluminum, can manufacturing and steel fabricating plants whose wages are usually affected by the basic settlement.
New fields of scientific research in the arts are producing additions to Columbia University's plans for a $6,000,000 arts center as a "graduate school of modern arts."
PHILADELPHIA, July 19 -- An overnight review of yesterday's 10,000-meter run made it clear today that Max Truex of the United States had placed second, rather than third.

LONDON, July 19 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Communist party newspaper Pravda warned Finland today that participation in the proposed "Outer Seven" free trade zone could put her "under the influence of powers concerned only with the strengthening of their political and economic positions."
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- A number of observers here report a growing feeling that the Western world has quietly reached three major economic turning points.

The Public Education Association was pleased that The Times devoted so much space in its editorial July 11 to the Board of Education establishment of a new division improve public relations for the city's schools. This editorial sets forth a number of points which our view can scarcely be over emphasized.
Two members of Congress urged President Eisenhower yesterday to appoint a fact-finding board to help end the six-day-old national steel strike.

"Living is an art and part of the art of living is knowing what to remember and what to forget," the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken said yesterday in his sermon on "The Fine Art of Forgetting" at the Riverside Church.

EAST WILLISTON, L. I., July 19 -- A golfer without a golf club membership became the Long Island amateur champion today. Art Silvestrone, 27-year-old stylist, ended his title bid at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club by defeating Joseph Darcy of Southward Ho, 10 and 8, in the scheduled thirty-six-hole final.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The Atomic Energy Commission is quietly preparing for immediate resumption of nuclear testing if the negotiations with the Soviet Union for a ban collapse.

MIAMI, Fla., July 19 -- The Dominican Republic's Minister of Labor, an outstanding liberal influence in the country's dictatorial Government, was killed Friday night in a mysterious automobile accident on a mountain highway. The minister, Ramon Marrero Aristy, died in a flaming car between the towns of Constanza and Monsenor Nouel. The details were not made public in Ciudad Trujillo, the Dominican capital.
Shares of five United States corporations will be listed on the Paris Bourse under a plan announced yesterday by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York and four French banking houses.

HARRISBURG, Pa., July 19 (AP) -- Van Johnson of Pittsburgh was killed today during a race at the near-by Williams Grove Speedway. He was driving the same Vargo Special in which Dick Linder was killed earlier this year.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 19 -- The police in Fairfield County shorefront communities are taking to the water in increasing numbers this summer to cope with the rise in pleasure boating.

UNTIL he was appointed President of Cuba last week, Dr. Osvaldo Dorticos Torrado was little known outside the Cuban legal profession and the revolutionary regime of Premier Fidel Castro. But persons acquainted with the revolution have said that Dr. Dorticos did much of the work shunned by those who specialized in oratory rather than the construction of a Government and an economy.
THE Brooklyn Championships tournament, played over the week-end, abounded in records and oddities.

LYNBROOK, L. I., July 19 -- An automobile speeding away from the police collided early today with an ambulance carrying a woman in labor to a hospital. She was transferred to a police ambulance and taken to Meadowbrook Hospital in East Meadow, where she gave birth to a healthy girl.
BALTIMORE, July 19 (AP) -- Billy O'Dell and Billy Loes teamed today for a three-hit pitching performance and a 2-1 Baltimore Oriole victory over the limping Detroit Tigers.

The superliner United States and her running mate, the America, will make thirty-four Atlantic crossings in the first five months of next year. The extended schedule was made public over the week-end by Kenneth F. Gautier, vice president for passenger traffic of the United States Lines Company.
EL PASO, Tex., July 19 (UPI) -- Gov. Earl Long went to church today and heard a sermon on repentance. He said he like the way the preacher "pumped it to them."

Approximately seventy passengers collapsed yesterday afternoon when two IRT trains from Flushing, Queens, were halted by a smoky fire in a hot, humid tunnel under the East River. Sixty-three persons were taken to hospitals after the trains finally pulled into the Grand Central subway station, and a number of others received oxygen from emergency squads.
GLOUCESTER, Mass., July 19 -- This fishing port paid tribute today to the more than 10,000 local fisherman who lost their lives at sea during Gloucester's 336-year history.
A tightening financial strait-jacket is constricting the city's cultural and recreational activities.

ON Monday, June 22, my wife and daughter and I said good-by to a couple from Capetown we had met on the boat from Balestrand to Gudvangen on the Sognefjord in Western Norway. We had ridden with them on a local bus up a spectacular mountain road to a high plateau called Stalheim.
Four new films will open this week at first-run theatres. The program follows:
GREENWICH, Conn., July 19 -- This town is trying to head off the discomforts of the hay fever season, which is due about the middle of next month, by urging property owners to eliminate ragweed.
A "paper" union has been barred from recognition by the State Labor Relations Board in the first crackdown under the board's new policy of denying certification to racket unions.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., July 19 -- A machine is winning at checkers from Dr. Arthur L. Samuel, the International Business Machines scientist who taught it the game.
Conditions in the steamship charter market worsened last week as both activity and freight rates decreased sharply.
TRIER, Germany, July 19 (AP) -- The Holy Tunic, one of the most venerated relics of the Roman Catholic Church, was displayed in Germany's oldest cathedral here today.

The American Civil Liberties Union made public yesterday two briefs designed to test again the constitutionality of the House Un-American Activities Committee. The briefs argue that the right of freedom of speech and association outweighs any value arising from the House committee's investigation of communism.

Until churches over the world open their doors freely to all worshipers regardless of race, the future of Christian civilization "will hang in the balance," the Rev. Dr. Richard E. Evans said yesterday.
POINT O'WOODS, L. I., July 19 -- Knute Lee's Eel, a Raven Class yacht, captured the Queen of the Bay race today, annexing one of Great South Bay's top yachting events.
SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., July 19 -- Champion Crikora Commotion, pert black miniature poodle owned by Mrs. J. Donald Duncan of New York, captured best-in-show honors for the second day in a row today.
ROME, July 19 -- Today saw the end of the Rome couture collections and the first half of the Italian showings.

Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy said yesterday that "the to-do" over the arrest of a woman in Harlem last Monday had had "a salutary effect" by increasing public awareness of the basic problems of the area.
Capital expenditures by the petroleum industry in the free world last year totaled $10,500,000, according to the 1958 Review of the Petroleum Industry by the Chase Manhattan Bank.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI) -- Americans for Democratic Action asserted today that the State Department had shown "reckless unconcern" for the Bill of Rights by using secret informers to check passport applicants.

Even though "every little mistake in human relations" here is likely to be "magnified out of its proportions" abroad, the United States must continue to convince the world that it practices democracy, the Premier of Eastern Nigeria declared yesterday.

A TEXAN has contracted to buy for $87,400 the entire fifty-two-piece collection of Steuben's "United States in Crystal." The sale of the engraved crystal pieces would be a record high for a single Steuben transaction.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The Social Security Administration will start in September a semi-annual count of centenarians on the old-age and survivors insurance rolls.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 19 -- The Indian Harbor Yacht Club's annual cruise, a three-day regatta on Long Island Sound, ended today with honors shared by three boats in the fleet of forty-six.
CHICAGO, July 19 (AP) -- Soybean futures became the star performers on the Board of Trade last week on the strongest bullish influence to hit any commodity there in months.

IT is to the credit of Ed Sullivan that during the summer months he does not take refuge in reruns of his winter variety programs over Channel 2. Last night, for example, he presented the taped program that he recorded a few weeks ago at Gian Carlo Menotti's "Festival of Two Worlds" at Spoleto, Italy.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- A liberal Senate Democrat called today on the Democratic leadership in Congress to "get in line with our party in the country."

"The older people were praying. A lot of people were down on their knees in the act of prayer," said John Bell, a passenger in one of the two Flushing IRT trains that were halted yesterday by a smoky fire in an East River tunnel.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 19 -- A pro-Communist revolt and army mutiny at Kirkuk, oil center in northeastern Iraq, was reported today to have resulted in near-civil war and hundreds of casualties.

CAMDEN, N. J., July 19 -- More than 100 American manufacturing companies that have participated in the construction of the world's first atomic-powered merchant ship were hosts here today at a press preview of her launching.

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 19 -- A proposal to subject price and wage increases in steel and other basic industries to compulsory Federal fact finding emerged here today at a conference sponsored by Gov. G. Mennen Williams.
LENOX, Mass., July 19 -- Tchaikovsky was the central figure, but a variety of music nevertheless was heard on the two concerts ending the current week-end of the Berkshire Festival.
Carl Sandburg, the poet and biographer, and Edward Steichen, the photographer, studied the Soviet exhibition at the Coliseum yesterday in preparation for a cultural mission to the Soviet Union.

Soon after he had arrived from Paris yesterday, Jean Riaud, the capitalist of Europe's harness racing drivers, took time out at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, and discussed the hazards of his profession and the eccentricities of his famous trotter, Jamin.

BALBOA, C. Z., July 19 -- Test boring was started this week to provide subsurface data for a new channel-widening project along the bends of Empire Reach in the Panama Canal's bottleneck at Gaillard Cut.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- An American magazine editor was permitted recently to deliver in Moscow a speech indicting Soviet foreign policy.

"ONE wonderful thing about the summer," a local mother commented recently, "is the chance it gives the children and me to get out into the country and learn something about nature. It's hard on children to be shut away in town."
ROME, July 19 -- President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia was said today to have appealed to Pope John XXIII for intervention in favor of the Algerian rebels.

The city's Department of Commerce and Public Events has come up with what it terms a "statistical post mortem" on an important phase of New York's economy during the recession year of 1958. The post mortem is a valuable survey which shows that the recession left several categories of employment virtually untouched here.
COLUMBUS, Ga., July 19 (AP) -- A fire that apparently was set by vandals heavily damaged a museum around midnight last night. Three art collections valued at more than $15,000 were destroyed.

ROME, July 19 -- The refugee from Geneva escapes its very special tedium with this conclusion: there are two striking differences between the second session of the foreign ministers' meeting and the first session that ended last month. Both differences are dismally significant.
ROME, July 16 -- The Italian economy is in a phase of healthy recovery this year, after a 1958 that was only moderately successful.

The earnings of American Viscose Corporation and its 50 per cent equity in the earnings of the Chemstrand Corporation and the Ketchikan Pulp Company for the first six months of 1959 amounted to $3.14 a share of American Viscose, the company reported yesterday. This compared with 74 cents a share in the same period of 1958.
ST. LOUIS, July 19 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals completed a three-game sweep over the Milwaukee Braves today by routing them, 9 -- 5, with sixteen hits. It was Milwaukee's sixth straight loss.

The twenty-eighth annual Gorge Gershwin Concert drew 15,000 listeners to Lewisohn Stadium Saturday evening. Alexander Smallens conducted the Stadium Symphony Orchestra, and soloists were Camilla Williams, soprano, Todd Duncan, baritone, and Earl Wild, pianist.
Four persons were killed and another injured by lightning yesterday at crowded Orchard Beach in the Bronx. Another bolt injured four persons just outside the Bronx Zoo.

Mr. Butler, in his New York television appearance, said he would step down any time a bare majority of the 108-member National Committee "thinks that my service is prejudicial to the best interests of the party and to the potential success that we should have in the campaign of 1960."
KINGS POINT, L. I., July 19 -- Children from Bergen, Norway, and Tokyo, Japan, joined hands and danced to a Swedish folk tune today on a broad lawn overlooking the skyline of Manhattan.
The Brazilian pianist Julio Braga, making his fourth appearance in New York, played an interesting program at Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday afternoon.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 19 -- Senator Kenneth B. Keating today assailed laws governing the admission of immigrants to the United States as "grossly inadequate and entirely too restrictive."
The Mayor's Committee on Slum Clearance yesterday issued its second quarterly report. It showed the following major changes in the city Title I program:

Guggenheimer Untermyer, one of the city's oldest law firms, has leased a floor in the office building being constructed at 80 Pine Street by Samuel Rudin. The lessees will move early next year from 30 Pine Street, where they have been for twenty-eight years. The lease was negotiated by Joe Mason of Helmsley-Spear Inc., agent for the building.
A year ago last week, revolution erupted in Iraq.

It is incredible that Governor Rockefeller and his Special Task Force on Protection From Radioactive Fall-Out have come to the conclusion that the people of the State of New York should build thick-walled protective shelters. This is either an astonishing display of ignorance, an attempt to stiffen our resolve in the cold war, or perhaps to give us a sense of security.
NAIROBI, Kenya, July 19 -- A boycott of goods produced in South Africa spread to Kenya today.
Governor Rockefeller left the door open last night for his name to be entered in New Hampshire's Presidential preference primary next March.

Retailers will emphasize men's mid-weight and light-weight suits next spring, according to a survey of 376 stores conducted by the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A. The importance of medium and light colors will increase, the survey notes.

The contract bridge team of David Weissman of Long Beach, L. I., Al Brodsky of New York, Alexander Schultz of Belle Harbor, Queens, and Herbert Ross of New York won the team-of-four championship last night in the twenty-seventh annual Brooklyn championships at the St. George Hotel.
CHICAGO, July 19 (AP) -- The Clay Court Committee of the United States Lawn Tennis Association censured Alex Olmedo of Peru, the Wimbledon champion, today.

A 13-year-old Negro boy, son of a United States Army sergeant stationed in Italy, read about Dr. Schweitzer's hospital in Africa. He decided to send the hospital a bottle of aspirin and asked the Allied Air Forces commander in Southern Europe if "one of your planes" could just drop the bottle at the hospital. An Italian radio station heard about the incident and told the story on the air.

BRIDGE conservatives who may tend to feel themselves in a maze of new and fancy bidding conventions may take some comfort in the final results of the Brooklyn Championships that were played over the week-end at the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn.
First-half earnings of the Radio Corporation of America were 44 per cent above the like 1958 period on a sales gain of 17 per cent.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI) -- The American Municipal Association urged Congress today to provide Federal disaster loans to small business concerns suffering economic injury from urban renewal or highway construction programs.
YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, July 20 -- In about three more weeks the effects of the steel strike may become starkly apparent in the Youngstown area.
In your June 12 editorial, "When Officers Retire," it would seem that one aspect of the situation was overlooked.
TOKYO, July 20 (AP) -- Two world records were bettered and Australian Murray Rose won the fastest 1,500-meter race of his career tonight as the United States-Japan swimming meet opened.

AN AFFLICTION of eggheads, some Oxford don or Sorbonne savant must have observed, is that they do not relish being catalogued as eggheads. Many of them wan also to be known as terribly regular guys.

Peter Campbell Brown, former city Corporation Counsel, will serve as legal counsel for the West Side Tennis Club at a hearing today of the City's Commission on Intergroup Relations concerning charges of racial and religious discrimination at the club.

"Jolly's Progress" will be one of the Theatre Guild's entries this season. Originally, Lonnie Coleman's dramatization of his novel, "Adams' Way," which was published by Dutton, had been a candidate for the 1958-59 term.
LI TLE ROCK, Ark., July 20 -- The four Little Rock public high schools that were closed last fall by Gov. Orval E. Faubus will reopen tomorrow to register pupils for the next term.
ONE or two things have to be said now about firearms and the shooting of the same, so in the beginning a couple of questions might as well be answered.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 20 (AP) Charley Neal hit Johnny Antonelli's first pitch in the ninth inning for a 365-foot homer into the left field pavilion today. The blow enabled the Los Angeles Dodgers to gain a 3-2 victory over the San Francisco Giants.
Mayor Wagner's office sent telegrams to about sixty Harlem leaders yesterday asking them to meet him and seventeen other city officials at 2:30 P. M. today at City Hall.

LA ROCHETTE. France, July 20 (AP) -- An 11-year-old elephant named Jumbo lumbered into this southeastern French village tonight on the first leg of an attempt to trace Hannibal's route through the Alps.

BABYLON, L. I., July 20 -lax Graf, a 53-year-old exconvict who is a Manhattan pinball machine distributor, was charged here yesterday with the 1956 murder of a Suffolk County labor leader, Edward J. Murtha, at Deer Park, L. I.

BUENOS AIRES, July 20 -- A strike by the National Metal Workers Union, with picketline clashes and factory bombings marked the beginning today of a critical week for Argentina's economic recovery program.
ROME, July 20 -- The Vatican called upon Roman Catholics in Sicily today not to set up another island Government with the support of Communists.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- A labor reform bill that is awaiting formal approval by the House Education and Labor Committee is still too strict for the American Federation of Industrial Organizations.

NEW DELHI, India, July 20 -- Communist China has prepared a secret plan to foment trouble in the states along the Himalayan border with the ultimate objective of annexing them, it was charged yesterday by H. V. Kamath, chairman of the Praja (People's) Socialist party.
United States foreign trade this year will come close to balancing with a record rise to a new peak for imports, according to the forecast by a leading trade group.

PHILADELPHIA, July 20 -- If horse players could handicap the quadrupeds as accurately as track nuts can handicap bipeds, all horse players would die rich instead of broke. Forecasts of the international dual meets between the United States and the Soviet Union were followed with an uncanny exactitude.

MEXICO CITY, July 20 -Australia successfully overcame the first difficult obstacle on the long road to a meeting at the Davis Cup summit with the United States today and Mexico's hopes for its greatest tennis conquest in history came to an end in heartbreaking disillusionment.
A Bronx waiter told the police that he accidentally shot his 18year-old son last night with a rifle he thought was empty, then, seeing the boy in pain, had loaded the gun and shot him dead.
FLORENCE, Italy, July 20 -- Expertly organized, the second half of the fall and winter Italian fashion collections got under way here this morning.

For the 209,400 stockholders of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. there was some good news yesterday that could save them a possible $580,000,000 in taxes. The Treasury and the Department of Justice said they were willing to grant tax concessions to shareholders in companies ordered to divest themselves of stock under the anti-trust laws.

FROM Montauk to Nova Scotia, commercial fishermen are now catching swordfish. These giants of the sea weigh hundreds of pounds and get their name from the long, pointed blade projected from their muzzle. During the summer months, fresh swordfish supplies are at their peak here.
Employes of downtown banking institutions will give blood to the Red Cross today at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, 33 Liberty Street.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- Rising wage and salary payments pushed personal incomes in June to a record rate of $382,900,000,000 a year.

A defective signal in the East River subway tunnel near the place where more than sixty persons were overcome by smoke on Sunday caused a twenty-five-minute delay in the morning rush hour yesterday on the IRT Flushing line.
Changes are needed in the organization, financing and control of American school systems, an educators' workshop was told yesterday.
Senator Jacob K. Javits advised the people of nations under Soviet domination yesterday to place their hope of ultimate freedom in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
A Negro educator is slated to be the first of his race to be nominated as associate superintendent of city schools.

IT may be summer outdoors, but every woman knows that it is winter indoors. We are in the season of the air-conditioner, and the happy woman is the woman who bundles up when she goes inside. Fortunately, the stores are full of good summer wraps that not only will add a layer of warmth but also will give the old summer wardrobe a new dash of fashion.
BERLIN, July 20 -- West Germany and West Berlin marked the fifteenth anniversary of the abortive bomb plot against Hitler on July 20, 1944.

CAIRO, July 20 -- The United Arab Republic has budgeted the equivalent of $331,000,000 for national defense spending in the next twelve months. A report made public yesterday indicates this is more than $12,500,000 over last year's military allocations.

The future of savings bank dividend rates became somewhat confused yesterday. Two Brooklyn savings banks, the Williamsburgh and the Lincoln, denied published reports that they would increase their dividend rate to 3 3/4 per cent on Jan. 1.
SANTA FE, N. M., July 21 (AP) -- A doctor and nurse were called late tonight to Louisiana Gov. Earl K. Long's motel room here.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 20 -- When the chariots of "Ben-Hur" take to the screen of the Egyptian Theatre in full color around Thanksgiving Day, they will be guaranteed to keep careening here for at least two years at the same theatre.
BOSTON, July 20 -- Boston University will adopt a unified, six-year program of college and medical school education designed to produce better physicians in less time.

GENEVA, July 20 -- The United States and Britain made a major concession to the Soviet Union today on the staffing of the international control posts that would police an agreement banning tests of nuclear weapons.
ATLANTIC BEACH, L. I., July 20 -- Owners of eighteen private beach clubs have joined to help underwrite a $250,000 project for the reclamation of twenty-seven bathing beaches here.
Yesterday morning the Tombs had two men named Jose Lopez, both held on narcotics charges. Bail of $2,000 was posted for one but the Corrections Department freed the other.
GENEVA, July 20 -- In the middle of today's private meeting of the Big Four foreign ministers' conference, Secretary of State Herter began talking about his plans for a vacation.
WARSAW, July 20 -- The Polish Ministry of Foreign Affairs today ordered Stanley Johnson, Warsaw correspondent for The Associated Press, to leave the country by Wednesday.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, July 20 -- The United States Embassy was informed today that Haiti's Foreign Ministry had indicated that an immigration order that has tied up Haitian travel to the United States would be rescinded.

The United Steelworkers of America, with 500,000 members in basic steel mills, iron ore mines, Great Lakes ore carriers and other operations affected by the stoppage. The union has another 500,000 members in aluminum, can manufacturing and steel fabricating plants whose wages are usually affected by the basic settlement.
One of the most-publicized achievements of Soviet surgery has been in the transplantation of the head and forefeet of one dog on the neck of another.
ST. LOUIS, July 20 (UPI) -The St. Louis-San Francisco Railway was charged today with criminal violations in connection with its holding of stock in the Central of Georgia Railway.
DETROIT, July 20 -- (AP) -Ford Motor Company today became the first auto manufacturer licensed to use a new process which bonds vinyl plastic to metal.

The leaders of the striking steel union indicated yesterday that they were concentrating their hopes for shortening the costly tie-up on the possibility of a wage breakthrough in the Big Three aluminum companies.
Two new attractions have arrived at the Central Park Zoo -- a button-eyed Japanese baby deer, to be named Bambi, and a newborn female yak, which some keepers already are calling Yacketty.

Aviation-Electronics-Electrical Equiment Shares of Group Securities, Inc., reported yesterday a gain of 63 per cent in net assets for the twelve months ended on June 30. The asset value of each share increased by 40 per cent in the same period.

The recent publicity on the St. Lawrence Seaway, with special emphasis on the probable bottleneck at the Welland Canal, reminds me forcefully of the effort nearly fifty years ago to secure construction of an all-American seaway.
