This would have crossed New York State instead of the barge canal which was subsequently built at greater expense.
Promoters of a $15,000,000 amusement park at Baychester Center in the Bronx are going to the public today to try to raise the money.

NICE, July 20 -- The 1959 Tour de France bicycle race is over. Victory after twenty-two days and 2,700 miles of unflagging pedaling has gone to Spain's Federico Bahamontes, known as the Eagle of Toledo.

Whoever starts a revolution releases forces that are destructive as well as creative. Premier Abdul Karim Kassim of Iraq is getting a harsh lesson in this fact of history. He has just had to put down a fierce uprising in the oil center of Kirkuk.

A thug who was allegedly fined $10,000 by underworld associates after they commuted his "death sentence" at the 1957 gangland convention in Apalachin, N. Y., was the star witness yesterday before the State Commission on Investigation.

The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, Inc., in its first quarter covering the thirteen weeks to May 30, had consolidated net earnings of about $14,638,000 compared with $13,274,000 for the corresponding period last year.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- The United States Tax Court today ruled that the Automobile Club of New York, Inc., must pay additional income taxes for 1944 through 1950 as a result of bookkeeping on prepaid dues.
GENEVA, July 20 -- The Western powers proposed today that the foreign ministers' conference transform itself into a permanent body to continue the search for a solution of the German problem.
SERENITY reigns over a small corner of the basement at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Here, a skilled Chinese craftsman performs the ancient oriental art of ink rubbing.
The Minneapolis Special School District 1 is planning the sale of $1,950,000 of site and building bonds on July 30. Dated July 1, 1959, the bonds will come due serially on Jan. 1 from 1960 to 1979.

ABOARD U. S S. NORTHAMPTON, at Sea, July 20 -Improved techniques in antisubmarine warfare but weakness in the fleet air defense were revealed in a five-day NATO exercise in the Atlantic, which was completed this afternoon.
HAVANA, July 20 -- The population of the Cuban capital grew and grew tonight as Havana prepared, in an atmosphere of political carnival, for the return of its hero.

The short interest position on the New York Stock Exchange was 3,264,681 shares on July 15. That was an increase of 22,988 shares from the revised figure of 3,241,693 shares reported as of June 15. The moderate rise in the latest period reversed a trend during which the short interest had fallen for six straight months.
A vast expansion of school vacation playgrounds was urged yesterday by Charles H. Silver, president of the Board of Education.
A group of 135 young men from nineteen foreign lands, all with one interest in common -the air -- arrived here yesterday for a month's visit to the United States.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The trade liberalization promised by Spain applies equally to all countries. According to some estimates, Spanish imports from the United States are likely to triple their present value of $280,000,000 to $300,000,000 a year.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 20 -The Baghdad radio said tonight that the Iraqi Government had canceled some celebrations of a national holiday this week as unconfirmed reports reached here of continued fighting in northern Iraq.
Advertising and banking mixed together yesterday to produce two unexpected developments.

A contract for the purchase of the branches of the Milwaukee Boston Stores in Manitowoc and Oshkosh, Wis., has been signed by Johnson Hill's, Inc., of Wisconsin Rapids, Wis., it was announced yesterday by Federated Department Stores, Inc. The Milwaukee Boston Store is a division of Federated.

A new issue of $50,000,000 of Tennessee Gas Transmission Company 5 1/4 per cent twenty-year first mortgage bonds is being offered to the public today by a syndicate headed jointly by Stone Webster Securities Corporation, White, Weld Co. and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 20 -- The Larchmont Yacht Club's Race Week, which should be used to unsatisfactory sailing conditions after sixty-one years of operation in whimsical summer breezes, had a little more to be unsatisfied about today.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized ten Western railroads and their subsidiaries today to raise inter -state one-way and roundtrip passenger coach fares on selected routes.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -Paul M. Butler's latest blow against Senator Lyndon B. Johnson's brand of Democratic leadership appeared today to be boomeranging.
NEW DELHI, India, July 20 -- The Communist government of Kerala has acted ruthlessly to set up a dictatorship of the Communist party, the Kerala branch of the Congress party has charged.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 20 -- The Federation of Industries in Indonesia published today the opinions of three prominent international lawyers that the nationalization of Dutch property by the Jakarta Governmeint was illegal.
PHILADELPHIA, July 20 -In the wake of a second decisive United States victory over the Soviet Union in men's track and field, two leading American coaches sounded a warning today.

FLORAL PARK, L. I., July 20 -- Two American workers who helped to build an exhibition ranch house in Moscow said today that the experience had left them with little envy for the lot of the Soviet working man.

With the bulk of the steel industry strikebound since last Tuesday midnight, steel production this week was expected to be only 374,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

YONKERS. July 20 -- Dancer Hanover, a 2-year-old pacer who has been to the races only once, was sold for $200,000 today. The price, paid by Lawrence B. Sheppard, owner of the Hanover Shoe Farm, Hanover, Pa., was a record for an active harness horse.

PARIS, July 20 -- Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia flew here today from Brussels, Belgium, for an official visit. He received an elaborate welcome from President Charles de Gaulle and his Ministers at Orly airfield.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -Fleet Admiral William D. Leahy, personal Chief of Staff to Presidents Franklin D. Roosevelt and Harry S. Truman during World War II, died today at the Bethesda Naval Hospital in Maryland. He was 84 years old.

CHICAGO, July 20 (AP) -All the new-crop soybean futures contracts spurted to new high prices for the season today on the Board of Trade after absorbing a flurry of selling in early dealings which knocked prices down about a cent.
WARSAW, July 20 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev told Polish workers today that the world situation was not bad, but that capitalists were not eating their share of caviar.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- Prince Edward County, Va., asked the Supreme Court today to set aside a Federal Appeals Court ruling requiring the county's white public schools to admit qualified Negroes in September.

Public trading began auspiciously yesterday in the Treasuy's new 4 3/4 per cent securities that are being offered in exchange for $13,973,000,000 of 1 5/8 and 4 per cent certificates of indebtedness due Aug. 1. For the Treasury debt conversion, the steel strike, with its threat of slackened economic activity, is a silver lining on a dark cloud.
AKRON, Ohio, July 20 (AP) The price of some replacement tires was reduced 5 to 15 per cent today by Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company.

Almost every day brings a new statistic rounding out the picture of what a booming, prosperous period the American economy enjoyed during the first half of this year. Yesterday, for example, the Government reported that personal incomes last month climbed to a record annual rate of $382,900,000,000, while for the first half of this year real per capita personal income was 4 per cent over the same period last year.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -President Eisenhower hinted today that he might veto the public works appropriations bill. He said the House and Senate had added starts on projects that would ultimately cost $1,200,000,000.
TOKYO, July 20 -- The Japanese economy has fully recovered from its recession of 1957-58 in an unexpectedly swift rise, the Economic Planning Board said in an annual report today.

COOPERSTOWN, N. Y., July 20 (AP) -- Five home runs sailed out of Doubleday Field today as the Pittsburgh Pirates and the Kansas City Athletics played a 5-5 tie in the annual Hall of Fame Game. The exhibition was called in the sixth inning because of rain.
PITTSBURGH, July 20 (AP) -- Two steel companies reported trouble today in getting supervisory personnel in and out of plants. However, there was no violence.
A "master plan" for slum eradication that would go far beyond the present Title I program has been proposed by Mayor Wagner.

CHICAGO, July 20 (AP) -Bernard (Tut) Bartzen, 31year-old southpaw from Dallas, today retained his national clay court tennis crown by defeating Whitney Reed, Alameda, Calif., 16 -- 0, 8 -- 6, 7 -- 5, in the final.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, July 20 (AP) -- Interior Secretary Pedro M. Hungria denied tonight that there was anything mysterious about the death Friday of Ramon Marrero Aristy, Dominican Minister of Labor.
A squall line with lightning, thunder, high winds and heavy rain passed through the metropolitan area last night, causing considerable damage in some suburban areas.

Your paper has recently carried a series of articles and editorials which have referred to the Democrats and to the Joint Economic Committee and myself as advocates of "unlimited easy money" and as spenders, and to our economic report as a "fiasco." Let us, however, examine the facts.

The Joy Manufacturing Company has signed a long-term lease for space in 100 Church Street. The company, a manufacturer of mining equipment and heavy machinery, has its head office in Pittsburgh. Its eastern sales office, now at 90 West Street, will occupy the new space in 100 Church Street in October.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI) -- Senator James E. Murray, Democrat of Montana, urged the Senate Appropriations Committee today to approve $23,000,000 to continue the Government's stockpiling program for manganese.
LONDON, July 20 (AP) -Sir Winston Churchill met old comrades from battles of long ago at the christening of his tenth grandchild today.

A television adaptation of the motion picture "Body and Soul" will be staged as the seasonal premiere of "Du Pont Show of the Month" on Sept. 28 from 8:30 to 10 P. M. It will be presented over the Columbia Broadcasting System network.
Sydney S. Baron, New York public relations man, received yesterday an apology from Bartley C. Crum for testimony that Mr. Crum had given before a Senate committee in Washington on July 13.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- The Federal Aviation Agency proposed today that all airliners be equipped with weather radar.

Like other dictators, Gen. Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina is increasingly impatient of criticism or even fair comment. He has just revenged himself on a reporter for this newspaper, Tad Szulc, by threatening him with arrest, and then permitting him to depart to the United States with a warning never to return.

Although some of the electronics and metals fought a rearguard action, the stock market staged a fairly general retreat yesterday and gave up market values of more than $1,300,000,000. It was the third successive day of lower prices.
Loew's, Inc., showed a sharp recovery in the twelve and forty weeks ended June 4, according to the results reported by Joseph R. Vogel, president of the motion picture producer.

Mr. Chairman: As indicated in my statement of July 16, I had hoped that we might concentrate on the specific elements of an interim agreed Berlin arrangement to last until German unification -- deferring until later in our deliberations further discussion of procedures for attaining German unification.

Hugh Lynch 3d of Bethesda, Md., won the junior title in the Eastern junior and boys' tennis championships yesterday. He bet top-seeded Arthur Ashe of Lynchburg, Va., 5 -- 7, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4, at the West Side Club, Forest Hills, Queens.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- The State Department welcomed today a statement attributed to Avery Brundage that he would support the recognition of the "Olympic Committee of the Republic of China."
Benjamin Cymrot denied again yesterday that his activities as a real estate broker had ever conflicted with his duties as executive officer of the old Bureau of Real Estate.
The Chilean Government has inherited a number of irate passengers holding tickets to Santiago from a bankrupt airline.

Today's new film is "The Enchanted Mirror," the second feature in the Russian Kinopanorama wide-screen process, at the Mayfair Theatre, Seventh Avenue and Forty-seventh Street. With the new opening, the Soviet-made "Great Is My Country'" completes its engagement at the theatre.
VIENNA, July 20 -- The editors of Vienna's non-Communist newspapers have decided to print nothing about the World Youth Festival.
SALTSJOEBADEN, Sweden, July 20 -- Cabinet ministers of seven countries outside the European common market opened a two-day conference here today.
WASHINGTON July 20 -- The Pentagon's civilian and military chiefs undertook today an unusual joint investigation of two major field commands.

Rain in the morning and in the early afternoon yesterday made a nice, soft cushion, without diminishing the speed of the Jamaica race track. This was a made-to-order condition for the Chilean-bred 5-year-old horse Babu, owned by William C. Partee.
Nnamdi Azikiwe, Premier of Eastern Nigeria, predicted yesterday that Nigeria would exchange diplomatic missions with the Soviet Union after achieving full independence next year.

ROME, July 20 -- The Mayor of Rome appealed to all citizens today to put rooms in their homes at the disposal of the "athletes and tourists from ninety-seven nations" whom the Italian capital is preparing to welcome for the 1960 Olympic Games.
Demolition activities are reported moving on schedule on the Lincoln Square Title I redevelopment project.

E. I. Du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., in the first six months of this year increased earnings 47.9 per cent above the 1958 level. Sales were up 25 per cent, according to the preliminiary report issued yesterday.

GUATEMALA CITY, July 19 -- A "very encouraging" show of oil was struck by the Ohio Oil Company at a little below 10,000 feet in a well it is drilling in Chinaja in the northern province of Alta Verapaz.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 20 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev of the Soviet Union has abruptly put off a visit to Scandinavia he was to have begun in Copenhagen Aug. 9.
Several months ago a woman doctor on the faculty of Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons leaned forward in amazement at what she saw in a Soviet operating room.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The Treasury bill rate fell a little this week, the Treasury reported tonight. The average interest rate on $1,000,000,000 of ninetyone day bills was 3.337, compared with 3.401 last week, and the average rate on $400,000,000 of 182-day bills was 3.869 per cent, compared with 4.029 per cent last week.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Tuesday, July 21 (AP) -- A power-packed Atlas intercontinental ballistic missile surged aloft early today, ending the six weeks' suspension of this missile's test program.
LONDON, July 20 -- Although demand was small and selective, a wide range of industrials gained a few pence on the stock market here today.
CHICAGO, July 20 (AP) -- The report of todays livestock markets here by the Department ol Agriculturefollows:
Twenty-one judges from some of the highest courts in North America went back to school today with a faculty that included an associate justice of the United States Supreme Court.

The Union Carbide Corporation had the highest sales and earnings in its history during the first half and second quarter of this year, Morse G. Dial, chairman and chief executive officer, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Almost conclusive evidence has now been provided that the entire Democratic hierarchy of the Senate -- which includes various shades of "liberals" and "moderates" -- feels the President at last has furnished the political issue the Democrats as a party have been seeking ever since this session of Congress began.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 1 point (5 cents a ball) up to 10 point (5 cents a bale) up to 10 yesterday.
THE fashion show scheduled to be offered at the American National Exhibition in Moscow ran into more difficulty Sunday night. It had trouble getting off the ground.
Carmine G. De Sapio, striking back at his critics last night, termed the New York County Democratic organization the strongest partisan group in the state.
WARSAW, July 20 -- Premier Khrushchev's decision to call off his Scandinavian tour is clashing with some of his publicity in Poland.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -Vice President Richard M. Nixon will reaffirm United States determination to stand by West Berlin when he meets Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev Sunday in Moscow.

It was raining and the landing strip was sloshy as the six European horses that will compete in the $50,000 International Trot at Roosevelt Raceway arrived yesterday at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

PROVIDENCE, R I., July 20 (AP) -- Harold Gomes survived four knockdowns to gain a unanimous fifteen-round decision over Paul Jorgenson and win the vacated world junior light-weight championship tonight. Gomes weighed 127 1/2, Jorgenson 129 1/2.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 20 -- The European Forestry Commission conceded last week that both production and consumption of round wood in Europe had by the end of 1957 far outstripped the "most optimistic" estimates for the 1950-60 decade. The commission, an arm of the Food and Agriculture Organization, made the announcement at a meeting in Rome which reviewed the calculations of ten years ago and made preliminary forecasts for the decade to 1970.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- The Teamsters Union asked the Supreme Court today to hold up the effectiveness of a court decision giving monitors broad powers to enforce cleanup demands.
Committees have been formed and planning begun for the annual Yule Bazaar of St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church. It will be held in the Parish House. 1 West Fiftythird Street, on Dec. 4 and 5.

"Perhaps the following anecdotes will pleafe fome-body -- if not everybody; -They can offend nobody: and are at the fervice of ANYBODY." And so started a column of news on Wednesday, Sept. 26, 1798, on the first of four sheets of The Columbian Centinel, "printed and publifhed on Wednefdays and Saturdays, by Benjamin Russell, Printer of the LAWS of the Union for the Northern States -- South fide, State-Street, next to the Coffee-Houfe, Boston, (Maffachufetts).
A leading Soviet meteorologist expressed doubt yesterday that practical means would be found for large-scale weather control.

About 1,200 stewards, stewardesses and pursers employed by Pan American World Airways will vote by mail on the terms of a new contract. The results, a Transport Workers Union spokesman said yesterday, will not be known before Aug. 24.
TRENTON, July 20 -- The Appellate Division of the New Jersey Superior Court today ruled that the state could not collect $7,000,000 in unredeemed trading stamps from the Sperry Hutchinson Co.
WHITEHORSE, Yukon, July 20 (UPI) -- A stomach upset forced Queen Elizabeth to curtail her Canadian tour activities today for the second day.

Seventy years ago four nine-pin lanes were installed in Turner Hall in Davenport, Iowa. Now the lanes, believed to be the last of their kind in the nation, are about to go the way of other horse-and-buggy relics. In a month or two Turner Hall will be torn down to make way for a municipal parking lot.
RYE, N. Y., July 20 -- Mrs. Bruce McGhie fired a 76 to take the qualifying medal as play began today in the ninth annual Women's Tri-County Golf Association championship at the Apawamis Club.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 20 -- The North Jersey Shore's chief social event of the summer season -- the thirteenth annual Turf Charity Ball and Carnival -- will be held Saturday in the spacious clubhouse of the Monmouth Park Jockey Club here.

NEWARK, July 20 -- The New York Central Railroad's ferryboat Niagara, which ran from Weehawken to Fortysecond Street, Manhattan, for more than forty-seven years, will become a floating machine shop and office.

Uncertainty over Fidel Castro's position of power in Cuba caused world sugar futures to decline yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. On last Friday, the market rose when it appeared that Castro's resignation might hold.

BRUNO KREISKY, new Foreign Minister of Austria, was on his first official mission abroad yesterday and, as fate would have it, to the country that gave him refuge from the Nazi terror. Dr. Kreisky is in Stockholm to participate in seven-power free-trade zone discussions.
ALBANY, July 20 -- The State Bar Association today threw its support behind a major change in the New York law governing the responsibility of insane persons for their crimes.
MADRID, July 20 -- Spain joined the Western European trading community today after nearly a quarter century of proud -- and costly -- isolation.

Net income of the Flintkote Company in the first six months of this year increased 59.5 per cent to $5,432,007 from $3,403,907 in the 1958 first half, the building-materials producer reported yesterday. After preferred dividend requirements, the net is equal to $1.15 a share on an average of 4,248,958 common shares outstanding, compared with 68 cents a share last year on an average of 4,150,577 common shares.

Helipat, a 5-year-old mare owned by Peter Fuller, found herself in the unfamiliar precincts of the winner's circle after the feature race at Jamaica yesterday. She pranced there with Dave Erb after beating a half-dozen others of her sex in a test of a mile and a sixteenth.
GENEVA, July 21 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter was reported today to have urged the French Government to reconsider its position on the storing of United States nuclear bombs in France.
BONN, Germany, July 21 -- France, Italy and West Germany are considering the establishment of a joint committee to decide political issues for the European Community.

Vice President Nixon leaves for Moscow today and for the next two weeks the eyes of the world will be upon him as he tours the Soviet Union. When he arrives in Moscow he will become the highest ranking American official to visit the Soviet Union since President Roosevelt's stay in Yalta almost a decade and a half ago.

In view of the crucial diplomatic and military problem of avoiding nuclear war both now and in the future it seems irresponsible for the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy to have endorsed the NATO atom arms pacts (Times, July 14, page 1) without giving adequate warning to Congress of the dangers for our future security implied by this decisive step.
SALTSJOEBADEN, Sweden. July 21 -- Economic Ministers of the "Outer Seven" nations moved today to form a free trade association by Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- President Eisenhower was pictured today as being deeply concerned about the possibility that a pending self-financing bill for the Tennessee Valley Authority might entail a diminution of the Presidency's executive power.
ROME, July 21 -- A vote in the regional Parliament of Sicily for a new Government was declared invalid tonight for lack of a quorum.

The Nuclear Ship Savannah, launched in Camden yesterday, was first publicly proposed by President Eisenhower in a speech on April 25, 1955. The project had a tumultuous year in Congress; for the vessel originally was to be a show ship for world display, and Congress did not like the idea.

WARSAW, July 21 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev has told Polish peasants that the Soviet Union has found communes are the wrong way to start on the road to socialization. The Soviet Premier did not mention Communist China's nation-wide system of communes.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) -- The Boston Globe charged in a legal brief today that George C. McConnaughey, then chairman of the Federal Communications commission, should have disqualified himself from voting in the award of Boston television Channel 5.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Frederick Henry Mueller, nominated today as Secretary of Commerce, is a strongly conservative Midwesterner.
The United States Post Office ban on "Lady Chatterley's Lover," the novel by D. H. Lawrence, was upset here yesterday by Federal Judge Frederick vanPelt Bryan.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- General of the Army Omar N. Bradley and Dr. Howard A. Rusk urged Congressional approval today of a bill to create a $50,000,000 Institute of International Medical Research within the National Institutes of Health.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Secretary of Labor, James P. Mitchell, announced today that he was moving formally into the steel dispute as the Government's fact-finder.
A reproduction of a shield bearing the coat of arms of the Organization of American States was given to Mayor Wagner yesterday at a brief ceremony at City Hall.

TOKYO, July 21 (UPI) -- Joe Alkire, a schoolboy from San Diego, paced an American quartet to a world record of 3 minutes 44.4 seconds for the 400- meter free-style relay today and pulled the United States to within 2 points of Japan in their three-day dual meet.

Judge Harold R. Medina, who presided at the trial of the eleven top Communists in this country in 1949, re-examines his career in the courts in "The Anatomy of Freedom." He gives his impressions of the Communist trials, his experience as defense counsel for Anthony Cramer, a German-American accused of treason, and his thoughts on education, the arts, justice, patriotism and security.

The city's proposed new Code of Ethics was modified yesterday to permit unpaid officials to do business with city agencies other than their own. The change was made by the City Council's Committee on Standards and Ethics as it reported out favorably the three bills forming the new code.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 22 -- Dick Blaikie, who comes from London, lives in Yonkers, works in advertising and sails yachts for fun, probably was the gladdest man at the Larchmont Yacht Club's race week today.
The Ford Foundation announced yesterday a five-year grant of $750,000 to Rutgers University to establish an experimental extension program on urban research in New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- Former Secretary of State Dean Acheson related today that during the early part of the Korean war Washington thought for a short time that Soviet bombers were on their way to attack the United States.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Following is the text of a statement issued yesterday by James P. Mitchell, the Secretary, of Labor, on the steel strike:

WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) -- Federal Judge F. Dickinson Letts today granted a court-appointed board of monitors permission to hire an outside legal firm to help speed its clean-up of the Teamsters Union.

The One William Street Fund, Inc., reported yesterday that 92.1 per cent of its total net assets were invested in common stocks as of June 30. The investments were in 108 common stocks, and compared with 91.1 per cent of total assets in 108 companies three months earlier.

Greater use of glass in buildings and automobiles swelled sales and enabled the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company to turn in record net earnings for the first half this year, according to the report issued yesterday.
A group of 136 young men from nineteen countries in Europe, the Middle East and Latin America put in a full day of sightseeing here yesterday as they began a month's stay in the United States.
Cary Grant and Ingrid Bergman are looking to next year when they will appear in their third film together.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 21 (AP) -- The Atlas missile fired successfully early today was saved from possible delay by a slender, heavily greased mechanic who squirmed into the rocket engine compartment to find a tiny fuel leak.

Your July 14 issue reports laconically that General Electric has announced a cut in the price of its giant steam-turbine generators. Thereon hangs an issue of the first importance, one worth recounting.

The United Steelworkers of America, with 500,000 members in basic steel mills, iron ore mines, Great Lakes ore carriers and other operations affected by the stoppage. The union has another 500,000 members in aluminum, can manufacturing and steel fabricating plants whose wages are usually affected by the basic settlement. These plants are not on strike.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 21 -- The Israeli Cabinet held an extraordinary meeting today to discuss recent violent disturbances in several parts of the country, particularly in Migdal Haemek Sunday and in Beersheba last night.

A book written eight years ago by William D. Leahy bore the title "I Was There." The title was appropriate. Admiral Leahy was writing history at first hand and he was well qualified to do so, since he had been present in an official capacity at all of the famous conferences of the war years -- Teheran, Yalta, Cairo, Quebec, Washington and Potsdam.

Evelyn Steinke's letter, "Taxation of Working Mothers," published July 14, amused me considerably. The inference that income tax laws are discriminatingly unfair against working mothers is erroneous. Taxes are indiscriminately high and unpleasant for everyone.
IT is just about time for the hardy hunter, whether he rishes or not, to begin making manly noises about preparations for the coming of fall.
DUBLIN, July 21 -- An invitation to Northern Ireland to cooperate with the Republic in economic matters was made by Premier Sean Lemass in the Dail Eireann (ParIlament) here tonight.

Stockholders of the Canadian Eagle Oil Company, Ltd., at a meeting yesterday in Toronto, accepted the offer from the Royal Dutch Petroleum Company and the Shell Transport and Trading Company, Ltd. to acquire the business and assets of Canadian Eagle.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- The Navy has ordered all its planes patrolling within range of Communist shores to have all their guns in place and ready to operate.

Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc., 110-year-old pharmaceutical and chemical producer, announced yesterday the election of J. Philip Smith as a vice president. Mr. Smith will head Pfizer Laboratories, one of Pfizer's two ethical marketing divisions.
HAVANA, July 21 -- Fidel Castro kept Cuba in suspense tonight on his political plans.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- Jerome S. Spevack got his patent today and does not have to worry now about the Government giving away his secret for making heavy water.

ROME, July 21 -- Pope John XXIII returned to the Vatican today from his summer residence at Castel Gandolfo to receive Premier Nobusuke Kishi of Japan. Rome was sweltering, and the Pontiff went back to Castel Gandolfo after the twenty-minute audience.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities opened an inquiry today into Communist training operations.
A program to combat deterioration of art collections in this country will be undertaken next year by the Institute of Fine Arts of New York University.
Mayor Wagner sent to the City Council yesterday five bills designed to carry out his program for preventing families with children from occupying single rooms in tenements and rooming houses.

G. Russell Clark, State Superintendent of Banks, plans to call a special session of the State Banking Board early next month to deal with "the whole question of savings rates," a spokesman indicated yesterday.

There are many ways of expressing the spirit of the "Good Neighbor" in American affairs, some big, some small. No gesture is ever lost or ever meaningless. Yesterday a pleasant enterprise was begun by the Avenue of the Americas Association when the replica of a shield bearing the coat of arms of the Organization of American States was presented to Mayor Wagner.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 21 -- Five Negro students were registered today without incident at Central High School.

Despite a fifty-five-day strike in eight of its rubber-products plants, earnings of the B. F. Goodrich Company in the first half were 37.1 per cent above the 1958 level on a sales rise of 14.8 per cent, the report disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) -- The House Judiciary Committee rejected today a Southern attempt to strip its civil rights bill of a section to provide criminal penalties for wilfully obstructing court-ordered school integration.
Slick Airways, Inc., announced yesterday a $22,000,000 order for six Lockheed turbo-propeller cargo planes.
RYE, N. Y., July 21 -- Many of the favorites were forced to the sidelines in the first round of the Women's Tri-County Golf Association championship at the Apawamis Club today.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) -- Representative Aime J. Forand got support today from former President Truman for his bill to broaden social security to include hospital and surgical benefits for the aged.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 4 points (20 cents a bale) up to 4 points off yesterday. The near months showed the most strength.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Government officials were puzzled tonight by Mr. Khrushchev's questioning of Vice President Nixon's aims in going to Moscow.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 21 -- David Ben-Gurion announced today that he had been unable to form a new coalition to replace Israel's caretaker Government.

IT still is amusing to hear Nathan Detroit trying to con Sky Masterson into making a bet on the number of slices of cheesecake sold at Mindy's yesterday. And Nathan Detroit not knowing the color of his own tie still is a funny bit.

ROME, July 21 -- Five years ago today an armistice ended the Indochina war. This event terminated French influence in what had been its richest colonial possession. At the same time, by partitioning Vietnam, it marked communism's deepest intrusion into Southeast Asia.
An agreement was reached yesterday morning on contract terms for settling the three-week strike of drivers of ready-mix concrete trucks.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- President Eisenhower has abandoned the idea of reducing taxes while he remains in the White House -- a prospect he held out in a message to Congress last January.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- A fleet of ships and planes carrying American aid to the world's disaster areas was proposed today by four Congressmen.

REBECCA Petriken is focusing her decorating attentions on the forgotten New Yorker -- the one-room apartment dweller. In the five model rooms she has decorated for Stern's, four show how everything that must be packed into small quarters can be planned with space to spare.

CHICAGO, July 21 (AP) -- The butcher hog market slipped to its lowest peak price in more than three years today with no indication that the recent downward trend has yet touched bottom. Prices were 25 to 50 cents lower.
TORONTO, July 21 -- A Canadian consulting engineer has left $1,000,000 for scholarships for deserving "plodders" at the University of Toronto but not a cent to his only son, a nearly blind invalid.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) -- The Senate today approved a five-year extension of the International Sugar Agreement.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Air Force officials believed today that they had solved the technical problems that delayed the perfecting of the Atlas intercontinental ballistic missile.
LONDON, July 21 (UPI) -- Bill Steinkraus of Westport, Conn., scored the third United States victory at the Royal Horse Show in today's Nizefela Stakes.
Directors of the Tennessee Corporation yesterday proposed a two-for-one split of the common stock.

PITTSBURGH, July 21 (UPI) -- agreement was reached tonight in a dispute concerning free passage of supervisory employes at the Pittsburgh and nearby Aliquippa works of Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation.
OTTAWA, July 21 -- The rigors of travel across the vast distances of Canada and the intense summer heat seem to be causing difficulties for Queen Elizabeth.

CHICAGO, July 21 (AP) -- Shortly before he died John Foster Dulles arranged to bequeath his personal papers to both the Eisenhower Presidential Library and Princeton University, it was made known today.

The R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company had the highest sales and earnings for any half-year period in the six months ended on June 30, according to the report of Bowman Gray, president. The manufacturer of Camel, Winston, Salem and Cavalier cigarettes, also noted that second quarter results exceeded those of any previous three months.
Mayor Wagner instructed city departments yesterday to report to his office by Aug. 3 on existing and proposed programs for the Harlem area.

Cue Publishing Company, publisher of Cue Magazine, has leased 4,000 square feet of office space in 11 West Forty-second Street from the salmon Management Company. The ten-year lease was negotiated by the Cross Brown Company, broker.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Premier Khrushchev's invitation to Premier Abdul Karim Kassim to visit Moscow was interpreted here today as a reflection of Soviet concern over anti-Communist developments in Iraq.
NAIROBI, Kenya, July 21 -- Preparations are being made here for changes in the Constitution of Kenya that would set this British colony on the road to self-government.

The Hanover Bank said yesterday that it expected to move the major part of its operations and personnel uptown early in 1961, continuing the march of banking institutions to new sites in the midtown area. In March, the First National City Bank of New York announced that it was making a similar move.

AMMAN, Jordan, July 21 (Reuters) -- Syria will reopen its borders to traffic from Jordan and diplomatic relations between Jordan and the United Arab Republic will be re-established "very soon," Abdel Khalik Hassouna, Secretary General of the Arab League, announced here tonight.
DETROIT, July 21 (AP) -- The Ford Motor Company reported today record consolidated net earnings of $285,900,000 for the first six months of 1959, equal to $5.22 a share.

The law under which James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, undertook his fact-finding role in the steel strike dates back to 1888. This was twenty-five years before the establishment of the Labor Department in 1913.
Federal officials reported yesterday that vital defense projects had enough steel to last at least until September.
The State Commission of Investigation said yesterday it did not believe the stories given to the commission by three visitors to the 1957 gangland convention in Apalachin.
AT lunch in a restaurant on recent humid day, it was interesting to note that salad was one of the most popular choices as a main dish.
SUMMERTIME is fine for swimmers, but hard on watches. To keep a timepiece in tip-top shape, despite the rigors of sailing and outdoor sports, Bulova Watch Company experts offer this advice:

Bill Holland of Warminster, Pa., winner of the Indianapolis 500-mile race ten years ago, is coming out of retirement again to drive a sprint car and possibly a midget in the second annual triple-header at the Trenton (N. J.) Speedway on Sunday.

World sugar prices continued to decline on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. All positions, with the exception of January, again made new lows for the life of the contract. Trade and commission house liquidation were reported. Short covering and light new buying limited the declines.

Thirty-five investors in "The Billy Barnes Revue" have contributed additional backing to move the entertainment to a Broadway home. Brought here from Los Angeles, the attraction has been residing at the off-Broadway York Playhouse since June 9.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 21 -- Alex Olmedo, the Peruvian-born United States Davis Cup star, was again a serious hardworking player today. The Wimbledon champion bore down all the way against two opponents in reaching the third round of the Pennsylvania lawn tennis championships at the Merion Cricket Club.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, and Senator John Sherman Cooper of Kentucky clashed heatedly today at a hearing on safety legislation for mines.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) -- Republican Congressional leaders denounced the House labor reform bill today as "woefully inadequate" and said it fell far short of what was needed to weed out union corruption.

LONDON, July 21 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan announced in the House of Commons today his proposals for the make-up of a commission to lay the groundwork for a review of the Constitution of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland.
LONDON, July 21 -- Stock exchange prices moved aimlessly today. Changes were generally in pennies; any bigger movements were in response to specific items of company news.

Frank Stanton, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, will appear on television Sunday to present a C. B. S. editorial calling for changes in Section 315 of the Federal Communications Act. The section, known generally as the equal time law, has created much confusion in broadcasting.
WARSAW, July 21 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev said tonight that he was puzzled by Vice President Richard M. Nixon's aims in going to Moscow.
MOSCOW, July 21 (UPI) -- Eighty Americans arrived in Moscow today to prepare for the fashion show they will present at the American National Exhibition.

SOMEWHERE in the raw wilderness between the Concho and the Colorado Rivers in West Texas the stage stopped and the orphan boy got out in a sleet storm. There was a bar, a livery stable and a restaurant, and that was all. Inside the restaurant a tall, silent man with six-guns tied down to his legs was standing at the window watching the doorway of the bar.

The Treasury's $13,973,000,000 debt conversion was pronounced an assured success in the financial district after a busy trading session yesterday. The public market readily absorbed large blocks of maturing securities that holders did not wish to exchange for the new 4 3/4 per cent notes.

The Detroit Edison Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday that power required for its service area was 14,168,340,000 kilowatt hours in the twelve months ended on June 30. This is a gain of 8.1 per cent over the like 1958 period.

PARIS, July 21 -- A Moslem Deputy from Algeria proposed today the formation of a commission of appeasement and reconciliation to end nearly five years of violence and "intolerable suffering for all Algerians."

Arthur Maxwell Co. bought the forty-two-family apartment building at 1940 Clinton Avenue, the Bronx, from the Clinton Management Company and refinanced the property with a new first-mortgage loan from the North Side Savings Bank.
Nine men were sentenced to up to a year in jail yesterday for illegally accepting city relief checks totaling more than $21,000.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- An Air Force general took issue today with testimony presented last week on pending military contract bills by Senator Kenneth B. Keating, Republican of New York.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- House investigators heard read today a letter in which a retired Army sergeant said he had to wash dishes, baby-sit and clean up after the dog in a general's home.
BONN, Germany, July 21 (AP) -- Informed sources said today West Germany was negotiating to buy $6,200,000 worth of arms from the United Arab Republic.

A total of 133,800 common shares in the Neiman-Marcus Company, owner of fashion stores in Dallas and Houston, Texas, are being offered to the public for the first time today. Underwriters of the issue are headed by Leh man Brothers.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) -- Mr. Bagwell declared in his letter that he "worked more for the general's wife than for him."
NORWICH, Conn., July 21 (AP) -- The city's seventy-eight striking municipal employes have been given until Thursday morning to return to work or risk losing their jobs.

" One-fourth of our total expense budget is devoted to education. I have said before, and repeat, that this is possibly the most important single expenditure we can make." -- Mayor Wagner, April 14, 1959, in his annual message to the City Council.

The appointments of Harry A. Murray and Richard G. Shapiro as vice presidents of Lord Taylor department store were announced yesterday by Melvin E. Dawley, who recently was named president. The appointments are effective at once.

The stock representing ownership of the eleven-story building at 636 Eleventh Avenue has been sold by Midtown Graphic Arts, Inc., to Alan H. Posner, realty investor. The building, which is occupied by leading printing concerns in the city, occupies the blockfront on the east side of the avenue from Forty-sixth to Forty-seventh Streets.

The New York Young Democratic Club last night endorsed Charles E. McGuinness, reform candidate for district leader in the First Assembly District South. Mr. McGuinness is opposing Carmine G. De Sapio, the incumbent and the leader of Tammany Hall.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Senate voted today to grant G. I. Bill education and home loan benefits to veterans who serve in peacetime. It would apply to all who entered the armed forces after January, 1955.
Combatants in the cigarette industry's brand battle are showing signs of throwing up a menthol marketing mist.
Dr. John B. King, a 50-year-old Negro educator, was nominated yesterday for the post of associate superintendent of schools.
LONDON, July 21 -- The men of England's staid old Law Society, after years of discussion, have decided to enlarge the facilities for women in its venerable gray stone headquarters in Chancery Lane.
An absorbing and chilling television drama of a "pocket," of survivors of an enemy missile attack on the United States has been prepared by the Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., July 21 -- A Federal judge here has taken under advisement the lawsuit of the former "Liz" Whitney, who asked that the Government be forced to explain what's going on in a condemned corner of her Upperville, Va., estate.

Twenty years of ineptness, mismanagement and corruption have brought the Spanish economy to such a pass that help of great magnitude and expert advice and control are needed. This is the simple explanation for the credits of more than $400,000,000 now being extended to Franco Spain by international organizations and banks, the United States Government and private American banks.
The Dominican Republic was denounced by the Inter-American Press Association yesterday for its action against a correspondent of The New York Times.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- President Eisenhower has all but written off a summit meeting with Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev.

Proceeds from a theatre party at the Dec. 10 performance of "Saratoga" will further the work of the Auxiliary of the James Ewing Hospital, an affiliate of Memorial Center for Cancer and Allied Diseases. The musical version of Edna Ferber's novel, "Saratoga Trunk," starring Carol Lawrence is scheduled to open at the Winter Garden on Dec. 7.

CHICAGO, July 21 (UPI) -- Jim Landis' seventh-inning single scored Luis Aparicio from second base tonight for a 2-1 Chicago White Sox victory over Boston. Chicago stayed in a virtual tie for first place in the American League, 2 percentage points behind Cleveland.

TANGERINE walls and splashes of white, black and turquoise furnishings are a feature of a Chinese-modern setting, one of four model living rooms that will go on view today at Gimbels. These rooms, on the ninth floor, mark the opening of the store's mid-summer collection, which is displayed in forty-one freshly decorated traditional and contemporary settings and vignettes.
WEIRTON, W. Va., July 21 -- The Ohio River by night has become, since the steel strike, a dark trench between great mills lying black and silent along its banks.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 21 (AP) -- Charley Neal, whose ninth-inning home run beat the San Francisco Giants yesterday, singled in the ninth today and scored on Gil Hodges' double for a 1-0 Los Angeles victory.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- Acting Secretary of State Douglas Dillon told representatives of the Assembly of Captive European Nations today that the United States refused to accept permanent Soviet domination over Eastern Europe.
GENEVA, July 21 -- The Western powers are prepared to break off the deadlocked Big Four foreign ministers' conference next week if the Soviet Union refuses to budge from its present position.

The Nov. 5 performance of "The Gang's All Here" will benefit the Humane Society of New York. The new Jerome Lawrence-Robert E. Lee play starring Melvyn Douglas is scheduled to open at the Ambassador Theatre on Oct. 1.

The master of the cruise liner Santa Rosa pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges that his negligence had contributed to the collision with the tanker Valchem March 26 off New Jersey. Four members of the tanker's crew were killed in the crash.

CLEVELAND, July 21 -- Losing, 5 -- 1, to the front-running Indians tonight at Municipal Stadium was hardly the way for the Yankees to launch what their manager, Casey Stengel, had termed the season's "most crucial series, so far."

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- General of the Army Omar N. Bradley told a House investigating subcommittee today that Congress should bar Pentagon procurement officers from negotiating contracts for private industry immediately after their retirement.

CAMDEN, N. J., July 21 -- The first Roman Catholic hospital in Atlantic City will be built on a new 700-acre development at the southern end of the city. The development also will have a shopping and business center, houses, apartments and lagoons.

COLLEGE students celebrate when one of their set attains the age of 21 (or 18, depending on the state) and can legally buy alcoholic beverages. Tournament bridge players have a similar custom, but their magic number is 300.
Hawaii borrowed $12,500,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance the construction of highways.
Mrs. Jeanette Toth, owner of a tenement whose tenants were evicted last week by the city because of hazardous conditions, is scheduled to appear in Bronx Municipal Term Court this morning.

BECAUSE of the high nutritive value of liver -- a four-ounce serving supplies more than 100 per cent of the day's requirements for riboflavin, niacin and iron -- many home cooks like to serve it often to their families.

Of the twenty-three members of the editorial board of the learned Soviet publication Botanichesky Zhurnal (The Botanical Journal) all but two have been dismissed recently for alleged hostility to the views of Academician Trofim D. Lysenko.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The United States and Soviet academies of sciences announced today agreement on an extensive exchange of scientists between the two nations.
CHICAGO, July 21 (AP) -- Fairly heavy profit taking braked the recent bullish movement in soybean futures today in the Board of Trade but failed to stop it.
Albert, a pet cockatoo, struck a blow for freedom Sunday night and flapped off into the night from a tenth-floor apartment at the Latham Hotel 4 East Twenty-eighth Street.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Democratic National Committee denied today that it had edited a statement by Gov. Edmund G. Brown of California so as to misrepresent him as critical of the party's Congressional leadership.

PITTSBURGH, Jully 22 (UPI) -- Robin Roberts spun a five-hitter that lifted the Philadelphia Phils to a 4-2 victory over Pittsburgh tonight. The Pirates won, 7-6, in the completion of a suspended game that preceded the scheduled contest.

YONKERS, July 21 -- The most important harness races of the evening, from the standpoint of owners' future hopes and purses involved, took place at Yonkers Raceway tonight before the sun set and while most of the track's spectators were struggling through traffic to get to the Westchester oval.

MAKILING, the Philippines, July 21 (UPI) -- The Philippine Army and the United States Navy helped today to save the Boy Scouts' Tenth World Jamboree from a water shortage, sanitation problems and thieves.
The collection of American art that became something of a battleground before its shipment to the Moscow fair will be on exhibition here in the fall.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Frederick H. Mueller, Under Secretary of Commerce, was nominated today by President Eisenhower to be Secretary of Commerce.

PARIS, July 21 -- Mineral resources of the Sahara will make France self-sufficient in petroleum products by 1963 and an exporter of them a few years later, Deputy Premier Jacques Soustelle told the French Senate today.
LONDON, July 21 -- Sir Roger Makins, former Ambassador to the United States and now Joint Permanent Secretary to the Treasury, has been named to be chairman of the Atomic Energy Authority of Britain.
Gerald Hamilton, 21 years old, of 148 West 142d Street, yesterday offended Magistrate Robert F. Mahoney's faith in human nature.

MILWAUKEE, July 21 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds handed Milwaukee its seventh straight National League setback tonight. They crushed the Braves, 12 -- 2, with a fifteen-hit attack and big Don Newcombe's pitching.
Following are excerpts from the opinion of Federal Judge Frederick vanPelt Bryan yesterday on "Lady Chatterley's Lover":

The Seeburg Corporation, Chicago, maker of coin-operated phonographs, yesterday offered holders of its common stock the right to subscribe to $5,135,000 of twenty-year 5 1/4 per cent convertible subordinated debentures.

It is ironic, in this age of emphasis on communicating, that the effort to convey a thought from one mind to another so often fails. Leave aside the failures that arise because of words that have lost meaning through overwork or imprecise use.
ST. LOUIS, July 21 (AP) -- An unfair-labor-practice charge was filed yesterday against four barge lines in a dispute that has crippled traffic on the country's inland waterways.

MOSCOW, July 20 -- A herd of fat Texas cattle is thriving in Kazakhstan, but agricultural leaders there have failed to take full advantage of the herd's excellent breeding and meat-producing qualities.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 21 -- The Planning and Zoning Commission decided today to find out whether moderate-income families could buy property and build homes here.
Salt water seepage was blamed by the Transit Authority yesterday for Sunday's fire and Monday's signal failure in the East River subway tunnel of the IRT Flushing line.
The vice president of the West Side Tennis Club swore yesterday that the club had adopted a membership policy that was not based on race, creed or national origin.

DANNY McDEVITT is both left-handed and a Dodger. When the team was in Brooklyn, all Dodgers were suspect, particularly left-handers. Yet the aura of wondrous daffiness has not completely deserted them even though they have deserted Flatbush.

LONDON, July 21 -- The London couturiers opened their doors to the press today in a blaze of heat that was better suited to sunbathing on the Riviera than to previewing fall clothes. However, those who have just returned from the Rome collections were already acclimated.
Good news flooded into the stock market yesterday and prices made their best one-day gains since June 10, adding about $2,400,000,000 to the market value of stocks on the New York Stock Exchange.

FLORENCE, Italy, July 21 -- Store buyers and reporters from eleven countries are attending the fashion showings at the imposing Pitti Palace here. Today, the second day of the Florentine collections, was not, with the exception of Carosa, a good day for the American buyer in search of wearable or trend-setting clothes.

Two more links in the metropolitan area's arterial highway system will be opened in forty days unless concrete truck drivers reject a strike settlement that was reached yesterday by union-management negotiators.

LEWISOHN STADIUM offered a Latin-American Night last night, with Carlos Chavez conducting the Stadium Symphony Orchestra and Aldo Parisot as soloist in the Villa-Lobos 'Cello Concerto No. 2 in A minor.
Joe Fields arrives at work at 12:15 P. M. and leaves about 6:20, Monday through Saturday. He earns $183 for a six-day, thirty-six-hour week.
Benjamin Cymrot testified yesterday that he believed, but did not know for a fact, that political influence had played a part in the awarding of certain contracts by the old Bureau of Real Estate.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 21 -- A religious observance set off the disturbances at Kirkuk last week, according to sources close to the official Lebanese delegation that returned from the Iraqi revolutionary anniversary' celebrations yesterday,

Depending on your own age category, a senior golfer can be young or old. But by the official measurement of golfing organizations, a man becomes a senior at either 50 or 55, defending on the rules of the individual association.
BALTIMORE, July 22 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon left for Moscow tonight with the hope of making "some yardage" in talks with the Soviet Union.
THE novelty of last night's concert at Lewisohn Stadium was the debut of Charles K. L. Davis, Hawaiian tenor and winner of the 1958 Metropolitan Opera Auditions of the Air.

RYE. N. Y., July 22 -- Three extra-hole matches marked the second round of the Women's Tri-County Golf Association championship at Apawamis Club today. The other contest ended on the eighteenth green.
An off-duty policeman shot and killed a 16-year-old Bronx boy early last night after the boy had wounded six persons with a blast from a sawed-off shotgun.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI) -- Following is a transcript of the President's news conference today:

World sugar prices rose yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange after two consecutive days of losses. The rise was termed a technical reaction to recent selling induced by uncertainty over Fidel Castro's position in Cuban politics.

LEVITTOWN, L. I., July 22 -- A controversial $10,443,969 budget for the operation of schools here was described by Superintendent of Schools Fred Ambellan today as one that contains "much that is good and much that is tragic for the children, staff and community."

MOSCOW, July 22 -- The man who talked the American National Exhibition into being and off the drawing boards is the man who two years ago talked the Brooklyn Dodgers out of Flatbush. "Impossible" had been the comment of many persons concerning both undertakings, which are a measure of the kind of extracurricular projects favored by Harold Chadick McClellan.
The New York Public Library is preparing to join in a book-burning in September for the good of libraries in general.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson, the majority leader, told the Senate today that a long steel strike could cause tax losses as great as $45,000,000 a week.

TOKYO, July 22 (UPI) -- Japan's swimmers, indicating they are ready to battle Australia and the United States for supremacy at the 1960 Olympics, set a world record in the final event today to defeat an American team in a three-day dual meet, 41 to 38.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI) -- United States military plane crews operating in international air space around the Communist nations have standing orders to shoot back if attacked, the Defense Department made clear today.

Excellent earnings reports -- in contrast with those from the pit of the 1958 recession -- continued to give the stock market a lift yesterday. Aggregate market values on the New York Stock Exchange rose almost $1,000,000,000.

YONKERS, July 22 -- Trader Horn, a 6-year-old brown horse by Worthy Boy-Blue Lass, will be driven by Billy Haughton of Brookville, L. I., when he goes to post as the even-money favorite in the first annual $50,000 national championship trot at Yonkers Raceway tomorrow night.
Encouraging word about the business recovery in Canada and a description of the changing economic forces underlying the improvement has been received from the Bank of Montreal.

The process of setting prices in the oil industry is a bit unusual. In the case of crude oil, for example, the price is set, in effect, by the buyer -- the big refining companies who "post" prices that they will pay. In the end, however, the prices reflect basic conditions of supply and demand.
Readers of The New York Times have seen from time to time a news item to the effect that the American Red Cress recently visited such and such a company and collected so many pints of blood.
WARSAW, July 22 (Reuters) -- Following are excerpts from the text of the joint Soviet-Polish declaration as made public in English tonight by the Polish press agency P. A. P.:
ALBANY, July 22 (AP) -- Beginning Sept. 1, the State University will call its teachers colleges "colleges of education.''
LANSING, Mich., July 22 -- The Michigan House of Representatives passed a flat-rate personal and corporate income tax today.

Twenty-four Cadillac sedans and two Chrysler limousines formerly used by city commissioners and- deputy commissioners were auctioned yesterday. They brought a total of $37,400 from dealers, car-rental companies and private individuals.

Vacation-bound motorists and others drained 2,863,000 barrels of gasoline from the nation's inventories in the week ended last Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 189,859,000 barrels, compared with 192,752,000 a week earlier and 179,556,000 a year ago.
BONN, German, July 22 ( AP) -- West Germany shows every sign of an even greater boom in the second half of this year than in the first, experts say.
The United States Court of Appeal yesterday extended the Post Office ban on "Lady Chatterley's Lover," the romantic novel by D. H. Lawrence, until 4 o'clock Monday afternoon.

THERE is a surprising amount of gunplay in Paul Hyde Bonner's new novel, "The Art of Llewellyn Jones."* The leading character's daughter accidentally blasts him with a fowling piece. He assassinates some doves. And his wife threatens him with one of those purse-concealed pistols that appear in old-fashioned melodramas when domestic relations reach the open-season stage of combat.

The first music scholarship to be awarded from the Mayor's Scholarship Fund will be announced July 31 at a luncheon at Sardi's at which Mayor Wagner will be host. The scholarship will be named in honor of Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d and will provide for a five-year course of study at the Mannes College of Music.

Ernest R. Breech, chairman of the Ford Motor Company, denied yesterday that the concern intended to retire minority shares of its English subsidiary, Such a plan was announced recently for the Company's Canadian unit.

Robert B. Blaikie, former Democratic leader of the Seventh Assembly District, has complained to The New York Times of a "serious omission of information" regarding his role in the Manhattantown Title I slum clearance project.

The United Steelworkers of America, with 500,000 members in basic steel mills, iron ore mines, Great Lakes ore carriers and other operations affected by the stoppage. The union has another 500,000 members in aluminum, can manufacturing and steel fabricating plants whose wages are usually affected by the basic settlement. These plants are not on strike.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 22 -- The most perplexed horseman at Roosevelt Raceway today was Walter Baroncini, the Italian driver from Milan, who will pilot the 7-year-old Icare in the $50,000 International Trot at Roosevelt Raceway on Aug. 1.
WARSAW, July 22 -- The Soviet Union held out the threat today that it would back East Germany in attempts to force the West out of West Berlin unless the "abnormal situation" in the city was ended.

Recent news items have reported opposition to the preliminary plan for the West Side Urban Renewal Area. No plan for the renovation of a neighborhood can be perfect, and certainly changes in any plan are indicated on the basis of valid criticisms.
THANKS in part to Marcel Proust, madeleines are probably the most celebrated of sweets in French pastry-making.

The July 16 article on the Castro regime by your Herbert L. Matthews is unworthy of publication. It is difficult to understand why so distinguished a journalist as Mr. Matthews has seen fit to lower himself to the extent of doing a "whitewash job" for probably the most dangerous man in the Western Hemisphere.
The Alvin Theatre, 250 West Fifty-second Street, has been sold by the Columbia Broadcasting System to Max Stahl and his son Stanley, owners of the Mark Hellinger.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Two thousand, and possibly more, young Americans are expected to be in Vienna next week for the World Youth Festival.
NEW DELHI, India, July 22 -- Indian and Pakistani officials began a trade conference here today.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Two retired Naval officers protested to a House investigating subcommittee today that they were being penalized because the Navy had held that they were salesmen of supplies to the Service.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- The United States may be going through its worst year for poliomyelitis since the Salk vaccine was introduced in 1955.
Of every dollar spent last year by Columbia University 69.3 cents went into teaching and administration. Dr. Grayson, Kirk, the president, told the Columbia College alumni yesterday.

BOSTON, July 22 (AP) -- The Rules Committee of the Massachusetts House reported today it had spent $1,393 on a three - day trip to New York City last month, to obtain "priceless information" on the operation of committee work by the New York legislature.

Directors of the Atlantic City Electric Company yesterday proposed a three-for-two split of the common stock, subject to approval of stockholders at a special meeting on Sept. 9. The split would be effected by the issuance of one additional share for each two shares held.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI) -- An attempt by three French scientists for a United, States patent covering atomic power reactors was rebuffed again this week with a court decision rejecting their claims.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., July 22 -- The second annual Cooks Tour of East Hampton homes, sponsored by the Ladies Village Improvement Society, will be held here on July 30. The tour will be in conjunction with the society's annual one-day fair to be held on the Mulford Farm grounds the next day.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Wednesday, July 15:
United States Government securities moved forward yesterday on a broad front with short-dated securities -- particularly discount bills and the new 4 3/4 per cent notes -- in the lead.

GENEVA, July 22 (Reuters) -- Following are excerpts from speeches by Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union and Secretary of State Christian A. Herter at the foreign ministers' conference:

WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI) -- The House Judiciary Committee beat down Southern opposition today and approved an Administration proposal that would make it a Federal crime to obstruct court-ordered school desegregation.

Your editorial characterization on July 9 of the amendment to the Mutual Security Act, which together with nineteen other Senators I sponsored, as an act of "Congressional irresponsibility" and as a "move to scuttle the whole program" was, to say the least, surprising.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -President Eisenhower confirmed today that he entertained little hope now for a summit meeting. But he said that the road to such a meeting would remain open as long as there was any hope of agreement at the Big Four foreign ministers' conference.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today a conditional railroad rate reduction on soft coal.

ATHENS, July 22 -- Manolis Glezos, a World War II resistance hero, was sentenced today to five years' imprisonment for helping to get Communist spies into Greece. He also was sentenced to four years of exile at an island and deprivation of civil rights for eight years.

SINCE early this year, the Walter Schwimmer organization in Chicago, a company of television producers, has been filming a bridge show to be presented on television. The shooting ended yesterday and the show will be seen, come Oct. 25, every Sunday afternoon at 3:30, Eastern standard time, on the A. B. C. network.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 22 -- The State Legislative Council agreed today to review the state bribery laws as a result of a case involving a policeman here.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- W. Averell Harriman said today he thought the Soviet leaders sought to destroy "everything we believe in."
TUSKEGEE, Ala., July 22 (AP) -- Hopes of being able to sign up as voters grew dimmer for Macon County Negroes today with notice that one of three newly appointed registrars would not serve.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 22 (UPI) -- The Iraqi Government announced today that "the situation has returned to normal" in the revolt-torn Kirkuk district of northern Iraq. It said a committee was making an inquiry there on the week-long Communist-inspired uprising.

Memo to Magistrate Robert F. Mahoney: Gerald Hamilton, 21 years old, of 148 West 142d Street, did not intend to offend your faith in human nature, as newspaper stories implied yesterday. He was just tardy.

Neither heavy rain and lightning, runaway horses, late scratches nor accident to jockey interfered with the completion of the $28,800 Astoria Stakes at Jamaica yesterday. In the face of all those difficulties, the five and a half furlong race for 2-year-old fillies got off only three minutes late.
CAIRO, July 22 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser complained tonight that his recent efforts to be friends with Premier Abdul Karim Kassim of Iraq had met with silence.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- President Eisenhower said today "it's a sorry choice" wheat growers have to make tomorrow in voting on continuance of Federal production controls for the 1960 crop.
A motion to dismiss charges of negligence against Capt. Frank S. Siwik, master of the Grace liner Santa Rosa, was taken under advisement yesterday by a Coast Guard civilian hearing examiner.

PITTSBURGH, July 22 (AP) -- The Jones and Laughlin Steel Corporation reported today new record highs in sales, production, shipments and net income for the second quarter and the first six months of 1959.
HAVANA, July 22 -- New pressures developed here today for Fidel Castro to resume the Premiership of Cuba.

An eleventh-hour addition of a Gilbert Stuart portrait of George Washington was made to a collection of paintings that left New York early this morning for the United States art show at the Moscow fair.

While the sounds of prize-fighters in training filled the Eighth Aveune Gymnasium, once called Stillman's, a pug-nosed little man stood alone in a corner yesterday, watching everything, saying little.
BOSTON, July 22 -- A hearing scheduled today in United States District Court on a Government motion to force Bernard Goldfine to turn over additional books and records was continued indefinitely.
ALBANY, July 22 -- For its first six months with higher passenger car tolls the Thruway showed a net profit of $2,346,482.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- A seasonal increase in food prices pushed the Consumer Price Index up four-tenths of 1 per cent in June to a record high, the Labor Department reported today.
The University System Building Authority of Georgia is planning the sale of $5,877,000 of student housing revenue bonds on Aug. 7. The obligations will come due serially from 1962 to 1989.
Heavy rains pelted the city yesterday and disrupted subway and highway traffic in Brooklyn.

MOSCOW, July 22 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon's jet ride to Moscow will thrust him into the midst of a subtle but vigorous East-West contest here for the attention and sympathies of the Soviet people.
LONDON, July 22 -- British scientists have designed an "entirely new" atomic apparatus in their attempts to extract power from the fusion reaction of the hydrogen bomb.

Production will begin this fall of a seamless metal tubing that can be shipped in ribbon form and inflated at the point of use. The new material, to be known as Strubing, will be turned out by the Wolverine Tube division of Calumet Hecla. Inc., at Allen Park, Mich.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -Measures to remedy labor-management abuses, finance highway construction and authorize a "decent" farm program were given top priority today among bills President Eisenhower wants from Congress.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- A man could make a career of laying things end to end in the National Rifle Association's museum and finding out how far they would reach.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 22 (UPI) -- Mike McCormick, a left-header, set the St. Louis Cardinals down on six scattered hits tonight as the San Francisco Giants snapped a three-game losing streak with a 6-1 victory.

BUENOS AIRES, July 22 -- The longstanding controversy over religious education in Argentina's public schools has flared into an open conflict between the Roman Catholic Church and officials of Cordoba province.

A demand was made yesterday for $8,180,000 in the city's 1960 capital budget to begin a long and costly program to curb the pollution of recreational waters. The allocation was urged by the Mayor's Committee on Elimination of Sources of Marginal Pollution in a letter to the City Planning Commission.
KNOXVILLE, (AP) -- The Tennessee Valley Authority said today that seven concerns had submitted identical bids on its purchase of 33,000 power line insulators.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Thursday, July 23 -- Sweden's Social Democratic government has rejected Soviet charges that it was partly responsible for the opposition to a visit by Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev.
The closing rounds of the annual Professional Golfers Association tournament will be televised by the Columbia Broadcasting System on Aug. 1 and 2. The tournament will be played in Minneapolis.

Jesse Hill Ford of Humboldt, Tenn., has received an Atlantic Grant to work on a novel entitled "The Mountains of Gilead.'' Mr. Ford attended Vanderbilt University and studied writing at the University of Florida.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- About 85,000 veterans are going to split a special $4,000,000 insurance dividend. The payments, starting this month, will average about $50 each.
Obedience trials continue to grow in popularity at dog shows. Invariably the crowd is four deep around the rings where the "educated" dogs are striving to graduate and get their degrees.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- The United States Chamber of Commerce today urged the Senate Finance Committee to approve bills restricting a state's taxing power to a company that had a permanent business establishment in the state.
The Manhattan and Long Island Chapters of the Karen Horney Clinic will benefit by the Oct. 14 evening performance of "The Warm Peninsula" at the Helen Hayes Theatre. The new play stars Julie Harris.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy said yesterday that he would not be pressured into assigning more Negro policemen to Harlem.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board set up a committee today to help streamline and speed its handling of labor-management problems.

The Big Three aluminum companies lined up with the strike-bound steel industry yesterday in rejecting union wage demands. Their action made it probable that the bulk of the country's aluminum production would be halted when present union contracts expire at midnight July 31.
An Eastern Air Lines pistonengined DC-7B veered off a runway at New York International Airport yesterday after touching down on arrival from Miami.

East and westbound trans-Atlantic services were resumed by the Italian Line yesterday. The company's ships had been immobilized for more than six weeks by a world-wide strike of 100,000 seamen that ended Saturday.

CHICAGO, July 22 (AP) -- Sherm Lollar's ninth-inning single enabled the Chicago White Sox to gain a 5-4 triumph over the Boston Red Sox today. Lollar's single sent Nellie Fox home from second with the winning run, hanging the defeat on Leo Kiely, the third of four Boston pitchers.
The Wagner administration is moving on two fronts to speed the reconstruction of the fifty-two-year-old Harlem Hospital, long a subject of bitter controversy in the crowded Harlem area.

With advertising becoming an increasingly large expense for companies, the president of the General Foods Company yesterday took the unusual step of talking to stockholders at length about the subject.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- A retired major general says no enlisted men were assigned to his home in 1957 to baby-sit, wash lingerie and dishes, and clean up after the dog.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, July 22 (Reuters) -- This city's Anglican Bishop, an opponent of the Government's racial segregation policies, said today that he would quit his post and country if the Prime Minister followed suit.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -Congress passed and sent to President Eisenhower today a $3,556,200,000 mutual security authorization for the 1960 fiscal year. It falls $353,200,000 short of the amount sought by the President.
CHICAGO, July 22 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows.
WARSAW, July 22 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev stood today in a great square in Warsaw and all around him -- in stone, in portraits in memories and in men -- was the story of twenty years of Poland.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 22 -- Israel's Minister of Police, Bechor Shalom Shitrit, gave a report to the Knesset (Parliament) today on two outbreaks of rioting that have occurred in the last four days.

John Reese of Hewlett, L. I. and John Galinato of West Point, N. Y., reached the boys 15 years division quarter-finals in the Long Island junior and boys tennis championships at the North Shore Tennis and Racquets Club, Bayside, Queens, yesterday.

Settlement of a two-and-a-half-month strike has enabled the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company to report a record second-quarter profit. R. S. Stevenson, president of the producer of agricultural and earth-moving machinery and industrial equipment, said yesterday the company looked forward to operating at high levels throughout the rest of the year.

BONN, Germany. July 22 -- West German official circles were pessimistic about the trend of the Geneva conference after Foreign Minister Heinrich von Brentano flew here today for a report to Chancellor Konrad Adenauer.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- President Eisenhower, a cattle raiser himself, today told a group of young farmers he was trying to improve the beef industry.

THE furniture, not the decorating ideas, creates the news in twenty-eight room and vignette settings that went on view this week at Abraham Straus. This is not surprising since the designers of the furniture shown arranged the settings.

Stockholders of the General Foods Corporation yesterday elected to the board John A. Sargent, vice president for finance. He was president of the Diamond Alkali Company before joining General Foods in 1957.

LONDON, July 22 (AP) -- Hugh Wiley of Towson, Md., won the King George V Gold Cup at London's inteernational horse show today for the second successive year. It is the show's top prize for men riders.

LONDON, July 22 -- Most oil the industrial leaders went ahead today on the Stock Exchange, although demand generally remained small and selective. Most of the changes were less than a shilling (14 cents) with gains outnumbering losses.
