JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 22 -- The Indonesian Parliament gave itself a new lease on life -- with sharply restricted powers -- by approving today President Sukarno's proposal that it continue functioning within the framework of the 1945 Constitution.

NEWARK, July 22 -- The 21-year-old daughter of a Short Hills, N. J., executive was reported missing early this morning by her parents after she had failed to return home after seeing her fiance off on a plane from Newark Airport.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -President Eisenhower praised Charles E. Bohlen highly again today but offered no definite indication that the Ambassador to the Philippines would be shifted to an important State Department assignment here.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 22 -- Two Negroes registered today at all-white Hall High School in the heart of one of city's better residential sections. Three others enrolled at Central High.
The City Housing Authority yesterday put the peace of mind of its Rockaway tenants above its desire to rush construction of new public housing in the area.

The British Foreign Secretary has given a picturesque but thoroughly accurate description of Soviet policy at Geneva. He calls it "negotiation by equivocation." To every legitimate and necessary question raised by the Western democracies the Soviet answer has been a quibble. Mr. Gromyko refuses to clarify the position of Western rights in Berlin after the expiration of his proposed eighteen months' time limit for exploring the possibility of a settlement.
Northern States Power Company accepted a bid yesterday by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc. and associates for the underwriting of its offering of 952,033 common shares to its stockholders.

Governor Rockefeller continues to stand fast for fiscal responsibility at Albany, the latest evidence being his recent statement in a television appearance broadcast nation-wide that he expected no relief for taxpayers at the 1960 session of the Legislature. The Governor has conceded on several occasions that he probably suffered in political popularity from his tax- increase program, which attempts to put the state back on a pay-as-we-go basis.
PHILADELPHIA, July 22 (AP) -- Longshoremen returned to work today at the port of Philadelphia, ending a nineteen-day tie-up of dry cargo handling.
The extension of the ban on standing vehicles to five more midtown streets got off to a ragged start yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Congress was told today that a nine-month stoppage of the interstate highway construction program was impending unless new funds were provided.

Brooklyn Borough President John Cashmore announced yesterday that his engineering staff had completed a face-lifting project on the Gothic-style anchorage of Brooklyn Bridge in the lower Fulton Street area.
SOUTHOLD, L. I., July 22 -- An exhibition replete with mementoes of bygone childhood life in this quaint 1640 community was opened here today at the Memorial Civic Center.
LOS ANGELES, July 22 (UPI) -- Bob Anderson's five-hit pitching anr Earl Averill's big bat helped the Chicago Cubs score a 7-2 triumph over the second-place Los Angeles Dodgers tonight.
Major changes in the operation of the Board of Education's multimillion-dollar school construction program are under cnsideration.
THE periodic tendency of Mike Wrallace to pursue sensationalism as an end in itself backfired last night over Channel 13.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- President Eisenhower made the following main points at his news conference today:

LONDON, July 22 -- At John Cavanagh's showing of fall fashions this morning, there was an air of excitement and suspense rather than the usual English calm. In fact, the atmosphere was charged with some of the same electricity that hovers over an important Paris showing.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Six witnesses before the House Committee on Un-American Activities declined to answer today when asked if they had taught at the Faculty of Social Science in New York City.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 22 -- Alex Olmedo is going to take a rest from tournament tennis next week, free from the tension and pressure that brought about his unhappy experience in the national clay court championships at the River Forest Club, Chicago.

CLEVELAND, July 22 -- On display on a stand in a public square in Shaker Heights, a swanky suburb out this way, is a black-covered, fern-topped coffin. Tacked on is a crudely-painted cardboard sign that proclaims: "Here lay the Yankees."

LONDON, July 22 -- The Labor party assailed the British Government's policy toward Central Africa on a wide front today, but centered its attack on the commission proposed yesterday for preparing next year's constitutional review for the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland.
FLORENCE, Italy, July 22 -- All seats in the Sala Bianca of the Pitti Palace were filled today. Buyers were rigidly alert in their chairs and reporters were ready with an extra sharpened pencil.
PARIS, July 22 -The Permanent Council of the Atlantic Alliance heard and approved today an explanation by the British Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd of the Western position in Geneva.
One hundred patrolmen were appointed to the Transit Authority police force yesterday, bringing the organization to its full quota of 916 members.

PRINCETON, N. J., July 22 -- A tiny fragment of bone found half a century ago in an Egyptian quarry has been identified by a Princeton University paleontologist as part of the skull of a 35,000,000-year-old squirrel-sized monkey.

CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, July 22 -- Pope John XXIII inaugurated a new audience building at his summer residence here tonight. Pilgrims and tourists from the United States were prominent among the 8,000 visitors who filled the hall to capacity.

IN THE life of almost every woman there comes a time when she will shop long and feverishly for one dress, wear it for a few hours and remember it for the rest of her life. Last night, the search fo rthis dress -- a wedding gown -- ended for many prospective fall brides.

PORTLAND, Ore., July 22 (AP) -- Eddie Machen of Portland scored a technical knockout over Reuben Vargas of San Francisco in the sixth round of their heavyweight fight here tonight. Machen weighed 197 pounds; Vargas, 195.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 22 -- Run over over a track made slow by afternoon rain, the Elkcam Stable's Atoll took the fourteenth running of the Lamplighter Handicap at Monmouth Park today by three and a half lengths.
The Soviet Union's seventy-three visiting track and field athletes who competed against the United States team in Philadelphia last week-end went on a sight-seeing tour of New York yesterday.

Firstamerica Corporation, Los Angeles, largest bank holding company in the country, has reported consolidated net operating earnings for the six months ended June 30 of $11,086,778, or 79 cents a share on the average number of shares outstanding.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 22 -- The youngsters, whose Larchmont Race Week sailing activities are normally confined to morning races, had Long Island Sound to themselves today.
The Citizens Union has called for the release of a grand jury presentment on television quiz shows on the ground that there was suspicion that the public had been "hoaxed" by the shows.
If present trends continue, ten years from now the Soviet Union will lead the United States in many broad areas of science and will be far ahead of this country in terms of trained manpower.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- President Eisenhower's thoughts on the inflationary potential of steel prices, as reported on his authority in a dispatch to this newspaper today, reveal the steadfastness of his view that great companies have, and have failed to take, the opportunity to check inflation that the unions will not initiate because of labor politics.
Charles Garside announced his resignation yesterday as president and chairman of the board of the Associated Hospital Service of New York, the official name of the local Blue Cross plan.
A survey on the uses of gross and net tonnage measurements of ocean-going vessels began yesterday.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 22 (AP) -- Mrs. Jan Burke's Whodunit came through with a drive in the stretch today to win the $109,800 Sunset Handicap as the favorite, 9-year-old Find, ran third in the closing-day feature at Hollywood Park.
MOUNT MORRIS, N. Y., July 22 (AP) -- An Air Force helicopter searching for an elderly professor crashed in the wooded gorge of the Genesee River today. The three men aboard were killed.
An oak tree blight is sweeping southeastern New York State Long Island, and parts of North Jersey, Connecticut and Massachusetts.
WELL, now, it does look as though we are going to have a most lively summer after all. Should top 1958 quite easily.
Pacific Lighting Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday that "winter weather of extreme warmth" had adversely affected operations in the twelve months ended on June 30.
HONOLULU, July 22 -- An uncertain shadow has been cast by James R. Hoffa over Hawaii's first state election campaign.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that he would probably confer this week-end with Robert Moses, chairman, and Thomas J. Shanahan, vice chairman, of his much-criticized Committee on Slum Clearance.
New, streamlined contract negotiations between the International Longshoremen's Association and Atlantic and Gulf Coast waterfront employers will begin on Aug. 10.

OTTAWA, July 22 (Canadian Press) -- A sharp increase in commodity exports to the United States lifted Canada into a better export position in the first six months of this year, although shipments to all other countries fell.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 22 -- The movie industry apparently is determined to get to the 1961 Civil War centennial lastest with the mostest. Some studios, perhaps impelled by the rebel yells in "The Horse Soldiers," at movie houses, are showing interest in the subject.

Grand Central Terminal, a place of surge and rush, provides seventy-five clocks for its public to hurry by. The best known, the four-faced Golden Clock atop the information desk on the Main Concourse serves a double purpose. It lures lagging feet to the train gate and is a favored meeting place for travelers.
TRENTON, July 22 -- The New Jersey Appellate Division of the State Superior Court ruled today that two prominent housing developers could not bar Negroes from purchasing their homes.

CHICAGO, July 22 (AP) -- The first heavy selling of soybean futures in almost two weeks dealt the near contracts a hard blow today on the Board of Trade, but the distant months continued their steady climb.

ORANGE, N. J., July 22 -The City Planning Board today proposed municipal spending of about $16,000,000 over the next twenty to thirty years to assure healthy growth, investment and prosperity for the community.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 22 -- President Juscelino Kubitschek made changes in his Cabinet today as the Presidential election campaign got under way.
LONDON, July 22 -- The vicar and church wardens of Selby Abbey cannot accept Sir Jacob Epstein's huge religious statue, "Ecce Homo," even as a gift.
United States savings certificates worth $30,000 and jewelry worth $6,000 were reported stolen yesterday from an apartment in Peter Cooper Village.
EAST ORANGE, N. J., July 22 -- Workmen completed demolition of the forty-foot chimney atop Clifford J. Scott High School here today.

ALBANY, July 22 - Speaker Joseph F. Carlino of the Assembly predicted today that there would be enough votes in the Legislature next year to approve the Governor's program against housing discrimination.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- President Eisenhower quickly dispelled the mystery today about newspaper accounts purporting to give his views on the possibility of a summit conference, on taxes, on setting the steel strike and on sundry other political probrems.

Mrs. Jeanette Toth pleaded guilty yesterday to sixty violations in a tenement she owns at 536 East 134th Street, the Bronx. Magistrate Samuel Ohringer, in Bronx Municipal Term Court, set sentencing for Aug. 12.
MADRID, July 22 (Reuters) -- A decree announcing heavier taxes and curbs on monopolistic practices was announced today.

GENEVA, July 22 -- Andrei A. Gromyko made some concessions to the Western powers in the foreign ministers' conference today. But the Allies found them inadequate. The Soviet Foreign Minister gave ground on two issues that had deadlocked the conference and had led the Allies to threaten to break off the negotiations.
NORWALK, Conn., July 23 -- Juvenile patrons at the Norwalk Public Library will have the opportunity to broaden their horizons through the recommendations of a new children's librarian.
LONDON, July 23 (UPI) -- The United States won the Prince of Wales Cup today at the Royal Horse Show, completing a sweep of the two major international trophies for the second straight year.

In 1947 Kevin Andrews, a young American, was graduated from Harvard with an A. B. in classics and literature and a traveling fellowship to study classical archaeology in Athens. For the next four and a half years he followed that pursuit throughout Greece, alone and mostly on foot.

CHICAGO, Friday, July 24 -- Miss Jacqueline Gay Hart, 21-year-old daughter of a prominent Short Hills, N. J., business executive, who had been missing since Tuesday night, was found dazed and incoherent early this morning in Grant Park, near this city's Outer Drive.
GENEVA, July 23 -- The Big Four foreign ministers agreed today to resume secret negotiations for an interim settlement of the Berlin crisis.
CARACAS, Venezuela, July 23 -- The Government introduced an agrarian reform bill today. It was expected to become law without major changes.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 23 (UPI) -- Members of a new Macon County Board of Registrars have refused to serve for fear of being "hounded" by the United States Civil Rights Commission, Gov. John Patterson said today.

Air traffic at New York International Airport was disrupted for several hours during a fog yesterday. A damaged plane alongside the instrument-landing runway made instrument landings hazardous, airport authorities ruled.

The Oct. 20 performance ofl '"ne Gang's All Here" has beenl chosen by the New York Alum-i nae of the Shipley School in Bryn Mawr, Pa., for the group's eighth annual theatre, benefit. The new play starring Melvyni Douglas is scheduled to open at: the Ambassador Theatre onl Oct. 1.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J. July 23 -- A state law that would ban discrimination in private housing was proposed here today by the New Jersey Committee Against Discrimination in Housing.

The public's fancy for small, economy cars is resulting in a sales and earnings bonanza for the American producers of the compact models. This is underscored by the latest showing of American Motors Corporation and Studebaker-Packard Corporation, the two domestic makers in the field.
PITTSBURGH, July 23 -- The first public relief check to a striking steelworker was written here Wednesday by George P. Mills, executive director of the Allegheny County Board of Assistance.

Lumber production rose to 228,555,000 board feet last week from a seven-month low of 199,101,000 the week before, according to reports received by The New York Times from regional associations. This compares with 224,251,000 board feet produced in the like week last year.

LAST May when "Prayer for an Assassin," by Igor Sentjurc, was published, I was so busy reading biographies of Sir Alexander Flemming and Kenneth Grahame and novels about emotionally unstable women and the Third World War that I overlooked it. Such oversights are unavoidable in the book-reviewing realm and nothing can be done to prevent them. Too many professionally competent books are published.
The recovery in national advertising volume is continuing to gain momentum. The Printers' Ink index yesterday showed a 6 per cent rise for the period through May from the level of a year before.

LOS ANGELES, July 23 (UPI) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers scored a costly victory tonight, defeating the Chicago Cubs, 5 -- 3, but losing their first baseman, Gil Hodges, for at least a week with an injured right leg.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Frol Kozlov, on his recent visit to the United States, confided privately that the Soviet Union was cutting back its nuclear power program because of the unexpectedly high cost of atomic energy.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The House completed congressional action today on a Democratic sponsored bill to let the Tennessee Valley Authority finance its own operations through bond issues. Approval came on a voice vote.
CARACAS, Venezuela, July 23 -- Formal accusations of malfeasance and criminal acts against former President Marcos Perez Jimenez were introduced in Federal Court here today.

Some Indians finished putting up the steelwork for a forty-story building in the financial district yesterday, and they sent up smoke signals to invite some other Indians a block away to come on over and celebrate.

The controversy over possible adverse effects of tobacco smoking has not prevented the American Tobacco Company from setting new records in sales and earnings for the three and six months ended June 30.
Edward R. Murrow, radio and television commentator, made application yesterday for a commission in the United States Naval Reserve.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The Treasury's huge $14,000,000,000 refunding operation this week was a smashing success.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 23 (UPI) -- The league-leading San Francisco Giants took advantage of three errors to score four unearned runs today and beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 5 -- 1, for a sweep of the two-game set.
CHICAGO, July 23 -- Belt tightening in preparation for a long ordeal was the general reaction among the 90,000 idle workers in the Chicago area's vast steel industry today.
VIENNA, July 23 -- The land, air and river invasion of Vienna has begun on a big scale.
DETROIT, July 23 -- This is a bad summer for weeds in the back yards of Ecorse, Trenton, Wyandotte and River Rouge, Mich.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (UPI) -- The Army said today it had an experimental plastic glue designed to repair broken bones and get a patient on his feet in two days.

Two more banks announced plans yesterday for major offices in the midtown area. The Bankers Trust Company said it planned to occupy a new twenty-six-story building on the west side of Park Avenue between Forty-eighth and Forty-ninth Streets.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 23 (UPI) -- United States track and field stars won the five events they entered today in Helsinki's "July Games" before 8,000 fans.

The Board of Monitors, appointed by Federal Judge Letts to help do away with dictatorship and corruption in the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, is now entering a new phase in its operations that bears evidence of increased power and effectiveness. It stems from the recent decision of the Federal Court of Appeals sustaining Judge Letts' power to enforce recommendations of the board.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The Senate voted, 49 to 42, today to send back to committee a bill to amend the student loyalty oath provision of the Defense Education Act. The vote, in effect, killed the bill for this session of Congress.

CHICAGO, July 23 (AP) -- A soaking general rain in most of the driest areas of the Midwest brought the strongest selling pressure in more than two weeks today into soybean futures on the Board of Trade.
" Little Joe" Burke, bright-eyed, cheerful and 7 weeks old, attended a convention of men and women in wheel chairs at the New Yorker Hotel yesterday.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., July 23 (AP) -- Engineers of the General Electric Company plan to open the New York State Fair gates Sept. 4 by receiving a signal from the Vanguard satellite as it whirls overhead 2,000 miles away.
Strict enforcement, including the towing away of offenders' vehicles, will start today on five midtown streets where standing vehicles have been banned since Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (UPI) -- The Soviet Union now claims a world altitude record for airplanes of 94,333 feet, the Soviet Embassy said today.
Resentment over Negro girls' dating Puerto Rico boys was said by the police to be the possible reason for a shooting in the Bronx Wednesday.
CLEVELAND, July 23 -- Eli Grba, the young man who somewhere along the line lost a vowel or two, lost his first decision as a Yankee tonight.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- James P. Mitchell, the President's one-man fact finder in the steel strike dispute, disclosed today that he was directing an almost Government-wide study.
The leasehold on the twelve-story Great Northern Hotel at 109 to 121 West Fifty-sixth Street has been purchased from the Grenor Company by a syndicate represented by Charles H. Kelman, lawyer.
HAVANA, July 23 -- Normal activities in Cuba came to a standstill for an hour this morning in an impressive demonstration of support for Dr. Fidel Castro.

Favorable earnings statements, even more favorable forecasts of future earnings and the biggest crops of stock-split rumors in recent weeks helped a hesitant stock market yesterday. Stocks closed about where they had opened, with small gains.
LOS ANGELES, July 23 -- "People seem to be buying and eating as much as usual," a grocer in outlying Fontana said this week, in a typical commentary on the steel strike.

WARSAW, July 23 -- A misty-eyed Premier Khrushchev ended a hectic tour of Poland today, leaving behind him massive political gifts for his Polish Communist host and a threat of new nerve warfare against the West.
TRENTON, July 23 -- A broad outline of proposals to end the commuter crisis was released today by the New Jersey Division of Railroad Transportation.
A higher average copper price was a big factor in doubling the half-year earnings of the Kennecott Copper Corporation as compared with the 1958 level.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 23 -- Seventeen Negroes registered without incident today at three senior high schools that once accepted only white students.

BALTIMORE, Md., July 23 -- Baltimore's 31,000 striking steel workers are drawing their last full pay checks this week. The total for the week will be $3,500,000, but, if the strike runs long, it will have to stretch for the duration.

MANILA, July 23 -- Ambassador Charles E. Bohlen is confronted with another irritant in Philippines-American relations involving military base negotiations. The Ambassador is withholding a formal protest against allegations of "murder" by Clark Air Force Base authorities.
MILWAUKEE, July 23 (AP) -- Willie Jones hit a bases-loaded home run with two out in the eighth for a 6-2 victory by the Cincinnati Reds tonight over the Milwaukee Braves.
Leland Hayward will produce a special show titled "The Fabulous Fifties" for telecast by C. B. S. on Jan. 17 from 8 to 9:30 P. M., the network announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Leadings of revenue freight last week totaled 585,070 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

Senator Richard L. Neuberger recently reported that in fifty-four countries where our Ambassadors have posts, twenty-four of them "were not easily conversant in the primary native language and that eleven could speak it only haltingly." If our career diplomats function at such a precarious linguistic level, what can be said for the more numerous, ubiquitous nonofficial ambassadors observing life abroad -- the tourists?

Initial steps were taken here yesterday for the formation of a new electrical-electronics-pharmaceutical company with a net worth of some $50,000,000 and initial sales of more than $90,000,000 a year.
LANSING, Mich., July 23 (AP) -- The Republican-controlled Michigan Senate by a vote of 21-12 today turned down a House-approved state income tax.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Cpl. Charles Melvin Price was doing K. P. duty at Camp Lee, Va., on the night of Nov. 7, 1944, when he received orders to report immediately to the general. "Corporal," the general said, "you have just been elected to Congress, sir."
A team of city inspectors has turned up 535 housing and health violations in twenty-six tenements in the Chelsea area, the Mayor's office reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Sam Rayburn, the Speaker of the House, asserted today that the Federal Reserve authorities considered themselves "immune to any direction or suggestion by the Congress."
Evert Schneider of the Netherlands gained the junior division semi-finals of the Long Island junior and boys' championships yesterday at the North Shore Tennis and Racquets Club, Bayside, Queens.
With the Treasury's $13,973,000,000 refunding out of the way, gilt-edge, short-term debt investments accelerated their movement to lower yields yesterday.
OSSINING, N. Y., July 23 -- Leroy Keith, who was sentenced to death for murder twenty-five years ago, died tonight in the electric chair at Sing Sing Prison for a second slaying.
Using what it calls an electronic model of the United States' economy, the Econometric Institute, Inc., pulled some interesting predictions out of a computer yesterday.
STAMFORD, Conn., July 23 -- An observatory containing a twenty-inch telescope available for public use will be constructed at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center on High Ridge Road.

The Pennsylvania and the New York Central Railroads, the No. 1 and 2 of the industry, finished the first half of 1959 well in the black. In the first half of last year, each system reported a deficit of more than $25,000,000.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The Government estimated today that economic activity climbed to a record yearly rate of $483,500,000,000 in the second quarter of this year.
LONDON, July 23 -- Michael is the London designer with the most international clientele. Anyone looking for a really chic little suit would find her heart's delight at this house.

MOSCOW, July 23 -- Technicians at the United States exposition were hectically putting the last exhibits into place as Vice President Richard M. Nixon arrived here today. Mr. Nixon will open the American National Exhibition tomorrow.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 23 -- Romance has come to Dr. Lemuel Gulliver more than 200 years after his creator, Jonathan Swift, turned him loose in "Gulliver's Travels."
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Retired high-ranking officers of the armed services who took big-money jobs in defense industries told a House subcommittee today that they were in effect, driven to them.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Reports from the Canadian duck breeding grounds in the next few weeks may be the deciding factor in whether hunters of the Eastern flyway will have a shortened season or even a curtailed daily bag limit this year.
YOUNGSTOWN, July 23 -- A $15,000,000 windfall resulting from the payment of retroactive supplemental unemployment benefits will help Ohio's steelworkers survive the strike.
CLEVELAND, July 23 -Steel workers in the Cleveland-Lorain area are tightening their belts, slashing expenditures, seeking extension of overdue bills and digging in for a long strike.
ROME, July 23 -- Crusades against noise are assuming a new urgency in a sleep-starved Italy.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- The Treasury opposed today the financing of the interstate highway construction program through special highway bonds.

The second mate of the Grace liner Santa Rosa pleaded not guilty in a Coast Guard hearing yesterday to a charge of contributory negligence in the collision of the liner with the tanker Valchem last March 26.

In the first half of this year the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company had record earnings of $28,704,805, or $8.27 a share. J. L. Mauthe, chairman, has said that the showing reflected benefits from investments in new facilities over recent years that were fully utilized for the first time.

CLEVELAND, July 23 (AP) -- Wage negotiation will start with the United States Rubber Company in Cincinnati Aug. 25 and with Firestone Tire and Rubber Company here Aug. 31, the United Rubber Workers Union announced today.
This week, the tenth anniversary of our ratification of NATO, finds the domestic battle still going on as to how much and what kind of mutual aid we shall support.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (UPI) Attorney General William P. Rogers said today it would be only "fair play" to require members of Congress to make their contacts with Federal agencies in the open and "on the record."
WASHINGTON, Friday, July 24 -- Wheat farmers embraced for the seventh consecutive year yesterday the control and price support program that the Administration had condemned.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 23 -- Pete Bordes, a 31-year-old radioman who lives in Greenwich Village and has no formal club affiliation, continued as an outstanding skipper at Larchmont Race Week today.
MOSCOW, July 23 -- A visitor from the United States -- TOCNOARH HUKCOH to the Russians and Mister Nixon to you -- has arrived in Moscow at a delicate moment.
YONKERS. July 23 -- Ground will be broken Wednesday at 4 P. M. for the $10,000,000 Andrus Pavilion at St. John's Riverside Hospital here.

The United Steelworkers of America, with 500,000 members in basic steel mills, iron ore mines, Great Lakes ore carriers and other operations affected by the stoppage. The union has another 500,000 members in aluminum, can manufacturing and steel fabricating plants whose wages are usually affected by the basic settlement These plants are not on strike.
CHICAGO, July 23 -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 23 -- A six-under-par 65 sent Tom Nieporte of Bronxville, N. Y., into the first-round lead of the Westchester open golf championship today.

FLORENCE, Italy, July 23 -- The frenzy of the Italian fall and winter fashion collections has ended. With the showing of Capucci last night and of Pucci, Enzo and Baratta this afternoon, we now have the complete Italian fashion picture.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., July 23 -- Judge Alexander P. Robertson of Warren County Surrogates Court reserved decision today on two procedural questions in an attempt by two grandnieces and a grandnephew of Mrs. Helen E. Foulds to break her will.
One of the minor miracles of modern living, the electronic eye, is being put to good use in pleasure boating. An automatic anchor light has been devised that turns on at dusk and shuts off at dawn.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 23 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold said today that he entertained "the warmest hopes" that the Geneva conference would end "on a happy note."

Loans to business by the larger New York City banks increased $40,000,000 to $9,710,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This was a drop of $209,000,000 since the first of the year but an increase of $7,000,000 since mid-year.
TROY, N. Y., July 23 (AP) -- Youth took over the New York State men's amateur golf championship today. Three of the state's leading players were defeated in the second round.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Following is the text of a statement by Vice President Richard M. Nixon, prepared for delivery on arrival at Voiukovo airport, Moscow:
A substantial increase of foreign operations, beginning with a major new plant in Italy, was announced yesterday by Cyanamid International, a division of American Cyanamid Company.

A teen-ager who confessed that he had "finished off" Julio Ramos, a 25-year-old Cuban, after six other youths had attacked the man in an East Harlem park last year, received a prison sentence yesterday of seven and one half to twenty years.
The American Heart Association announced yesterday that it would form a committee of physicians, scientists and community leaders to study the problem of multiple health appeals.
GARDINERS ISLAND, L. I., July 23 -- Reports of rapidly decreasing numbers of the colorful osprey, or fishhawk, are disturbing local ornithologists.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- Secretary Ezra Taft Benson announced today that the Agriculture Department's voluntary program of grading lamb and mutton carcasses would be continued.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Following is the letter of transmittal sent to President Eisenhower with the third interim report of the President's Committee to Study the United States Military Assistance Program:

The Brooklyn Union Gas Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues for three, six and twelve months ended on June 30. However, higher operating expenses offset the revenue gains so that net income for the quarter and the half trailed the like 1958 levels.

JERSEY CITY, July 23 -- Two hundred and fifty persons, four-fifths of them Negroes, packed a courtroom to capacity today to hear complaints of assault and battery made against four Jersey City patrolmen by three Negroes.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The Administration ran into criticism from within its own postpone development of a nuclear-powered airplane.

LONDON, July 23 -- R. A. Butler, Home Secretary, ruled today that the diaries of Sir Roger Casement might soon be examined by qualified experts, but would not be open for public inspection for 100 years.
LONDON, July 23 -- The demand for industrials increased on the stock market here today stimulated by Wednesday's Wall Street advance.
TEL AVIV, Israel, July 23 -- Leaders of Reform Judaism in the United States charged here today that similar movements in Israel were encountering discrimination.

LOS ANGELES, July 23 -- The American Federation of Musicians and its Los Angeles Local 47 petitioned the National Labor Relations Board District office here today to call a new representation election among 1,400 musicians employed in Hollywood's major film studios.
The addition of phosphates to animal diets has markedly reduced tooth decay in laboratory experiments, a Massachusetts Institute of Technology professor said yesterday.
LONDON, July 23 -- An attempt will be made tomorrow to cross the English Channel in Britain's new Hovecraft, the saucer-like contraption that scuds over land or water on a tight cushion of air.
A proposal for an "economy panel" of citizens to serve as watchdogs over public works construction was put before the Board of Estimate yesterday by City Council President Abe Stark.

The Railway Express Agency filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday for an increase in rates and charges on less-than-carload shipments. If approved, the rise would yield some $20,586,000 a year, assuming no diversion in traffic because of the increase.

RABAT, Morocco, July 23 -- Reports circulated today that the long-awaited meeting of President Charles de Gaulle of France and King Mohammed V of Morocco, scheduled Aug. 3, was in doubt and might be long delayed.
YOUNGSTOWN, N. Y., July 23 -- Lieut. Gov. Malcolm Wilson, for five years a $25-a-week tour guide at Old Fort Niagara, returned here today as the Acting Governor of the state.
MOSCOW, July 23 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon pledged on his arrival here today that he would work for better understanding between the United States and the Soviet Union.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., July 23 -- When the weather clears, the trout and bass in well stocked near-by Pocono Mountain lakes and streams will become innocent victims of the steel strike.

BONN, Germany, July 23 -- The President of West Germany and his elected successor assured Dr. Joachim Prinz, president of the American Jewish Congress, in separate talks today that anti-Semitism had little support in this country.

HENDERSON, N. C., July 23 (AP) -- A North Carolina judge sentenced three textile union leaders today to prison terms of from six to ten years as the ringleaders in a conspiracy to blow up vital installations at the Harriet-Henderson Cotton Mills.

A MOST extraordinary sports spectacle will be unveiled for public entertainment a week from tomorrow night. It will be the first international harness-racing event ever staged in this country. Trotters from France, Italy, Sweden, Norway and Germany, as well as Canada's Philip Frost and Trader Horn, the United States entrant, will compete in a mile-and-a-half race at Roosevelt Raceway.

A "feeling" among traders that Cuba would change its selling policy and withhold some supplies of sugar caused world sugar prices to rise yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Final prices were up 1 to 11 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 29,250 tons.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 23 -- Alex Olmedo reached the quarter-finals of the Pennsylvania lawn tennis championships at the Merion Cricket Club today as play was transferred to the turf courts for the first time in the tournament following three days of rain.
Pay checks for work done before the steel strike started are still going out to many of the 500,000 workers.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Two Republican Senators joined Democrats today in assailing President Eisenhower's veto message on the omnibus housing bill as deliberately misleading.
CHICAGO, July 23 (UPI) -- For the ninety - second time, surgeons operated on Dr. Emil Grubbe today for cancer.

In his letter published July 16 former Governor Herbert Lehman sets the admirable goal of "improvement in the present method of selecting judges to the end that most qualified judges may be chosen without concern for party politics." He then properly adds,"* * * this is more simply said than done."

Your July 16 editorial on Khru shchev's visit to Poland refers to territories east of the Oder-Neiss frontier which, you say, "the Polis. Communist regime annexed at Soviet instigation." You refer also to the German expellees from those lands whose political spokesmen (though they have been miraculous; absorbed into the life and the economy of West Germany these four teen years past) claim for them "Heimatrecht," or right of return.
ALBANY, July 23 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller set up a five-member committee today to look into the controversy over the licensing of milk dealers.

Mustato came through with an effervescent performance in the Dry Monopole Handicap at Jamaica yesterday. The 5-year-old horse owned by Mrs. Thomas Waller established a track record for the mile and a sixteenth in beating four rivals before a crowd of 18,078.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- Supreme Court Justice Felix Frankfurter delayed a decision today on a plea by the Teamsters Union for a stay of an order arming court-appointed monitors with wide clean-up powers.

YONKERS, July 23 -- Trader Horn, the 7-year-old stallion who has been beating rivals consistently in recent weeks, did it again tonight, scoring an impressive triumph in the $50,000 National Championship Trot at Yonkers Raceway.

Twelve young American composers have received Ford Foundation fellowships to enable them to serve in twelve different high school systems during the forthcoming school year, the Ford Foundation announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- A battle-scarred labor reform bill emerged from the House Education and Labor Committee today by a vote of 16 to 14.
LONDON, July 23 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan told the House of Commons today it would be unwise to set any time limit for the four-power foreign ministers' conference in Geneva.

One of the major mysteries in the world of commercial food packaging is why most of the spice packaging in this country continues to be as inept and outmoded as a button hook. Literally, tons of spices whose only virtues are their flavors are sold each year in porous paper boxes or metal cans with ineffective seals.
OCEANPORT, N. J., July 23 -- Monmouth Park was doubly drenched today, once by rain and then by a flow of affection that greeted James E. (Sunny Jim ) Fitzsimmons on his eighty-fifth birthday.
ALBANY, July 23 -- Governor Rockefeller has revived a special committee created by the previous administration to study changes in the state law on criminal insanity.
There is talk of bringing "Macbeth" to Broadway for a limited period with Jason Robards Jr. and Siobhan McKenna in the leading roles.

The first trial in a Federal Court involving the Invention Secrecy Act of 1951 resulted in a decision here yesterday against the Government and in favor of a Bronx manufacturer of optical instruments, specifically bombsights.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., July 23 -- There was a sell-out here today of all paperback copies of Maxine Davis' "The Sexual Responsibility of Woman" following a police ban placed on the copies yesterday in adjoining Rockport.

Operating in high gear in the second quarter, the Chrysler Corporation rolled up consolidated net earnings of $58,000,000 in the first half of this year. For the similar six months a year earlier the automotive producer showed a net loss of $25,239,802, after a tax credit of $27,000,000.
Dr. Charles W. Hughes, who was dismissed by Hunter College in 1954 during an investigation into alleged Communist activities on the campus, was reinstated yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Bartley C. Crum repudiated today any inference that he made imputed an attempted bribe or unethical deal to Edward Bennett Williams.
ALGIERS, July 23 -- French land, sea and air forces have begun what is described as the biggest offensive of the Algerian war in the wooded, mountainous Kabylia region east of here.

Robert F Williams suspended president of the Union County, N. C., branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, announced yesterday that he would not take court action for reinstatement.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Fresh charges of waste, inefficiency and bad administration throughout the foreign-aid program were published today by a House Appropriations subcommittee.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- James Stewart, the film star, won promotion today to the rank of Brigadier General in the Air Force Reserves.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- A Presidential committee recommended today the creation of a single agency to administer the major programs of foreign economic aid.
General Electric Company scientists yesterday demonstrated a new device that they described as the most important advance in the field of electronics since the transistor.
New York's biggest redeveloper of local slum areas, Webb Knapp, Inc., is preparing to undertake its fourth Title I project -- the Bellevue South housing cooperative of 2,000 units.

ALBANY, July 23 -- Key Republican leaders across the state have made secret pledges to support Governor Rockefeller for the Presidential nomination in 1960. The pledges were obtained early this month by State Chairman L. Judson Morhouse.

The British Government, led by Conservative Prime Minister Macmillan, is beginning to grapple with one of the knottiest of all the complex and delicate African problems. This is what to do next year when a review has to be made of the status of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland, commonly known as the Central African Federation.
TORONTO, July 23 -- The lucrative coal import trade between Lake Erie ports and Toronto is in danger of drying up.
MORRISVILLE, Pa., July 23 -- For the strikers at the Fairless Works of the United States Steel Corporation the mailman had no back-pay checks today.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., July 23 -- Forty-one acres of an estate have been offered to the Town of New Canaan for use as a public park and bird sanctuary, the Board of Selectmen announced today.

SANTIAGO, Chile, July 23 -- Finance Minister Roberto Vergara Herrera, who recently returned from a trip to the United States, Britain, West Germany and France, said today credits he had obtained in the four countries amounted to nearly $300,000,000.
NORWICH, Conn., July 23 -- Striking workers returned to the Public Works Department today after accepting a City Council offer for a temporary wage increase.

Despite widespread fair employment and educational laws, Jews are "virtually barred" from executive jobs in major insurance companies, banks and public utilities, a civil rights expert said yesterday.

CAIRO, July 23 -- The United Arab Republic paraded its tanks, guns and soldiers in a three-hour parade down Cairo's Nile Corniche today. Overhead, nearly 200 Soviet-made MIG jets and light bombers flew by a few minutes after the Republic's military commander had challenged any invader to test the country's "devastating striking power."

BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 23 (Reuters) -- Rashid Ali Gailani, leader of the 1941 pro-Nazi revolution in Iraq, has been sentenced to be hanged for attempting to overthrow Premior Abdul Karim Kassim's regime by a coup planned for last Dec. 9, the Baghdad press announced today.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (UPI) -- The Mercury astronauts will wear $3,750 outfits consisting of a pressure suit made for the Navy and air-conditioned underwear made for the Air Force.
Frogmen of the Royal Canadian Navy have completed initial underwater blasting to clear the entrance to Goose Bay in northern Labrador.

This country's textile industry is making rapid progress in recovering from the depressed conditions that have been the rule since 1951, it was asserted yesterday by Spencer Love, chairman and president of Burlington Industries, Inc.

LONDON, July 23 -- The British Government's Commission of Inquiry into last winter's violence in Nyasaland rejected today the Colonial Office charge that African nationalists had planned a "massacre" of officials, European settlers and others opposed to their movement.
BUFFALO, July 23 -- Idle steel workers in the Buffalo area are losing about $2,325,000 a week in wages.
The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association has decided to take legal action against Police Corn-: missioner Stephen P. Kennedy to obtain a dues check-off system for its members.
ALBANY, July 23 -- The Rockefeller Administration's economy drive, heretofore confined largely to eliminating calling cards and gold printing on book covers, is shifting to bigger game.

The recent trouble in Harlem has highlighted the problems of this community. While they can be described as racial, they are also problems of the city's newest immigrant groups, the Negroes and the Puerto Ricans.
The Eastern Air Lines plane that veered off a runway at New York International Airport Wednesday was put aboard a flatbed truck and hauled to a hangar yesterday.

CHARLES J. SOLOMON of Philadelphia has won many honors as a bridge player and in the organization of tournament bridge. Heretofore he has been most celebrated as a bridge husband, for he and Mrs. Solomon constitute the highest-ranking husband-and-wife pair in bridge annals.

Eight persons were arrested yesterday and charged early today in a city-wide raid on an abortion ring. Two men and two women were charged with abortion and conspiracy; four were held as material witnesses.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 23 -- Steelworkers in the Birmingham-Gadsden area apparently have "hedged" their budgets over the last several months against the possibility of a strike. For the time being -- and that should extend for at least a month -- there will be no severe pinch felt among the more cautious rank-and-file workers.
Directors of the National Distillers and Chemical Corporation yesterday increased the quarterly common dividend to 30 cents a share, payable on Sept. 1, from 25 cents paid in previous quarters.

The Massachusetts Investors Trust reported yesterday record net assets of $1,539,750,862. These are equal to $13.98 a share on 110,150,489 shares outstanding as of June 30. These figures compared with assets of $1,149,844,598, or $10.98 a share, on 104,677,195 shares outstanding a year earlier.
PARIS, July 23 (AP) -- Japan and France today officially recognized that the development of further commercial relations is in the common interest of the two nations.

Miss Anna Kidansky, 67 years old, moved in Supreme Court yesterday to recover $65,300 she lost last Oct. 24. The money later was recovered from a garbage can by a janitor who turned it over to the police.

The Board of Education reserved decision yesterday on an appeal to rescind the scheduled transfer of 400 Negro pupils from the Bedford-Stuyvesant area of Brooklyn to schools in a white community in Queens.

Lowell M. Birrell, 52-year-old financier and lawyer who has been indicted on sixty-nine counts of grand larceny in an alleged multi-million-dollar stock fraud, was taken into custody yesterday in Rio de Janeiro.
PARIS, July 23 -- Premier Michel Debre announced today emergency financial help to Roman Catholic education and promised a legislative solution of this question by the end of the year.

A permanent injunction against the "pirated" showing of Charlie Chaplin's "Modern Times" and fourteen other Chaplin films has been obtained by the Roy Export Company Establishment, owner of the copyrights of the films.
Ask not for whom the bell tolls at Camp Monakewaygo. It tolls for steam railroading in the United States.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- The House Commerce Committee voted today to exempt television and radio spot news shows from the Communications Act's provision requiring equal broadcast time for political candidates.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., July 23 -- Lawrence J. Bauer, a 52-year-old executive of a baking company, was charged today with having lied while testifying before Suffolk County's special grand jury.

MOSCOW, July 23 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev greeted Vice President Richard M. Nixon today with an angry charge of United States interference in Communist affairs and a sarcastic welcome to the land of a "captive people."

THERE was a time when the only women who could afford a fur coat were those in the upper-income brackets. It was the all-time status symbol. No one is giving coats away, but Arnold Constable has a selection of coats, jackets and stoles that even a $65-a-week secretary can afford.
OTTAWA, July 24 (Canadian Press) -- Cargo shipped through the St. Lawrence Seaway from its opening April 25 to the end of June aggregated 5,431,000 tons, it was announced today.
MOSCOW July 24 -- The Soviet Union's upper crust turned out tonight in their Sunday best at the opening of the American National Exhibition.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 24 -- Fears were expressed in Western circles here today that charges of misuse and mismanagement of United States aid funds in South Vietnam could cripple assistance programs at a crucial moment.
HOUSTON, Texas, July 24, (AP) -- Hurricane Debra started turning inland from the Gulf of Mexico tonight, ripping at the middle Texas coast with winds exceeding ninety miles an hour.

The Chase Manhattan Bank reported yesterday that its retail charge credit plan, now eight months old, had 5,000 merchant members with about 5,700 stores. Some 300,000 customers hold credit cards under the plan.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) -- WHDH, Inc., said today there was "no basis" for upsetting the Federal Communications Commission's award in 1957 of television channel 5 in Boston to WHDH.

A YEAR ago, there were 16,777,216 possible arrangements for the shelving and wall-hung furniture of Poul Cadovius. Today, this Danish designer, founder of Royal System, has bettered this figure by at least a few million.

A unit of 10,000 square feet in the Central Bergen Industrial Terminal in Garfield, N. J., has been leased by Krain iCanton, manufacturer of Christmas decorations, and its affili[ ares, Noel Decorations, Inc., and Hell,loom Manufacturers.
American physicists have jubilantly taken to the Soviet Union a photograph that they feared a Russian scientist would get first.

Last January Abe Stark, the City Council President, was urging establishment of a permanent watchdog committee to review construction practices in education and other city agencies. Now, having got nowhere with that dubious idea, he returns to the fray with the suggestion that an "economy panel" of citizens be created which would, in the terms of our news account, "serve as watchdogs over public works construction."
The strongest pillar of Pan-Americanism should be "the creation of purchasing power for the peoples of the Western Hemisphere," Jorge Marcano, Consul General of Venezuela, declared yesterday.
ALGIERS, July 24 -- An offensive by 20,000 French troops against the rebel stronghold in Kabylia east of here "is proceeding according to plan," according to the French high command.
YONKERS, July 24 -- On the eve of an important test for youngsters -- the $56,397 Yonkers Trot for 3-year-olds -- a 2-year-old, Adios Larry, caused a considerable stir at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
GENEVA, July 24 -- A Soviet counter-proposal today on the staffing of control posts for policing a ban on nuclear weapons tests was said to fall far short of Western requirements.
Vice President Nixon's visit to Moscow has shown, among other things, the rough and ready character of Premier Khrushchev's diplomacy -- if diplomacy is the right word to apply to it.
MOSCOW, July 24 -- The American National Exhibition that opened here today is a glittering, colorful acclaim of consumer America.
SYRACUSE, July 24 (AP) -- Lieut. Gov. Malcolm Wilson said today that any legislation to require New York State residents to build fall-out or bomb shelters would be enacted only as a "last resort."
The Federal Aviation Agency issued a set of maintenance directives yesterday designed to prevent landing-gear difficulties on Boeing 707 jet airliners.
I am honored on behalf of President Eisenhower to open this American Exhibition in Moscow.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- Representatives of state highway officials and road builders appealed to Congress today to act quickly to deal with the financial crisis facing interstate highway construction.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Democrats and Republicans split today over the meaning of the national referendum in which wheat farmers voted to continue the present acreage control and price support program.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The United States lodged a sharply worded protest today against the attack on an American Naval patrol plane by two Communist MIG fighters over the Sea of Japan June 16.

Directors of the Eaton Manufacturing Company increased the quarterly dividend yesterday with the declaration of 90 cents a common share, payable Aug. 25. Shareholders had received 75 cents quarterly since the first quarter of 1957.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The co-captains of Government finance appealed publicly to Congress for the first time today not to try to tell the Federal Reserve how to conduct its business.
LOUISVILLE, July 24 (AP) -- Alonzo Johnson, one-time barber from Braddock, Pa., scored a unanimous decision over Willie Pastrano in their ten-round televised bout tonight at Freedom Hall.
Two additional mutual savings banks the Bank for Savings in the City of New York and the Onondaga County Savings Bank, Syracuse, have resigned from the American Bankers Association.
A violent summer squall struck the city yesterday with flooding rain and winds that reached hurricane force.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- The Senate confirmed today the promotions of the following Army brigadier generals to the temporary rank of major general:
DETROIT, July 24 -- Somewhere in the Motor City tonight Casey Stengel and George Weiss, the field and front-office managers of the backsliding Yankees, held a post-midnight conference.

OMAHA, Neb., July 24 -- Arthur B. Bisguier and Anthony F. Saidy of New York shared the lead with Hans Berliner of Littleton, Colo., and Donato Rivera of Puerto Rico after the fourth round of the United States Chess Federation open championship today. Each member of this quartet had a score of 4 -- 0.
MOSCOW, July 24 (AP) -- President Eisenhower expressed his best wishes for the well-being and prosperity of the Soviet people in a message to Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev today.
A Beethoven festival will be the feature of the last week of concerts at Lewisohn Stadium. Four of the week's five concerts will be devoted to Beethoven and will be conducted by Josef Krips.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The joint Treasury-Federal Reserve study of the Government securities market has concluded that the interests of the public and of the Government "are being effectively served through the present market."

Three six-story buildings contining 120 apartments and nine stores at 2340 to 2356 Amsterdam Avenue, facing Hlghbridge Park, were purchased by Soltzer-Lampert, realty operators, and resold to a syndicate of investors.
The nation's second largest aluminum producer, Reynolds Metals Company, joined its major competitors yesterday in rejecting the demand of the United Steelworkers of America for a wage increase.

The Securities and Exchange Commission's regulation of securities markets passed its twenty-fifth year this month with relationship between brokers and their Federal supervisors on a more cooperative and understanding basis than existed in 1934. Then difficulties arose principally on how to adapt the new regulatory law to a highly technical business.
LEICESTER, England, July 24 (Reuters) -- Britain's nuclear power stations are getting less business than expected, H. G. Nelson, head of the English Electric Company, said today.
A water-main break at the southeast corner of Broadway and Fortieth Street early yesterday created havoc with subway riders and auto drivers.
HAVERFORD, Pa., July 24 -- Alex Olmedo lost his first set of the week today in gaining the semi-finals of the Pennsylvania lawn tennis championships at the Merion Cricket Club.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 24 -- Formal pre-registration for students in Little Rock's public high schools ended today with 2,133 signed for classes beginning in September.

LENOX, Mass., July 24 -- The Berkshire Festival's week-end opened tonight with a concert by Pierre Monteux and the Boston Symphony Orchestra, with Isaac Stern as soloist in the Brahms Violin Concerto.
Sword Dancer, the winner of the Belmont Stakes, heads a star-studded cast of thoroughbreds that will vie for more than $400,000 today in three stakes races.
THERE are elements we miss in even the finest stereophonic reproductions of music. Not to be overlooked among these are the distractions, as well as the attractions, of the concert hall.
Despite the heat, humidity and heavy rains, the tourist business in New York City, the resort areas near by and upstate is holding up surprisingly well.

Dr. Alfred J. Marrow, chairman of the Inter-Group Relations Committee, says that he recognizes the right of private clubs to choose their own members, but not to bar racial or religious groups. Can jargon go further?

DETROIT, July 24 (AP) -- Ignoring the revocation of its charter, the Detroit branch of the American Cancer Society said today it would press its own cancer-fighting program with United Foundation aid.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Officials here said reports from Moscow indicated the Soviet authorities violated two no-censorship agreements with the United States today.
The new ban on standing commercial vehicles in five crosstown streets seemed to be working out to the satisfaction of the city authorities yesterday, the first day of strict enforcement.

A documentary pictorial biography of George Washington by Walter B. Wheeler is planned for fall publication by Public Affairs Press of Washington. As yet untitled, the book will bring together reproductions of "virtually all extant visual material" relating to the life of the first President, especially paintings, engravings and documents.

THE biggest bridge tournament of every year, throughout the world, is the summer tournament of the American Contract Bridge League. This year's renewal begins today in Chicago at the Conrad Hilton Hotel.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 24 President Sukarno announced today that a nation-wide ban on political activities, imposed by the army June 2, would be partly lifted as of Aug. 1.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- A man is equipped with two separate detectors (his ears) that tell him the direction a sound is coming from. A Texas inventor has adapted the principle to a hearing aid.
The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad sustained another deficit in June and finished the first half with a net loss of $3,277,543. The June deficit was $151,052.

MADRID, July 24 -- The new economic reforms sweeping Spain offer strong inducements both for American investors and American exporters in this growing market, economists believe. Spain has just devalued her currency from 42 to 60 pesetas to the dollar.
MONTREAL, July 24 (AP) -- With ailing Neale Fraser on the sidelines, Roy Emerson and Rod Laver carried Australia to a 2-0 lead over Canada in the Davis Cup American zone semi-finals today.
CHICAGO, July 24 -- Miss Jacqueline Gay Hart admitted to the Federal Bureau of Investigation tonight that she had not been kidnapped. She said she did not know how she had reached Chicago.
Senator Jean David of Haiti said yesterday that he had been removed as his country's Ambassador-designate to Japan because of his refusal to represent "a dictatorial regime."

Texaco, Inc., reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $162,723,460, or $2.79 a share, for the first half of this year. This compared with $138,535,542, or $2.37 a share, in the first half of 1958.

CLEVELAND July 24 (AP) -- United States District Judge Charles J. McNamee will preside at a hearing Tuesday in which an effort will be made to agree on the liability of the Bradley Transportation Company in the sinking of the freighter Carl D. Bradley.

LONDON, July 24 -- On his quest for truth in the Dark Continent, Sir Patrick Arthur Devlin was armed with the skills acquired in a lifetime of tracking that elusive quarry, justice, through bramble bush of common law.

The United Parents Associations asked the Board of Education yesterday to take immediate action on a deferred upon to transfer pupils from the Bradford Stuyvesant area of Brooklyn to the Glendale-Ridgewood section of Queens.

BALBOA, C. Z., July 24 -- The final tabulation of tolls and cargo tonnage for the Panama Canal's fiscal year ended June 30 shows that all previous records were broken in these categories as well as in the number of ship transits.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- Continental Air Lines, Inc., today urged the Civil Aeronautics Board to permit it to fly between Texas and California.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) -- The Army reassigned five general officers today in a routine shift of commands that made a super-secret intelligence officer Chief of Public Information.

WASHINGTON, July. 24 -- Average wholesale prices in primary markets fell 0.2 per cent to 119.2 per cent of their 1947-49 base during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

MOSCOW, July 24 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon challenged Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev today to peaceful competition in the spiritual as well as the material aspect of life as he opened the first American fair ever held in Moscow.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 24 -- Skip Etchells of Rocky Point, Jimmy Sykes, a Manhasset Bay youth, and Peter Bordes, a New Yorker with no club ties, were all but ready to wrap up the silverware as Larchmont Race Week champions in their classes after today's races.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The State Department announced today that Secretary Christian A. Herter would represent the United States at a Pan-American conference in Santiago, Chile, beginning Aug. 12.

THE whole world knows America's reputation for producing time-saving gadgets and equipment for the homemaker. Just how these products of industry influence and flavor the quality of family life is not understood quite so well.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The Director of the Central Intelligence Agency, in a detailed review of the Communist challenge around the world, cited tonight a long list of trends he regarded as favorable to the Western democracies.

While the Russians in Moscow obtained the removal of books in the United States exhibition there that contained ideas unpalatable to them, the Russians in New York were found yesterday to have put glass over books in their exhibit at the Coliseum.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) -- Senator John A. Carroll said today that a congressman's duty to represent his constituents did not extend to "backdoor approaches" to influence regulatory agencies.
HARTFORD, July 24 Associate Justice Raymond E. Baldwin was appointed tonight as Chief Justice of the Connecticut Supreme Court of Errors.
The National Broadcasting Company succeeded in televising here late Thursday a film made the same day in Moscow showing the arrival of Vice President Richard M. Nixon.
Mayor Wagner lent his support yesterday to the efforts of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association to get Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy to approve a voluntary check-off of membership dues.
EDGEWATER, N. J., July 24 -- The prospect of an economic rebirth for this waterfront borough below the Palisades was announced today by Mayor Joseph F. Regan.

The New York Telephone Company reported yesterday sizable gains in operating revenues and net income for the second quarter and the twelve months ended June 30. This was the first report issued by Clifton W. Phalen, new president of the company.
The ninth annual Byzantine Mass for Freedom of Religion in Russia and other Communist-Dominated Countries was celebrated yesterday on the Bronx campus of Fordham University.
BUENOS AIRES, July 24 -- President Arturo Frondizi faced a situation tonight in which the Argentine Navy was in a state of near-mutiny.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., July 24 -- The Empire State Music Festival opened its third week-end tonight with a successful performance of the opera that brought last year's festival to a disastrous close.
MILWAUKEE, July 24 (UP) -- Juan Pizarro pitched a four hitter while Joe Adcock batted in three runs and led the Milwaukee Braves to an 8-0 victory over Pittsburgh tonight.
MOSCOW, July 24 -- At Soviet insistence, more than 100 books were removed today from the shelves of the book show at the American National Exhibition.

ROME, July 24 -- Italy is now in the process of drafting a plan designed to unite Western countries in a concerted program of economic aid for the Middle East. Soundings have been taken in Washington, which appears to display some interest.

HIGGANUM, Conn., July 24 -- State Representative Lansing T. Carpenter was fatally injured by his own automobile in an accident in the yard of his home on Walkley Hill Road this morning. He was 61 years old.
The rising tide of nationalism that has washed over India, the Middle East and parts of Africa has touched southern Nassau County on Long Island.

LOS ANGELES, July 24 (AP) -- Held to three hits through seven innings, the St. Louis Cardinals chased Johnny Podres with four singles in the eighth inning tonight and defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 2 -- 1.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 24 -- Potentialities for a chemical industry in Latin America are enormous, provided that the member republics concur in establishing it on a regional basis. If set up to serve national markets, on the other hand, the projected plants would have to operate as heavily protected monopolies.
NEW DELHI, India, July 24 -- Communist China has "almost entirely" abandoned its program of producing steel in hundreds of thousands of back-yard blast furnaces.

Because of my inability to be present at the opening of the American Exhibition in the Soviet capital city, I have requested the Vice President of the United States to convey to you and to the Soviet people my personal greetings.
WEST CHESTER, Pa., July 24 (AP) -- A court-appointed master recommended today that the Lenape Swim Club be denied a charter of incorporation as a private club because of racial prejudice.
Terms for a two-year contract to end the forty-day strike of warehouse workers against the A. P. chain were reached yesterday.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 4 points (20 cents a bale) above to 2 points (10 cents) below Thursday's close.
CHICAGO, July 24 (AP) -- Despite a good shipper and local packer demand, butcher hog prices sank today to another new three-year low for the fifth successive decline this week.
ST. JOSEPH, Mo., July 24 (AP) -- Approval by directors of a merger involving the Anchor Serum Company, of St. Joseph and two Netherlands concerns was announced yesterday.

NEWARK, July 24 -- At a press conference here this afternoon Police Director Joseph F. Weldon said that the disappearance of Miss Hart was still a missing-persons case as far as the Newark police were concerned.

ROME, July 24 (Reuters) -- Leonard Schnall, 28 years old, of New York, was killed Tuesday when the car he was driving crashed on the coastal road at Terracina, about sixty miles south of here, the United States Embassy said today.
HAVANA, July 24 -- Cuba plans to export democracy and not revolutions, Minister of State Raul Roa Garcia declared today.
CHICAGO, July 24 (AP) -- Al Smith's home run in the ninth inning carried the league-leading Chicago White Sox to a 2-1 victory over the Baltimore Orioles and Hoyt Wilhelm tonight.

Movie attendance continues at significantly higher level than last year. The latest report by Sindlinger Co., Inc., business analyst, shows that the upward trend begun last February has been maintained through the late spring and early summer.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, July 24 (AP) -- A court trying Tad Szulc, a correspondent of The New York Times, in absentia convicted him today of slandering Brig. Gen. Maximo R. Bonetti Burgos.
May I compliment you on the cordial spirit and sincere motivation behind your editorial entitled "Base in the Philippines."
Mayor Wagner met for two hours yesterday with Robert Moses and Thomas J. Shanahan and then said he would make an announcement Monday about the city's Title I program.

The English Channel has been a challenge to the human courage and ingenuity for centuries. Men of every sort have tried their skill, daring and endurance in ways to cross or conquer it in almost every generation since before Caesar's time.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- It seems likely now that man, after a million years of intermittent mental progress, is about to be as smart as the racoon. This will be a great help to the wood duck.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- A labor controls bill much tougher than one approved yesterday by the House Labor Committee was unveiled today with apparent Administration approval.
Although gains slightly outnumbered losses on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, the tone of the market was dull and prices eased.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 24 (AP) -- Willie Mays, suffering from a neck-muscle spasm, rode the bench tonight as the San Francisco Giants opened a three-game series against the Chicago Cubs. Felipe Alou took over in center field.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Congress opened its second round of surgery on the foreign-aid bill today with a cut of $726,500,000 in President Eisenhower's request for funds for the fiscal year 1960.

Congress is moving toward a decision on a piece of legislation that combines in unusual fashion great benefits and considerable potential harm. It is the law for overseas disposal of our farm surpluses, by sale for foreign currencies or by outright grant. The issue is not whether the program shall continue but whether it shall be greatly expanded into a "food for peace" program.

The Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company increased its first half profit this year, and recently received a contract to build two nuclear-powered Polaris missile submarines at prices aggregating about $64,000,000, its report announced yesterday.

GLENS FALLS, N. Y., July 24 -- A battle over the $4,500,000 estate left by Mrs. Helen E. Foulds of Glens Falls was adjourned to Sept. 10 in Warren County Surrogates Court today. Counsel for three heirs seek to break her will.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 24 -- The police tonight held Lowell McAfee Birrell, the American financier, for deportation to face a grand larceny indictment in New York.
The Treasury's two new issues of securities -- 4 3/4 per cent notes due next summer and in May of 1964 -- continued yesterday to win the favor of investors at rising prices.

LONDON, July 24 -- The Government prepared for next week's debate on African problems by introducing in the House of Commons today a motion accepting the report of its Commission of Inquiry for Nyasaland.

LANSING, Mich., July 24 (UPI) -- Michigan's long struggle between an income tax and an increased sales tax to solve its financial troubles neared an end today with the sales tax apparently winning out.

Following is an account of the informal exchanges in Moscow yesterday between Vice President Richard M. Nixon and Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev. It was compiled from dispatches of The New York Times, The Associated Press, United Press International and Reuters.

AN 18-year-old entry in a fashion design contest gave the all-male panel of judges an awkward moment earlier this week.

A bill now before the City Council would require compulsory tree planting by the city's property owners. There is no doubt that there should be some stimulus for tree planting both to beautify our streets and make them more livable. Many community-minded residential and business property owners are now setting out trees entirely on their own initiative and at their own expense.

MOSCOW, July 24 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon and Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev debated in public today the merits of washing machines, capitalism, free exchange of ideas, summit meetings, rockets and ultimatums.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- A Democratic armistice was reached today between Paul M. Butler, National Chairman, and the party's Congressional leaders.
ROME, July 24 -- The Government paid tribute today to United States couples who adopt Italian children.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The Federal Communications Commission has ordered that long-distance telephone rates be cut by $50,000,000 a year.
DAYTON, Ohio, July 24 (AP) -- The Rike-Kumler Company announced today it was affiliating with Federated Department Stores, Inc., which operates some of the nation's largest merchandising outlets.

Play, representing the Avon-wood Stable, took the main race at Jamaica yesterday just when playing the horses was beginning to seem like work. In the six races before the feature event, short-priced horses had figured in all the pay-off spots, and the $2 bettors in the crowd of 18,002 weren't having any fun.

The latest market letter put out by Aubrey G. Lanston Co., government bond dealer, cuts through the political dispute in Washington about the "feasibility" of Treasury bond- buying by the Federal Reserve System to curb rising interest rates whenever such moves would be "consistent" with central bank policy.

Will Rogers used to say that all he knew was what he read in the papers. But apparently the trade experts in the Department of State don't even take the trouble to read. Just released is a reply to the more than six months old questionnaire of Senator Fulbright concerning trade with the Soviet Union.

The French offensive against the Algerian rebels in the Kabylia region east of Algiers has an easily understood importance. The rugged, forest-covered range that runs parallel to the coast has been the strongest fortress of the rebellion since it began four and a half years ago.
RYE, N. Y., July 24 -- Mrs. Truce McGhie of Whippoorwill on the Women's Tri-County golf championship over the pawamis Club course today.

CHICAGO, July 24 (AP) -- Soybean futures worked their way back toward the high road today on the Board of Trade as the market appeared to have absorbed all the accumulation of profit-taking in yesterday sharp decline.

Eastern Air Lines, Inc., had a bumpy flight in the first half of this year. Earnings fell to $3,645,940 from $4,940,378 in the 1958 period, according to the semi-annual report of Thomas F. Armstrong, president.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The steel strike had a slight secondary impact on the volume of claims for unemployment insurance last week, the Labor Department reported today.
A Hempstead L. I., man was charged yesterday with masterminding a scheme to swindle investors out of $500,000

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Vice Admiral Hyman G. Rickover has given a House investigating subcommittee a list of retired high-ranking military officers who allegedly had tried to exert pressure on him for their new employers in defense industries.
GENEVA, July 24 -- The Big Four foreign ministers started "parallel" talks on the Berlin and all-German problems today and proved anew that parallel lines never meet.
Commodity futures prices closed generally higher yesterday in dull trading. Evening of positions prior to the week-end accounted for most of the volume.

LONDON, July 24 (AP) -- Bil Steinkraus of Westport, Conn., suffered a concussion and face lacerations when thrown by his horse today at the Royal International Horse Show. His injuries were not serious, however.

Roman Catholic lay leaders have a task in developing a world government far stronger than any federation that has existed in the past, the International Director of the Secretariat of World Sodalities said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Bernard Goldfine escaped jail today for contempt of Congress. At the same time, he was directed in Federal Court to answer the Congressional questions that led to the charge if recalled by House investigators.
MRS. JOSEPH ACKER of Poughkeepsie, N. Y., has sent a recipe for pickled watermelon rind. The recipe, she says, gives perfect results.
BOSTON, July 24 -- The decision of the First United States Court of Appeals upholding the convictions of Mr. Goldfine and Miss Paperman was unanimous.

MOSCOW, July 24 -- There is an odd paradox about the Khrushchev-Nixon row today. It was perhaps the most startling personal international incident since the war, and yet, given the situation and the personalities of the men involved, it was not surprising and almost inevitable.

WASHINGTON, July 24, (AP) -- Cases of paralytic poliomyelitis increased by 50 per cent last week to a 1959 weekly high of 166. They ran more than three times the number listed for the comparable 1958 week.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) -- Senator John L. McClellan, its chairman, said today that the Senate rackets committee might send investigators to the Tampa area in Florida to look into charges of acid-bombings and other violence.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 24 -- Bob Watson of Ardsley would like to have more golf championships staged at the Metropolis Country Club. In a drizzle of rain here today, Watson won the Westchester open title, adding it to the Metropolitan open crown he captured on this same course last September.

LONDON, July 24 -- Despite restricting week-end influences, most of the industrials closed week on bright note today. But Government funds sustained fresh falls, ranging from 1s. 3d. (17 1/2 cents) to three times as much in the medium, long and undated funds, and up to 1s. 10 1/2d. (26 1/4 cents) in the short- term issues.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) -- The Democratic leader, Lyndon B. Johnson, told the Senate today that it had become clear that President Eisenhower was "misinformed" about provisions of the housing bill, which he vetoed earlier this month.

The first of the giant Boeing Intercontinental jet planes, which on Thursday set a nonstop New York-to-Moscow record, will go into commercial service for Pan American World Airways next month between the West Coast and London.

CLEVELAND, July 25 -- Cal McLish chalked up his eighth straight victory today, an 8-1 decision over the Washington Senators, as the Cleveland Indians won their third straight.

Years before this generation of happy pleasure boatmen (and women), their parents and their grandparents made a summer vacation mecca of the Thousand Islands. Now that the St. Lawrence Seaway has been opened, this has become more than ever, the boatmen's seventh heaven.
