ST. THOMAS, Virgin Islands, July 25 -- Gov. John David Merwin has announced that the highest revenues in the history of the Virgin Islands were produced in the fiscal year ended June 30. The total was $5,224,156 for a population of fewer than 30,000 residents.
Task Group Bravo, Rear Admiral R. J. Stroh commanding, which arrived in New York Thursday night, is part of the continuous watch against submarines maintained by the United States Navy.

THERE is widespread interest these days in a phenomenon loosely called the Educational Theatre responsible, it has been estimated, for more than 60,000 annual stage productions, (if high school performances are counted) and for at least 12,000 by approximately 2,000 community theatres and 1,000 active drama departments.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 25 -- A red-haired, 26-year-old giant of a man from South Africa, relatively unknown in this country until this year, defeated Alex Olmedo in the Pennsylvania lawn tennis championships today.

LONDON, July 25 (UPI) -- Hugh Wiley of Towson, Md., capped another brilliant showing by United States riders at the Royal Horse Show today by winning three trophies during the final program of the week-long event.

The bond market has just put behind it one of the most trying ordeals since World War II. The breather did not come until yields on certain United States Government securities rose beyond 5 per cent for the first time in more than thirty years.

Six Jewish organizations asked Congress yesterday to declare opposition to Mutual Security aid for "Saudi Arabia or any other country that creates discrimination because of race or religion among American citizens in the granting of any rights otherwise available to United States citizens generally."

THE forty to eighty weekly art exhibitions in New York during the season from September to June bring along with them a flood of communications no less numerous and varied. Letters come from people who are sure they have discovered old master paintings in an attic or who want to proclaim the latest fledging genius.

The day of July 26 is being celebrated with a fervor and emotion in Cuba that show the profundity of the event that has shaken the "Pearl of the Antilles."

The N. S. (Nuclear Ship) Savannah, the world's first nuclear-powered merchant vessel, was christened by Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower last Tuesday and launched into the Delaware River at the New York Shipbuilding Corporation's yard at Camden, N. J., in the presence of 15,000 spectators.

THE flood of paper which now threatens to submerge the world is something peculiar to this century. GREENWICH, Conn., July 25 -- Cliff Hipkins' Quincy Adams-17 boat Lady Luck, Al Kostanecki's Luders-16 Grundoon, and Grant Thompson's Lightning Geisha were among the winners today in the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound regatta staged by the Rocky Point Club.

BOSTON, July 25 -- Intellectual capacity is only one of the qualities listed by ten members of the Boston University faculty in a written symposium, released today, on the question: "Who Should Go to College?"

FREGENE, Italy, July 25 -Romano Mussolini, the youngest son of the late dictator, is drawing loud acclaim in the National Jazz Festival here. He is applauded not for his name and resemblance to his father, but for his "Italian blues."
TRENTON, July 25 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner today expressed grave reservations about a measure before him that is needed to begin the college scholarship program in New Jersey.

Recording for the Blind, Inc., will produce a series of 125 books for use by blind children in Connecticut public schools. The non-profit organization, which provides educational material free of charge primarily to blind college students and adults reports that this is the first time that a state agency has arranged with a national organization to produce textbooks for blind children on a state-wide basis.
The Dec. 9 evening performance of "Five Finger Exercise'' will benefit the Riverdale Children's Association. The play will open Dee. 2 at the Music Box Theatre.
MILWAUKEE, July 25 (UPI) Lew Burdette scored his thirteenth triumph of the year today when he pitched the Milwaukee Braves to a four-hit 3 -- 0 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

PAWTUCKET, R. I., July 25 (AP) -- Mrs. John Dalton's Leon K. the only stakes winner in the field of ten juveniles, today won the $17,775 Narragansett Nursery Stakes at Narragansett Park by two and a half lengths.

VALLETTA, Malta, July 18 -A Bronze Age village the size of a soccer field has been unearthed on the southeastern coast of Malta. Dating to about 1350 B. C., it stands atop a ridge that has steep slopes and a defensive wall.

PUERTO DE ANDRAITX, Majorca, July 15 -- Spaniards are strumming guitars along the waterfront here these summer nights.

BROWBEATEN and neglected, little Lindy Wellin lived a frightened life with her handsome, feckless mother, Poppy, in a broken-down cottage somewhere in East Anglia. She would lie in bed at night, rigid with terror, imagining that the old, black trunk on top of the wardrobe held the dismembered corpse of her father, and once, when Poppy came up in answer to her screams, she cried out her fear.

A swarm of policemen and agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation strolled up Broadway from Twenty-third Street to Columbus Circle yesterday with a group of Puerto Rican nationalists carrying angry placards.

LOS ANGELES, July 25 -- The controversial Watts towers, subject of much wrangling between art lovers and building experts, will have to stand or fall on the outcome of a stress test in the next few weeks.

BONN, Germany, July 25 -- East Germany is for the Soviet Union an advanced position, a buffer state and a colony. So long as the nuclear deterrent exists it is quite unlikely that the Soviets can even contemplate a forward movement into West Europe, and they certainly have no reason to fear an invasion from the West.
HAMBURG, Germany, July 18 -- This North Sea port fears that it will suffer in a conflict between the two emerging trade blocs of Western Europe.

Thunder rumbled in the cold war last week, but when the storm had passed the situation appeared to be about as it was before. A long, lively and unprecedented debate in Moscow and continued stalemate at Geneva gave little promise far any immediate relaxation of cold war tensions.

GOTEBERG, Sweden, July 25 (AP) -- There appeared to be a marked difference of opinion today between Ingemar Johansson and Bill Rosensohn concerning the site and date of a return title match with Floyd Patterson.

The three principal factors in the New England business situation, present and prospective, are the steel strike, the growing toughness of credit, and the weather. WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI) -- Billions of dollars in pension funds for workers, have been shifted from Government and corporation bonds to blue chip common stocks as a hedge against inflation, a survey revealed today.

DETROIT, July 25 -- Little Bobby Richardson and littler Fritz Brickell each slugged his first major-league homer today. But because the Yankees were guilty of five errors, they needed Yogi Berra's 296th major-league round-tripper, a two-run blow in the ninth inning, to overcome the Tigers, 9 -- 8, at Briggs Stadium.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., July 25 (AP) -- Federal District Judge Albert V. Bryan today ordered the Arlington County School Board to admit twelve more Negro children to three former all-white public schools.
LONG BEACH, Calif., July 25 (AP) -- A willowy Japanese girl -- the first to give the Orient the Miss Universe title -- today began her reign "floating on a cloud and living a dream."

TOKYO, July 20 -- Deep personal tragedy accompanied a historic ring triumph for Japan's new champion wrestler in the annual sumo (Japanese wrestling) tournament at Nagoya yesterday. The situation, which was of a kind that goes straight to the hearts of the chivalrous Japanese sporting public, has inevitably made the ponderous grappler the current national hero of Japan.
BERLIN, July 25 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter pledged during a six-hour visit to West Berlin today that Allied troops would continue to defend the freedom of the city.
LONDON, July 25 -- The public argument between Vice President Nixon and Premier Khrushchev was cited in the press here today as a good reason for private diplomacy.

BOSTON -- This is to be the last summer tourist season for the State of Maine before its newly enacted anti-discrimination law becomes effective. The Maine Legislature at its last winter's session passed the law to become effective on Sept. 12.

OMAHA, July 25 -- The leaders in the annual tournament for the open championship of the United States Chess Federation were slowed a bit in today's fifth round. Five players, including three New Yorkers, were tied for first place with scores of 4 1/2 -- 1/2.

CHICAGO, July 25 -- Sherm Lollar's ninth-inning home run and Harry Simpson's seventeenth-inning pinch single kept the Chicago White Sox in first place today. The Chicagoans won, 3 -- 2, from the Baltimore Orioles, rallying for the fourth straight time for a one-run decision.

WESTPORT, Conn., July 25 (UPI) -- It was ladies' day all the way at the Fairfield County Hunt Club today. Three young women turned in top-notch performances to win places on the Pan-American Games team as the United States Olympic equestrian committee dressage trials ended.
The week-end lull in the wage war between the United Steelworkers of America and the steel and aluminum industries produced only one meeting yesterday.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 24 -- The hopeless frustration with which this city's residents once viewed the plight of their public high schools is gone. In its place is a determination to get on with the job of education.

Department store sales in this area last week were slightly ahead of 1958. Merchants estimated that volume was 1 or 2 per cent better than the same period a year ago. The showing was in contrast to a brighter picture for the rest of the nation.

TEN-YEAR-OLD Tacey runs away from Aunt Fanny's too-elegant apartment in Greenwich, Conn., where she has been sent while Granny is ill. She sets out for her home at Greendale, only fourteen miles away, and is joined by an 11-year-old boy who is also running away in order to save his dog from the dog warden.
IMMIGRATION to Israel has had a telling effect on that young country's folk music. People streaming in from all compass points have taken some of their cultural baggage with them.
LOS ANGELES, July 25 (AP) -- Johnny Roseboro gave three unearned runs to St. Louis tonight with three errors and the Cardinals defeated Los Angeles, 4 -- 2, in ten innings before 48,691.

The Rev. Dr. Gardner C. Taylor, a member of the city's Board of Education, will depart tomorrow by air for a preaching mission in Australia. There he will deliver 102 sermons and addresses on a six-week tour.

WILLI HEINRICH, one of the most successful West German writers, is such an angry young man that his resentment spills all over his novel. His male protagonists are forever bursting with, or have their voices muffled with, "rage and disappointment."

THERE has been no "summer slack" in the publishing of new mysteries this year; but it still seems a good idea to pause and emphasize the large number of unusually good paperback reprints newly available for summer reading (35 cents each, unless otherwise indicated).
TROY, N. Y., July 25 (AP) -- The two young favorites from Buffalo, John Konsek and Ward Wettlaufer, won their semi-final matches today in the New York State men's amateur golf tournament.

Many persons have already made plans to attend the seventh Ball of the Roses, an annual benefit for the free medical care program of Roosevelt Hospital. The fete will be held in the Plaza next Jan. 7.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 25 (Reuters) -- Representatives of nine Arab countries began today to prepare for a two-week conference on ways to apply more economic pressure against Israel. The conference will begin Monday.
LOS ANGELES, July 25 -- Smog or no smog, Southern California's population boom continues at a pace of nearly 1,000 persons a day.
SYRACUSE, July 25 -- A pamphlet just issued by the State University College of Forestry at Syracuse University has warned landowners to be alert for pine-needle scale infections of their evergreens.
HAVANA, July 25 -- A man identified as a top leader of a Cuban counter-revolutionary organization operating from the United States was captured at dawn today in his flaming aircraft.
The vice president of the Board of Education yesterday questioned the legality of a plan to transfer 400 pupils from overcrowded schools in Brooklyn to less used ones in Queens.

"THE BIG BANKROLL" is a galloping account of the life and times of Arnold Rothstein, the gambler, who was fatally shot on the night of Nov. 4, 1928, in a New York hotel room. It glows with the colorful memories of a bygone era, is studded with true anecdotes that have the excitement of fiction and examines in true perspective the fabulous career of a master criminal.

World shipbuilding experienced generally unsettled conditions in the second quarter of this year as building volume retreated farther from the peacetime high of 10,205,791 gross tons established a year ago.
OCEANPORT, N. J., July 25 -- Sword Dancer of the Brookmeade Stable finished two lengths in front of his nearest pursuer, Mrs. Tilyou Christopher's Amerigo, in the $113,730 Monmouth Handicap today.

OLD CHATHAM, N. Y., July 25 -- The Shaker Museum here will benefit next Saturday from its fourth annual festival, to be held on the museum grounds. Mrs. Richard Shaffer is chairman for the event, which this year will be tied in with New York State's Hudson-Champlain Celebration.
KATMANDU, Nepal, July 24 -- The first elected Parliament in the history of Nepal was inaugurated in a colorful ceremony here today.
MOUNT POCONO, Pa., July 24 (AP) -- Republican chairmen of ten Northeastern states praised today President Eisenhower's efforts to hold the line against inflation by working for a balanced budget.
Plans for reducing smoke at the three transit power plants it will acquire from the city next Saturday were made known yesterday by the Consolidated Edison Company.
Entry blanks are available for preliminary run-offs for the annual Harvest Dance Contest, the Parks Department announced yesterday.

"FLIGHT," a short story by John Steinbeck, is being made into a motion picture in a most unorthodox fashion in the very Santa Lucia mountain where the author set his brief and vivid tale. Steinbeck fans will recall it as a bitingly realistic account of a boy who kills a man and takes refuge in the mountains.

"PUBLIC debt." I am obliged to Mr. Burnham for quoting the sentence I had in mind ("The Machiavellians," p. 259). "Germany to win the war." Mr. Burnham says that, writing "in the autumn of 1940," he was referring to the German war against Russia.

The textile industry, in the doldrums since 1951, has made a rapid recovery this year. Spencer Love, chairman and president of Burlington Industries, Inc., one of the largest textile concerns, said last week that "few other industries are as closely in balance in relation to present or potential supply and demand as is our textile industry at the present time."
MOSCOW, July 25 (UPI) -- Mrs. Richard M. Nixon continued her "mingle-with-the-Russians" campaign today by donning a white surgical coat and handing out lollipops and chewing gum to sick children.

THE cheeriest thing about Frank Capra's and Frank Sinatra's "A Hole in the Head," outside of the built-in jocularity of this new comedy at Loew's State, is the fact that it brings Mr. Capra back to directing feature films, a pursuit he had curiously neglected since "Here Comes the Groom" in 1951.
DREAM-OF-THE-WEEK: Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d talking with Arthur Laurents about a new musical. Dream? No.

In your editorial of July 15, "The Treasury's Problem," you ask the question: "Are there devices by which the Federal Reserve System. without pumping up the nation's bank reserves and money supply to inflationary proportions, could help solve the Treasury's problem?"

In one of our largest military establishments in the South, a secret but very large number of highly skilled personnel are constantly on the alert as a part of the military mobilization essential to our national defense.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 25 -- "Now Sweden has a touch of Siberian chill,"' a visiting Finnish official said here this week. The Finn, whose country has experienced many wintry blasts from the East, referred to Soviet Premier Khrushchev's sudden postponement of his scheduled tour of Denmark, Sweden and Norway.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- A private analysis of the productivity of Federal Government employes indicates improvement during the last twelve years at an annual average rate of 1 1/2 pet cent.

FRANKFORT, Ky., July 25 -- Agreements signed this week by the Governors of Indiana and Kentucky to build three more Ohio River bridges are regarded as a major step in the transportation plans of the two states.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- The Washington Canoe Club won the national championship of the American Canoe Association today. The judges ruled that the apparent winner, Inwood Canoe Club of New York, had interfered with Washington during one event.

PRISON riots erupt into public attention like earthquakes. This year, one state after another has been jolted by violent reminders that all is not well within the walls of their penal institutions. In a recent one, at Washington State Prison, thirty-nine hostages, including twenty-five visiting men, women and children, were held in a thirteen-hour reign of terror by four knife-wielding convicts trying to exact their freedom.

BLUE RIDGE, N. C., July 25 -- The United States should have a big constructive goal of its own to give appealing the world, instead of simply reacting to Russian proposals, a consultant to President Eisenhower said here tonight.

"GOD of Abraham, God of Isaac, God of Jacob, not of the philosophers and scholars." This motto, which Blaise Pascal, seventeenth - century French religious philosopher, burned into his mind, no more suits Paul Tillich than a hair shirt.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., July 25 (UPI) -- Gov. Earl K. Long of Louisiana predicted today that he and Harry S. Truman would "have the same ideas" on a Democratic Presidential ticket by convention time in July, 1960.

ONCE upon a time, in the olden days before World War II, there lived a humble sportswriter and bon vivant whose name was Paul Gallico. Now this Paul Gallico was wont to scriven paragraphs about earthbound matters like prize-fights and golf matches and also prose stuff for such organs of opinion as Esquire, The Magazine for Men.

Re Joseph Wechsberg's fine article, which reads like a French menu for gourmets, may I add the statement that the acceptance of foreign words and, still more, the coining of new French words has always been deeply resented by the intelligentsia of France.
Growing taxes and shrinking living quarters are relegating heroic stuffed moose heads to the museums.
THE inauguration of regular jet service between Sydney, Australia, and San Francisco this Friday will at last bring the relatively remote continent within one day's flying time of American shores.

Supplies began to show signs of tightening last week on fall apparel that had been reordered. Resident buying offices particularly noted that this was the case in the sweater field. Good quantities of sweaters had been ordered and shipped well in advance of the season.

"HAVE you ever closed your eyes and thought of something you have seen? Maybe your dog. You could see him though he wasn't really there. That was a thought picture." Pers Crowell, known to me before this as an artist who draws lovely horses, discusses in a leisurely and uncomplicated way, thoughts: where they come from; what you can do with them; the effect of imagination and memory; what dreams and absentmindedness are.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- For the first time in ten years Democrats are getting more campaign contributions than Republicans.

Madison Avenue agencies have long been accustomed to claiming that they have the biggest and best of everything. When it comes to physical facilities, however, there is an agency in Paris that probably ranks as the showplace of this or any other industry.

THE latest intelligence about charter airplane flights to Europe deals with a strange decision by the Civil Aeronautics Board, a decision that is likely to cast some reasonable doubts on that agency's firm position on the bona fides of charter passengers.

The News of the Week in Review of July 19 conveys the impression that the Arabian-American Oil Company does not question job applicants as to their religion but merely refers them to the Saudi Arabian Consulate to obtain a visa because of the exclusion of Jews from that country.

THIS absorbing if somber collection of dissident, revisionist or merely rueful stories, poems and essays from the Communist world sends the reader's mind along many avenues of reflection and speculation without, in the end, leading it to stay definable conclusion. This is as it should be.

MY heart goes out to translators from European languages. They have often told us, and I believe them, of the impossibility of conveying exact nuances, of the falseness of the friends called cognates, of the phrases so graceful in the originals which come limping home in English.

CINCINNATI, July 25 (AP) -- The Milwaukee manager, Fred Haney, today added Sam Jones, a pitcher, and Johnny Logan and Jim Gilliam, infielders, to his National League All-Star team for the game at Los Angeles on Aug. 3.

The Yankees defeated the Tigers, 9 -- 8, yesterday at Detroit on Yogi Berra's two-run homer in the ninth inning. Harry Simpson's pinch single in the seventeenth enabled the White Sox to gain a 3-2 triumph over the Baltimore Orioles at Chicago.

THE rays from two light sources intermixed in an inverted white bowl, or sphere, to produce highly diffuse bounce illumination for projecting color or black-and-white negatives, is the new enlarging principle introduced in the novel Chromega D-4, at a recent press preview here, by Simmon Brothers, Inc., Long Island City, makers of the Omega line of enlarging equipment.
SINGLE-SOLUTION processing of photographic contact and enlarging papers is made possible with the third in the series of Unibath combined developer-fixer solutions just placed on the market.
NEWARK, July 25 -- Municipal and private agencies in Newark were urged today to give "particular attention" to the housing and employment problems of Negro residents.

Recently there have appeared in your Travel Section many articles on the current trend to car camping as a cheap and enjoyable vacation. We have read these articles with interest and varying degrees of amusement (we have camped as a family since our marriage and prior to that with college outing groups and Scout troops).

TURN boys into chefs? The authors, a husband-and-wife culinary team, claim it can be done -- and in "The Boys' Cook Book" they dish up a course in cookery that includes everything from soups to desserts. To help the young cook find his way down the menu, Helen and Philip Brown include a glossary of cooking terms.
DAKAR, Senegal, July 25 -- There are three small independent countries in West Africa at the present time. Next year there will be six, maybe more.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., July 25 (AP) -- A graduate psychology student refused to tell the police today how a mathematics student, son of a retired admiral, had been shot to death in his apartment near the Purdue University campus.
The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States will mark its 100th birthday today at 4:45 P. M.

FOR a long time now there has been general agreement that the cost of moviemaking is too high. Producers have blamed the stars for demanding enormous salaries plus a percentage of the gross. Stars in return have contended that they do more for movies than the producers; that, in fact, the producers are vastly overpriced. Now a producer has bluntly declared that the major studios are the true villains.

The American Women's Voluntary Services, Inc., will benefit from the Dec. 15 performance of "L'Hurluberlu" ("Scatterbrain"). Rex Harrison will play the leading role in the Jean Anouilh comedy scheduled to open Dec. 8 at the ANTA Theatre.

A growing trend among colleges to make the teaching profession as attractive as possible as a means of luring more talent into the ranks was reflected last week in an announcement by Fordham University.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 25 -- The Soviet Union and Indonesia will sign an agreement Tuesday under which Moscow will extend an additional $17,500,000 credit to Indonesia, the Foreign Ministry announced today. A loan of $100,000,000 was previously granted by the Soviet Union.
"Make sure your locker is closed by Freddie before you leave. Anyone caught stealing here will be barred from this gym forever."
MOSCOW, July 25 -- Tens of thousands of Russians got their first look at the American National Exhibition here today.
LINCOLN, N. H., July 25 (AP) -- Sherman Adams, center a year ago of a Washington political storm, is living in seclusion here, the town that was his home when he first entered politics.

SHIRLEY BOOTH, who has made only two television appearances according to one set of files, has been booked to star in Stephen Vincent Benet's "A Child Is Born." The half-hour Nativity play will be televised on a Tuesday evening in December as a special feature of the Ford series to be produced by Hubbell Robinson over the National Broadcasting Company network.

Total nonagricultural employment in Illinois rose in May to 3,419,900. This was 37,100 above April and 109,200 above recession-riddled May, 1958. The largest gain -- 15,300 above April and 86,100 above a year ago -- was made in the largest employment category, manufacturing.
CHICAGO, July 25 (UPI) -- Claiborne Farm's Dunce rallied with a stretch drive on the rail today to win the $140,425 Arlington Classic by a length and a half.
HOUSTON, Tex., July 25 (UPI) -- Hurricane Debra, the worst, tropical storm of the season, battered the Texas coast today with lashing rain squalls. Damage to property was estimated at millions.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Behind President Eisenhower's experiment in more direct and personal relations with Washington correspondents is a conviction that Americans need to know vital issues and a decision to do something about it.
Most of the giant manufacturing cities in the East and Midwest have been losing jobs in the last decade, despite an over-all national gain in factory employment of more than a million.

GENEVA, July 25 -- An American Soviet affairs specialist walked out of a private session of the foreign ministers' conference this week and exclaimed with almost as much admiration as exasperation: "That man is impossible."
HAMILTON, Mass., July 25 -- Stars they cannot see, sounds they cannot hear and depths they cannot plumb will help space-ship navigators steer their courses into the unknown reaches of space.

More than two hundred years ago Benjamin Franklin demonstrated by his famous kite experiment that thunderclouds carry ordinary electric charges and that lightning is a huge electrical discharge, or spark. A striking aspect of the experiment -- an experiment recognized at the time as epoch-making -- was that Franklin was not instantly killed, as was the case a year later when an experimenter in Russia lost his life doing what Franklin had done.

LIME ROCK, Conn., July 25 -- Rodger Ward, victor in this year's Indianapolis 500-mile auto race, drove a midget car in the 150-mile experimental free-formula race today. What's more, he ran away from his monster competitors to win.

THE Oregon Shakespearean Festival here, dedicated to the production of the playwright in the form for which he wrote -- swift, continuous action -- will have a new Elizabethan stage this summer. In its nineteenth season the festival successfully faced a $275,000 fund-raising campaign.

Waltz romped to a mile and three-sixteenths track record in winning the forty-second running of the Dwyer Handicap at Jamaica yesterday. Bagdad, the 4-5 favorite, finished next to last in the field of six 3-year-olds.

DANBY, Vt. -- Although the highway construction program in the Green Mountain State has gained considerable impetus in recent years, the popularity of Vermont's picturesque back roads continues to rate high among visitors interested in a leisurely exploration of the good, old-fashioned gravel and dirt roads that stood grandpa and grandma in such good stead back in the horse-and-buggy days.
LOS ANGELES, July 25 -The port of Los Angeles has opened a $4,000,000 "supertanker" terminal to accommodate the oil-burning behemoths of the world.

IT is not easy to talk about yourself in poetry and be sure that you will interest everyone. Think of some of those dead passages where Shelley or Wordsworth are more interested in themselves than they can get us to be.

DENIS MACK SMITH of Cambridge University has written a political history of Italy from unification in 1860 to the end of World War II which no serious student of Italy can afford to overlook. In fact, this work -- which is much more extensive than its number of pages suggests -- has no equal in any language and there are few studies which can be regarded as even distant rivals.

WITHIN the next few weeks the back-to-school movement will be under way. Even now, mothers of seasoned young scholars are making mental notes of what's needed to replenish outgrown school wardrobes. But for mothers of beginners the job of readying a child for his first big day in the academic world is not always so simple. First and foremost, mother needs to be ready herself.

Antonino Rocca of Argentina and Miguel Perez of Puerto Rico won again in the feature wrestling exhibition before some 20,000 fans at Madison Square Garden last night. They defeated Jerry and Eddie Graham of Hollywood, Calif., in a tag-team match.

"DIDN'T I tell those dead to lie down closer to the shell holes ?" From a hilltop above the battle scene, Mario Monicelli, director, furiously shouted these instructions across a vast sweep of mountainous territory, where several hundred extras were busily re-enacting a World War I Italian front engagement on actual sites for a Dino De Laurentiis production to be called, aptly, "La Grande Guerra" ("The Great War").

WASHINGTON, July 25 -James R. Hoffa, preparing for what he has called "the day of reckoning at the polls," is polishing up a plan for a department of political action in his International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

THE wealth of Dutch graphic work, from the fantasies of Hieronymus Bosch to the abstractions by Piet Mondrian, is set forth in a discerning selection by J. G. van Gelder, Professor of Fine Art at the University of Utrecht. This succinctly illuminating account spans more than five centuries.

DETROIT, July 25 -- The first grass-roots reaction to proposals for a comprehensive, perhaps compulsory, shelter program to protect the nation against nuclear attack is likely to develop here within the next few days.

SALONIKA, Greece, July 25 (Reuters) -- More than 150 clergymen, economists, sociologists and political leaders from thirtyfour countries met here today for the start of a ten-day conference to consider the effects of rapid social change.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., July 25 -- Preliminary results from tests conducted here this week showed that a corner of the basement of the C. A. Keller house would be the best place for the family in case of fallout from a nuclear explosion.

AFTER a half-dozen erroneous predictions, the year has finally come when both Stan Musial and Ted Williams are grown old. It is a fine dramatic thing that age should embrace these two men simultaneously, but in the autumn, when it now appears that each will announce his retirement, a state of extended mourning is certain to settle about the taverns, patios, offices and television sets where sentimental baseball fans gather.

DURING the past eight or ten years American landscape architects and garden designers have introduced a touch of Japanese design in many home gardens. The demand for small gardens has been a factor in the use of Japanese themes.

STANTON, Del., July 25 -- Christiana Stable's Endine took the mile-and-a-quarter $155,000 Delaware Handicap for fillies and mares with its winner's prize of $108,312.50 for the second year in a row today. She defeated the fast-closing Polamby by half a length in a photo finish.

YESTERDAY Edward Steichen's photographic essay, "The Family of Man," went on view at the American National Exhibition in Moscow, enabling more people around the world to see this remarkable collection of 503 photographs.

IN his rather wide-ranging comments on my "Congress and the American Tradition," Lindsay Rogers annotates my unreliability by, for example, stating that "In 1943 [Burnham] prophesied that after hostilities ended the public debt would be repudiated."

OSAKA, Japan, July 25 (UPI) -- Frank McKinney set a world record for the 200-meter back-stroke and Alan Somers swam the fastest 1,500-meter free-style race of 1959 tonight as the United States gained an 18-17 lead over Japan at the halfway mark in a dual swimming meet.

MADRID, July 25 -- This week Spain turned an economic corner in her long, proud history. With his Government nearly bankrupt and harried by inflation, Generalissimo Francisco Franco agreed to sweeping economic reforms, after months of pleading by the brilliant young Spanish economists in his entourage.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 25 -- An application from Greece to join the European Economic Community, or common market, received a unanimously favorable vote at a meeting here today of the foreign and economic ministers of the six member states.

THE intrepid few in Baltimore who years ago bought paintings by living and imaginatively inclined artists -- sometimes called "avant garde" artists -- were scornfully regarded as eccentrics by the community.

MOSCOW, July 25 -- The American exhibition is the greatest foreign invasion to reach Moscow since Napoleon. A resourceful ticket scalper, or even a deviationist cop on a lonely stretch of fence, could quickly make himself a fortune, and the reason is fairly clear.

GENEVA, July 25 -- The United States was authoritatively represented tonight as unalterably opposed to a summit conference on the basis of what now seem to be the possible results of the foreign ministers' conference here.

VIENNA, July 25 -- The self-appointed New York City leaders of the United States delegation to the Seventh World Youth Festival lost control tonight after a violent debate in which the charge of communism was shouted across the floor at the temporary chairman.

THE clans have gathered in Chicago, where the biggest national tournament of the year is now under way at the Conrad Hilton hotel. Beginning today, the leading pairs of life masters (the highest rank in the American Contract Bridge League) will play through four days for the gold cup given thirty years ago by Waldemar von Zedtwitz.

Expectant mothers in several Essex County, N. J., communities who may have to go to a hospital while their husbands are at their offices may avail themselves of a chauffeur and car provided by the Home Owners Club of New Jersey.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, July 21 -- The waters of the Blue Nile are flowing through the Sennar Dam sluices and filling the new Manaqil Canal, which will bring under cultivation a further 600,000 acres of desert to the south of the existing Gezira cotton plantations.

MOSCOW, July 25 -- Little more than an hour after Vice President Nixon streaked into Moscow in a huge Boeing jetliner and little more than ten hours after he had left the United States, he and Mrs. Nixon were taking a brisk walk through the crowds along broad Tchaikowsky Street.

YONKERS, July 25. -- Stanley Dancer gave a storybook touch to the celebration of his thirty-second birthday tonight by scoring with John A. Hanover in the $56,397 Yonkers Trot before a crowd of 35,082 at Yonkers Raceway.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 25 --- Lowell McAfee Birrell, American financier, wanted in New York on charges of grand larceny, will be expelled from Brazil as soon as possible, Police Chief Crisanto Figueiredo said today.

AN impressive display of virtuoso performance and virtuoso recording technique comes from R. C. A. Victor in the shape of a new Barber of Seville, recorded under the direction of Erich Leinsdorf (four disks).

WHILE his biographer, Robert Crichton, was completing his book, Ferdinand Waldo Demara Jr., had already posed under more than a dozen real and faked names as a navy surgeon, a penologist, a high-school teacher, "a monk, a novice and a pseudo priest in probably more Catholic orders and organizations than any man in the history of the Roman Catholic Church."
The increasing need in private and governmental offices abroad for well-trained young women is the basis for a new program to be started this fall at Bennett College, Millbrook, N. Y.
A TELEVISION drama of stunning power and educational value has come from an unexpected source: the Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington.

The United Steelworkers of America with 500,000 members in basic steel mills, iron ore mines, Great Lakes ore carriers and other operations affected by the stoppage. The union has another 500,000 members in aluminum can manufacturing and steel fabricating plants whose wages are usually affected by the basic settlement.

HAVANA, July 18 -- The revolutionary Government is making radical changes in Cuba's educational system. The ideals of the Castro revolution and nationalism will be emphasized from kindergarten to university.

DESCRIBING a Danish count who thumbed his way through Spain by doing rope tricks as payment to the truck drivers who gave him rides, John Haycraft says that Spain was to him "an escape." The count "loved it because the sun made him feel differently.

The Draper Committee, in its third report to President Eisenhower, has offered a number of sensible and practical suggestions about our use of the foreign-aid program. It has not glossed over the mistakes of the past nor presented a starry-eyed vision of the future. But it has shown some ways in which our aid could be made more effective. That should be our chief concern.

FOR air travelers all over the world there comes now the good news that apparently someone in authority cares, someone is promising to see to it that the price of international airplane tickets will be forced down in the fairly early future.
What's the boss like? An apple polisher? Scared of "upstairs"? Conservative? Pleasants? Unpleasant?
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 25 -- Specialists appraising the problems of the aged have declared that it it important to keep older persons in their own homes, whenever possible.
In your "Saga of a Lady of Liberty" (July 5) you tell of the creation, and then disappearance, of the Statue of Liberty in Paris.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- France is expected in the near future to submit a formal request to the United States for technical assistance in building a nuclear-powered submarine.
In the last eight years American production of durable goods has risen 27 per cent but the number of workers making them has dropped 511,000.

DETROIT, July 25 -- More than half the adults in Wayne County thought in 1956, according to a survey, that politics was dirty or dishonest. Forty-three per cent of the county's political workers agreed.
ALGIERS, July 25 (Reuters) -- French troops continued to pour into the Kabylia Mountain region east of Algiers today in a powerful new offensive against Algerian nationalist insurgents.

Dr. Robert S. Harris, Professor of Biochemistry of Nutrition at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, reported last week that the addition of phosphates to animal diets has markedly reduced tooth decay in laboratory experiments. Studies are now being planned, he said, to find whether phosphates have the same ability to prevent tooth decay in children. Preliminary reports from a test in Sweden, he reported, indicate that such is the case.
DOVER, England, July 25 (AP) -- Inside Dover Harbor, the Hovercraft fluttered off the sea and over the beach to land without fuss amid a welcoming chorus of ships' sirens.

SYRACUSE, July 25 (AP) -- Robert C. Fuller, an executive with an oil company in Parish, Oswego County, was elected commander of the New York State American Legion today. Mr. Fuller, 49 years old, has been a Legionnaire for twelve years. He is a past Fifth District commander.
NEW PALTZ, N. Y., July 25 -- Six faculty members have petitioned the president of New Paltz State Teachers College to fight housing discrimination here.

HERE is a piece of publishing audacity. With one Harry Golden book on the best-seller list for a whole year, now comes another Golden treasury of Lower East Side reminiscence, cheerful irony, paradox, and capsule wisdom culled from that unique one-man, once-in-awhile publication, The Carolina Israelite.
ROSELLE PARK, N. J., July 25 -- Community leaders called on Gov. Robert B. Meyner today to recommend legislative action for stepping up civil defense preparedness.

NEWARK, July 25 -- Jacqueline Gay Hart flew home with her father and fiance tonight after admitting that she had run away to Chicago because of tension over her forthcoming marriage. She said she had "sort of exploded."
LONDON, July 25 -- The fiftieth anniversary of Louis Bleriot's historic flight across the English Channel was commemorated today by another unusual Channel crossing.

CASAS GRANDES, Chihuahua, Mexico -- One of the biggest archaeological projects in the Western Hemisphere is now under way at Casas Grandes, in northern Mexico. Called the Joint Casas Grandes Expedition, it is sponsored by the Amerind Foundation of Dragoon, Ariz., and the Instituto Nacional de Antropologia y Historia of Mexico City.
AKRON, July 25 (UPI) -- Three American records were set today as the Cuyahoga Falls open senior and age group meet ended its second day of activity.

GRADUATES of the Borscht circuit and Madison Avenue abound on stage and backstage in television, but two writers now milking laughs on one of the summer season's major comedy shows are alumni of London's Haberdashers Askes Hatcham Boys School.
ATHENS, July 20 -- Laborers pulling up pavement to repair sewers in a busy section of the Athens seaport, Piraeus, have discovered three outstanding ancient works of sculpture.

It is feared that President Eisenhower will veto a Democrat-sponsored bill to permit the Tennessee Valley Authority to issue bonds for the purpose of expanding its operations. If this is Mr. Eisenhower's intention, we believe he is mistaken.

AN International Congress of Strings, 100 strong, is playing classic chamber music and string orchestra repertory this summer within the latest wilderness to pass from Indian tribal sovereignty to that of the U. S. A.: postal address -- Greenleaf Lake State Park, Braggs, Okla.
In your News of the Week in Review of July 19, under "Union's Reply," occurs the simile: "As phony as a $7 bill." This was used by the steelworkers to describe the steel management's attitude.

CHICAGO, July 25 -- New York area players were among the winners in opening play as the American Contract Bridge League's summer national tournament, the largest bridge tournament of the year, opened here today at the Conrad Hilton Hotel.
The people of the free part of Berlin received a new guarantee yesterday that they have the support of the United States and of the rest of the free world against the alien forces that hem them in.
The police in Brooklyn arrested a man early yesterday who they said had admitted seventy burglaries in the last four months in the Flatbush and Crown Heights sections.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 25 -- The seventh annual predicted log contest of the Stamford Yacht Club was won today by Dr. Ralph U. Whipple in his fifty-foot Sea Whip with a score of 98.5656 per cent of prediction.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Until Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev heard of it, Captive Nations Week was causing less of a stir in the United States press than the concurrent observance of National Hot Dog Month.
A reopening of trade with the Soviet Union appears to be a logical step toward improved relations with that country, in the opinion of Robert C. Lee.
BUENOS AIRES, July 25 -- President Arturo Frondizi dismissed his Navy Secretary today under pressure of a near-mutiny in the fleet, naval air force and marine corps.

SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., July 25 -- A sparsely attended military funeral was held yesterday for Manning R. Johnson, Negro leader and one-time Communist organizer who later became an undercover agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

SANDHAMN, Sweden, July 25 (AP) -- Sweden regained sailing's International Gold Cup today when Ernie Fay of Galveston, Tex., skippering Sabre, signaled midway through the fifth and decisive race that he would not continue.
The threat of an interest rate war seems likely to bring about the reimposition of a ceiling on rates that may be paid depositors by New York State mutual savings banks.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, July 25 (Reuters) -- North Korea ignored today a protest over the attack by two MIG jet fighters on a United States Navy patrol plane June 16.

RABAT, Morocco, July 24 -- Seventeen Algerian nationalist students are now in the United States on public grants and scholarships. The figure will rise to about twenty-five by the end of the year, says the president of an outlawed Algerian student organization.
The motif of this year's La Fete des Roses, to be held at the Plaza on Oct. 15, will be that of a Japanese garden.

TO most buyers of recordings, spoken-word disks are like the fungo hitting before a crucial league game -- pleasant enough but not the main attraction. But a new catalogue issued by the Listening Library (10 East Forty-fourth Street) indicates how varied and sizable a group these recordings have become.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 25 -Sam Hunter, acting director of the Minneapolis Institute of Arts, has announced that he plans to continue the policies of his predecessor in acquiring the highest quality of works of all periods for the institute's permanent collection.

VALLEY STREAM, L. I., July 25 -- John Butler, president of the South Nassau School Boards Association, said today that he would relinquish the presidencies of two school boards here. The resignation would make his retirement as president of the association mandatory.
A district attorney and a psychiatrist expressed opinions yesterday favoring liberalization of state laws on criminal insanity.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -There was agreement in Washington today that Vice President Richard M. Nixon had thus far in his visit to the Soviet Union immeasurably advanced his Presidential prospects for next year.

THE men in the air-conditioned lunch trucks passed out foil-sealed dishes of chicken, green salad, pie and an apple to the cast, crew and extras, a corps of approximately 500 persons manning the William Goetz production of "The Mountain Road."

POINT PLEASANT, N. J., July 25 -- A nine-and-a-half-hour search for 6-year-old Kathleen Smith ended last night when a state police skin diver recovered her body near the Bay Head Shores bathing beach here.

Minnesota non-farm employment reached 932,579 in mid-June, a record for the month. The total exceeded the previous high June, in 1956, by 8,500 and was 28,273 above a year ago. The increase above May 15 was 14,480. Manufacturing employment rose 10,700, or 5 per cent higher than in 1958 and back up to the pre-recession level of 1957.
BUENOS AIRES, July 25 -Argentina's annual festival of the cow, the Seventy-third National Rural Exposition, opened today on a note of optimism for the livestock industry.
The Maumelle Ordnance Works, built during World War II by the Government at a cost in excess of $14,000,000, will be offered for sale on Sept. 29, the General Services Administration has announced.

I have just returned from a tour of Europe, and thought of how wonderful it would be to have a Tivoli of our own right here in Central Park. I, as a native New Yorker, think it is about time we attracted overseas visitors, not only with a Tivoli in Central Park, but as Mr. Sanderson suggests, with more trees, greenery and outdoor cafes.
The 1959 season of the Coast Guard's International Ice Patrol just ended was one of the busiest in ice patrol history.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The virtual acknowledgement by Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller of New York that, if the prospect pleases, he will be a contender in state primaries next spring to determine the Presidential preference of Republican voters, and the announced pledges of key New York Republicans to support him if he runs, have increased the likelihood of a contest to the finish between him and Vice President Richard M. Nixon.

Judging by the stock market at least, the psychological effect of the steel strike on the business community seemed to be rather minor -- at least for the time being. True enough, stocks sold off somewhat right after the long-expected walkout began.
AS any radio listener hereabouts knows, this safari base near Mount Kilimanjaro is midway between Cairo and Cape Town and is also the geographical center of British East Africa.
MONTREAL, July 25 -- The control of man's genetic heritage was a highlight of discussions at the ninth International Congress of Pediatrics, which closed here last night.
HANOVER, N. J., July 25 -- Hunters from Mr. and Mrs. Henry D. Paxson's Holicong, Pa., stable won three blue ribbons at the Hanover Farm Horse Show today.
ATLANTA, July 25 -- Federal pressure to end segregation in the waiting rooms for trains, buses and airlines in the South has brought varying results.

Six years ago last night Fidel Castro told 200 armed followers: "Colleagues, you will win tomorrow or be beaten, but no matter what happens this movement will triumph!" The following morning they assaulted the Moncada Barracks at Santiago de Cuba.

THE West Seventy-sixth Street Neighborhood Improvement Association will distribute flower boxes this afternoon to every building on West Seventy-sixth Street from Central Park West to Riverside Drive. The gifts are designed to encourage pride in the neighborhood.

AMID the usual huzzas, Zack Wheat, a Dodger idol in the days the Dodgers lived happily in their native state in Brooklyn, was inducted last week into baseball's Hall of Fame at Cooperstown. His selection was merited and popular. If there was any criticism, it was solely on the score that "it should have been made long ago."
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- A couple of parcels of public land, one of them amounting to 9,000,000 acres, are bothering the Interior Department at the moment, for different reasons.

THERE is a fascinating aspect of the Vancouver International Festival that only a few, thoughtful citizens of the city in British Columbia have considered. Is such an undertaking the best way for a community to raise artistic standards and to win wider appreciation for the arts?
ALBANY, July 25 -- In 1843, a man named M'Naghten tried to assassinate the British Prime Minister, Sir Robert Peel. But his aim was off, and he killed a secretary instead.

TOKYO, July 25 -- The Japanese Government issued a strong condemnation of the Japan Council Against Atomic and Hydrogen Bombs this week. It alleged that the organization had been heavily infiltrated by Communists and received substantial financial support from Communist China and the Soviet Union.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., July 25 (AP) -- A group of human-relations leaders concluded today that discrimination in housing was being intensified by the insecurity feelings of the typical residents of suburbia.

During a recent visit to the Soviet Union as a tourist I was asked many questions by Russians whom I met in parks and restaurants and on beaches. They are eager to know about every aspect of American life.

IN bringing the Ballet Rambert from London to Jacob's Pillow, Ted Shawn has hit the nail exactly on the head; it could not have come to a better place. As Shawn is constantly reminding his audiences, the Pillow is primarily an educational institution, and the festival performances that fill the theatre all summer are designed as part of the educational experience of both the resident student body and the visiting public.

IT is as exciting for any one interested in American art to rummage through the card catalogue of the Archives of American Art in Detroit as it must be for an archeologist to discover the first fragments of a buried city.

LOS ANGELES, July 25 -- Democratic strategists in California have already started backstage planning for the possibility of a presidential race in 1960 between Gov. Edmund G. Brown and New York's Governor Rockefeller.
MOSCOW, July 25 (UPI) -First Deputy Premier Frol R. Kozlov, a man who knows his subways, said today that he thought the ones in New York were "lousy."
CLEVELAND, July 25 -American-owned vessels are being squeezed out of the Great Lakes grain market, the Lake Carriers Association said today.
The minor explosion in Iraq ten days ago lays bare the deep-seated problems beneath the surface of Premier Abdul Karim Kassim's political troubles.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 25 -- Art Ceccarelli of the Cubs beat the San Francisco Giants today, 5 -- 3. It was his fourth straight victory since being called up from Fort Worth three weeks ago.
MONTICELLO, N. Y., July 25 (AP) -- Albert Anastasia, 16 years old, drowned in Lake St. Dominic near here today while visiting his sister at a summer camp.

IT goes without saying -- yet occasionally needs to be said again -- that every good novel must establish a conviction of place. "Measure My Love" is a novel whose great virtue is its beautiful re-creation in words of a real place, most convincingly established.

At the Larchmont Yacht Club, Tuesday through Friday, the Sailboat Training Facility, Inc., will hold the second set of meetings in a series aimed at giving qualified persons additional knowledge of sailing techniques.

KARACHI, July 25 -- The Pakistan Government has appealed to the United States for aid to 11,000,000 people in the flood-ravaged West Pakistan Province.

AALSMEER, Holland -- Our week-long tour of Holland's canals and rivers in our rented cabin cruiser has proved to be one of the high spots of our European vacation. In contrast to sightseeing by car and train, it has been a refreshing experience to sit on deck and watch the ancient houses, windmills and waterfront gardens move slowly past.
MOSCOW, July 25 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon, in a surprise announcement today, said that he and his wife and their party would pay a fourday visit to Poland after leaving the Soviet Union.

ALTHOUGH Bertrand Russell once before has written on "My Mental Development" (in 17 brief pages), "My Philosophical Development" constitutes his full length, definitive intellectual autobiography. It is a fascinating document written with Russell's usual lucidity.

A Queens civic group announced yesterday that Mrs. Caroline K. Simon, Secretary of State in Governor Rockefeller's Cabinet, had promised aid in its effort to maintain a racial balance and avoid the creation of "new segregated ghettos."

PRIMITIVE man lived in caves and found it good. Modern man hoping for survival in an atomic age re-examines the possibility. In "Ex ploring Caves," Polly Longsworth writes about both primitive and modern man and about all the creatures and things that have lived, sought shelter or existed in caves.
HAVANA, July 25 -- The excitement, intoxication and exhilaration of a nation caught in a revolutionary surge have come to a thundering climax in Havana this week-end.

CARBONDALE, Pa., July 25 -- One of the most unusual redevelopment projects in the country, soon to get under way here, hinges on putting out a coal mine fire that has menaced the city for twelve years.
RABAT, Morocco, July 25 -The Moroccan Cabinet met in a day-long session today to discuss the question of the devaluation of the Moroccan franc.
The Rev. Dr. Daniel A. Poling, editor of The Christian Herald, yesterday supported the Post Office ban on "Lady Chatterley's Lover," a romantic novel by D. H. Lawrence.

Brown, Professor of Business Administration at the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration, together with Miss Eleanor G. May, Associate in Research.

In railroad executive offices throughout the land, some deceptively dry-looking documents are making popular summer reading.

NICE, France, July 22 -- To patrons of Christian Dior in Paris, Bonwit Teller or Lord Taylor in New York and shops the world over catering to an exclusive clientele, Mme. Claude Kogan is known as the creator of ultra-chic swim suits that sell for a $35 minimum.

CHARLES W. FERGUSON, who last year gave us the scholarly, and readable biography of Cardinal Wolsey, "Naked to Mine Enemies," is a senior editor of The Reader's Digest. He is the author of four other books and many magazine articles and is a seasoned and active public speaker.
LONDON, July 25 -- The public here, from what it can read in the British press, appears to be concerned more with Queen Elizabeth's health than with the reception she has received in Canada.

SPURRED on perhaps, by the critical acclaim for his direction of "Compulsion." Richard Fleischer passed through town last week en route to Europe with plans for three new projects intended to activate his brand-new independent film unit.
WATERTOWN, N. Y., July 25 -- Nearly 18,000 National Guardsmen and Army Reservists, many from the New York City area, moved into Camp Drum today for their annual two weeks of summer training.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -Senate subcommittee hearings on proposals to make it more difficult for railroads to cut passenger service are scheduled to end next week. Thereafter the subcommittee is expected to report a bill that will tighten regulations somewhat, but not as much as proposed in the bill that inspired the hearings.
Oil operations in Iraq are proceeding at a record pace despite the revolution and the several disquieting incidents that have taken place in that Middle East country.
John A. Matousek has joined Acme Precision Products, Inc., Dayton, Ohio, as vice president and general manager. He had been general manager of the General Tire and Rubber Company's Respro division.

HARTFORD, July 25 -- Connecticut's new law on minority representation for all public boards, commissions and committees in the state, elective or appointive, was clarified this week in an opinion by Albert L. Coles, the State Attorney General.
PARIS, July 24 -- In two widely separated cities of France, peaceful citizens have suddenly been confronted with a plague familiar to New York -youth gangs, "rumbles" and "turfs."

PROFESSIONAL and power tools are readily available to home gardeners at moderate rental fees. By renting equipment by the day or week, property owners can do necessary chores and still save on the price of expensive tools.

POSTMASTER GENERAL ARTHUR E. SUMMERFIELD yesterday made public the design of the Hawaii Statehood 7-cent air mail commemorative stamp which he plans to release on the day when Hawaii is formally admitted to the Union as the fiftieth state.

A FEW well-selected oriental accessories can make an ikebana, or Japanese flower arrangement, at home in an American room. The arranger can select from many readily available imports of Japanese objets d'art, such as the popular kakemono, or hang-scroll.

I can only say "Amen!" to James D. Sanderson's plan to civilize New York with one exception -- his suggestion to turn part of Central Park into an amusement center patterned after Tivoli in Copenhagen.

An 11-year-old girl was attacked and bitten by a German shepherd dog yesterday in the backyard of a friend's house in Brooklyn. The girl, Joyce Fischetti, was taken to Kings County Hospital in serious condition with wounds on the face, arms and legs.
Denmark has honored a United States Coast Guard cutter for its role in the search for survivors of the ill-fated Danish liner Hans Hedtoft.

The proposal to set up a Council of Foreign Ministers was the first one made by the United States at the first summit conference after the end of the war in Europe. OTTAWA, July 25 -- Premier Joseph Smallwood of Newfoundland is expected to ask an election to endorse his stand in a financial quarrel with the Federal Government.
HAVANA, July 25 (AP) -- Senor del Pino, 32 years old, complained on May 30 that he had been attacked at Miami Beach by a gang that he called "Fidel Castro police."

WHETHER it is on a patio, a terrace or at public picnic grounds, an outdoor buffet is one of the pleasantest of summer's diversions. Some of the most delectable of such feasts are served occasionally in the home of Mrs. Hanns Ditisheim, the wife of a New York investment banker.

A VACATION for many is a change of environment. For urban and even suburban dwellers, there are few changes so abrupt or rewarding as a visit to a natural woodland. Such visits are more meaningful if a few rules of safety and good manners are observed.
LARCHMONT, N. J., July 25 -- A husband-and-wife team, Dick and Beverly Becker of the American Yacht Club, gained the highest award of the sixty-first Larchmont Yacht Club Race Week today.

Chevrolet has announced plans to almost double the size of the Baltimore assembly plants. This will make the Baltimore operations the second largest in Chevrolet's national network of ten combination car and truck assembly plants. This project is the largest single industrial expansion ever announced in Baltimore City.
LEVITTOWN, L. I., July 25 -- Lyle C. Smith, the first president of the school board here, has agreed to run as a "non-partisan" candidate in a special school board election on Aug. 13.
The state's railroads have urged Governor Rockefeller to intervene with the Thruway Authority to bar use of ninety-eight-foot-long tandem-trailers on the toll road.
TOKYO, July 20 -- Tokyo's millions, and thousands of summer visitors, may have seen the last of the great annual competitive fireworks festivals on the Sumida River if the police have their way.
OTTAWA, July 25 -- Through no fault of hers, Queen Elizabeth's tour of Canada will end next week on a far less happy note than was intended.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., July 25 -- Oarsmen from the New York Athletic Club dominated the metropolitan championships at Travers Island today. In an eighteen - event program, the Winged Foot rowers retained the James H. Hughes Memorial Trophy.

THIS may sound like an anachronism but it's true: in San Diego, Calif., and in Cleveland, Ohio, they are building electric automobiles. Not the square, high-box, tiller-steered electric of revered memory, like the Baker, or the Rauch and Lange, or the Detroit Electric which began in 1906 as the Anderson Electric, and was still being manufactured as late as 1923.

Plans for the establishment of India's first watch industry are proceeding under arrangements with a group of French companies, according to the Information Service of India. The first wrist watch factory is to be set up under an agreement by the Phoenix Watch Company, Bombay, Lhorlogerie de Savoi and a group of other French companies.

LONDON, July 25 (UPI) -- The Moscow radio denounced today 'the quacks who peddle" reports of anti-Semitism in the Soviet Union and denied for the second day charges in the United States press of discrimination against Jews.

COLONIA, N. J., July 26 -- Seymour Holub, who had not played tournament golf for six years prior to yesterday, combined with Tony Pacifico and won the New Jersey Golf Association's Scotch foursome tournament at the Colonia Country Club today. The Shackamaxon pair beat forty other teams with 75, 75 -- 150 in the 36-hole affair.

CHICAGO, July 26 -- Many persons here appeared to feel that Mr. Nixon had done well. Thhe three television stations here showed the debate reported extraordinary interest. They reported hundreds of telephone calls asking when the film would be shown.

PITTSBURGH, July 26 -- There were no signs last week that any steel customer was short of steel. The two-week extension of the steel labor contract was said to have made it possible for a great number of steel users to get what was coming to them on promised shipments.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 26 (UPI) -- Bob Anderson pitched the Chicago Cubs to a 7-3 victory over the San Francisco Giants today.
NEW DELHI, India, July 15 -- India's foreign liabilities at the end of 1958 are estimated at $1,369,200,000. The United States has emerged as the largest creditor with loans totaling $642,600,000.

CHICAGO, July 26 (UPI) -- Milt Pappas dropped the Chicago White Sox from the American League lead into second place today. He pitched a five-hit shutout as the Baltimore Orioles won the second game of a double header, 4 -- 0, after the Sox took the opener, 4 -- 1.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI) -- Two Republican Senators said today the United States must keep a close eye on developments in Cuba and the possibility of Communist infiltration in the regime of Dr. Fidel Castro.

TICONDEROGA, N. Y., July 26 -- A latter-day Samuel de Champlain, complete with black boots, blue cloak and red plumed hat, splashed ashore from a canoe fleet in the shadow of Fort Ticonderoga this hot, sunny afternoon.
LONDON, July 26 -- The Labor party will be confronted at its forthcoming annual conference with at least 140 resolutions on the party's divided outlook toward nuclear disarmament.

MOSCOW, July 26 -- The Communist party propaganda apparatus intensified its efforts today to inject a sour note into the opening days of the American National Exhibition and the visit of Vice President Richard M. Nixon.
NEW ORLEANS, La., July 26 -- Everyone interviewed here seemed pleased that the Vice President had been firm and outspoken in the debate. Some comments:
A California scientist has reported the discovery of a strange new golden bacterium that can dismantle one of the toughest known viruses into minute granules, "rodlets" and rings.

MOSCOW, July 26 -- The fashion show at the American National Exhibition is recognized by some Russian visitors for what it was intended to be, "unusual." The main goal of its American producers was to demonstrate through skits how America lives, rather than to present a staggering array of high-priced clothes.

LONDON, July 26 (AP) -- Pan American Airlines plans an official protest that the British are using unfair tactics in the high-speed battle of the airways between the Boeing 707 and the British-built Comet, aviation sources said today.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 26 -- The Robert R. Martin Memorial Trophy was won today by Dr. Allen B. DuMont in his fifty-four foot, Annapolis-built Hurricane III. Dr. DuMont's score was 99.25 per cent correct. Last month he won the Atlantic Highlands to Atlantic City event.
An economist for the city urged last night that New York take "more direct action" to combat raiding of its industrial plants by other communities.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 26 -- One of the unwritten laws of the movie world is that an actor must never admit he is not in demand. Every agent in Hollywood may know he has been turned down for small parts in horror movies, but the star tells it differently.

ZURICH, Switzerland, July 26 -- Another great stride toward European economic integration, destined to affect the Stock Exchange business profoundly, was taken last week when Spain emerged from her post-war isolation to become the eighteenth full member of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Republican leaders not only have written off any chances of recapturing the Senate in 1960, but also are not now expecting any significant gains.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -Naval officers rarely lose an opportunity to ignore their own Vice Admiral Hymen G. Rickover, of atomic submarine fame.
LONDON, July 26 -- A healthy midsummer lassitude seems to have settled over the financial district here. Last week's stock market was the quietest in five months.
OSAKA, Japan, July 26 (AP) -- The United States swimming team defeated Japan in a two-day meet ending today, 37 to 33. Three world records were bettered before a crowd of 7,500.
HANOVER, N. J., July 26 -Pennsylvania horses won the hunter and jumper championships at the three-day Hanover Farm horse show today.
DOTHAN, Ala., July 26 (UPI) -- An Army lieutenant, making his first parachute jump yesterday, went up after leaving the plane, instead of down.

The International Commission of Jurists, meeting in Geneva, has now issued its preliminary report on "The Question of Tibet and the Rule of Law." This distinguished body, nonpolitical and nongovernmental, derives its support from more than 30,000 lawyers in fifty countries. Its word, therefore, carries weight.
DETROIT, July 26 -- That man Lary did it again today.
HAVERFORD, Pa., July 26 -- Barry MacKay won the Pennsylvania lawn tennis championship today for the second successive year.
ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, July 26 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser said tonight that the United Arab Republic would not shy away from a decisive battle with Israel.

TROY, N. Y., July 26 (AP) -- Nineteen-year-old John Konsek set a course record for amateurs today as he overwhelmed Ward Wettlaufer, 4 and 3, and retained the New York State amateur golf championship.
The man who will become the city's Welfare Commissioner on Aug. 21 declared yesterday that public assistance should be based upon need alone, without regard to the morals of applicants.

The General Services Administration has leased a building to be constructed at the northwest corner of East 151st Street and Walton Avenue, the Bronx. The building will house the offices of the Social Security Administration for the lower Bronx.

LENOX, Mass., July 26 -- Two special features of this afternoon's Berkshire Festival concert by Charles Munch and the Boston Symphony Orchestra were the appearances of Rudolf Serkin as soloist in the Brahms D minor Piano Concerto, and of Aaron Copland, conducting the Suite from his opera "The Tender Land."

CHICAGO, July 26 -- The largest group ever to play in a single session of a bridge tournament began play here today in the national tournament of the American Contract Bridge League at the Conrad Hilton Hotel.

Governor Rockefeller has revived a previously created committee whose function is to study changes in the state law on criminal insanity. At the same time the State Bar Association has come forward with a series of new definitions that it proposes for enactment into a new statute.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Attorney General William P. Rogers has told Congress that the Administration opposes repeal of the ban on Presidential third terms because the ban has not had a fair test.
ORANGEBURG, N. Y., July 26 -- A pre-Revolutionary farmhouse was dedicated here today as the headquarters of the Tappan Zee Historical Society.
THIS week the fashion press of the world will attend the premiere of Jacques Heim's fall collection in Paris. But New Yorkers can buy a Heim fall design at Bonwit Teller right now.

HAVANA, July 26 -- Dr. Fidel Castro resumed tonight the position of Premier of Cuba.

Geraldine Page, Jason Robards Jr. and George C. Scott will be the stars of S. Lee Pogostin's first original one-hour television play, "People Kill People Sometimes."

Foreign carriers on Atlantic air routes are steadily nibbling at the share of United States- flag airlines in this major travel area. Although the bulk of trans-Atlantic air travel is American, foreign competition is on the increase, and future prospects are that it will take more and more of the business, according to executives of the two American companies, Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines.

RYE, N. Y., July 26 -- The twenty-eighth annual American Yacht Club cruise drew a record number of starters, thirty-two, for the overnight race that opened the six-day junket on Long Island Sound today. The rest of the fifty-one entries, also an over-all record, are expected to join the flotilla at rendezvous tomorrow at Duck Island Roads, off Clinton, Conn., where the overnight passage ends.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 26 -- Two guest skippers, Bobby Coulson and Frank Scully, took turns winning a pair of International Class races with Robert Haynes' Annie in wispery air off the Larchmont Yacht Club today.

The Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation reported that second-quarter earnings were more than 100 per cent and half year profits 79 per cent above the like periods of a year ago. Higher sales, elimination of marginal and unprofitable units in 1958 were cited.

Spokesmen for coastal and intercoastal steamship operators report that they are "encouraged" by growing opposition to an extension of the regulatory powers of the Interstate Commerce Commission over shipping.

The goal of all actors -- playing the pivotal role in a Broadway play -- finally will be achieved by Nehemiah Persoff. The performer has been chosen to impersonate Harry Golden in the Jerome Lawrence-Robert E. Lee biographical drama, based on Mr. Golden's book, "Only in America."
Bright lantana and geranium plants in boxes were placed on window ledges along five blocks of West Seventy-sixth Street between Central Park West and Riverside Drive in a community project yesterday.

A bright picture of sales and earnings was produced by the Eastman Kodak Company in the quarter and half-year ended June 14. They were the best on record for the period.

A BOOMING mail order business in international foods is conducted on Third Avenue, in the vicinity of Twenty-eighth Street. There are three outstanding food shops in as many blocks and the only nation not represented is the United States.
SHORT HILLS, N. J., July 26 (AP) -- No bills will ever be submitted in the fifty-hour search for Miss Jacqueline Gay Hart, but the all-out search involved a large expense of men and time.

The urgency of the growing threat to the city's bathing beaches from continued and worsening pollution of our recreational waters in many areas has been emphasized by the demand of a special city committee for $8,180,000 in the 1960 capital budget. This would begin a long and necessarily costly program of corrective measures. The committee, headed by Public Works Commissioner Zurmuhlen, was formed to seek a solution to the beach-pollution problem.
Correspondents of The New York Times have made a spot check in several cities with large Negro populations to learn whether Negro districts have Negro or white policemen.

STROLLERS in the vicinity of St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church on Second Avenue just before 11 o'clock yesterday morning could have seen Albert Clinton Petite, a conservatively dressed young man, arrive on a stripped-down, collapsible bicycle of the type used by para troopers.
MOSCOW, July 26 -- Not the least startling sight these last few days in Moscow was a tableau of Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev and his associates cheerfully quaffing icecold Pepsi-Cola from paper cups.

CLEVELAND, July 26 (UPI) -- Jim Baxes' twelth-inning single drove in the winning run today as the Cleveland Indians scored a 4-3 second-game victory over the Washington Senators. A crowd of 30,121 saw the Indians win the opener, 9 -- 0, as Jim Perry pitched a two-hitter and Woody Held smashed two homers.

The reapportionment of Congressional districts is a major key to civil liberties, the American Civil Liberties Union declared yesterday. The group endorsed a reapportionment bill now before the House Judiciary Committee.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 26 -- The Roman Catholic Diocese of Bridgeport announced today that it would undertake a house-to-house census Sept. 13 through 20 in Fairfield County.
The population of the United States keeps right on growing. We have added the equivalent of today's Philippines or Egypt since 1950.
LIBERAL charge account and credit plans now offered by New York stores and banks could lure any woman into a state of euphoria, not to mention extravagance.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- A widely supported program for the development of a national air cargo fleet operated by commercial carriers came to a sudden and mysterious halt in the Pentagon last week.

The Grace Line has asked for bids for the construction of three combination cargo-passenger vessels. The ships, which will employ cargo containers, are designed for service on Trade Route 2, the Grace Line route between the Eastern Seaboard and the West Coast of South America.

The city will soon begin a study of the feasibility of staggering working hours to relieve rush-hour subway congestion, Mayor Wagner announced yesterday.

HONG KONG, July 26 -- Reports are increasing here of open criticism in Communist China of that country's leadership. In addition, there are many recent indications of changes in major mainland policies.

"There are great and exciting things ahead for God's faithful people," the Rev. David M. Paton predicted in a sermon yesterday at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue and Tenth Street.
HONOLULU, July 26 -- This is a significant week for labor and management in Hawaii.
KATMANDU, Nepal, July 26 -- The outlook for stability and progress is better in Nepal today than at any time since the autocratic regime of the Rana family was overthrown in 1951.
HAVANA, July 26 -- Cuba's bedraggled but proud rebel army paraded today in happy confusion before its idolized leader, Dr. Fidel Castro.
