A new home is being sought for Circle in the Square, the group that has been residing at 5 Sheridan Square in Greenwich Village. Theodore Mann, co-sponsor with Jose Quintero and Leigh Connell, confirmed reports yesterday that notification had been received from the landlord, Sheridan Towers, to move by Oct. 31.

READING, Vt., July 26 -- Josiah P. Marvel, a retired social worker and organizer during World War II of the Quaker Emergency Service, was found dead yesterday at Hurricane Hill, his farm home here. Windsor County authorities listed his death as a suicide from an overdose of narcotics.
Volume in the steamship charter market fell last week as virtually all commodity trades were hit by charterer disinterest, even at current low rate levels.

An increasing number of New Yorkers are discovering this month that doorbell politics begins with a sheet of bright green paper -- the designating petition. Participants in party primary contests have been busy collecting signatures in support of their candidates since June 30.
VIENNA, July 26 -- The New York leadership of the American delegation that was repudiated last night was put back in control today by the managers of the Seventh World Youth Festival.
MINNEAPOLIS July 26 -- "I think this will help Nixon politically -- dammit!"
KINGSTON, Jamaica, July 26 -- Sir Alexander Bustamante, leader of the Jamaica Labor party, has declined to issue a call for nonviolence in the last stage of the election campaign here.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- (UPI) -- Neil H. McElroy, Secretary of Defense, said tonight the Soviet Union might have beaten the United States in the race to get the first intercontinental ballistic missiles into the hands of combat units.
CITY "cliff dwellers" longing for real cliffs, a faraway island or a dip in an old-fashioned swimming hole can find rural recreation in a variety of places.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., July 26 (UP) -- President Eisenhower said today he had received a report from Vice President Richard M. Nixon that led him to believe Nixon's outspoken debate with Premier Nikita S. Krushchev two days ago was not as bitter as it seemed.
CLERMONT, France, July 26 (UPI) -- Stirling Moss of England won the Auvergne Grand Prix today. The auto race was marred by two serious accidents.

DETROIT, July 26 -- A depressed Bill Skowron, his fractured left wrist in a cast, packed his baseball gear today and returned to New York, resigned to the fact that he is through for the year.
VIENNA July 26 -- The International Youth Festival, two years in massive and Soviet-directed preparation, opened here today with the biggest splash of Communist showmanship seen in the West.

CHICAGO, July 26 -- Every good bridge player knows by heart a number of stratagems that work against weaker players but not against other good ones. These include various simple false cards, underleads of high cards and especially the device of leading an unguarded suit when declarer at a no-trump contract, expecting that the opponents will then avoid leading that suit.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- The imposition of margin requirements on the purchase of Government bonds -- by specifying mandatory down payments or by voluntary means, or both -- was suggested today in a massive official study of the Federal securities market.
A tale of "dictatorship by fear" in Haiti was related here yesterday by two men who were formerly powerful supporters of President Francois Duvalier.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI) -- Attorney General William P. Rogers today reported that United States Attorneys throughout the nation filed more suits, wound up more cases and collected more money than ever before, in the fiscal year ended June 30.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey said today he would expect to do "right well" in the South, despite his strong civil rights views, if he won the 1960 Democratic Presidential nomination.
Two thousand persons attended the 100th anniversary celebration yesterday of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., July 26 (AP) -- Senator James O. Eastland, Democrat of Mississippi, declared tonight that the Supreme Court had transformed itself into a "super legislature" in an attempt to dictate all activities of Federal and state government.
The National Presbyterian Church in Washington is planning to construct new quarters there, the Rev. Dr. Edward L. R. Elson said yesterday.

MOUNT MAKILING, Philippines, July 26 (AP) -- Twelve thousand Boy Scouts from fifty-one countries paraded in final review before international scout leaders today as the tenth World Scout Jamboree came to a close.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- A new type of nuclear submarine power plant that will be quieter, simpler and more reliable is under development by the Naval Research Branch of the Atomic Energy Commission. Admiral Hyman G. Rickover leads the branch.
WHETHER baseball is a sport or a business is still debatable. Outstanding Congressional minds are about to kick this one around again within the next few days.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., July 26 -- "Oedipus Rex" is not only one of the great pivotal works in Stravinsky's relentless evolution as a composer but also one of the monuments of neoclassicism. It deserves to be performed often but gets infrequent hearings. One of these occurred last night at the Empire State Music Festival.
NAPLES, Italy, July 26 (AP) -- Laszlo Kovats of Hungary today won the Capri-to-Naples race for the world distance swimming championship.

The Fairmount Chemical Company has purchased a large plot of land adjoining its plant on Blanchard Street, Newark, to expand its manufacturing. The buyer, which also has a plant on Ferry Street, bought the additional property from the Arthur Venneri Realty Company in a deal negotiated by the Archie Schwartz Realty Company, brokers.
HOUSTON, Tex., July 26 -- Houstonians in general, even some who oppose Mr. Nixon, applauded his role in the debate.
GENEVA, July 26 -- The Western powers face a new test of their unity during the ninth week of the foreign ministers' conference, starting here tomorrow.

In a busy evening at Lewisohn Stadium on Saturday, Leonard Bernstein spoke and conducted, Seymour Lipkin played the piano and conducted, Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer briefly spoke, and the audience also had its say.

In an effort to keep United States scientists informed of up-to-date advances in Soviet science the National Science Foundation has released a translation study that makes available seventy-six Soviet scientific journals from the more than two thousand published throughout the Soviet Union. In July, 1831, Horace Holden sailed out of New Bedford aboard the whaler Mentor on his first seagoing voyage. In May, 1832, the ship was wrecked on a reef in the Palau Islands in the South Pacific. Ten sailors and Holden survived the disaster and were captured by natives.

VIENNA, July 26 -- One of journalism's most astonishing episodes is now occurring in Vienna. The week's biggest news story is under total boycott by this capital's ten non-Communist newspapers, which have voluntarily undertaken not to print a word about it.

Prices of domestic cotton futures held to a narrow trading range last week. At the close on Friday active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 15 points (75 cents a bale) lower than a week earlier.

CAIRO, July 26 -- The seventh anniversary today of the abdication and exile of King Farouk found Cairo celebrating a fine midsummer holiday. Quietly, in its own way and without fanfare or publicity, one of the most valuable social institutions in the city does its work on the lower East Side. This is Grand street Settlement, which serves more than 2,500 members of thirty different races and creeds annually.

Mexico's can-making industries are expanding rapidly in expectation of a soaring demand for canned products during the next decade. Canned goods are generally a luxury in Mexico, which is predominantly a fresh produce country.

Sutro Bros. Co., an investment company and a member of the New York Stock Exchange, has leased 10,000 square feet of space at 20 East Forty-sixth Street for its fourth midtown office. Jewish students with excellent secondary school records face "no significant" discrimination in college admissions, according to a report issued yesterday by the American Jewish Congress.

Russian tradition has it that the city of Moscow was founded some 812 years ago. UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 26 -- Short of stringent governmental measures, the economy of Panama is likely to decline in the next decade. This is the major conclusion reached by the Economic Commission for Latin America after a two-year analysis.
The National Van Lines, Inc., has made a move of its own. Its advertising account has Been awarded to the Chicago office of Maxon, Inc.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., Harlem Democrat, announced yesterday that Tammany's choice for the Municipal Court in the Eighth District would be challenged by a Negro in the Sept., 15, primary.

"For 2 Cents Plain" If anything can be predicted in the unpredictable book world the expression "For 2 Cents Plain" soon should become a byword across the country. For this is the title of the second group, just published, of Harry Golden's essays culled from the pages of The Carolina Israelite, a collection that is directly in the spirit of his still-best-selling "Only in America."

CLINTON, Conn. July 27 -- Fred Hibberd's yawl, Caprice, a 38-footer of the host club fleet, captured the Commodore John B. Shethar Bowl today by placing first on corrected time in the overnight race which opened the twenty-eighth annual American Yacht Club cruise on Long Island Sound.

SEATTLE, Wash., July 27 -- George H. Deming of New York questioned the patriotism and sincerity today of "splinter groups" that resist the development of new forms of urban government.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, July 27 -- A carnival atmosphere reigned on this island capital today as the end of the campaign for tomorrow's general elections approached.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI) -- The House today passed and sent to the Senate a bill to prevent new holding companies from setting up chain operations in the savings and loan field.

TORONTO, July 27 (Canadian Press) -- Abitibi Power and Paper Company, Ltd., had first-half net earnings of $5,320,524, or $1.22 a share, compared with $4,437,557, or $1, in the corresponding period last year. Net sales were $64,952,813, compared with $62,139,478.
A grocer looked at a man a few feet away from him in Felony Court yesterday and said he was "positive" the man was one of two who had robbed his store of $347.41 on July 11.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The Government's shortest-term borrowing costs declined this week to the lowest level since late May.

NEW DELHI, India, July 27 -- The Indian Communist party announced plans today to hold demonstrations throughout the country to protest any move by the central Government to dismiss the Communist Ministry of Kerala State.

United States concern willing to get credit without compensation for thus saving American National Exhibition in Moscow please wire Harold C. McClellan, general manager, Sokolniki Park, Moscow.

Two American steamship companies will get back from the Government $1,125,000 of about $1,650,000 they spent on steps preliminary to the prospective building of two superliners. The money was in architect, design and decorator fees.

Lack of activity in the Cuban sugar market depressed world sugar prices on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Final prices were unchanged to 4 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) lower on 18,700 tons.

A new secondary school, the St. Sergius High School, will open in September at 1190 Park Avenue. School officials said it would be the first high school to be established by the Russian Orthodox Church outside of Russia.

The popularity of the Treasury's new issues of 4 3/4 per cent notes is still the prime news in the bond market. In a trading session otherwise quiet and uneventful, the new Government securities were bid up to new highs.

A jurisdictional dispute among rival groups of ship painters threatened a tie-up today of the Port of New York by longshoremen.
A racial dispute over Harlem's wholesale liquor salesmen has raised fears among white business men that a widespread "buy black" campaign is in the offing in the area.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Senator Olin D. Johnston, Democrat of South Carolina, blocked the Judiciary Committee again today from starting work on a civil rights bill.
GENEVA, July 27 -- The foreign secretaries of the United States, Britain and France will meet here tomorrow to discuss ways to reopen negotiations on general disarmament.

THERE may be something of a rumpus at 8 P. M. on Aug. 11 in the Assembly Chamber of the New Jersey State House at Trenton. The state's Fish and Game Council will hold public hearings then on tentative hunting regulations, announced a couple of weeks ago.

HACKENSACK, N. J., July 27 -- Chances are that if you are a consistent bowler your ball will travel into the pins somewhere between fourteen and eighteen miles an hour. Through a number of experimental rolls at Bowler City today, it was determined that bowlers send their balls down the alley at these speeds.
United Air Lines posted record revenues and earnings for both the second quarter and first half, W. A. Patterson, president, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI) -- Representative Frank Kowalski, a critic of military manpower waste, said today he had evidence of a "ridiculous" Air Force plan for giving men practice in saluting.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The post-war rate of growth of the nation's industrial output has been "materially greater" than indicated by the accepted statistical measurements, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

NICE, France, July 27 -- The Tour de France bike race ended nine days ago but no one would know it. The newspapers are still full of bizarre echoes of the tour and bike racing itself, this continent's summertime sports staple, has not yet recovered from the paralysis it brought on.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 27 -- A chronic complaint these days among producers here is that they are unable to make movies because important stars are not available.
Regulation in the public interest has worked in the last half century, New York's Superintendent of Insurance said yesterday.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., July 27 -- One of the highlights of the annual fair of the Ladies Village Improvement Society that will be held here on Friday will be two showings of a fashion show entitled "Fashions of Today and Yesterday."
WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI) -- The House voted without dissent today to give each of its members an additional $600 a year for stationery -- or a total of $1,800.
SHORT HILLS, N. J., July 27 -- The wedding of Jacqueline Gay Hart, originally scheduled for Aug. 29, has been postponed indefinitely.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI) -- The establishment of a third baseball major league got an enthusiastic welcome in Congress today.

VIENNA, July 27 -- Soviet showmanship and Western European Communist professionalism scored heavily all along the line today against Austrian opponents and rebels in the United States delegation to the World Youth Festival.
ROME, July 27 -- Renewed efforts by the Sicilian Assembly to elect a new chief of the island Government failed again tonight. An anti-Communist candidate was leading by one vote.

CHICAGO, July 27 -- Union Tank Car Company, Chicago, today announced the purchase of the Lindsay Company, St. Paul, manufacturer of water softeners, for 225,000 shares of Union Tank Car stock. WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- Representative Thompson said today both management and labor had threatened to oppose him in the next election if he did not support their labor reform views.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 27 -- The seventy-first annual Southampton invitation grass court tennis tournament started at the Meadow Club today. The entry of sixty-four players was headed by Ian Vermaak of South Africa and Antonio Palafox of Mexico.
Two thieves pretended to be exterminators to get into a Broadway restaurant early yesterday, then got out with $20,000.

LENINGRAD, July 27 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon reported to President Eisenhower early today that his long conversation with Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev yesterday had made "no substantial progress" in resolving United States-Soviet differences over the future of Germany and Berlin.
TERRE HAUTE, Ind., July 27 (AP) -- Lawyers defending the eight accused operators of an alleged multi-million-dollar gambling syndicate rested their case today without calling any witnesses.
ROME, July 27 -- Although no election is ahead, Christian Democratic leaders are campaigning vigorously.
MILWAUKEE, July 27 (UPI) -- The Milwaukee Braves beat the Pittsburgh Pirates again today, 5 -- 2, and regained second place in the National League.

The Alleghany Corporation signed a contract yesterday to acquire the vast Courthouse Square realty development project of Webb Knapp, Inc., in downtown Denver. The closing is expected early next year.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- The Supreme Court has been asked to review the contempt-of-court conviction of Orion Sherwood, who sought to sail into forbidden Pacific waters last year in protest against projected nuclear tests.
MONTREAL, July 27 (Canadian Press) -- Port authorities believe that ocean shipping traffic so far this year has refuted Montreal's pre-Seaway fears of dwindling maritime business.

A Canadian physician yesterday appealed to the police here for help in recovering valuable medical records and photographic slides that he reported were stolen from his auto a few hours after midnight.

CHICAGO, July 27 (AP) -- A late flurry of selling wiped out moderate gains that corn and soybean futures had held almost all day on the Board of Trade and left all corn and soybeans contracts below Friday's masses.

The United States Rubber Company raised its net income in the first six months of this year by 118 per cent by expanding net sales to a record $508,864,623.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- Twenty companies are getting 50 per cent of the Government's defense contracts,, Senator John J. Sparkman said today.
The nation's production of raw steel dropped to 365,000 net tons last week the first full week of the nation-wide steel strike, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

A feud is raging between Michael Ellis, operator-producer of the Bucks County Playhouse in New Hope, Pa., and Ned Armstrong, dramatist. It started over the week-end when Mr. Ellis canceled the scheduled tryout there of Mr. Armstrong's three - character comedy, "Intermission." At the same time, Mr. Armstrong resigned as Mr. Ellis' publicity director.

Senator Humphrey was not a victim of the "equal time" provisions of Section 315. The Senator is not yet a candidate for office but merely a candidate for a candidacy. And as such he was not entitled to "equal time."
BUENOS AIRES, July 27 -- The Frondizi Administration received alarming new evidence of its unpopularity today in results from municipal elections in Santa Fe Province.

PARIS, July 27 -- The first regular Parliamentary session of Fifth French Republic ended today with a modest record of accomplishment and with the postponement of really divisive issues until the fall session.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- The United States Tax Court decided today that Welburn Mayock is not now liable for taxes on the entire $65,000 he collected in 1948 for getting the Treasury to issue a tax ruling desired by a wealthy New Yorker.
Charges that teachers at the New Paltz State Teachers College had suffered discrimination in off-campus housing are to be investigated by the State Commission Against Discrimination.
GENEVA, July 27 (AP) -- West Germany has agreed in principle to propose a nonaggression pact with Poland and Czechoslovakia, Bonn officials said today:

BUENOS AIRES, July 27 -- Argentina's petroleum picture has brightened measurably in the year that has passed since President Arturo Frondizi announced the entrance of private foreign developers into the nationalized Argentine fields.

A public offering of 318,736 shares of the common stock of Wilcox Electric Company, Inc., is being made today by investment bankers headed jointly by Lee Higginson Corporation and Stern Brothers Co. The price is $16.50 a share. Wilcox manufactures aeronautical radio and navigation systems in Kansas City, Mo.

WESTPORT, Conn., July 27 -- It is not often that one encounters opera on the straw-hat circuit. It is even rarer to find contemporary opera there. The White Barn Theatre last night had the initiative to present works by Jan Meyerowitz, a composer resident in New York, and Hermann Reutter, a German living in Stuttgart.

The sixth and final week of the season of concerts at Lewisohn Stadium opened last night with the first of four Beethoven programs. Like the similar Beethoven cycle last summer, this one is being led by Josef Krips.
A takin, "a cow-like critter that looks like a fattish goat without a goat's horns," is on its way to the Bronx Zoo from Rangoon, Burma.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 27 (UPI) -- About seventy-five masked and hooded men burned crosses last night in front of a church and two homes in a suburban residential area.
LONDON, July 27 -- Britain will lend Nigeria 15,000,000 ($42,000,000) for development programs, the Colonial Office announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The absence of open criticism by Vice President Nixon's political rivals of his conduct behind the Iron Curtain undoubtedly reflects their proper sense of the predominance of the national interest in the circumstances.

Tourists and defense business have supplanted sugar and pineapples as Hawaii's chief cash crops, a leading island economist said here yesterday. But, he warned, the tourist tide will have to be augmented by permanent settlers if Hawaii's recent rapid rate of growth is to continue.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The principal contestants in the fight over legislation to raise the ceiling on interest rates of Government bonds debated the issue face to face today. Neither side yielded any ground.
SOGNE, Norway, July 27 (Reuters) -- Steven C. Rockefeller, 23-year-old son of Governor Rockefeller of New York, escorted a Norwegian girl around her village here today.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- Births during May dropped below those in May, 1958, the first time this had occurred in 1959.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Gen. Nathan F. Twining returned today to his Pentagon desk as Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. He underwent surgery May 12 for lung cancer.
DETROIT, July 27 -- The National Association of County Officials began applying pressure today to get more forceful Federal action on civil defense.

WHITE PLAINS, July 27 -- A garageman under contract to service stalled vehicles on the New York State Thruway today lost a preliminary move in Supreme Court to halt free service to motorists by Thruway emergency crews.
HAVANA, July 27 -- Premier Fidel Castro likened himself today to the late President Roosevelt as a victim of attacks by "trusts and monopolies" against social reform.
AMITYVILLE, L. I., July 27 -- The Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's annual Cruise Week championship regatta started today under ideal sailing conditions.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI) -- The United States plans to launch a "paddle-wheel" satellite early next month to test the feasibility of using the sun's energy to operate radio equipment in space probes.

NEWARK, July 27 -- The Appellate Division ruled today that Frankie Carbo could not be allowed bail. Carbo is in jail awaiting extradition to New York, where he is charged with conspiring to promote boxing without a license.
TOKYO, July (AP) -- Communist China said today "all interested countries should immediately adopt necessary measures to check the dangerous activities of the Laotian Government."

Joseph Kessel, whose novel "The Lion" was published by Knopf last month, is finishing a work of non-fiction. It is a story of Felix Kersten, a Finnish-born medical man who served as the German Gestapo leader Himmler's physician during World War II.

Premier Khrushchev has gone to great pains to make clear his displeasure at our country's observance of Captive Nations Week. His annoyance is understandable. It has long been a prime goal of his foreign policy, as it was of Stalin's, to force the West to accept the legitimacy and permanence of the Communist territorial conquests which have so radically changed the world in the last two decades.
Net assets of the 155 members of the National Association of Investment Companies as of June 30 were $14,800,000,000, George A. Mooney, executive director, announced yesterday.

THE finest service that Frederick Henry Mueller ever rendered his home town of Grand Rapids, Mich., was to be appointed Secretary of Commerce. In one swoop, the words furniture and Grand Rapids were coupled on the front pages of the nation's newspapers last week in the stories of the new Secretary's background.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 27 -- The treatment of Africans in South-West Africa was denounced today by four members of a United Nations committee.
Earnings of the Long Island Rail Road fell last month to $306,571 from $552,895 in 1958, with the drop due largely to increased operating expenses.
GRAND CANYON, Ariz., July 27 (AP) -- The body of a Roman Catholic priest missing in Grand Canyon since Saturday was found today at the base of a 200-foot cliff. Search continued for a companion.

HAVANA, July 27 -- Dr. Castro said at the news conference that United States owners of sugar land and cattle ranches, as well as other landowners in Cuba, must accept the twenty-year bonds that the Cuban Government had offered in compensation for expropriated land.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon has demonstrated in Mossow that Americans shun appeasement, Senator Karl Mundt, Republican of South Dakota, told the Senate today.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI) -- An organization of American States fact-finding committee submitted evidence today that a close associate of Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba lent aid to last month's unsuccessful invasion of Nicaragua.

In regard to an Associated Press story in The Times about former Secretary of the Interior Douglas McKay, who generously donated his eyes to our affiliated eye bank in Portland, Ore., when he died on July 22, we would like to again bring to your readers' attention the fact that eyes cannot be "willed" as stated in the release.
A look at Soviet agricultural progress, as exhibited at the Coliseum, left Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson still a fervent apostle of the American system of farming yesterday.
After an uncertain start, stocks pushed ahead yesterday and added almost $1,800,000,000 to aggregate market values on the New York Stock Exchange.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Two Representatives, a Democrat and a Republican, appealed in the House today for backing of their tougher substitute for the House Labor committee's labor reform bill.
The bond market is still headed down and the cost of money up, according to the Standard and Poor's Corporation's mid-year study of supply and demand forces at work in the capital market.
DETROIT, July 27 (UPI) -- Manager Jimmie Dykes of the Detroit Tigers expressed doubt today that a third major league would have "much of a chance."
The mothers of the thirty debutantes scheduled to be presented at the tenth annual Gotham Ball on Thanksgiving Day will meet on Oct. 8 to discuss plans for the fete.
LE PLANEY, France, July 27 (AP) -- Jumbo the mountain-climbing elephant and her saddened handlers plodded slowly out of this village tonight, their dreams of glory shattered by an oversight.

CHICAGO, July 27 -- Norman Kay of Merchantsville, N. J., and Robert Jordan of Philadelphia took a commanding lead today in the Life Masters' Pair Contest. The contest is the principal event of the American Contract Bridge League's national tournament at the Conrad Hilton Hotel here.
As expected, Fidel Castro returned to the Premiership of Cuba. He did it with his flair for drama, in what was a spectacular and impressive public demonstration.

More than 90 per cent of the therapeutic abortions performed at Mount Sinai Hospital during the last six years were illegal by the strict interpretation of the law, according to the hospital's director of obstetrics and gynecology.

LENINGRAD, July 27 (AP) -- Mrs. Richard M. Nixon described today how she and four other women sat and "didn't say a word" for close to six hours while her husband and Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev held their dinner table conference yesterday.

ALGIERS, July 27 -- French forces engaged in a major effort to wipe out the Algerian rebel stronghold in the mountains of Kabylia have yet to come to grips with the rebel main body, according to a report today on the first six days of operation.

LONDON, July 27 (AP) -- Pan American World Airlines, Inc., said tonight it was seeking a change in emergency procedures at London Airport. It charged the British press with sensational treatment of minor faults in its Boeing 707 jet-liners.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The United States' old dilemma in the struggle between colonialist and anti-colonialist forces is plaguing the State Department again this summer. It centers now on Algeria, where the French Army has started a major offensive against rebel strongholds.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI) -- The Senate adopted by voice vote tonight a measure to grant a lump sum payment of $2,000 to Navy and Marine officers forced to retire under a new program designed to avaoid promotion chaos.
AT the Forty-second Street library last spring, a Smith "girl" -- a World War II vintage -- raised her head from a book and spotted a covey of college girls in Jamaica-length shorts.

YONKERS, July 27 -- Hunch players among the several hundred riders of the Yonkers Subway Special should have collected $9 for each $2 they bet in tonight's feature at the Raceway. For the winner of the $33,525 Princess Filly Pace was Rapid Transit, under a slick drive by Hugh Bell.
OYSTER BAY, L. I., July 27 -- Plans to save home owners $1,000,000 in taxes by consolidating garbage and parking districts next year in the Town of Oyster Bay were announced today by the Town Board.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 27 -- The Tennessee Supreme Court upheld today the convictions of two officials of the Teamsters Union on charges of shooting at nonunion truck drivers near Knoxville.
Puerto Rico is being turned into a huge test market by United States manufacturers interested in distributing their goods in Latin America.

New Yorkers willing, for the most part, to travel on crowded highways are once more demonstrating that they value the attractions thirty miles from Times Square that are available at Jones Beach. The model beach resort is marking its thirtieth anniversary this summer. It is once again having a prosperous season, although inclement weather has cut into attendance at the big nighttime attraction, the Marine Stadium.

A third major baseball league was formed here yesterday. It will be known as the Continental League and so far it includes New York, Houston, Toronto, Denver and the Twin Cities area of Minneapolis-St. Paul.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 27 -- The Belgian Government objects to aspects of the plan to establish a political secretariat for the six-nation. European Community in Paris.

WHAT a girl takes to college her freshman year is important. However, what she forgets may prove to be the most essential gear of all. This has been the experience of many college freshmen, among them the eleven girls who make up Stern's College and Career Board.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 27 -- The death sentence has been provided for the first time in this nine-year-old republic. Such a sentence can be imposed on persons found guilty of "economic sabotage," the Sukarno Government decided today.
CHICAGO, July 27 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- A proposal to abolish the Housing and Home Finance Agency, which is responsible for Government housing programs, was made today by Senator Homer E. Capehart.
TRENTON, July 27 -- New Jersey legislative leaders decided today to study more thoroughly Gov. Robert B. Meyner's proposal to solve the state's rapid-transit problem.
GENEVA, July 27 -- The Western powers and the Soviet Union agreed today to sum up in writing for each other the possible bases for a limited truce in the Berlin crisis.

A Brooklyn man, identified as one of the ten most wanted men by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the New York Police Department, surrendered yesterday at the Kings County District Attorney's office on a murder charge.
Nearly fifty of the nation's leading athletes, past and present, performed at Madison Square Garden yesterday as part of the Equitable Life Assurance Society's 100th anniversary program.
LONDON, July 27 -- The stock market maintained its improvement today despite a contraction in turnover mainly ascribed to vacation influences.

Sweeping procedural changes in the city's Title I program were agreed upon yesterday at a closed session of the Board of Estimate. The meeting was attended by Robert Moses, chairman of the Committee on Slum Clearance, and Thomas J. Shanahan, vice chairman.
Park Commissioner Robert Moses was accused yesterday of failing to cooperate with members of the Bronx Board of Trade in their quest for a solution of the borough's traffic problems.
PORTLAND, Me., July 27 (AP) -- Medical specialists of thirty nations gathered here today to exchange research results about mental retardation.
"Our American Heritage," a series of six one-hour dramas based on outstanding events in United States history, will be televised next season by the National Broadcasting Company.
LIMA, Peru, July 27 -- The Government issued a decree last night authorizing an increase in the price of gasoline and other petroleum products.

The consolidated net earnings of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) for the first half were estimated yesterday by Eugene Holman, chairman, at $315,000,000, or $1.47 each on the 214,890,000 shares outstanding.
A STITCH, in time will enable girls between the ages of 10 and 21 to compete in the Singer Young Stylemaker Contest.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 27 -- No negotiations on the general problem of disarmament have taken place since September, 1957, when a subcommittee of the United Nations Disarmament Commission held its last meeting in London.
General Telephone and Electronics Corporation announced yesterday that its revenues in the first half topped a half billion dollars for the first time in any six months' period.
A missing consignment of artichokes, brought here to please the palate of a horse, threatens to become an international incident.

Robert Ussery scored victories in three straight races at Jamaica yesterday. The nation's leading jockey capped the triple aboard Start Counting, Michael G. Phipps' 4-year-old colt, in the featured seventh race.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The House of Representatives approved today United States participation in a billion-dollar bank to help the development of the twenty Latin-American republics.
LONDON, July 27 -- Britain's attitude toward the prospect of a summit conference was described by informed sources here today as still cautiously optimistic.
LENINGRAD, July 27 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon wrung a hard-won agreement from Soviet authorities today to permit Vice Admiral Hyman G. Rickover to inspect the atomic icebreaker Lenin.

Lynne L. White, chairman of the New York, Chicago and St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad, concerned about the impending merger of the neighboring Erie and the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, confirmed in a telephone interview yesterday reports that his company had been looking about for a likely merger candidate of its own.

MOSCOW, July 27 (AP) -- The television tape of the debate between Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev and Vice President Richard M. Nixon at the American National Exhibition last Friday was shown on Moscow television late tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- A bipartisan drive was started in the House of Representatives today to require a halt in future foreign aid spending unless Congress gets the information it wants on how the aid program is run.

We argued for years that the Consolidated Edison Company could do a more businesslike job of generating electricity for the transit system's subway trains than the city government. The three city plants having been sold to private ownership, Consolidated Edison takes over operation next Saturday, and the next thing to watch is whether the company can master the smoke nuisance.

ANY woman who has wanted to own real jewelry, but has given up all hope of ever acquiring it, can solve her problem at De Pinna's. Its collection of all-that-glitters-but-is-not-real is perhaps the best in the city.
LENINGRAD, July 27 -- From the moment Vice President Richard M. Nixon touched down in Leningrad today his Soviet tour took on all the aspects of a midterm election jaunt.

Norman Skinner, 33-year-old former Columbia University basketball star who has been charged with a series of car thefts, was accused yesterday of criminally receiving another car -- this time a $6,800 Cadillac that was taken last June 5 from Yonkers Raceway.
ALBANY, July 27 -- Governor Rockefeller re-established today a committee that his predecessor had set up to keep an eye on migrant labor problems in the state.
The appointment of Bernhard Scher as executive director of the Girls' Service League, Inc., 138 East Nineteenth Street, has been announced. He will begin his duties Saturday.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Pat Nixon's political trade-mark around the world might well be her high heels.
HONOLULU, July 27 -- Candidates for the right to steer Hawaii into statehood ended the most vigorous election campaign in this territory's history tonight.
Atlantic City, N. J., is planning the sale of $3,040,000 of bonds on Sept. 15 to finance municipal improvements.

The Wellington Fund reported yesterday record net assets of $954,642,688, as of June 30. These were equal to $14.45 a share on 66,078,463 shares outstanding. This compared with net assets of $709,642,000, or $12.61 a share, on 56,286,168 shares a year earlier.

Offerings of $20,000,000 of 5 1/8 per cent first mortgage pipeline bonds of the Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation, due in 1980, and 15,000 shares of the company's $5.60 cumulative preferred stock were made yesterday.
NOVOSIBIRSK, U. S. S. R., July 28 (UPI) -- Mrs. Richard M. Nixon went to a fashion show today.

AN orange cake that meets all the specifications for a good hot-weather dessert is being baked these days by William Greenberg Jr. It is available at his two shops, 817 Madison Avenue (Sixty-eighth Street) and 1181 Madison Avenue (Eighty-sixth Street).

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon's trip into Western Siberia has raised a small corner of the curtain with which Soviet authorities have concealed much of their country from foreigners.
BAY CITY, Mich., July 28 -- The 4,500-ton U. S. S. Lynde D. McCormick, a guided-missile destroyer, was launched today in the yards of the Defoe Shipbuilding Company here.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- The scheduled airlines called for authority today to raise passenger fares.

GLENS FALLS, N. Y., July 28 -- Directors of Imperial Color Chemical and Paper Corporation, manufacturer of chemical pigment colors, today declared a special dividend of 30 cents with the regular quarterly dividend of 35 cents, both payable on Oct. 1.

HONOLULU, July 28 -- A Nisei war hero, who lost an arm fighting for his native America in World War II, appeared certain tonight to have been elected to Congress to represent Hawaii, the fiftieth state.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Federal Trade Commission today bared a new set of anti-trust enforcement teeth. The teeth were provided for the F. T. C. and four other regulatory agencies in a bill signed last Thursday by President Eisenhower. They enhance the agencies' power to enforce the cease and desist orders they issue and have issued against violators of the Clayton anti-trust law.
The Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway Company reported yesterday a 17 per cent gain in operating revenues in the first half and an increase of 43 per cent in net income.

LONDON, July 28 (AP) -- Rise Stevens, American mezzo-soprano, will not sing with the San Francisco Opera Company this year because she thinks the company is paying a foreign artist more money than it is offering her. She accused the company of being unfair to American artists.

LEWISOHN STADIUM'S Beethoven Festival continued last night before an audience of 8,500. Josef Krips conducted, and the piano soloist was Gina Bachauer, making her Stadium debut in the "Emperor" Concerto. The Second and Seventh Symphonies were the other works on the program.

A theatre party at the American premiere of the British comedy "Gilt and Gingerbread" at the John Drew Theatre in East Hampton, L.I., will benefit Boys Harbor. The event will take place on the evening of Aug. 24.

The Gulf Oil Corporation reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $141,814,000 for the first half of 1959. Earnings were equivalent to $4.38 each on the 32,396,443 shares outstanding on June 30.
Commission house profit-taking and local selling lowered wool quotations yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Prices closed at or near the lows for the session.
ALBANY, July 28 -- Charles A. Schoeneck Jr., who only five months ago was in revolt against the Rockefeller Administration, will be the new Republican leader of the Assembly.

The directors of the Bulova Watch Company elected Harry B. Henshel president yesterday. John L. Weinberg, a partner in the investment banking firm of Goldman, Sachs Co., was elected a director at the annual stockholders' meeting that preceded the directors' meeting.
HAVANA, July 28 -- The Cuban revolutionary Government is formulating a new concept of what it terms representative democracy.
Copies of The New York Times for general distribution were printed at its new West Side plant, 101 West End Avenue, for the first time early yesterday.
The revision of slum clearance procedures in the city will include a diminution of the powers of Thomas J. Shanahan, vice chairman of the Committee on Slum Clearance.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- Representative Francis E. Walter introduced today a bill he said was designed to plug a loophole in the Subversive Activities Control Act.
THE imaginary tenants of the five model apartments opening Friday at Washington Square Village are up against a host of real life problems.
Please allow me to emphasize the importance of the letter published in your issue of July 24 from City Councilman Earl Brown concerning recent disturbances in Harlem.

CLEVELAND, July 28 (AP) -- Home runs by Frank Malzone and Pete Runnels powered the last-place Boston Red Sox to an 8-4 triumph that knocked Cleveland out of first place in the American League tonight.

I feel constrained to comment on the implication with which you concluded your editorial of July 23 on "The Price of Oil." Referring to the price paid for gasoline at service stations, you concluded with the statement that "consumers may yet get a break."

BEIRUT, July 28 (AP) -- Political groups on all sides denounced today the assassination of Mr. Moghabghab. This dampened fears that the attack would be exploited to cause a civil war like the one that brought United States marines here last year.

The vice chairman of the Democratic State Committee has stirred up a Manhattan controversy by siding with an insurgent in a district leadership fight. In Tammany this is regarded as a serious breach of protocol.
The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation yesterday mailed reports of favorable operating results to stockholders covering the three and six months ended on June 30.
Burlington Industries Inc., a complex of companies making up the world's largest textile enterprise, reported a sharp rise in earnings yesterday.

The month of June this summer set up a firm statistical claim to be long remembered and carefully noted for its quadruplets -- first at East Orange and then at Staten Island, three boys and one girl to a set. The famous "Gosh!" of Dr. Dafoe, repeated for each arriving Dionne quintuplet, again applies.

YONKERS, July 28 -- The S. L. and K. Stable's Elaine Rodney from Buffalo, handled by Clint Hodgins, scored a three-quarter length victory over Spring Frost in 2:07.3 in the $34,325 Blossom Filly Trot before 21,149 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
KINGSTON, Jamaica, July 28 -- The People's National party, headed by Chief Minister Norman W. Manley, was returned to power tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI) -- The Government asked today for a retrial of conspiracy charges against Richard A. Mack, a former Federal Communications Commissioner, and Thurman A. Whiteside, a Miami lawyer, at the "earliest possible date."
Youngsters -- both animal and human -- had their day in the sun at the Bronx Zoo yesterday.
IN a business executive, the capacity to organize, the talent for solving knotty problems and the ability to report a profit from operations is a much sought-after combination.
NARROWSBURG, N. Y., July 28 (AP) -- That may be romance blooming among the steep Nor wegian hills, but Governor Rockefeller says his son hasn't told him so.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 28 -- Antonio Palafox had a difficult time on his first day of play in the Southampton invitation grass court tennis tournament today at the Meadow Club.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 28 -A mercy appeal for artichokes, the favorite food of Jamin, France's famous trotter, was answered in spades today. Tomorrow morning at 8:30 about 150 pounds of the herbs will arrive by United Air Lines at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, from Monterey, Calif.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- Railroad groups contended today that enactment of a bill to aid the nation's commuters would raise new obstacles to efficient railway operation.
KANSAS CITY, July 28 (UPI) -- The Kansas City Athletics tonight ran up the major league's longest winning streak of the year, nine in a row, by defeating Washington, 6 -- 1.

There can be nothing but pleasure and satisfaction throughout the Western Hemisphere at the passage by Congress of the bill arranging for United States participation in an Inter-American Development Bank. President Eisenhower is strongly in favor of this billion-dollar institution, to which the United States will contribute $450,000,000.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Bert Bell, the commissioner of the National Football League, announced today the imminent formation of a new professional football league.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The House Ways and Means Committee voted tentatively today not to increase the Federal gasoline tax. It appeared that this would be its final decision.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI) -- George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, joined today the attack on President Eisenhower's veto of the housing bill.
The United States has become too small for "Person to Person," which will specialize next season in "visits" to the homes of famous persons in Europe and possibly other foreign areas.

The strikebound United States Steel Corporation reported yesterday that its net profits in the first half of this year had set a record of $254,948,496. This amounted to just over 10 cents on each dollar of sales.

Betty Linn, the only mare in the race, was the easy winner of the feature event at Jamaica yesterday. The six-furlong purse attracted a field of nine, and the 18,023 fans made Vincent Tufo's 5-year-old horse, Commendation, the favorite.

The proposal for a third major baseball league with New York as one of its key teams developed a little acrimony around the edges yesterday as William A. Shea replied to comments by the two major league presidents.
A voluntary code of standards is being worked out by the producers of plastic film used by dry-cleaning establishments.

MOSCOW, July 28 -- Before the repairs got under way, dust churned up from the Soviet-made concrete floors by trudging thousands swirled across everything and everyone. Anxious officials poured on water and there was mud.

The world's shipyards last year completed 885 sea-going merchant vessels aggregating 12,459,000 deadweight tons, Walter L. Green, chairman of the board of the American Bureau of Shipping, said yesterday. This surpassed a record set in 1957.
The validity of the city's 10-cent tax on taxicab rides was upheld yesterday by State Supreme Court Justice Arthur G. Klein.

The national championship sports car races at Montgomery, N.Y., on Aug. 8 and 9 are shaping up as one of the banner events of the year. As of yesterday, more than seventy cars had been entered, indicating a final list of close to 150 in the event that is under the sponsorship of the American Legion.

The steady increase in our agricultural surpluses clearly demonstrates that acreage allotment is an insufficient safeguard against our farm price support policy leading to these surpluses. Improvements in production techniques have made it possible for agricultural producers to raise on reduced acreage more than they were able to raise prior to their acreage allotments.
CHICAGO, July 28 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

PARIS, July 28 -- The second day of the Paris fashion collections for fall and winter assured longer skirts, longer suit jackets, great sleeve interest, rounder shoulders, belts, darker colors and excellent coats.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The first Atlas intercontinental ballistic missiles are expected to be installed and ready for combat use by Sept. 1, Lieut. Gen. Bernard A. Schriever told Congress today. General Schriever, who heads the Air Research and Development Command, said "this country has no cause for alarm," although the new target date is sixty days later than originally set.

Outside the Tavern-on-the-Green in Central Park yesterday morning a small rocket sailed a couple of hundred feet in the air, the nose cone separated and floated back to earth under a tiny silk parachute. In the cobblestone courtyard a boy-sized tractor pushed an artificial snow bank.

Josef Krips will conduct a Beethoven program tonight at 8:30 at Lewisohn Stadium. On the program are the Fifth Symphony, "Coriolanus" Overture and the Triple Concerto, with Leonard Bernstein, pianist; John Corigliano, violinist, and Laszlo Varga, 'cellist.

SOUTHAMPTON L.I., July 28 -- The Roman Catholic Church of the Sacred Heart of Jesus and Mary will benefit from its fourteenth annual fair to be held on the parish ground here on the evening of Aug. and the afternoon and evening of Aug. 8. Miss Dorothy McMaster is general chairman.
A new one-year agreement has been signed at Detroit by the National Maritime Union and eight Great Lakes dry cargo and tanker companies.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 28 (AP) -- Stockholders of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, meeting at a time when their plants were closed by a strike, postponed action today on a proposal designed to reduce bonus payments to top management executives.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -The Administration declared today that it was not satisfied with the bill passed by the House last month to revise the Federal pension program for war veterans with disabilities not connected with the service.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 28 -Naim Moghabghab, a former Cabinet Minister and close aide of former President Camille Chamoun, was beaten, stoned and kicked to death last night on his way to President Fuad Chehab's summer palace in Beit ed Din.

The American Can Company's inventories are sufficient to supply normal can requirements into the fourth quarter, William C. Stolk, president, disclosed in reporting record results for the quarter and six months ended on June 30.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Senate moved today to exempt radio and television news programs from the "equal time" provisions of the Federal Communications Act.

NOVOSIBIRSK, U. S. S. R., July 28 -- One paradox of the Soviet Union that this vast, untamed stretch of the country makes so clear is that it is talking about catching up with the United States before it has caught up with itself.

BRISTOL, England, July 28 -- There is no doubt about it, the company from Howard Payne College in Texas has been the big success so far of the International Festival of University Theatre being held here this week.

Kings County Judge Hyman Barshay threatened yesterday to send seventy-one building inspectors to jail if they failed to fill out financial questionnaires ordered by the District Attorney's racket bureau.

Following are statements issued about the steel-strike situation yesterday by Roger M. Blough, chairman of the board of the United States Steel Corporation, and David J. McDonald, president of the United Steelworkers of America:
MIDSUMMER is the peak time for blackberries.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 28 (UPI) -- The last-place Philadelphia Phillies won the seventh game in their last eight starts tonight, defeating the league leading San Francisco Giants, 3 -- 2.

A year of exploration into American customs and ways of living began yesterday for 106 European teen-agers. Arriving bright-eyed with expectation, they trooped off the Greek Line ship New York ready to take up their studies in 106 American homes.
NEW DELHI, July 28 -- India and Pakistan have agreed to exchange certain essential commodities.
LONDON, July 28 -- The British Government has protested to the Soviet Union "at the highest level" over Soviet broadcasts in Persian denouncing Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran and his Government.
Advertising agency men take pride in landing an account, particularly one that had earlier defected. Yesterday Cunningham Walsh, Inc., got one back after thirty-one years.
SCARSDALE, N. Y., July 28 -- There was a four-way tie at 72 for the medal in the Westchester division of the fifty-seventh annual metropolitan amateur golf championship today.

VIENNA, July 28 -- A dispute that has smoldered forty years in the mountainous South Tyrol again is poisoning relationships between Austria and Italy. If this cannot soon be pacified there is distinct possibility that violence may flare in the disputed area. And, unfortunately, negotiations have reached a stalemate.

HARRISBURG, Pa., July 28 (UPI) -- A special state legislative investigating committee reported today that negligence had contributed substantially to the disaster at Pittston, Pa., in January in which twelve men died when the swollen Susquehanna River flooded a mine.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Republicans joined with Southern Democrats today to dilute the civil rights bill being drafted in the House Judiciary Committee. The coalition, which worked earlier this year on budgetary issues and legislation to restrict the Supreme Court, was used to reject a proposal for empowering the Justice Department to seek injunctions in rights cases.

NOVOSIBIRSK, U.S.S.R., July 28 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon arrived today in this Siberian industrial city, usually closed to foreigners, and urged that the Soviet Union and the United States agree to open all their cities to each other.
COLLEGE girls may be fickle about fraternity men or their courses of study, but they are eternally true to one love -the sweater.

FALLS CHURCH, Va., July 28 -- A schoolteacher of Japanese descent has been refused a position in the public schools here because of her race. She was described by a school board member as "perhaps even a little better qualified than the others."

WASHINGTON, July 28 -Senator John L. McClellan, whose two-and-a-half-year investigation of labor and management practices has inspired many labor reform bills, gave his faintest praise today to the Elliott bill.
MOSCOW, July 28 -- The Soviet press heaped scorn and disbelief today on the American National Exhibition here.
The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steel maker, reported yesterday record profits and sales for both the second quarter and the first half of this year.

The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare warned yesterday that compulsory health insurance for the aged under Government auspices would "win out" unless Government and private groups could agree on a program to meet the need.
CHICAGO, July 28 -- The Masters' Pair Contest in the national bridge tournament here may be remembered as the tournament of slams.

Financing of the proposed Benicia-Martinez Bridge over the Carquinez Strait on the Sacramento River in California was assured yesterday by the sale of $34,000,000 of revenue bonds due In 1995 and callable in 1964.
The appointment of Louis F. Buckley as director of the New York Regional Office of the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor was announced yesterday.

TelAutograph Corporation announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement to purchase Hogan Laboratories, Inc., and its wholly-owned subsidiary, Faximile, Inc., for an undisclosed sum. Under the agreement, TelAutograph will acquire Hogan's manufacturing facilities, assets and patents while Hogan will retain ownership of existing patent licenses.
Columbia University announced yesterday that Dr. David Donald had been appointed to the Harold Vyvyan Harmsworth Chair of American History at Oxford University for the 1959-60 academic year.
MADRID, July 28 -- The Spanish Government opened the door to foreign investors today.
Four members of one family, including two children, were trapped and killed yesterday in a Brooklyn tenement fire that injured thirteen other persons.
CAIRO, July 28 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser told the Israelis again today that he would "welcome them to battle" if they tried to invade the United Arab Republic.
Ten thousand employes of the A. P. food store chain who were thrown out of work June 20 by a strike of warehouse men, will receive retroactive unemployment benefits.

CHICAGO, July 28 -- Last year's top runners led the field into the final session of the Masters' Mixed Team-of-Four Contest in the American Contract Bridge League's National Tournament here tonight. The players entered the round in the same order in which they finished in 1958.
Governor Rockefeller was reported yesterday to be desirous of getting James A. Farley to serve as the Democratic member of the new State Harness Racing Commission.

GREAT NECK, L. I. July 28 -- The first case of sabotage in a labor dispute between the Donno Company, a private garbage collection concern, and Local 813 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters occurred during the night when sugar was poured into the gasoline tanks of fifteen of the company's thirty-three trucks.
PARIS, July 28 -- Thirty-five Africans were killed today and about 100 others were injured in disturbances at Brazzaville, Congo Republic, the French news agency has reported.
PAINFUL as have been the unexpected misfortunes that have befallen the Yankees since last April, their plight certainly has proved a lifesaver for the rest of the American League.
The opening gun was fired yesterday by Mayor Wagner in an expected battle to modify the Erwin court reform bill passed this year by the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI) -- Dewey Short, Assistant Secretary of the Army, conceded today that the military services might make some improper use of servicemen. But he said it was a problem that had existed "from the Romans to today."
WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI) -- A so-called national "fair trade" bill, which cleared one Congressional hurdle handily, appeared destined today for a lingering death behind another roadblock.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 28 -- Gov. Orval E. Faubus presented today a "freedom of choice" plan under which two of Little Rock's public high schools would be integrated and the other two segregated.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The House of Representatives gave tentative approval tonight to a closely cut $3,186,000,000 foreign aid appropriation for the year ahead.

The Investors Funding Corporation of New York has purchased a seven-story building containing 149 apartments at 2100-22 Wallace Avenue, the Bronx. It is the first change of ownership of the structure since it was constructed twenty years ago.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 28 -- Indonesia ordered today a nationwide ban on the showing of "The Inn of the Sixth Happiness." The action was the result of a recent protest by the Communist Chinese Embassy here that the American film "humiliated" the Chinese people.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 28 -- A private road over a high-pressure, natural-gas pipeline is posing a problem here.
ALBANY, July 28 -- The Public Service Commission agreed today to take another look at the utility billing system that saves about $9,000,000 a year for 1,000,000 New York City apartment dwellers.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 28 -- West Coast stevedoring employers and Harry Bridges' longshoremen's union agreed here today to a three-year contract clearing the way for mechanization of the waterfront.
CHICAGO, July 28 (AP) -- A general setback took all grain futures prices down moderately today in sluggish dealings on the Board of Trade.
ROME, July 28 -- Silvio Milazzo, Communist-backed leader of the Sicilian autonomists, was re-elected as chief of the island government tonight.
VIENNA, July 28 -- The young Pole stood on a Vienna street corner and there was a look of astonishment on his face.

The announcement from the Medical School at Boston University about a new six-year medical school program points up the realization of the growing need of well-rounded physicians to cope with the changing environment. After an intensive two-year study the school has announced that as soon as funds become available a six-year medical school plan designed along the tutorial system will be instituted.

A series of hypothetical questions and answers to help persuade the public of the need for a city school bond issue is being prepared by the Board of Education. It hopes to present the material in pamphlet form.

NEW DELHI, India, July 28 -- The Burmah Shell combine of Britain, which owns and operates a refinery in Trombay near Bombay, with a capacity of 2,000,000 tons a year, has "voluntarily" surrendered a concession offered by the Indian Government.
The establishment of a new private agency to conduct labor elections of all types was announced yesterday.
Three Missourians -- a father, mother and 15-year-old daughter -- arrived in New York last Sunday.
A new use has been found for the colon, that second class citizen among punctuation marks.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 28 -- Jim Sykes, the top young skipper during Larchmont Race Week, won with his Lightning craft, Dixie, as the three-day Eastern Junior Race Week began today at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club.

Kim Stanley's next Broadway appearance is set for "Cheri," the tentative opening date of which is Oct. 8 at the Morosco. She will be co-starred with Horst Buchholz, a popular young German actor, in his American stage debut.
Operating revenues and earnings of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., and subsidiaries set new highs in the six and twelve months ended on June 30, it was reported yesterday.

LONDON, July 28 -- The undertone of the stock market as a whole remained firm today, although price changes again were irregular. Demand increased but it was still highly selective and not always sufficient to offset selling.

Pittsburgh's second and third largest banks, Peoples First National Bank and Trust Company and Fidelity Trust Company, said yesterday that their plans for consolidation had received preliminary approval from the Controller of the Currency.
The threat of a longshore tie-up of the port over a jurisdictional dispute among ship painters abated last night.

NEWARK, July 28 -- Harvey O'Connor of Little Compton, R. I., a writer, pleaded not guilty today to an indictment charging willful refusal to testify before a subcommittee of the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

ON AUG. 18, 1933, Mrs. Ruby Hart Phillips, wife of James Doyle Phillips, The New York Times correspondent in Havana, wrote in her diary: "What a relief to be able to sit in the cafes and not expect shooting to break out at any moment." Her relief was short-lived, for the shootings, murders, bombings and lootings that followed the downfall of the Machado dictatorship continued.
LONDON, July 28 -- The Government survived tonight a Labor party effort to overturn current policy toward Central Africa.
The striking mechanical employes at fifty-five new-car dealers in the metropolitan area voted yesterday to continue their strike but to limit it to twenty shops.

GENEVA, July 28 -- The Western powers at the Big Four foreign ministers' conference proposed to the Soviet Union today a five-year agreement on Berlin. The proposal included a limited role for the United Nations in supervising propaganda activities in both parts of the divided city.

A story about prison life from the point of view of the guards and administrators is told by Gladys Duffy and Blaise Whitehead Lane in "Warden's Wife." Mrs. Duffy's husband Clinton has been a warden of San Quentin Prison.
Puerto Rico borrowed $15,200,000 in the United States market yesterday to finance public improvements throughout the island commonwealth.

ROANOKE, Va., July 28 (UPI) -- The Secretary of Agriculture called on rural electric cooperatives today to "stand more on your own feet" by paying higher interest rates on money borrowed from the Government.

The new Treasury issues of 4 3/4 per cent notes stopped for breath yesterday for the first time since they made their market appearance on July 20. Profit-taking sales caused the new issue, due in August of next year, to decline 1/32 of a point to a premium bid of 100 9/32. The 4 3/4s due in May of 1964 closed at the same level, off 3/32 for the day.
The Brooklyn-bound tube of the Brookryn Battery Tunnel was closed for two hours yesterday afternoon as a result of an accident.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI) -- House investigators asked the National Association of Manufacturers today to disclose how much in dues it received from its member-companies that are among the nation's 100 top defense contractors.

Morgan, Finnegan, Durham Pine, patent lawyers, have leased two-thirds of a floor in the office building being constructed by Samuel Rudin at 80 Pine Street. They have been downtown for fifty years and will move from 30 Broad Street where they have been for the last twenty-seven years. Deane H. Stokes of Helmsley-Spear, Inc., renting agents, negotiated the Pine Street lease.

NARROWSBURG, N. Y., July 28 -- Governor Rockefeller wandered deep into the woods today greeting Boy Scouts, singing Scout songs, obeying Scout laws, making speeches and giving the impression he was gunning for a Scoutsmaster's job.
NORWALK, Conn., July 28 -A police commission action retiring a 65-year-old lieutenant last January was reversed today in a decision handed down by Judge Robert Wall of Superior Court, Bridgeport.
ULAN BATOR, Outer Mongolia. Diplomat's in Outer Mongolia believe that the exile of Vyacheslav M. Molotov to this remote diplomatic post is nearing an end.
Members of a United States trade mission to Nigeria reported yesterday that the West African country offered investment opportunities unequalled in any underdeveloped area.

DETROIT, July 28 -- The National Association of County Officials heard today that New Jersey counties were handicapped in coping with problems of urbanization and metropolitan growth by the lack of a broad-based state tax.
NEWPORT, Ky., July 28 (UPI) -- Seven prisoners, apparently using smuggled-in saws, broke out of the Newport City jail early today during a storm. All eluded police roadblocks set up in three states.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 2 to 6 points (10 to 30 cents a bale) yesterday.
The membership of the Esso Tanker Men's Union is now being polled on a plan to affiliate the organization with the giant, 60,000-member Seafarers International Union of North America.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Part of the dust raised at the American National Exhibition in Moscow seems to have settled in Washington.

OMAHA, July 28 -- Paul Benko of New York today took the lead from Anthony F. Saidy of New York in the eighth round of the United States Chess Federation open championship. Benko, playing the black pieces, defeated Saidy in fifty moves of an old Indian defense.
A few weeks from now people will return from their vacations leaving an incredible number of helpless pets behind.

The president of the Sperry-Rand Corporation, H. F. Vickers, told stockholders at the annual meeting at the Statler-Hilton Hotel yesterday that profits for the April-June quarter were more than twice as high as those of last year's period.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- President Eisenhower gave a second dinner last night for a group of Washington newsmen.
Stock market prices advanced to historic highs yesterday on an upsurge of oils, and aggregate market values on the New York Stock Exchange rose more than $1,400,000,000.
NOW this is the way to figure out the Atlantic City White Marlin Tournament, which starts today:

CHICAGO, July 28 -- Since one-run victories are a specialty of the White Sox -- some say it's the thing they do best -- it was hardly a surprise to the 43,829 fans at Comiskey Stadium tonight when Chicago beat the Yankees, 4 -- 3.
The following publications, issued recently, may be of interest to high school graduates:

MOSCOW, Wednesday, July 29 (AP) -- A Soviet crew began asphalting the crumbling concrete floor of the domed center building of the American National Exhibition early today. It was a rush job to beat the dust problem.
LOS ANGELES, July 28 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers sent the Pittsburgh Pirates to their eighth straight defeat tonight, 9 -- 4.

PEORIA, Ill., July 28 (AP) -Two Illinois department store giants -- Block Kuhl Company, Peoria, and Carson, Pirie Scott Co., Chicago -- confirmed today that they were negotiating some form of joint operation.

Bob Watson is an example of a successful golf professional who has been graduated from the college ranks. While continuing to teach the game in scholarly fashion at the Ardsley Country Club, Ardsley-on-Hudson, N. Y., Watson has won the metropolitan and Westchester open championships during the past year.
John Wayne will begin shooting in September what he intends to be "the biggest Western movie ever put on film."

A one-story taxpayer containing six stores at 91-01 to 91-11 Springfield Boulevard in Queens Village, Queens, has been sold by the Natled Realty Corporation. It has a frontage of ninety-five feet and was bought by a syndicate of investors represented by Philip Burack, a Manhattan lawyer Joseph R. Ruffino of the Kraham Realty Company, Kew Gardens brokers, negotiated the deal.
WHITING, Ind., July 28 (UPI) -- Striking oil workers made a court agreement tonight not to block the gates of the huge Standard Oil Whiting refinery with mass pickets.
Now that it's no longer called a Discomfort Index, the Weather Bureau's new system of gauging the stickiness outside has received wide and tolerant acceptance, officials of the bureau said yesterday.

The longer the city man waits between visits back to the little old town he came from, the more eye-opening will be his impressions and the stranger the once familiar scene. More shocking than change will be the landmarks still in place.

Several days ago The Times published the results of a survey which showed that Riverdale and other parts of New York City are heavily infested with the ragweed plant which will shortly bloom and distress hay fever sufferers for miles around.
LONDON, July 29 -- A British research group has isolated the virus that causes trachoma and has demonstrated it successfully on a blind volunteer.
Mayor Wagner indicated yesterday that the expected revision of Title I procedures did not mean that allegations of past misdeeds or mismanagement in the slum-clearance program would be buried.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 29 -- Broadway is hearing another siren call from the movie industry. First the actors headed West. Then came the writers, who were followed by directors. Now the word has reached the producers in the legitimate theatre.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- At his news conference today the President made statements which reveal that he thinks it increasingly necessary to guard against Congressional encroachments of the powers and prerogatives of his office. This new vigil reflects a change of attitude to some degree from the early years of his Presidency when he was accustomed to stress instead the Constitutional function of Congress.

Production of electric power rose to a four-week high of 13,577,000,000 kilowatt-hours last week from 13,415,000,000 in the preceding week, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. This compared with an output of 12,319,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the comparable period last year.
Motorists drained 1,702,000 barrels of gasoline from the nation's inventories in the week ended last Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

IT was strange to see Leonard Bernstein in front of a piano and not conducting. What is more, it was his own orchestra that was backing him up. He appeared with the Stadium Symphony last night (the Stadium Symphony is, of course, the New York Philharmonic in summer guise); along with John Corigliano and Laszlo Varga, in Beethoven's Triple Concerto, and the conductor was Josef Krips.

An analysis of current political trends purporting to demonstrate that Governor Rockefeller would make a stronger Republican Presidential candidate than Vice President Richard M. Nixon has been prepared for L. Judson Morhouse.

Mrs. Indira Gandhi, daughter of Prime Minister Nehru and president of India's dominant Congress party, has challenged the Central Government to intervene in the case of the Communist-ruled state of Kerala. It can do this within the framework of the Constitution. Its intervention would consist of a declaration that the present regime in Kerala no longer enjoys the confidence of the people and of the Central Government and must resign and permit a new election.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) --The North and South got together today to honor a couple of Yankee patriots. The House Interior Committee approved a resolution to make St. Ann's Churchyard in New York a national historic site.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The House Judiciary Committee approved two more sections of a draft civil rights bill today and rejected a third.
KINGSTON, Jamaica, July 29 -- Norman W. Manley was installed in office again today as Chief Minister of Jamaica after his election victory yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI) -- The Atomic Energy Commission opposed today a measure that would prohibit dumping radioactive wastes in the Gulf of Mexico less than 200 miles from shore or in less than 1,000 fathoms of water.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Bipartisan forces backing a new substitute labor reform bill got a lift from President Eisenhower today.

SVERDLOVSK. U. S. S. R., July 29 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon got a close look today at the new Siberia -- the Siberia of industrial communities and scientific citadels springing up in a land once famed for endless snow and eternal exile.

HAVANA, July 29 -- The revolutionary Government tonight declared tomorrow, July 30, the Day of the Martyrs. This is the date in 1957 on which Frank Pais, youthful underground leader in Oriente Province of Premier Fidel Castro's 26th of July Movement was killed in Santiago de Cuba by the forces of former President Fulgencio Batista.
OMAHA, July 29 -- A four-way tie for first place developed today in the ninth round of the open championship of the United States Chess Federation.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- President Eisenhower ordered a fresh search today for a basis of international disarmament, looking to renewed negotiations with the Soviet Union.

The new Holland-America Line terminal at West Houston Street yesterday moved another step toward completion when a $3,977,000 contract was signed for the concrete framing of the pier's superstructure.

Margaret Bourke-White, the Life magazine photographer who contracted Parkinson's disease in 1952, will be the subject of a television drama to be presented next season by the National Broadcasting Company.

A financial report by the president of Columbia University indicates that less than 40 per cent of the school's costs during the past academic year were covered by tuition fees. The balance was made up by endowments, grants and similar sources. This situation, far from being unique at Columbia, is true of most private colleges.

The General Motors Corporation, the world's largest producer of automobiles, cleared $590,000,000 in the first half of this year. That was 76.6 per cent more than the $334,000,000 earnings of the 1958 period.
A touch of the Los Angeles type of smog brushed five areas of Manhattan yesterday morning. New Yorkers suffered from smarting eyes and difficulty in breathing.

Beethoven's Ninth Symphony will be the highlight of tonight's concert at 8:30 at Lewisohn Stadium. Josef Krips will conduct, and vocal soloists will be Theresa Greene-Coleman, Nell Rankin, Rudolf Petrak and Mack Harrell.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- President Eisenhower said today that he hoped to travel after he left the White House.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended July 22:
Orders for the arrest of Frederick Emerson Peters were canceled yesterday in Post Office branches and law-enforcement offices from Maine to California.

Operating economies enabled the Westinghouse Electric Corporation to raise first-half earnings by 14 per cent and the second-quarter earnings by 15.5 per cent from the 1958 levels despite slightly lower sales.

A building containing fifty-six apartments at 5314 Sixth Avenue in the Bay Ridge area of Brooklyn has been sold by the Orway Realty Corporation to an investor. On a plot of 100 by 100 feet, it is assessed at $135,000. The sale was for cash over mortgages amounting to $140,000.

FREEHOLD, N. J., July 29 -- "What it is," explained Mushky Jackson, "is that this Freehold Raceway must be over a hundred years old, and still and all the man who owns it has it looking like a brand-new track."
DILL is the farmer's stepchild. Although it is one of the most fragrant and delicately flavored of herbs, it definitely falls into the "limited commodity" group of vegetables on the local scene.

MOSCOW, Thursday, July 30 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev has asked that the Big Four foreign ministers in Geneva agree quickly as best they can on what they can and make room at the conference table for the heads of government.

More than a fourth of the city's 844 public school buildings are obsolete and educationally substandard, Dr. John J. Theobald, Superintendent of Schools, said yesterday. He released the preliminary findings of a city-wide inventory of school facilities.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., July 29 -- A delayed spraying program coupled with an unusual wet-weather-tide cycle condition has made it a wonderful summer for mosquitoes in New Jersey.
