WASHINGTON, July 29 -- President Eisenhower hailed today the multi-racial backgrounds of Hawaii's election winners.

MINEOLA, L. I., July 29 -- Nassau County expects to spend $2,000,000 in the next year for the improvement of public parks and playgrounds and for the development of additional recreational and scenic areas.

NATIVE Hawaiian by ancestry, James Kealoha is known on the mainland, in Europe and Asia as Mayor of Hilo, where he lives. . . . But his job since 1948 has been chairman of Hawaii County on the Island of Hawaii. . . .

Between early March and mid-July world commerce receives a vital assist from an arm of the United States Coast Guard -- the International Ice Patrol. During this time the glaciers of the Arctic are exposed to the nearly direct rays of the sun, and gigantic chunks of ice break off to become one of the worst hazards to navigation -- icebergs.
CHICAGO, July 29 -- No one was hurt by the six-inning 4-4 tie the Yankees and the White Sox played at rain-soaked Comiskey Park tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Estimates by the Department of Commerce of the volume of exports in June and in the second quarter as a whole show slight improvement -- so slight that officials are not willing to call it a trend.
The ocean liner Queen Elizabeth and the freighter American Hunter collided in a dense fog in mid-channel in the Lower Bay yesterday afternoon. No one was injured.
The build-up of inventories by steel users before the steel strike was called, and the general economic upturn have contributed importantly toward heavy earnings by steel producers this year.

Santa Clara County, Calif., announced yesterday plans for the sale of $7,000,000 of serial bonds to finance county improvements. The sale will be held on Aug. 11. The bonds will come due on Sept. 1 from 1961 to 1984.

Reluctance of Congress to match highway construction needs with responsible financing had its logical sequel yesterday in the gravely unsatisfactory program voted out by the House Ways and Means Committee.
SVERDLOVSK, U. S. S. R., July 29 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon has devised, or stumbled into, the perfect way to launch a campaign for the American Presidency.

MONROE, La., July 29 (UPI) -- Gov. Earl K. Long came back to Louisiana today, ready to call a special session of the Legislature and daring his political foes to try to impeach him for erratic conduct.

LOS ANGELES, July 29 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers took first place in the National League tonight by defeating the Pittsburgh Pirates, 2 -- 0. A single by Joe Pignatano and a double by Don Zimmer drove in the runs in the eighth. It was the Pirates' ninth consecutive loss.

WINOOSKI, PARK Vt., July 29 (AP) -- The New York Giants tonight obtained George Shaw, a quarterback, from the Baltimore Colts in exchange for their No. 1 National Football League draft choice in 1960 and another high draft selection later this year.
FOR the last two months, Alfred Lowden has spent his week-ends raiding the antique shops in the northeast corner of the United States.

Directors of The Davega Stores Corporation announced yesterday the election of S. David Leibowitt and Mack Halperin as directors. The action follows the resignation of H. M. Stein, former president and treasurer and Abram Davega, former vice president.

OREN ETHELBIRT LONG, born in Kansas 70 years ago went to Hilo in 1917 as a social settlement workers, became tenth territorial governor. . . . Educated at Johnson College in Tennessee and the University of Michigan, the new Democratic Senator was Army Y. M. C. A. educational director at Fort Shafter, vice principal of McKinley High School in Honolulu and personnel officer of a sugar company. . . .

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The scheduled $50,000,000 cut in long-distance telephone rates is equivalent to about 3 per cent of long-distance telephone revenues, according to estimates of a House subcommittee and by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.
Fresh from his six-week visit to the Soviet Union, W. Averell Harriman visited the Soviet exhibition at the Coliseum yesterday.
Inmates of the City Prison (the Tombs) at 125 White Street donated 134 pints of blood to the New York Regional Red Cross blood program yesterday.
LONDON, July 29 (AP) -- The husband-manager of Rise Stevens, the opera singer, said today that she has authorized her lawyer to sue the San Francisco Opera Company for $1,000,000.
MOSCOW, July 29 -- The managers of the American National Exhibition here took their eyes off the floor for the first time this week to find other problems still besetting the show.

Directors of Victoreen Instrument Company and Tenney Engineering, Inc., the nation's oldest and largest maker of environmental test chambers, voted yesterday to merge the two companies, subject to stockholder approval.
Her Majesty's Ship Victorious, due to dock here early today, offers her crew mushrooms for breakfast, a tot of rum for each man at midday, a can of beer before supper and more coffee than tea.
SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 29 -- Chris Crawford of Piedmont, Calif., the top favored American in the field, was beaten in the Southampton invitation tennis tournament today on the Meadow Club turf.
PARIS, July 29 -- The decision to end the Geneva foreign ministers conference next week produced neither shock nor disappointment in French Government circles.
Two victors in the Hawaiian election will be the first Americans of Japanese or Chinese descent to enter the United States Congress.
ANOTHER nice swatch of real estate has fallen into the state's hands under the Fish and Wildlife Management Act. This one will add upward of 7,000 acres to controlled public hunting in New York.

BAY SHORE, L. I., July 29 -- Stan Ogilvy's flame of the Larchmont fleet made it two victories in a row today in a bid for the Corry Trophy, emblematic of the Star Class supremacy of Great South Bay. But Flame's triumph over Loring Catlin's Stampede was by only the narrowest of margins.

Commuter service on the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad suffered substantial delays yesterday morning and minor interference later in the day as a result of a mishap to a freight train at New Rochelle.

Pan American World Airways, Inc., and American-Saint Gobain Corporation, a subsidiary of Compagnie de Saint-Gobain of Paris, a glass manufacturer, and Brockton Taunton Gas Company, are offering rights to their stockholders to purchase convertible debentures.
TRAVEL posters can make a colorful addition to the city playroom, country cottage or beach house.

A six-hour day and a 51 per cent wage increase will be among the new contract demands of the International Longshoremen's Association, Patrick J. (Packy) Connolly, president of the association's Atlantic Coast District, said yesterday.
PORTLAND, Me., July 29 (AP) -- As many as 10 per cent of the mentally retarded may be that way because of inherited body chemistry conditions, a Boston researcher said here today.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- President Eisenhower made the following main points at his news conference today:

At a meeting recently in Water Mill, L. I., for volunteers aiding the blind, Mr. and Mrs. Casimir de Rham of Tuxedo Park, N. Y., and Southampton, L. I., displayed their completed Braille textbook for a blind child.
CHICAGO, July 29 (AP) -- A late rally left grain futures prices steady to strong today on the Board of Trade with rye galloping ahead as much as 4 1/4 cents a bushel.
ALBANY, July 29 (AP) -- Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz held today that fire trucks could go off to parades as long as arrangements were made for adequate protection while they were away.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- President Eisenhower said today he was "very, very hopeful" that the Senate would restore "a lot" of the funds cut from the foreign aid appropriation by the House of Representatives.

Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation reported yesterday a gain of 21 per cent in operating revenues and 12 per cent in net income for the twelve months ended June 30. Operating revenues for the June quarter rose 24 per cent and net income 11 per cent.
A member of the highest Federal court and a member of the highest New York State court agreed yesterday that better understanding between state and Federal judges had been promoted by a seminar here.
A seven-year delay in the fluoridation of the city's water has already cost families nearly $1,000,000,000 in preventable dental work, according to Dr. Percy T. Phillips.
Sir Edmund Hillary, one of the first two men to climb Mount Everest, told yesterday of his hope to lead another expedition up the world's highest mountain -- this time without oxygen masks.

CHICAGO, Thursday, July 30 -- An error was discovered early today in the scoring of the Life Masters' Pair Championship in the American Contract Bridge League's National Tournament. The team that was at first announced as the winner dropped back to third or fourth place.
LONDON, July 29 -- Prices moved up on the stock market here today, although among the industrials the day's best levels weren't always held.
NINETY-POUND weaklings are gaining in brawn and bravado at a new day camp in Westport, Conn.

M. Steinberg Son, textile exporters, sold the five-story building at 75-77 Leonard Street to the Harmacol Realty Corporation. Steinberg bought the parcel about six weeks ago. The property, 50 by 100 feet, formerly was the home of the Publix Shirt Company and then of Goldfarb Brothers, textile dealers, who will vacate it soon. The sale by Steinberg Son was negotiated by Jacob Zinovoy of the Charles F. Noyes Company and Abraham Dickstein, brokers.
Two leading ophthalmologists said here last night that the recent experiment appeared to establish that the virus causing trachoma had been isolated.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI) -- The House passed and sent to the Senate today a bill designed to keep persons convicted in state courts from abusing the right to appeal their cases to the Federal courts.
HONOLULU, July 29 -- Hawaii will enter the Union with a Republican executive department and two men of Oriental ancestry in its three-member delegation in Congress.
BRONXVILLE, N. Y., July 29 -- Jimmy Iverson, a 22-year-old Columbia graduate, gave ample warning today that he would be hard to beat over his home course, the Siwanoy Country Club.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton exchange moved 2 points off to 4 points up yesterday. A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.
The Scene of the collision between the Queen Elizabeth and the American Hunter probably could not have been conjured up better by a Hollywood producer.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI) -- A House Armed Services subcommittee urged the Army today to issue a regulation prohibiting the use of enlisted men to do "housekeeping" chores for high-ranking officers.
SUMMER is not the time for a woman to abandon a girdle, providing she needs one. If she wears one with a dress, she also might need one under slacks, shorts or bathing suit.

SHELTER ISLAND, N. Y., July 29 -- Two Larchmont Yacht Club craft -- W. B. Lockwood's Herreshoff Newport-29 sloop Dolphin, sailed by his son, John Lockwood, and Richard F. Sheehan's new Swedish-built yawl Pursuit -- won the two Cruising Club races on the American Yacht Club's twenty-eighth annual cruise today.

" Up From Liberalism," by William F. Buckley Jr., will be published by McDowell, Obolensky on Sept. 30. It is described as a "controversial attack on the manners and meaning of contemporary American liberalism." The book will have an introduction by John Dos Passos. Mr. Buckley, editor of The National Review, is the author of "God and Man at Yale" and co-author of "McCarthy and His Enemies."
Now that the six months' sales and earnings of the big three auto makers are out, the slide rule experts are busy figuring earnings ratios and comparing them with last year.

I have had the pleasure of meeting Dr. David Inglis, whose letter appeared on your editorial page of July 22, and I find him to be a most engaging person. I profess to be theoretical physicist myself, and have great respect for Dr. Inglis accomplishments in that field. It is therefore with some regret that take issue with his opinion on the NATO atomic arms agreements, as expressed in his letter.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- A Senate subcommittee was told today that retired college professors were, treated with less consideration than the Army gave its mules.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI) -- The retrial of Richard A. Mack and Thurman A. Whiteside on conspiracy charges in the award of Miami television Channel 10 was set today for Nov. 3 in Washington.
Diversification, operating efficiencies and the improvement in the economy raised sales and earnings of Textron, Inc., to record levels in the three and six months ended July 4.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- President Eisenhower called attention to the country's overall armed might today in implying that the Soviet Union could not practice blackmail diplomacy against the United States.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- Senator E. L. Bartlett has introduced two bills that would create a joint board to regulate transportation between Alaska, Hawaii and the other states.
OCEANPORT, N. J., July 29 (UPI) -- Parapet survived a foul claim today and won the $22,000 Midsummer Hurdle Handicap in a blanket finish at Monmouth Park.
A public housing project to be known as The Stephen Wise Houses will be built within the West Side urban renewal area.

The Christian Democrats have now lost the hard-fought battle to prevent their maverick, Silvio Milazzo, from becoming Chief Minister of the Sicilian Regional Government. There was national significance to this struggle. It adversely affects the main political party of Italy and its present orientation; it is a rebuff to the Vatican; it is a local triumph for the Communist and Socialist Left, and defeat for the extreme Right.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- A bill to establish national shoreline parks for recreation purposes was introduced in the Senate today.

George C. Johnson, chairman of the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn, said yesterday that it was "inconceivable" that the State Banking Board would re-impose a ceiling on dividend rates paid savings bank depositors.

GENEVA, July 29 -- The Western powers and the Soviet Union agreed today that the Big Four foreign ministers' conference, now in its ninth week, would end by next Wednesday with or without a Berlin settlement.

SVERDLOVSK, July 29 (UPI) -- While touring the big Uralmash Factory, Mr. Nixon had a lively discussion with Nikolai Stravtsev, the plant foreman, about the "Iron Curtain." The Vice President defined this as "a barrier to ideas."

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- Imports of crude oil and its products under Federal controls averaged 1,441,509 barrels a day during the allocation period that ended on June 30, the Department of Interior reported today.
A private from Pennsylvania who fought the British in Brooklyn in 1776 is posthumously putting in a good word for the ex-general who is now President of the United States.

Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., and its subsidiaries reported yesterday a sharp change in the earnings picture in the nine months ended on May 30. Profits from operations of $7,249,000 compared with a net loss of $184,000 in the 1958 period.

David W. Frankel, realty investor, has purchased the sixteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 315 East Sixty-eighth Street, northeast corner of Second Avenue, from the General Realty and Utilities Corporation.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- The Senate passed by voice vote today a bill under which the Attorney General could compel corporations to produce records to aid in investigation of civil antitrust cases.

A complex formula for the creation of the independent Republic of Cyprus was drafted last Feb. 5-11 in Zurich by Premier Konstantin Karamanlis of Turkey. Britain on Feb. 19 approved the settlement by which she would retain sovereignty over two military enclaves in the island.

Mrs. Marion Javits, wife of New York's Senator Jacob K. Javits, said yesterday that she was going to Hollywood to appear in a movie. She will play the secretary to the head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in Columbia's "Who Was That Lady?"
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- The Aero Space Industries Association was described today as a lobby paid for with taxpayers' dollars -- and ordered to produce lists of cocktail party guests.

The landlord's men sat on one side of the long table -- a lawyer, a stockholder, a builder, big confident men in short-sleeved summer shirts. A dozen tenants sat opposite -- a cab driver with his wife and child, a sculptor, an actress, housewives in print dresses.

When Mr. Mikoyan and Mr. Kozlov visited the United States, the formal receptions they received during most of their travels were of the full red-carpet type. But public reaction to the two Soviet officials varied from warm hospitality to apathy and hostility.

DETROIT, July 29 -- Spokesmen for business, labor and government told the National Association of County Official today that special inducements to attract industry were "no substitute for permanent, stable long-range economic values."

PHILADELPHIA, July 29 (AP) -- Pennsylvania's Supreme Court ordered a Bucks County justice of the peace today to stop arresting and fining persons who worked on Sunday, pending determination of the legality of his actions.
Contract negotiations covering the eight Atlantic Coast shipyards of the Bethlehem Steel Company were deadlocked yesterday over extending the present agreement.

ABOARD THE QUEEN ELIZABETH, July 29 -- It was 3:20 P. M. on the Queen Elizabeth's clocks when the crunch of the collision with the freighter American Hunter caused this mammoth ship to quiver -- but not a glass stirred on the dining salon tables.

John Huston apparently is ready to make good on his often-repeated vow to direct a film about Sigmund Freud's probings of the subconscious. He has signed to make the movie for Universal-International.

KURE, Japan, July 29 (UPI) -- United States swimmers smashed a listed world record and three meet marks tonight. They won four of seven races against Japanese stars and Australia's Mervyn Rose. It was an exhibition meet and no point scores were kept.

JERSEY CITY, July 29 -- The president of the New Jersey Joint Council of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters was indicted today by a Hudson County grand jury on two bribery charges that grew out of testimony before the Senate rackets-investigating committee three weeks ago.
ATHENS, July 29 -- Lieut. Gen. George Grivas, former guerrilla leader in Cyprus, said tonight that he "dissociated" himself from the agreements by which the island is becoming a sovereign state.

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn upheld an injunction yesterday restraining members of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers' Union from illegal picketing and from using force or violence at the Garden City, L. I., plant of Newsday.
Now that the Post Office ban has been lifted against the unexpurgated edition of "Lady Chatterley's Lover," four companies are rushing to get the D. H. Lawrence novel into paperback form.

Copper futures declined yesterday on the Commodity Exchange. The market opened about 50 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) lower on commission house liquidation and stop-loss selling. The London market was lower. Dealers were best buyers. Light commission house buying before the close limited the decline. Final prices were 75 to 95 points lower on 405 lots (50,000 pounds each).
The Ford Foundation announced yesterday a grant of $182,000 to Brigham Young University, Provo, Utah, for an experiment in treating serious juvenile delinquents without sending them away from home.

HERMAN MILLER has come "home" again and invited callers. On a recent evening, the doors of this showroom were flung open to reveal a furnished house. Miller is situated at 305 East Sixty-third Street.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- A railroad president today characterized as vicious and socialistic a bill to prevent the hasty curtailment of rail commuter service.

A thorough investigation will begin soon of what has long been regarded as a potential boon to the community -- staggered work hours for millions of persons in the city. Several superficial surveys along this line have been made, and the data gathered will be useful addenda to what is to be an all-encompassing investigation that will consider its effect on business and on the workers who would have to adjust to it.

" THE DAUGHTERS OF NECESSITY," by Peter S. Feibleman, is a haunting novel about haunted people. The scene is a river town in the low country on the river near New Orleans. Here the high-born and the high-hearted fight with silky savagery over issues that were old when Greek classical drama was young.

A plan to merge the Calaveras Cement Company of San Francisco into the Flintkote Company was announced jointly yesterday by I. J. Harvey Jr., chairman of Flintkote, and W. W. Mein Sr., chairman of Calaveras.

The recent rally in the bond market petered out yesterday. Firmness was still evident in all sections of the market, but investors generally had recovered their professional bargaining poise and dealers had lost much of their anxiety about maintaining inventories.

PARTNER in a Honolulu law firm and president of Finance Factors, Ltd., and associated financing and investment companies, Hiram Leong Fong figures his annual earnings at more than $50,000 and his personal assets at several million. . . .
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- President Eisenhower expressed anxiety today over what he viewed as an attempt by Congress to erode the executive power of the Presidency.
President Eisenhower reaffirmed yesterday his determination to keep hands off the fifteen-day-old steel strike.
Celanese Corporation of America announced yesterday plans to seek stockholders' approval for a reorganization that would dissolve a holding company affiliate with a two-companies-for-one stock deal.

Fundamental Investors, Inc., reported yesterday record net assets as of June 30 of $581,214,400, or $19.85 a share on 29,282,656 shares outstanding. This compared with $400,604,316, or $15.18 a share on 26,391,422 shares outstanding as of June 30, 1958.

It is not news to most of us to learn that the average size of New York City families has been dropping steadily since the end of the last century. But it is interesting to learn from new studies by the Department of City Planning exactly what this decrease has been and presumably what has caused it.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- Robert S. Anderson, Secretary of the Treasury, presented a gold medal today to the widow of one of the men who helped stamp but yellow fever more than fifty years ago.
The collision yesterday between the Queen Elizabeth and the American Hunter has focused attention on the question of who was in actual charge of the two vessels -- the masters or the harbor pilots.

THE National Broadcasting Company's confirmation of earlier reports that "Omnibus" faces an uncertain future is bound to be disquieting. Television has so few outlets for experimental programing that a further reduction in the scope of Robert L. Saudek's pioneer project must be regretted.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The House Ways and Means Committee recommended today that the interstate highway building program be financed with a $1,000,000,000 revenue bond issue.
CHICAGO, July 29 -- The most talked-about man of the national bridge tournament here is Robert Jordan of Philadelphia.
Wall Street thought principally of oils yesterday as prices on the New York Stock Exchange pushed ahead to historic highs despite the virtual neutrality of the rest of the list.
Kenyon Eckhardt, Inc., has distributed a new business tool that deals with a rarely mentioned peril of the generally perilous agency business -- legal problems in advertising.
BUENOS AIRES, July 28 -- A leading Peronist union leader said today that half a million workers would be on strike next month unless there was immediate relief from the rising cost of living.
SVERDLOVSK. U. S. S. R., July 29 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon ran into an intensive barrage of heckling by Siberian workers today.

The Sinclair Oil Corporation cleared $27,031,877 in the first half of this year, P. C. Spencer, chairman, reported yesterday. This is equivalent to $1.76 each on the average of 15,323,274 shares outstanding.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 29 -- Gamal Abdel Nasser's bitter attacks on Israel in speeches this week are regarded here as an effort to improve his relations with the other Arab states rather than as a serious threat of war.

NEW DELHI, India, Thursday, July 30 -- The Soviet Union has offered India a ruble credit of the equivalent of $378,000,000 to help finance India's third Five-Year plan, which will begin in April, 1961.
The Consolidated Edison Company paid a first instalment of $15,000,000 yesterday toward the purchase of the city's three rapid transit power plants.
Silver Ship earned $17,380 in winning the Gravesend Handicap at Jamaica yesterday. Pretty good for a horse that was claimed on May 23 for $10,000, but there's more to it than that.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The first impact on the diplomatic community here of Vice President Richard M. Nixon's right-and-tumble verbal encounter with Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev of the Soviet Union was shock.
Negotiations for a $3,500,000 Haifa port improvement project have been concluded by the Israeli port authority. Allalouf Co., shipping agents of Tel Aviv and Haifa, reported yesterday.
" If the bloodhounds had caught Eliza, fleeing across the ice, they merely would have licked her face," says A. Kent McClelland, secretary of the American Bloodhound Association.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 29 (AP) -- Phiadelphia's Gene Freese slammed his second straight game-winning homer today as the Phillies beat the San Francisco Giants, 3 -- 1. Don Cardwell hurled a six-hitter for the Phils, who downed San Francisco for the second game in a row.
The backlog of the Republic Aviation Corporation on June 30 was $532,000,000, according to an interim report by Mundy I. Peale, president of of the Farmingdale, L. I., concern.
YONKERS, July 29 -- In a race that produced little in thrills but lots of money to the winner, Blaze Hanover triumphed in the $113,812 Hilltop Trot before 24,736 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 29 -- Jim Sykes, one of the season's most successful young skippers, won today for the second straight time in the Eastern Junior Race Week open regatta. The Rocky Point Club sponsored the program.

A NISEI -- a native American of Japanese parents -- Daniel Ken Inouye was born in Honlulu thirty-four years ago, the son of a naturalized Japanese clerk. . . . Family name of Democratic Representative is pronounced "in-NO-way." . . . One of Hawaii's outstanding war heroes. . .
JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 29 -- Indonesia is planning to approach the United States for a $200,000,000 to $300,000,000 development loan, Foreign Minister Subandrio said today.
PARIS, July 29 -- All the couturies who showed today -- Chanel, Heim and Desses -- agree on the soft silhouette and the longer skirt for fall and winter.
A high rate of paralytic polio in the country was reported yesterday by Dr. Daniel Bergsma, associate director of medical care for the National Foundation.
One of London's busiest producers, Henry Sherek sent word yesterday that he is confronted with a schedule of five plays. One is "Edgar," in which Robert Morley will be starred with Stanley Baxter.
Many pleasure craft off the Rockaways and the Long Island shores were fog-bound yesterday and unable to return to land during the late afternoon and early evening.

GEORGE M. WEISS sat back at his desk in the Yankees' sumptuous Fifth Avenue suite. His gaze wandered out the window, twenty-nine stories above street level. No, he wasn't contemplating taking a final leap to end it all. Frankly, though, he admitted he was puzzled.

SVERDLOVSK, July 29 (AP) -- Vice President Nixon's tour of the Siberian science city Novosibirsk this morning turned out to be a disappointment. Soviet authorities allowed him to see only a single building which, they said, is to house their institute of hydrodynamics.

I have read with interest the July 27 letter of John P. McGrath, former Corporation Counsel of the City of New York, with respect to Title I. A good deal of it makes sense. The work of Robert Moses and Thomas Shanahan cannot be lightly glossed over.
LOS ANGELES, July 29 (UPI) -- The estate of the late Tyrone Power may be insolvent after all his debts are paid, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, July 29, (UPI) -- Commissioner Ford C. Frick said today organized baseball was "on the level" about helping a third major league get started. He cautioned Congress against passing restrictive laws that would hamper the newcomer to the national pastime.

MAINLAND Republicans look upon William Francis Quinn, the 40-year-old Territorial Governor of Hawaii who was elected as the new state's first Governor Tuesday, as one of the party's promising younger men.
The American Jewish Congress found yesterday that the principles of religious freedom and separation of church and state were being upheld by an overwhelming majority" of sates.

WEBSTER'S dictionary dismisses the word "brunch," after a brief definition, as merely a colloquialism. But the meal, which neatly telescopes breakfast and lunch, has become practically a week-end institution with Americans. It is especially popular with home cooks because it simplifies meal preparation so admirably.

The 93 per cent of Hawaii's registered voters who went to the polls on Tuesday reflected, in part, the necessity felt by the sugar planters eighty or ninety years ago and later by the pineapple growers for an abundance of cheap labor. To some critics in the early part of the present century it looked as though a sort of feudalism was being constructed in the beautiful Pacific archipelago.
Shipyard negotiations remained stalemated on the issue of a contract extension yesterday after more than five hours of talking.

ALBANY, July 30 -- The new Republican majority leader of the Assembly indicated today that he would present most Rockefeller Administration programs to his G. O. P. colleagues before pushing them on the floor.
YONKERS, July 30 -- Bright Knight weaved through plenty of traffic tonight to capture harness racing's richest prize, the $123,712.50 Empire Race, at Yonkers Raceway.
BRONXVILLE, N. Y., July 30 -- Joseph J. Kryla Jr. of Lee-wood, the defender, led three former champions into the quarter-final round of the Westchester amateur golf championship today.
NEW DELHI, July 50 -- Widespread opposition to the Communist government in Kerala, India's smallest and southernmost state, has led during the last two months to an intensive campaign of agitation.

PARIS, July 30 -- The death of an Algerian labor leader of "accidental" burns while in French custody in Algiers, provoked tonight a demand by the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions for an independent investigation.

HOW much a college girl spends on clothes depends on the size of her budget and the extent of her wardrobe. Taking it for granted that most prospective freshmen have certain carry-overs from their high school attire, Altman's College Board suggests that the average newcomer invest about $250 for her initial campus debut.

Northwest Bancorporation, Minneapolis, bank holding company operating seventy-six banks in seven Midwestern states, reported yesterday consolidated net operating earnings for the first half of 1959 of $6,683,097, or $1.25 a common share after preferred stock dividends. Share earnings were based on the 5,153,154 common shares outstanding.

SHANNON, Ireland, July 30 (UPI) -- A British Overseas Airways Stratocruiser carrying seventy-nine persons was forced to turn back from a flight to Boston today when the craft developed mechanical trouble.

ASIDE from being two of our most fascinating sports, both from the point of view of the spectator as well as the participant, baseball and football do not have much in common. And nowhere are they farther apart than when the pros set out to begin their preliminary exercises for the opening of another season.

The head of the house recently received by mail a "vintage chart" from Sherry, wine and spirit merchants of Madison Avenue. He naturally took great pleasure in browsing through this, for any catalogue makes good reading, and a vintage chart ranks among the very best.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- The Senate Appropriations Committee restored today $466,347,263 that the House had cut from a supplemental appropriation bill.
DEGTYARSK, U. S. S. R., July 30 -- Eight hundred feet down in a murky Urals mine, Vice President Richard M. Nixon held a vigorous talk today with two strong-armed copper miners about war and peace.

SVERDLOVSK, U. S. S. R., July 30 (UPI) -- Mrs. Richard M. Nixon tried to introduce chewing gum to the small fry of Siberia today.
Blyth Co., Inc. and Schwabacher Co. offered to the public yesterday, 150,000 common shares of Raytherm Corporation of Redwood City, Calif., a maker of wire and cable. The price was $7.50 a share.
A woman at the Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company has been rummaging around in a 135-year-old collection of junk from the company basement. She struck gold.

READING an exciting, well-written book about people and ways of life different from his own can be a delightful pastime for a child. Such reading can help to broaden a youngster's point of view and help him to understand other people better.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 30 -- Jim Sykes, a clever skipper from the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club, finished on top as the Eastern Junior Race Week open regatta ended today off the Stamford Yacht Club. A fleet of 121 competed.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 3O (AP) -- A San Francisco matron's will left $600,000 as a memorial fund to her dead dog, a dollar to her estranged husband and nothing to her son.
NEW DELHI, July 30 (Reuters) -- President Rajendra Prasad is expected to act tomorrow.

The Standard Oil Company of California had a net income of $118,152,797, or $1.87 a share, in the first half of this year, R. G. Follis, chairman, reported yesterday. This compares with $116,735,443, or $1.85 a share, in the similar period last year.

I must take exception to your comments of July 25. It is true that I suggested a so-called "economy panel" at a recent Board of Estimate meeting. It is not true that I made any charges reflecting on the integrity or competence of anyone in public service.
Her Majesty's Ship Victorious, pastel green in color and packed with electronic secrets, slipped into Pier 90 late yesterday afternoon without trouble despite a flood tide running against her.
YONKERS, July 30 -- Two brothers here who, the police said, thought they would serve justice best by taking it into their own hands faced a City Court judge today on charges of simple assault.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 30 -- The influential Turkish daily newspaper Vatan was ordered closed for a month and its chief editor, 74-year-old Ahmed Emin Yalman, sentenced to sixteen months' imprisonment and fined 4,000 Turkish lira following judgment in the special Press Court yesterday.

Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation and its subsidiary reported yesterday higher operating revenues and lower net income for three and twelve months ended on June 30. The gains in operating revenues were offset by increased operating expenses and taxes in both periods, the gas pipeline system noted.

To Alfred H. Lawrence, the money boss of Michigan's State Highway Department, electronic equipment for processing paper work is just as necessary for the building of express highways as are bulldozers, cranes and other earth-moving machinery.
Plans are being made by Paul Feigay to return to Broadway. Mr. Feigay, who was co-producer of the memorable "On the Town," was last represented here by "Me and Molly" (1948).

CHICAGO, July 30 -- The White Sox were quite nice to Casey Stengel on the Yankee manager's sixty-ninth birthday at Comiskey Park today. Before the game, they presented a 100-pound cake with suitable trimmings to Casey. Then they had him serenaded by a band, which played "happy birthday," "the old gray mare" and other tunes.
Organized labor in New York, which for the last twenty years has done its walking on the picket line, has decided the time has come to hold a Labor Day parade.
CHICAGO, July 30 (AP) -- Wheat futures showed some signs today of working out of their recent narrow price rut on the Board of Trade as all contracts scored additional small gains.

The Times editorial of July 2 characterized the proposed "G. Bill" for peacetime veterans as not being in the same category of "typical veterans grab" and of having the merit of aiming to improve the "over-all" level of education by offering inducements to formal draftees to continue their education or vocational training."

A small boy shagged a ball and returned it to the infield where two picnic teams were playing yesterday. A family group paused and looked enviously at the couples dancing to the music of a three-piece band in a wooded picnic area.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- Senator Olin D. Johnston, Democrat of South Carolina, said today that racial conditions in New York City were terrible. He blamed enforced integration.
MONTGOMERY, Ala, July 30 (UPI) -- An all-white jury tonight charged with raping a father charged with raping a white housewife and recommended the death penalty.
CANOGA PARK, Calif., July 30 (UPI) -- The police took new steps today to safeguard a 30-year-old housewive attacked for the fourth time by a man she scarred with an electric iron four years ago.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 30 (UPI) -- Willie McCovey, playing his first game in the major leagues, smashed two triples and two singles today to spark the San Francisco Giants to a 7-2 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies. The triumph ended the Giants' four-game losing streak.
A Roman Catholic priest who has been a Jesuit for sixty-seven years will celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of his ordination today at Loyola Seminary, Shrub Oak, N.Y.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., July 30 -- Suffolk County Judge Lloyd P. Dodge, appearing today before a special grand jury, refused to testify concerning his activities before taking office last year.
Directors of the Vick Chemical Company yesterday voted to split its stock on a two-for-one basis and announced their intention of raising the dividend rate, if the split is approved by shareholders.
Pan American World Airways has announced a $60,000,000 order for twelve long-range Lockheed turbo-prop cargo planes.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 30 -- Jewish congregations in the Soviet Union have declined invitations to send observers to an assembly that the World Jewish Congress will hold here beginning Sunday.
TOKYO, July 30 -- South Korea proposed to Japan today the resumption of negotiations aimed at establishing full diplomatic relations.

A State Supreme Court justice yesterday denied a motion by seventy-one building inspectors to restrain the King County's District Attorney's office from forcing them to submit financial questionnaires to a grand jury.

IF college fashions were graded, Gimbels' new collection would rate an A-plus. This store has gone all-out to round up a varied assortment of spirited but practical clothes. Sporty separates have a casual air and a well-put-together look. The man-tailored influence gains momentum, along with new shapes and lengths in jackets.

In foul weather, which to the skipper means rain, wind and low visibility, a pleasure boat needs both its compass and its windshield wiper. Paradoxically enough, these two aids have worked against each other.

BOSTON, July 30 -- Richard Cardinal Cushing, head of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston, will sponsor the New England premiere of an opera in the Cathedral of the Holy Cross here on Sept. 25. This is believed to be the first time that a member of the Roman Catholic hierarchy in North America has personally sponsored an opera in his own cathedral.
CLEVELAND, July 30 (AP) -- Minnie Minoso drove in every Cleveland run today. The last one, in the ninth inning, broke a tie and beat the Boston Red Sox, 4 -- 3.
CHICAGO, July 30 -- Play began today in three-session contests for men's pairs and women's pairs in the American Contract Bridge League's national tournament here.
Commodity futures prices closed generally irregular yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading was dull.
Philadelphia longshoremen are seeking a coastwise protective agreement that might close every Atlantic port whenever there is a minor strike in any port.
NEW DELHI, India, July 30 -- Reliable sources said today that all formalities had been completed for the Central Government to take over the government of the Communist-ruled State of Kerala.

Loans to business by the larger New York City banks declined $2,000,000 to $9,708,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York re ported yesterday. This brought the cumulative increase since mid-year to $5,000,000, and the decrease since the year-end to $211,000,000.

Volume, trading interest and prices of stocks all eased Thursday. The decline in prices was only the second in the last eight days. For the first time in that period there were more losses than gains.
MILWAUKEE, July 30 (AP) -- Warren Spahn, Milwaukee's star southpaw, chalked up the 260th victory of his career tonight as the Braves beat the Chicago Cubs, 6 -- 2.
DAKAR, Senegal, July 30 -- The Mali Federation, combining the states of Senegal and the French Sudan, is moving rapidly and irrevocably toward full independence.

It is unhappy news that Lieut. Gen. Grivas, former guerrilla leader in Cyprus, has "disassociated" himself from the agreements that will lead to an independent Republic of Cyprus. From present reports, the move seems involved with an internal political quarrel in Greece, where General Grivas now lives.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 30 -- (UPI) -- Jesse Levan, the first baseman for the Chattanooga Lookouts in the Southern Association, was thrown out of baseball for life today. He was accused of serving as a go-between for a gambler who tried and failed to fix games.

After two days of exposure to the wonders of biological research, a 10-year-old boy has donated his two most prized possessions to aid in a better understanding of the monsters that roam the deep.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 30 -- John McCleary of the Antlers Country Club, Johnstown, defeated Ronald Simkulet of the Ely Park Golf Club, Binghamton, at the twentieth hole in the New York State Golf Association's junior championship final at the Garden City Golf Club today.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- More than forty House Democrats organized today to back a labor bill favorable to unions.

LONDON, July 30 -- A Foreign Office spokesman said today that the British Government, as co-chairman of the Geneva conference of 1954, was "deeply concerned about the maintenance of peace in Laos." "The situation is under consideration", he added.
To millions of wartime American soldiers, the Brooklyn Army Terminal is a spot they quickly visited, vaguely remember and will never see again -- and not regret it.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- Senator Robert S. Kerr, Democrat of Oklahoma, suggested today a traveling exhibition of some of President Eisenhower's paintings.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- President Eisenhower proclaimed Oct. 7 today as a national day of prayer. He urged Americans to turn to God that day in thanksgiving and supplication.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Both houses passed and sent to the White House today a military construction bill giving Congress new controls over $10,000,000,000 a year in defense spending.
JERSEY CITY, July 30 -- Brutality charges against three Jersey City policemen were dismissed today after an eight-hour hearing by a special panel of three city magistrates.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Two natural adversaries on monetary matters joined today in rare agreement, declaring that the House Ways and Means Committee's bond-financing plan for the interstate highway program was "highly inflationary."
WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI) -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson took issue today with President Eisenhower's concern over legislation he thought would encroach upon his executive powers.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The cynicism of the American people toward politics and politicians was hardly diminished by what the top Democratic Congressional leaders said to the press after the visit paid them recently by Paul M. Butler, their party's National Chairman.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 30 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold left for Paris tonight for his first meeting with President Charles de Gaulee.

The nation's 518 mutual savings banks gained $202,000,000 in deposits during June, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks reported yesterday. This compared with a $120,000,000 increase in May and a $305,000,000 increase in June, 1958.
The Bethlehem Steel Corporation produced, sold and shipped more steel in the first half of this year than ever before, and achieved record high profits.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI) -- House investigators clashed with officials of the Air Force Association today over the civilian group's role in disputes on missiles and other new weapons.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Charges that the United States aid program in South Vietnam has been "an outragous scandal" were denounced today by the three top United States officials in that country. The officials called the charges either false or distorted.

Gulton Industries, Inc., Metuchen, N. J., manufacturer of ultrasonic and electronics instruments, announced yesterday that J. Paul Jordan and James G. Alexakis had been elected vice presidents. Both men will continue in their present positions and assume new executive functions.

Two men who attended the Apalachin crime conference were freed from Civil Prison yesterday by order of Supreme Court Justice Frederick Backer. He ruled that they had, whether truthfully or not answered questions of the State Investigation Commission.

Should Soviet Premier Khrushchev be invited to visit this country, and, if so, when? These questions are obviously very much in the air. That the matter should come to the forefront when Vice President Nixon is touring the Soviet Union is natural, and Premier Khrushchev has indicated that he would like to come. It is worth looking at the arguments pro and con.

LONDON, July 30 -- The seventh Parliament in the reign of Queen Elizabeth II adjourned today on an amiable exchange between the Government and the Opposition over the threatened abandonment of the Chinley-Grindleford railway line, an unprofitable line in Derbyshire.

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., July 30 -- Reichhold Chemicals, Inc., of White Plains, has purchased the Varcum Chemical Corporation, George E. Lewis, president of Varcum, announced today. The price and the effective date were not disclosed.

DALLAS, Tex., July 30 (AP) -- A Federal judge refused today to order integration of Dallas schools this fall. But he told the school board to "put your house in order" for integration, which he said would surely come.
CHICAGO, July 30 -- The new Life Masters' Pair champions, holders of the principal pair title in American contract bridge competition, are Edward Rosen and Daniel Rotman of Chicago.
The American Tobacco Company will make its long expected move this week into the menthol cigarette field with the introduction of a new product called Riviera.
The annual theatre benefit of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council will be the Oct. 19 performance of "The Gang's All Here" at the Ambassador Theatre.
HONOLULU, July 30 -- Gov-elect William F. Quinn today tentatively set Sept. 1 for the opening of the first State Legislature of Hawaii.

Max N. Hurwitz has purchased four buildings containing sixty-eight apartments and two stores at 443-45-47-49 West Thirty-seventh Street. The property, on a plot 100 by 100 feet, was sold by the Weisvord Realty Corporation, which owned it for thirty years.
A Navy request for funds to arm several cruisers with Polaris fleet ballistic missiles has been rejected by the Department of Defense.

FISHERS ISLAND, N. Y., July 30 -- Richard F. Sheehan's dark green yawl, the thirty-five foot Pursuit out of Larchmont, and Ralph E. Heinzerling's twenty-eight-foot black sloop, Firebird, from Port Washington, L. I., were repeat winners today as the twenty-eighth annual American Yacht Club Cruise fleet raced here from Shelter Island.
The Pan American World Airways jet airliner that crash-landed here July 12 had three failures of a landing-gear stabilizer within the previous few days.

L. V. Hoffman Co. were the brokers in the purchase of the blockfront on the west side of Second Avenue between Sixty-eighth and Sixty-ninth Streets by Benjamin Kaufman for improvement with apartments.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- Government investigators developed evidence today that a small oil concern had made Frank Leahy an officer in the hope that he could raise millions of dollars for its depleted treasury from wealthy acquaintances.

CINCINNATI, July 30 (AP) -- Officials of Local 100 of the Teamsters Union today obtained a temporary restraining order to prevent fifteen members of a pro-Hoffa rebel faction from entering union headquarters or interfering with operations of the local's officers.

Barroco and Tom Thumb hooked up in what might just as well have been a match race in the feature event at Jamaica yesterday. Although there were three others in the test of a mile and three-sixteenths, the 17,417 fans played Barroco and Tom Thumb heavily and sent Barroco off the odds-on favorite.

DETROIT, July 30 (AP) -- Ward's automotive reports said today that 232,232 imported cars were registered in the United States during the first five months of 1959. This compared with 128,331 in the first five months of last year.
Two Federal judges here have ordered deputy marshals into the streets around Foley Square to draft jurors to complete trial juries in the last two weeks.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI) -- The Cuban delegate walked out of a meeting of the Council of the Organization of American States tonight, declaring it was uncertain whether his country would attend the meeting of hemispheric Foreign Ministers in Santiago, Chile.
The Rockefeller Foundation said yesterday that its grants in the second quarter of 1959 amounted to $6,146,200.
Jewish groups have sent 120 books in Yiddish and Hebrew to the American exhibition in Moscow to show minority culture and freedom in the United States.
LANSING, Mich., July 30 -- John C. Mackie, Michigan State Highway Commissioner, expressed the opinion that the in-
Despite the sharp increase in poliomyelitis cases in some areas of the country, New York City appears headed for a low polio year, Health Department figures indicate.

PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 30 (Canadian Press) -- John Sonberg and Joe Caminiti, representing the New York Athletic Club, triumphed today over Ecorse, Mich., in the junior 145-pound doubles in the second day of the Royal Canadian Henley regatta. The time was 7:44.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today charged the Procter Gamble Company and its subsidiary, the Procter Gamble Distributor Company, Cincinnati, with illegal restraint of trade.
A series of mishaps delayed thousands of passengers on the IRT Lexington Avenue line and the New Haven Railroad yesterday.

RABAT, Morocco, July 30 -- The Moroccan Government opened a diplomatic, newspaper and radio offensive against France today that appeared to be linked with a monetary and political crisis developing in Morocco.

GENEVA, July 30 -- Britain attacked today the Soviet Union's demand to have its citizens outnumber foreigners by 2 to 1 in control posts in the Soviet Union for policing a ban on nuclear weapons tests.

A teen-age boy was fatally injured yesterday and a young woman suffered a broken leg when a woman driver lost control of her car and it crashed into a sidewalk at the intersection of Union Turnpike and Utopia Parkway, Hillcrest, Queens.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 30 -- Bill Casper Jr., the United States Open titleholder, and eight others deadlocked for the lead in the first round of the Professional Golfers Association championship today. They set the pace for 174 starters at the Minneapolis Golf Club with 69's.

An American edition of a book about the effects of atomic bombs Will be published Sept. 28 by Roy under the title "Formula for Death: E=MC2 (The Atom Bombs and After)." The author, Fernand Gigon, presents the case histories of some of the people who survived the atom-bomb attack on Hiroshima and Nagasaki only to be "mutated,"
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- Areas containing two-thirds of the nation's workers now have only a low or moderate rate of unemployment, the Labor Department said today.
Few bankers probably could reel off the names of the world's six largest banks in the order of size. The first few, of course, would come easily, but then surprises would be likely.
Though Len Matthews lost four of five amateur bouts to Marvin (Candy) McFarland, he is favored at 8-5 to defeat McFarland in their first professional encounter at Madison Square Garden tonight.
PORTLAND, Conn., July 30 (AP) -- Thirteen giant tanks of chemicals blew up today in a half-million-dollar fire that forced evacuation of a half-mile area.
The chairmen of two Congressional committees said yesterday that they would seek copies of the recently impounded grand jury presentment on television quiz shows.
BUFFALO, July 30 (UPI) -- Eight miles of the Niagara section of the state Thruway in and around Buffalo were opened today. Motorists will pay a 15-cent charge to drive on the strip.
Congress was called upon yesterday by Mayor Wagner to repass the National Housing Act over President Eisenhower's veto.

Now more than halfway through its sixth year, the city's Personnel Department looks back over the record it has compiled and finds reason for satisfaction. The agency has given careful supervision to the city's Career and Salary Plan, set up in 1954 to achieve an equitable classification, promotion and compensation program for city employes.
Television has discovered the Mafia, and will dramatize it in three shows next season.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- President Eisenhower has picked Walter C. Dowling, American Ambassador in Korea, as the next Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs, it was learned tonight.
