SVERDLOVSK, U. S. S. R., July 30 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon gave a strong indication today that he favored a visit by Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev to the United States and perhaps a similar visit by President Eisenhower to the Soviet Union.

VIENNA, July 30 -- A World Youth Festival seminar on atomic energy that was apparently intended to give delegates a distorted picture of the United States atomic energy programs misfired last evening.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Southerners won approval today of a broad anti-bombing provision in the pending civil rights bill. Going beyond President Eisenhower's recom mendations, the House Judiciary Committee voted to make it a Federal crime to flee across state lines to escape prosecution for bombing or setting fire to a building or a vehicle.
Governor Rockefeller announced yesterday the appointment of a ten-member committee to work out details of his program for protection against radioactive fall-out.
The leader of 500,000 striking steel workers made it plain yesterday that his union would welcome more active Federal "involvement" in efforts to settle the crippling tie-up.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 30 -- President Sukarno named 122 Indonesians, including a few Communist party leaders, today to membership on two new state bodies, the Provisional Supreme Advisory Council and the National Planning Council.

A cooked vegetable will be lighter on the purse than a salad this week-end. Local lettuce supplies are falling, resulting in a considerable price increase. Cauliflower shows the biggest price drop among vegetables; other good buys include eggplant, cabbage and squash.
ST. LOUIS, July 30 (AP) -- Federal Conciliator Eugene J. Barry said today the negotiations with one of three unions involved in an inland waterways barge line dispute had reached an impasse.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI) -- The Federal Communications Commission tightened today ground rules for candidates seeking equal time on radio and television during election campaigns.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 30 -- The movie industry, having reluctantly tasted of the forbidden fruit of television is now gorging itself on it.
The Queen Elizabeth, with a patch on her starboard bow, sailed for home yesterday twenty tons heavier and ten passengers lighter than she was Wednesday afternoon.
Alfred L. Hollender has been promoted to executive vice president at the Grey Advertising Agency, Inc. He had been vice president in charge of television.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Loadings of revenue freight last week totaled 536,430 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
PHILADELPHIA, July 30 (UPI) -- Two young California girls beat the favorites today in the Philadelphia District women's grass court tennis tournament.

The staggering task of informing the people of New York State of the conditions, budgetary and otherwise, that make necessary a liberalization of legal debt limit to carry on an adequate school construction program in New York City over the next decade has been started.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Defense Department is making a major change in the command -- and perhaps the organization -- of the costly and thus far unsuccessful project to build a nuclear-powered airplane.

The bond market moved forward again yesterday, but the gains were slight and the trading cautious. The spotlight was still on United States Government securities, most of which registered slight gains after an interval of profit-taking.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The United States Court of Appeals held today for the second time that the Communist party must register with the Government as a subversive organization dominated by the Soviet Union.
MOSCOW, July 30 (AP) -- The controversy over books removed from the shelves of the American National Exhibition because of Soviet objections was still up in the air today.

HUDSON, Wis., July 30 (AP) -- Seven cars of a Chicago and North Western Railway train carrying 209 passengers lurched off the track this afternoon as the train roared through northwestern Wisconsin's rugged hill country. No one was killed, but about 100 persons were injured.

GENEVA, July 30 -- The Big Four foreign ministers, deadlocked in the conference that is nearing an end here, tried a new tactic today. They set up a committee of ex perts to work on some of the lesser difficulties in the way of a settlement of the Berlin crisis.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Gov. Edmund G. Brown of California came here today for a round of private political chats and promptly set off speculation over his own aspirations.
SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 30 -- Antonio Palafox, champion of Mexico, was beaten in the Southampton invitation tennis tournament at the Meadow Club today by Ray Weedon of South Africa.

PERVOURALSK, U. S. S. R., July 30 -- When Vice President Richard M. Nixon was bumping along a rough, dusty road between here and Sverdlovsk this morning, he came suddenly on a small crowd gathered on a sunny hillside before a solitary stone memorial resembling a miniature Washington monument.
I note that 400 new litter baskets have just been distributed throughout the city in the hope that they will inspire the citizens not to litter our streets.
An increase in the commission rates for selling, leasing and managing property in the Bronx was announced yesterday by the committee on ethics and commissions of the Real Estate Board of the Bronx.
WESTPORT, Conn., July 30 -- A dozen housewives who set up a chair-and-table roadblock early today were dispersed when the police threatened to arrest them.

The expansion program of Food Fair Stores, Inc., in the fiscal year ended on May 2, placed the supermarket chain in tenth place among the nation's largest retailers of all types, the annual statement added in its report of record sales and earnings.
LONDON, July 30 -- Prices moved irregularly on the stock market here today as the turnover contracted before the August bank holiday next Monday.
WESTPORT, Conn., July 30 -- Motorists who argue with policemen who stop them for speeding have not had much chance here of winning the arguments lately.

Just thirteen years ago, titanium was mainly a laboratory curiosity. Since then the light-weight, hig-strength metal has begun to come into its own. More than 1,000,000 flight hours have been racked up by jet aircraft engines using components made of titanium, according to Pratt Whitney Aircraft.
The Military Sea Transportation Service announced yesterday that it had chartered the largest tanker under United States registry for her maiden cargo voyage.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The State Department denied today Premier Khrushchev's allegation that United States television networks had failed to give a full translation of his remarks during the Soviet leader's debate with Vice President Nixon last week.

The twenty-one-story Trinity Building at 111 Broadway and its companion structure, the United States Realty Building, at 115 Broadway in the adjoining block to the north have been purchased by the Sylvan Lawrence Company, realty investors and large owners of downtown Manhattan property.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., July 30 (AP) -- The Federal Correctional Institution here disclosed today that John Kasper, racial agitator, was punched in the face by a Negro prisoner Saturday.

The Rev. Dr. Eugene Carson Blake, chief administrative officer of the United Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A., has suggested that churches begin to pay some taxes on their real estate. They are now generally exempt from such taxes.

In your issue of July 23, in a column by A. M. Rosenthal, a sentence in the description of Khrushchev watching a parade in Warsaw is as follows: "The Soviet Premier, a yellow Boy Scout scarf knotted about his neck, was the honored guest * * *."
After a lapse of five weeks customers returned in large numbers at noon yesterday to 400 A. P. food stores throughout the metropolitan area.

PARIS, July 30 -- Dior left the fashion press gasping with amazement this morning. Young daytime fashions for fall and winter were in complete opposition to everything else shown by the rest of the Paris couture so far. And the evening clothes offered by this house left one with no choice but to give a fancy dress party.

WEST COVINA, Calif., July 30 (UPI) -- Dr. R. Bernard Finch, accused of killing his socially prominent wife, was bound over for Superior Court trial today by a judge who described himself as a long-time friend of the defendant and his father.
Bank tellers on Fifth Avenue and in Newark yesterday thrwarted would-be robbers who said they had threatened members of their families.
Fourteen American shipping companies yesterday offered their "know-how" on a nonprofit basis to operate a "great white fleet" on mercy missions around the world.

The agent of a tenement owned by a Harlem religious leader was refused permission yesterday to change her plea of guilty to charges of thirty-eight violations of the Multiple Dwelling Law in the building.

NEW LONDON, Conn., July 30 -- One of the great yachting fleets of the season was making up today for the annual cruise of the New York Yacht Club. Tomorrow those involved in the racing will begin working to the Eastward through squadron runs, with the first port of call Newport, thirty-seven miles away.
TERRE HAUTE, Ind., July 30 (AP) -- Eight men accused of attempting to evade the Federal excise tax on $3,000,000 worth of bet were convicted on five counts each in Federal court tonight.

Net new orders for machine tools aggregated $307,200,000 in the first half of 1959, an increase of 71 per cent over those of the 1958 period, the National Machine Tool Builders Association reported yesterday in Cleveland.

PORTLAND, Ore., July 30 (UPI) -- The Portland baseball team of the Pacific Coast League sued the major leagues for $1,800,000 today, charging that "monopolistic practices" were threatening to ruin minor league baseball.
Michigan took the first step yesterday toward financing the state's share of a five-year highway building program estimated to cost $1,250,000,000.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa accused Superintendent of Schools John J. Theobald yesterday of "putting on a crying-towel act" in an attempt to win votes for the $500,000,000 school-bond issue.

AN all-Beethoven program consisting of the First and Ninth Symphonies, played by the Stadium Symphony Orchestra under the direction of Josef Krips, was the attraction that drew 14,000 music-lovers to Lewisohn Stadium last night.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 30 -- A 70-year-old transcontinental jewel thief was accused of breaking into and entering the home of Alexander L. Guterma today and ended up in the familiar confines of a jail cell.
Better profit margins and a general improvement in efficiency of operations enabled the Babcock Wilcox Company to show record earnings of $10,185,921 in the first six months this year.

The city will start an experiment for adults who seek treatment for drug addiction without going through the courts as soon as a twenty-four-bed section at Metropolitan Hospital has been modified for the purpose.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- The Government reported today that farm assets had increased 9 per cent during 1958 to set a record high. The increase was $17,000,000,000.
SAIGON, Vietnam, July 30 -- Large-scale Communist terrorist activities are reported to have broken out in the Buddhist Kingdom of Laos.
ONE way to take advantage today's peak supply of plums is to freeze them as a puree. This can be used as a sauce for ice cream or puddings or as a base for ice cream or plum whip.
MRS. MONA ROWELL of New York, who was born and brought up in Wales, has submitted the following defense for "Welsh rarebit" rather than the more commonly used Welsh rabbit:

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The United States plans to place a small seismograph on the moon within six years to measure "moonquakes" and to answer age-old questions about the composition and the origin of the moon.
OSLO, Norway, July 31 (AP) -- Ray Norton, Warren Cawley and Bob Davis scored for the United States today in the final phase of the Yankee track meet at Bislet Stadium.
CHICAGO, July 31 (AP) -- A late rally on short covering for the weekend raised all grain futures contracts today on the Board of Trade. About half the contracts finished with gains of a cent or more.

The pilots for the Queen Elizabeth and for the American Hunter both told a Coast Guard inquiry yesterday that despite radar observations they could not avoid a collision of the two ships in dense fog off Coney Island last Wednesday afternoon.

LONDON, July 31 -- Business was restricted on the stock exchange here today before the long August bank holiday weekend. But there was still steady selective buying of top class industrials. Changes as a whole were usually confined to a few pence and were too mixed to show any decided trend.

New securities offered publicly here in July declined from the level of a year before, and, in the case of stock emissions, were the smallest for any month since November. Bond offerings, however, were larger than in June, principally because of bigger home loans.
Eastview, an institution looking in several difficult directions, opened its modern glass doors this week to three types of problem patients -- the alcoholic, the addictive and the psychiatric.
PHILADELPHIA, July 31 -- Mayor Richardson Dilworth told port employers and union representatives today that their waterfront disputes must be ended for the public's sake.
MOSCOW, July 31 -- A survey of the reporters traveling in the Soviet Union with Vice President Richard M. Nixon indicated almost unanimous agreement today on these points:

YONKERS, July 31 -- Adios Butler, winner of the William H. Cane pace, first leg of the triple crown, repeated that victory tonight in the $25,000 Encore, closing-night feature for 3-year-olds at Yonkers Raceway. Clint Hodgins drove Adios Butler one mile in 2:02 1/5 before 30,696 fans.
Little happened in the stock market yesterday. Volume fell to the lowest level since June 19 -- 2,271,810 shares against 3,240,000 on Thursday -- and prices barely changed.
CHICAGO, July 31 (AP) -- Hospitals operated in the red last year as to patient charges, the American Hospital Association said today.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- Managed Funds, Inc., a St. Louis mutual fund, is under orders to revise its registration statement before it sells any more stock.

WASHINGTON July 31 -- (UPI) -- Sponsors of a Senate resolution for establishment of a "white fleet" of United States mercy ships today accepted an offer from American steamship lines to lend their "know-how" to the project.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Following is the text of a statement to President Eisenhower today by members of the executive committee of the National Governors Conference who recently returned from the Soviet Union:
LOS ANGELES, July 31 (AP) -- Don Drysdale scored his fourteenth victory and struck out fourteen batters tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 5 -- 4.

Incorporated Investors, Inc., reported yesterday that net assets on June 30 were $326,636,267, against $238,122,157 a year earlier. Share net asset value increased to $9.88 on 33,050,904 shares outstanding from $7.75 a share on 31,529,692 shares outstanding on June 30, 1958.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- An international assembly of teacher representatives convened here today. It will try to prove that Rudyard Kipling was wrong when he wrote, "Oh, East is East, and West is West, and never the twain shall meet."
A Lutheran church that began in a New Jersey log cabin in 1714 will mark its 245th anniversary at a festival service tomorrow at 10 A. M.

Ground will be broken Wednesday at noon for the Zeckendorf Hotel, which will occupy a site running through the block from West Fifty-first to Fifty-second Streets, east of the Avenue of the Americas Sixth Avenue).

GREENWICH, Conn., July 31 -- Harold H. Channell, 70-year-old jewel thief, had committed a jewel robbery here yesterday before he was seized for entering the home of Alexander L. Guterma, the police charged tonight.

Sentimentalists, souvenir seekers and students of horse-racing form will be out in great number at Jamaica today. The famous track in Southern Queens will be no more after the running of the claiming sprint that makes up the ninth race on the card.
Committees representing the New York and New Jersey Legislatures began negotiations yesterday to resolve the complaint of nonresidents that the New York income-tax law discriminates against them.
ROME, July 31 -- Naples is without water and has become a matter of national concern. Italians are asking again what is wrong in southern Italy.

Walter Thabit, in a letter published July 20, criticizes the plan for constructing fall-out shelters submitted to Governor Rockefeller by his Special Task Force on Protection From Radioactive Fall-Out.
HONOLULU, July 31 -- Admiral Herbert G. Hopwood announced today that two more modern supercarriers would be assigned to the Pacific Fleet.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 31 -- Little Jerry Barber's 65 for 134 broke a scoring jam and sent him into a two-stroke lead in the Professional Golfers Association championship today.

NEWPORT, R. I., July 31 -- The New York Yacht Club's annual elegant racing cruise began today with Henry Mercer's Weatherly giving another demonstration that she was master of Chandler Hovey's Easterner.
ATLANTIC CITY, July 31 (AP) -- Three new professional football leagues are in the works, Commissioner Bert Bell of the National Football League said today.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Government officials told a Senate subcommittee today that most of the charges of waste are corruption in the aid program in South Vietnam were based on unfounded rumor.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) -- The House Elections subcommittee will hold a closed meeting Tuesday afternoon to begin examining ballots cast last fall in the disputed election of Representative Dale Alford, Democrat of Arkansas.

LONDON, July 31 -- British concern about the reported attacks in Laos seems likely to produce a Geneva meeting on the matter between Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- The United States Chamber of Commerce said today that the Securities and Exchange Commission was trying to impose by edict a requirement for advance notice of business mergers which Congress so far has refused to approve.

The Very Rev. John Baptist Janssens, Superior General of the Society of Jesus, announced yesterday the appointment of the Very Rev. John M. Daley as new Provincial Superior of the Maryland Province of the Jesuit Order.
BOSTON, July 30 -- The Cambridge Drama Festival production of "Macbeth," which opened last night at the Arts Center Theatre in near-by Brighton, is more successful as spectacle than as tragedy.

INDIAN RIVER, Mich., July 31 (AP) -- A giant crucifix of bronze and wood, weighing eighteen tons and rising seventy-five feet into the sky, was erected today on a hill overlooking a shrine a mile south of here.

MOSCOW, July 30 -- Comparison shoppers, habitues of Moscow's G. U. M. department store, have descended on the American National Exhibition here. Their main question about the myriad of goods on display, from sponges to spongecakes, is: "How much does it cost?"

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat from Tennessee, warned baseball executives today that their efforts to help or hinder the proposed third major league would be watched closely by Congress.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) -- The armed forces joined today to give a giant farewell salute to two retiring combat leaders -- Gen. O. P. Weyland and Gen Earle E. Partridge of the Air Force.
NAGOYA, Japan, July 31 (AP) -- American swimmers, for the first time on their tour, lost the 100-meter free-style tonight in a United States-Japan meet.
After more than a year's delay, city officials have given approval to a group of architects to begin drafting final plans for rebuilding Bellevue Hospital.

PARIS, July 31 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold of the United Nations met French Government leaders today for a "tour of the diplomatic horizon" that almost certainly focused sharply on France's war with the Algerian rebels.

SYOSSET, L. I., July 31 -- The Nassau County police are investigating the possible sabotage of twelve new cars that were splattered with paint remover at a showroom picketed by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters here.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- A Senate investigation into the commuter problem ended today amid heated exchanges between Senators Clifford P. Case, Republican of New Jersey, and George A. Smathers, Democrat of Florida.

LONDON, July 31 -- Jungle fighting between Laotian Army troops and Communist rebel bands has spread to a second province bordering on Communist North Vietnam, according to reports received here today.

Separate two-year wage agreements traveling 700 city ferry, fireboat and sanitation-scow employes have been reached between the city and Local 333 of the United Marine Division, National Maritime Union.

No one would disagree with the statement in your editorial of July 25 that "* * * there should be some stimulus for tree planting both to beautify our streets and make them more livable." The only question is whether it can be accomplished on a voluntary basis.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Dr. Bernard Maisel of the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in New York City has developed a new technique for surgery on the heart. It was disclosed in a patent he received this week for a special operating table. In cases requiring an increase in the blood supply to the heart muscle, as in angina pectoris, it is desirable to operate on the rear of the heart.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- A seven-man study team from India reported today that it had found American cotton spinning mills closed to foreign visitors. The cotton manufacturers said this was not so.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The United States Army was under orders tonight to restore sobriety in a tight little Alaskan island fifty miles off the Russian coast in the Bering Sea.

SVERDLOVSK, U. S. S. R., July 31 -- Forty-one years ago this month, on a sultry day, a jittery commisar gave orders that ended the life of Nicholas II, Czar of all the Russias, and his family, in what was then the provincial town of Ekaterinburg.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 1 to 8 points (5 to 40 cents a bale) yesterday.
A musical scholarship to be awarded to a high school senior was announced yesterday by the Mayor's Committee on Scholastic Achievement.
An article in the current issue of Science holds that the United States has a far greater lead in industrial production over the Soviet Union than American economists have hitherto believed.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- The Tariff Commission yesterday recommended to President Eisenhower that quota restrictions be placed on imports of rye, rye flour, and rye meal.

Benefiting from the upturn in the automotive and appliance fields, and the economies and efficiencies effected in manufacturing operations, the Borg-Warner Corporation's half-year sales and earnings exceeded those of any similar period in its history.

A resumption of negotiations between Japan and the Republic of Korea looking to the establishment of full diplomatic relations, which has just been announced in Tokyo, represents a victory for moderation and patience. In this case the major concession has been made by the free Koreans, who were deeply affronted by Japan's declared purpose to repatriate Koreans to the Communist North without the consent of the free Republic.

The property at 44 Morton Street, between Bedford and Hudson Streets in Greenwich Village, has been sold by Warner M. Wilcox to Robert Carrington. It consists of a three-story building at the front of the plot and two three-story dwellings in the back.
The 4 3/4 per cent coupon carried by the Treasury's newest issues of notes is still the bond market's most popular offering to investors.

GRAND CANYON, Ariz., July 31 (UPI) -- A 15-year old boy was rescued from the depths of the Grand Canyon today by a daring Army helicopter crew after seven days of exposure to 120-degree heat. He was reported in "remarkably good" condition.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- A railroad spokesman told Congress today that if the railroads were given a fair chance they not only would provide for their own future but would give the United States its greatest defense bargain.

MADRID, July 31 (Reuters) -- Luis Miguel Gonzales, known as Dominguin, hero of the bull ring, was reported tonight resting fairly comfortably after suffering a deep horn thrust in the abdomen in a contest at Valencia yesterday.
HONG KONG, July 31 -- More evidence of the easing of restrictions in Red China's commune system emerged today in an interview with a merchant just back from a visit to his former home.
OCEANPORT, N. J., July 31 (AP) -- Jim Hobales climbed off a mount in the hurdles race and returned on the flat in the next event at Monmouth Park today to win aboard New Order at odds of 30-1.
MADRID, July 30 -- There are 888 male "political prisoners" in Spanish jails, according to the Ministry of Justice here.
SVERDLOSVK, U. S. S. R., July 31 (AP) -- Mrs. Richard M. Nixon did a polka today with a little Russian girl amid a circle of dancers at a Young Pioneer summer camp in the pine woods.

A new series of reprints of "hard-to-get" children's classics will be published in September by a new concern, Looking Glass Library, 475 Madison Avenue, New York 22. Priced at $1.50, each volume will have the original unabridged text and fifteen to 300 black-and-white line drawings within the text.
Len Matthews, Philadelphia lightweight, scored a unanimous decision over Candy McFarland in the ten-round main event at Madison Square Garden last night.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 31 -- Twenty years ago I used to meet in a shabby Balkan cafe with a group of young Yugoslavs discussing what they intended to do with their future and their country. All were either Communists or fellow-travelers. As such they played desperate hide-and-seek with the police of the monarchy which then ruled.

BOSTON, July 31 (AP) -- The Boston and Albany Railroad today petitioned the Public Utilities Department for authority to discontinue all commuter and local passenger service on its main line between Boston and Framingham, Worcester and Springfield.
NEW DELHI, India, July 31 -- The Communist government of the state of Kerala was turned out of office today.

A group of policemen won a temporary injunction yesterday barring Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy from assigning policemen to higher positions without changing their ranks. However, it was disclosed that acting ranks were abolished two months ago.
RABAT, Morocco, July 31 -- Premier Abdallah Ibrahim charged today that the French Army had "assassinated" Aissat Idir, an imprisoned Algerian labor union leader.

CHICAGO, July 31 -- John Simon of St. Louis is one of the pioneers of contract bridge, especially in expert rubber-bridge games. As early as 1929 or 1930 bridge experts making coast-to-coast trips made it a point to stop off in St. Louis for a session or two in "Jack Simon's game."
SEATTLE, July 31 (UPI) -- A Superior Court judge ruled today that a white couple could not be compelled to sell their home to Negroes.

CHICAGO, July 31 -- Easley Blackwood, the inventor of the most popular slam bidding method, and Mrs. Helen Sobel, the world's top-ranking women's player, were the leaders in the Men's and Women's Pair Contests after the second session of play today in the American Contract Bridge League's national tournament here.
The last obstacle to the transfer of the city's three rapid transit power plants to the Consolidated Edison Company was removed yesterday.
After an hour-and-a-half tour of the Soviet exhibition at the Coliseum yesterday, Secretary of Defense Neil H. McElroy said he had seen nothing to cause him military concern.

Supplies of industrial steel products held in warehouses are declining at the rate of 150,000 to 200,000 tons a week. The tightest items are flat rolled products, with activity heaviest in steel shapes used by the construction industry.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- A Senate-House conference committee completed today a $39,228,239,000 defense appropriations bill.
IT has been said that we know more about the surface of the moon that faces us than we do of the crust of our own planet. The reason is that so much of the earth lies hidden beneath the oceans.

Rosensohn Enterprises, Inc., which is planning the second Ingemar Johansson-Floyd Patterson world title fight, was expanded yesterday by the election of Irving Kahn, president of TelePrompTer Corporation, as a third director.
A House committee moved in court here yesterday for permission to inspect the minutes of the grand jury that had investigated charges that television quiz shows had been rigged.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) -- The Pennsylvania Railroad sought permission from the Interstate Commerce Commission today to increase commuter fares about 15 per cent between New York City and points in the New Jersey shore area.

PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 31 (Canadian Press) -- St. Catharines Rowing Club today took the feature junior eights event in the third day's program of the Royal Canadian Henley regatta. St. Catharines defeated a Vancouver eight in 6:41.1.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 31 (AP) -- San Francisco's sensational rookie, Willie McCovey, drove in the winning run tonight as the Giants ripped the Pittsburgh Pirates, 4 -- 3, and retained first place in the National League.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- Northern Natural Gas Company, Omaha, Neb., received authority today to expand its pipeline system to provide new service to 342 communities in six Midwestern states.
WESTBURY, L. I., July 31 -- Harness racing's most far reaching event since the sport emerged from the county fair almost two decades ago is all set for Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow night.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Nine Governors urged President Eisenhower today to invite Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev to the United States and to visit the Soviet Union himself. They did not suggest who should make the first visit.

In your July 23 editorial on "Mr. Rockefeller and Taxes," after stating that no one has been badly hurt by the Rockefeller tax program, you say "everybody would have been hurt if the state administration had continued down the seductive garden path of multi-million-dollar bond-issue borrowing, exhaustion of reserves and deficit-spending."
Two men who have contributed greatly to the nation and to the Air Force -- the one in uniform, the other in civilian clothes -- leave office this week.

NELSON, B. C., July 31 (Canadian Press) -- Shawled mothers sat in silence today as a magistrate announced the release of seventy-seven Freedomite children who had been in provincial government custody -- some for five years.
A contract was signed yesterday between the Publishers Association of New York City and the International Association of Machinists.
The crippled Norwegian freighter Francisville arrived here early yesterday morning under tow of two Moran Towing and Transportation Company tugs.

KANSAS CITY, July 31 -- Baseball's longest winning streak of the season and the American League's longest since 1954 ended tonight. Whatever it was that had helped the amazing Athletics win eleven straight and fifteen of seventeen, they ran out of it when the Yankees dropped in at Municipal Stadium.
An explanation of the recent accident to a Boeing 707 jet airliner here was put forward by the manufacturer yesterday together with a series of corrective measures.
A paperback publisher agreed in court yesterday to label "abridged" all newly printed expurgated copies of "Lady Chatterley's Lover" so there would be no confusion with the unexpurgated editions.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 31 -- Twice escaping elimination by a stroke in the second set, Ian Vermaak of South Africa again averted the seemingly inevitable in pulling out from 1 -- 4 in the third and defeated Ronald Holmberg of Brooklyn today. The scores of the quarterfinal match in the Southampton invitation tennis tournament at the Meadow Club were 2 -- 6, 14 -- 12, 6 -- 4.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The Malayan rubber industry is expanding its research to increase production and cut costs, a spokesman said today.

Consolidated Freightways, Inc., one of the nation's largest common carrier trucking systems, announced yesterday that it had received Interstate Commerce Commission approval of its purchase of three separate trucking lines and the operating rights of a fourth carrier.
The Women's City Club asked Mayor Wagner yesterday for "a prompt investigation and correction of abuses" in slum-clearance administration.

ROME, July 31 -- In the second encyclical letter of his reign, Pope John XXIII has urged Roman Catholic priests to pattern their lives and pastoral activities on those of the French curate-saint of Ars, St. Jean-Marie-Baptiste Vianney.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- Chief Justice and Mrs. Earl Warren will stop off in Moscow during a visit to Europe this summer.

A "naked owner" of a stock is not an investor who has lost his shirt in the stock market. He is someone who owns a stock under a trust agreement, but doesn't receive the dividends. These go to another individual, called, of all things, a "usufructuary," defined literally as one who "enjoys the fruit" of a property.
" CROSSING the river, they buried in its bank a bottle which contained a paper claiming the region for their King, George I.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce reported today that sales of merchant wholesalers in the first six months of this year were $61,900,000,000, a rise of 14 per cent above those of the first half of 1958.

Continued hot weather tells on motorists as well as others, and driving habits of their fellow automobilists that are mere annoyances much of the time become, under the continued sweltering rays of the sun, genuine irritations. Take horn-honking, for example. The horn-honker not only is guilty of bad manners but also adds needlessly to the stress and strain of traffic.

The State Banking Department is leaning toward authorization of higher dividend rates on long-term savings as a solution of the dividend rate controversy engaging Brooklyn and Manhattan savings banks.

The Railway Express Agency, which last month formulated a reorganization of its standard operating agreement with the nation's railroads, yesterday concluded a new five-year agreement with the regularly-scheduled airlines of the country.
Three landlords were charged yesterday with filing fraudulent applications for rent increases, according to District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.

BOSTON, July 31 -- The Pilot, official weekly newspaper of the Boston Roman Catholic Archdiocese, today countered Methodist questions for Catholic Presidential aspirants with questions for Methodist seeking public office.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- The House Labor Committee formally reported to the House today a labor controls bill shunned by a majority of the committee.

MOSCOW, July 31 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon returned here today by Soviet jet airliner from his Siberian trip, which he ended with a visit to an atomic power station under construction in the Urals.

RABAT, Morocco, July 31 -- Crown Prince Moulay Has-disturbed country today from Paris. A few hours later, Premier Abdallah Ibrahim, with whom the Crown Prince is reported to be in disagreement, left for a conference in Liberia.
The threat that the striking steel union would extend its walkout to giant copper mines and refineries in Arizona and Utah was temporarily averted yesterday.
CHICAGO, July 31 -- President Lincoln was not called Honest Abe for nothing.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Average wholesale prices in primary markets fell 1 per cent to 119.2 per cent of their 1947-1949 level during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

ONE never knows what will turn up in the stores these days. For example, when looking for a mousetrap, the most purposeful homemaker has been known to be sidetracked by something as far afield as a moosehead.

SOEGNE, Norway, July 31 (UPI) -- The minister in this small Norwegian community said today that "everything is pointing to a happy union" between one of his flock, Anne Marie Rasmussen, and Steven Rockefeller, son of the Governor of New York.

PARIS, July 31 -- The Paris fashion showings for fall and winter came to an exciting conclusion today with the news that Givenchy had shown the best collection of his career. In some opinions, the pupil even had surpassed his master, Balenciaga.
Work will continue in the Bethlehem Steel Company's eight Atlantic Coast shipyards despite the expiration of its work contract with the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America.

GENEVA, July 31 -- With time running out, the deadlock in the foreign ministers' conference hardened today. There was no progress in a two-and-a-half-hour "working tea" of the Big Four ministers at the Soviet villa. And the experts' committee set up yesterday ended a session of an hour and three-quarters without scheduling another meeting.
